Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED] 
Age: 58 
Sex: Male
Date of Admission: [REDACTED] 
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED] 

Reason for Admission: COVID-19 infection with ocular manifestations

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted for acute loss of vision in both eyes to 20/400 with no relative afferent pupillary defect present and fundus photography in the ED with non-mydriatic camera being normal. Additional laboratory assessments that were found to be abnormal included elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (40), C-reactive protein (33), and D dimers (2000). Chest CT revealed ground glass changes consistent with COVID-19; pulse ox revealed diminished saturation of 88%. A non-contrast head CT was normal, but an MRI of the brain and orbits revealed a large occipital stroke. The patient was administered with anticoagulation, Decadron, and supplemental oxygen. Access to monoclonal antibody was denied. The inflammatory markers and D dimer normalized, and pulmonary function improved. However, the visual loss was permanent. 

Diagnosis at discharge: COVID-19 infection with ocular manifestations and large occipital stroke.

Discharge Instructions:
1. Continue the medications prescribed during hospitalization.
2. Monitor oxygen saturation level, and if it drops to 90% or less, contact the primary care physician or emergency services.
3. Self-quarantine for at least 14 days after discharge.
4. Schedule a follow-up visit with the primary care physician for a detailed evaluation to determine any further treatment.

Follow-up: Schedule a follow-up visit with the primary care physician for a detailed evaluation to determine any further treatment. 

Summary: The patient was admitted due to ocular manifestations and acute loss of vision in both eyes, which were found to be the result of a large occipital stroke and COVID-19 infection. Although the patient's pulmonary function improved, the visual loss was permanent. The patient was discharged and given instructions on how to continue treatment and self-quarantine. A follow-up visit with the primary care physician was scheduled to assess the need for further treatment.

Patient: 53-year-old male with a history of alcohol-related liver cirrhosis, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus type 2.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to San Camillo Forlanini Hospital for a laparoscopic anatomical segment 8 resection. The surgery was successful and the patient was placed on a fast-track protocol with early feeding and mobilization. The patient recovered as expected and was discharged home on postoperative day 4.

Diagnostic Assessment:
A 4.3cm lesion was detected through a triphasic CT scan and was classified as hepatocellular carcinoma according to the LIRADS classification. The diagnosis was confirmed during the surgical procedure. 

Treatment:
The patient underwent laparoscopic anatomical segment 8 resection following confirmation of tumor location and absence of major vessel involvement. The patient was monitored postoperatively and discharged in stable condition with normal liver function.

Follow-up Care:
The patient returned for follow-up appointments on a regular basis to monitor his condition. As of the most recent visit, which was more than 1 year post-surgery, the patient was healthy and showed no signs of recurrence. 

Summary:
This 53-year-old male patient with a history of alcohol-related liver cirrhosis, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus type 2 underwent successful laparoscopic anatomical segment 8 resection surgery at San Camillo Forlanini Hospital due to the presence of a 4.3cm lesion in the liver, which was confirmed to be hepatocellular carcinoma. The resection was successful, and the patient was discharged in stable condition and returned for regular follow-up appointments. As of the latest appointment, which was more than 1 year post-surgery, the patient showed no signs of recurrence.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Gender: Female
Age: 60

History and Reason for Admission:
The patient was referred to our clinic with deterioration of the visual field. She had undergone treatment for NTG earlier and presented with normal IOP levels. Family history revealed that both parents had undergone treatment for glaucoma.

Hospital Course:
On initial examination, both optic discs appeared pale but not excavated, and did not match advanced visual fields. Drops were discontinued, and the patient was advised for follow-up. On the follow-up visit, there was further deterioration in the visual fields, and an MR scan revealed a meningioma, which was removed successfully by bilateral craniotomy. The patient showed significant improvement and complete resolution of visual fields in the right eye but had significant loss remaining in the left eye.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Rapid bilateral vision loss with regard to the BCVA and VF due to olfactory groove meningioma.

Discharge Plan:
The patient will be discharged with a recommendation for continued follow-up with the treating physician and appropriate specialists to monitor and manage any signs of vision loss, particularly in the left eye.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name], DOB: [Date of Birth], Age: 56 years
Gender: Male

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the clinic with high intraocular pressure (IOP) ranging from 30-48 mmHg, and a family history of glaucoma. He underwent trabeculectomy in both eyes; however, despite low IOP readings, vision deterioration was observed over the course of three years. An MR scan was performed, which revealed an intracranial meningioma. Bilateral craniotomy was performed, and the meningioma was resected. Post-surgery, the patient's right eye is blind, and the left eye has preserved some useful visual field with a best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) of approximately 0.1. The patient's condition has been stable for the past 2 years.

Diagnosis:
True high tension primary glaucoma with a family history and intracranial meningioma.

Treatment:
Trabeculectomy in both eyes and bilateral craniotomy to resect the meningioma.

Prognosis:
The patient’s right eye is blind, and the left eye has preserved some useful visual field with a BCVA of approximately 0.1. The patient's condition has remained stable for the past 2 years.

Recommendations:
The patient should continue to receive regular follow-up care to monitor the stability of his visual field and prevent any further deterioration. It is recommended that he undergo regular ophthalmological checkups to assess the pressure and status of his left eye.

Follow-up Visit:
A follow-up appointment with an ophthalmologist should be scheduled promptly to ensure continuous monitoring of visual field stability and intraocular pressure.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 82
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Reason for Admission:
The patient presented to our clinic for consultation and left ptosis surgery and was previously treated elsewhere for NTG.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient reported normal IOP (14 mmHg) and BCVA of 1.0 and 1.0, right and left eye, respectively. On ophthalmoscopy, both eyes showed glaucomatous changes, but the left eye was more advanced than the right. In addition, only the left eye exhibited VF changes typical for glaucoma that corresponded ideally with a retinal nerve fiber layer thickness defect in OCT examinations.

Further examination revealed a 4 x 4mm pituitary microadenoma that was found to be contacting the chiasm. While the cause of this condition is unclear, the patient’s condition remained stable throughout his observation with no change in visual field or tumor size.

Diagnosis:
The patient presented with unilateral stable glaucoma with coexisting pituitary adenoma.

Discharge Plan:
The patient was given a detailed follow-up plan upon discharge and scheduled for routine follow-up appointments with his ophthalmologist and endocrinologist.

Instructions:
The patient was advised to monitor any changes in vision and immediately report any symptoms to his ophthalmologist. He was also asked to continue monitoring his pituitary microadenoma under the supervision of his endocrinologist.

Referrals/Consultations:
The patient was referred to an endocrinologist for the management of his pituitary microadenoma.

Procedures/Treatments:
The patient underwent left ptosis surgery.

Condition Upon Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition with no complications.

Discharge Summary for 65-Year-Old Female

Reason for admission:
Left eye pallor with consistent VF loss and narrow angle in gonioscopy.

Hospital course:
The patient was referred to our clinic for examination. The initial examination showed BCVA of 1.0 and 0.5+ with correction +4.5 DSph for the right and left eye, respectively. IOP was 15 and 16 mmHg for the right and left eye, respectively. After the examination, MRI scan was conducted which indicated meningioma involving the optic nerve canal which was surgically removed through left craniotomy. The pathology report confirmed the diagnosis of psammomatous meningioma.

Discharge plan:
The patient is stable and being regularly monitored for any signs of relapse. The BCVA two years after surgery remains the same with a correction of +4.5 Dsph and 0.4 for the right and left eye, respectively.

Recommendation:
The patient is advised to follow-up regularly with an ophthalmologist for routine eye examination to ensure there is no recurrence of the same condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 70-year-old female referred to our clinic for progressive NTG.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with NTG with a BCVA of 0.5 and 1.0 in the right and left eyes, respectively. The IOP while on glaucoma drops was 15 and 16 mm Hg for the right and left eyes, respectively. Upon examination, both discs appeared clearly glaucomatous with C/D = 0.8–0.9 and disc hemorrhage was noted on the right side.

The patient underwent an MR scan, which revealed pituitary macroadenoma affecting the chiasm, measuring 24 × 30 × 20 mm. The patient underwent a transsphenoidal resection to remove the tumor. Following surgery, the VF improved very rapidly and has remained stable for 4 years.

Summary:

This case report describes a 70-year-old female who was referred to our clinic for progressive NTG. She was found to have pituitary macroadenoma affecting the chiasm, which was deemed responsible for the bitemporal hemianopia observed in her VF. Following the tumor's removal, the patient's VF improved and has remained stable for four years.

To the best of our knowledge, coexistence of true glaucoma was observed in less than 1% of cases with this medical presentation. The patient's glaucoma was observed to progress, although interestingly, surgical excision of the tumor halted its progression. The influence of the adenoma on the optic disc appearance is still uncertain.

Hospital Course:

The patient, who was involved in a murder case, was admitted to our forensic facility for toxicology testing and a complete neuropsychiatric evaluation. The case is complicated due to the defendant's claimed genetic predisposition to anti-social behavior and his regular consumption of alcohol and drugs since the beginning of adolescence.

Toxicology testing revealed detectable levels of benzoylecgonine in urine and pubic hair, while blood and saliva samples showed no significant levels of drugs or alcohol. A full clinical and neuropsychological examination was performed, which identified a personality disorder not otherwise specified. MRI imaging showed a decrease in cortical thickness with enlarged lateral ventricles, significant volumetric asymmetry of the amygdalae, and a decreased volume of the right orbito-frontal cortex in comparison with the left one. PET-CT testing did not indicate any alteration of brain perfusion or metabolism.

Based on the tests and evaluations, it is concluded that the patient did not show any clinical signs of neurological impairment or alcohol-dependence. The patient will be transferred back to the custody of the court.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Age: 25
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital after being accused of sexually assaulting and robbing two women while under the influence of alcohol. He reported a history of physical and psychological abuse by his father during his childhood, as well as being sexually assaulted himself by a teenager. The patient also reported aggressive behavior towards his wife and a history of burglary and stabbing.

Diagnostic Assessment:
A full clinical and neuropsychological examination was conducted, which revealed no signs of neurological impairment. The patient was not found to have alcohol dependence, but an antisocial personality disorder was diagnosed. The patient had an IQ level of 59, which may have contributed to poor decision-making skills. Genetic testing showed variation in the MAOA and HTR1B genes.

Treatment Plan:
The patient was not prescribed any medication but was provided with psychotherapy sessions to address aggressive behavior and antisocial tendencies. The patient was advised to abstain from alcohol to prevent any future criminal behavior. The patient's wife was made aware of the issues and given resources for her safety.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient was referred to a community-based mental health program for continued therapy sessions and follow-up treatment. The patient was also encouraged to seek out support groups to address potential future behavior.

Prognosis:
The patient faces the possibility of future legal consequences if he does not receive proper treatment and abstain from violent behavior, including continued aggression towards his wife. With consistent treatment and support, the patient has the potential to develop more healthy and nonviolent coping mechanisms.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 27-year-old female

Admission Date: [Date]

Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for respiratory failure and diagnosed with hypoplastic left lung syndrome. The patient underwent a multidisciplinary approach involving cardiology, pediatric surgery, pulmonology, and neonatology for her management. The patient underwent a trial of different ventilator modalities with a higher positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) and a course of dexamethasone, but it did not result in any improvement. Due to the futility of these efforts and the severe ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) mismatch in her left lung, a decision was made to trial left main bronchial plugging. 

The patient received an inflatable 5Fr bronchial blocker and underwent left bronchial blocker placement. This resulted in an immediate improvement of the patient's respiratory status with a decrease in oxygen requirement and improved ventilation with weaning of ventilator settings and better inflation of the right lung. The patient underwent surgical exploration by anterolateral thoracotomy, 80% of the emphysematous left upper lobe was removed, a small area of the pulmonary sequestration was also identified, and a chest tube was placed. The procedure was successful, and the patient's respiratory support was weaned as tolerated.

At the time of discharge, the patient's chest X-ray showed improvement, and she was discharged home two months after surgery. Follow-up appointments were scheduled with her primary care physician and specialists involved in her care. 

Discharge Diagnosis:

Hypoplastic left lung syndrome

Discharge Instructions:

1. Follow up with your primary care physician as scheduled.
2. Follow-up appointments with specialists involved in your care have been scheduled.
3. Follow up as needed with your respiratory therapist as advised. 
4. Take all medications as prescribed.
5. Continue to monitor your respiratory symptoms and oxygen levels.
6. Maintain a healthy lifestyle with a balanced diet and regular exercise.

All the best for your continued recovery.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 74 years
Gender: Male
Admission Date: July 2019
Discharge Date: September 2021

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) in May 2019. Before starting the treatment, HBV serology revealed the presence of HBeAg and HBV DNA in serum. He was diagnosed with HBVr and started entecavir (ETV) treatment in July 2019. The therapy reduced viremia to a certain extent, but the decrease plateaued after 6 months. In January 2021, the patient switched to tenofovir alafenamide (TAF), which resulted in a rapid decline of HBV DNA levels.

Past Medical History:
The patient received a kidney transplant for nephroangiosclerosis in August 2013, and he was included in the follow-up program as per protocol. The serologic screening for HBV pre-transplant showed that he was HBsAg-negative and anti-HBs-positive. He was positive for the HBeAg and antibodies to the HBeAg and to the hepatitis B core antigen (anti-HBc). After the transplant, the patient received immunosuppressive induction as prescribed. The kidney donor was negative for HBV. The indices of hepatic cytolysis were normal throughout the follow-up program. The patient was diagnosed with HBVr in May 2019.

Assessment and Plan:
The case report revealed that the patient, despite having a high titer of HBV DNA in serum, was HBsAg-negative. The patient was diagnosed with HBVr and started ETV treatment, which initially reduced viremia but plateaued after 6 months. The patient switched to TAF treatment, which resulted in a rapid decline of HBV DNA levels. The patient had four mutations within the a-determinant and five additional mutations within the MHR. The patient was infected with HBV genotype D.

Follow-Up:
The patient underwent a close follow-up for the first 6 months of ETV treatment, followed by monthly scheduling thereafter. The patient started TAF treatment in January 2021, which resulted in a rapid decline of HBV DNA levels. The patient experienced a single episode of ALT elevation in the 2nd month of TAF treatment in the course of an infection of the residual left limb.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged from the Infectious Disease Section of the Verona University Hospital in September 2021. The patient died due to coronary heart disease.

In summary, the patient presented with HBVr and was treated with ETV followed by TAF treatment. The patient had multiple mutations within the a-determinant and MHR, and was infected with HBV genotype D. Follow-up included monitoring of viral load and liver function. The patient ultimately died due to a coronary heart disease.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course
The patient was admitted to our facility for generalized seizures with no previous acute symptoms. He had a personal history of ureterovesical junction obstruction and mild hydronephrosis. The patient had an episode of seizures about two months prior to admission and was undergoing chronic therapy with sodium valproate (Depakine). A brain MRI performed at that time was normal. The family history revealed ageusia and anosmia in both parents.

Upon admission, the patient was intubated and mechanically ventilated, as he developed severe respiratory distress and pallor. The laboratory tests revealed anemia, a severely increased number of monocytes, and a mildly increased C-reactive protein. After taking into account the family history, a real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) was performed, which tested positive for SARS-CoV-2. A thoracic computed tomography (CT) showed consolidation in the lower lobe of the left lung associated with an opacity in the right apex, indicating the possibility of atelectasis.

The patient was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of severe COVID-19. The medical team initiated antibiotic treatment, antiviral therapy, corticosteroids, anticoagulants, and antipyretics, and continued the chronic anticonvulsant therapy with sodium valproate. However, the patient’s condition deteriorated progressively, and he developed desaturation and bradycardia. The laboratory tests showed leucopenia, neutropenia, mildly increased creatin kinase, a high ferritin level, hypoalbuminemia, a prolonged time of prothrombin, and an increased international normalized ratio (INR).

The patient passed away on the fourth day of admission despite all efforts to resuscitate him.

Final Diagnosis
The patient was diagnosed with severe COVID-19.

Summary of Treatment
- Antibiotics (ceftriaxone 800 mg twice a day and amikacin 100 mg twice a day)
- Antiviral therapy (lopinavir/ritonavir 2.5 mL twice a day)
- Corticosteroids (Dexamethasone 4 mg twice a day)
- Anticoagulants (enoxaparin 0.2 mL in a single daily dose)
- Antipyretics (Paracetamol)
- Chronic anticonvulsant therapy with sodium valproate (Depakine)

Condition on Discharge
Deceased.

Follow-up
N/A.

Reason for Admission:
The patient reported a 1-month history of spontaneous clear left side nipple discharge with a recent appearance of a homolateral painless breast swelling.

History and Physical Examination:
The patient had a past medical history pertinent for obesity class I and bilateral hypoacusia for otosclerosis. On physical examination, he was an overweight Caucasian male with symmetrical breasts. On palpation, there was a bilateral pseudogynaecomastia with a smooth, ill-defined left breast thickening, especially at the union of the outer quadrants. With applied pressure, a minimal clear stream of discharge fluid was elicited from the left nipple and was felt to be localized to a single duct.

Treatment:
The patient did not undergo axillary dissection and was administered tamoxifen as approved adjuvant hormone treatment for men with ER-positive early stage breast cancer.

Follow-up:
The patient was noted to be doing well 6 months post-operatively and is still on follow-up at the time of writing.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Intraductal papilloma (IP) with atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) and a single focus of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) solid-cribriform type.

Recommendations:
Follow-up with the multidisciplinary team for further management.

Stable.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Admission Diagnosis: Angiosarcoma of scalp.

Hospital Course:

The patient, an 83-year-old female presented to the emergency department with a large ulcerated and necrotic bulging lesion on her forehead, along with ill-defined, dusky erythematous plaques extending on the parietal and frontal areas of the scalp and the face, and violaceous-darkish nodules. Bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy was present on physical examination. The patient had comorbidities including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, hypertension, diabetes, and ischemic encephalopathy.

Diagnostic workup revealed a full dermal proliferation of irregular anastomosing vascular channels lined by single or double layers of enlarged endothelial cells, with a confirmed immunoreactivity for CD31, CD34 and ERG, leading to a diagnosis of angiosarcoma of the scalp.

Total body computed tomography (CT) showed cervical lymphadenopathy without brain or visceral metastases.

Although radiotherapy and electrochemotherapy were considered, they were not performed due to the patient’s advanced age, comorbidities, and tumor size. The patient's family provided photographic documentation of the lesion evolution. The lesion had emerged four months before admission, as a 2 cm bruise-like patch on the forehead, and had rapidly developed into a large purplish plaque after 1 month, then to the current presentation.

The patient was referred to palliative care and was advised to return to the hospital in case of any emergency. The family was instructed to provide necessary care and support to the patient.

Discharge Diagnosis: Angiosarcoma of scalp.

Discharge Condition: Discharged to palliative care.

Discharge Instructions: The patient is discharged to palliative care, with instructions to seek emergency medical attention in case of any discomfort or symptoms. The family has been instructed to provide necessary care and support to the patient.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Admission Diagnosis: Acute breakdown with disorganized thought, obsessive symptoms, rumination, and catatonic behaviors, associated with asthenia, reduced autonomous mobility, persistent hyporeactivity to stimuli, stiffness in the limbs, and hypomymia.

Hospital Course:
The patient was initially admitted to the psychiatric ward and treated with quetiapine and lorazepam. Aripiprazole was later prescribed with gradual titration, resulting in a transient improvement. However, the patient exhibited signs of psychomotor retardation, hyperreactivity to stimuli, anorexia, and asthenia. After discontinuing the medication, the patient was hospitalized in an intensive care unit for 4 weeks, followed by a pediatric ward for 1 week, and finally in our hospital for 10 days.

During hospitalization, the patient presented with limb stiffness, perioral myokymia and myoclonus, facial amimia, uncoordinated movements of the tongue, difficulty swallowing, polypnea, tachycardia, and arterial hypertension. Intravenous hydration, dantrolene, clonidine, intravenous benzodiazepines, and carvedilol were administered, followed by bromocriptine therapy, and intravenous lorazepam 2 mg 5 times a day. A gradual improvement in vigilance, reduction of hypertonus, and resolution of hyperthermia were observed, with gradual motor improvement. Blood test results showed a reduction in CK (404 U/L, normal CK range 0–50 UI/mL), and a mild increase in liver enzymes (ALT 72 U/L).

Discharge Diagnosis: Acute breakdown with motor symptoms and stiffness.

Disposition: The patient was discharged in good condition with monthly clinical and CPK controls.

Follow-up Instructions: The patient is advised to continue monthly clinical and CPK controls.

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted to the Respiratory Disease Unit at the University Hospital for a 6-month exertional dyspnea and bilateral pleural effusion that was prevalent on the right side, detected on chest computed tomography (CT). The patient underwent a series of procedures, including thoracic ultrasound, medical thoracoscopy, and surgical pleural biopsy, to obtain a definitive diagnosis.

Hospital Course:
The patient had a complex hospital course, with multiple diagnostic tests and procedures performed during the hospital stay. Initially, a repeated CT scan was conducted, which ruled out a pulmonary embolism but confirmed moderate right pleural effusion with parietal and visceral pleural thickening, in the absence of significant parenchymal abnormalities. Subsequent thoracentesis was performed, and the fluid was consistent with exudate. However, the microbiological tests, including an acid-alcohol-fast bacilli (AAFB) search, were negative. The patient subsequently underwent a medical thoracoscopy, which revealed a large lymphoplasmacytic infiltration, fibrosis, reactive mesothelial cells, and vascular proliferation, suggestive for non-specific pleuritis (NSP). The patient was treated with steroids and showed clinical and radiological improvement.

Six months later, the patient complained of chest discomfort and mild dyspnea, and a relapse of a small amount of right pleural effusion associated with diffuse pleural thickening was detected through a CT scan. The patient was referred to the Thoracic Surgery Unit of Sant’ Andrea University Hospital (Rome) for a surgical pleural biopsy, which revealed a diffuse fibrosing pleuritis, with hyaline features, fibrinous exudate, and a dense lymphocytic and plasma cell inflammation. Immunoperoxidase stains showed a marked increase of IgG4 positive plasma cells, with high IgG4 serum levels. Based on these findings, the patient was diagnosed with IgG4-related pleuritis. Steroid therapy was promptly initiated, with complete resolution of pleural effusion, improved respiratory symptoms, and the progressive reduction of IgG4 serum levels.

Diagnosis and Condition:
The final diagnosis was IgG4-related pleuritis. The patient's condition improved with steroid therapy, and the discharge was approved.

Discharge Plan:
The patient is advised to continue taking the prescribed medication and to follow-up with their physician as per schedule. Detailed instructions on the dosages, side-effects, and warnings of the prescribed medication are given to the patient along with instructions on when to schedule follow-up appointments.

Summary:
The admission to the Respiratory Disease Unit at the University Hospital was due to a 6-month exertional dyspnea and bilateral pleural effusion prevalent on the right side. The patient was diagnosed with IgG4-related pleuritis after a series of diagnostic tests and procedures and was treated with steroid therapy, which resulted in a complete and stable resolution of pleural effusion, improved respiratory symptoms, and progressive reduction of IgG4 serum levels. The patient was discharged with detailed instructions on the dosages, side-effects, and warnings of the prescribed medication and when to schedule follow-up appointments.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
DOB: [redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to our facility at the age of 2 months with a lump on her left thigh, which had progressively grown after birth. The lesion was first described on the prenatal ultrasound at 30 weeks of gestation, and the patient was delivered by cesarean section due to fetal distress but was otherwise normal at birth. Development was normal, and there was no relevant family history. 

Upon physical examination, a 25/10 mm nodule was found on the antero-intern side of the left thigh that was firm, mobile and within the deep layers. The initial X-ray and ultrasound showed a pre-femoral soft tissue mass that measured approximately 30/13 mm, with nonhomogeneous structure, hypoechoic areas, calcifications, and weak Doppler signal, being located anteriorly to the vascular elements of the thigh. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed a mass of 19.33/15.19/34 mm, with a nonspecific vascular involvement.

Elective surgery was scheduled, and an italic S-shaped incision on the antero-internal face of the left thigh was performed. The tumor was resected, and the sartorius muscle was resected at a distance of about 2 cm distal and proximal to the tumor, with complete tumor resection. The patient had a favorable surgical outcome and was discharged 3 days postoperatively.

Diagnostic Findings:

Histologically, the mass in the sartorius muscle was noted as a proliferation of tapered cells arranged in an irregular spiral pattern and crossed by thin-walled vessels. A pseudocapsule formed by a thin layer of connective tissue <1 mm covered the mass. Neoplastic proliferation encompassed residual skeletal muscle fibers in the center of the lesion. Extracapsular and peripheral scarce mature adipose tissue were seen with isolated large-caliber blood vessels. 

Immunostaining revealed the following results: vimentin positive, smooth muscle actin positive in nodules with necrosis and calcifications (miotic nodules), desmin focal positive, Ki67 low (about 5 positive cells per 100 tumor cells, suggesting low cell kinetics).

Diagnosis:

A diagnosis of IM of left sartorius muscle was made.

Follow-up:

At one year after surgery follow up, the child had no recurrence.

Discharge:

The patient was discharged in good condition with appropriate follow-up arrangements.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: Case 2

DOB: [redacted]

Gender: Male

Date of admission: [redacted]

Date of discharge: [redacted]

Diagnosis: Anterior Maxillary Pain

Hospital Course:

Case 2 is an 8-year-old male child who presented to the hospital with chief complaints of pain in the anterior maxilla following exposure to cold water. The patient had a history of trauma to the anterior primary teeth at the age of one year, with composite resin repair of a fracture in the crown of the upper right primary central incisor. Physical examination revealed an abnormal position of the upper right permanent central incisor and clouding of the labial surface, which were likely due to trauma to the primary teeth. The VAS value was 6 for cold water and 7.5 for air blowing.

Immediate treatment reduced VAS to zero for cold water and air blowing. The patient underwent treatment once monthly for seven months. While the sensitivity did not completely disappear, the VAS for air blowing was 2-4, and for cold water it was 1-2. During the treatment, there was no appearance of discolored, devitalized teeth, gingival inflammation, or percussion pain. Digital analysis showed significantly reduced cloudiness, from 27,886 pixels to 7904 pixels. The hypomineralized tooth was mostly cloudy, with a narrow area of brown color, which significantly decreased after treatment (p < 0.03).

Recommendations:

Case 2 was discharged in good condition. Follow-up care should continue as needed.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: Case 3
Gender: Female
Age: 8 years and 7 months
Chief Complaint: Cold water pain in the left side of the maxilla.

History of Present Illness:
The patient, Case 3, an 8-year-old female child, presented to the hospital with a chief complaint of cold water pain in the left side of the maxilla. The left upper second primary molar was extracted because of apical periodontitis and root resorption due to severe caries when the patient was 4 years old. The patient also complained of pain from air blowing and cold water, which was managed by hypersensitivity treatment. During the 7th treatment, the hypersensitivity improved.

Past Medical History:
There was no significant past medical history.

Physical Examination:
The patient demonstrated dark brown hypomineralization on the buccal tooth surface of the first premolars, along with root resorption and apical periodontitis. During treatment for hypersensitivity, the VAS score improved from 4 to 0, indicating effective pain management.

Diagnosis:
The patient presented with cold water pain and hypersensitivity due to caries and root resorption in the left upper second primary molar, as well as dark brown hypomineralization on the buccal tooth surface of the first premolars.

Treatment:
The patient was treated for hypersensitivity with effective pain management using tooth sensitivity treatment, which resulted in a reduction in the VAS score from 4 to 0. Further treatment was reapplied as necessary to manage the patient's symptoms.

Follow-up:
The patient demonstrated improved hypersensitivity with a VAS score of 0 during the 7th treatment. The dark brown tooth surface of the first premolars has lightened to pale brown. Digital analysis also showed a significant reduction in the area of the brownish tint.

Recommendations:
The patient should continue to receive regular dental examinations to monitor any changes in symptoms or oral health. It is recommended that the patient and her caregivers receive education on maintaining proper oral care to prevent further caries and tooth decay.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged from hospital care after effective treatment for hypersensitivity. The patient will continue to receive care as an outpatient and return for follow-up as necessary.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: Case 4 - Male, 5 years and 9 months old.

Chief Complaint:
The patient visited the hospital with a complaint of cold water pain in the anterior mandible.

Diagnosis: 
Hypomineralization of permanent teeth.

Clinical Course:
The patient's lower central incisors were observed with brownish-white discoloration on the labial side. The patient experienced pain from air blowing and cold water with a VAS value of 3. After treatment, the VAS value was reduced to zero. After one month of treatment, the VAS value was 0.5, and after four treatments, the VAS value was zero. The color of the hypomineralization improved significantly after seven treatments. The cloudiness areas improved from 6872 to 1903, and brown areas decreased significantly from 6595 to 1667. 

Treatment:
The patient was treated to suppress hypersensitivity.

Follow-up plans:
No follow-up is required at this time.

Recommendations:
The patient should maintain regular dental hygiene habits, including brushing twice a day and flossing.

Outcome:
The patient's discomfort and hypomineralization were successfully addressed with treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 54-year-old female

History of Present Illness:
The patient was referred for fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) on a rapidly growing thyroid nodule which was subsequently diagnosed as a low-risk indeterminate lesion (AUS/FLUS). After five months, the nodule had grown to 3.6 cm and a second FNAB was performed, with a diagnosis of suspicious for malignancy being rendered. The patient underwent a total thyroidectomy with cervical lymph node dissection followed by chemotherapy with cisplatin plus doxorubicin. The disease was initially stable, but it eventually progressed, leading to the administration of paclitaxel. However, the disease continued to grow and hence lenvatinib in combination with pembrolizumab was started and continued for 18 months. While the lung lesions responded well to the therapy, a pleural nontarget lesion showed progression. The pleural lesion is being treated with stereotactic radiotherapy (42 Gy in seven fractions).

Hospital Course:
The patient has been on lenvatinib and pembrolizumab for 18 months, during which time the lung lesions positively responded to the treatment. However, the pleural nontarget lesion showed progression, and hence, the patient was treated with stereotactic radiotherapy.

Diagnoses:
Hürthle cell carcinoma with foci of paucicellular anaplastic cancer (Stage IVB; cT3b cN0 Mx/pT4b pN0 M0)
Thyroid cancer metastasis

Procedures:
Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB)
Total thyroidectomy
Cervical lymph node dissection
Chemotherapy with cisplatin plus doxorubicin
Lenvatinib in combination with pembrolizumab
Stereotactic radiotherapy (42 Gy in seven fractions)

Summary:
The patient presented with a rapidly growing thyroid nodule, which was diagnosed as a low-risk indeterminate lesion (AUS/FLUS) after FNAB. After a few months, the nodule grew to 3.6 cm, and a second FNAB was performed, leading to a diagnosis of suspicious for malignancy. The patient underwent a total thyroidectomy with cervical lymph node dissection and received chemotherapy with cisplatin plus doxorubicin, which was followed by paclitaxel. However, the disease continued to grow and hence lenvatinib in combination with pembrolizumab was started, which was continued for 18 months. While the lung lesions positively responded to the treatment, a pleural nontarget lesion showed progression, and the patient was treated with stereotactic radiotherapy. The patient is still alive, and the treatment with lenvatinib and pembrolizumab is still ongoing.

Hospital Course:
The patient is an 11-year-old male with no notable medical history who presented for his first dental visit. No symptoms were reported by the patient or his parents during the visit. An orthopantomogram was performed, which revealed an intraosseous lesion associated with the left mandibular third molar germ. To better characterize the lesion, a computed tomography (CT) scan was required. The analysis established bone integrity around the lesion and its independence from the local neuro-vascular structures. Surgical intervention was deemed necessary to prevent the risk of developing pulpal necrosis. Under local anesthesia, the germ of the third molar and the underlying lesion were extracted through a mucoperiosteal flap. Healing was uneventful, and the patient was discharged.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [REDACTED]
- Age: 61 years
- Sex: Female
- Diagnosis: Nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NA-AION)

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our clinic with sudden and painless loss of vision in her right eye, which occurred after a flight from Paris to Madrid. The patient had a known history of high cholesterol, but her other medical history was unremarkable. Upon physical examination, the patient had poor vision in her right eye, with pupillary defect, color vision deficiency, and visual field loss. Fundus examination showed swelling of the right optic disc, with hemorrhaging, congestion, and tortuosity. Cranial computed tomography (CT) revealed white matter lesions. Based on these findings, the patient was diagnosed with NA-AION associated with cerebral small vessel disease (SVD). 

After one year of treatment with aspirin, the patient presented with visual disturbances in her left eye while on a 10-day road trip through the French Alps. Fundus examination revealed hemorrhaging and leakage, along with visual field loss. This was diagnosed as NA-AION in the left eye. 

Ultimately, after further progression of the disease, the patient experienced disc atrophy and retinal nerve fiber layer thickness loss in both eyes. 

Discharge Condition:
- The patient discharged from the clinic with a diagnosis of NA-AION.
- The patient will continue to follow up with ophthalmology. 

Recommendations:
- The patient should continue to monitor her cholesterol levels. 
- The patient should consider avoiding long flights or trips to high altitudes to reduce the risk of further episodes.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 83
Sex: Female

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Respiratory distress
Final Diagnosis: Severe prosthetic valve stenosis, pannus

The patient was an 83-year-old female with a medical history significant for high cholesterol, hypertension, carotid vasculopathy, and smoking. The patient had undergone valvular replacement with a St. Jude 21 mm mechanical prosthesis 20 years prior due to degenerative aortic stenosis. She was admitted to the hospital for respiratory distress.

During the admission, TTE showed LV dysfunction with severe prosthetic valve stenosis, and TEE showed hypomobility of the anterior leaflet. MDCT was performed, which revealed that the anterior aortic leaflet was stuck and surrounded by hypodense tissue indicating a pannus.

The patient underwent repeat surgical repair with a bioprosthesis. The diagnosis of pannus was confirmed by pathology.

The patient was closely monitored throughout her hospitalization, and her vital signs and respiratory symptoms improved. The patient was discharged in good condition to follow-up with her primary care physician.

Follow-up plan: 
The patient is advised to follow up with her primary care physician for continued management of her medical conditions. A cardiac rehabilitation program can be considered with the primary care physician's recommendation.

Discharge Medications: 
Not Applicable - the patient did not require new medications upon discharge. 

Instructions: 
The patient is advised to keep all follow-up appointments with her primary care physician. In case of worsening respiratory symptoms or any new symptoms, the patient is advised to seek medical attention immediately.

Consultants: 
Cardiology, Pathology

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Admitting Diagnosis: Mitral Valve Dysplasia and Subaortic Stenosis

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 44-year-old female, was admitted with a diagnosis of mitral valve dysplasia and subaortic stenosis. She underwent subaortic membrane resection and septal myectomy in 1989 and a St. Jude Regent 17 mm was implanted in 2006 to improve her physical condition due to worsening exertional dyspnea and persistence of subaortic stenosis. However, the patient's condition progressively worsened over the last 2 years. Recent TTE detected an increase in the intraventricular gradient with LV hypertrophy, and TEE confirmed severe subaortic stenosis. Additionally, a new subaortic membrane formation was suspected but not clearly detected by TEE. MDCT provided accurate 3D reconstructions of the LV outlet tract (LVOT) with a better topographic assessment of the new SAM and its surrounding structures, which was crucial in guiding surgical excision of the SAM.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient's case was closely monitored during her stay in the hospital. She underwent several diagnostic tests to determine the root cause of her worsening physical condition. Based on the diagnosis, the medical team opted to perform surgical excision of the subaortic membrane formation. The patient was informed of the risks and benefits of the procedure, and written consent was obtained from the patient.

Following the surgery, the patient was closely monitored for any postoperative complications. She was administered appropriate medications, and her vital signs and laboratory values were continuously monitored to ensure that she remained stable. Physical therapy was also initiated to aid in her recovery and to prevent complications such as deep vein thrombosis.

The patient's condition improved after the surgery, and her postoperative care and management were successful. She was discharged in an improved condition with appropriate instructions and referrals for follow-up care and management.

Discharge Diagnosis: Mitral Valve Dysplasia and Subaortic Stenosis

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 80
Gender: Male
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient presented with intermittent fever and serial hemocultures growing Enterococcus faecalis. Diagnosis of endocarditis was confirmed with TTE detecting paravalvular regurgitation (PVR) with focal hyperechogenic thickening of the leaflets. Antibiotic treatment was started, and TEE revealed a pulsatile perivalvular pseudoaneurysm in the mitroaortic intervalvular fibrosa (MAIVF). MDCT was performed and confirmed the presence of a pseudoaneurysm communicating with LVOT and a periaortic abscess in the anterolateral side of the vessel with longitudinal extension.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

Endocarditis with perivalvular pseudoaneurysm and periaortic abscess.

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient underwent antibiotic treatment for endocarditis, and a pulsatile perivalvular pseudoaneurysm was detected in the mitroaortic intervalvular fibrosa. A periaortic abscess was also observed, indicating the severity of the condition. 

DISCHARGE PLAN:

The patient was discharged with instructions to follow up with their primary care physician. They were advised to continue taking any prescribed medications and follow up with any recommended tests or procedures. A follow-up appointment with a heart specialist was scheduled for further assessment of the patient's condition. The patient was also advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and avoid risk factors associated with heart disease.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient is a 69-year-old male with hypertension, high cholesterol, and previous history of myocardial infarction who underwent trans-catheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) for severe degenerative aortic stenosis in April 2020. A few days after the procedure, an increased transprosthesis gradient was detected during a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) without any associated fever or positive hemoculture. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) showed hypomobility of the noncoronary cusp of the biological valve. Valve thrombosis was suspected, and heparin administration was started. A multidetector computed tomography (MDCT) scan revealed a misfolding of the prosthesis’ frame causing a paravalvular leak, which further confirmed the suspicion of valve thrombosis when two hypodense appositions were found at the lower edge of the valve. The patient underwent balloon valvuloplasty with complete resolution of the valvular dysfunction.

Summary:

Patient is a 69-year-old male with hypertension, high cholesterol, and previous history of myocardial infarction who underwent trans-catheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) with LOTUS Edge 27 mm for severe degenerative aortic stenosis in April 2020. TTE detected an increased transprosthesis gradient, and TEE showed hypomobility of the valve’s noncoronary cusp. Valve thrombosis was suspected, and heparin administration was initiated. MDCT revealed a misfolding of the prosthesis’ frame and a paravalvular leak, which confirmed the suspicion of valve thrombosis. The patient underwent balloon valvuloplasty with complete resolution of the valvular dysfunction.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 45 years old
Gender: Female

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: COVID-19 with Pulmonary Embolism
Final Diagnosis: COVID-19 with Pulmonary Embolism

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our institution due to worsening dyspnea, chest pain, and desaturation. Her COVID-19 diagnosis was confirmed with a positive RT-PCR test result for SARS-CoV-2. The patient also presented with a massive pulmonary embolism, as evidenced by her CT pulmonary angiography, leading to right ventricular dysfunction. Systemic thrombolysis with r-tPA (alteplase) was administered, leading to improvement in her hemodynamic and ventilatory patterns. Throughout her hospital stay, the patient experienced additional complications including septic shock, respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation support, and severe anemia. The patient had a satisfactory clinical response to treatment with successful extubation and transfer to the general hospital floor.

Medications:
The patient is on an indefinite anticoagulation therapy with a factor-XA inhibitor prescribed at the time of discharge.

Follow-up:
The patient was evaluated by the OB-GYN attending physician, who contraindicated the further use of estrogenic hormonal contraceptives.

Instructions:
The patient should continue her anticoagulation therapy and follow up with her OB-GYN for family planning counseling. The patient is advised to seek medical attention immediately if she experiences any recurrence of symptoms.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged from our institution with stable vital signs and satisfactory clinical evolution.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 74-year-old male, ASA physical class III, with a history of hypertension and previous cystolitholapaxy for bilateral ureteral stones, was admitted for tumor-wide excision, mandibulotomy, tracheostomy, and free flap reconstruction because of mouth floor squamous cell carcinoma. The patient presented with a mild productive cough and was being treated with losartan and hydrochlorothiazide. The patient underwent general anesthesia without any complications. Following a standard monitoring setup, mechanical ventilation was implemented, and the patient was induced with remifentanil, lidocaine, propofol, and succinylcholine. A cuffed 8.0 sized tracheostomy tube was placed, and the patient underwent an uneventful tracheostomy without any complications. Despite the recruitment maneuver, the patient's SpO2 continued to drop down from 96% to 89%, and physical examinations revealed that chest wall movement was normal at the left side but significantly suppressed at the right side. The patient was evaluated with a bedside lung POCUS, which indicated decreasing lung sliding over the right upper lung field and a reduced sandy seashore sign. Right mainstem intubation by the tracheostomy tube was excluded by fiberoptic bronchoscopy exam. However, copious sticky yellowish sputum was encountered in the bronchial branches, especially at the right upper bronchus. Portable chest radiography was taken, which showed partial atelectasis over the right upper lobe and increased interstitial lung density, which was compatible with the ultrasound findings. After adequate suctioning and recruitment maneuvers, an ABG analysis was repeated, which revealed a low PaO2. Due to suspected pneumonia, the surgery was deferred, and empirical antimicrobial treatment with piperacillin and tazobactam was initiated. Haemophilus influenza was isolated from the sputum culture. After a 10-day antibiotic treatment course, a repeat chest radiograph was clear, and the patient received the pre-planned surgery uneventfully.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted for tumor-wide excision, mandibulotomy, tracheostomy, and free flap reconstruction for mouth floor squamous cell carcinoma. An uneventful procedure was conducted, but the patient's SpO2 dropped down, and physical examinations revealed suppressed chest wall movement at the right side. A bedside lung POCUS was conducted, which indicated partial atelectasis over the right upper lobe and increased interstitial lung density. Antibiotic treatment was initiated after the sputum culture revealed an infection with Haemophilus influenza. After 10 days of treatment, a follow-up chest radiograph was clear, and the patient underwent the pre-planned surgery uneventfully.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 79-year-old female with a history of hypertension, heart failure, and middle cerebral artery infarction who underwent total hip arthroplasty under general anesthesia. Before the surgery, several modalities were monitored, including electrocardiography, noninvasive blood pressure, pulse oximetry, and bispectral index monitoring. The anesthesia was induced with propofol and rocuronium, and intra-arterial cannulation was performed for continuous blood pressure monitoring. During surgery, the patient experienced a drop in oxygen saturation levels from 93.1% to 83.1%. The patient was ventilated at a fraction of inspired oxygen of 0.4, and the arterial blood gas showed that the partial pressure of oxygen dropped from 161.6 to 51.2, which suggested atelectasis due to a collapsed lung. Treatment included increasing the positive end expiratory pressure to 10 cm H2O and FiO2 to 1.0 and performing a recruitment maneuver. The patient's oxygen saturation level increased only temporarily and dropped again to 81%. To address this, muscle relaxation was reversed, and spontaneous respiration was induced. The oxygen saturation level recovered to 90%, and the surgery continued. 

Discharge Summary:

The patient, having undergone surgery, was monitored for her vital signs and underwent various modalities (electrocardiography, noninvasive blood pressure, pulse oximetry, and bispectral index monitoring) prior to the procedure. Unfortunately, the patient suffered a drop in oxygen saturation levels during surgery, which was due to atelectasis (a collapsed lung). The medical team administered adjustments to the patient's ventilation parameters and was able to recover the oxygen saturation level temporarily. However, to fully address the issue, muscle relaxants were reversed, and spontaneous respiration was induced. This led to a recovery of the oxygen saturation level. After the surgery, the patient recovered and was discharged.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 91-year-old Caucasian man with a history of coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, interstitial lung disease, and obstructive sleep apnea.

Admission: The patient was admitted with a 2-week history of productive cough, fever, shortness of breath, and malaise.

Hospital Course: The patient was intubated for respiratory failure and started on antibiotics for his acute right pleural effusion and abdominal mass-like lesion. He underwent chest tube placement and pleural fluid analysis, which was consistent with empyema. The blood culture showed beta-hemolytic streptococci, and the pleural fluid culture grew Streptococcus anginosus. The patient was scheduled for CT-guided drainage of the liver abscess but did not undergo the procedure due to significant improvement in the hepatic collection size. He received intrapleural thrombolytic for his persistent pleural effusion. Unfortunately, he developed worsening respiratory distress, and repeat CT chest showed progressive atelectasis, necessitating re-intubation.

Outcome: After two weeks of hospitalization, the patient was terminally extubated and placed on comfort care.

Follow-up: The patient's family was informed of his status and provided with an appropriate bereavement program. The patient's primary care physician was also informed of his condition for continuity of care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 93-year-old female

Admission date: [date]
Discharge date: [date]

Admission Diagnosis: Hypokalaemia, malnutrition, decreased renal function

Hospital course: The patient presented with hypokalaemia, malnutrition, and decreased renal function. She has undergone bowel resection several times in the past and was suffering from watery diarrhoea, likely due to de-adaptation of short bowel syndrome. An infusion of magnesium and potassium improved her electrolyte imbalance and renal function, but the diarrhea persisted. A colonoscopy and pathological specimens were taken, but no specific findings were observed. Stool culture and histopathological examination did not reveal any exact cause for her symptoms. The patient was switched to central venous nutrition which resulted in improvement of her diarrhea.

Hospital course summary: The patient was admitted with hypokalaemia, malnutrition, and decreased renal function. She had a past medical history of bowel resection and was diagnosed with de-adaptation of short bowel syndrome. The treatment involved an infusion of magnesium and potassium and central venous nutrition, which resulted in improvement of her diarrhea. The patient was discharged in good general condition.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with fever, shortness of breath and cough. Initial assessment showed polypnea, hypoxia, fever, elevated C-Reactive Protein and bilateral middle and lower zone air space opacities on chest X-ray. The patient was started on empirical treatment for community acquired pneumonia and was later transferred to ICU due to aggravated tachypnea, severe hypoxemia and diffuse ground-glass opacities on thoracic-CT scan. The patient was diagnosed with Pneumocystis jirovecii (P. jirovecii) and was treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole plus corticosteroids. The patient required intubation and completed a period of protective IMV. ECMO was initiated due to refractory hypoxemia and was maintained for 40 days, followed by weaning off for 19 days. The pneumomediastinum and bilateral pneumothorax were managed conservatively and showed great improvement on a subsequent CT-scan. ART was started and the patient showed significant myopathy during the hospital stay. After 69 days of ICU stay, the patient was transferred to the ward and later discharged in a stable condition.

Hospital Course Summary:
A 29-year-old male, severely immunosuppressed due to HIV, was admitted to the hospital with fever, cough and shortness of breath. The patient was diagnosed with Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia and required ECMO and intubation due to refractory hypoxemia. The patient was treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and corticosteroids and showed significant myopathy during the hospital stay. After 69 days of ICU stay, the patient was transferred to the ward and later discharged in a stable condition.

Admission Summary:

A 64-year-old female with hypertension, dyslipidemia and chronic pulmonary disease was admitted to the Emergency Room (ER) with symptoms of fever, shortness of breath and cough. The patient was diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and treated with antibiotics. Her symptoms worsened, and she was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU).

Hospital Course Summary:

Despite previous treatment, the patient remained hypoxic. She required intubation and was connected to Veno-Venous Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (VV-ECMO) due to refractory respiratory acidemia. A diagnosis of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP) was confirmed via positive immunofluorescence in bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL). The patient exhibited severe immunosuppression and high serum viral load of Cytomegalovirus (CMV). Treatment with TMP-SMX and corticosteroids were started for PJP at the recommended dosage. ECMO was discontinued after ten days. The patient required extensive respiratory therapy with invasive ventilation and prone positioning. There was recrudescence of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS), and a broad spectrum of antibiotics were started due to suspected nosocomial infection. The BAL was repeated and continued to yield positive findings for P. jirovecii and CMV via Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR). The patient completed a total of:

- 33 days of TMP-SMX for PJP
- 21 days of ganciclovir for CMV

The patient responded positively with respiratory improvement and started antiretroviral therapy (ART). She was extubated after 83 days and transferred to a rehabilitation unit with residual oxygen support of 2 liters per minute. After months of pulmonary rehabilitation, she was discharged, achieving full recovery.

Disposition:

The patient was transferred to a rehabilitation unit for respiratory therapy and muscular rehabilitation, where she received full recovery and was subsequently discharged.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission: A 53-year-old female with no relevant medical history presented to the ER with a two-month history of progressive psychomotor slowness and confusion. Physical examination revealed agitation and fever. CT scan showed intra-axial lesions in the left frontal and temporal lobes, and CSF had mild pleocytosis and moderately elevated proteins. Serology for HIV was positive, and nucleic acid test of the CSF was positive for toxoplasma gondii, resulting in a de novo diagnosis of HIV infection with severe immunosuppression manifested as cerebral toxoplasmosis.

Treatment: The presumptive diagnosis of PJP was confirmed with direct dye-examination and PCR positive for P. jirovecii in BAL. The patient was treated with TMP-SMX for both PJP and cerebral toxoplasmosis. Broad-spectrum antibiotics were started after worsening lung opacities, and VV-ECMO was initiated due to septic shock and ARDS.

Complications: Indirect immunofluorescence was positive for P. jirovecii in BAL, and the patient completed treatment for PJP. Multidrug-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa was isolated in respiratory secretions, and targeted antibiotic therapy with cefepime was initiated for lobar nosocomial pneumonia.

Outcome: After one month of ICU stay, the patient was discharged to the ward for muscular rehabilitation. She was free of acute infectious complications and started on antiretroviral therapy.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY
 
Patient Name: [redacted]
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]
 
Hospital Course Summary:
 
The patient was admitted to the hospital with a history of worsening cough, dyspnea and fever. Initial assessment revealed hypoxia, fever and several ground glass opacities on thoracic CT-scan. The patient was started on empirical treatment and admitted to the ward. The patient's need for oxygen support increased, and he was eventually admitted to the ICU and received VV-ECMO support. PJP was confirmed by positive immunofluorescence in BAL. The patient became delirious and agitated during treatment, which caused flow problems in the ECMO circuit, and required sedation and intubation. The patient completed 21 days of treatment, and ECMO support was maintained for 26 days. After the patient was transferred to the ward for rehabilitation, he received follow-up CT-scan and ART therapy.
 
Follow-up:
All four patients are under regular observation as part of our Infectious Diseases program. They have all achieved functional and radiological recovery and are in good health. 
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
HIV infection, PJP, delirium, agitated behavior, ECMO support 
 
Discharge Instructions:
The patient should continue ART therapy and follow-up on a regular basis with health care providers. If the patient experiences any symptoms or side effects, he should contact his healthcare provider as soon as possible. The patient should also avoid exposure to any respiratory infections. 
 
Contact Information:
Dr. [redacted], Infectious Diseases Program Director, can be contacted at [redacted].

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Gender: Male
Age: 52

Hospital course: The patient was admitted to the emergency room due to repeated lipothymia, hematemesis, and melaena. Upon admission, the patient was hemodynamically unstable and showed acute anemia, with a hemoglobin value of 6g/dL. The patient had a history of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) therapy and enalapril therapy for hypertension. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen revealed a narrow lumen of the second portion of the duodenum, and an esophagus-gastro-duodenoscopy (EGDS) examination revealed multiple sub-centimeter lymph node formations in the stomach. The patient's condition worsened, and he was transferred to Intensive Care, was intubated, and underwent therapy to restore hemodynamic balance. An emergency gastroscopy was performed, which revealed an ulcerative lesion of the duodenal bulb with circumferential extension to the intestinal wall. On the fifth day, the hemodynamics were unstable, and the anemia persisted; conditions precipitated due to common complications of hypovolemia. Hemorrhagic shock and peritonitis due to enterobiasis were assessed as causes of death.

Autopsy findings: After 72 h, an autopsy was performed. Femoral blood was analyzed for alcohol and volatiles by head-space gas chromatography coupled with a flame ionization detector. All post-mortem specimens were screened for the presence of the main different classes of drugs using immunological or chromatographic methods as appropriate. A systematic toxicological analysis was performed by the LC-MS/MS system in multiple reaction monitoring mode.

Diagnosis: Hemorrhagic shock and peritonitis due to enterobiasis.

Disposition: Deceased.

Follow-up: There is no follow-up required as the patient is deceased.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Admission Date: [Redacted]

Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Fever and poor general condition

Brief Hospital Course: A nine-day-old male newborn was admitted to the hospital due to fever and poor general condition. He was diagnosed with SARS-CoV-2 at admission and developed respiratory failure and diarrhea with enterorrhagia, which led to PICU admission. He was supported with noninvasive ventilation and treated with antibiotic wide coverage. In the subsequent three days, his neurological condition deteriorated with impaired consciousness and pathological spontaneous motricity, leading to intubation and mechanical ventilation. The chest radiograph and CT scan showed a picture of bilateral interstitial pneumonia with an extensive area of atelectasis in the basal site. 

Diagnostic and Therapeutic Procedures: Nasopharyngeal swabs and bronchoalveolar lavage were performed to assess the SARS-CoV-2 viral load. SARS-CoV-2 variant determination was performed by SNP detection approach, suggesting VOC 202012/01 Lineage B.1.1.7 variant. Anti-SARS-CoV-2 hyperimmune plasma and medications like dexamethasone and remdesivir were administered. A lumbar puncture was performed, and the metabolic test on blood and liquor were normal. Immunological screening showed no abnormalities. The EEG showed hypovolted brain electrical activity with a discontinuous pattern. The cerebral CT scan was normal, but the brain MRI showed deep medullary vein thrombosis associated with cytotoxic edema in the deep periventricular white matter, which was treated with enoxaparin. Extended thrombophilic screening including homocysteine, anticardiolipin antibodies, antiphospholipid antibodies, anti-beta-2-glycoprotein antibodies, protein S, protein C, activated protein C resistance, lupus anticoagulant, factor XIII, von Willebrand factor antigen, Factor V Leyden mutation, factor II prothrombin mutation, and MTHFR mutation were normal. 

Condition at Discharge: The patient's condition progressively improved, and after 13 days, he was extubated and in four more days became oxygen independent. At the five-month follow-up visit, the baby was doing well, without any clinical problems. The T1-weighted MRI showed significant reduction in linear hyperintense lesions, normal intensity of periventricular white matter, and enlargement of lateral ventricles. 

Discharge Medications: Not Applicable

Follow-Up Plan: The patient was discharged from the hospital after 42 days with detailed instructions for close follow-up with his healthcare provider. 

Attending Physician: [Redacted]

Hospital Course: 

Admission Date: [Date]  
Discharge Date: [Date]  
Patient: [Name]  

History and Presenting Problem: 
This 5-year-old boy with a molecularly confirmed diagnosis of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) presented with intellectual disability (ID), autism spectrum disorder (ASD), joint hyperlaxity, and morphogenetic anomalies. The patient’s mother had a history of epilepsy with tonic–clonic seizures, photosensitivity, and moderate elevation in serum creatinine phosphokinase (CPK) levels following physical exercise.

Assessment and Findings: 
The patient was born from non-consanguineous parents after an uneventful dizygotic twin pregnancy. He had delayed milestones and showed a lack of eye contact, visual tracking, and social interest from early on. EEG showed focal spikes over the frontal region and the left temporal region and generalized spike-and-wave complexes during sleep. A brain MRI showed normal results. Muscular dystrophy was confirmed through genetic analysis of the dystrophin gene which detected the deletion of exons 46-51 of the gene. The child presented with severe developmental delays and autistic features, including poor eye contact, absence of protodeclarative pointing, attention deficit, and inadequate social-communicative abilities. Joint hyperlaxity and peculiar facial traits were noted, including a high forehead, epicanthic folds, deep-set eyes, an elongated face, and large ears. Following array-CGH analysis and FMR1 molecular analysis, the comorbidity with Fragile X syndrome (FXS) was confirmed.

Treatment and Course: 
The patient received a rehabilitation program that showed a slight improvement, especially in his motor skills. The patient was discharged to continue therapy as an outpatient. The family was referred to genetic counseling.

Discharge Diagnoses: 
1. Duchenne muscular dystrophy
2. Intellectual disability
3. Autism spectrum disorder
4. Joint hyperlaxity
5. Morphogenetic anomalies
6. Fragile X syndrome  

Discharge Condition: 
The patient was discharged in stable condition with continued symptoms and ongoing medical needs.  

Discharge Medications: 
N/A  

Follow-Up: 
Follow-up appointments with the rehabilitation program and genetic counseling were scheduled.

Discharge summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted with developmental delay, macrocephaly, tremors of the upper limbs, axial hypotonia, and apnea episodes.

Hospital Course:
During her hospitalization, the patient was thoroughly evaluated with a battery of diagnostic tools including brain ultrasound and MRI, EEG, audiometric and fundus oculi examinations as well as molecular analysis for FXS. The diagnosis of FXS in the proband revealed a de novo heterozygous variant c.592G>A p.(Glu198Lys) in the PPP2R5D gene, which is reported in HGMD (Human Gene Mutation Database). The same variant was previously reported de novo in patients affected by moderate/severe ID. Array-CGH revealed a “likely benign” 9q21.31 duplication of approximately 200 kb.

Clinical Findings:
The patient presented with a broad and rounded forehead, a small nose with a saddle root and anteverted nostrils, a reverse epicanthus, sparse eyebrows in the medial portion, fetal finger pads, ligamentous hyperlaxity, and a sandal gap with prominent heel. She reached head control at 3.5 months, sitting position at 10 months, and non-autonomous standing station at 15 months. Up to 15 months, she presented difficulties in handling objects with coarse grip. Language was poor with very few words developed at 13 months.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with phenobarbital and oxygen for apnea episodes.

Follow-up Care:
The patient will require long-term follow-up and care from a multidisciplinary team to address her developmental delays.

Discharge Condition:
The patient's condition has improved, and she is being discharged to home with her parents.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Developmental delay, macrocephaly, tremors of the upper limbs, axial hypotonia, and apnea episodes, likely caused by the de novo heterozygous variant c.592G>A p.(Glu198Lys) in the PPP2R5D gene reported in HGMD (Human Gene Mutation Database).

Instructions:
The patient's parents have been advised to continue evaluating her developmental progress and provide additional support as needed. They have also been advised to seek further genetic counseling if they decide to have additional children.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: Patient 3, Gender: Male, Age: 33 years

Hospital Course:
Patient 3 was admitted due to a history of seizure episodes, which started at the age of 10 years. Brain angio-MRI revealed left A1 segment agenesis, temporo-mesial sclerosis, asymmetry of the supratentorial ventricular system, and an occipital horn. The patient also has a history of comatose episode following a severe seizure crisis.

Family History:
Family history revealed that two other male patients (both cousin's sons) were affected by ID of undetermined cause and diagnosis. The patient's sister was found to carry a PM of the FMR1 gene and had one unaffected daughter and one son affected by FXS.

Physical Examination:
Physical examination showed an elongated face, high forehead, wide and anteverted ears, long and flat philtrum, joint hyperlaxity, hypotonia, and midface hypoplasia.

Diagnostic Tests:
Molecular analysis of the FMR1 gene and array-CGH were performed, which revealed an FMR1 MFM allele (>200 CGGs). Following this result, the patient's mother was tested and found heterozygous for a normal allele of 30 CGG triplets and a PM allele with 79 CGGs. SNTG2, TPO, and PXDN genes, and possibly MYT1L were found to be deleted in the chromosome 2p25.3 span, derived from his premutated mother. Real-time PCR revealed decreased levels of MYT1L transcript in the patient when compared to his mother and neurotypical controls.

Treatment:
The patient is currently undergoing anticonvulsive treatment with valproic acid, oxcarbazepine, and topiramate.

Discharge Plan:
The patient will be discharged with recommendations to continue anticonvulsive treatment with valproic acid, oxcarbazepine, and topiramate. The patient should also undergo regular follow-up appointments with a neurologist to monitor his condition. Genetic counseling may also be recommended to the patient and his family due to the genetic component of his condition.

Discharge Summary:

Identification:
Patient Name: 2.II.1 (a right)
Gender: Male
Age: 35 years

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted at the age of 34 years old, with high serum ferritin levels and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. The patient was diagnosed with iron overload disease and underwent magnetic resonance imaging, which showed hepatic iron overload. The treatment for the patient consisted of iron chelation with Desferoxamine. Phlebotomies were also performed in combination with the iron chelation treatment.

The patient's treatment continued until 2020 when the iron chelation treatment was stopped. The patient is now asymptomatic and will continue with maintenance therapy.

Identification:
Patient Name: A.II.1
Gender: Male
Age: 35 years

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted at the age of 35 years old, with high levels of serum ferritin and iron. The patient was diagnosed with HH, and magnetic resonance imaging showed severe hepatic iron overload. The treatment for the patient consisted of weekly phlebotomies in combination with iron chelation (Desferoxamine). After 100 phlebotomies and approximately 22 g of iron removal, the ferritin levels dropped to normal levels.

Identification:
Patient Name: A.II.2
Gender: Male
Age: 37 years

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted at the age of 37 years old, with high levels of serum ferritin and iron. The patient was diagnosed with HH, and magnetic resonance imaging showed severe hepatic iron overload. The treatment for the patient consisted of monthly phlebotomies in combination with iron chelation (Desferoxamine). After 46 phlebotomies that removed a total amount of 9 g of iron, the ferritin and transferrin saturation parameters normalized. The iron depletion was partially confirmed by the last hepatic magnetic resonance, which showed a moderate iron overload.

Summary:
The patients were diagnosed with HH and underwent treatments to manage the iron overload. The patient with the iron chelation treatment is now asymptomatic and will continue with maintenance therapy. The patients who underwent phlebotomies in combination with iron chelation successfully reduced their serum ferritin and iron levels. The patients are now ready for discharge.

Patient: B.II.1
Age: 46
Sex: Male

Diagnosis: Hemochromatosis (Cys282Tyr mutation carrier), dyslipidemia, internal hemorrhoids, chronic arthropathy (feet, spine, hands)

Treatment: Monthly erythroapheresis (later reduced to every two months), phlebotomies

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission: The patient was admitted to the hospital with hyperferritinemia and hepatic iron accumulation detected by hepatic magnetic resonance.

Treatment: The patient was initially treated with monthly erythroapheresis. In January 2015, phlebotomies were introduced as part of the treatment plan. The rate of erythroapheresis was later reduced to once every two months.

Results: In May 2017, the hepatic magnetic resonance showed no signs of hepatic iron overload.

Discharge: The patient is being discharged from the hospital with instructions to continue regular phlebotomies and routine monitoring of iron levels. Follow-up appointments with the healthcare provider are recommended to monitor the patient's progress and adjust treatment as necessary.

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 65-year-old woman with a noncontributory medical history and was admitted to undergo surgical reconstructive therapy for peri-implantitis lesion localized around the mandibular left distal implant. The procedure involved prosthetic superstructure removal, oral and buccal full-thickness mucoperiosteal flaps incision, surface debridement and decontamination, and guided bone regeneration of an infra-bony defect using a mineralized dehydrated bone allograft and resorbable membrane in the non-submerged mode of wound healing. During the procedure, the patient experienced sudden onset swelling on the left cheek and periorbital space due to air-powder debridement of soft tissue. The procedure was immediately stopped, and the surgical area was rinsed with sterile saline solution to remove all residual bicarbonate particles. The subcutaneous emphysema diagnosis was based on the sudden onset during air-powder debridement of soft tissue swelling associated with crepitus in the absence of erythema, oedema, significant pain, or lymphadenopathy. 

Treatment:
