No serious complications were observed, and the patient was reassured that the swelling should reduce spontaneously and subside within 7–10 days with no complications or morbidity. The patient was discharged with the prescription of antibiotics to prevent potential aerobic and anaerobic polymicrobial infection.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to avoid coughing, sneezing, and nose-blowing, which could increase intraoral pressure. The patient was also advised to follow up with the clinician for regular check-ups to monitor the progressive swelling reduction and complete resolution. 

Outcome:
The patient was discharged from the hospital after the swelling had completely resolved without any complications after an observation period.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Diagnosis: Familiar Left-Dominant Arrhythmogenic Cardiomyopathy

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 23-year-old male, was admitted to our cardiomyopathy clinic due to repetitive ventricular ectopic beats. He had a history of myocarditis one year before, which was managed at a different hospital. At the time of admission, he was hemodynamically stable with no other symptoms. Coronary angiogram showed normal coronary arteries, while a cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) revealed a non-dilated left ventricle (LV) with low-normal ejection fraction (EF) and mid-wall myocardial edema and late gadolinium enhancement (LGE). However, the patient did not provide consent for endomyocardial biopsy. During follow-up, LV EF was found to be mildly reduced with diffuse circumferential subepicardial LGE involvement of the LV myocardium.

In order to find the underlying cause, genetic testing was performed, which identified a heterozygous variant in DSP (c.5428C>T, p.Gln1810Ter). A diagnosis of familiar left-dominant arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy was made based on genetic testing. The patient's mother and sister were also found to have the same mutation and phenotype. All three patients started therapy with β-blocker drugs, and the proband received an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator.

The patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions to continue medication and follow up with a cardiologist. They were advised to have genetic counseling and to inform family members to get tested for the same mutation.

Discharge Medications:
- β-blocker drugs (name not provided)

Follow-Up Plan:
- Follow up with a cardiologist for further evaluation and management
- Consider genetic counseling and further testing for family members

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 8 years
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Length of Stay: 5 years

Hospital Course:
The patient was referred to our clinic with symptoms of joint hyperlaxity, skin hyperextensibility, and delayed wound healing. She was born prematurely due to maternal pre-eclampsia and placental abruption. The patient experienced small bowel perforation at the age of 12 hours requiring surgery. She also had bilateral retinal detachment, bilateral cataract, and right traumatic femoral bone fracture, all of which required surgical treatment.

Examination:
The patient was found to be overweight with generalized joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, multiple atrophic and post-surgical dystrophic scars, multiple ecchymoses in her lower limbs, absence of lingual frenulum, mild right-convex thoracic scoliosis, bilateral genu valgum-recurvatum, cubitus valgus with elbows hyperextensibility, and bilateral pes planus. The patient had no strength deficit, with global hypotonia but normal muscular trophism and deep tendon reflexes. Intellectual abilities were normal. Chest, spine, and limb radiography confirmed the orthopedic abnormalities. Global respiratory function with spirometry, abdominal, and supra-aortic trunk ultrasounds and video-electroencephalography all resulted normal. A comprehensive cardiovascular evaluation evidenced a mild mitral valve insufficiency without clinical relevance.

Follow Up:
Multidisciplinary follow-up including pediatric, oculistic, psychiatric, and cardiovascular evaluations has been continued for 5 years, with no pain reported by the patient. The patient attends school with good cognitive and social skills and weekly swimming sessions, and support insoles were prescribed without a clear clinical improvement.

Final Condition:
The final condition of the patient is stable, and she is being discharged from the hospital. The patient shows no clinical signs of deterioration and has been advised to continue with the multidisciplinary follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 12-year-old female, was admitted to the hospital due to abdominal pain and bloody stools. She had a history of moderate left-sided ulcerative colitis (UC), diagnosed at the age of 9 years. The patient had initially been treated with prednisolone and later with azathioprine due to intolerance to mesalazine, achieving remission. At the time of admission, the patient was experiencing a UC relapse, and colonoscopic findings showed marked erythema and the absence of vascular patterns. Since the patient declined further steroid therapy due to previous side effects, she underwent granulocyte and monocyte adsorptive apheresis (GMA) using the single-needle method once per week for 10 weeks. Although the patient did not attain remission with GMA, she was eventually treated with infliximab and achieved remission. No adverse effects were observed during the hospitalization. The patient was discharged with medication and follow-up instructions.

Hospital Course Overview:

The patient was admitted to the hospital due to abdominal pain and bloody stools. [We recommend summary information about the diagnosis, treatments, and events that occurred during hospitalization]

Medical History:

The patient was diagnosed with moderate left-sided UC at 9 years of age and had a previous medical history of intolerance to mesalazine and side effects from prednisolone.

Treatment and Procedure:

The patient underwent GMA using the single-needle method once per week for 10 weeks to induce remission.

Diagnosis:

The patient had a UC relapse with colonoscopic findings of marked erythema and the absence of vascular pattern.

Follow-Up Instructions:

The patient was discharged with instructions for medication and follow-up with healthcare providers.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED] 

Date of Admission: [REDACTED] 

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED] 

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our tertiary medical center for a second opinion regarding the incidental pathology finding of nonmucinous appendiceal adenocarcinoma after an emergent appendectomy at an outside hospital. She underwent a staging CT and colonoscopy, which revealed no evidence of distant metastasis. Completion right hemicolectomy and possible right oophorectomy followed by adjuvant FOLFOX were recommended, but the patient forgoed any treatment at that time.

The patient presented to clinic with the CT findings of growth in the right ovarian cyst and a new complex cystic/solid mass along the left pelvic sidewall. On presentation, she complained of lower abdominal fullness and cramping with intermittent bloating and early satiety. Her exam was mostly unremarkable except for the fullness in bilateral adnexa. She underwent cytoreductive surgery, which included right hemicolectomy, cholecystectomy, and total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with en bloc resection of the adnexal masses. This was followed by HIPEC with mitomycin C. The patient had an uneventful postoperative recovery and was discharged on postoperative day 6.

Pathology revealed primary gallbladder adenocarcinoma, moderately to poorly differentiated, arising in a background of high-grade biliary intraepithelial neoplasm and porcelain gallbladder. The carcinoma extended through the visceral peritoneum onto the serosal surface and into the pericystic soft tissue on the hepatic bed surface. All tumor deposits collected from the operation were consistent with metastasis from the biliary origin. The patient completed four cycles of gemcitabine and cisplatin before switching to FOLFOX after surveillance imaging demonstrated disease progression. The patient presented with an acute abdomen secondary to perforated viscus shortly after receiving the first cycle of FOLFOX and underwent emergent laparotomy. She was subsequently transitioned to hospice. 

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient presented with nonmucinous appendiceal adenocarcinoma after an emergent appendectomy at an outside hospital. Further imaging revealed that the patient had growth in the right ovarian cyst and a new complex cystic/solid mass along the left pelvic sidewall. The patient underwent cytoreductive surgery, which included right hemicolectomy, cholecystectomy, and total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with en bloc resection of the adnexal masses. This was followed by HIPEC with mitomycin C. The pathology revealed primary gallbladder adenocarcinoma, moderately to poorly differentiated, arising in a background of high-grade biliary intraepithelial neoplasm and porcelain gallbladder. The carcinoma extended through the visceral peritoneum onto the serosal surface and into the pericystic soft tissue on the hepatic bed surface. The patient completed four cycles of gemcitabine and cisplatin before switching to FOLFOX after surveillance imaging demonstrated disease progression. The patient presented with an acute abdomen secondary to perforated viscus shortly after receiving the first cycle of FOLFOX and underwent emergent laparotomy. She was subsequently transitioned to hospice.

3-Day Discharge Summary

History and Admission:
The patient is a 33-year-old female living in Fresno, California, with a history of coccidioidal meningitis. She presented to the hospital with diplopia and headache. Upon admission to the Emergency Department, a CT of the head showed hydrocephalus and a right posterior parietal ventriculoperitoneal shunt tube.

Hospital Course:
Lumbar puncture was performed, revealing leukocytes and high protein in the CSF. Additional testing was positive for Coccidioides complement fixation and VDRL. The patient also had a prior history of syphilis that was not appropriately treated. She was started on medications for both CNS infection with Coccidioides and neurosyphilis. Unfortunately, her mental status continued to decline, requiring intubation. An external ventricular drain was placed due to worsening hydrocephalus, but imaging showed bifrontal hemorrhage despite these interventions. The patient was transitioned to comfort-focused care and discharged on hospice care.

Laboratory, Radiology, and ECG Findings:
Leukocytes of 51/uL with lymphocyte predominance were found on CSF analysis. CT imaging showed hydrocephalus and ventriculomegaly with bifrontal hemorrhage.

Impressions and Plan:
The patient's history of coccidioidal meningitis and untreated syphilis led to her presentation with diplopia and headache. Despite treatment for both conditions, her neurological status continued to worsen. Hospice care was initiated, and the patient was discharged.

Hospital Course: 
The patient was admitted to our epilepsy center for evaluation of seizures. After reviewing the video recorded by the patient and his wife, he was found to be experiencing atypical postictal behavior, which was linked to his habitual postictal state. During the admission, EEG redemonstrated interictal generalized spike and polyspike, and slow wave complexes. The patient was diagnosed with genetic generalized epilepsy despite the history suggesting focal epilepsy, and his habitual postictal state that simulated a FS. The patient was discharged with instructions to continue taking his current regimen of levetiracetam, and topiramate was increased to 100 mg total daily. 

Hospital Course Summary: 
The patient was admitted for evaluation of seizures. During the admission, EEG redemonstrated interictal generalized spike and polyspike and slow wave complexes. It was determined that his seizures were due to genetic generalized epilepsy. The patient was discharged with instructions to continue taking his current medication regimen.

[Hospital Course]

The 60-year-old Japanese male patient was admitted due to dyspnea, tachypnea, hypoxemia, and low-grade fever. Blood tests showed leukocytosis, high C-reactive protein levels, and normal liver and renal function. Imaging tests revealed diffuse ground-glass opacification and consolidation in bilateral lung fields. He received noninvasive intermittent positive pressure ventilation and high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone therapy, as well as empiric antibiotics, for an ARDS of unknown etiology.

After 3 days of steroid pulse therapy, the patient significantly improved and was eventually discharged without any symptoms of dyspnea. The steroid was gradually tapered down and discontinued after 7 months.

However, the patient was readmitted in 10 months due to a relapse of dyspnea along with grasping pain in both thighs, proximal muscle weakness in extremities, and elevation of serum creatinine kinase. Imaging tests showed a mixture of diffuse ground-glass opacification and consolidation similar to previous roentgenological patterns. Although the Euroline myositis line blot assay showed negative results for either myositis-specific or myositis-associated antibodies, the short-tau inversion recovery sequence (STIR) of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed inflammatory changes in both hamstring muscles.

Again, after 3 days of high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone therapy, the patient's dyspnea and muscle weakness improved dramatically and the diffuse abnormal shadows in the chest CT scan and high signal on STIR MRI of the hamstring muscles disappeared. The steroid was gradually tapered down, and the patient was discharged without respiratory and muscular symptoms after 26 days.

 [Summary]

The 60-year-old Japanese male patient was admitted twice for dyspnea and respiratory distress and diagnosed with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) of unknown etiology and a relapse of ARDS along with an initial manifestation of seronegative polymyositis (PM). The patient received high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone therapy, which effectively treated both episodes. Imaging and blood tests were performed to evaluate the patient's condition.

The patient was discharged after a complete resolution of symptoms without any complications and had no further medical issues after the last admission.

Hospital Course:

This 70-year-old Caucasian woman was admitted to the hospital with right-sided weakness, paresthesias, blurry vision, and dysarthria. MRI imaging of the brain revealed an enhancing, hypercellular mass in the left thalamus with additional signal abnormalities and enhancement in the cortex of the left frontal lobe and subcortical white matter that was concerning for an intracranial neoplastic process. CT imaging of the head, chest, abdomen, and pelvis did not show evidence of lymphadenopathy or neoplastic processes elsewhere. Lumbar puncture for cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) analysis with flow cytometry showed mostly T cells without evidence of B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

The patient finally underwent left parietal stereotactic brain biopsy, which showed diffuse aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma with positive immunohistochemical studies for CD20, CD23, BCL-6, MUM1, and LE1 and approximately 80% of cells expressing Ki-67 proliferation antigen. The patient began treatment with oral dexamethasone and underwent whole brain radiation therapy (WBRT) while continuing systemic treatment with ibrutinib.

The repeat MRI of the brain two months later showed near resolution of the patient's lymphoma with only a few small foci of nonspecific enhancement adjacent to the biopsy cavity within the left thalamus and no evidence of mass effect, midline shift, or abnormal extra-axial collection. Discharge instructions were given, and the patient was advised to follow up with the oncologist for continued monitoring.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for evaluation of penile pain that extended to the perineal and inguinal regions, which was more severe during erection. During physical examination, no pathologic findings were detected. Subsequent ultrasound evaluation showed thrombosis of the deep dorsal penile vein. Laboratory tests were conducted, revealing normal levels of fibrinogen, anti-thrombin III, protein S, Protein C, and normal platelets and white blood cell counts. Tests were also negative for anti-phospholipid-IgG, IgM, and lupus anticoagulant.

The patient was started on the Rivaroxaban treatment with the dosage of 15 mg twice a day immediately after diagnosis. Two months after starting the treatment, the patient's symptoms improved and he no longer reported any penile pain during erection or sexual disturbances. Follow-up ultrasound evaluation revealed a partial thrombosis at the proximal part of the vein, and mild pain was noted at the site of the partial thrombosis with the pressure of the ultrasound probe.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Deep dorsal penile vein thrombosis

Discharge Condition:
The patient's condition improved with the use of Rivaroxaban and he was discharged in a stable condition.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient should continue to take Rivaroxaban as prescribed. It is important to report any new or worsening symptoms to the healthcare provider. The patient should also continue monitoring for any side effects of the medication.

Follow-up Care:
The patient will follow-up with his primary care physician for further evaluation and monitoring. Further follow-up with the urologist may be necessary depending on the outcome of the follow-up evaluations.

Primary Care Physician Name: N/A
Urologist Name: N/A
Disposition: Discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 45-year-old male

Admission Date: [DATE]

Discharge Date: [DATE]

Reason for Admission: Postural instability and dysarthria 

Medical History: Rheumatic mitral stenosis (since 2005), Penicillin allergy 

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the emergency department with postural instability and dysarthria, which led to a widened support polygon to avoid falling. The patient also reported dyspnea at effort, which occurred 3 days before admission. The initial examination found the patient conscious with a heart rate of 125 b/m and a blood pressure of 135/85 mm Hg. The patient was polypneic and orthopneic with a respiratory rate of 28 breaths/min, an O2 saturation of 96% on ambient air with bilateral crackles. The patient had a fever measured at 39.5C. Cardiac auscultation revealed a low-pitched diastolic rumble heard at the apex. The neurologic examination revealed an unsteady gait and the patient was unable to perform Romberg's test.

Tests and Procedures:

The ECG showed coarse-mesh atrial fibrillation with an average ventricular rate of 90 cycles per minute. The chest X-ray did not show any abnormalities. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) found rheumatic changes of the mitral valve, including commissural fusion and thickening. Also, the patient had a mobile vegetation measuring 11.7 mm of length, located in the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve. The left atrium was dilated at 47 cm2 while size and function of the left ventricle was normal. Pulmonary arterial systolic pressure (PASP) was important, and the filling pressures of the left ventricle were elevated. In addition to that, moderate aortic stenosis and regurgitation and mitral regurgitation at grade A were reported. A brain MRI was performed, showing a recent ischemic stroke involving the right peduncular territory associated with chronic lacunar infarcts.

Diagnosis:

The diagnosis of infective endocarditis was made based on the modified Duke criteria (1 major clinical criteria +3 minors clinical criteria).

Treatment:

Antibiotic therapy was started combining Vancomycin at 30mg/kg/day for 6 weeks and Gentamicin at 3mg/kg/day for 2 weeks, in addition to intravenous diuretics with a strict control of kalaemia. Enoxaparin was started at a curative dose for the supraventricular arrhythmia. 

Outcome:

Within 4 days, the fever disappeared, and the patient's postural instability and dysarthria were less important than at admission. Routine TTEs showed a regression of the vegetation and a normalization of the left ventricular pressures. The patient was satisfied after the improvement of his clinical condition and was addressed to the cardiovascular surgery department for surgical treatment of his valve disease.

Follow-up Care:

The patient was discharged from the hospital with no complications and was advised to continue follow-up care with his primary care physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 29 years
Gender: Female

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of a left cervical swelling that had been present for 11 months. The mass was painless and had grown rapidly after the end of the breastfeeding period. The patient's family history was unremarkable for cancer. The cervical examination showed a postero-lateral mass of the left neck measuring 6 cm in diameter, painless, of firm consistency, unilobed, soft, adherent to the superficial and deep plane. There was no palpable cervical lymphadenopathy or inflammatory signs of the adjacent skin. Further investigation through cervical MRI revealed a mass of the left posterior cervical soft parts and multiple homolateral supraclavicular and lateral cervical lymph nodes. A biopsy of the mass was performed and concluded as desmoid tumor. Abdominopelvic and thoracic CT scans showed no other progressive lesions elsewhere.

Treatment:
A large resection of the tumor was indicated, and the patient underwent surgery through a direct surgical approach. The mass was found to originate from the trapezius muscle without local infiltration of surrounding structures. Complete excision of the mass was accomplished, involving the fascia and trapezius muscle. A close suction drain was placed, and the patient's safety margins were macroscopically healthy. The post-operative outcomes were simple without any complications, and the patient was discharged from the hospital on postoperative day 5.

Follow-up:
After a three-month follow-up examination, no local or distant tumor recurrence was found. The case was analyzed by a multidisciplinary committee, and it was decided to follow the patient without any adjuvant treatment, given its long-term side-effects and the safety margins are healthy.

Diagnosis:
Desmoid tumor

Disposition:
Patient was discharged in a satisfactory condition with instructions to follow up regularly with her treating physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted with a history of severe traumatic brain injury two years ago. He had been undergoing regular rehabilitation treatment to improve his motor functions and mobility.

Hospital Course:
During his hospital stay, the patient received physical therapy to support his rehabilitation efforts. The rehabilitation consisted of electrical stimulation, resistance training and endurance conditioning exercises such as stationary bike and walking on the treadmill. At the time of admission, he was dependent on a wheeled walker and ankle foot orthosis. The patient demonstrated right hemiplegia and had significant difficulty with writing. He also displayed aphasia, bradykinesia, and dyscoordination of movements in his right upper and lower extremities.  Despite these issues, he was able to effectively grasp and grip objects with his right hand and arm.

Discharge Condition:
The patient exhibits good recovery potential and his motor functions have improved over time. While still unable to walk or stand independently, the patient has demonstrated progress with his rehabilitation and has shown a desire for continued recovery.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged home with outpatient rehabilitation care.

Follow-Up Plan:
The patient will continue to receive outpatient rehabilitation treatment to improve his motor functions and mobility.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 53-year-old male, was admitted with a pruritic rash on the trunk and upper and lower extremities. Physical examination revealed lichenified papules throughout the trunk and extremities, most notably on the back. Biopsies of the rash showed mild spongiosis with an underlying superficial and deep perivascular infiltrate.

Treatment:
Initial treatment with topical halobetasol, topical tacrolimus, oral antihistamines, prednisone, and mycophenolate mofetil did not provide significant improvement. Dupilumab was initiated at standard dosing, which resulted in significant improvement of the patient's rash and pruritus within three months. Mild pruritus between injections and minimal residual post-inflammatory hyperpigmented macules were reported. However, due to insurance reasons, dupilumab was stopped after 1 year, and the initial pruritic rash returned. After insurance reapproval, dupilumab was restarted, leading to complete resolution of the rash and pruritus.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient should follow up with their primary care physician or dermatologist as recommended. They should continue to avoid any known allergens or irritants that may exacerbate their symptoms in the future. The patient should also comply with medication regimens and report any side effects or adverse reactions to their healthcare provider. 

Follow-up Plan:
The patient is advised to follow up with their dermatologist or primary care physician for regular checkups to monitor their condition. They will continue receiving treatment with dupilumab as prescribed to maintain control over their rash and pruritus symptoms. 

Signed, 
[Physician Name] MD
[Medical Institution/Practice]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 43 years
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Admitting Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Hospital: [REDACTED]

Medical History:
The patient had a 1-year history of a pruritic rash affecting her legs and abdomen. Her medical history was unremarkable.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for evaluation of the pruritic rash. On examination, the patient had erythematous, blanchable papules coalescing into small plaques on her abdomen and distal part of the legs. Biopsy revealed superficial perivascular lymphocytes with abundant interstitial eosinophils consistent with DHR.

Patch testing was performed and the results were 2+ for nickel sulfate and 1+ for p-tert-butylphenol formaldehyde resin, but the rash was persistent even with allergen avoidance. The patient was treated with multiple topical regimens, including triamcinolone and clobetasol, as well as oral prednisone, but failed to achieve complete resolution.

The patient was then started on mycophenolate mofetil therapy, which resulted in excellent control but poor gastrointestinal tolerance. Subsequently, dupilumab was started at standard dosing. After 5 months of treatment, the patient's rash and pruritus had completely resolved without any side effects.

Summary:
The patient presented with a pruritic rash that persisted even with allergen avoidance. Biopsy results were consistent with DHR. The patient failed to achieve complete resolution with multiple topical regimens, including oral prednisone and mycophenolate mofetil therapy, due to poor tolerability. Dupilumab was initiated and resulted in excellent control of the rash without any side effects.

Follow-Up:
The patient was discharged with an appointment for follow-up in 1 month.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
ID Number: N/A
Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Reason for Admission: The patient was admitted with a 1-year history of recurrent diffuse, pruritic rash.

History of Present Illness: The patient presented with a generalized eruption of erythematous papules with minimal scale on the extremities and trunk particularly the flanks. Initial differential diagnosis included hypersensitivity dermatitis, contact dermatitis, non-bullous pemphigoid, atopic dermatitis, and Grover disease. A biopsy was performed on the left part of the chest and revealed a predominantly perivascular inflammatory infiltrate with occasional eosinophils consistent with DHR. A direct immunofluorescence test was negative.

Hospital Course: The patient failed multiple therapies, including topical triamcinolone, clobetasol, and hydroxyzine. Oral prednisone helped but was discontinued due to steroid-induced diabetes. The patient was started on dupilumab 300 mg injections every 14 days and within 4 months, his dermatitis and pruritus resolved. Due to cost, the injections were spaced to every 30 days, and he continued to experience resolution of his symptoms without any side effect from the medication.

Discharge Condition: The patient's dermatitis and pruritus resolved with the treatment of dupilumab 300 mg injections every 14 days.

Follow-up: N/A

Signed,
Dr. [Doctor's name]
Date: N/A

Patient Information:
78-year-old male who presented with a history of extreme pruritus and mild lichenification on the upper chest and lower back with faint pink patches. 

Clinical Course:
Upon presentation, patch testing was performed, and a biopsy was taken, revealing mild acanthosis and minimal spongiosis with a perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate containing rare eosinophils, consistent with a DHR. The patient received multiple therapies before being started on dupilumab, with dramatic improvement in pruritus and a 50%-60% reduction of the rash within the first 2 months with no associated side effects. 

Treatment:
The patient failed multiple therapies including topical corticosteroids, antihistamines, doxepin, narrow-band UV-B light, doxepin, gabapentin, butorphanol, and aprepitant. The patient was then started on dupilumab and remains stable on this medication. Azathioprine was poorly tolerated due to fatigue. 

Follow-Up:
The patient will continue follow-up with his physician for management of his condition.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Patient Information:
Name: [insert name]
Age: 31 years
Gender: Female
Race: African American
Medical History: therapeutic abortions (2), spontaneous abortion (1), familial history of cervical cancer and endometrial cancer

Chief Complaint:
Vaginal bleeding at 22-weeks gestation

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to an outside hospital due to vaginal bleeding at 22-weeks gestation. Physical examination revealed pelvic pain and uterine contractions, and the patient subsequently expelled a mass vaginally with no fetal contents. Pathology results from the previous hospital showed that the mass was highly cellular and composed of spindle-shaped and multinucleated giant cells with focal myxomatous change. The differential diagnosis included endometrial stromal sarcoma, undifferentiated uterine sarcoma, and primary vaginal sarcoma. The patient underwent examination under anesthesia which demonstrated active bleeding from a defect of the posterior vaginal wall. The cervix was long, closed, and high with no evidence of bleeding, and the fetus had normal heart tones. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

At 27-weeks gestation, the patient was referred to our institution for maternal-fetal medicine and gynecology oncology consultation. She denied any prior gynecologic history or history of infertility issues, and her physical examination was unremarkable. Given the differential diagnosis, MRI was performed which revealed a peri-centimeter cyst in the cervix and a multiloculated cystic structure in the fetal abdomen with no evidence of metastasis. Due to the inability to determine the origin of the cancer, the decision was made to perform a cesarean hysterectomy at 36 weeks. Betamethasone was administered 24 hours apart for two doses as preparation for the procedure.

At 36 weeks and 1 day, the patient underwent a planned exam under anesthesia of the vaginal canal with cesarean hysterectomy, bilateral salpingectomy, and peritoneal biopsies. A male infant was delivered and admitted to NICU due to prematurity. The patient had no palpable or visibly enlarged pelvic/periaortic lymph nodes or evidence of metastatic disease throughout the peritoneal cavity. The final surgical pathology report showed no malignant or neoplastic cells.

At the 3-month follow-up surveillance visit, the patient was noted to have a 1 cm posterior vaginal wall lesion. A biopsy revealed a high-grade sarcoma that was positive for estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor. CT scan showed no evidence of metastatic disease, and the patient underwent an upper vaginectomy and proctoscopy. Surgical pathology showed residual sarcoma morphologically similar to the original pathology. All other vaginal biopsies were negative for malignancy. The patient was treated with high dose rate vaginal brachytherapy using a multi-channel vaginal cylinder. A CT scan 36 months after surgery showed no evidence of disease, and the patient remains disease-free 58 months after completion of vaginal brachytherapy.

Discharge Diagnosis:
High-grade sarcoma of the posterior vaginal wall, treated with upper vaginectomy and proctoscopy and high dose rate vaginal brachytherapy

Follow-Up:
The patient is advised to attend regular follow-up appointments with her gynecologist and oncologist.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
MR#: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 55-year-old male with a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and unspecified autoimmune disease, was admitted due to acute onset of confusion, visual hallucinations, and behavioral change. The patient was evaluated and MRI of the brain revealed multifocal areas of restricted diffusion with partial suppression of CSF signal on fluid-attenuated inversion recovery sequence suggestive of superimposed inflammatory process affecting the meninges. In addition, there was abnormal vessel wall thickening and enhancement. LP was performed, which demonstrated a lymphocytic pleocytosis and abnormal opening pressure. India ink was performed on the CSF, which revealed a small number of encapsulated yeasts. The patient was subsequently diagnosed with cryptococcal meningoencephalitis and treated with appropriate anti-fungal medications.

Medical Management:
The patient was started on a four-week regimen of amphotericin B and flucytosine followed by eight weeks of fluconazole. The opening pressure was monitored daily with daily LPs to keep it less than 20 cm H20.

Discharge Status:
The patient's mental status was notably improved and closer to neurologic baseline after completing treatment and was subsequently discharged to an inpatient rehabilitation facility.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient will follow up with their primary care physician and specialists as needed upon discharge. Further neurologic evaluations will be scheduled to assess for any residual deficits.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient, a 35-year-old male with a history of high cholesterol and seizure disorder, presented to our hospital following multiple cerebral infarcts in multiple vascular territories. MRI of the brain showed new areas of diffusion restriction in the left cerebellar hemisphere and left medial occipital lobe. The etiology of his multifocal strokes was thought to be related to his newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation and left atrial thrombus.

Additional investigations revealed the presence of cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, with a mildly elevated opening pressure, lymphocytic pleocytosis, and hypoglycorrhachia. The patient was diagnosed with cryptococcal meningoencephalitis and started on a four-week course of amphotericin B and flucytosine. A repeat LP after several days of treatment showed mildly improved pleocytosis. He did not require any additional lumbar punctures, and his symptoms gradually improved.

To manage the patient's condition, we discharged him to an inpatient rehabilitation facility before returning home.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 71 years
Sex: Male

Medical History:
- Hypertension
- Diabetes mellitus

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for a two-week history of painless right submandibular swelling that was not associated with fever. Clinical examination revealed a right submandibular swelling with normal overlying skin measuring 6 × 5 cm that was non-tender, mobile, and firm in consistency. Pus was noted at the Wharton’s duct orifice, and no sialolith was palpable.

Preoperative blood investigations, electrocardiography, and chest radiographs were normal. A CT scan of the neck was performed, which showed opacity in the right submandibular gland and duct. A diagnosis of right submandibular stone was made, and the patient underwent excision of the right submandibular gland under general anesthesia. 

Intraoperatively, the right submandibular gland was indurated. During the excision, the surgeon noted another firm bulge along the submandibular duct that turned out to be a few smaller pieces of stones within the duct. The size of the largest stone was 25 mm.

Postoperative recovery was uneventful. Histopathology examination revealed severe acute-on-chronic sialadenitis with multiple calculi.

Plan & Recommendations:
- The patient was discharged and advised to follow-up with his primary care physician regularly for management of his hypertension and diabetes mellitus.
- No further recommendations.

Follow-Up:
- Follow-up visit to the primary care physician was scheduled.

Signed,
Dr. [redacted]
Attending Physician.

Hospital Course:
42-year-old male presented to the emergency department with abdominal pain and diarrhea, with symptoms starting three days prior. Pertinent positives included pain in the periumbilical region, gradually worsening pain progressions, and tenderness in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. He had low-grade fever, decreased appetite, and diarrhea, which developed following oral antibiotic therapy for an upper respiratory tract infection. On examination, the patient appeared sick with tachycardia, diffuse tenderness on the abdominal examination, elevated leukocyte count and inflammatory markers. CT scan confirmed the diagnosis of cecal lipoma and acute appendicitis, and he was prepared for an emergency laparoscopy. The patient underwent surgery with no complications, resulting in limited segmental resection of the cecum and appendectomy. Histopathological examination of the resected sample confirmed the cecal lipoma and acute appendicitis diagnosis. After an uneventful recovery, the patient was discharged on the fifth postoperative day and followed up after three months, remaining asymptomatic with no active issues.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

History:
A 29-year-old non-gravid woman with a complaint of a lump in her right breast, low-grade fever, and unilateral pain in breast tissue presented to the hospital. The patient was evaluated by USG and cystic fluid aspiration, and the presumptive diagnosis of acute mastitis with underlying bacterial abscess was established. The patient was initially treated with a course of antibiotics and antipyretics for one week.

Hospital Course:
The patient's condition worsened over time, and she was referred to a teaching hospital for a surgical consult. Surgery was performed to drain pus collection and excisional tissue biopsy after surgical resection of the mass. The excisional biopsy material was sent to histopathology, which showed areas of acute and chronic inflammation along with predominant lobulocentric granulomatous inflammation. The diagnosis of idiopathic granulomatous mastitis was established, and the patient was treated with corticosteroids (prednisolone) as part of her drug dosage regimen. The patient was followed up monthly for the next three months, evaluated for improvement in clinical symptoms, and underwent a USG scan, which showed complete resolution of the lesion with no abnormal findings.

Summary:
A 29-year-old woman presented with a lump in her right breast and was diagnosed with acute mastitis with underlying bacterial abscess. Despite treatment with antibiotics and antipyretics, her condition worsened, and she was referred to a teaching hospital for a surgical consult. Post-surgery, the patient was diagnosed with idiopathic granulomatous mastitis and treated with corticosteroids (prednisolone). After three months of follow-up and evaluation of clinical symptoms, the patient's USG scan showed complete resolution of the lesion with no abnormal findings.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Patient’s Name]
Age: 58 years
Gender: Male

Hospital Course:
[Patient’s Name] was admitted to the hospital after referral from a urologist due to a painless enlarging mass at the right groin region. An MRI showed a focal subcutaneous lesion with nodular morphology but with no malignancy features. The patient underwent an excisional biopsy, and the tumor was removed along with surrounding adipose tissue.

Diagnosis:
Based on the pathological examination, [Patient’s Name] was diagnosed with an atypical pleomorphic lipomatous tumor. The tumor was subcutaneous, nodular, non-capsulated, multilobulated, well-circumscribed, and greyish-yellowish, with a variable amount of atypical bland spindle cells and mature adipocytes. Multinucleated floret-like cells were present in a myxoid stroma with ropey collagen bundle cells. Sclerosing areas were not found.

Treatment:
The tumor was surgically removed along with surrounding adipose tissue, and margins were preserved. No complications associated with the procedure were noted.

Follow-Up:
The patient will be scheduled for follow-up appointments to monitor the affected area for any recurrence or development of any new lesions.

Summary:
[Patient’s Name] presented with a painless enlarging mass at the right groin region, which was diagnosed as an atypical pleomorphic lipomatous tumor. The patient underwent an excisional biopsy, and the tumor was removed along with surrounding adipose tissue. No complications associated with the procedure were noted, and the patient will be scheduled for follow-up appointments to monitor the affected area for any recurrence or development of any new lesions.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 15 years
Gender: Female
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

ADM: The patient was admitted to the pediatric cardiac surgery clinic with a confirmed diagnosis of CCL syndrome since birth. At the time of admission, she presented with cardiovascular symptoms including shortness of breath, palpitations, and chest pain.

HOSPITAL COURSE: The patient underwent a midline sternotomy procedure under general anesthesia. The procedure involved the resection of the thymus due to its enormous size and standard cannulation through the ascending aorta and superior and inferior vena cava. Cardioplegic arrest with full flow of cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) was induced for the patient. The surgical team examined the aortic valve and found some significant enlargement and dilatation of the leaflet; however, no intervention was performed as the valve was manually competent. The surgical team also identified significant enlargement of both atria, and as a result, resected right and left atrial appendages in combination with atrioplasty.

The surgical team opened the left atrium, examined the mitral valve, and found significant myxomatous changes of both anterior and posterior leaflets. The valve was deemed irreparable, and the decision was made intraoperatively to replace the mitral valve with a 33-mm St. Jude Medical Epic porcine valve prosthesis. After this, the team performed commissural tricuspid annuloplasty on the tricuspid valve which rendered it competent. The patient was fully rewarmed and weaned off CPB with trace tricuspid regurgitation observed on intraoperative TEE.

POST-PROCEDURE: The patient was transferred to the cardiac surgery intensive care unit (CSICU) and monitored for stability. During the first 15 hours in the CSICU, the chest tubes drained blood with a total of 1,450 mL (right lower pleura), 300 mL (mediastinum), and 1,330 mL (left lower pleura). The bleeding was controlled after the patient received five units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs), seven units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP), two units of cryoprecipitated antihemophilic factor (Cryo), two units of platelets, and two doses of intravenous protamine sulfate (50 mg per dose). The patient was subsequently shifted from the CSICU to the ward on postoperative day 3 (POD 3) and monitored for normal lab values.

DISCHARGE CONDITION: The patient's chest drains were removed subsequently, and she was able to resume normal activity. Predischarge transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showed no significant changes, and the patient was deemed satisfactory for discharge. The patient was discharged home on POD 6 and advised to follow the prescribed postoperative care plan. She was provided with instructions for taking care of any wounds and incisions that need monitoring. Additionally, the patient was advised to contact the clinic immediately if she experiences any sudden worsening of symptoms that require medical attention.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS/TREATMENT: Mitral and tricuspid valve replacement with a 33-mm St. Jude Medical Epic porcine valve prosthesis and commissural tricuspid annuloplasty performed for CCL syndrome.

FOLLOW-UP PLANS: The patient was advised to follow up with the clinic for further evaluation and counseling with a medical geneticist. She was scheduled for regular check-ups to monitor her condition and recovery progress.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Date of admission: [Redacted]

Date of discharge: [Redacted]

Admission Diagnosis: Acute heart failure secondary to dilated cardiomyopathy

Hospital Course: 

The patient is an 11-year-old boy who presented with palpitations, easy fatigability, and chest discomfort with a history of Crohn's disease. An echocardiogram confirmed acute heart failure secondary to dilated cardiomyopathy with severe mitral regurgitation and an ejection fraction of 21%. The patient received anti-failure medications and was discharged home with regular pediatric cardiology and pediatric hematology follow-up.

Summary of Hospitalization: 

The patient was admitted to our hospital with palpitations, easy fatigability, and chest discomfort. The investigations revealed acute heart failure secondary to dilated cardiomyopathy with severe mitral regurgitation and an ejection fraction of 21%. The patient was started on anti-failure medications and discharged home with regular follow-up planned with pediatric cardiology and pediatric hematology departments. 

Discharge Instructions: 

1. Follow up with pediatric cardiology and pediatric hematology departments regularly 
2. Continue taking prescribed medications as directed 
3. Follow a healthy and balanced diet
4. Avoid strenuous activities or activities that may cause excessive fatigue 
5. Monitor for any signs or symptoms of worsening symptoms 
6. Seek medical attention immediately if there are any concerns. 

Follow-up instructions: 

The patient will receive follow-up care from the pediatric cardiology, pediatric hematology and, the possibility of starting a different anti-tumor necrosis factor agent ustekinumab should be discussed with pediatric gastroenterology specialist as needed. 

Signed, 

[Redacted]

Hospital Course:

In September 2020, a 42-year-old male with a history of an inguinal hernia was referred to our Department of Internal Medicine due to a finding in a chest X-ray. The patient was found to have a solitary pulmonary nodule in the right mid-lung that was 2 cm in diameter.

Physical Examination:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for further evaluation. His vital signs were stable, and he had no malignancy-related symptoms. A physical examination showed no abnormalities, and he was asymptomatic.

Diagnostic Evaluations:

Blood tests showed no significant abnormalities, except for an elevated C-reactive protein of 83 mg/dL. A chest X-ray showed a solitary pulmonary nodule in the right upper lobe. The patient underwent a CT scan, which revealed ground glass opacities that suggested either inflammatory or infectious conditions, similar to atypical pneumonia. A second RT-PCR test was positive for COVID-19 pneumonia.

Treatment and Management:

The patient was discharged with no treatment after 5 days, as his examination was normal with stable vital signs and laboratory blood tests. The patient attended a follow-up in our outpatient clinic with a new chest X-ray and new laboratory blood tests 10 days after discharge, which showed complete resolution of the pneumonia.

Conclusion:

Based on diagnostic findings, the patient was diagnosed with COVID-19 pneumonia. The patient had a positive test for IgG against SARS-CoV-2 after the resolution of pneumonia. The patient received no treatment and was discharged with complete resolution of his condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: Not provided
Age: 27 years
Sex: Female

Hospital Course:
This patient presented with a slowly growing abdominal lump with no other symptoms except for fullness of the abdomen after taking food and weight loss. Clinical examination revealed a large, non-tender, soft cystic swelling occupying the entire upper abdomen. On radiological investigations, ultrasonogram (USG) showed a complex cystic mass with internal septation. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) abdomen showed a large multiseptated cystic lesion occupying almost the entire abdomen and adhered to the pancreas with mass effect. The lesion was well defined, lobulated, hypodense in nature, and associated with main pancreatic duct dilatation. USG-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) revealed straw-colored aspirate with mature lymphocytes. After the complete preoperative workup, the patient underwent surgical exploration. On exploration, there was a large multiloculated cystic lesion extending through gastrocolic omentum, pushing the stomach up and transverse colon downwards with hundreds of cystic spaces containing lymphatic fluid. Cysts were decompressed, and the entire lesion was excised. The anterior surface of the pancreas was forming the base of the lesion. Postoperatively, the patient had continued lymphatic discharge from the abdominal drain, and the patient was discharged with it.

Clinical Findings:
On radiological investigations, ultrasonogram (USG) showed a complex cystic mass with internal septation. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) abdomen showed a large multiseptated cystic lesion occupying almost the entire abdomen and associated with main pancreatic duct dilatation. USG-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) revealed straw-colored aspirate with mature lymphocytes. The final histopathological examination showed unremarkable pancreatic tissue with attached lesion consisting of dilated lymphatic spaces with lymphatic follicles in the wall, with congested blood vessels and fibrocollagenous tissue with chronic inflammatory infiltrate. Cytocentrifuged smears from fluid showed lymphocytes, and no malignant or atypical cells were seen.

Outcomes:
The surgical exploration led to a complete excision of the entire lesion. Postoperatively, the patient had continued lymphatic discharge from the abdominal drain, and the patient was discharged with it. During the follow-up in the outpatient department, the drain output gradually decreased over two weeks and was eventually removed.

Diagnosis:
Not provided

Recommendations:
Not provided

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Patient Name]
Date of Admission: [Date of Admission]
Date of Discharge: [Date of Discharge]
Attending Physician: [Name of Attending Physician]

Hospital Course Summary:
A 58-year-old female patient with past medical history of diabetes and hypertension was admitted to the hospital for evaluation of an enlarging left breast mass that she first noticed three years ago. The patient reported a progressive increase in size of the mass in the past few months along with 34 pounds weight loss over the last nine months. Physical examination revealed a palpable breast mass of approximately 3 centimeters in the tail of the left breast with no other significant physical findings.

Laboratory tests showed normal WBC count, absolute lymphocyte count of 4400/mL, hemoglobin levels within normal range and slightly higher platelet count. Prior mammograms and ultrasounds were inconclusive and did not show any suspicious calcifications or architectural distortions.

The patient underwent percutaneous breast biopsy, which revealed diffuse atypical small lymphocytic cells. Subsequent immunohistochemical staining revealed neoplastic lymphoma cells positive for CD20, CD5, CD23, PAX5, CD4, BCL2, and negative for CD3, CD10, BCL1 and BCL6. The bone marrow biopsy showed diffuse involvement with small lymphocytic lymphoma. Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) studies revealed trisomy 12 cytogenetic abnormality. CT imaging revealed extensive mediastinal lymphadenopathy and retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy.

The final diagnosis was primary small lymphocytic lymphoma of the breast with bone marrow involvement, Stage 4. She was treated with the FCR regimen comprising of fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, and rituximab which resulted in clinical and radiologic remission. The breast mass was no longer palpable, and repeat CT scans did not reveal any evidence of pathological lymphadenopathy.

Discharge Diagnosis: 
The patient was diagnosed with small lymphocytic lymphoma (Stage 4), with bone marrow involvement.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged with stable medical condition.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to have follow-up visits with her oncologist for regular check-ups and surveillance. She was instructed to follow up with CT scans and other oncologic evaluations per the recommendation of the treating physician. She was also advised to continue taking her regular medications for diabetes and hypertension as prescribed. 

Signed,
Attending Physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Anonymous
Medical Record Number: 123456

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]
Length of Stay: [#] days
Discharging Provider: Dr. [Name]

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 41-month-old infant girl who was admitted to the hospital with progressive bullous itchy skin rash, associated with cough, rhinorrhea, and a fever. The patient had decreased urine output and oral intake but without any gastrointestinal complications. The diagnosis of bullous impetigo was made by the attending physician. The patient was given intravenous antibiotics and diphenhydramine for the rash. The patient showed clinical improvement in three days and was discharged on oral antibiotics.

The patient has a medical history of THES (Trichohepatoenteric Syndrome) confirmed by whole exons sequence analysis. She presented to the hospital at the age of six months with weight loss and diarrhea. The patient was misdiagnosed with cow milk protein allergy and was started on hypoallergenic formula. The diagnosis of THES was later confirmed, and she was switched to amino acid-based infant formula. She was admitted at 12 months of age for dehydration and nasogastric tube feeding due to poor weight gain. The patient was discharged, with instructions to continue the hypoallergenic formula and a regular diet.

At the time of discharge, the patient's weight and height were 10 kg (<3rd percentile) and 85 cm (<3rd percentile), respectively. She was able to tolerate normal oral feeding. She did not show any signs of intellectual disability and is developmentally up to her age now. She is active and plays with her cousins. She can speak and understand both Arabic and English, and according to the mother, she is starting to memorize songs.

Plan:
The patient will be discharged on oral antibiotics that should be administered as prescribed by the attending physician. The patient's mother was instructed to continue hypoallergenic baby formulas and a regular diet. The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care physician in two weeks for a recheck. The patient's parents were informed of the importance of regular well-child visits, and they were provided with a list of recommended child care practices.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]  
Patient Age: 49  
Admission Date: MM/DD/YYYY  
Discharge Date: MM/DD/YYYY  

Admitting Diagnosis: Cirrhosis


Hospital Course:
The patient presented with complaints of fever, abdominal bloating, and weight loss, and was diagnosed with cirrhosis at a local hospital. Upon deterioration, the patient was referred to our center, where she presented with swollen legs, mild hepatomegaly, and huge splenomegaly. Complete blood count revealed thrombocytopenia and lymphocytosis. Bone marrow biopsy revealed lymphocytic infiltration, and cytogenetic testing showed a normal karyotype. 
Flow cytometric analysis of the bone marrow suggested T-cell large granular lymphocytic leukemia. The patient received methotrexate treatment for one month, which resulted in amelioration of the clinical condition, including no fever, regression of splenomegaly, and an increasing proportion of neutrophils. The patient was given outpatient treatment and kept being examined monthly.

Discharge Diagnosis:
T-cell large granular lymphocytic leukemia

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Medications:
Not applicable.

Follow-up:
The patient is to continue outpatient treatment and examination monthly.  Any further concerns or questions should be directed to their primary care physician.

Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow up regularly with their primary care physician and maintain a healthy lifestyle. Any new or concerning symptoms should be reported to their physician immediately.

Hospital Course:

This 50-year-old male patient presented with a painless visual field defect in his right eye related to nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION). He had a past medical history of diabetes and displayed elevated serum HbA1c levels, and a comprehensive ophthalmic examination with fundoscopy revealed swelling in the right optic disc. A computed tomography of the brain and orbit was performed to rule out compressive optic neuropathy. Treatment was initiated with intravenous steroids. Three months after the initial presentation, the patient experienced worsening visual field disturbances in his right eye and reported impaired red saturation and light brightness. He exhibited a relative afferent pupillary defect with a pale right optic disc on examination. Furthermore, the HVF test revealed a tunnel vision in his right eye and an inferior arcuate scotoma in his left eye. Methylprednisolone was administered daily for five days and oral steroids were gradually tapered. During one-month follow-up, VA remained consistent and the left eye showed the resolving of optic disc swelling; however, the patient's left eye visual field continued to deteriorate to inferior altitudinal scotoma. After conducting a lumbar puncture test and multiple MRIs, it was concluded that the patient developed bilateral sequential NAION. Management has been initiated in collaboration with the endocrine department to optimize diabetic status. The final VA reflects right eye tunnel vision and left eye inferior altitudinal scotoma.

Hospital Course
The patient presented to the family medicine clinic with abdominal bloating and persistent diarrhea associated with a failure to gain weight. The initial laboratory investigation revealed elevated liver enzymes and protein levels. Stool analysis and glucose level were normal. The patient was referred to pediatric gastroenterology center for further investigation. Upper endoscopy showed no abnormal gross findings with mild duodenal inflammation in the histopathological examination. Examination of the 72-hour fecal fat collection indicated fat malabsorption. Subsequently, the fecal pancreatic elastase level was measured as 20 fecal μg/g, indicative of exocrine pancreatic dysfunction. Abdominal CT scan of the pancreas demonstrated complete replacement of pancreatic parenchyma by fatty tissue.

Diagnosis and Treatment
The blood sample of the patient was sent for genetic analysis, and the diagnosis of Shwachman-Diamond syndrome was established as the analysis revealed a mutation in the SBDS gene. The patient was treated with pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy. After two months of follow-up, the parents reported that the patient had significant improvement in diarrhea and a weight gain was observed.

Follow-up and Recommendations
The patient will require ongoing management and monitoring of pancreatic insufficiency. Further evaluation and management of the underlying genetic condition will be necessary. Close follow-up with a pediatrician and pediatric gastroenterologist is recommended.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Reason for Hospitalization:
The patient was admitted due to a five-day clinical picture consisting of additive, symmetrical polyarticular pain, located in the wrists, knees, and left shoulder without other associated symptoms.

Hospital Course:
During the hospitalization, the patient underwent magnetic resonance imaging of the different compromised anatomical compartments. The imaging revealed bilateral carpal synovitis, left suprapatellar synovitis, and synovitis of the sternoclavicular joints along with bursitis of the lateral collateral ligament of the left lower limb and a peritendinous inflammatory process of the triangular fibrocartilage in the right wrist. Laboratory studies showed marked elevation of acute-phase reactants. Differential diagnoses of infectious etiology were sought, including a positive fourth-generation HIV enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay with a subsequent CD4 count of 98 cells/mm3 and a viral load of 459,000 copies/mL. Treatment with prednisolone at a dose of 1 mg/kg and sulfasalazine (1 g per day) was initiated, and sequential changes from disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) were made, such as methotrexate and leflunomide, but no significant improvement in joint symptoms was noted. Subsequently, the patient achieved a complete joint response when antiretroviral therapy (abacavir, dolutegravir/lamivudine) was initiated, thereby achieving a response to therapy resulting in gradual reduction of glucocorticoid doses and tapering to maintenance therapy solely with sulfasalazine.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with symmetrical polyarticular pain, synovitis of joints, bursitis, and peritendinous inflammatory process.

Condition at Discharge:
At the time of discharge, the patient's condition was stable, showing a complete joint response.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was referred to an infectious disease specialist for continued antiretroviral therapy.

Instructions:
The patient was instructed to continue antiretroviral therapy and sulfasalazine maintenance therapy. Follow-up was scheduled with the infectious disease specialist.
