Hospital Course:
The patient, a 43-year-old male with no known medical problems, was admitted from an outside hospital with concern for intraabdominal hemorrhage due to an MVC three weeks prior. CT scan showed fluid in the lesser sac suggestive of pancreatic hemorrhage, then he was transferred to the University of Kentucky Medical Center. Interventional radiology was consulted and an arterio-portal fistula in the liver was embolized with Embozene. The patient developed an elevated white blood cell count and increased abdominal distension following the procedure. A repeat CT scan revealed an increase in the size of the lesser sac hematoma and a pseudoaneurysm in the anterior spleen. Coil embolization of the splenic artery was performed with postembolization angiography showing no anterograde flow through the splenic artery. CT scan one month later revealed normal splenic parenchyma, with a persistent hematoma anterior and superior to the spleen.

Summary:
The 43-year-old male presented due to the intraabdominal hemorrhage after an MVC. CT scan showed fluid in the lesser sac suggestive of pancreatic hemorrhage. The patient underwent embolization of the liver arterio-portal fistula, but complications were noted. Thereafter, coil embolization of the splenic artery was performed with postembolization angiography showing no anterograde flow. CT scan one month later revealed normal splenic parenchyma and persistent hematoma anterior and superior to the spleen. Subsequently, the patient expired due to multiple myeloma confirmed with a bone marrow biopsy specimen.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with chronic nasal obstruction and hyposmia on the left side, which had been present for six months. The symptoms were not relieved by self-administered medications. On clinical examination, a bump was noted along the floor of the left nasal cavity. 

Investigations and Diagnostics:
A plain radiograph of the paranasal sinus and nasal cavity revealed a radiopaque focus in the left nasal cavity. A CT scan of paranasal sinuses was performed, revealing a tooth-like bony structure in the hard palate extending into the left inferior nasal cavity, resembling a canine with a relatively smaller size, along with a deviated nasal septum with convexity to the left. An Orthopantomogram showed a tooth-like radiopaque structure, and a three-dimensional computed tomography (3D CT) scan showed a tooth-like structure in the left nasal cavity. The intranasal tooth was supernumerary, with mild mucosal thickening noted in the bilateral maxillary and sphenoid sinuses. 

Treatment and Outcome:
The patient underwent an endoscopic removal of the ectopic intranasal tooth and subsequently had complete resolution of nasal obstruction and hyposmia. 

Follow-up and Recommendations:
Follow-up appointments were scheduled to monitor the patient's symptoms and ensure complete recovery. No further recommendations were given.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the emergency department with severe left iliac fossa pain, nausea, and vomiting. They had a recent laparoscopic bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and it was determined they had a left ureteric iatrogenic injury. An urgent CT-guided nephrostomy insertion was performed due to pain, and a proper antegrade nephrostogram was done three weeks later. A complete transection of the ureteric injury was suspected, and the nephrostomy was left in situ for reconstructive surgery to be scheduled. Eleven weeks post-traumatic injury, the patient underwent a left retrograde study, and it showed an annular stricture at the level of the injury, less than 0.5 cm, which was successfully treated with a ureteric stent.

Hospital Course Summary:

A 56-year-old woman underwent laparoscopic bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and during the procedure, adhesions obscured the anatomy of the left ureter leading to left ureteric iatrogenic injury. One week later, severe left iliac fossa pain and nausea with vomiting prompted the patient to return to the hospital. A CT scan revealed an extravasation of contrast at the level of the left renal pelvis and ureteric dilatation down to the pelvic ureter. Urgent CT-guided nephrostomy insertion was performed to address the pain, and later a diagnosis of complete transection of the ureteric injury was suspected. Reconstruction surgery was planned to resolve the issue, and a stent was inserted to treat the annular stricture discovered during the left retrograde study. The patient was discharged in a stable condition.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 76-year-old female with a history of hypertension, was admitted with persistent forehead swelling, which started two months after her recovery from COVID-19 pneumonia. Further evaluation revealed multifocal sinusitis with breach of the inner and outer tables of the right frontal sinus with dural enhancement. The patient was diagnosed with post-COVID mucormycosis and empirically started on Amphotericin. She underwent surgical debridement twice due to culture results showing extended-spectrum beta-lactamase-producing Escherichia coli, methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. She was discharged on a six-week course of IV vancomycin, PO levofloxacin, and PO posaconazole. Two weeks later, the patient presented with hypokalemia and acute kidney injury, likely due to vancomycin-related renal derangements and potassium wasting. The patient was admitted for fluid resuscitation and switched to daptomycin. Repeat MRI at the end of her antibiotic course demonstrated improvement. However, two weeks later, the patient developed new periorbital swelling and frontal sinus sequestrum formation and was recommended to undergo craniectomy for definitive source control. The patient was restarted on daptomycin and meropenem while awaiting surgery. 

Hospital Course Summary:
- Admitted with persistent forehead swelling two months after recovering from COVID-19 pneumonia
- Multifocal sinusitis with breach of the inner and outer tables of the right frontal sinus with dural enhancement
- Diagnosed with post-COVID mucormycosis and empirically started on Amphotericin
- Underwent surgical debridement twice due to culture results showing extended-spectrum beta-lactamase-producing Escherichia coli, methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa
- Discharged on a six-week course of IV vancomycin, PO levofloxacin, and PO posaconazole
- Presented with hypokalemia and acute kidney injury, likely due to vancomycin-related renal derangements and potassium wasting
- Admitted for fluid resuscitation and switched to daptomycin
- Repeat MRI demonstrated improvement
- Developed new periorbital swelling and frontal sinus sequestrum formation
- Recommended to undergo craniectomy for definitive source control
- Restarted on daptomycin and meropenem while awaiting surgery.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 29
Sex: Male
Medical Record Number: [redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the emergency department following a car accident which resulted in profuse bleeding due to a perineum injury. The investigations revealed no major fractures or internal bleeding. He was taken to the operating theatre where the posterior pelvic floor was found to be completely disrupted. Multiple packs were inserted to manage extensive venous bleeding. The patient underwent a defunctioning sigmoid colostomy and 22 units of blood were required for the first 48 hours. He was followed up for several months during which the wound was managed and healed by granulation. Physiological tests were performed to test the sphincter function which showed a combination of puborectalis and gluteal muscles contraction with resting sphincter pressure of around 30 cmH2O. The presence of rectal sensation was noted. The defecography showed a normal anorectum which was displaced toward the pubic bone. The patient successfully underwent colostomy closure and expressed satisfactory defecation and micturition without incontinence.

Diagnosis:

Perineum injury due to a car accident with posterior pelvic floor disruption.

Treatment:

The patient was immediately taken to the operating theatre for injury assessment. Multiple packs were inserted to manage extensive venous bleeding. A defunctioning sigmoid colostomy was performed. The wound was managed and healed by granulation.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient had a successful colostomy closure and expressed satisfactory defecation and micturition without incontinence.

Follow-up and Recommendations:

The patient is advised to follow-up for regular checkups to ensure continued improvement.

Patient Information:
Age: 44 years old
Gender: Female

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted due to a partial laceration of the posterior perineum that occurred as a result of a car accident.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent a sigmoid colostomy upon admission. Subsequently, she received conservative management procedures, and it was determined that she had adequate home support to be discharged earlier than expected. The patient irrigated her wound daily with handheld bidets and attended follow-up appointments every three weeks. After five months, the wound had shrunk to 1 x 2 cm, and no infections were present.

Follow-Up:
A defecation portogram revealed an anteriorly displaced anus with an anorectal angle of 70°; this angle widened to only 90° on straining, and evacuation was incomplete. However, no atypical rectum descent was noticed, and the patient reported complete evacuation in the toilet after the examination. Seven months post-injury, the colostomy was closed, and the patient reported normal bowel movement with no incontinence experienced. Fifteen months post-injury, the patient reported complete healing of the wound and the occasional use of glycerin suppositories, with no fecal impaction present.

Conclusion:
The patient's condition improved over time, and she was discharged after proper management of her wound. She had several follow-up appointments, which demonstrated the progression of her condition. Ultimately, the patient had complete healing of the wound, and her defecation function was adequate.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [Insert Name]
Age: 25
Sex: Female

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to difficulty in swallowing. She had a history of growth retardation, short stature, microcephaly, and microphthalmia. She was diagnosed with Fanconi anemia when she was five years old, and the diagnosis was confirmed in this admission. She had multiple lymphadenopathies in the bilateral deep cervical lymph nodes, and a tumoral formation in the hypopharynx leading to only a 3 mm passage opening was detected. The patient was diagnosed with T3N2cM0 hypopharyngeal cancer, and curative radiotherapy with concomitant cetuximab chemotherapy was initiated. However, the patient developed progressive cytopenia, and the treatment was terminated. Despite receiving daily G-CSF, her blood counts did not significantly improve, and she had a nasogastric tube placed for feeding. On the 30th day of the start of radiotherapy, her oxygen saturation regressed, and she was intubated. The patient died 40 days after radiotherapy began due to respiratory failure and sepsis.

Diagnosis:
T3N2cM0 hypopharyngeal cancer

Course of Treatment:
The patient underwent curative radiotherapy with concomitant cetuximab chemotherapy. The complete blood count was near-normal at the beginning of RT, with only mild leukopenia. The first cetuximab dose was 350 mg/m2 with RT, and the remaining maintenance dosage was scheduled as 250 mg/m2 but could not be administered due to a sudden drop in blood count. Her treatment was terminated due to progressive cytopenia, after receiving 21.2 Gy in 10 days for the primary lesion. G-CSF was initiated for hematological recovery, and erythrocyte and platelet transfusion was administered when necessary. A nasogastric tube was placed for feeding, in addition to parenteral nutritional support.

Course of Hospitalization:
The patient was admitted to the gastroenterology department due to difficulty in swallowing. Stenosis was observed in the hypopharynx that restricts the passage of the scope follows through. Multiple lymphadenopathies in the bilateral deep cervical lymph nodes were detected, and a squamous cell carcinoma of the hypopharynx was revealed. 

Outcome:
The patient died 40 days after radiotherapy began due to respiratory failure and sepsis. 

Follow-Up:
N/A 

Hospital Course/Management:
1. The patient was admitted to the gastroenterology department due to difficulty in swallowing.
2. Multiple lymphadenopathies in the bilateral deep cervical lymph nodes were detected.
3. Squamous cell carcinoma of the hypopharynx was revealed.
4. Curative radiotherapy with concomitant cetuximab chemotherapy was initiated.
5. The patient developed progressive cytopenia, and the treatment was terminated.
6. Despite receiving daily G-CSF, her blood counts did not significantly improve, and she had a nasogastric tube placed for feeding.
7. On the 30th day of the start of radiotherapy, her oxygen saturation regressed, and she was intubated.
8. The patient died 40 days after radiotherapy began due to respiratory failure and sepsis.

Discharge Summary:

Patient ID: ##########
DOB: ##/##/####

Patient Name: #######

Gender: Male
Age: 4 years old

Admission Date: DD/MM/YYYY
Discharge Date: DD/MM/YYYY

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with a high fever, abdominal pain, loose motions, and emesis. He had a history of close contact with a COVID-19 patient. Initial investigations showed dengue NS1 Ag positive and rt-PCR for SARS-CoV-2 negative. The patient was treated for dengue shock syndrome with plasma leakage and received intravenous ceftriaxone, inotropes, and colloids. On the 5th and 6th day of fever, he developed petechial rashes on both extremities, cheilosis, and an erythematous rash over the trunk.

The patient also developed respiratory distress and cough with bilateral inflammatory lesions and pleural effusion evident on CXR. Echocardiography revealed dilated coronary arteries, left main coronary artery, and left coronary artery with the loss of distal tapering and mild left ventricular dysfunction.

The anti-SARS-CoV-2 antibody (IgG) test came back positive on the seventh day of fever. A pediatric cardiologist was consulted, and the patient received one dose of intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) followed by enoxaparin for five days. Thereafter, oral prednisolone and aspirin were added. Meanwhile, the patient became afebrile, and the rash faded. His general condition improved with a gradual return of appetite.

After 12 days in the pediatric intensive care unit, the patient improved and was transferred to the ward for further observation. The patient was discharged after five days with the necessary advice and follow-up appointment.

Clinical Findings:

The patient was febrile with a high temperature of 102°F and had tachypnea and tachycardia. Auscultation of the lungs revealed bilateral crepitations with good air entry. The abdomen was distended, flanks were full with mild, diffuse abdominal tenderness. The initial investigations showed thrombocytopenia, positive C-reactive protein, and altered coagulation profiles. The chest X-ray (CXR) initially revealed bilateral pulmonary infiltrations. The patient also developed respiratory distress and cough with bilateral inflammatory lesions and pleural effusion evident on a repeat CXR.

Treatment:

The patient received intravenous ceftriaxone, inotropes, and colloids for dengue shock syndrome with plasma leakage. After the diagnosis of KD was established, the patient was administered one dose of intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG), followed by enoxaparin for five days. Oral prednisolone and aspirin were added.

Follow-up:

The patient was discharged with advice to continue oral medication and attend follow-up appointments for further observation.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED] 

Discharge Date: [REDACTED] 

Hospital Course: 

The patient, a previously healthy 12-year-old girl, was admitted with symptoms of high intermittent fever, headache, cough, arthralgia, and generalized body aches. Upon admission, the patient was febrile, tachycardic with unrecordable blood pressure, and prolonged capillary refill time. The patient had a history of one episode of dengue fever in the past. The initial investigations showed thrombocytopenia, mild hypoalbuminemia, hypocalcemia, positive C-reactive protein, altered liver function tests with coagulopathy, and chest X-ray revealed bilateral pleural effusions with pneumonitis. The patient was managed for dengue shock syndrome with plasma leakage and respiratory distress with medical intervention (inotropes, IV furosemide, and albumin along with IV ceftriaxone and amikacin) in the Pediatric Intensive Care Unit (PICU). During the hospital course, the patient underwent a bedside echocardiogram which revealed a prominent LMCA, minimal pericardial effusion, mild pleural effusion, and good biventricular function.

Diagnosis: 

The patient was diagnosed with mucocutaneous involvement with respiratory symptoms caused by SARS-CoV-2 infection confirmed by a positive anti-SARS-CoV-2 IgG test.

Treatment and Management: 

After reviewing the laboratory reports and echocardiographic features, the pediatric cardiologist recommended treatment with one dose of IVIG 2g/Kg and started oral prednisolone and aspirin. With these interventions, the patient began to show clinical and laboratory improvements and was transferred to the main ward. During the stay, the patient was given oxygen via a face mask at a flow rate of 3L/min. Upon discharge from the hospital, the patient was advised for necessary follow-up arrangements.

Summary: 

The patient was diagnosed with mucocutaneous involvement with respiratory symptoms caused by SARS-CoV-2 infection. In the pediatric intensive care unit, the patient was managed for dengue shock syndrome with plasma leakage. Treatment with IVIG 2g/Kg and oral prednisolone and aspirin was initiated upon reviewing the laboratory reports and echocardiographic features to improve the patient's clinical and laboratory conditions. The patient was discharged from the hospital with the necessary follow-up arrangements.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient, a three-year-old girl, was admitted to the Pediatric Intensive Care Unit (PICU) with high continued fever, diffuse abdominal pain, emesis, and diarrhea. She had experienced two episodes of melena and hematemesis. She had a history of contact with a COVID-19 positive patient in the last month but had no symptoms before the present illness.

On admission, she was diagnosed with dengue shock syndrome with plasma leakage. The patient was treated with inotropes, IV furosemide, colloids, and levofloxacin. Her initial investigations revealed thrombocytopenia, hypoalbuminemia, hypocalcemia, positive C-reactive protein, mildly raised serum procalcitonin, altered liver function, and coagulopathy. Her chest X-ray revealed bilateral pleural effusions with pneumonitis.

Her echocardiography showed prominent dilated coronaries, LMCA (+2.5 SD), LAD (+2.0 SD) with loss of distal tapering and perivascular brightness, bilateral pleural effusions, a mildly dilated left ventricle with mild LV dysfunction (EF 57%). Her cardiac enzymes showed raised serum troponin I, NT-pro-BNP with raised serum ferritin, and marked increased D-dimer level. 

The rt-PCR for SARS-CoV-2 Ag came back negative; however, the anti-SARS-CoV-2 antibody (IgG) was sent and came positive. By the sixth day of fever, the patient had conjunctival congestion and an erythematous rash on her trunk, which gradually faded.

After consultation with cardiologists, one dose of IVIG 2g/Kg was given; thereafter, oral prednisolone and aspirin were added. Three days after the IVIG, repeat tests showed decreased serum troponin I and NT-pro-BNP. Her general condition had improved considerably, and she was transferred to the pediatric ward after seven days of PICU support. Thereafter she was discharged with advice and a follow-up appointment.

Diagnostic Impressions:

1. Dengue shock syndrome with plasma leakage
2. Positive anti-SARS-CoV-2 antibody (IgG)

Procedures:

None

Consultations:

Consultation with Cardiologists

Recommendations:

1. Follow-up with primary care provider
2. Continue oral prednisolone and aspirin as advised by the cardiologists
3. Follow up with a Cardiologist for further management of Coronary Artery Abnormalities

1. Patient Information:
The patient is a nine-year-old boy who was admitted to the Pediatric Intensive Care Unit (PICU) with high fever, headache, generalized body aches, abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and vomiting. He had a history of respiratory tract infection and tested positive for dengue NS1 Antigen.

2. Hospital Course:
The patient presented with respiratory distress, unrecordable blood pressure, tachycardia, and tachypnea. He was treated for dengue shock syndrome with plasma leakage and was given oxygen, inotropes, albumin, colloids, furosemide, imipenem, and amikacin. Blood tests showed anemia, thrombocytopenia, hypoalbuminemia, hypocalcemia, and coagulopathy. Stool occult blood test was positive, and CXR revealed pleural effusions and pneumonitis. The echocardiogram showed minimal pericardial effusion, bilateral pleural effusions, mild LV dysfunction, high serum ferritin, D-dimer, and a slightly raised NT-pro-BNP. The patient developed an erythematous rash on his trunk with conjunctival congestion on the seventh day of fever. An anti-SARS-CoV-2 antibody test was positive on the eighth day of fever, and he was started on IV methylprednisolone at a dose of 30 mg/Kg for three days. On the ninth day of illness, the patient developed respiratory distress and became confused and aggressive. Repeat CXR showed persistent pulmonary infiltrations with pleural effusion. A brain MRI revealed no neurological abnormalities, and repeat echocardiography revealed dilated coronaries and mild LV dysfunction.

3. Treatment:
The patient received one dose of IVIG and was given methylprednisolone and aspirin. Platelet count was closely monitored. He was placed on mechanical ventilation and gradually weaned from it after the second day. The patient's neurological complaints started resolving, repeat blood tests results were improved with remission of pleural effusion.

4. Discharge Status:
The patient was transferred to the pediatric ward after 12 days of PICU admission and was discharged on request after five days with the necessary advice and follow-ups.

5. Follow-up:
The patient should follow up with their pediatrician and cardiologist for further evaluation and management.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient, a previously healthy nine-year-old male with a weight of 31 Kg, was admitted to our hospital with complaints of high fever, body aches, headache, abdominal cramps, emesis, and rashes. He had a history of dengue infection two years previously and was in contact with a COVID-19 patient one month before the illness. On admission, he was noted to have respiratory distress, fluctuating blood pressure, cold periphery, and bilateral pleural effusions with pneumonitis. He tested positive for dengue NS1 Ag and his rt-PCR for SARS-CoV-2 was negative, and blood and urine cultures yielded no growth.

Investigations revealed thrombocytopenia, hypoalbuminemia, hypocalcemia, altered liver functions, coagulopathy, positive C-reactive protein, and slightly increased blood urea. He also had high levels of serum ferritin, D-dimer, serum troponin I, and NT-pro-BNP. An echocardiogram showed a mild pericardial effusion, prominent dilated coronaries, LMCA (+3.0 SD), LAD (+2.5 SD), bilateral pleural effusion, and fair LV function. The test for SARS-CoV-2 antibody (IgG) came back positive.

The patient was initially managed for dengue shock syndrome with plasma leakage using IV inotropes, albumin, calcium gluconate, antibiotics (imipenem, levofloxacin), and furosemide. After evaluating his condition and consultation with pediatric cardiologists, he was treated with a single dose of IVIG, followed by methylprednisolone, aspirin, and clopidogrel. His general condition gradually improved, and serial CXRs showed gradually reducing pleural effusions.

The patient was transferred to the pediatric ward ten days after PICU admission and was discharged with necessary advice and follow-up plans.

Patient Outcomes:

The patient was discharged from the hospital with improving laboratory reports. His condition gradually improved and his pleural effusions showed marked reduction. During his hospital course, the patient was managed for dengue shock syndrome with plasma leakage using IV inotropes, albumin, calcium gluconate, antibiotics, and furosemide, along with a single dose of IVIG. He was also started on methylprednisolone, aspirin, and clopidogrel.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient presented to hospital with chief complaints of macrohematuria and an abnormally low hemoglobin level. CT revealed left hydronephrosis, a bladder tumor on the right lateral wall, and right external iliac lymph node involvement. Transurethral resection of the bladder tumor was performed, and he was diagnosed with high-grade UC of the bladder with muscle layer invasion. After two courses with GC, CT revealed left external iliac lymph node involvement as a new lesion, although the bladder tumor and right external iliac lymph node decreased in size. Pembrolizumab was administered as a second-line treatment and disease progression was monitored using whole-body CT and pelvic MRI. CT findings after the administration of pembrolizumab revealed shrinking of the bladder tumor, positive lymph nodes, and right kidney. Open RC with bilateral pelvic lymphadenectomy and bilateral ureterocutaneostomy was performed. Pathological examination of the surgical specimen indicated UC, with a pathological stage of Tis without lymphovascular invasion, a negative surgical margin, and negative lymph node involvement. The patient was followed up for 30 months without evidence of local recurrence or distant metastasis.

Discharge Summary:

Patient was a 46-year-old African male who presented with a five-day history of cough, shortness of breath, diarrhea, muscle cramping, fatigue, poor oral intake, and decreased urinary output. He was tested positive for COVID-19 one day prior to admission. On examination, the patient was febrile and hemodynamically stable with a blood pressure of 125/57 mmHg, heart rate of 83 bpm, respiratory rate of 24 per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93%.

Initial laboratory tests revealed elevated levels of creatinine, BUN, creatinine kinase, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), C-reactive protein, and D-dimer. Arterial blood gas showed anion gap acidosis. EKG findings were non-significant for hyperkalemia, and chest x-ray was negative for the acute process of viral infection. Urinary analysis showed proteinuria and hematuria.

The patient was admitted to the COVID ICU and was started on a fluid resuscitation protocol followed by medication to address elevated potassium levels. A nephrology consultation was also obtained. Supportive treatment, including hydration, steroids, and sodium bicarbonate, was provided, but the patient did not show any improvement. He subsequently underwent hemodialysis and his renal function and electrolyte levels improved.

On discharge, the patient's electrolyte levels and renal function had improved. Additional pulmonary rehabilitation exercise was suggested for enhanced recovery from COVID-19 pneumonia. Follow-up care was recommended and the patient was discharged on room air.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with symptoms of shortness of breath, cough, weakness, lightheadedness, acrocyanosis, jaundice, and darkening of urine. Physical examination revealed mucosal pallor, acrocyanosis, and icterus of the facial skin. The chest x-ray showed an enlarged cardiac silhouette, perihilar vascular fullness, and bilateral interstitial prominence likely indicative of pulmonary vascular congestion. The cardiac echocardiogram revealed an ejection fraction of 60-65% with mild left ventricular wall thickness and grade I diastolic dysfunction. The patient was positive for SARS-CoV-2 but negative for influenza A, influenza B, and respiratory syncytial virus.

Treatment:

The patient received two units of crossmatch least incompatible warmed blood on day one and one unit of the same on day two of admission to treat the symptomatic anemia. The SARS-CoV-2 pneumonia was treated with oral remdesivir for five days and intravenous dexamethasone 6 mg for seven days. The patient was given intravenous 40 mg furosemide for pulmonary congestion, and empiric ceftriaxone and azithromycin for pneumonia for three days. Post-transfusions, the patient’s day-three hemoglobin was 10.2 g/dL which stabilized at her baseline of 7-8 g/dL by discharge.

Follow-up:

The patient required readmission to a cancer institute two days post-discharge where she was hospitalized for eight days, requiring five units of packed red blood cells and 60 mg of methylprednisolone IV daily. Her hemoglobin level improved to 9.2 g/dl and remained stable prior to discharge. On evaluation by an oncologist, weekly treatment with rituximab was recommended post-discharge for four weeks. On discharge, she was prescribed prednisone 40 mg for seven days followed by a taper to 20 mg for another seven days and a follow-up appointment with oncology. The patient is recommended to be discharged to a sub-acute rehabilitation center.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Male
Age: 32
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Diagnosis:
- Dysphagia
- Pyrosis
- Cough
- Shortness of breath

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 32-year-old male with a history of COVID-19 infection, presented to the ED with dysphagia, pyrosis, cough, and shortness of breath. Physical examination revealed bilateral wheezes over lung bases and palpable lymphadenopathy. CT-chest with contrast demonstrated mediastinal and bilateral hilar adenopathy, multiple pulmonary nodules, and mild interlobular septal thickening. The esophagram confirmed an extrinsic mass effect involving the middle esophagus. The patient underwent Endobronchial Ultrasound Bronchoscopy (EBUS) with transbronchial needle aspiration and biopsy, which revealed abundant non-necrotizing granulomas, mature lymphocytes, and endobronchial cells.

Treatment:
The patient was started on oral prednisone 40 mg once daily and was discharged from the hospital. Follow-up with the pulmonology clinic demonstrated improvement in respiratory symptoms after three months of steroid therapy. The patient underwent EGD with dilation followed by manometry studies a few months after discharge, which showed no gross or histological abnormalities. Despite partial improvement in dysphagia, the patient continues to follow up with pulmonology and gastroenterology clinics for further evaluation and management.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient's condition improved and he was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Medications:
None specified in the case report.

Follow-Up Plan:
The patient will follow up with pulmonology and gastroenterology clinics for continued evaluation and management of dysphagia.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Gender: Female
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Large lobulated multicompartmental supra-sellar mass centered within the hypothalamus/optic chiasm.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a two-year-old female with a six-week history of macrocephaly and truncal and peripheral ataxia, was admitted to the hospital for further evaluation. An urgent brain MRI demonstrated the presence of a large lobulated multicompartmental supra-sellar mass centered within the hypothalamus/optic chiasm, with extension into the surrounding structures and mass effect on the midbrain and third ventricle causing obstructive hydrocephalus.

The patient underwent an endoscopic biopsy and septostomy, along with a right-sided ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt to manage her hydrocephalus. The pathology of the lesion confirmed the diagnosis of a low-grade glioma that was BRAF-V600E negative on immunohistochemistry but positive on next-generation sequencing. She was started on chemotherapy with vincristine and carboplatin but had rapid tumor progression with worsening hydrocephalus six weeks into chemotherapy.

This progression caused the patient to develop further complications, including progressive right-sided hemiparesis, bitemporal hemianopia, central hypothyroidism, and feeding difficulties requiring a gastrostomy tube and placement of a second VP shunt.

After extensive discussions and mutual expert consensus, her chemotherapy was stopped, and she was started on the novel targeted agent dabrafenib. By three months of starting dabrafenib, the size of her tumor decreased by more than 70%, with continued decline until plateauing after two years of therapy.

Prior to dabrafenib, the patient had marked motor and speech impairments but is now able to perform all age-appropriate developmental skills independently. She no longer requires tube feeding and has been growing well. Her bitemporal hemianopia has improved markedly. Her visual acuity is the only symptom that has not shown significant recovery, as she continues to have low but stable visual acuity bilaterally.

The patient was enrolled in the ORCYD biomarker study to test her plasma and CSF for the presence of the BRAF-V600E mutation and to correlate the assay results with the MRI changes observed while on dabrafenib therapy. However, the BRAF-V600E mutation was not detected in any of the samples from either plasma or CSF.

The patient was discharged in stable condition with plans to continue on dabrafenib as long as the patient is tolerating the therapy well with no recurrence or progression of the tumor.

Discharge Medications:

None.

Follow-up:

The patient will follow up with her oncologist for regular check-ups and monitoring. Future imaging studies will be performed as needed to evaluate the progression of the tumor.

Discharge Summary:

Patient:
- 79-year-old male with left knee prosthesis infection, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease stage 3A.

Hospital Course:
- Patient presented with subjective fever partially improved with acetaminophen.
- History of severe allergic reactions to cephalexin and ciprofloxacin trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole.
- Started on ertapenem and daptomycin.
- Developed new diffuse interstitial opacities on chest x-ray; suspected Daptomycin AEP and discontinued antibiotic.
- Shortness of breath, desaturation, tachycardia, and persistent fever on second day of admission.
- New reticulopapular, non-pruritic rash on lower limbs and trunk with new-onset eosinophilia.
- CT scan of the chest showed diffuse reticulonodular opacities, ground-glass opacities, and nodularities.
- Meropenem started, and methylprednisolone and inhaled breathing treatments were ordered.
- Patient's symptoms significantly improved thereafter.
- Repeat chest x-ray one month later showed resolution of the interstitial markings.

Patient Discharge Status:
- The patient was discharged in a stable condition.

Follow-up Care:
- Follow-up appointment with primary care physician recommended to monitor left knee prosthesis infection, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease stage 3A.
- Patient advised to avoid cephalexin and ciprofloxacin trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole due to severe allergic reactions.
- The patient will continue to avoid Daptomycin.

Discharge Summary:

Patient:

A 62-year-old male with a history of dysphagia was diagnosed with lower esophageal cancer and underwent Ivor Lewis esophagectomy with distal pancreatectomy and splenectomy. The patient's lifestyle included 1500 ml beer consumption per day and 40 cigarettes per day for the past 40 years.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for evaluation and treatment of lower esophageal cancer. Computed tomography (CT) showed thickening of the wall in the lower esophagus as the primary lesion was demonstrated, and the tumor formed a mass with the solitary metastatic abdominal lymph node, and invaded pancreas body and gastric body. No other distant metastasis was detected on CT.

The patient underwent neoadjuvant chemotherapy, but after once administration, he could not continue chemotherapy for the exacerbation of dysphagia, and underwent radical surgery. Reconstruction of gastric conduit was possible although the lymph node was adherent to lesser side of gastric body, which was resected when reconstruction of gastric conduit. In addition, partial resection of lung was performed simultaneously owing to involvement of bilateral pulmonary ligaments to the primary tumor.

After the surgery, the patient had an uneventful postoperative course and was able to take orally. He underwent two courses of chemotherapy as adjuvant chemotherapy. At present, the patient is still alive and has no recurrence for 7 years after surgery.

Diagnosis:

Lower esophageal cancer confirmed squamous cell carcinoma on biopsy with pancreatic invasion, cStage IIIC.

Pathological Examination:

The resected specimen revealed that the primary lesion was observed from lower esophagus to esophagogastric junction, and metastatic lymph node was fixed to stomach and pancreas body. The tumor was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma, moderately differentiated type. The vascular and lymphatic invasion were confirmed. The histopathological response of chemotherapy was grade 1a.

Medications:

None

Follow-Up Instructions:

The patient should return for routine follow-up visits with his oncologist. The patient should also avoid smoking and alcohol.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: Not Disclosed
Gender: Female
Age: 51
Date of Admission: Not Disclosed
Date of Discharge: Not Disclosed
Admitting Diagnosis: High myopia with epiretinal membrane
Hospital Course: The patient presented with decreased visual acuity due to high myopia with epiretinal membrane in both eyes. After vitrectomy and internal limiting membrane peeling, the patient's left eye vision improved to 20/28. However, the patient developed sudden decline in left eye vision, and OCT demonstrated disruption of the interdigitation and ellipsoid zones and elevation of the RPE, indicating polypoidal choroidal vasculopathy (PIC). Intravitreal ranibizumab injection was recommended, and after a month, vision improved to 20/100 and the nodule-like lesion regressed. The patient was closely observed, and the area of chorioretinal atrophy (CRA) increased gradually at a rate of 0.45 mm2/year, resulting in a decrease in choroidal thickness to 16 μm after 40 months post-injection. The patient's BCVA was 20/70 in the left eye, and two new atrophic lesions were noted in the parafovea.
Diagnosis at Discharge: High myopia with polypoidal choroidal vasculopathy (PIC) and chorioretinal atrophy (CRA) in the left eye
Summary of Hospitalization: The patient was admitted with decreased visual acuity due to high myopia with epiretinal membrane. The patient underwent vitrectomy and internal limiting membrane peeling that improved vision in the left eye. However, the patient later developed sudden decline in vision in the left eye due to polypoidal choroidal vasculopathy. After intravitreal ranibizumab injection, the nodule-like lesion regressed leaving an expanded RPE defect, and the patient was observed closely for progression of the chorioretinal atrophy. During a follow-up of 40 months, CRA increased gradually at a rate of 0.45 mm2/year, and two new atrophic lesions were noted in the parafovea.
Condition at Discharge: Stable
Follow-up Instructions: The patient is advised to continue regular eye check-ups and follow-up appointments with the ophthalmologist for monitoring of chorioretinal atrophy progression.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 82-year-old male with HCC and PVTT

Admission Date: [Date]

Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our department for the surgical treatment of HCC with PVTT invasion. Due to overwhelming PVTT extensions, old age, and poor performance status, the patient was not a surgical candidate and received a combination treatment of atezolizumab plus bevacizumab with radiotherapy for PVTT.

During preparation for radiotherapy, the patient developed anal pain and persistent fever, and CT showed perianal abscess due to anal fistula. The patient recovered soon after percutaneous abscess drainage but the adverse event interrupted atezolizumab plus bevacizumab treatment, and radiotherapy could not be introduced.

Abdominal CT showed size reduction of the main tumor and PVTT, with a reduction in tumor enhancement on contrast-enhanced CT. Serum AFP levels decreased from 90,700 ng/mL before treatment to 18,371 ng/mL and 6301 ng/mL 3 and 5 weeks after atezolizumab plus bevacizumab treatment, respectively. The patient continued the atezolizumab plus bevacizumab treatment after creating colostomy, performed 47 days after the first administration of atezolizumab plus bevacizumab.

Subsequently, beginning from the 83rd day after the first administration of atezolizumab plus bevacizumab, the patient received atezolizumab monotherapy. The reason for choosing atezolizumab monotherapy was that the bleeding from the colostomy persisted from the collateral blood circulation due to the liver cirrhosis. The patient received a one-time atezolizumab plus bevacizumab treatment and continued with atezolizumab monotherapy afterward (9 regimens administered until now); there is no apparent sign of residual tumors at 9 months after the introduction of atezolizumab plus bevacizumab treatment.

Condition on Discharge:

The patient’s condition on discharge was stable, and there were no signs of residual tumors.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient was advised to continue with regular follow-ups and to avoid alcohol consumption.

Follow-up:

The patient was scheduled for follow-up later on [Date].

Discharge Summary:


Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Patient Name: [insert name]                      MR#: [insert number]

Hospital: [insert hospital name]

Admitting Diagnosis: Chronic persistent swallowing dysfunction

History: The patient has a history of excessive intake of alcohol and locally grown tobacco use for several years.

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted to the hospital due to chronic persistent swallowing dysfunction for six months. White light endoscopy revealed a 22 mm flat lesion in the middle esophagus. The lesion was covered with scattered leukoplakia and normal vascular network could not be seen in the lesion. The patient received narrow-band imaging (NBI) under endoscopy which revealed the lesion with an indistinct brownish area, local white penniform area and white tiny papillary surface structure. Further low and high magnifying endoscopy with NBI (ME-NBI) showed tiny irregular papillary microsurface structure with various shapes and sizes, and non-typical intraepithelial papillary capillary loops (IPCL) confined to the papillary microsurface structure. Iodine staining endoscopy showed a less-stained lesion and showed more distinct white tiny papillary surface structure than conventional white light endoscopy. Biopsy showed a low-grade intraepithelial neoplasia. Chest and abdominal CT scan revealed no abnormal lesions. The endoscopic manifestations under WLE, ME-NBI, and iodine staining endoscopy, combining with pathology, led to the diagnosis of early esophageal cancer. Therefore, endoscopic therapy was chosen. The lesion was completely resected with endoscopic submucosal dissection. The lesion was histopathologically confirmed as early VCCE which was limited within the mucosal lamina propria (m2) and completely resected. There were no lymphovascular and neural invasions of cancer cells, and no cancer cells to be seen in the lateral and vertical margin of the resected specimen (the distance of the lesion to the closest margin of the resected specimen was 3.012mm).

Disposition: The patient is discharged in good condition.

Instructions: The patient is advised to follow up with their primary care physician. 

Summary: The patient was admitted to the hospital with chronic persistent swallowing dysfunction. Endoscopy revealed an early esophageal cancer which was completely resected with endoscopic submucosal dissection. The patient is discharged in good condition and advised to follow up with their primary care physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Hospital Number: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A
Admitting Diagnosis: N/A
Admitted Service: N/A

Hospital Course:

A 25-year-old male with a history of blurred vision in the right eye, headache, and weight loss of approximately 30 kg was admitted with a suspected craniopharyngioma. Initial MRI showed a tumor located suprasellarly that was not associated with the pituitary gland. Endocrine evaluation revealed secondary hypogonadism and adrenal insufficiency. The tumor was removed, and perioperative frozen section histological examination suggested the tumor to be a possible malignant lymphoma due to lymphocytic infiltration. The patient was transferred to the Department of Endocrinology at Odense University Hospital, where pituitary hormone insufficiency of all anterior axes and diabetes insipidus was diagnosed, and treatment with various hormones was implemented. Final histological diagnosis revealed autoimmune hypophysitis.

Ten months postoperatively, the patient reported impaired vision, and MRI demonstrated that the pituitary remnant tissue was causing pressure on the optic chiasm. Treatment with glucocorticoid pulse therapy was initiated, which was followed by steroid-sparing treatment with azathioprine when the patient had intolerable adverse effects. The patient responded well to treatment, but after an initial reduction in the pituitary mass, there was a recurrence of the mass, and treatment with rituximab was initiated. The patient responded well to rituximab treatment, resulting in almost complete regression of the pituitary mass.

The patient was discharged with the recommendation to follow up with routine imaging and endocrine evaluation. The patient remains in sustained remission with no further complications, with the control MRI showing no evidence of recurrence.

Discharge Medications:

N/A

Follow-Up:

It is recommended that the patient continue to follow up with imaging and endocrine evaluation to monitor for any potential recurrence of the pituitary mass or complications related to his existing hormone deficiencies. The patient should be advised to seek medical attention if he experiences any recurrence of symptoms.

Discharge Summary: 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: 
The patient, a 75-year-old former smoker with a history of atrial fibrillation, arterial hypertension, and gastroesophageal reflux, was admitted to the hospital for breathlessness. She was exposed to passive smoking due to running a bar-tobacco shop. Clinical examination showed interstitial lung disease (ILD) with subpleural reticulations and crackles at lung bases.

HOSPITAL COURSE: 
The patient underwent chest computed tomography (CT) scan, standard biology, serological testing, bronchoscopy, and bronchoalveolar lavage. Pulmonary function tests demonstrated bronchial obstruction and alteration of gas diffusion. ILD multidisciplinary discussion (MDD) reached a CT pattern of possible usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP), which led to the decision to perform surgical lung biopsy. Wedge resection of the right upper and lower lobes was performed by video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery. Both resected lung specimens showed a similar pattern of UIP: fibroblastic foci and honeycombing. In addition, the right lower lobe specimen displayed numerous disseminated foci of well-differentiated focally invasive malignancy without invasion of visceral pleura. Complete resection was obtained without malignant margins.

DIAGNOSIS: 
Interstitial lung disease with subpleural reticulations and bronchial obstruction. Surgical biopsy revealed usual interstitial pneumonia with disseminated foci of well-differentiated focally invasive malignancy.

TREATMENT: 
Nintedanib was started as an antifibrotic treatment owing to pathological confirmation of UIP.

CONDITION ON DISCHARGE: 
At the last follow-up in October 2019, that is, 2 years after initiation of nintedanib, clinical, functional (FVC, 130% pred.; TLCO, 61% pred.), and CT scan evaluations were stable. There was no evidence of malignancy progression.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS: 
The patient is advised to continue taking prescribed medications as directed and follow up with the primary care physician on a regular basis. She is also advised to avoid exposure to passive smoking and other environmental irritants to prevent further lung damage. 

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES: 
- Interstitial lung disease
- Bronchial obstruction
- Usual interstitial pneumonia with disseminated foci of well-differentiated focally invasive malignancy. 

FINAL DIAGNOSES:
- Usual interstitial pneumonia with disseminated foci of well-differentiated focally invasive malignancy.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

History of Presenting Complaint:
The patient, a 48-year-old male, presented with a history of recurrent urethral stricture for the past 8 years. He had a surgical history of open suprapubic cystostomy (SPC) 8 years ago with surgical site infection (SSI) postoperatively which was managed conservatively.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of swelling in the right inguinoscrotal region associated with repeated thinning of urinary stream and recurrent episodes of burning micturition. The swelling had been static and persistent for the past 2 months. On examination, the patient had a 5-cm long vertical midline scar in the suprapubic region. An irreducible soft swelling of 8 cm × 6 cm was present in the right inguinal region which extended up to the base of scrotum. Cystoscopy revealed narrowing in bulbar urethra with deviations in the proximal anterior urethra. Ultrasound showed findings consistent with right inguinal omentocele and a scarred suprapubic region.

A preoperative diagnosis of right-sided, complete, irreducible, inguinal omentocele with urethral stricture was made. The patient underwent right open hernioplasty with cystourethroscopy along with internal optic urethrotomy (IOU). During surgery, a right indirect hernial sac with omentum as content was found and a mesh hernioplasty was performed. A hernial sac with omentum as content was also found in midline beneath the scar of old SPC and was dissected out. IOU was done and 18-Fr Foley's catheter left in situ. The patient developed SSI on postoperative day (POD)-2 which was managed by wound irrigation and oral antibiotics.

Condition at Discharge:
At follow-up after 1 month, a repeat cystourethroscopy was performed which showed fibrosis and narrowing at the site of IOU. A repeat IOU was done. The patient now has a good urinary stream, no complaint of restriction in passage and dilatations have become a smooth affair. The patient has been on 4 monthly dilatation for the past year which have all been smooth and has now been called after 6 months for next follow-up.

Summary:
The patient was admitted with complaints of swelling in the right inguinoscrotal region associated with repeated thinning of urinary stream and recurrent episodes of burning micturition. He underwent right open hernioplasty with cystourethroscopy along with internal optic urethrotomy (IOU) and is now doing well. A postoperative diagnosis of right-sided, complete, irreducible, indirect inguinal hernia, and incisional hernia with omentum as contents with urethral stricture was made. The patient has been scheduled for next follow-up in 6 months.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 35-year-old man, presented with a 12-year history of low back pain, which had been radiating to his right leg for the past 4 months. There was also numbness observed, extending to the lateral side of the sole of his right foot. On examination, the patient had 30% sensory loss in the right S1 dermatome, and an MRI of the lumbosacral spine showed an IM cystic lesion at L2-3, which was hypointense on T1-weighted images and hyperintense on T2-weighted images. The patient underwent posterior laminectomy for differential diagnosis of a neoplastic lesion.

Postoperative Course:
L2-3 laminectomy and posterior longitudinal myelotomy were performed under microscopic guidance. Intraoperatively, three grayish white cysts were identified. Two of the cysts were completely excised, while the third cyst was only decompressed due to its adherence to the nerve roots. Histopathological examination revealed that it was a NCC. Postoperatively, the patient reported significant relief from back pain, and there was a significant reduction in radiating pain. He was started on albendazole and steroids and was discharged from the hospital on the 4th postoperative day.

Follow-up:
The patient was followed up biweekly for the first month, and thereafter, monthly follow-ups were conducted for the next 2 months. The patient remained asymptomatic, and an MRI performed at the 6-month follow-up confirmed the resolution of the cystic lesion. The patient has been monitored biannually for 2 years and remains symptom-free.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 65-year-old gentleman without any comorbidities who presented with progressive jaundice, anorexia, and weight loss since 4 to 5 weeks. The patient was diagnosed with a pancreatic head adenocarcinoma with an incomplete intestinal rotation, an rRHA arising from SMA. The patient underwent a pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy. 

Procedure:

During surgery, the small bowel loops were found clumped in right upper abdomen and a Kocher's maneuver was performed after interbowel adhesiolysis to free all the loops till the third part of duodenum. SMA and SMV were then identified and looped at the lower border of pancreas. Hepatoduodenal ligament dissection was then performed to identify the replaced right hepatic artery and the main portal vein. The retropancreatic tunnel was created above the portal vein superiorly and the SMA inferiorly, and then the plane was widened till the area above SMV. Uncinate dissection, duodenojejunal flexure mobilization, and standard lymphadenectomy were then performed, followed by division of jejunum, first part of duodenum common bile duct and pancreas. Reconstruction was performed as the modified Blumgart technique of duct to mucosa pancreatico-jejunostomy with 5–0 polypropylene, single layer interrupted hepatico jejunostomy using 4–0 polypropylene and antecolic stapled posterior gastrojejunostomy.

Results:

The patient recovered uneventfully and was discharged on the postoperative day 8. The histopathological examination showed moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma confined to pancreas with all margins free and a single peripancreatic node out of 18 was positive. The patient is doing well at 4-month follow up on adjuvant 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy.

Summary:

In summary, the patient was diagnosed with a pancreatic head adenocarcinoma with an incomplete intestinal rotation, an rRHA arising from SMA and underwent a pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy without any complications. The patient is recovering well and is currently on adjuvant chemotherapy. Further follow-up is recommended as per standard of care.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with symptoms of jaundice, anorexia, and weight loss which were diagnosed to be caused by a hypoechoic lesion in the head of the pancreas. A pancreaticoduodenectomy was performed, and during surgery, intestinal nonrotation was identified. The surgery was successful, with all margins free and no node out of 16 was positive. 

Diagnosis:
Postoperative hypoechoic lesion in the head of the pancreas with direct hyperbilirubinemia; intestinal nonrotation; elevated CA 19-9.

Treatment:
Pancreaticoduodenectomy with modified Blumgart technique of duct to mucosa pancreaticojejunostomy, single layer interrupted hepaticojejunostomy, and stapled posterior gastrojejunostomy.

Condition at Discharge:
Patient is doing well with no adjuvant therapy at 3 years' follow-up. He had a postoperative chyle leak and superficial surgical site infection, which were managed conservatively.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:

The patient was a 70-year-old man who presented with repeated upper abdominal pain and was diagnosed with resectable pancreatic cancer of the pancreatic body. Preoperative computed tomography (CT) suggested that the patient may have a stricture of the CA root, which may have been caused by median arcuate ligament (MAL). Pancreaticoduodenectomy with division of the MAL was scheduled but unexpected bleeding around the CA was observed during surgery. Bleeding could be controlled by simple compression only, and hemostasis by suturing was attempted first. Contrary to expectations, the bleeding intensified, making it difficult to confirm the bleeding point. Therefore, supraceliac aortic cross-clamping (SAC) was performed to manage the bleeding. After performing SAC, the bleeding intensity significantly decreased, and a defect of the adventitia measuring 7 mm in diameter on the CA was confirmed. The defect was repaired, and the patient underwent a distal pancreatectomy to decrease the risk of hepatic infarction. The patient was discharged uneventfully on postoperative day 19.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was a 70-year-old man who presented to our institution with repeated upper abdominal pain and was diagnosed with resectable pancreatic cancer of the pancreatic body. Preoperative computed tomography (CT) suggested that the patient may have a stricture of the CA root, which may have been caused by median arcuate ligament (MAL). Pancreaticoduodenectomy with division of the MAL was scheduled, but unexpected bleeding was observed during surgery due to the injury incurred when the MAL was cut to release CA compression. Bleeding was controlled by simple compression only, and hemostasis by suturing was attempted first. However, the bleeding intensified, making it difficult to confirm the bleeding point. Therefore, supraceliac aortic cross-clamping (SAC) was performed to manage the bleeding. After performing SAC, the bleeding intensity significantly decreased, and a defect of the adventitia measuring 7 mm in diameter on the CA was confirmed. The defect was repaired, and the patient underwent a distal pancreatectomy to decrease the risk of hepatic infarction. The patient was discharged uneventfully on postoperative day 19.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Admitting Diagnosis: Multiple neck lumps

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 56-year-old woman, was admitted to the surgical department with a history of multiple neck lumps for 4 months. On clinical examination, multiple bilateral enlarged cervical lymph nodes were identified, which were firm to hard in consistency. The patient also reported vague abdominal pain, loss of appetite, and lower back pain. Further examination revealed a firm lump on the lower pole of the left thyroid lobe, and enlarged right inguinal lymph nodes. Imaging studies showed a mixed density mass lesion in the lower pole of the left thyroid lobe and multiple nodules in the thyroid gland. Biopsies revealed moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, indicating metastatic tumors.

The patient was treated with palliative chemoradiotherapy for 6 months. After 6 months, generalised body oedema was observed, and the patient was transferred to a specialized cancer treatment center for further palliative management. The patient passed away due to acute renal failure secondary to ureteric obstruction.

Final Diagnosis: Squamous cell carcinoma of the uterine cervix metastasizing to the cervical lymph nodes and thyroid gland.

Discharge Medications: None.

Follow-up: None.

Summary:

The patient, a 56-year-old woman, presented with multiple neck lumps, which were diagnosed to be metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the uterine cervix in cervical lymph nodes, thyroid gland, and endometrium through biopsy. She was treated with palliative chemoradiotherapy for 6 months and was subsequently transferred to a specialized cancer treatment center, where she passed away due to acute renal failure secondary to ureteric obstruction. There are no discharge medications or follow-up required at this time.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 43
Gender: Female
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Reason for Admission: Post-surgical pain management following pelvic exenteration due to cervical carcinoma

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for the management of post-surgical pain following pelvic exenteration due to cervical carcinoma. She was started on continuous intravenous infusion of oxycodone at 30 mg/day, which was gradually increased to a maximum dose of 288 mg/day (MED 576 mg/day) to manage the pain. As the pain subsided, the dose was gradually reduced, and the intravenous infusion was discontinued at a dose of 18 mg/day. However, six hours after discontinuation, the patient developed restlessness and an itching sensation in her legs, likely due to an opioid withdrawal syndrome. To manage the symptoms, the continuous intravenous infusion of oxycodone was resumed at a dose of 18 mg/day, and the symptoms disappeared. The oxycodone dose was further reduced and discontinued gradually over 10 days. Subsequently, the patient did not report any withdrawal symptoms.

Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for post-surgical pain management following pelvic exenteration due to cervical carcinoma. She was started on continuous intravenous infusion of oxycodone, which was gradually increased and then reduced over the course of her hospitalization. She developed symptoms of opioid withdrawal after discontinuation of the oxycodone infusion, which were effectively managed by resuming the infusion at a lower dose. The oxycodone was tapered and discontinued gradually over a period of 10 days, with no recurrence of withdrawal symptoms. The patient was stable and without any complications at the time of discharge.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]

Admission Date: [redacted]

Discharge Date: [redacted]

Medical History:

The patient is a 43-year-old male with a medical history significant for hepatocellular carcinoma who underwent liver transplantation from a living donor.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for severe acute pancreatitis with severe abdominal pain. Continuous intravenous infusion of fentanyl at 1200 μg/day was started to control abdominal pain. The fentanyl dose was increased according to pain intensity, reaching 2400 μg/day (MED 240 mg/day) after 10 days in the hospital. Administration of a pancreatic enzyme inhibitor, antibiotic, and fluid alleviated the pancreatitis and abdominal pain.

The patient subsequently developed nausea/vomiting, elevated blood pressure, and restlessness 12 hours after discontinuation of continuous intravenous fentanyl infusion. Continuous intravenous fentanyl infusion of 240 μg/day was resumed, and these symptoms disappeared.

The patient was then switched to a transdermal fentanyl patch to taper the opioid more slowly. Pancreatitis with abdominal pain recurred transiently one month later, and therefore, continuous intravenous fentanyl infusion was resumed, titrated to 600 μg/day. The dose was gradually decreased daily (600, 300, 240, 180, 120, and 60 μg/day).

Once the pancreatitis had improved, the fentanyl could be discontinued without causing withdrawal symptoms. The discontinuation was finally completed 64 days after the onset of withdrawal symptoms.

Final Diagnosis:

Severe acute pancreatitis with severe abdominal pain secondary to hepatocellular carcinoma and liver transplantation.

Summary:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for severe acute pancreatitis with severe abdominal pain, and continuous intravenous infusion of fentanyl was initiated to control the pain. The patient experienced withdrawal symptoms after discontinuation of the fentanyl infusion, and therefore, a transdermal fentanyl patch was initiated to taper the opioid more slowly. The fentanyl infusion was successfully discontinued without causing withdrawal symptoms 64 days after the onset of withdrawal symptoms. The patient was discharged home in stable condition.

• Name: [Insert Name]

Medical Diagnosis:
• Vulvar sarcoma

History of Presenting Illness and Treatment:
The patient was treated with proton beam radiotherapy and developed a painful ulcer within the irradiation field a month after completing treatment. She received sustained-release oxycodone starting at 40 mg/day, which was gradually increased up to 160 mg/day (MED 240 mg/day) for pain control. The ulcer was relieved through skin grafting. The oxycodone dosage was gradually reduced, with mild restlessness occurring at 20 mg/day (12.5% of the maximum dosage); however, administration of the same dosage was continued as the symptom was mild and disappeared after a few days.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient reported experiencing cold sweats, malaise, and leg pain six hours after discontinuing oxycodone. Administration of sustained-release oxycodone (10 mg/day) once again was recommended, leading to the disappearance of symptoms. The patient continued receiving this medication for approximately five months due to fear of experiencing withdrawal symptoms. Final oxycodone discontinuation was achieved 323 days after the first onset of withdrawal symptoms.

Summary:
The patient was admitted due to treatment for vulvar sarcoma that was complicated by a painful ulcer. Pain control was achieved through sustained-release oxycodone, which saw a gradual decrease in dosage amount over the course of several months. Mild restlessness occurred at a dosage reduction of 20 mg/day, but the same dosage was administered continuously, and the symptom soon vanished. After experiencing withdrawal symptoms upon oxycodone discontinuation, sustained-release oxycodone administration was re-started and gradually reduced until discontinuation was achieved 323 days after the first onset of withdrawal symptoms.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: N/A
Date of Birth: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A
Reason for Admission: N/A

HOSPITAL COURSE:

This patient is a 37-year-old woman with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) who provided home care for her mother who had end-stage breast cancer. Her father was visually impaired, and the daughter was the main caregiver. The home care staff initially had difficulty contacting and communicating with her as she often focused on household tasks such as dishwashing.

After the diagnosis of ASD was disclosed, the patient received consultation and social skill training at an outpatient clinic to improve her communication, scheduling, and caregiving abilities. Inappropriate behavior decreased following explanations and making communication rules with the patient.

The patient's mother's condition worsened, and she required opioids for pain control. The patient was able to communicate with the home care staff effectively and provide appropriate care during this time. Unfortunately, the patient's mother passed away at home.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:

The patient is being discharged from care and services as her mother has passed away.

FOLLOW-UP RECOMMENDATIONS:

No further follow-up recommendations are needed at this time.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

We extend our sincerest condolences to the patient and her family. If the patient requires further assistance with grief counseling or support, she is encouraged to contact her primary care physician for further recommendations.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 57
Sex: Male
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Length of Stay: [Redacted]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for acute onset of painless hematochezia for 1 day. He had unprovoked deep venous thrombosis and portal-vein thrombosis on Apixaban, diagnosed 18 months prior to admission.

Hospital Course:
The patient was tachycardic and mildly hypotensive upon admission. There was no evidence of chronic liver disease on exam. The hemoglobin level was low and subsequently decreased, while the platelet count was within normal limits. Laboratory tests were conducted, and the results were normal, except for low albumin levels.

The patient's anticoagulation therapy was discontinued, and he was resuscitated with IV crystalloids. EGD and colonoscopy were performed, revealing small non-bleeding esophageal varices and a colonic varix with active bleeding, respectively. 

The patient was treated with IV octreotide at the satellite hospital and was later transferred to our tertiary institution for escalation of care. Liver-protocol computed tomography (CT) was performed for TIPS evaluation, revealing a steatotic liver and chronically thrombosed SMV with a patent portal vein. The patient was deemed not to be a candidate for either TIPS or BRTO in the setting of chronic SMV thrombosis.

The patient continued to have hematochezia, and a trans-hepatic portogram was performed, revealing an elevated absolute portal pressure. Digital subtraction images confirmed the site of the SMV occlusion at the confluence of two large SMV branches, in addition to retrograde flow through the large right CV. A catheter and stiff Glidewire were used to recanalize the occluded SMV using balloon angioplasty and self-expanding stents. Follow-up venography showed antegrade flow in the right SMV branch into the SMV stent with a marked reduction in filling of the right CV. 

Liver biopsy showed steatohepatitis with stage 2/4 fibrosis. Apixaban and low-dose aspirin were started. Two months after discharge, the patient had no recurrent bleeding and CT showed patent SMV stents. A plan for surveillance was determined using cross-sectional imaging every 6 months for 2 years.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Painless Hematochezia, Steatohepatitis with Stage 2/4 Fibrosis, Chronic SMV Thrombosis

Discharge Medications:
Apixaban, Low-Dose Aspirin

Discharge Instructions:
The patient should continue to take Apixaban and low-dose aspirin as prescribed. The patient should also follow his surveillance plan that involves cross-sectional imaging every 6 months for two years. It is essential that the patient maintains regular follow-ups with his primary care physician and GI specialist. If he experiences any signs of recurrent bleeding or side effects from medication, he should contact his physicians immediately.

Follow-Up Plan:
The patient's care team will communicate the discharge summary to the primary care physician and GI specialist. It is essential that the patient maintains regular follow-ups with the team and adheres to the surveillance plan.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: Male, 63 years old.

Admission Date: November 16, 2018

Discharge Date: N/A

Diagnosis: Stage II PBL

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with complaints of persistent left epistaxis and a history of swelling in the left orbit and maxillary sinus. Examination revealed multiple enlarged, indurated, and painless lymph nodes in the cervical and left submandibular areas. Blood tests showed anemia and thrombocytopenia. Subsequent imaging and biopsy revealed a diagnosis of stage II PBL.

With curative intent, the patient underwent bortezomib chemotherapy in combination with CDOP regimen. After two cycles of chemotherapy, the patient showed a significant decrease in the size and intensity of nasopharyngeal lesions. Follow-up imaging after three cycles of chemotherapy showed a diminished range of lesions and reduced 18F-FDG uptake. The patient achieved a partial response (PR) after five cycles of chemotherapy treatment.

The patient underwent mobilization and collection of autologous peripheral blood stem cells. During one cycle of chemotherapy, enhanced MRI scanning revealed no significant change. The patient later received local radiotherapy (RT) to nasopharyngeal regions, followed by two cycles of chemotherapy with lenalidomide.

The patient received conditioning BEAM high-dose chemotherapy with consolidative autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (ASCT). During the transplant, the patient experienced grade 4 myelosuppression, requiring G-CSF. The patient received lenalidomide-based maintenance therapy after the transplant. Currently, the patient is monitored with serial MRI scanning and presents a 32-month overall survival and 22-month progression-free survival.

Summary:

The patient was admitted with complaints of persistent left epistaxis and a history of swelling in the left orbit and maxillary sinus. The diagnosis was confirmed as stage II PBL, and the patient underwent treatment with chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. The patient achieved a partial response and continues to be monitored for progression of the disease.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Age: 19 years

Gender: Male

Diagnosis: Paroxysmal Kinesigenic Dyskinesia (PKD)

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to our institute with right hand and foot dyskinesia. He had a significant family history of PKD. The patient's grandfather, uncle, and grandfather's brother had involuntary movements triggered by voluntary movements and were confirmed to have PRRT2-PxMD. The patient first experienced paroxysmal involuntary left hand and toe flexion with left forearm pronation triggered by sudden voluntary movements at the age of 14. The patient underwent right-sided Vo thalamotomy at the age of 15 and developed right elbow, hand, and toe flexion four months after the surgery. Carbamazepine (100 mg/day) was prescribed again, and the PKD attacks reduced. He underwent left-sided Vo thalamotomy at the age of 19, which resulted in the complete resolution of PKD attacks immediately after the surgery. Left-sided PKD attacks never developed six years after the right Vo thalamotomy, and right-sided PKD attacks never developed two years after the left Vo thalamotomy without medication. 

Clinical Findings:

The patient presented with paroxysmal involuntary left hand and toe flexion with left forearm pronation triggered by sudden voluntary movements, and right hand and foot dyskinesia.

Treatment:

The patient underwent stereotactic ablative surgery consisting of right-sided Vo thalamotomy at the age of 15 and left-sided Vo thalamotomy at the age of 19. 

Follow-up:

The patient did not experience any recurrence of PKD after the thalamotomies, without the aid of medication. The locations of the coagulated lesions were confirmed using Brainlab Elements. 

Conclusion:

Paroxysmal Kinesigenic Dyskinesia is a rare movement disorder associated with PRRT2-PxMD. The patient underwent stereotactic ablative surgery consisting of right-sided Vo thalamotomy at the age of 15 and left-sided Vo thalamotomy at the age of 19, which resulted in the complete resolution of PKD attacks. No further recurrence of PKD was noted without the aid of medication.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Age: 46 years
Sex: Female

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: 
The patient presented with a two-year history of refractory pain in the cervical spine, head, and left upper arm with rising intensity. Reduced range of motion of the cervical spine and a sensible radicular syndrome were noted on clinical examination corresponding to the nerve roots C4-C6. She had a high need for pain medication. The laboratory tests showed no evidence of infection or tumor.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
Radiographs, CT scan, and MRI revealed a tumor at the left side C3-C4 in the cervical spine without any further pathologies in the complete tumor workup. Biopsy and additional reference pathology yielded the result of an aggressive osteoblastoma (Enneking Type III). In the interdisciplinary tumor board, a decision was made for complete wide resection, and radiation therapy was considered in dependence on the final pathology after tumor resection. An unremarkable occlusion test of the left vertebral artery was performed to simulate a potentially necessary ligation.

SUMMARY OF CARE:
The patient underwent complete wide resection for an aggressive osteoblastoma (Enneking Type III) in the cervical spine. The procedure was successful, and no complications were noted. The patient is scheduled for a follow-up visit with the oncologist in three months.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
Aggressive osteoblastoma (Enneking Type III)

DISCHARGE CONDITION:
Stable

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient should follow-up with the oncologist in three months for further evaluation and management. The patient should also discuss any concerns related to her condition, including pain management, with the physician.
