Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not provided
Medical Record Number: Not provided
Date of Admission: Not provided
Date of Discharge: Not provided
Attending Physician: Not provided

Chief Complaint:
The patient presented with a history of univentricular heart with tricuspid atresia. The patient was admitted for Fontan conversion surgery due to serious right atriomegaly with frequent episodes of atrial tachycardia.

Hospital Course:
The patient successfully underwent Fontan conversion surgery, but unfortunately suffered from severe single ventricle dysfunction resulting in low cardiac output syndrome (LCOS). The patient was implanted with an ECMO device, but could not be weaned off due to multi-organ failure and eventually passed away.

Pertinent Findings:
The pre-operative ventricular function was mildly reduced (50%). Seven patients required pace-maker implantation due to post-operative sinus node dysfunction or atrioventricular conduction abnormalities. At the time of discharge, 15 patients had sinus rhythm, 5 had a stable pacemaker rhythm, 2 had atrial fibrillation, and 1 had atrial flutter. One patient was discharged in sinus rhythm but had a pacemaker implant five months after the operation due to sinus node dysfunction. During the follow-up period of 14 months (IQR 7–27), 2/23 patients experienced a recurrence of arrhythmia more than three months after surgery.

Outcome:
During the follow-up period of 14 months (IQR 7–27), there were no cases of late mortality. 17/23 patients had an improvement in their NYHA functional class. Five patients in NYHA III progressed to class II and 4 to class I. Eight patients progressed from class II to class I. At the follow-up electrocardiogram, 16 patients were in sinus rhythm, 6 had stable pacemaker rhythm, and 1 had permanent atrial fibrillation.

Discharge Instructions:
No relevant discharge instructions were given as the patient unfortunately passed away.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: July 2020
Date of Discharge: [Patient is still under observation]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital in July 2020 after a chest CT scan revealed the presence of two lung lesions. The patient underwent wedge resection of these lesions a month later. Gross examination of the surgical specimens revealed an intraparenchymal, peripheral, solid, yellow-white lesion measuring 1.4 cm in greatest dimension. Histological assessment identified a well-circumscribed lesion composed of two different morphological components, tightly adhered but not intermingled each other. A final diagnosis of “combined pulmonary adenocarcinoma with atypical carcinoid” was made.

Genetic testing of the tumor tissue was performed, which revealed a number of somatic mutations in each entity. The adenocarcinoma and carcinoid components of the mixed neoplasm shared the same mutations in BRAF, NF1, STK11, and AKT2 genes. Further, four additional somatic mutations were detected in the DDR2, CDK6, and SMARCA4 genes in the adenocarcinoma component, whereas no specific mutations were identified in the carcinoid component. A different genetic profile emerged from the molecular analysis of the two additional adenocarcinoma nodules, which lacked those somatic mutations identified in the mixed nodules, but shared two somatic missense mutations in the KRAS and NOTCH1 genes.

Due to ROS1 positivity observed in the upper pulmonary lobe neoplasia, the patient started crizotinib in November 2020. The patient is still receiving the treatment, and the current status of the disease is stable.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient requires regular medical follow-up and evaluation to monitor the status of the disease. The patient is advised to follow up with the oncologist at regular intervals and take the prescribed medication as instructed. The patient should also maintain good health practices, including a healthy diet, regular exercise, and stress reduction.

Conclusion:
The discharge summary indicates that the patient was admitted to the hospital and underwent wedge resection of two lung lesions. The final diagnosis was "combined pulmonary adenocarcinoma with atypical carcinoid." The genetic analysis revealed different somatic mutations in the different tumor entities. The patient started crizotinib due to ROS1 positivity, and the current status of the disease is stable. The patient is advised to follow medical instructions and maintain good health practices.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information: 
66-year-old female who underwent upper left lung lobectomy and regional lymph adenectomy for a pulmonary mass.

Hospital Course: 
The patient was diagnosed with combined pulmonary adenocarcinoma with atypical carcinoid and was classified as stage pT3 (PL3) pN2 sec UICC 2017. The patient underwent targeted NGS analysis on Ion Torrent NGS platform using the Ocav3 panel, which found both common and private genes mutations in each investigated entity of primary and metastatic sites, but did not show any shared point mutations, CNVs, or gene fusions in both adenocarcinoma and carcinoid components from any sites.

The patient progressed in December 2016 with the onset of osteoblastic bone lesions and in February 2017, cisplatin plus pemetrexed regimen started for six cycles, reporting a partial response after four cycles. In November 2017, due to a massive bone metastasis with bone marrow infiltration, the patient passed away.

Diagnosis: 
Combined pulmonary adenocarcinoma with atypical carcinoid.

Medical History: 
No significant medical history was reported.

Allergies: 
No allergies were reported.

Treatment: 
Cisplatin plus pemetrexed regimen for six cycles.

Follow-up: 
The patient passed away due to a massive bone metastasis with bone marrow infiltration in November 2017.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [Patient's Name]
Date of Admission: 02/08/2018
Date of Discharge: 03/21/2018
Attending Physician: [Physician's Name]

History of Present Illness:
58-year-old African American male with a long-standing complaint of scaly and itchy feet presented to the clinic with visible inflammation on the plantar surface of both feet. An initial specimen collection from the patient's plantar surface showed hyphae indicative of a fungal infection under KOH (potassium hydroxide) preparation. The patient was treated with ketoconazole topical cream and 20% Urea creams daily, which showed improvement with minimal remaining inflammation.

Hospital Course:
The patient responded well to the treatment and showed complete resolution of underlying fungal infection on the plantar surface of his feet with minimal inflammation. With further consideration, the patient's exaggerated immune reaction caused by Trichophyton was suspected as an underlying cause of allergic response (delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction) to the fungus instead of a cutaneous fungal infection alone. To confirm this hypothesis, the patient was subjected to intradermal skin testing with intradermal Candida and Trichophyton allergens.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged on March 21, 2018.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Tinea Pedis with an underlying delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction.

Discharge Medications:
None prescribed on discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is encouraged to follow up with their regular physician for any further complaint of scaly and itchy feet. It is also recommended to use good hygiene practices, take care of skin, and avoid sharing towels and other personal items.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 70 years
Sex: Female

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department with a one-week history of left knee pain, swelling, and erythema. The patient had hypertension, end-stage renal disease (ESRD), and multiple prosthetic joints including a left total knee arthroplasty (TKA). Prior to developing symptoms in her knee, the patient suffered from loose stools and abdominal pain that had resolved. Physical examination revealed tachycardia, respiratory distress, and a restricted range of motion on her left knee.

Laboratory workup showed a high white blood cell count (WBC) and hemoglobin levels within normal limits. X-rays indicated no significant findings apart from a prior total knee replacement. A preliminary diagnosis of sepsis due to septic arthritis was confirmed by the presence of purulent fluid and a positive culture indicating Yersinia enterocolitica. The patient received supportive management and underwent resection of her left TKA and placement of a biodegradable implant.

After consultation with infectious disease specialists, the patient was discharged home to complete 6 weeks of outpatient intravenous antibiotics. Follow-up appointments showed the complete resolution of infection, and the patient has not experienced any recurrence or reinfection of her knee after over a year.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient should follow the recommended outpatient intravenous antibiotic regimen as prescribed. Additionally, the patient should follow up with her primary care physician and specialists as directed, continue current medications, and monitor vital signs as needed. The patient should report any concerns or worsening of symptoms to her healthcare provider immediately.

Diagnosis:
Septic arthritis caused by Yersinia enterocolitica

Condition at Discharge:
Stable

Discharging Provider:
[REDACTED]

Discharge Summary: 

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 73
Gender: Male
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Brief Hospital Course: 
The patient presented with symptoms of SARS-CoV-2 infection and was admitted to the hospital for nearly three months. Throughout his stay, the patient underwent various treatments, such as dexamethasone, azithromycin, and ceftriaxone, to cover the complications caused by COVID-19. He was intubated for most of his stay and treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics to combat ventilator-associated pneumonia. Unfortunately, his gastrointestinal bleed and pulmonary embolism made it difficult to provide optimal treatment, and his respiratory status eventually declined, leading to prolonged hospitalization. During the second month, the patient tested positive for T. asahii in his urine sample. 

Diagnostic Tests and Procedures: 
The patient underwent multiple diagnostic tests and procedures, including sputum and urine cultures, chest X-rays, esophagoduodenoscopy, and colonoscopy. Pathologic reports suggested that the biopsy material from a colon mass could not exclude the presence of an advanced malignant lesion. 

Course in Hospital: 
During his hospitalization, the patient required continuous care, which included long-term antibiotic treatment for ventilator-associated pneumonia and medication to manage T. asahii infection. He was started on fluconazole initially, followed by voriconazole after specific resistance patterns were determined. The patient underwent a tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube placement without complications. 

Discharge Condition: 
The patient's condition deteriorated to the point where palliative care was initiated at the long-term care facility. He eventually expired at the facility.

Follow-Up: 
As the patient has passed away, no follow-up care is necessary.

Summary: 
This 73-year-old male patient with a history of COPD, hypertension, and cerebrovascular accident presented with COVID-19 infection and developed complications. The prolonged hospital stay included antibiotic treatments to cover for ventilator-associated pneumonia and treatments for T. asahii infection, with multiple diagnostic tests performed to manage the patient's condition. Despite continuous care, the patient's condition deteriorated, leading to palliative care and eventually passing away.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [XXXX]
Medical Record: [XXXX]
Date of Admission: [XX/XX/XXXX]
Date of Discharge: [XX/XX/XXXX]

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient, a 33-year-old male with a history of alcohol consumption, presented to our center with complaints of profuse bleeding per rectum mixed with stool for three days. He was also experiencing general fatigue for a week prior to the initial presentation. On examination, he presented with pallor and dehydration. The patient’s blood tests showed a hemoglobin level of 10.8 g/dL and a hematocrit level of 31.6%. Neutrophil levels were high at 78%, and the platelet count was 291,000/mm3. The total leukocyte count was 11,510/mm3. The urine examination indicated the presence of traces of sugar and albumin (++). The colonoscopy revealed multiple transverse ulcers with overlying exudates in the terminal ileum and ascending and transverse colon. The histopathological examination of the ileum and colon showed patchy ulcers with exudates, granulation tissue, fibrosis, deep lymphoplasmocytic inflammation, and crypt regenerative changes with fibrinoid changes in scattered capillaries and venules, indicating a diagnosis of ileocaecal tuberculosis. Following this, the patient underwent two pints of whole blood transfusion and was managed with four antitubercular drugs, which showed significant improvement. He was discharged on oral antitubercular medications (isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, ethambutol, and pyridoxine) after 10 days of admission. On follow-up after two weeks, he was responding well to the antitubercular medications with improved symptoms. Laboratory tests also indicate liver functions are within the normal range.

DIAGNOSIS:
Ileocaecal tuberculosis.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient is advised to continue the prescribed antitubercular medications for the given duration without fail. We recommend that he avoid alcohol consumption and mind his hygiene while ingesting meals. Moreover, consume a well-balanced diet, maintain good nutrition and hydration, and take enough rest and sleep. We recommend a follow-up visit with the treating physician in two weeks or as needed.

FOLLOW-UP CARE:
Follow-up care is recommended with the treating physician in two weeks or as needed.

Discharge Summary

Patient: [Patient Name]
DOB: [Patient Date of Birth]
Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]

Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Chief Complaint: Exertional dyspnea and bilateral lower extremity edema

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 35-year-old female who was admitted to the Emergency Department with a 3-month history of worsening exertional dyspnea and bilateral lower extremity edema. The patient also endorsed a nonproductive cough, pleuritic chest pain, occasional orthopnea, and an unintentional weight loss of 20 pounds over a one-month period. She was afebrile with mild tachycardia and respiratory distress. An electrocardiogram revealed sinus tachycardia with no acute injury pattern, and a chest radiograph showed a pleural-based wedge-like consolidation in the right inferior lobe consistent with Hampton's Hump. A limited echocardiogram revealed tricuspid valve vegetations and a slightly enlarged right ventricle without any D-sign. The patient subsequently underwent a CT-angiogram of the chest, which revealed multiple septic emboli and mycotic aneurysms and multiple segmental pulmonary arterial occlusions with associated infarcts or hemorrhage.

The patient was treated with IV ceftriaxone and azithromycin to cover possible community-acquired pneumonia, and IV vancomycin, gentamycin, and ciprofloxacin to provide coverage for possible MRSA endocarditis. The patient was admitted with consultation of Cardiothoracic Surgery and Infectious Disease (ID). Blood cultures remained negative, and the causative pathogen was not identified.

The patient subsequently underwent a tricuspid valve annuloplasty and reconstruction using autologous pericardial tissue. The patient's blood cultures remained negative, and ID recommended the patient receive ceftriaxone 2 g IV daily for 6 weeks. Pathology of the valve leaflets indicated granulation tissue with focal areas of bacterial colonization without bacterial identification. The remainder of the patient's postoperative course was uncomplicated, and on hospital day 15, she was transferred to a skilled nursing facility to complete her 6-week course of IV ceftriaxone.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with tricuspid valve vegetations, septic emboli, and mycotic aneurysms.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was in good condition at the time of discharge.

Follow-up:
The patient will follow-up with primary care physician and Cardiothoracic Surgery for post-operative management.

Medications on Discharge:
The medications the patient took upon discharge were not documented.

Allergies:
The patient has no known allergies.

Hospital Course:
Female child presented at the early neonatal period with skin lesions, intermittent painless vaginal bleeding, and breast enlargement. Parents took the child to the nearby health facility but were reassured. Child's growth in length was fast compared to peers, but she had poor weight gain. At 3 ½ years, the child presented with bowlegs and was discharged without intervention. But after one week, she sustained pathological fractures on both upper and lower extremities. The patient was put on POP cast and later underwent open fixation with a plate. During the procedure, tachycardia was detected, and the patient was diagnosed with hyperthyroidism. The child was given PTU and propranolol, and the plate was displaced after eight months. The orthopedic surgeon decided to revise the operation, but the thyroid function remained uncontrolled.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient is a 5-year-old female child who was symptomatic since the early neonatal period with skin lesions, intermittent painless vaginal bleeding, and breast enlargement. At 3 ½ years, the child presented with bowlegs and was later diagnosed with hyperthyroidism during the procedure of open fixation with a plate. After eight months, her plate was displaced, and her orthopedic surgeon referred her to a paediatric endocrinology clinic for better management of hyperthyroidism. The patient was emaciated, weighed 16 kg, and her height was 115 cm. She had protruded eyes, CAL spots on her skin, a 5 cm by 3 cm anterior neck mass with an irregular surface, and breast enlargement. The patient had a grade III early systolic murmur and swelling at the right midshaft of the humerus with tenderness short POP on the left lower arm. The patient was diagnosed with MAS.

Hospital Course:
A 45-year-old obese male with severe diabetes mellitus and general fatigue presented to our university hospital. Further evaluations revealed sleep apnea syndrome and SITSH with a poorly enhanced mass measuring 5 × 6 × 8 mm in the pituitary gland diagnosed as thyrotroph adenoma. Despite initial treatment with somatostatin analog, the tumor did not respond entirely. Laparoscopic surgery was performed, and complete tumor resection was achieved with the tissue samples obtained for electron microscopy. The patient had transient diabetes insipidus and subsequently contracted influenza type A followed by hyponatremia, which was managed carefully. Postoperative MRI revealed complete resection without any tumor recurrence. Further, blood examination after 6 months showed an improvement in endocrinological parameters. The patient has remained healthy for 2 years without any tumor recurrence or other complications.

Summary:
A 45-year-old obese male presented with severe diabetes mellitus, SITSH, and general fatigue. Laryngological surgery performed due to a poorly enhanced mass measuring 5 × 6 × 8 mm diagnosed the mass as thyrotroph adenoma. Although initial treatment was unsuccessful with somatostatin analogs, full tumor resection was achieved using laparoscopic surgery. He had transient diabetes insipidus and contracted influenza type A followed by hyponatremia, which was managed carefully. Postoperative MRI showed complete tumor resection without any recurrence, and blood examination revealed improved endocrinological parameters after six months. The patient has remained healthy for two years without any recurrence or other complications.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED] 
Gender: Nonbinary (Presumed Female at Birth) 
Age: 28 
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course: 
The patient was admitted with polycythemia, presenting with hemoglobin 168 g/L and hematocrit 0.49, both within the male reference range. The primary care physician had previously referred the patient due to concerns regarding polycythemia, which signaled elevated hemoglobin and hematocrit levels. It was found that the patient had been undergoing full masculinizing hormone therapy with transdermal testosterone gel for approximately six months.

After conducting a thorough evaluation, it was observed that the patient's hemoglobin, hematocrit, and red blood cell count had increased to the male reference range, as expected after 6 months of masculinizing testosterone therapy. Smoking cessation was advised as continued smoking can also increase hematocrit.

No changes in platelet count or white blood cells were observed. Ferritin reference ranges were considered in the context of iron status and were interpreted according to the patient's circumstances. The patient was informed that interpretation of iron studies for individuals who have a ferritin below the male reference range should be guided by red cell indices. The premenopausal female reference range was used for the same interpretation of ferritin levels in trans individuals who are menstruating or pregnant.

The patient was informed that the reference ranges of the affirmed gender should be utilized. As such, the male reference range would be most appropriate for this nonbinary individual, who was advised to be mindful of this when reviewing their own results.

Recommendations:
1. Continue with full-dose masculinizing hormone therapy with transdermal testosterone gel.
2. Smoking cessation recommended to decrease hematocrit and reduce risk of cardiovascular disease.
3. Be mindful of reference ranges when interpreting lab results.
4. Follow up with primary care physician as recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification: A 68-year-old trans woman with a history of hypertension, high cholesterol, and vaginoplasty.

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted for coronary angiogram with concern for contrast-induced nephropathy due to unknown estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR). Serum creatinine was measured, but eGFR had not been reported for the last 18 months. Laboratory providers require a male or female marker to estimate eGFR, and using the Chronic Kidney Disease Epidemiology Collaboration (CKD-EPI) formula, female classification would result in Stage 3 chronic kidney disease, while the male classification would result in Stage 2 chronic kidney disease. Given that the patient had been on long-term feminizing hormone therapy, the female reference range for renal function was deemed most appropriate.

Plan at Discharge: The patient was discharged with an understanding of the importance of accurate assessment of renal function, particularly in situations that may potentially affect it, such as radioiodine contrast administration. Recommendations were made to specify the sex-specific reference interval desired for reporting renal function on laboratory requests, allowing for appropriate reference range to be reported, and the patient to be informed if misgendered. In case either a male or female calculated eGFR suggested renoprotective strategies, and 24-hour urine creatinine clearance can be performed to more accurately assess renal function.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 70-year-old trans woman
Medical Record Number:
Date of Admission:
Date of Discharge: 

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted due to mild lower urinary tract symptoms and reduced urinary flow. The patient was on feminizing hormone therapy for 6 months with transdermal estradiol and cyproterone acetate. A routine health check prompted a PSA test, which revealed a result of 2 ng/mL. A digital rectal examination showed a mildly enlarged prostate gland. An ultrasound of the prostate revealed a mildly enlarged prostate volume of 35 mL. Repeat PSA monitoring showed a decrease in PSA concentration and an improvement in urinary flow.

Past Medical History:
The patient had no family history of prostate cancer.

Clinical Impression:
The patient had mild lower urinary tract symptoms with reduced urinary flow, a mildly enlarged prostate gland, and a decreasing PSA concentration.

Treatment and Management:
There are no studies examining the effect of feminizing hormone therapy on PSA. Androgen deprivation as part of feminizing hormone therapy is associated with a substantially lower risk for prostate cancer. Individualized decisions based upon clinical history and examination should inform the need for serial monitoring for PSA velocity or imaging.

Discharge Medications:
N/A (No medications prescribed at the time of discharge)

Follow-Up:
The patient should follow up as scheduled with their primary care physician or specialist to monitor their urinary flow and PSA concentration.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: Not provided
- Age: 49
- Gender: Transgender male
- Diagnosis: Chest pain, high cardiac troponin

Hospital Course:
- Patient presented with central chest pain.
- High-sensitivity cardiac troponin was elevated.
- There is debate concerning the use of sex-specific reference ranges for high-sensitivity cardiac troponin.
- Despite being on established testosterone therapy for 10 years, there is currently insufficient data to suggest that cardiac remodeling or a change in cardiac size occurs with high testosterone concentrations.
- To minimize the risk of missing an acute coronary event, the sex presumed at birth (female) reference range was used to interpret high-sensitivity cardiac troponin levels.
- Patient was informed of this rationale and monitored with serial troponins to ensure no rise.
- Patient's subsequent high-sensitivity cardiac troponin was elevated above the male reference range and ECG revealed anterior ST-segment depression consistent with acute coronary syndrome.

Summary:
- Patient presented with chest pain and elevated high-sensitivity cardiac troponin.
- Despite being on testosterone therapy for 10 years, there is currently insufficient data to suggest that cardiac remodeling occurs.
- To minimize the risk of missing an acute coronary event, the sex presumed at birth (female) reference range was used to interpret high-sensitivity cardiac troponin levels.
- Patient was informed of this rationale and monitored with serial troponins to ensure no rise.
- Elevated subsequent troponin levels and ECG findings were consistent with acute coronary syndrome.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient was admitted with symptoms of generalized muscle pain, dry skin, and mild facial puffiness. Laboratory investigations revealed severe hypothyroidism along with raised levels of anti-thyroid peroxidase and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies, suggesting Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Elevated levels of serum creatine kinase and myoglobin levels were indicative of rhabdomyolysis. Transthoracic echocardiography detected minimal circumferential pericardial effusion, and flexible laryngoscopy was normal. 

The patient's symptoms improved with intravenous fluids and oral levothyroxine, and the levels of CK and myoglobin showed a decreasing trend. He was discharged on Day 4 and advised to continue taking the prescribed medication. The patient was instructed to follow up with his primary care physician and endocrinologist for further management of his thyroid condition. 

The patient's hospital course was unremarkable after initiation of treatment, and he was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 33
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Admission Diagnosis:

Severe postburn mentosternal contracture and cicatricial carcinoma.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for skin grafting surgery due to a severe burn that occurred when she was four years old. She had undergone two reconstructive procedures in local medical centers at the ages of seven and 14. The patient presented with severe scar contractures and a large tumor of approximately 15 × 12 cm on the lower lip, neck, and anterior chest. In addition, the patient had limited mouth opening (15 mm) and Mallampati test could not be performed. The patient had tried several medical centers for treatment in the past year, but had failed for unsuccessful airway topicalization and intubation (ATI). Due to the pain caused by the occurrence of cicatricial carcinoma, affecting eating and speaking, the patient was referred to our hospital for further evaluation and management.

During the preoperative physical examination, the patient's chin, chest, and bilateral armpits fused together; the cervicomental and mentosternal angles were completely obliterated; the anterior neck structures, including the larynx, the trachea, and the carotid arteries, were unidentifiable or impalpable. The left nostril was obstructive for stenosis, but the right nostril breathing was smooth. Preoperative X-rays and a computed tomography scan revealed distortion of the upper airway and no stenosis of the trachea. Face mask ventilation could not be performed due to the nearly fixed neck and regressed mandible. According to guidelines on the management of difficult airway, an awake flexible bronchoscopic intubation with topicalization was considered the preferred approach; however, the patient rejected ATI for discomfort and nociceptive recall before. Other awake strategies, including lightwand, GlideScopeⓇ Video laryngoscope, laryngeal mask airway, oral or nasal blind intubation, retrograde intubation, surgical tracheostomy, seemed impossible. Therefore, a flexible bronchoscopic intubation protocol under precise sedation, topicalization, and spontaneous respiration preservation was scheduled.

After obtaining a written informed consent with explanation focused on the risks of difficult airway and intramuscular injection of Atropine 0.5 mg to reduce secretion 30 minutes before transferring to the operating room, the patient was monitored for respiration rate, ventilation volume, pulse oximetry, electrocardiogram, blood pressure and bispectral index (BIS). Preoxygenation was performed once the patient arrived in the operating room and intravenous midazolam 2 mg and sufentanil 5 μg were administered. Nasal passage was anesthetized by pledgets with 2% lidocaine and 0.25% phenylephrine. Sevoflurane 2% with a flow rate of 4 L/min with 100% O2 was administered via an endoscopic mask connected to the ventilator circuit. The concentration of sevoflurane was gradually increased to 4% and stopped when the BIS reached 55-60 within 3 minutes, then airway reassessment and precise topicalization were achieved by a modified SAYGO technique.

An epidural catheter, with an outer diameter of 3.8 mm and 1.5 cm longer, was fixed to the fiberscope (MDH A10; Zhuhai Mindhao Medical Technology Co., Ltd., ShenZhen, China). Topicalization was achieved by spraying 2% lidocaine (7 ml) via the catheter onto the posterior nasal canal, pharyngeal cavity, epiglottis, glottis, and tracheal. Meanwhile, supplemental oxygen 10 L/min was delivered by a hose through the mouth to avoid hypoxemia. When lidocaine worked, about 5 minutes later, sevoflurane was inhaled again until the BIS reached 55–60. Then, a Parker Flex-Tip® tube with an inner diameter of 6.0 mm (Lead Medical Instrument Co., Ltd., Guangzhou, China), which was heated by 40 ℃ and lubricated in advance, was successfully and smoothly inserted into the trachea from the direction of flexible bronchoscopy. No stress reactions and no intubation-related complications occurred during intubation, and the patient was very satisfied with this experience after emergence.

The patient was discharged on [redacted] with instructions to follow-up with her primary care physician.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient: late seventies female with a history of endovascular aortic repair for a large infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm, and subsequent embolization of a type 2 endoleak resulting in bilateral lower limb weakness and numbness.

Hospitalization:

Patient was admitted for embolization of a type 2 endoleak by the interventional radiologist. Five hours after the procedure, the patient complained of bilateral lower limb weakness and numbness. Lumbar spinal drain was inserted to decompress the spinal cord to allow more arterial flow. Urgent CT aortogram followed by MRI thoracolumbar spine was performed, which showed postinterval embolization of bilateral feeding arteries and Onyx material extending into the spinal canal. 

Rehabilitation:

The patient was subsequently admitted for inpatient multidisciplinary rehabilitation. After 1 month of inpatient rehabilitation, she made some neurological recovery with functional improvement. However, she was still unable to ambulate and was dependent on a wheelchair for longer distance ambulation. The patient was discharged to a subacute rehabilitation facility before being discharged home. 

Follow-up:

Electrophysiology study performed 12 weeks later showed electrophysiological evidence of an acute right lumbar plexopathy involving the right obturator and femoral nerves, with no evidence of axonal continuity. The patient was reviewed in the outpatient clinic 14 weeks later and neurologically remained largely unchanged for right lower limb, although left lower limb power had improved.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [INSERT DATE]
Discharge Date: [INSERT DATE]

Patient Name: [INSERT PATIENT NAME]
DOB: [INSERT DATE OF BIRTH]
Gender: Female

Medical History:
The patient was referred to this tertiary hospital for specialist evaluation of a non-specific cough, which was present for 6 weeks associated with a right pulmonary mass. The physical examination revealed diminished breath sounds on the right side of the lung. Chest radiograph revealed a mass located in the right upper lobe and middle lobe of the right lung, with a central area of calcification. Chest computed tomography (CT) scan confirmed the chest radiograph findings, and surgical removal of the mass was performed.

Hospital Course:
Thoracotomy was performed on the right side, and the lesion was resected, leading to lobectomy of both upper lobe and middle lobe. No associated lymphadenopathy was noted. Macroscopically, a well-circumscribed mass measuring 5.5 × 5.5 × 4 cm was present, and the excised tumor had an osseous center measuring 2 × 1 × 1 cm. From the histological point of view, the mass consisted of disorganization of the normal bronchoalveolar parenchyma, myofibroblastic cells, and inflammatory cell infiltrates, such as lymphocytes, neutrophils, eosinophils, and histiocytes. In the center of the lesion, a large ossification was found.

Results:
Immunohistochemistry revealed calponin antigens, SMA, desmin, P53, bcL2, CK, HMW, and, in several myofibroblastic cells, expression of ALK-1. It was negative for beta-catenin, cyclin D1, Myo-D1, S100p, CD34, CD99, and CD117. The histological and immunohistochemistry characteristics were compatible with an inflammatory myofibroblastic pseudotumor.

Outcome:
The post-operative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged home after 2 weeks of surgery. The patient re-presented to the hospital 1 year after surgery. The child had normal daily activities, normal chest x-ray and no recurrences.

Diagnosis:
Inflammatory Myofibroblastic Pseudotumor

Plan:
There is no plan for outpatient follow-up.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: February 2021
Discharge Date: April 2021
Reason for Admission: Persistent fever and non-resolving pneumonia

Brief Hospital course:
The patient, a 35-year-old gentleman, was admitted to our institution in February 2021 due to persistent fever and non-resolving pneumonia caused by probable Organizing Pneumonia. The patient had a history of PCR-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection in October 2020. A bronchoscopic transbronchial lung biopsy was done, and the patient was started on high-dose steroids, with which he improved. He was discharged home.
The patient was readmitted in April 2021 due to a persistent fever. Since the patient was on high-dose steroids, the fever was attributed to a probable secondary infection or organizing pneumonia itself. Sputum culture grew Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and an antibiotic, piperacillin, was commenced. Computed tomography thorax showed resolution of the previously seen left lower lobe consolidation but had new-onset bilateral ground-glass opacities (GGOs). Nasal swab for SARS-CoV-2 RT-PCR was positive (Cepheid assay, April 2021), with a Ct value of Envelope gene (E gene) 23.2 and nucleoprotein gene (N) 24.1. A diagnosis of COVID-19 re-infection was made. 
The patient received remdesivir injection and other symptomatic medications. He became afebrile within 2 days and was discharged from the hospital. During routine follow-up in June 2021, he was asymptomatic, and his anti-N and anti-S-RBD antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 proved to be positive (Table).

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [INSERT DATE]
Discharge Date: [INSERT DATE]

Emergent admission of a 34-year-old female patient with an intense, periumbilical, and pelvic abdominal pain associated with acute vomiting was presented to our emergency room. The clinical examination revealed a painful mass that was irreducible and impulsive in nature at the umbilical level. An abdominal ultrasound scan showed that the patient was suffering from an evolving mono-fetal pregnancy estimated at 1 kg which was strangulated through an umbilical orifice.

Given this unexpected diagnosis, a multi-disciplinary team recommended an MRI was performed, without injection because of the teratogenic nature of the test. Our radiological assessment showed a strangulation of the pregnant uterus through an orifice of 6 cm, which resulted in a strangulated hernia of a pregnant uterus at the umbilical level with the right ovary, though there was no visible intestinal loop. After discussion with the patient, a multidisciplinary team recommended moving forward with a ceolioscopic exploration under general anesthesia. The procedure went smoothly, and the gravid uterus and right ovary were safely reduced using a careful dissection of the hernia sac and external manual assistance. 

Before the intraperitoneal plate was placed, an obstetrical ultrasound scan confirmed that there was a viable and evolving pregnancy. The patient's postoperative evolution was favorable, and she was discharged two days after the operation. During the two-year follow-up, there was no recurrence of the condition. 

The patient opted for tubal ligation and was scheduled for a cesarean section at the end of the pregnancy. With the assistance of our team, the patient gave birth to a 2.5 kg male infant with good psychomotor development. Further evaluation was not warranted, and the patient did not experience any adverse postoperative complications. 

Overall, the patient received exceptional care and support from our team. Her medical condition was managed in a timely and effective manner, and she was discharged without any outstanding medical concerns or issues.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 57-year-old male, presented to Al-Bairouni Hospital with complaints of a breast mass in 2019. Physical examination revealed a suspicious abnormality on Ultrasound, which measured 32 mm. The CT scan showed infiltration in the left breast, with no signs of metastases. An excisional biopsy was performed, which revealed poorly differentiated grade III invasive ductal carcinoma.

The patient underwent a mastectomy in 2019 with axillary node resection. Hormonal receptor tests showed positive Estrogen Receptor (ER+), negative Progesterone Receptor (PR-), and negative Human Epidermal Receptor (HER-). The final diagnosis was invasive ductal carcinoma stage IIA [T:2, N:0, M:0].

The patient received eight cycles of chemotherapy with Docetaxel and 16 sessions of radiation to the chest wall. The last session was on October 4, 2020. Six months after the surgery, the PET scan showed no signs of recurrence.

The patient was discharged on [REDACTED] with instructions to follow-up with the healthcare provider as scheduled. He was advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle, get regular check-ups, and report any unusual symptoms.

Invasive ductal carcinoma stage IIA [T:2, N:0, M:0].

Discharge Medications:

N/A

Discharge Instructions:

1. Follow-up with the healthcare provider as scheduled.
2. Maintain a healthy lifestyle.
3. Get regular check-ups.
4. Report any unusual symptoms.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 34-year-old pregnant female with a history of diabetes and three previous miscarriages due to hypertensive peaks. She was admitted to the endocrinology department at 20 weeks of amenorrhea due to a hypertensive crisis, headaches, palpitations, and hot flashes. Diagnosis of a secretory neuroendocrine tumor was suspected, and a biological assessment including urinary and plasma catecholamines came back positive. An abdominal-pelvic MRI showed an abdominal latero-aortic mass measuring 36 * 33 mm, corresponding to paraganglioma.

The patient was scheduled for surgery for laparoscopic removal of her paraganglioma. The anesthetic management was carefully planned to prevent perioperative morbidity related to hemodynamic instability. After installation in left lateral decubitus proclive 30°, the patient underwent anesthesia induction, intubation, and maintenance of anesthesia with close monitoring of vital signs. During tumor manipulation, episodes of arterial hypertension and hypotension were observed and managed with analgesia, administration of vasoactive drugs and close glycemic monitoring.

The tumor removal was followed by episodes of arterial hypotension, which were managed by lightening anesthesia and volemic expansion with drug administration. For paraganglioma extraction, the procedure lasted 2 hours, with an intraoperative diuresis of 500 ml and estimated bleeding of 80 cc. After the procedure, the patient was transferred to the intensive care unit for clinical and biological monitoring and was weaned from all drugs two days later. 

The patient was discharged to the visceral surgery department for further management with antihypertensive treatment resumed. Obstetrical evaluation with a foeto-placental ultrasound was performed, which returned normal with the presence of fetal heart activity. The patient will continue to be monitored.

Discharge Summary:

Patient XY, a 44-year-old female, presented with vomiting and abdominal pain following consumption of locally foraged mushrooms. Admitted to the National Liver Unit, the patient was diagnosed with acute liver failure and underwent an orthotopic liver transplant. Post-operatively, the patient suffered from skin necrosis, sepsis, and AVN. Following bilateral total hip replacements, the patient showed significant improvement and was discharged after being able to mobilize independently at home and use a wheelchair outside.

Hospital Course:
Admission & Diagnosis:
- Patient presented with vomiting and abdominal pain following mushroom consumption
- Diagnosis of acute liver failure secondary to fungi consumption made
- Transferred to National Liver Unit and underwent orthotopic liver transplant

Post-Operative Course:
- Skin necrosis, sepsis, and AVN observed
- Multidisciplinary team input provided, including Dermatology, Plastics, and Pain team
- MRI revealed AVN in both femoral heads
- Bilateral total hip replacements performed
- Rehabilitative physiotherapy commenced post-operatively

Discharge:
- Patient discharged after being able to mobilize independently at home and use a wheelchair outside
- Showed significant improvement in muscle strength and mobility
- Maintains good mobility and range of movement in lower limbs, with the aid of crutches while outside

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 73-year-old male, presented to the emergency department with persistent hiccups over the past five days. The patient is a known diabetic and hypertensive for 15 years and has a history of rate-controlled atrial fibrillation, managed with beta-blockers and warfarin. Two weeks prior to admission, the patient suffered a subacute ischemic infarct of the right medial occipital lobe, which was confirmed on a computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain. On clinical examination, there were decreased breath sounds and crackles noted in the basal segments of the right lower lobe. The patient had a low-grade fever (temperature 37.8 C) whilst other vital signs were stable. Chest radiograph confirmed the presence of bilateral lower lobe pulmonary infiltrates. Blood investigations revealed a leukocytosis, neutrophilia, and an elevated C-reactive protein (CRP). Blood cultures were negative, and arterial blood gases were normal. A tentative diagnosis of persistent hiccups secondary to aspiration pneumonia was made. The patient was immediately started on antibiotics and a low-dose chlorpromazine infusion, and his blood pressure was closely monitored. 

Discharge Summary:
The patient was treated for persistent hiccups secondary to aspiration pneumonia and showed a near-complete resolution of his symptoms within 36 hours of treatment and a complete resolution prior to discharge four days later. Laboratory investigations were repeated prior to discharge and a decrease was noted in both CRP and leukocytes. The patient was transitioned to a 10-day course of oral antibiotics and metronidazole. At follow-up 14 days later, the patient reported no recurrence of the hiccups. The patient was counseled on the importance of continued follow-up with his primary care physician, maintaining a healthy lifestyle, and adhering to his medication regimen. Detailed discharge instructions were provided to both the patient and his family, and all questions were answered to their satisfaction.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 59
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Soft Tissue Plasmacytoma

HOSPITAL COURSE

The patient was admitted to the hospital with a gradually increasing mass located in the soft tissue of the oral cavity. The pathology report showed increased infiltration of the buccal mucosa with monoclonal plasma cells, and the diagnosis of soft tissue plasmacytoma was confirmed. The patient received localized radiotherapy with a total dose of 40 Gy, and the bone marrow biopsy revealed the absence of neoplastic infiltration.

After five years, the patient presented with a painless swelling in his right testis. An ultrasound of the scrotum was performed that showed a hypoechoic mass in the right testicle with increased vascularization, and a normal-appearing left testis. The patient subsequently underwent a right radical orchiectomy and histopathology report showed testicular infiltration by a plasma cell neoplasm with identical immunophenotype to the primary site in the oral cavity. After one year, the patient presented again with painless swelling of his left testis that was attributed to disease relapse.

TREATMENT

The patient refused to undergo left orchiectomy, thus he proceeded with systemic treatment based on lenalidomide, bortezomib and dexamethasone. Following 4 cycles of treatment, the patient underwent high dose melphalan with autologous stem cell transplantation. A complete response was achieved with negative PET/CT scan and negative marrow minimal residual disease assessment. The patient continued on lenalidomide maintenance; however, six months later he was diagnosed with disease relapse in his left testicle. Since the patient refused surgery, he was initiated with next-line therapy, with bortezomib, cyclophosphamide and dexamethasone, he responded partially and still remains in remission.

FOLLOW-UP

The patient will continue to undergo close monitoring with regular imaging studies to detect any signs of disease relapse. The hospital or the patient's primary care physician should be notified immediately if the patient presents with any new symptoms or complications.

DISCHARGE DISPOSITION

The patient remains under the care of the hospital for further monitoring and treatment. The patient understands the need for close follow-up care and has been instructed to attend all appointments and follow-up visits.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 12-year-old Bahraini male

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented to the A&E with a history of a fall resulting in an obvious elbow joint deformity. Plain radiographs showed a fracture-dislocation involving the olecranon process, Salter-Harris type I fracture of the radial neck, and posterior elbow joint dislocation.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent open reduction and internal fixation of the fracture under general anesthesia and was placed in a lateral position. The radial head was indirectly reduced, and the olecranon was directly visualized and reduced and held with a tension band and two 1.6 mm K-wires. The elbow was protected with an above-elbow slab for three weeks, and active and passive elbow range of motion was initiated thereafter.

Outcome:
The patient completed the six weeks of fixation with uneventful healing of the bone and complete range of flexion, extension, supination, and pronation. The implant was removed after six months, and the patient continued to have a full range of motion with evidence of bony union.

Follow-Up:
Recommend a follow-up appointment in [time frame] for a re-evaluation of the patient's condition.

Discharge Instructions:
To ensure a successful recovery, the patient should follow the recommended follow-up appointment, comply with medication regimens, and maintain a healthy lifestyle.

[Names of medical team members involved in the patient's care]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Patient’s Name]
Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]
Date of Admission: [Date of Admission]
Date of Discharge: [Date of Discharge]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 38-year-old Caucasian woman, presented to the emergency department at 35 weeks of gestation with acute right hip pain associated with right leg shortening and external rotation. Her medical history was significant for hereditary thrombophilia and secondary anemia. Hip radiography revealed an unstable displaced right-sided femoral neck fracture with no evidence of osteonecrosis. The patient underwent emergency cesarean section due to premature rupture of membranes. A healthy 2300 g female was successfully delivered, and three days later, the patient was transferred to the orthopedic surgery department for the treatment of the fracture.

Treatment:
Due to the fracture's significant degree of displacement, the patient underwent total hip arthroplasty. The fracture was treated with a total uncemented prosthesis consisting of a 50 mm cup with 32 mm ultra-high-molecular-weight polyethylene insert and a 32 mm head with a 4 mm ceramic insert. Postoperative radiography confirmed the correct placement of the prosthesis. Antibiotic and anticoagulant prophylaxis was initiated with ampicillin/sulbactam and enoxaparin sodium, respectively.

Complications:
Three days after the intervention, the patient developed moderate abdominal pain without fever and accelerated intestinal transit, which both worsened over the next four days. The diagnosis of Clostridium difficile infection was ambiguous. Empiric treatment with metronidazole was initiated, and there was quick improvement. The patient was discharged five days later.

Follow-Up:
Close follow-up was advised with orthopedic and obstetric follow-up evaluations as an outpatient.

Instructions:
The patient was instructed to maintain a normal healthy diet and to continue with follow-up appointments with her obstetrician and orthopedic surgeon. The patient was advised not to put any weight on the affected leg and to use the prescribed walking aids. The patient was also instructed to avoid activities that may place stress on the affected leg, such as running, jumping, or twisting motions, and to avoid long periods of sitting or standing.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Age: 21

Sex: Male

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Dengue fever with acute pancreatitis

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with complaints of fever, vomiting, pain in the abdomen, headache, and myalgia for three days. The patient tested positive for nonstructural antigen 1 for dengue fever and was diagnosed with acute pancreatitis with a score of 2/10 (mild) as per the revised Atlanta classification of acute pancreatitis.

The patient was kept nil by mouth and was treated with intravenous fluids, antibiotics, antipyretics, opioids, and proton pump inhibitors. During the course of the hospital stay, the patient gradually improved along with an increase in platelet count. The patient did not require any platelet transfusion. Along with the improvement in hematological parameters, there was a decrease in amylase and lipase levels.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of fever, vomiting, pain in the abdomen, headache, and myalgia for three days. The patient tested positive for nonstructural antigen 1 for dengue fever and was diagnosed with mild acute pancreatitis. During the course of the hospital stay, the patient was treated with intravenous fluids, antibiotics, antipyretics, opioids, and proton pump inhibitors.

The patient gradually improved along with an increase in platelet count. The patient did not require any platelet transfusion and was kept nil by mouth. Along with the improvement in hematological parameters, there was a decrease in amylase and lipase levels. Follow-up:

Patient Signature: [REDACTED]

Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course Summary:

Admitted with the complaint of a gradually enlarging, painless, tender lump on the right medial thigh. Laboratory blood test were unremarkable, and MRI Scan suggested soft tissue neoplasm with a possibility of neurogenic tumor. Excisional biopsy was performed and the pathology report revealed a high-grade sarcoma, favoring the epithelioid variant of PLS. Furthermore, the patient was referred to the Department of Nuclear Medicine & Molecular Imaging for a post-surgical restaging and assessment of possible metastases. The 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography-computed tomography (18F-FDG PET-CT) scan revealed an ill-defined hypermetabolic hypodense lesion involving segment VI of the liver, multiple hypermetabolic osseous lesions involving the skull base, right iliac bone, and few vertebrae, which was suggestive of skeletal metastases, and a non-hypermetabolic pulmonary nodule in the right lung field. Microscopic residual disease cannot be completely ruled out, and the patient was due for further biopsy of the suspected metastases lesions, but the patient did not attend the follow-up appointments.

Hospital Course:

Admitted with: red and painful areas on lower extremities associated with swelling 5 days after receiving Pfizer vaccine. 

History of Present Illness:

Patient received all childhood vaccinations without complications. No history of infections, sore throat, or diarrhea.

Past Medical History:

No prior skin lesions or systemic diseases. No use of topical or systemic medication.

Physical Examination:

Examination revealed tender and erythematous nodules on both legs.

Vaccine-Related Erythema Nodosum or Arthus-like phenomenon

Treatment:

Oral ibuprofen 600 mg four times daily for symptom relief.

Outcome:

Patient improved within three days of treatment, and nodules started to flatten. Two weeks after receiving treatment, symptoms had completely resolved.

All laboratory investigations were normal. No appreciable laboratory or diagnostic results mentioned in the case report.

Follow-up:

None mentioned in the case report.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Dates of Admission: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the hospital with right hip and low back pain with radiation to his posterior right thigh. He had reproducible pain in the right sacroiliac joint region after SI joint provocative testing. Preoperative imaging revealed lumbarization of the S1 vertebra, mammillary bodies in the alar region, and a residual S1-S2 disc. The patient underwent SI joint fusion using the iFuse implant System® (SI-Bone, Inc., Santa Clara, California). On postoperative day 19, the patient presented to the emergency room with a three-day history of pain in the right gluteal and posterior thigh regions. Physical exam revealed a well-healed surgical incision with a large bruise extending from his right hip down the right leg. CT of the pelvis showed a large gluteal hematoma that extended into the posterior compartment of the thigh. CT angiogram (CTA) of the right lower extremity showed disruption of the blood flow through the superior gluteal artery at the level of the inferior two implants as the vessel exited the greater sciatic notch. Interventional radiology was consulted for possible embolization, but they determined there was no visible active extravasation and recommended observation and serial hemoglobin draws. The patient's hemoglobin dropped over 24 hours and the decision was made to take the patient to the operating room for exploration and removal of hematoma. The surgical team successfully evacuated the hematoma and identified a branch of the superior gluteal artery that was lacerated with active bleeding. The vessel was clamped and ligated using 3-0 silk sutures. A 15-French subfascial Jackson Pratt drain was placed at the end of the procedure. On postoperative day three, he was discharged in improved condition and his surgical drain was removed at the three-week postoperative visit.

Diagnosis:
Right hip and low back pain

Procedure:
SI joint fusion using the iFuse implant System®

Complication:
Gluteal hematoma, laceration of the superior gluteal artery

Condition at Discharge:
Improved

Follow-up Care:
Two-month follow-up visit, walking unassisted and not requiring pain medicines at four-month follow-up visit

Instructions at Discharge:
None specified in case report.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital from the emergency department for unresponsiveness. On presentation, the patient was lethargic, had facial swelling, macroglossia, and bibasilar crackles of the lung fields. Laboratory results revealed elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone and low free thyroxine. The EKG showed low voltage QRS complexes with electrical alternans, and CXR showed an enlarged cardiac silhouette with congested lung fields. The patient was diagnosed with myxedema coma secondary to iatrogenic hypothyroidism and was treated with intravenous levothyroxine and hydrocortisone. The endocrinology service was consulted, and the patient was transferred to the medicine telemetry service for further management.

Hospital Course:
The following day, transthoracic echocardiogram revealed a large pericardial effusion with heart swinging in the pericardial sac and the diastolic collapse of both atria and right ventricle. The patient was upgraded to the Cardiac ICU and underwent urgent pericardiocentesis with 1300 mL straw-colored fluid drained. Pericardial fluid analysis was negative for malignant cells, acid-fast bacilli stain, and culture. Following pericardiocentesis, the patient was discharged on levothyroxine. Serial TSH and T4 measurements over the subsequent two months showed normalization of both values.

Course of Treatment:
The patient was managed with intravenous levothyroxine and hydrocortisone to treat iatrogenic hypothyroidism. Urgent pericardiocentesis was performed in the Cardiac ICU to treat large pericardial effusion with diastolic collapse of both atria and the right ventricle. The patient was discharged on levothyroxine.

Follow-up Care:
On six months follow-up, repeat TTE showed diminishing pericardial effusion without echocardiographic evidence of cardiac tamponade. No further follow-up is needed at this time. 

Diagnosis:
Myxedema coma secondary to iatrogenic hypothyroidism with large pericardial effusion.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient's condition has improved, and she no longer requires hospitalization.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: __________

Medical Record Number: __________

Admission Date: __________

Discharge Date: __________

Admitting Diagnosis:

95-year-old female with past medical history of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, hypertension, and asthma admitted for evaluation of nausea, vomiting, and a two-month history of intermittent diarrhea, worsening for the last few days.

Hospital Course:

Upon admission, the patient complained of severe, diffuse, waxing, and waning abdominal cramps, which were relieved after episodes of vomiting. As per laboratory and stool studies, hypokalemia was noted along with normal lipase, transaminases, and bilirubin levels. A CT scan of the abdomen revealed intussusception with the lead point not categorized.

On the following day, the patient underwent an open procedure right hemicolectomy and the abnormal area was removed. The surgical pathology revealed high-grade dysplasia in a tubulovillous adenoma without in-situ or invasive carcinoma.

Postoperative Course:

The patient's kidney function decreased (Cr 1.3 mg/dl with oliguria) on postoperative day two but was tackled by administering IV fluids. The patient received home care services and was subsequently discharged on day six.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Intussusception with high-grade dysplasia in a tubulovillous adenoma causing hypokalemia. 

Instructions at the Time of Discharge:

The patient and their immediate caregivers were advised to follow up with their primary care physician for further evaluation and treatment of medical conditions listed above.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course: 
The patient is a 31-year-old Caucasian male who was admitted to the hospital due to a 10-day history of progressively worsening symptoms. He presented initially with a sore throat and dysphagia, followed by a productive cough with orange-colored sputum five days later. Four days before presenting to the ED, he reported experiencing fever, chills, night sweats, significant diarrhea, emesis, and pleuritic chest pain. Upon admission, he appeared ill and anxious. The physical exam revealed a febrile patient, with tachycardia, hypotension, and signs of respiratory distress. He was started on intravenous antibiotics for suspected bacterial pneumonia, and further workup was performed to rule out other potential causes of his symptoms. A portable chest X-Ray showed right upper lobe pneumonia, and a CT angiogram of the chest ruled out pulmonary embolism. A CT scan of the neck revealed no abnormalities.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was hospitalized for five days with a diagnosis of bacterial pneumonia with negative blood cultures. During the hospital stay, he was treated with antibiotics, which led to an improvement in his symptoms. He was discharged home on oral antibiotics and instructed to follow up with his primary care physician for further management.

Admission and Discharge Diagnoses:
Admission Diagnosis: Bacterial pneumonia
Discharge Diagnosis: Resolved bacterial pneumonia

Hospital Course:
The patient was started on one gram of ceftriaxone and 500 mg of azithromycin intravenously for the suspected infection on arrival, which led to no improvement initially. No notable findings were seen on testing including monospot, rapid streptococcus A antigen via pharyngeal swab, (1,3)-beta-D-glucan, and HIV-1 RNA via serum. The patient was negative for Mycoplasma pneumoniae, SARS-CoV-2, or Chlamydia pneumoniae by PCR. A portable chest X-Ray demonstrated right upper lobe pneumonia, and a CT angiogram of the chest was performed, which ruled out pulmonary emboli. His antibiotic regimen was then escalated to three grams of ampicillin-sulbactam every six hours, resulting in improved WBC counts. Blood cultures taken on the fifth day of hospitalization grew a single anaerobic gram-negative bacterium, F. necrophorum. The patient’s condition improved and he was discharged with oral antibiotics, amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, every 12 hours for seven days.

Follow-Up Plan:
The patient was advised to follow up with the primary care physician in three weeks for a repeat CT scan of his chest to monitor the resolution of pulmonary lesions.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged home with stable vital signs and no evidence of ongoing symptoms.

Medications at Discharge:
Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, given orally every twelve hours for seven days.

Instructions at Discharge:
The patient was advised to follow up with his primary care physician in three weeks for a repeat CT scan of his chest to monitor the resolution of pulmonary lesions.

The patient should continue to take prednisone as prescribed and follow-up with his primary care physician. Any recurrence of thrombocytopenia or symptoms of COVID-19 should be reported to the healthcare provider immediately.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 21 years
Gender: Male
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the psychiatric ward due to an agitated and aggressive state after a violent conflict with his parents. Clinical findings were compatible with acute intoxication, and the patient confirmed substance abuse, but the exact quantity of intake could not be determined at admission. The patient was diagnosed with acute organic delirium caused by GHB withdrawal on the second day, and treatment was initiated. The patient's psychopharmacological treatment was intensified with olanzapine and intravenous diazepam. On day 11, the psychiatrists decided to initiate bilateral frontotemporal ECT as "en bloc" treatment. The ECT series were shown in figure form. The patient's level of agitation decreased after the second ECT was administered. After the fourth ECT, all sedatives and psychopharmacological treatment were discontinued, and the patient was transferred to a general internal medicine ward. The patient displayed no neurological or psychiatric symptoms on day 18.

Summary of Care:
The patient was admitted to the psychiatric ward due to acute intoxication and was diagnosed with acute organic delirium caused by GHB withdrawal. The patient's psychopharmacological treatment was intensified with olanzapine and intravenous diazepam. On day 11, the psychiatrists decided to initiate bilateral frontotemporal ECT as "en bloc" treatment. The patient's level of agitation decreased after the second ECT was administered. After the fourth ECT, all sedatives and psychopharmacological treatment were discontinued, and the patient was transferred to a general internal medicine ward. The patient showed complete remission before discharge.

Diagnoses:
1. Acute organic delirium caused by GHB withdrawal

Procedures:
1. Bilateral frontotemporal ECT as "en bloc" treatment

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition improved, and he was discharged without any neurological or psychiatric symptoms.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to follow up with psychiatric services for further evaluation and management. He was informed about drug addiction services and the importance of abstinence from substance abuse. The patient provided consent to report his case in the medical literature.

Patient Information:
- Name: [Patient name]
- Age: 56
- Gender: Female
- Ethnicity: North African
- Medical and Surgical History: None

Chief complaint:
- Raynaud phenomenon for 3 months
- Inflammatory arthralgias affecting wrists, elbows, and ankles
- Pain and proximal muscle weakness in lower limbs
- Weakness extended to upper limbs
- Slight dysphonia and dysphagia

Hospital Course:
- Physical examination revealed proximal tetraparesis and mild neck, shoulder, hip, and ankle weakness
- Tendon reflexes were normal
- Nail fold capillary microscopy was normal
- Blood tests showed high levels of creatinine kinase (CK) enzyme
- Autoimmune screening for myositis-specific and myositis-associated autoantibodies were negative
- Electromyography (EMG) showed signs of myopathy
- Muscle biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of inflammatory myopathy
- Prednisone treatment was initiated, leading to a slight improvement in muscle weakness and a decrease in CK serum level
- Development of intermittent diplopia, ptosis, and dysarthria a month later
- Serum acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies were positive, muscle-specific kinase antibodies were negative
- Computed tomography (CT) revealed a large anterior mediastinal mass
- Thymoma was identified on a subsequent biopsy
- Diagnosis of inflammatory myositis associated with myasthenia gravis were made
- Specialized treatment with pyridostigmine and steroids was initiated, leading to significant improvements in generalized weakness, ptosis, and dysarthria
- Thymectomy was performed as part of an additional treatment plan
- Currently on low dose steroid and pyridostigmine, and is asymptomatic 
- Features of myositis have not relapsed

Diagnosis:
- Inflammatory myopathy
- Myasthenia gravis
- Thymoma

Plan:
- Continue low dose steroid and pyridostigmine treatment
- Follow up with medical team as scheduled to monitor health and response to treatment

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 70

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer, and a high carbohydrate antigen 19-9 level. Enhanced CT revealed a 15-mm mass in the pancreatic body and dilatation of the peripheral main pancreatic duct. The patient underwent DP with lymph node dissection. DP was performed by transecting the pancreas at the right border of the portal vein with a powered linear stapler. Additional pancreatic tissue was observed on the dorsal aspect of the portal vein and the patient was diagnosed with pancreas-associated protein type II. After the diagnosis, additional pancreatic resection was conducted using a powered linear stapler. The total operative time was 527 minutes, and the estimated blood loss was 730 mL. Based on the TNM staging, the pathological diagnosis was T3N0M0, stage IIA. In addition, the pathological margin was negative. The patient had no complications and was discharged on postoperative day 23.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted for pancreatic cancer and underwent DP with lymph node dissection followed by additional pancreatic resection due to the diagnosis of pancreas-associated protein type II. The pathological diagnosis was T3N0M0, stage IIA with no complications. The patient was discharged on postoperative day 23.

Discharge Summary:
