Discharge Date: [insert date]

Patient Name: [insert name]
DOB: [insert date of birth]
Gender: Female

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted due to newly diagnosed duodenal papillary carcinoma. The diagnosis was made based on preoperative CT images and confirmed via pathological biopsy. The patient underwent a successful pancreaticoduodenectomy (PD) with lymph node dissection followed by transection of the pancreas. During the procedure, the pancreatic parenchyma was identified and transected resulting in a 2 mm section of the main pancreatic duct being exposed. The pathological margin was negative, and the patient was diagnosed with PAP (type II). The patient experienced a grade-B pancreatic fistula and recovered after conservative treatment. The patient's total operative time was 439 minutes, and the estimated blood loss was 250 mL.

Diagnosis:

The patient has a history of familial adenomatous polyposis and rectal cancer. The patient is also newly diagnosed with duodenal papillary carcinoma. The patient was diagnosed with PAP (type II) during the pancreaticoduodenectomy.

Treatment:

The patient underwent a successful pancreaticoduodenectomy (PD) with lymph node dissection followed by transection of the pancreas. During the procedure, the pancreatic parenchyma was identified and transected resulting in a 2 mm section of the main pancreatic duct being exposed. The patient recovered after conservative treatment of the grade-B pancreatic fistula.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient recovered well and was discharged in stable condition on day 18 post-surgery.

Follow-up:

The patient requires regular follow-up with the treating physician to monitor recovery progress.

Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]

Patient Name: [NAME]

Medical Record Number: [NUMBER]

Diagnosis:
- Fetal chromosome aberration del (18) (q22.3; q23)

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 27-year-old G1P0 pregnant woman, was admitted to the hospital after obtaining non-invasive prenatal gene detection that indicated a high risk of trisomy 18. Ultrasound examination at 23+2 weeks of gestation revealed a single live fetus with a gestational age of 23+2 weeks in utero, along with the umbilical cord wrapped around the neck of the fetus. According to measurement indexes of fetal development, amniocentesis, chromosome karyotype analysis, and CNVs were recommended to further determine the condition of the fetal chromosome.

Chromosome karyotype analysis showed that the fetal chromosomes were del (18) (q22.3; q23). CNV detection results confirmed the genotype of the fetus that detected a definite pathogenic genomic 18q22.3q23.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in the confirmed diagnosis of Fetal chromosome aberration del (18) (q22.3; q23), following appropriate evaluation and consultation.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient was scheduled for regular follow-up at the obstetrics department to monitor the pregnancy and provide appropriate care. The patient was advised to undergo genetic counseling for further support and guidance.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: Not specified
Age: 35 years old
Gender: Female
Hospital Admission Date: Not specified
Hospital Discharge Date: Not specified

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital following the results of non-invasive prenatal gene detection. Ultrasound examination showed that there was a single live fetus in utero, but it was difficult to determine whether the fetus had only 1 umbilical artery to supply blood. The couple requested amniocentesis, chromosome karyotype analysis, and CNVs to further confirm the diagnosis.

Upon reviewing the results of chromosome karyotype analysis after amniocentesis, the fetal chromosome karyotype was found to be 46, XY, del (18) (q22.2; q23). CNV detection results showed that this sample detected chromosome aneuploidy or CNVs of more than 100 kb, which was regarded as the definite pathogenic genomic: seq [hg19] del (18) (q22.1q23), chr18: g.6602000178020000del. After half a year, personnel of the prenatal diagnosis center followed up the 2 couples and learned that both couples voluntarily terminated their pregnancy after knowing the results of amniocentesis.

Conclusion:
This patient was diagnosed with a fetal chromosome abnormality and chose to terminate the pregnancy voluntarily after receiving the results of amniocentesis. Prenatal diagnosis center personnel followed up on the couple's decision to terminate the pregnancy. No further information is available at this time.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]          Sex: Male	   Age: 78 years	 

Date of Admission: February 28, 2018
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course	

The patient presented at the clinic with complaints of numbness in the soles of both feet. On lumbar MRI, severe L4-5 central stenosis and root redundancy were diagnosed. On February 28, 2018, L4-5 OLIF, followed by bilateral L4 laminotomy and L4-5 percutaneous posterior screw fixation (PPSF) was performed. 

Postoperatively, there was an increase in the disc height and foramen height. Two days later, the patient was allowed to walk while wearing an orthosis, and the radiating pain improved; he was then discharged from the hospital. At 6 weeks after surgery, lumbar CT and radiographic examination showed that the fusion was maintained without subsidence of the surgical site.

In the 10th week after surgery, the patient visited the outpatient clinic with a cane, complaining of persistent pain below both ankles and motor weakness of the right ankle. A decrease in dorsiflexion of the right ankle was observed. The Medical Research Council (MRC) muscle strength grade of the right ankle was 2. We confirmed the resolution of the previous central stenosis and root redundancy on lumbar MRI and found no other specific findings.

On May 21, 2018, the patient underwent right L4/5 facetectomy and foraminotomy to release the right L4 nerve root. During surgery, the tissues compressing the L4 nerve root and the osteophyte protruding severely and trapping the nerve root were identified and removed. Within 1 week of hospitalization after surgery, the radiating pain in both feet disappeared, and dorsiflexion of the right ankle was restored to MRC grade 4. After the second surgery, follow-up CT of the lumbar spine confirmed clear decompression of the right foramen.

Impression	

This is a case of a 78-year-old male with severe L4-5 central stenosis and root redundancy, who underwent L4-5 OLIF, bilateral L4 laminotomy, and L4-5 PPSF. The patient presented with persistent pain below both ankles and motor weakness of the right ankle 10 weeks after the procedure, which prompted a second surgery with right L4/5 facetectomy and foraminotomy. The symptoms resolved after the second surgery. 

Plan	

Continue to monitor the patient after the second surgery and provide supportive care as needed. Follow up with the patient to assess the long-term effectiveness of the procedure to release the right L4 nerve root. Provide further targeted treatment if necessary. Educate the patient about the surgery and the importance of taking measures to prevent further spinal cord injury.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 80 years old
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admission Diagnosis: Suspected traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage
Discharge Diagnosis: Distal PICA aneurysm

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to our hospital with a history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and cerebral infarction ten years prior. She also had a recent minor head trauma that caused a headache. An initial non-contrast brain CT scan revealed minimal subarachnoid hemorrhage on the left ambient cistern with an enlarged ventricle. She was admitted to the neurosurgery department as a suspected case of traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage. The CT angiography showed no vascular abnormalities. After ten days of hospitalization, the patient showed sudden stuporous mental deterioration. A subsequent brain CT scan revealed subarachnoid hemorrhage on all the cisterns, with intraventricular hemorrhage. The patient underwent digital subtraction angiography that revealed a bilobulated distal PICA aneurysm.

Treatment:
The patient underwent coil embolization under general anesthesia. The Right femoral artery puncture was made after left subclavian angiography, in which the left vertebral artery was not visible. A catheter optimized for intracranial access was advanced to the V4 segment of the right vertebral artery to reach the Headway 17 microcatheter to the aneurysmal sac. After deploying the coil in the VA just before the PICA origin, the microcatheter was positioned in the PICA with the help of the coil mass. Additional coil deployment took place after accidentally migrating some of the coil masses to the VA origin. The procedure was completed after the confirmation of PICA occlusion.

Outcome:
The patient recovered fully with supportive care in the ICU after the coil embolization, and follow-up MRI results showed no acute cerebral infarction in the PICA territory. The patient underwent a follow-up angiography a year after the procedure, which revealed no aneurysmal sacs in the distal PICA, and the recanalized VA was located medial to the deployed coil mass.

Care Plan:
The patient will follow up closely with a neurologist for the management of high blood pressure and dyslipidemia to prevent future complications. The patient should avoid any head trauma to prevent similar complications in the future.

Signature/Stamp:
[REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
An 8-year-old child was admitted with complaints of purpura, hematemesis, bloody stools, and abdominal pain. He had an erythematous pinpoint rash on his arms that had spread to his legs. The patient was diagnosed with Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) with alimentary tract hemorrhage and was treated with methylprednisolone, infusion of blood products, and somatostatin. However, the treatment was not successful as the patient still had massive gastrointestinal hemorrhage, poor circulation, a reduced level of consciousness, and unstable vital signs.

Diagnostic Studies:
Abdominal ultrasonography and plain abdominal radiography gave negative results for enterobrosis. A contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen showed liquid samples and gas shadows on the left and front of the stomach.

Medical Management:
The patient underwent an emergency laparotomy. The surgery discovered that the anterior wall of the descending duodenum was thinner with a 1 cm × 1 cm diameter perforation, and the posterior wall had a 3 cm × 1 cm ulcer, which had penetrated into the peritoneum of the pancreas and experienced active bleeding from the broken end of the vessel. He was administered postoperative care such as nasal continuous positive airway pressure-assisted ventilation, anti-infection treatment, albumin transfusion, platelet transfusion, abdominal drainage, methylprednisolone, fluconazole antifungal treatment, and wound dressing.

Follow-up:
The patient's general symptoms gradually improved, vital signs were stable, and abdominal pain was relieved. The drainage tube was removed after discharge, and the abdominal CT was repeated after 1 month. The duodenostomy tube was removed 50 days after the surgery. During the 2-month follow-up assessment, there was no evidence of rebleeding.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Gender: [Gender]
Age: [Age]
Hospital Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Hospital Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

History of Present Illness:
The patient was admitted to the emergency service after a ski injury resulting in an effusion of the knee and severe posterior knee pain. Initial physical examination showed tenderness of the posterior structures of the knee, limited ROM, and pain with extension. Radiological studies confirmed the presence of avulsed fragments belonging to the PCL and lateral meniscus along with concomitant avulsion fractures of the medial meniscus and PCL. The patient underwent surgical management, and temporary fixation of the medial meniscus's avulsion fracture was done with Kirschner wires, followed by permanent fixation with two headless 3.0 mm compression screws, and subsequently the PCL avulsion fracture was fixed with a 4.0 mm partially threaded, cannulated, cancellous screw with a washer. Post-operative X-rays showed fracture healing, and weight-bearing was resumed in the sixth week after the surgery. The patient reported progress in visual analog scale score and Lysholm score in follow-ups.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to a ski injury resulting in avulsed fragments belonging to the PCL and lateral meniscus along with concomitant avulsion fractures of the medial meniscus and PCL. The patient underwent surgical management with temporary fixation of the medial meniscus's avulsion fracture done with Kirschner wires, followed by permanent fixation with two headless 3.0 mm compression screws, and subsequently the PCL avulsion fracture was fixed with a 4.0 mm partially threaded, cannulated, cancellous screw with a washer. The patient underwent post-operative X-ray evaluations and follow-ups.

Condition on Discharge:
At the time of discharge, the patient was asymptomatic and had achieved full weight-bearing and ROM without pain in the third month after the operation.

Final Diagnosis:
Avulsion fractures of the medial meniscus and PCL along with avulsed fragments belonging to the PCL and lateral meniscus.

Follow-up Recommendations:
The patient was advised to continue weight-bearing as tolerated and to avoid any activities that might result in knee injury. The patient was also advised to follow up with the orthopedic surgeon for further evaluation at regular intervals.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A
Admitting Diagnosis: Vision loss affecting the left eye
Final Diagnosis: Superior temporal BRVO and secondary ME

Hospital Course:
The 71-year-old female patient presented to our hospital in January 2018 with vision loss affecting her left eye. The best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) in her left eye was 13/20. The patient's UWPC and OCT images showed inferior temporal BRVO and secondary macular edema (ME) in her left eye. The patient received three doses of intravitreal aflibercept (IVA), which resolved her ME. Her BCVA improved to 20/20, and no recurrence was found at the time of follow-up.

In July 2021, the patient received her second dose of the SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccine BNT162b2 (Pfizer-BioNTech). The following day, she reported vision loss in her left eye, and her BCVA decreased to 20/30. UWPC and OCT imaging showed superior temporal BRVO and secondary ME in her left eye. The patient received an additional one-time dose of IVA, which resolved her ME. Her BCVA improved to 20/20, and no avascular area was found on OCT angiography.

The patient had not previously been infected with SARS-CoV-2. No other significant past medical history was reported. The patient was discharged home in stable condition.

Hospital Course Summary:
A 71-year-old female patient presented with vision loss affecting her left eye. UWPC and OCT imaging confirmed inferior temporal BRVO and secondary ME in her left eye. The patient received three doses of IVA, which resolved her ME, and her BCVA improved to 20/20 with no recurrence. In July 2021, the patient received her second dose of the SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccine BNT162b2, after which she reported vision loss in her left eye. Imaging showed superior temporal BRVO and secondary ME in her left eye. The patient received an additional one-time dose of IVA, which resolved her ME, and her BCVA improved to 20/20. The patient was discharged home in stable condition.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]
Admitting Diagnosis: Possible pulmonary infection

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 51-year-old male, was admitted to our center with symptoms of cough, fatigue, and shortness of breath for 2 weeks. He had a previous episode of pulmonary cryptococcosis and was being treated for chronic HBV infection. CT scans showed multiple areas of consolidations and ground-glass shadows of bilateral lung fields. Laboratory examinations showed high C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. A pulmonary infection was initially suspected and piperacillin sodium/tazobactam sodium was given for 1 week, but no improvement was observed. Contrast-enhanced CT scans showed multiple consolidations and ground-glass shadows with rough margins. Further examinations, including bronchoscopic examinations and laboratory testing, were performed. Cryptococcal antigen testing was positive, leading to a clinical diagnosis of pulmonary cryptococcosis.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with fluconazole (200mg/day) and bicyclol (50mg/day) orally for 3 weeks. After the antifungal therapy, the patient's symptoms disappeared, and the abnormality on the CT scan improved. The patient was discharged with instructions to continue taking medication as prescribed.

Follow-up:
During the follow-up of 3 and 6 months, the patient's condition improved, and he recovered fully. Cryptococcal antigen level was 12.57ng/mL. During the 2-year follow-up, no recurrence occurred. 

Summary:
The patient was diagnosed with pulmonary cryptococcosis and treated with fluconazole and bicyclol, which resulted in symptom improvement and recovery. The patient was discharged with instructions to continue taking his medication as prescribed. Future follow-up is recommended to monitor for any recurrence.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Syncope

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of fainting. The patient had no history of medical problems and was not taking any medications. All his test results, such as electrolyte level, hemoglobin level, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and C-reactive protein level were normal. Additionally, his electrocardiogram, 24 hours ambulatory electrocardiogram monitoring, echocardiogram, tilt table test, and exercise tolerance test showed no abnormal findings. In the physical examination, the patient did not show any neurological symptoms including motor, sensory, or cognitive deficits. The deep tendon reflex was normoactive in all the extremities. Based on the patient's history and examination results, the cardiologist diagnosed the patient with transient loss of consciousness due to syncope.

Diagnostic Imaging:
To confirm the diagnosis, the patient underwent DCE MRI scans. In the Ktrans map of DCE MRI of healthy control participants, no specific abnormal findings were observed. However, in the patient, bright blue-colored lines were observed within the sulci throughout the cerebral cortex, indicating disruption of the BBB of vessels in the overall cerebral sulci. The quantitative analysis showed that the averaged T2 intensity was 403.95 ± 24.91 (AU) for healthy control and 404.50 ± 24.21 (AU) for the patient, which was not statistically different. The average Ktrans within 10 randomly selected ROIs was 0.000156 ± 0.000099 (minutes−1) for healthy controls and 0.001067 ± 0.000806 (minutes−1) for the patient.

Final Diagnosis: Transient loss of consciousness due to syncope with disruption of the blood-brain barrier.

Hospital Course Summary: 
The patient was admitted with a complaint of fainting while hiking on a cold winter night. After ruling out any underlying medical issues, the patient was diagnosed with transient loss of consciousness due to syncope. Additional diagnostic imaging, including DCE-MRI, revealed disruption of the blood-brain barrier, which could explain the fainting episode. The patient was monitored and treated appropriately while in the hospital and discharged in stable condition. Upon discharge, the patient was advised to avoid excessive physical activity in cold temperatures and to follow up with the treating physician if any further symptoms developed.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Sex: Female
Age: 80 years old
Date of admission: [REDACTED]
Date of discharge: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Bleeding from the prolapsed uterus

Clinical Synopsis:
An 80-year-old female was admitted with bleeding from the prolapsed uterus. The patient had a history of 3 vaginal births, the most recent one at the age of 30. Upon admission, a large portion of the vagina containing the cervix and part of the uterine body was found below the vaginal introitus (International Continence Society grade 3). Further examination revealed an exophytic infiltrating lesion covering the entire surface of the hypertrophic cervix spreading to the vaginal fornices.

Diagnostic Procedure:
The lesion in the cervix was sampled, and a rectoscopy was performed with sampling of the anal canal lesion for histopathology. The microscopic examination revealed, in the cervical specimen, moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma, featuring a strong and diffuse immunohistochemical p16 reaction in the neoplastic cells. In addition, the microscopic examination of the biopsy specimen from the anal canal lesion revealed moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. MRI was also performed and revealed prolapsed cervix of irregular morphology, multiple low T2 signal round myometrial lesions suggestive of uterine fibroids, and an irregular mass-like thickening of the distal part of the rectum and anal canal.

Treatment:
The patient underwent a radical vaginal hysterectomy with extensive colpectomy preceded by laparoscopic pelvic and para-aortic lymphadenectomy, followed by radiotherapy. The patient did not consent to the anal extirpation due to personal reasons.

Discharge Condition:
The patient has been discharged in stable condition.

Medications:
The patient has been given appropriate medications. Please consult the medication list in the electronic health record.

Follow-up:
The duration of follow-up was six months.

Summary:
The patient was admitted for bleeding from the prolapsed uterus and diagnosed with moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma and moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. The patient underwent a radical vaginal hysterectomy with extensive colpectomy preceded by laparoscopic pelvic and para-aortic lymphadenectomy, followed by radiotherapy. The patient has been discharged in stable condition, and follow-up will continue for the next six months.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not Provided
Gender: Female 
Age: 43 years 
Medical Record Number: Not Provided

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with bilateral vocal cord polyps. After diagnostic laryngoscopy, the patient underwent vocal cord polyp resection via transoral laser microsurgery. The procedure was performed successfully with no intraoperative complications. Routine nasotracheal intubation with a video laryngoscope was performed before the operation, and the endotracheal tube cuff was filled with water to make inadvertent laser damage noticeable. A saline-soaked absorbent cotton was also placed at the subglottis to protect the trachea.

Fifteen hours after the operation, the patient experienced sudden dull pain in the anterior neck, which was evaluated with a direct rigid laryngoscopy that revealed no abnormalities. The patient was discharged from the hospital. However, the patient returned to the emergency room eight hours later due to subcutaneous emphysema and cough. A head, neck, and chest CT scan revealed mediastinal emphysema and extensive subcutaneous emphysema from the base of the skull to the chest, along with a suspected tear on the membranous trachea located 4.5 cm under the glottis, extending to ∼8.5 cm under the glottis.

The patient underwent emergency surgical chest exploration, which revealed a 4-cm long and narrow tracheal tear on the membranous trachea that was successfully sutured with no other injuries being identified. The patient was discharged on the 11th postoperative day due to recovery. No tracheal stenosis or respiratory dysfunction was noted during follow-up after one month.

Diagnosis:
Bilateral vocal cord polyps 

Procedures:
Transoral laser microsurgery vocal cord polyp resection
Routine nasotracheal intubation with a video laryngoscope 

Follow-up and Outcomes:
No tracheal stenosis or respiratory dysfunction was noted during follow-up after one month from the date of surgery. 

Significant Findings and Treatment:
The patient had a suspected tear on the membranous trachea, extending to ∼8.5 cm under the glottis, which was identified and treated surgically with no postoperative complications reported. 

Discharge Medications:
None 

Instructions:
The patient has been advised to avoid any strenuous physical activity or heavy lifting for a minimum period of 4 weeks. The patient has been advised to follow up with the doctor after one month for a postoperative evaluation.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Prob and III-3
Age: 32
Gender: Male

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]
Length of Stay: [insert length of stay]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the Department of Neurology of our hospital for unsteady steps. The patient gradually had unsteady steps for more than 7 months and became worse over time before admission. The patient complained of recent difficulties with eye-opening, involuntary tremor of both upper limbs, and catatonia. 

Neurological examination revealed dysarthria, ptosis of both eyes, unstable and inaccurate bilateral finger-nose test, and clumsy bilateral alternating bilateral movements. Auxiliary examinations showed cerebellar atrophy with no clear abnormal signals in the head magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and no atrophy or thinning of the cervical cord in the cervical MRI. 

The patient's familial history revealed that the mother developed similar symptoms in her 30s, the younger maternal uncle began to suffer from illness in his 20s and subsequently died from disease in his 30s, and the daughter of the younger maternal uncle gradually had unsteady steps and unclear speech.

Serum samples of the proband and his cousin were collected to identify the genes involved in the pathogenesis of SCA. Sanger sequencing of the proband and his cousin revealed a c.1852A > G missense mutation in the exon region of the AFG3L2 gene, resulting in a lysine-glutamate amino acid substitution (p.K618E). The clinical manifestations, combined with auxiliary examinations and sequencing results, led to the diagnosis of SCA28. 

The patients did not receive any drug treatment, and the proband received rehabilitation treatment. The symptoms of ataxia were still progressively aggravated.

Discharge Diagnosis: SCA28 

Condition at Discharge:

The patient's condition at the time of discharge remained unchanged. The patient was advised to continue his current treatment. Follow-up appointments were scheduled with the department of Neurology for monitoring of the patient's condition. 

Discharge Medications: N/A 

Follow-Up Plan:

The patient was advised to follow up with the department of Neurology for monitoring of his condition. Further referral for genetic counseling was also recommended. 

Discharge Condition: The patient was discharged in a stable condition. 

Treatment Provided: Rehabilitation treatment was provided to the proband. 

Disposition: The patient was discharged home.

Patient Identification:
Name: Confidential, Mr. X
Age: 35 Years
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:
Mr. X was admitted to our hospital with a history of epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting. Physical examination revealed the presence of asymptomatic brownish variable-sized round macules with scales on both palms and soles that had been present for several months. The skin lesions were consistent with secondary syphilis. Mr. X reported sexual intercourse with multiple sexual partners several months prior to admission. Laboratory evaluation revealed an elevated C-reactive protein level. The serum venereal disease research laboratory test was positive and the fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS) test was reactive.

Diagnostic Findings:
Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) revealed multiple geographic ulcers with easy touch bleeding and whitish exudates in the antrum. The esophagus, body and fundus of the stomach, and duodenum were normal. Endoscopic biopsies taken from the antrum showed a dense mononuclear cell infiltrate with prominent plasma cells on hematoxylin–eosin staining. Warthin-Starry silver staining was subsequently performed, and numerous spirochetes were identified in the lamina propria, confirming gastric syphilis.

Treatment:
Mr. X was treated with an intramuscular injection of 2.4 million units of benzathine penicillin once a week for 3 weeks. His clinical symptoms resolved within 5 days of treatment initiation.

Follow-up:
Follow-up EGD after 2 months showed complete resolution of multiple geographic ulcers. Biopsies of the gastric mucosa were negative for spirochetes, and the lymphocytic infiltrate resolved.

In conclusion, Mr. X was diagnosed with gastric syphilis. He was treated accordingly with intramuscular benzathine penicillin. His symptoms resolved quickly, and he showed complete resolution of multiple geographic ulcers during follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification:
The patient is a 33-year-old man who presented at the outpatient clinic with a 1-month history of epigastric pain.

Hospital Course:
The patient was diagnosed with gastric syphilis after a positive treponema pallidum hemagglutination test and FTA-ABS test. Endoscopic examination revealed multiple flat elevated lesions with focal erosion and ulceration on the body and large geographic ulcers with regular edges and even whitish exudates on the lesser curvature side of the lower body. Warthin-Starry silver staining of endoscopic biopsy specimens confirmed the diagnosis. The patient was treated with an intramuscular injection of benzathine penicillin for three weeks. Clinical symptoms and gastric lesions were completely resolved.

Diagnosis:
Gastric syphilis

Treatment:
The patient received an intramuscular injection of 2.4 million units of benzathine penicillin once a week for 3 weeks.

Follow-up Care:
Follow-up care to monitor for any possible recurrence of the disease is recommended.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Summary:
The 33-year-old male patient was diagnosed with gastric syphilis after presenting with epigastric pain at the outpatient clinic. Endoscopic examination revealed multiple lesions and geographic ulcers in the stomach, which were confirmed through biopsy. The patient received treatment in the form of an intramuscular injection of benzathine penicillin over a period of three weeks, which completely resolved the gastric lesions. Follow-up care is recommended to ensure there is no recurrence of the disease. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Attending Physician: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Medical History:
The patient presented with shortness of breath and was diagnosed with left-sided pneumothorax upon admission. The patient had no significant medical history prior to admission.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient received a 12 French trocar tube to allow their lungs to expand slowly. However, on the day after chest tube insertion, the patient experienced air leakage through the chest tube. An x-ray revealed that the lungs had not expanded much and thus, the partial clamped rubber tube was de-clamped. An hour after de-clamping, the patient suddenly complained of severe respiratory distress, cough with foamy sputum, and vomiting. The chest tube was immediately clamped to stop drainage and the patient was transferred to the intensive care unit for mechanical ventilation. After supportive care including mechanical ventilation and intubation, the patient's condition improved and they were transferred to a general ward. A chest tube was later inserted due to the recurrence of pneumothorax and the patient underwent video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) wedge resection. Following the surgery, the patient recovered without any complications and was discharged.

Assessment and Plan:
The patient showed evidence of left-sided pneumothorax upon admission. The patient underwent a chest tube insertion and VATS surgery, which resulted in recovery without any complications. There were no adverse symptoms found during the 6-month follow-up. The patient was discharged with a recommendation for regular check-ups with their primary care physician.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]   Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]   Admitting Physician: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient, a 6-month-old male, was admitted to our hospital due to a mass on the mandibular alveolar ridge. The patient underwent a CT scan which showed a multicentric osteolytic lesion with expansion of the surrounding bone and numerous displaced tooth germs. A biopsy was performed, and the tumor was diagnosed as MNTI.

The patient underwent a marginal mandibulectomy approximately 5 mm lateral to the tumor which was successful in preserving the inferior margin of the mandible. The mental foramen on the left side was included in the resection, and all deciduous tooth germs were included in the excision, except for the right deciduous second molar. The postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged from the hospital on the 7th day after the surgery with good general condition.

FOLLOW-UP PLAN:
The patient is being closely followed up and will require occlusal reconstruction and recovery of masticatory function following removal of the mandibular dentition. The patient should schedule follow-up appointments with his pediatrician and the hospital's dental department.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
- Multinodular Basal Cell Carcinoma

DISCHARGE CONDITIONS:
- Stable

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
- None

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
- Continue to monitor the surgical wound for any signs of infection
- Make follow-up appointments with your pediatrician and the hospital's dental department
- Report any abnormal symptoms or signs of illness to your pediatrician immediately
- Avoid giving any hard or sticky foods to your child until he has fully recovered from the surgery.

FOLLOW-UP CARE:
Pediatrician follow-up appointment scheduled for 1 week after discharge. Dental department follow-up appointment scheduled for 2 weeks after discharge.

DISCHARGE NOTES:
The patient experienced no complications during his hospital stay and was discharged in good condition. The patient should ensure to attend all follow-up appointments as scheduled.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Enter Date]
Discharge Date: [Enter Date]

Patient: [Patient's Name]
Age: 25
Gender: Male
Diagnosis: Acute Interstitial Nephritis (AIN)

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of increased serum creatinine levels and no other symptoms. The physical examination did not show any particular findings. Laboratory tests revealed renal dysfunction with elevated C-reactive protein. Urinary markers for tubular injury were also high. Renal biopsy was performed, which showed marked interstitial lymphocytic and eosinophilic infiltration indicative of AIN. 

The patient's medication history revealed he had been diagnosed with temporal lobe epilepsy 12 years ago and was using carbamazepine, zonisamide, valproate, and lacosamide. After discontinuing zonisamide and starting oral prednisolone, the patient's serum creatinine levels decreased, and prednisolone dose was tapered monthly. However, serum creatinine levels increased again 10 months later, and 67Ga scintigraphy showed AIN recurrence. 

Valproate and lacosamide were discontinued, and oral prednisolone was restarted. Renal function immediately improved, although minor epilepsy occurrence increased. Prednisolone dose was gradually tapered; however, serum creatinine levels rose again after reaching 1.99 mg/dL. Repeat renal biopsy revealed similar findings as tubulitis with both lymphocytic and eosinophilic infiltrations. 

A dose of 1500 mg of oral mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) was added to the corticosteroid therapy since the patient had multiple AIN recurrence, and was corticosteroid dependent, which was well tolerated. This allowed for successful prednisolone dose tapering to 5 mg daily, serum creatinine level stabilization, and no AIN recurrence for over 20 months.

Discharge Medications:
- Prednisolone 5 mg daily
- Carbamazepine

Follow-Up:
The patient should see the neurologist regularly for epilepsy treatment and continue following up with the nephrology department for AIN recurrence monitoring. 

Codes:
AIN - 593.89
Temporal lobe epilepsy - 345.5 
Carbamazepine - 250237
Zonisamide - 215410
Valproate - 347217
Lacosamide - 471364

Discharge Summary:

Patient name: [Redacted]
Medical record number: [Redacted]
Admission date: [Redacted]
Discharge date: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of anorexia, easy fatigability, and melena. The patient was found to have a large mass in the stomach, which was confirmed through upper GI endoscopy and abdominal CT. The mass was located close to the lesser gastric curvature and showed increased vascularity.

Operative Procedure:
The patient underwent a laparoscopic surgery to remove the mass. The gastrocolic and posterior gastric attachments were divided to access the lesser sac. The tumor base was located at the posterior gastric wall and exhibited increased vascularity without any invasion into adjacent tissues. After creating a liberal longitudinal anterior gastrotomy, the tumor was delivered and sequentially stapled using linear staplers in close apposition to the tumor. The staple line was oversewn on its luminal aspect and the gastrotomy was closed using 2–0 delayed-absorbable barbed suture in two layers. The patient was discharged from the hospital on day 5.

Follow-up:
The postoperative course was unremarkable except for a superficial surgical site infection. The histopathology report confirmed a GIST with negative margins, indicating a high potential for malignancy. The patient was discharged on day 5, and adjuvant imatinib therapy was commenced after consultation with the medical oncologist.

Diagnosis:
Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)

Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of anorexia, easy fatigability, and melena. The patient underwent laparoscopic surgery to remove a Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST) located close to the lesser gastric curvature. The tumor was removed through sequential stapling, oversewn, and gastrotomy closure. The patient had an unremarkable postoperative course except for a superficial surgical site infection. The patient was discharged on day 5, and adjuvant imatinib therapy was commenced after consultation with the medical oncologist.
