Chief Complaint:
Patient was admitted with right intermittent claudication of 3 years.

History of Present Illness:
Patient, a 76-year-old Asian man, had a 55-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and had been treated with insulin for 3 years. Upon vascular examination, the patient had a right femoral bruit and diminished right popliteal pulse, suggesting the presence of a right femoral lesion. However, the right ankle-brachial index (ABI) measured by a volume plethysmograph was 1.28, within the normal range, while the left ABI was elevated to 1.55, indicating that the infrapopliteal arteries at the left ankle were incompressible. Upstroke time of the right ankle was prolonged, whereas upstroke time of the left ankle was within the normal range. These findings suggest that the right ABI was falsely normalized due to incompressible infrapopliteal arteries at the right ankle despite the presence of peripheral artery disease (PAD) in the right extremity.

Past Medical History:
The patient had diabetic retinopathy and a 55-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Hospital Course:
The patient was treated with supervised exercise training and did not undergo revascularization. After completion of the 6-month supervised exercise training program, he continued to spend 2 hours a day walking. Five years from the initial assessment, the right ABI had decreased to 0.83, with upstroke time at the right ankle indicating the progression of the right lower extremity PAD. However, there was no deterioration in his symptoms, and he had no difficulty in performing daily activities.

Diagnostic Tests:
Intra-arterial angiography revealed the presence of a severe stenotic lesion at the origin of the right superficial femoral artery, whereas there was no occlusive arterial disease in the left extremity. Fluoroscopic images showed severe calcification of infrapopliteal arteries at the right ankle. Computed tomography also revealed severe calcification of the bilateral infrapopliteal arteries.

Follow-up:
The patient is scheduled for regular follow-up appointments to monitor the progression of his peripheral artery disease.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Sex: Male
Age: 66 years old
Chief Complaint: Bilateral intermittent claudication and exertional dyspnea

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with complaints of bilateral intermittent claudication and exertional dyspnea. The patient was a known case of type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 28 years and was being treated with insulin. The patient had diabetic retinopathy and had a history of smoking, with a 40 pack-year history. On vascular examination, there was a right femoral bruit, diminished right popliteal pulse, and absent right and left dorsalis pedis pulses. These findings suggested the presence of right femoral and bilateral infrapopliteal lesions.

The patient's right ABI and left ABI were within normal range; however, the upstroke times in the right and left ankles were prolonged (≥ 180 milliseconds), indicating the presence of bilateral lower-extremity PAD. Furthermore, the right ABI decreased from 1.11 to 0.48, and the left ABI decreased from 1.03 to 0.67 after exercise. Computed tomography angiography revealed the presence of right SFA stenotic lesions, bilateral infrapopliteal occlusive lesions, and spotty calcification in bilateral infrapopliteal arteries. Intra-arterial angiography showed the presence of right SFA stenotic lesions and bilateral infrapopliteal occlusive lesions. Coronary angiography showed severe stenotic lesions in the right coronary artery and the left anterior descending coronary artery (LAD), and the patient underwent percutaneous coronary intervention for the LAD stenosis. 

After percutaneous coronary intervention, the patient underwent supervised exercise training. The patient was discharged in stable condition with appropriate medication and follow-up was advised.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted with complaints of bilateral intermittent claudication and exertional dyspnea. After a thorough examination, it was determined that the patient had right femoral and bilateral infrapopliteal lesions, requiring both computed tomography angiography and intra-arterial angiography. The examinations revealed the presence of right SFA stenotic lesions and bilateral infrapopliteal occlusive lesions. The patient also had severe stenotic lesions in the right coronary artery and the left anterior descending coronary artery (LAD), requiring percutaneous coronary intervention. The patient underwent supervised exercise training and was discharged in stable condition. Appropriate medication was prescribed, and follow-up was advised.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Sex: Male
Age: 37
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for blunt chest and abdominal trauma after a motorcycle accident. On admission, he had a Glasgow Coma scale score of 15 and was hemodynamically stable. Imaging studies revealed nonspecific wall thickening of the proximal jejunum and trace pneumoperitoneum with no evidence of extravasation of oral contrast.

Based on the presence of pneumoperitoneum in a patient with blunt abdominal trauma, the patient was taken to the operating room. During exploratory laparotomy, no evidence of bowel perforation was found, and a segmental section of the diseased portion of the colon was taken and sent to pathology.

Pathology results revealed multiple enlarged cystic nodules ranging from 0.5 to 3 cm in the bowel wall. Radiologic studies were reviewed by a panel of abdominal radiologists, who suggested that the proximity of the pneumoperitoneum to the pneumatosis cystoides intestinalis suggested that the pneumoperitoneum may have been caused by incidental atraumatic or traumatic rupture of the cysts, but they could not rule out bowel perforation based on imaging alone.

The patient had an uncomplicated postoperative course and was transferred to an acute care facility of equal acuity for further medical management as per the patient’s health insurance request.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

The patient’s condition was treated in a prompt and timely manner, and he is stable at the time of discharge. The patient will follow up with his primary care physician for a postoperative checkup and discuss any further medical management if required.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:

The patient is stable at the time of discharge and will continue to follow up with his primary care physicians as recommended. Discharge instructions, including activity limitations and follow-up appointments, have been provided to the patient.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:

[N/A]

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:

Blunt chest and abdominal trauma, with the presence of pneumoperitoneum and multiple enlarged cystic nodules ranging from 0.5 to 3 cm in the bowel wall.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 76 years
Sex: Female
Medical Record Number (MRN): [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED] 
Discharge Date: [REDACTED] 

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our hospital with a chief complaint of abdominal distension and postmenopausal bleeding. She was found to have a bulky uterus with a subendometrial mass on vaginal ultrasonography. Adenosarcoma was suspected on the basis of findings from biopsy by hysteroscopy. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was performed for further examination. Sagittal T2-weighted imaging (WI) showed a large heterogeneous high-intensity mass, approximately 241 × 114 × 88 mm3 in size, without myometrial invasion expanding the uterine cavity and extending into the cervical canal. Subsequently, total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral adnexectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy were performed. The pathology report indicated that the tumor was diagnosed as adenosarcoma with SO without myometrial invasion (T1aN0M0). A follow-up CT scan performed 6 months after surgery revealed peritoneal sarcomatosis. The patient's gynecologist recommended adjuvant chemotherapy, but she did not wish to receive the treatment and died of the disease 1.5 months after recurrence. 

Diagnosis:

Adenosarcoma with SO

Treatment:

Total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral adnexectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy

Follow-up Care:

The patient was advised to follow-up with her gynecologist for regular check-ups and to monitor any potential recurrence of the disease. 

Discharge Condition:

The patient's condition was critical at discharge, and she passed away due to peritoneal sarcomatosis 1.5 months after recurrence. 

Discharge Medications:

Not Applicable 

Discharge Instructions:

Not Applicable 

Signed,

[REDACTED]

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [REDACTED]       Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]          Discharge Date: [REDACTED] 

This 57-year-old female patient (P3) was admitted to our hospital with symptoms of low abdominal pain and abnormal uterine bleeding. The patient had a history of no significant past medical conditions. Endometrial biopsy revealed atypical endometrial hyperplasia.

Uterine mass with necrotic foci and a solid nodule accompanied by tiny cyst were detected on MRI. A whole-body PET-CT scan showed FDG uptake in the uterine tumor. The patient underwent abdominal modified radical hysterectomy with bilateral adnexectomy, pelvic and para-aortic lymphadenectomy, and omentectomy.

On pathological examination, the uterine tumor was reported to be adenosarcoma with minimal myometrial invasion and SO, and the right ovarian nodule was diagnosed as an adult GCT. The patient underwent thoracoscopic segmentectomy of the left upper lobe for the left upper lung metastasis that was observed 3 months after the surgery.

At the time of discharge, the patient was clinically stable, with no signs of the recurrence of the disease. Proper follow-up appointments and imaging studies were advised to monitor the patient's health status in the future.

Primary Diagnosis: Uterine Adenosarcoma with Stromal Overgrowth (T1bN0M0)
Secondary Diagnoses: Adult Granulosa Cell Tumor (GCT) of the Right Ovary, Left Upper Lung Metastasis

Procedures Performed: Abdominal Modified Radical Hysterectomy with Bilateral Adnexectomy, Pelvic and Para-aortic Lymphadenectomy, Omentectomy, Thoracoscopic Segmentectomy of Left Upper Lobe

Condition at Discharge: clinically stable

Follow-up care: Appropriate follow-up care and monitoring advised.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The 9-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital due to intermittent right lower abdominal pain, anorexia, vomit, and high-grade fever. Initial examination showed leukocytosis, neutrophilia, and an elevated C-reactive protein. A heterogeneous lesion of 40 × 37 mm within the colon, no appendix and some swollen mesenteric nodes of at least 10 mm were reported. A complementary abdominal CT scan revealed findings suggestive of ileocolic intussusception with an invagination area of approximately 6.6 × 4.9 cm. After surgical consult, the patient underwent an exploratory laparoscopy that required laparotomy conversion. A well-defined, 5 cm mass at the ileocecal valve and multiple hard pericecal lymph nodes were observed. Preserved permeability between the ileum and colon, complete integrity of the cecum wall, and lack of vermiform appendix were also reported. 

Treatment:
The patient was admitted to the inpatient floor where antibiotic therapy based on ampicillin sulbactam, and metronidazole was initiated. The oncologist department was consulted and complementary laboratory exams were ordered. Antibiotic therapy was changed to piperacillin/tazobactam and amikacin due to the uncertainty of the etiology of her clinical picture. Bowel rest was initiated, and parenteral nutrition was administered. Later, a regular diet was successfully initiated.

Diagnosis:
The histopathological report described an incidental well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumor grade I pT1 pN0 at the tip of the appendix in the middle of a clinical picture caused by an acute necrotizing appendicitis of a complete subserosal appendix. The patient underwent an omentectomy and resection of approximately 40 cm of terminal ileum, cecum, and ascending colon. Pericolonic lymph nodes were resected as well.

Discharge plan:
The patient remained hemodynamically stable, without abdominal pain or distention, and was discharged in good condition. Follow-up appointments were scheduled with her oncologist and primary care physician to monitor her condition and ensure optimal management of short bowel syndrome.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Age: 31 years old
Gender: Male

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of bloody purulent stool, fever, erythema, and blisters on the face. The patient had been diagnosed with UC three years prior but did not receive regular treatment as prescribed. The initial laboratory examination yielded an elevated white blood cell count, increased C-reactive protein, procalcitonin, and Epstein-Barr virus DNA levels and a low hemoglobin level. The computed tomography and computed tomographic enterography exhibited extensive colonic wall thickening with a few perienteral exudative changes and multiple lymph nodes in the retroperitoneal and mesangial areas consistent with the characteristics of UC. Biopsies of cutaneous lesions were performed, revealing localized epidermal ulceration with neutrophil infiltration and dermal appendages with the infiltration of chronic inflammatory cells and neutrophils. A clinical diagnosis of acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis was considered. After ruling out other infectious diseases and lymphoproliferative syndrome, corticosteroid treatment was initiated despite high levels of EBV DNA. There was no recurrence of SS within three months. Colonoscopy revealed scattered polypoid hyperplasia from the ascending colon to the sigmoid colon. Histology of the resected polyp was characterized by crypt dilatation, branching, twisting with interstitial edema, local interstitial fibrosis, and muscle fiber penetration growth. Localized neutrophils infiltrated into the epithelium to form cryptonitis. These histological results were consistent with the characteristics of MPPs.

Discharge Information:
The patient was discharged after the treatment for UC and acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis was completed. The patient was advised to take regular medication for UC and to have regular follow-up appointments with a gastroenterologist. The patient was also instructed to follow a healthy lifestyle, including regular exercise, a healthy diet, and stress management. The patient was advised to avoid smoking and consuming alcohol. The patient was instructed to follow up with their primary care physician if they experienced any new or persistent symptoms.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 39
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Intravesical ichthyosis with atypical flat black pigmented bladder tumors

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with irritative LUTS with macrohematuria and recurrent urinary infections over the past 10 years. Cystoscopy revealed diffuse atypical flat black pigmented bladder tumors. A TUR-B was performed to remove most of the tumors, and histology confirmed a diagnosis of intravesical ichthyosis with condyloma-like benign hyperkeratotic squamous cell deposits.

The patient had a history of extravesical CA and tested positive for HPV42-DNA. A standard HPV-vaccine (Gardasil-9®) was administered. Colonoscopy revealed no signs of intestinal condylomata, and one small sigmoidal tubulovillous adenoma was resected.

Postoperatively, the patient experienced recurrent urinary infections with macrohematuria, and two control-cystoscopies showed minimal persistence of ichthyosis with extensive scarring, but no signs of active growth. The next cystoscopy is planned in 3 months, with a re-TUR-B if lesions progress.

The patient was in good physical condition, with a past medical history of hypothyroidism and a penicillin-allergy. She was never vaccinated against HPV and did not smoke. No signs of malignancy were detected in her urine cytology.

Discharge Condition:
Stable, with ongoing follow-up planned. 

Discharge Medications:
[No medications prescribed at discharge.]

Follow-Up:
The patient is scheduled for a follow-up cystoscopy in three months.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]                MRN: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]       Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Refractory Ascites

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the gastroenterology department with refractory ascites. The medical history revealed hypertension, hypothyroidism and chronic nephritis. The patient denied fever, chest pain, rashes, oral ulcers, arthralgias and visual changes. A physical examination revealed palpable lymph nodes in both neck and groins, abdominal distension, mobile dullness, and mild edema of both lower limbs. Abdominal enhanced CT depicted pneumonia, bilateral pleural effusion, and abdominal effusion, and ascites test showed increased mononuclear cells. The patient had been treated previously in the gastroenterology department of many hospitals for ascites, and had undergone various tests without a clear diagnosis. The differential diagnosis included liver cirrhosis, tuberculosis, tumor, rheumatism, endocrine, cardiac insufficiency, and nephritis. After completing thorough investigations, the patient was diagnosed with Castleman's disease based on lymph node biopsy pathology. 

Hospital Course Summary:
A 57-year-old male patient with refractory ascites presented. He had no history of metabolic syndrome or alcohol consumption. The medical history revealed hypertension, hypothyroidism and chronic nephritis. After a thorough workup of his medical history, clinical examination, and radiological investigations, the patient was diagnosed with Castleman's disease based on lymph node biopsy pathology. The patient was given several treatment options, including CHOP chemotherapy, oral thalidomide, and steroid therapy, but he refused and chose to manage his symptoms with oral diuretics due to economic reasons. The patient was discharged on oral diuretics to alleviate ascites, and was advised to comply with follow-up appointments and regular laboratory monitoring.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [Redacted]
- Age: 45 years
- Sex: Female
- Nationality: Han
- Diagnosis: Fungal keratitis caused by P. insidiosum

Summary:
The patient presented to the clinic with complaints of pain, redness, and decreased vision in her right eye, a week after being exposed to river water. Corneal scrapings and confocal microscopy were performed, and a mass of hyphae was discovered. Fungal keratitis was identified, and the patient underwent right corneal keratectomy. Empirical antifungal and antibacterial therapy was initiated, but the ulcer and symptoms did not improve, and the patient was admitted to the hospital. The patient underwent lamellar keratoplasty, and amphotericin B was administered. However, four days post-surgery, the patient developed a full-thickness central infiltrate with hypopyon. The right eye was enucleated, and the microbial culture revealed the presence of P. insidiosum.

Hospital Course:
- August 2017: Presenting symptoms of right eye pain, redness, and decreased vision after being exposed to river water
- Corneal scrapings, confocal microscopy, and fungal keratitis diagnosis
- Right corneal keratectomy and initiation of empirical antifungal and antibacterial therapy
- Persistence of ulcer and symptoms led to hospital admission
- Lamellar keratoplasty, amphotericin B administration, and development of full-thickness infiltrate with hypopyon
- Enucleation of right eye and identification of P. insidiosum through microbial culture
- Adjustment of combined antibacterial treatment with linezolid and azithromycin
- No recurrence of infection observed during follow-up

Condition at Discharge:
- Stable

Instructions:
- Perform follow-up as scheduled
- Continue with prescribed medication
- Avoid exposure to potential irritants or allergens
- If any symptoms recur, seek immediate medical attention

Follow-up:
- Schedule and attend follow-up appointments as recommended by healthcare provider.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 51-year-old female of Han ethnicity, was admitted to our hospital in September 2018 after developing pain, redness, and hyperemia in her right eye following entry of some cigarette ash. Corneal scraping was performed, and antifungal and antibacterial therapy with levofloxacin eye drops, cefminox sodium, and voriconazole was initiated. After two weeks of outpatient treatment, the patient was hospitalized due to the appearance of a grayish-white ulcer in her cornea.

Diagnostic findings:

The patient underwent a penetrating keratoplasty, and exudation was noted in the anterior chamber post-surgery. Intracameral fluconazole injection was administered, but the infiltrates continued to progressively worsen and remained unresponsive to any treatment. A subsequent enucleation was performed due to persistent infection. A sample of the corneal fragment revealed a positive culture for a fungus that was definitively identified as P. insidiosum by ITS rRNA gene sequencing analysis.

Treatment course:

The patient was treated with antifungal medications and underwent surgical intervention in a bid to relieve her symptoms. Unfortunately, these attempts were unsuccessful, and the patient ultimately required enucleation of the affected eye. 

Follow-up:

Follow-up care with ophthalmology is recommended for the patient to assess the outcome of the intervention and provide any necessary care.

Hospital Course:

This is a comprehensive discharge summary for a 55-year-old male of Han nationality who was admitted to our hospital with symptoms of irritation, pain, and hyposesthesia in the left eye. Patient's presenting complaints were initially diagnosed as viral keratitis at a local ophthalmic clinic. However, after 4 days of antiviral therapy, no significant improvement was observed, and the patient was eventually referred to our hospital. Upon admission, the patient presented with conjunctival hypertrophy and infiltrated growth into cornea about 2 mm from the nasal limbus, microvascular tissue hypertrophy of about 2.5 mm across the corneal limbus, and hyperemia grayish-white infiltrate of cornea about 5 mm in diameter.

Diagnostic Approach:

The patient underwent direct microscopy of corneal scrapings stained with Gram and KOH preparation, which yielded negative results for organisms. The patient was then prescribed empiric fortified topical and systemic antibiotics, including ornidazole, tobramycin, vancomycin, natamycin, and fluconazole. However, after three days, there was still no noteworthy improvement, prompting the decision to perform an excision of pterygium and therapeutic penetrating keratoplasty in the left eye. Cultures of the patient's corneal tissue for bacteria, fungus, and Acanthamoeba were negative. Because there was evidence of increased keratoneuritis, antiamebic therapy (chlorhexidine) was initiated, and voriconazole was also added. Yet, twelve days after the surgery, corneal opacity was rescraped, and the infiltration extended deeply into the anterior chamber. A second penetrating keratoplasty was performed, virtually limbus to limbus, along with an intracameral amphotericin B injection. 

Outcome:

The patient's medical condition did not improve. 10 days after the second operation, the infection spread to the adjacent sclera and progressed to endophthalmitis, necessitating enucleation. Eventually, the corneal cultures growing on PDA plate were identified as P. insidiosum by MALDI-TOF-MS, confirming the diagnosis of pythiosis.

Discharge Condition:

The patient has been discharged, and his overall condition is stable. The patient was advised to follow up with an ophthalmologist for further management and rehabilitation.

Patient Information:
Name: [patient name]
Age: 54 years old
Sex: Male
Medical History: Medically free

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a gradual painless decrease in vision of his left eye over one year, accompanied by mild pain, photophobia, and redness from time to time. The patient underwent uneventful cataract surgery of both eyes 13 years prior to his presentation. On examination, the best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) was measured as 20/28 in the right eye (OD) and 20/400 in the left eye (OS). Slit-lamp biomicroscopic examination of OD was unremarkable. However, examination of OS showed 1+ mixed anterior chamber cells and a relatively small CCC, along with a thick turbid greenish fluid behind the IOL. The fundus was poorly visualized. B-scan detected moderately dense vitreous opacities suggestive of vitritis, with no associated choroidal thickening. UBM detected a hyperechoic collection of turbid fluid behind the IOL with a distended capsular bag, confirming the presumed diagnosis of CBDS.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
Late-onset CBDS with a high possibility of associated P. acnes was assumed, and surgical intervention was considered. After explaining the surgical procedure and obtaining written informed consent from the patient, a pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) with a posterior capsulotomy was performed. Initially, 23 gauge three PPV trocars were placed 3.5 mm away from the limbus. Intravitreal vancomycin (1 mg/0.1 mL) was injected at the end of the procedure due to the high possibility of associated P. acnes endophthalmitis. The aspirated material was sent to histopathology for gram stains and cultures. After 72 hours, Thioglycolate broth was positive for the growth of P. acnes confirming the presumed diagnosis.

Disposition and Follow-up:
The post-operative period was uneventful, and no signs of intraocular inflammation were detected. At six months, the patient had a 20/25 BCVA and did fine without any complaints. The patient was discharged from the clinic.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Hospital Admission Dates: [redacted]

Admission Diagnosis: Critical limb ischemia of the right leg

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted due to critical limb ischemia of the right leg. She had a medical history of HIV infection, coronary artery disease, peripheral vascular disease, and polysubstance abuse. Vascular surgery was performed, which included bilateral lower extremity angiogram, femoral artery angioplasty, and a femoral artery stent. The postoperative course was uneventful. The patient was started on a medication regimen that included Apixaban, Clopidogrel, Darunavir/Cobicistat (Prezcobix), Abacavir/Dolutegravir/Lamivudine (Triumeq), Atorvastatin, Isosorbide Dinitrate, and Hydralazine.

During her follow-up visit, the patient reported low back pain, which led to a CT scan that revealed a large retroperitoneal hematoma. The hematoma was managed conservatively, and the patient's vital signs remained stable throughout her admission. The patient was discharged on Apixaban and Clopidogrel as recommended by the vascular team.

Four weeks later, the patient was readmitted with urosepsis. A follow-up CT abdomen revealed a resolving retroperitoneal hematoma. The patient reported that during her outpatient management she had only been compliant with her antiretroviral therapy (ART) and not with her antiplatelet or anticoagulant medication (Clopidogrel and Apixaban). Her anticoagulant regimen was then changed to Enoxaparin out of concern with potential drug-drug interaction with Apixaban and Cobicistat.

Hospital Discharge:
The patient was discharged with stable hemoglobin and vital signs. She was advised to continue her anticoagulant regimen of Enoxaparin and Clopidogrel. The patient was recommended to follow-up with her healthcare provider in two weeks. Within the hospital, the patient was compliant with her inpatient treatment plan, and no adverse events were encountered.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient: a 55-year-old Japanese female diagnosed with osteoarthritis of the knee.

History of Present Illness: The patient presented with pain in both knees in 2013, which was diagnosed as osteoarthritis of the knee. In December 2017, the patient experienced knee collapse while playing tennis, and MRI of the right knee showed a horizontal dissection of the lateral meniscus and cartilage defect on the lateral condyle of the femur.

Course of Treatment: Injections of hyaluronic acid (HA) were administered every 2 weeks since 2018, but joint edema and pain recurrence have been remitted. In April 2018, the patient received ASC treatment due to the ineffectiveness of previous interventions. The first ASC transplantation was performed on the right knee on June 11, 2018, and on April 22, 2019, the second ASC transplant was performed on the right knee and the first ASC transplant was performed on the left knee.

Hospital Course: After the initial ASC transplantation, the patient experienced some pain recurrence due to violent movements, but an improvement was noted during Timed Up and Go Test. In September 2018, the patient resumed playing tennis and was living almost without pain. MRI performed on December 10, 2018, showed no pain even when the subject jumped on one leg, and a repaired cartilage defect was observed. While the patient had a slight fever on the day of the procedure on June 22, 2019, she was in good condition on August 5, 2019, and was able to assume a sitting position.

Summary: The patient, a 55-year-old Japanese female diagnosed with osteoarthritis of the knee, was treated with injections of hyaluronic acid and subsequent ASC treatment that involved two ASC transplantations. The initial ASC transplantation caused some pain recurrence, but the patient experienced improvement during Timed Up and Go Test, and was able to resume playing tennis without significant pain. MRI performed on December 10, 2018, showed a repaired cartilage defect. The patient was in a good condition on August 5, 2019, with the ability to assume a sitting position.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 32-year-old Middle Eastern man, was admitted to our facility with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. He had undergone a laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy 13 days prior and was prescribed a protein pump inhibitor and enoxaparin 40 mg daily.

Upon examination, the patient appeared unwell, dehydrated, and in pain. Further evaluation revealed a white blood cell count of 27,300/μL, hemoglobin of 17.3 g/dL, and serum lactate of 7.6 mmol/L. A computed tomography (CT) scan revealed extensive acute on chronic portosplenic and superior mesenteric vein thrombosis, with consequent small bowel ischemia. The patient was admitted under the acute surgical team and underwent laparoscopic exploration, which confirmed the CT findings. A midline laparotomy was performed, and 255 cm of small bowel was resected. The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit, followed by a second look 24 hours later, which revealed both the small and large intestines to be healthy. Primary anastomosis and abdominal closure were performed. During recuperation, the patient was gradually introduced to a solid diet and was transferred out of the hospital on the 12th day with a prescription for warfarin. A thrombophilia screen was negative.

Condition upon Discharge:
At the time of discharge, the patient's general condition had improved significantly. He was tolerating oral intake and had reduced his Body Mass Index to 19. No clinical manifestations of short bowel syndrome were observed.

Outpatient Treatment Plan:
- Continue warfarin at home.
- Follow up with outpatient surgical team for further evaluation and postoperative care.
- Maintain a healthy lifestyle and diet.

Follow-up Care:
The patient will be seen regularly for follow-up evaluations to ensure maintenance of a healthy lifestyle and monitor for any potential complications from the previous surgery.

Final Diagnosis:
Extensive acute on chronic portosplenic and superior mesenteric vein thrombosis with consequent small bowel ischemia after laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: [Name], Female, 63 years old
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]
Admitting Diagnosis: Palpable right axillary mass
Discharge Diagnosis: Bilateral breast cancer consisting of occult right breast cancer with axillary metastasis (TxN1M0) and early-stage left breast cancer (T1bN0M0)

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with a palpable right axillary mass. A 14-gauge core-needle biopsy revealed the right axillary lymph node as a metastatic carcinoma, possibly from the breast, with positive estrogen receptor (ER) status. Breast MRI showed a 0.6-cm irregular enhancing mass in the left upper inner breast, assessed as breast imaging reporting and data system (BI-RADS) category 4C. Second-look US confirmed the mass as an invasive carcinoma of no special type, same as that of right axillary metastasis. Subsequently, the patient underwent right axillary lymph node dissection and left breast conserving surgery with sentinel lymph node biopsy. Histologic findings of cancer cells in all three lymph nodes of the right axilla were fairly different from those of cancer cells in the left breast, indicating that the metastasis to the right axillary lymph node did not originate from the left breast cancer, although both of them showed ER positivity. Metastatic cancer cells in the right axilla were also positive for gross cystic disease fluid protein-15 (GCDFP-15) and GATA binding protein 3 (GATA3), suggesting that the metastasis was derived from the breast. Finally, the patient received four cycles of doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide followed by four cycles of taxane (AC-T) chemotherapy and radiation therapy for each breast and hormone therapy.

Evaluation and Management:
The patient received prompt and appropriate evaluation and management of her right axillary mass, invasive carcinoma of no special type in the left upper inner breast, and macrometastatic lymph nodes in the right axilla. The patient underwent right axillary lymph node dissection and left breast conserving surgery with sentinel lymph node biopsy, followed by appropriate treatment based on the final diagnosis.

Hospital Course and Discharge Status:
The patient's postoperative course was uneventful, and she was discharged in stable condition. No recurrence or metastasis was observed 14 months postoperatively.

Follow-up:
The patient will be followed up regularly with appropriate imaging studies to monitor for any recurrence of the cancer. She will also continue hormonal therapy, as appropriate.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Unidentified

Medical Record Number: Unidentified

Date of Admission: Unidentified

Date of Discharge: Unidentified

Reason for Admission: Left ovarian cyst torsion

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 77-year-old Japanese woman, para 7, was admitted to our hospital with sudden onset of left lower abdominal pain. Computed tomography (CT) revealed a 7.5-cm long elliptical mass in the left adnexal region that was continuous with the uterus. She was diagnosed with torsion of a left ovarian cyst and underwent surgery.

The patient had a history of left-side breast cancer and underwent total left mastectomy at the age of 67, with no recurrence thereafter. Although she was a carrier of hepatitis C, her liver function and coagulation remained normal, and she was being followed-up without medication. Furthermore, she was taking nifedipine and candesartan cilexetil for hypertension. Her family history and psychosocial history were unremarkable. She also had no history of trauma.

After admission, the hematoma did not enlarge, and the hemoglobin and hematocrit levels did not decrease. After 11 days of bed rest, with no exacerbation of the inflammatory response, lower abdominal pain was relieved, and she was discharged. After discharge, we planned to investigate the cause of her bleeding on an outpatient basis, but 6 days after discharge, she was readmitted to our hospital after relapse of symptoms caused by retroperitoneal bleeding from the same site. The hematoma had grown to a size of 11.7 cm, and an abnormal vascular network was found extending from the left side of the uterus to the left adnexal area. It was suspected to be an arteriovenous malformation (AVM) or arteriovenous fistula (AVF) from the uterine artery to the left ovarian vein (LOV).

Urgent treatment was needed for her repeated bleeding, and vascular embolization therapy was performed simultaneously with angiography. The cause of retroperitoneal bleeding was rupture of the LOV, the distension of which was caused by reflux. We performed embolization of LOV with N-butyl-2-cyanoacrylate and placed a coil centrally to prevent recanalization. The retroperitoneal hematoma gradually shrank and disappeared. At her final visit 2 years later, the hematoma had not recurred.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient, a 77-year-old Japanese woman, para 7, was admitted to our hospital with torsion of a left ovarian cyst. She had a history of left-side breast cancer and hypertension, but her liver function and coagulation remained normal, and there were no significant findings on physical examination. After surgery and 11 days of bed rest, lower abdominal pain was relieved, and she was discharged.

However, she was readmitted to our hospital 6 days after discharge with relapse of symptoms caused by retroperitoneal bleeding from the same site. An abnormal vascular network extending from the left side of the uterus to the left adnexal area was found, which was suspected to be an arteriovenous malformation or arteriovenous fistula from the uterine artery to the left ovarian vein. Urgent treatment was needed for her repeated bleeding, and vascular embolization therapy was performed with no recurrence of hematoma detected at her final visit 2 years later.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 48
Gender: Female
Diagnosis: Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the Department of Gynecology with physical examination and further diagnostic imaging revealed pelvic masses. She had undergone laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy eight years before for a borderline ovarian tumor. She underwent a hysterectomy and pelvic lymph node dissection due to recurrent mucinous borderline ovarian tumor. Postoperative examination revealed endometrial lymphoma, which was diagnosed as non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, consistent with diffuse large B-cell non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. The patient underwent bone marrow biopsy and PET-CT to observe whether there were other lymph node abnormalities, which came out negative.

Treatment:
The patient has received four postoperative courses of CHOP chemotherapy in the Department of Hematology. The patient has been advised to have regular medical check-ups to continue monitoring their health.

Prognosis:
The patient is currently stable and showing no signs of any abnormality in the follow-up tests.

Recommendations:
The patient is advised to maintain regular medical visits for health monitoring. Further, the patient should maintain a healthy lifestyle that includes proper nutrition, exercise, and rest. Any symptoms of discomfort during recovery and follow-up should be brought to the attention of the medical team promptly.

Follow-Up Recommendations:
The patient should continue to follow up with Oncology and Hematology Departments on a regular basis to monitor their health status.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 13 years
Race: Caucasian
Admission Date:  [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was admitted for severe anorexia nervosa, depression, anxiety, and compulsive tendencies. The patient had a history of multiple admissions to different healthcare facilities for anorexia nervosa and aggressive behavior. During the hospital course, the patient had symptoms of sadness, loneliness, anhedonia, and hopelessness and had minimum interest in seeking treatment for her eating disorder. The patient was placed in 1:1 supervision for safety concerns, as she had a history of physically aggressive behavior towards the staff and family.

During the admission, the patient refused to take her medication for anxiety and hid meals. She was physically restrained and had to receive emergency medication, as she posed a risk to herself and others. She was transferred to our hospital after stabbing her father with a knife, blaming him for her eating disorder treatment. She was handcuffed and ankle-cuffed to the bed throughout her stay.

The patient was diagnosed with Conduct Disorder (CD) after the violent incident, and the eating disorder facility refused to accept the patient, leading to her treatment plan being revised. Behavioral expectations and positive reinforcement were implemented for meeting the patient's daily nutritional needs. She was prescribed chlorpromazine to address her aggression. After gaining 2.7 kg, the patient was referred to an eating disorder partial hospitalization program.

Unfortunately, the patient was readmitted after she refused to eat, losing weight and refusing medication, leading to her arrest and remand to Juvenile Justice Center (JJC). She was readmitted to our pediatric hospital, where she was treated with olanzapine and fluoxetine to address anxiety. She received Lorazepam for anxiety during feedings via NG tube initially. Afterwards, she was readmitted to JJC for further treatment.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:

1. Anorexia Nervosa
2. Depression
3. Anxiety
4. Conduct Disorder

FOLLOW-UP:

The patient has remained in outpatient treatment, following up with our adolescent medicine team, and her menses returned. We anticipate that the patient will need long-term treatment due to the severity of her symptoms related to anorexia nervosa and conduct disorder.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

1. Follow-up with adolescent medicine team.
2. Take medications as prescribed.
3. Continue eating disorder treatment.
4. Attend all recommended therapy sessions.
5. Maintain contact with healthcare providers. Please notify us of any changes in symptoms or concerns.

Discharge Summary:

Admission date: [Date]
Discharge date: [Date]

Patient: 41-year-old Ukrainian male with complaints of numbness and cramping in the lower extremities and general weakness over the past 8 years. The patient also presented with complete hair loss in the legs and thinning of the skin over the lower limbs, and symptoms of axonal polyneuropathy and cognitive deficiency.

Hospital Course:

During the patient's hospital stay, diagnostic tests excluded endocrine diseases, infections, and dysmetabolic origins. Examination under nerve conduction study (NCS) determined signs of gross axonal damage in the motor and sensory fibers of the lower extremities, with secondary demyelination. The patient's biopsied gastric and duodenal mucosa revealed subatrophy of villi in combination with crypt hyperplasia, which corresponded to celiac disease per the Marsh IIIB classification.

Treatment:

The patient received two cycles of five operations of medium-volume membrane plasma exchange, combined with intravenous pulse methylprednisolone. Metabolic therapy included the administration of α-lipoic acid, vitamins B6, B12, and E, ipidacrine, sulodexide, l-carnitine, and initiation of a gluten-free diet.

Follow-up:

Eight months following the start of treatment, regression of the clinical symptoms of axonal polyneuropathy and cognitive deficiency was observed. During the next neurological examination, the patient showed improvement in a previously impaired exteroception, including the normalization of thermoception and vibrational sensation. Cognitive function was also normalized.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Axonal polyneuropathy, cognitive deficiency, and celiac disease.

Discharge Condition:

Improved. The patient was discharged with instructions to continue a gluten-free diet and continue with the prescribed medication regimen. Follow-up care was scheduled.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: Not specified
Sex: Male
Age: 70 years
Admission date: Not specified
Discharge date: Not specified

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted due to Pulmonary embolism (PEA) as a result of chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH). Surgical treatment including cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) was initiated; however, the patient could not be weaned off CPB due to severe residual PH combined with right heart dysfunction. Hence, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) was used and the patient gradually recovered from PEA. The patient developed severe secondary left ventricular dysfunction on the basis of right ventricular dysfunction, during ECMO support, which was further managed.

The patient’s condition was stabilized during the postoperative period with comprehensive care, including reducing ECMO flow, increasing vasopressor dose, inhaled nitric oxide and treprostinil treatment, lung protective ventilation, and myocardial oxygen supply improvement. The patient underwent atrial septostomy to decompress the right ventricle, so as to reduce the pulmonary arterial pressure. The patient gradually recovered from ECMO and no longer needed it. Other interventions were initiated, such as reducing tidal volume, initiating positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) and tracheostomy on POD 13, due to unexpected brain ischemia and luminal infarction. Finally, the patient was transferred to a local hospital for further treatment on POD 16.

Throughout the hospitalization, the patient received comprehensive care and support. The patient was closely monitored and managed by an interdisciplinary team of healthcare professionals. The patient and family were regularly informed of the patient’s condition, management, and prognosis. Appropriate counseling and education were provided to the patient and family. The patient was discharged in a stable condition with appropriate referrals and instructions for follow-up care.

Diagnoses:

- Chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH)
- Pulmonary embolism (PEA)
- Left ventricular dysfunction following ECMO support

Interventions:

- Cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB)
- Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO)
- Vasopressor therapy
- Inhaled nitric oxide and treprostinil treatment
- Lung protective ventilation
- Positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP)
- Atrial septostomy
- Tracheostomy

Follow-up care:

The patient was discharged with appropriate referrals to follow-up care with their local healthcare provider for further monitoring, treatment, and management of chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH), pulmonary embolism (PEA), and left ventricular dysfunction following ECMO support. The patient was instructed to follow a healthy lifestyle, including regular exercise, a balanced diet, and compliance with medications and medical appointments. The patient was advised to report any sudden onset of symptoms immediately and to seek emergency care if necessary.

Hospital Course:

This 3-month-old male infant presented with stridor and failure to thrive. After several medical consultations and emergency department visits, he was referred to a neurology clinic, which promptly scheduled an airway assessment surgery. A lingual surface cystic mass, measuring 2 x 3 cm in size and significantly occluding the laryngeal inlet, was identified during flexible laryngoscopy. Direct laryngoscopy and bronchoscopy under general anesthesia revealed that the vocal cords, subglottic area, and trachea were observed to be normal. The lesion was finally diagnosed as a vallecular cyst based on clinical, endoscopic, and histological findings.

Procedure:

Microlaryngoscopic marsupialization was performed to remove the cyst and drain serous fluid. A biopsy of the cyst wall revealed connective tissue covered with non-keratinizing squamous epithelium with vascular congestion and chronic inflammation, further supporting the diagnosis of a vallecular cyst.

Symptoms:

The patient's symptoms completely resolved postoperatively, and he was feeding well. He remained asymptomatic at four and seven months follow-up visits, during which he rapidly gained weight, reaching 5.5 kg at four months and 8.4 kg at seven months of age.

Conclusion:

This is a case of a three-month-old male infant with a vallecular cyst causing stridor and failure to thrive. The diagnosis was reached after flexible laryngoscopy, direct laryngoscopy, and bronchoscopy under general anesthesia. Microlaryngoscopic marsupialization was performed to remove the cyst, and the patient's symptoms resolved postoperatively. He remained asymptomatic and gained weight significantly at seven-month follow-up visits after the surgery.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not provided
Age: 56
Sex: Not provided
Medical Record Number: Not provided
Date of Admission: Not provided
Date of Discharge: Not provided

Chief Complaint: Right eye pain, redness, lid swelling, and double vision
Diagnosis: Direct carotid cavernous fistula (CCF)

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with right eye pain, redness, lid swelling, and double vision that had progressed over six weeks. After appropriate imaging studies, the diagnosis of direct CCF was made, and urgent embolization was performed, which led to complete resolution of his symptoms. The patient was closely monitored post-procedure, and no complications were noted.

Physical Exam:

The patient had bilateral visual acuity of 6/9. His right eye was proptosed with the presence of grade 1 relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD). It was swollen, tender with palpable thrill, and an audible bruit was present. Slit-lamp examination revealed generalized episcleral congestion with corkscrew vessels, and raised intraocular pressure (IOP) of 28 mmHg. Both optic discs and posterior poles were normal.

Diagnostic Tests:

An urgent CT angiography demonstrated an engorged right superior ophthalmic vein (SOV) and bulky right CS. The left SOV was prominent with a similar contrast enhancement to the internal carotid artery. After an urgent successful digital subtraction angiography (DSA), the diagnosis of direct CCF was confirmed.

Medications:

Not provided

Follow-up Instructions:

The patient was advised to follow-up with his ophthalmologist as needed. No other specific follow-up instructions were issued upon discharge. The patient was advised to seek urgent care if he experienced recurring symptoms. 

Approved by: Not provided
Attending Physician: Not provided
Discharge Date: Not provided

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 65
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
	
Hospital Course:

The patient, a 65-year-old lady with hypertension, diabetes, and high cholesterol, was admitted with symptoms of redness, lid swelling, and double vision in the right eye accompanied by blurring of vision. Further examination revealed that she had mild head trauma and facial injury resulting from a motor vehicle accident about two months earlier.

Upon admission, a brain computed tomography (CT) scan was performed and reported as normal. A slit-lamp examination revealed conjunctival chemosis and corkscrew vessels in the right eye, with an intraocular pressure (IOP) measured at 29 mmHg. Ophthalmoplegia, grade one relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), proptosis, and an audible bruit were also observed.

A CTA was performed to determine the cause of the symptoms, which revealed early filling and enlargement of the right superior ophthalmic vein (SOV) with early arterial enhancement of the right carotid sinus (CS). The diagnosis of right direct carotid-cavernous fistula (CCF) was confirmed with DSA, and the patient underwent successful embolization to resolve the ocular sequelae.

The patient was observed and monitored for any complications, and her vision improved to 6/9 in both eyes. The patient was discharged in stable condition, with instructions for routine follow-up with an ophthalmologist.

Diagnoses:

- Right direct carotid-cavernous fistula (CCF)
- Mild head trauma and facial injury
- Hypertension
- Diabetes
- High cholesterol

Procedures Performed:

- CTA
- DSA
- Embolization

Condition on Discharge:

- Stable, with improved vision (6/9 in both eyes)

Instructions:

- Follow-up with ophthalmologist for further management and monitoring.

1. Patient Information:
The patient is a 49-year-old woman with underlying hypertension who was initially treated for right eye infective conjunctivitis. She was referred for persistent and worsening eye redness for three weeks.

2. Presenting Complaint:
The patient presented with persistent and worsening eye redness, with no blurring of vision, lid swelling, or trauma.

3. History and Physical Exam:
On examination, the patient had dilated right episcleral vessels which were blanched with topical phenylephrine 2.5%. She was treated for episcleritis with topical steroids, with improvement after two weeks, except for right eye IOP which was raised to 24 mmHg. A topical IOP lowering agent was initiated for the working diagnosis of steroid responder. On subsequent review, she was noted to have proptosis, orbital bruit, corkscrew vessels with controlled IOP and normal optic nerve functions. B-scan ultrasonography showed dilated SOV in the right eye.

4. Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with right indirect CCF after an urgent CTA that demonstrated the dilated right SOV. The DSA further confirmed the diagnosis.

5. Management:
The patient underwent successful embolization which resolved all ocular features.

6. Follow-up:
It is advised that the patient follow-up for further evaluation and monitoring.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 74-year-old man who presented to the neurology clinic with left sixth nerve palsy and painless horizontal diplopia worse with a left-directed gaze. The double vision was aborted by occluding either eye. With eye-straining, he developed a dull bitemporal headache. The patient was alert, oriented, well-nourished, in no apparent distress, and denied any vision loss, dysarthria, dysphagia, chewing difficulty, neck weakness, or breathing difficulty. The patient had a history of bilateral below-knee amputations due to peripheral vascular disease secondary to smoking.

On examination, there was an obvious left lateral rectus paresis upon assuming left gaze. However, vertical gaze was unaffected and the pupils were spared. Cranial nerve examination revealed no facial weakness. Power in the arms was graded at 5/5 in all muscle groups with the medical research council (MRC) grading scale, and deep tendon reflexes in the upper extremities were preserved with normal finger-to-nose coordination.

A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain with and without gadolinium enhancement revealed no lesion of the brainstem or cavernous sinus, and magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) revealed no cavernous sinus aneurysm. An MG panel for AChR modulating, binding, and blocking antibodies was negative. Striational antibodies were negative. A MuSK-antibody titer was high at 1.6 units per milliliter (mL); positive is 1.0 or higher. A sedimentation rate was normal. Based upon the negative MRI and MRA of the brain findings, the ocular manifestations, and positive MuSK serology, a diagnosis of MuSK-ocular MG was made. 

The patient was advised about the potential for bulbar weakness and myasthenic crisis. A trial of pyridostigmine at a dose of 60 milligrams (mg) three times daily was ineffective. The patient opted against therapy with prednisone and/or rituximab, and he preferred wearing an occlusive eye patch. 

The patient was discharged with instructions to continue wearing an occlusive eye patch and to follow up with the neurology clinic as needed.
