Discharge Summary
Patient Name: [REDACTED] 
DOB: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Hospitalization Dates: [REDACTED]

Chief Complaint: Severe and progressive abdominal pain of three days’ duration.

History of Present Illness: 65-year-old male patient was admitted with stomach pain and lack of bowel movements for three days. Abdominal pain was localized to the left side of his abdomen and worse with movement. The patient also reported nausea but no vomiting. Abdominal X-rays revealed small bowel dilation; CT scan conducted hours later revealed SBO. The patient underwent exploratory laparotomy, release of SBO with removal of abdominal wall mesh and Jackson-Pratt (JP) drain placement. An incision was made directly over the site of the previous mesh that was around the site of the umbilicus. Dissection was taken down to the deep subcutaneous tissue. The mesh was then completely removed. A JP drain was left in the abdomen and the incision was closed. 

Past Medical History: Patient had a past medical history of an open ventral hernia repair with mesh approximately four years prior to this encounter (2017), as well as multiple instances of SBO and a long history of tenderness and a mass at the side of his past hernia repair.

Hospital Course: The patient was followed in an inpatient setting for four additional days, the course of which was uneventful.

Postoperative Diagnosis: SBO due to adhesions with abdominal wall and ventral hernia mesh.

Treatment: The patient underwent exploratory laparotomy, release of SBO with removal of abdominal wall mesh and Jackson-Pratt (JP) drain placement.

Outcome: After recovering from anesthesia, the patient was followed in an inpatient setting for four additional days, the course of which was uneventful. The patient was discharged home on the fourth postoperative day and followed in an outpatient setting.

Follow-up: The patient was scheduled for a follow-up appointment in an outpatient setting.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 35-year-old male who presented to our emergency department after sustaining significant facial trauma due to a car accident. Upon arrival, he demonstrated reduced consciousness and was intubated for airway protection. Imaging studies showed multiple comminuted facial and basilar skull fractures, as well as intradural air spanning C1-C4 and L3-S1 levels. The patient remained intubated in the trauma ICU and received dexamethasone for a right facial nerve paresis. His condition improved and he was extubated 9 hours after admission.

Discharge Summary:

The patient was discharged home on post-injury day 3 in good condition. Upon discharge, he remained without strength or sensation deficits in his extremities. He was prescribed a two-week course of dexamethasone for a right facial nerve paresis, although there was no significant improvement noted by the time of discharge.

Recommendations upon discharge include proper wound care and monitoring for any signs of infection. Follow-up appointments with the appropriate specialists should be made to ensure proper healing of the facial fractures and nerve damage.

The patient's family was educated on the signs of head trauma and the importance of seeking immediate medical attention in the event of any changes in mental status, behavior, or physical symptoms. They were also advised to follow up with their primary care physician for ongoing care and monitoring of the patient's recovery progress.

Hospital Course:

- The patient is a healthy 25-year-old male who fell 8-10 meters from a third-story balcony and was brought to the emergency department. He was comatose and pulseless at the scene and required CPR and rapid sequence intubation for stabilization.
- Upon arrival to our hospital, he developed hypotension and lost a carotid pulse, requiring a second round of CPR before return of spontaneous circulation.
- CT scans revealed bilateral temporal bone fractures, a transverse clival fracture, and traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhages with pneumocephalus. Spinal imaging revealed intradural air at the L3-L4 levels but no evidence of direct spinal trauma or pneumothorax/pneumoperitoneum.
- The patient had a GCS of 6T on arrival and underwent intubation. He withdrew all extremities from painful stimuli on neurological examination and was noted to have dried blood in both ears.
- He was admitted to the trauma ICU with an intracranial pressure monitor that was later removed. His GCS improved rapidly and he was extubated after 11 hours. He remained coherent and oriented but was amnestic to his injury and had a left facial nerve paresis.
- The patient underwent operative fixation for pelvic injuries on hospital day 2 and was discharged to rehabilitation in good condition on post-injury day 8.

Discharge Summary:

- The patient was admitted to our hospital after a fall from a third-story balcony resulting in multiple injuries. He underwent stabilization measures for hypotension and loss of carotid pulse and was managed in the ICU for several days.
- During his hospital stay, he was extubated and the intracranial pressure monitor was removed. His neurological status improved rapidly, despite a left facial nerve paresis and amnesia for his injury.
- The patient underwent a successful operative fixation of his pelvic injuries and was transferred to rehabilitation in good condition.
- Follow-up for the patient's facial nerve paresis is recommended.

Hospital Course Summary:

The 54-year-old male with a history of alcohol abuse was admitted to the emergency with acute-onset, diffuse, cramping abdominal pain, worst in the epigastrium and lasting one day. He had no prior abdominal surgeries. Upon examination, he had moderate guarding and generalized tenderness with hypoactive bowel sounds. The laboratory evaluation showed microcytic anemia and thrombocytopenia on complete blood count, hypokalemia on basic metabolic profile, and a normal lipase level. Abdominal X-ray showed an evolving small bowel obstruction, which was confirmed by a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast. On the same CT scan series, a urachal remnant with a superimposed mass lesion was depicted.

An emergent surgery was performed to release the small bowel obstruction after receiving a platelet transfusion. During the surgery, an extensive mass was found concerning for a malignancy. A frozen section was intraoperatively sent and read as adenocarcinoma. An incisional biopsy of the urachal mass was also sent, which resulted in a final pathology specimen of a moderately differentiated urachal adenocarcinoma.

The patient was staged at Stage IIID (Sheldon staging) due to the spread to local viscera other than the bladder. Due to the involvement of multiple loops of the small bowel and the mesentery of the small and large bowels, the tumor was deemed unresectable. Systemic chemotherapy with 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), folinic acid, and oxaliplatin (modified FOLFOX-6) was initiated. The patient completed six cycles of chemotherapy and tolerated it well.

The patient is still awaiting additional imaging to evaluate the response to therapy. Further follow-up and management are recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [date]
Discharge Date: [date]

Patient: 81-year-old male

Medical History:
- Hypertension
- Coronary artery disease
- Non-melanoma skin cancer

Reason for Admission: A new cutaneous manifestation

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a two-week history of a progressively enlarging asymptomatic lesion on his left chest. Physical examination revealed a well-demarcated erythematous, indurated plaque overlying the previous harvest site of his left internal thoracic artery. A punch biopsy was performed to further classify this new development. Histopathologic evaluation revealed uninvolved epidermis with diffuse dermal sclerosis and underlying panniculitis. These localized sclerodermatous changes were attributed to recent arterectomy. Given the asymptomatic nature of the plaque, the management options were discussed with the patient, and he opted for observation during his bi-annual skin examinations.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Localized sclerodermatous changes attributed to recent arterectomy.

Recommendations and Plan:
The patient is discharged for outpatient follow-up with recommendations for bi-annual skin examinations. Any changes or concerns should be discussed with his healthcare provider. The patient was educated on ways to reduce his risk of recurrence and the importance of following up with his healthcare provider regularly. He was discharged in stable condition and advised to follow up as scheduled.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented with a progressively enlarging asymptomatic lesion on his left chest. A biopsy was performed, and the histopathologic evaluation revealed uninvolved epidermis with diffuse dermal sclerosis and underlying panniculitis, which were attributed to recent arterectomy. The patient opted for observation during his bi-annual skin examinations. He was discharged in stable condition and advised to follow up as scheduled. The patient was educated on ways to reduce his risk of recurrence and the importance of following up with his healthcare provider regularly.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: 

Diagnosis: Grade 4 astrocytoma with molecular studies indicating an IDH-mutated, ATRX mutated, and MGMT promoter methylated phenotype with hypermutation.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 28-year-old male with a history of a grade 3 astrocytoma, presented to the emergency department with a general tonic-clonic seizure. Upon admission, he was found to have disease progression with extension into the splenium and anterior-inferior extension into the left thalamus and basal ganglia. Despite changes to his antiepileptic medication, he had seizure recurrence a few weeks following admission.

A repeat maximal safe resection with GammaTile placement was performed due to presuming that the area of tumor recurrence received a definitive dose in the past. The patient developed right upper and lower extremity weakness/spasticity with right foot drop and mild right face weakness as a result of the surgery. 

After the progression of disease in the splenium and left thalamus/basal ganglia was observed, a treatment plan was made to take the progressive regions of disease outside the irradiated GammaTile volume to 35 Gy in 10 fractions. 

Due to the hypermutation phenotype of his tumor, the patient was started on CCNU and completed his EBRT with no issue or progression of his neurological symptoms. He was last seen in follow-up by our team three months after his most recent EBRT, at which point he reported significant improvement in the right leg tremors/spasms and improved headache. He demonstrated decreased right foot drop but continued to have word-finding difficulties and short-term memory deficits.

Discharge Diagnosis: Grade 4 astrocytoma with molecular studies indicating an IDH-mutated, ATRX mutated, and MGMT promoter methylated phenotype with hypermutation. 

Discharge Plan: The patient is scheduled to complete six cycles of CCNU with alternative systemic therapy thereafter upon disease progression.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Age: 60
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Foreign Body in Hypopharynx with Perforation

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with a foreign body sensation in the throat, dysphagia, and odynophagia after having lunch. She had no other related gastrointestinal or airway-related complaints. A lateral neck soft tissue X-ray confirmed the presence of a foreign body in the hypopharynx with a linear radiolucency in the retropharyngeal space representing free air. A neck computed tomography (CT) scan demonstrated a linear hyperdense foreign body in the hypopharynx with free air along the retropharyngeal space representing a concealed perforation.

The patient was treated with endoscopic examination under general anesthesia and foreign body removal. A whitish plastic foreign body was found in the hypopharynx and was removed using foreign body forceps under endoscopic guidance. Examination post foreign body removal showed a small wound in the posterior pharyngeal wall, which represents the site of perforation. An upper gastrointestinal series showed a normal contrast passage through the hypopharynx and esophagus without any evidence of leakage. The patient was treated conservatively with close observation, strict nasogastric tube (NGT) feeding, analgesics, and intravenous antibiotic therapy for seven days. Flexible nasopharyngeal endoscopy was repeated and demonstrated an almost healed posterior pharyngeal wall perforation. The patient was allowed to resume oral feeding and was discharged home in a stable condition.

Follow-Up:

The patient is advised to follow-up with her primary care physician for further evaluation of the wound site in the posterior pharyngeal wall. She is also advised to seek medical attention if she experiences any recurrence of foreign body sensation, dysphagia, or odynophagia. 

Diet:

The patient is advised to gradually resume a normal diet based on her comfort level.

Activity:

The patient should avoid strenuous activity that may cause recurrence of symptoms.

Medications:

Patient medications will be clearly communicated to her primary care physician, for medication management. 

Condition on Discharge:

The patient's symptoms have resolved, and she has been discharged home in a stable condition.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

PATIENT: 67-year-old male

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with anaphylaxis after consuming a nut-containing bar. He had a past medical history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and glaucoma. The initial laboratory investigations indicated an elevation of troponin levels, which increased within the first 24 hours. He was initially treated with epinephrine, methylprednisolone, and diphenhydramine, but due to refractory anaphylaxis, he was admitted to the ventilator unit for monitoring of biphasic anaphylactic reaction. The patient was then titrated off the epinephrine drip for lack of hemodynamic instability congruent with anaphylaxis.

Hospital Day 1 - Serial troponin monitoring showed a significant increase. The patient reported intermittent, non-radiating, mid-sternal chest pressure, which was 5/10 in intensity and decreased to 2/10 in intensity within 24 hours after receiving epinephrine.

Hospital Day 2 - EKG showed a left anterior fascicular block with no ST-segment changes. He was started on aspirin, heparin infusion, and atorvastatin. An echocardiogram showed a normal left ventricular systolic function with an ejection fraction of 56-60%. Additionally, LV segmental wall motion abnormalities, hypokinesis in the mid inferolateral segment were also found. Chest X-ray did not show any abnormalities.

Hospital Day 3 - Elective coronary angiogram was performed, which revealed single-vessel disease. The left main, left circumflex, and right coronary arteries were normal. A patent stent in the inferior branch of the diagonal artery with 30% in-stent restenosis and a jailed superior branch of the diagonal with 95% ostial lesion was also revealed.

Hospital Day 4 - Serial troponin monitoring showed a downward trend. The patient's chest pain resolved, and he was discharged to follow up with the outpatient cardiology clinic.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:

1. Anaphylaxis
2. Coronary artery disease with single-vessel disease
3. High cholesterol
4. Hypertension
5. Glaucoma

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

1. The patient should avoid eating any food that contains nuts or similar ingredients.
2. The patient should continue taking aspirin, heparin infusion, and atorvastatin as prescribed and follow up with the outpatient cardiology clinic.
3. The patient should follow up with the primary care physician for hypertension and high cholesterol management.
4. The patient should continue taking glaucoma medications as prescribed and follow up with the ophthalmologist.
5. The patient should return to the ED immediately if he experiences a severe allergic reaction.
6. The patient should notify his treating physicians of any changes in his condition or occurrence of new symptoms.

FOLLOW-UP CARE:

Follow up with the outpatient cardiology clinic for further evaluation and management.

Hospital Course:

The patient was a 74-year-old male admitted for altered mental status and non-responsiveness. On admission, the patient had an elevated blood glucose and anion gap, as well as hypernatremia, acute kidney injury, and hemoconcentration. Imaging studies showed a right lower lobe mass or consolidation with multiple mediastinal and hilar masses compatible with lymphadenopathy, a suprasellar mass, and nodular densities in the adrenal glands and kidneys. Additional investigations showed small lymph nodes in the parotid glands, a persistent primary respiratory alkalosis with secondary metabolic alkalosis, and endocrine abnormalities consistent with gonadotropin deficiency and hypothyroidism.

Treatment:

The patient was started on half normal saline and insulin for the hyperglycemia. The acute kidney injury improved by day 3, though the hypernatremia did not correct until the patient was started on desmopressin on day 7. Given the significant metastatic burden, the plan was to obtain a lung biopsy and conduct a high dexamethasone suppression test for ectopic ACTH production. However, the patient declined further workup or treatment and opted for hospice.

Course:

The patient was sent home on hospice and was advised to increase his water intake. The family was informed of the abnormal imaging findings and provided with the options for palliative care. The patient's prognosis was explained to the family, and they agreed to the plan for comfort measures. A follow-up appointment was scheduled with the primary care provider. Discharge instructions were provided to the family, and they were advised to follow up with the primary care provider regularly.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 45-year-old transgender male

Medical History: Guillain Barre Syndrome, heterozygous Factor V Leiden

Admission Diagnosis: Endocarditis with mitral valve involvement and associated complications

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted with lethargy, shortness of breath, weight gain, and lower extremity edema. Physical exam and laboratory work revealed leukocytosis, creatinine elevation, hemoglobin decrease, B-type natriuretic peptide elevation, and D-dimer elevation. CT chest showed cardiomegaly, pulmonary edema, bilateral lower lobe consolidations, pleural effusions, large pericardial effusion, and perisplenic abscess. Echocardiogram showed a mobile vegetation on the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve, moderate-severe mitral valve insufficiency, dilated left atrium, and elevated peak pulmonary artery pressure. Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics were started for infective endocarditis and diuresis for heart failure. Splenic fluid and blood cultures grew Enterococcus faecalis. The patient underwent cardiothoracic surgery with an On-X mechanical mitral valve, complicated by mediastinal thrombus formation and hemothorax requiring surgical exploration. The patient was stabilized and discharged with IV penicillin G and ceftriaxone to complete six weeks of antibiotic therapy.

Post-Discharge Follow-Up: N/A

Follow-Up Appointments: N/A

Relevant Medications: N/A

Discharge Condition: Stable

Discharge Instructions: The patient should follow up with a primary care physician and a cardiologist. They should continue taking antibiotics as prescribed and avoid strenuous activities. If they experience any symptoms suggestive of complications or endocarditis recurrence, they should seek medical care immediately.

Discharge Diagnosis: Endocarditis, mitral valve insufficiency, heart failure, sepsis, thrombus formation, hemothorax.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: [Name]
DOB: [Date of birth]
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Admission Diagnosis:
Chronic appendicitis

Hospital Course:
[Name] was admitted to the clinic with ongoing RLQ abdominal pain of one-month duration, associated with mild fever. It was noted from histopathology reports that there was chronic lymphoplasmacytic inflammation with associated histiocytes and granulation tissue, further supporting the diagnosis of chronic appendicitis. 

Treatment:
Laparoscopic appendectomy was performed on [Name]. The appendix was identified and found to be chronically scarred and chronically inflamed in appearance. The mesoappendix was taken down with Sonicision, the base transected with Endo-GIA, and delivered from the peritoneal cavity in an Endobag and sent to pathology.

Discharge Condition:
[Name] was discharged home on the same day as his procedure with no complaints.

Instructions:
Please follow up with your primary care physician (PCP) in the coming days to ensure that there has been complete resolution of symptoms.

Signed,
[Doctor's name]

Hospital Course:

This is a comprehensive discharge summary for a 77-year-old male with a history of COPD and melanoma who presented with worsening dyspnea, cough and diarrhea. The patient was started on pembrolizumab in 2017 for lung metastasis but presented with severe bullous changes in bilateral lungs, a small right pleural effusion, and a spiculated nodule in the left lower lobe measuring 1.1 cm by 2.2 cm in 2019. Treatment included discontinuation of pembrolizumab, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and methylprednisolone. A bronchoscopy was performed, which showed mucosa inflammation of the right lower lobe, right middle lobe, and the anterior segment of the right upper lobe with dark yellow mucus plug seen. He was discharged on prednisone 40 mg b.i.d. plan to taper down over the next six weeks. The patient developed two consecutive episodes of secondary spontaneous pneumothorax. In June 2021, he was tapered down to prednisone 2.5 mg daily, and his respiratory status was stable, with chest CT showing resolution of pneumonitis. The patient expired in his sleep in September 2021.

Summary of hospitalization:

The admission was for a 77-year-old male with a history of COPD and melanoma who presented with generalized weakness, acute on chronic worsening dyspnea, cough, and diarrhea. He had been receiving pembrolizumab for lung metastasis which had resulted in severe bullous changes in bilateral lungs. Treatment included discontinuation of pembrolizumab, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and methylprednisolone. The patient had two episodes of secondary spontaneous pneumothorax during hospitalization which required chest tube placement. The patient was discharged on prednisone with a plan to taper down over six weeks.

Discharge Instructions:

Patient passed away in September 2021.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: February 2020

Discharge Date: February 2020

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical History: Malignant mucosal lentiginous melanoma of the left gingiva (stage III; pT3, N1, M0)

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 64-year-old female, was admitted with fatigue and worsening shortness of breath. She had undergone chemotherapy and radiation for the above-mentioned medical history. She was diagnosed with nivolumab-induced pneumonitis along with transaminitis and thyroiditis. She had a history of being a current smoker of 1 ppd for the last 30 years. Chest CT without contrast showed interstitial/ground-glass changes, and multiple pulmonary nodules were seen in the upper lobes bilaterally, right middle lobe, and right lower lobe. BAL results were negative, including a viral panel, Gram stain, and culture, and fungal stain and culture. She underwent bronchoscopy with BAL with findings of erythematous bronchial mucosa of the right lower lobe. She was started on ceftriaxone and azithromycin for possible pneumonia, and intravenous steroids were initiated. After increasing the steroids, she felt better, and her breathing improved. She was discharged on prednisone 60 mg daily and was recommended to follow up on an outpatient basis with oncology and pulmonology. Unfortunately, she did not follow up with either oncology or pulmonology and was lost to follow-up.

Discharge Summary

Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course:
A 65-year-old female with non-small cell adenocarcinoma of the right middle lobe, status after right middle lobectomy and mediastinal node dissection, presented with elevated creatinine levels in March 2020. Her kidney biopsy revealed acute and chronic interstitial nephritis grade 3 and tubulitis. She was started on a prednisone 40mg taper and her creatinine improved. She was diagnosed with pembrolizumab-induced acute interstitial nephritis and was advised to stop the medication. She was discharged on a steroid taper. Her creatinine levels increased again once her pembrolizumab was resumed in July 2020, and the medication was discontinued indefinitely after discussion with her oncology team. She was discharged on a prednisone 10mg taper and followed up in the outpatient setting.

Hospital Course: Complete

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Metastatic Melanoma
Discharge Diagnosis: Remission of Metastatic Melanoma

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 53-year-old female, was admitted to our hospital in February 2019 with left inguinal swelling. Core biopsy later confirmed it to be melanoma, which was diagnosed as metastatic melanoma (cTx, pN1b, M1). After her left inguinal node dissection in March 2019, she was started on pembrolizumab for the treatment of her condition. However, in January 2020, she presented to the outpatient oncology with progressive weakness, fatigue, lethargy, myalgia, poor appetite, weight loss, and mood changes over a period of 6-8 weeks. She was diagnosed with pembrolizumab-induced hypophysitis, and her treatment was modified accordingly.

Management and Treatment:
The patient was started on prednisone 1 mg/kg/day with gradual tapering to the maintenance dose of 10 mg daily after being diagnosed with pembrolizumab-induced hypophysitis. She responded well to the therapy, and her cortisol levels normalized in March 2020. Pembrolizumab treatment was resumed in March 2020, and she completed the course in April 2021. Her repeat chest CT scans in May 2020 were negative for any recurrent cancer. She is currently tolerating pembrolizumab, reporting good energy levels without any fatigue, myalgia, or mood changes while still on prednisone 7.5 mg daily.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's latest follow-up in August 2021 did not show any evidence of recurrent disease, and she was discharged from our hospital in remission of metastatic melanoma.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was advised to continue prednisone 7.5 mg daily for the next few months and to have regular follow-up visits with an oncologist.

Final Diagnosis:
Metastatic melanoma in remission.

Signed by:
[REDACTED], MD
Hospitalist

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 71-year-old female who presented with lower limb weakness, paresthesias, and increased urinary frequency. On examination, she had symmetrical lower limb motor weakness with reduced sensations in lower limbs symmetrically. Diagnostic workup showed disseminated malignancy with metastatic lesions to anterior chest wall, liver, lungs, and a necrotic 3.5 cm nodal mass in the left gastric region. A repeat MRI spine with contrast showed a 20*10*19 mm enhancing soft tissue metastatic mass lesion seen within conus. An endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) showed a deep, malignant-looking gastric ulcer on the high anterior greater curve of the stomach. Biopsy from the stomach lesion surprisingly showed a metastatic malignant melanoma with a mutation within codon 600. The patient was managed with palliative treatment.
During hospitalization, the patient contracted COVID-19 pneumonia and developed bilateral segmental pulmonary emboli. She was treated with oral dexamethasone and oxygen inhalation via nasal cannula, and anticoagulation with apixaban was started. The patient's neurological symptoms worsened and progressed to paraplegia, urinary and fecal incontinence over a period of three to four weeks since initial presentation. The patient passed away three months after diagnosis of metastatic melanoma under community palliative care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 79-year-old Caucasian male with a 7-year history of myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS)

Hospitalization Dates: [insert dates]

Medical History: Positive for MDS and cholecystectomy. Daily medications included thalidomide, deferasirox, dimethicone, pantoprazole, gabapentin, vitamin B12, and folic acid. The patient also took erythropoietin and rivaroxaban three times a week and filgrastim every fifth day.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with complaints of abdominal pain, fever, oral intolerance, nausea, and vomiting. On admission, he was ill and dehydrated with tenderness of the epigastrium and right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Laboratory results showed abnormalities, and abdominopelvic ultrasonography revealed mild fluid in subhepatic and inflamed echogenic fat in the upper abdomen and around the pancreas. A CT scan demonstrated edematous wall thickening of the entire duodenum with water halo and significant adjacent fat stranding and swelling of the pancreas, implying the possibility of ischemia or necrosis.

The patient was managed with intravenous antibiotics and fluid resuscitation. However, his condition deteriorated, leading to severe electrolyte imbalance, gasping, severe acidosis (arterial pH = 6.8), and GCS 4/15. The second CT scan revealed a marked decrease in the enhancement of the edematous duodenum and target sign, suggesting microvascular ischemia or necrosis.

The patient was immediately transferred to the operating room, where a midline laparotomy incision was made. Kocher’s maneuver was performed to explore the duodenum and the retroperitoneal structures. A Whipple’s procedure was planned initially, but the patient's cardiac arrest during the operation directed the plan to a damage control surgery. The overall operation time was approximately one hour and a half. To achieve a damage control surgery, decompression of the stomach was done by a red (18 French) nasogastric tube. Lastly, an open (corrugated sheet) drain was placed near the duodenum.

Despite two hours of supportive therapy, blood pressure remained 40 mmHg/pulse, leading to a cardiac arrest with asystole rhythm and patient expiration.

Impressions:

From the available data, the patient had a severe case of duodenal ischemia or necrosis after admission with abdominal pain, fever, oral intolerance, nausea, and vomiting. The possible etiologies may have been microvascular ischemia or necrosis.

Follow-up:

The patient expired during hospitalization, and the next of kin refused an autopsy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Patient's Name]
Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]
Date of Discharge: [Date of Discharge]

Hospital Course:
[Patient's Name], an 83-year-old Japanese woman, was admitted to our department with a chief complaint of a mass in her right maxillary premolar region. The patient had initially noticed a painless mass in her right maxillary premolar region in 2002, but she did not seek any treatment for it. She was referred to us for examination and treatment due to difficulty in performing tracheal intubation for surgery of sigmoid colon cancer at another hospital.

After performing several tests, the patient was diagnosed with peripheral ossifying fibroma with squamous cell carcinoma. We suspected a benign gingival tumor in the right maxillary premolar region, which was confirmed by a biopsy. Later, tumorectomy was performed under general anesthesia to remove the tumor, including the surrounding tissue. One week after surgery, the wound was covered with an oral appliance for protection.

The microscopic findings of the surgically removed tumor were similar to those of the biopsy specimen. The tumor was composed of spindle-shaped cells that were proliferating with collagenous fiber, and scattered bone formation was also observed. The epithelial component of the tumor was considered to be well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. No signs of local recurrence or metastasis have been observed during follow-up.

Patient History:
The patient's history included sigmoid colon cancer, subarachnoid hemorrhaging, bronchitic asthma, and cardiac insufficiency.

Physical Exam:
Regarding the intra- and extra-oral findings, a massive pedunculated mass in the right maxillary premolar region measuring 83 × 58 × 35 mm was palpable. Furthermore, it covered the front of the right palate, and it protruded to the extra-oral region from the right maxillary premolar alveolar region. Its surface was almost entirely smooth, and some erosions and ulcerations were seen. It was elastic and hard and showed no tenderness on palpation. There was no palpable regional lymphadenopathy.

Diagnosis:
Peripheral ossifying fibroma with squamous cell carcinoma (pT1N0M0)

Treatment:
Tumorectomy was performed under general anesthesia to remove the tumor, including the surrounding tissue. One week after surgery, the wound was covered with an oral appliance for protection.

Condition at discharge:
At the time of discharge, the patient's condition was stable, and there were no signs of local recurrence or metastasis during follow-up.

Follow-Up Plan:
The patient will continue regular follow-up appointments with her primary care physician to monitor for any signs of recurrence or metastasis.

Discharge Summary:

This is a summary of the hospitalization of a 19-year-old female patient who was diagnosed with pheochromocytoma and paraganglioma. The patient had a history of tumor occupation in the right adrenal gland, which was surgically removed and diagnosed as pheochromocytoma. During this hospitalization, multiple tumor occupations were found in the left adrenal and paraganglion region zones. The patient had symptoms of fever, headache, and high blood pressure. Further scans revealed occupying lesions in the right lung and pancreas that were diagnosed as masses.

Hospital Course:

History: The patient was first diagnosed with a tumor in the right adrenal gland during a regular physical examination five years ago. The tumor was surgically removed and found to be a pheochromocytoma. The patient was regularly followed up and recent scans showed multiple tumor occupations in the left adrenal and paraganglion region zones. The patient had symptoms of fever, headache, and high blood pressure. Further scans revealed occupying lesions in the right lung and pancreas that were diagnosed as masses.

Presenting Illness: The patient was admitted to the hospital for further examination and treatment of the tumor occupations and masses.

Medical Management: The medical team conducted various tests and examinations to confirm the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma and paraganglioma with occupying lesions in the right lung and pancreas. The patient was treated with appropriate medications to manage the symptoms of fever, headache, and high blood pressure.

Final Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with combined pheochromocytoma and paraganglioma (PPGLs) with lesions in the left adrenal gland, paraganglion region, right lung, and pancreas.

Disposition: The patient was discharged with recommendations for continued follow-up and monitoring of the lesions for potential further treatment.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 57 years
Sex: Female
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with a diagnosis of advanced stage ovarian cancer. She underwent carboplatin-paclitaxel based chemotherapy in a neoadjuvant setting. The patient received a debulking surgery with hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC) and had a CVL inserted via the right jugular vein into the superior vena cava in prevision of surgery. The first 48 postoperative hours were marked by hypotension, difficult pain management, and transient hyperlactatemia that responded to fluid replacement and norepinephrine. On postoperative day 3, she presented acute onset dyspnea with bilateral pleural effusions indicating major drop in SpO2. After being stabilized by switching to nonrebreather mask and being in supine position, arteriovenous oxygen difference was obtained through arterial and central venous line sampling. A CT pulmonary angiography confirmed large bilateral pleural effusions, acute pulmonary embolism in the right middle and upper lobe pulmonary arteries, and ultimately an anatomical variant of the left upper pulmonary vein draining into the left innominate vein.

Diagnosis at Discharge:
Advanced stage ovarian cancer, bilateral pleural effusions with atelectasis, acute pulmonary embolism, anatomical variant of the left upper pulmonary vein draining into the left innominate vein.

Treatment Given:
Bilateral chest drainage was done and low molecular weight heparin was administered twice daily to treat the acute pulmonary embolism. No evidence for deep venous thrombosis was found. The patient showed significant clinical improvement with disappearance of the platypnea–orthodeoxia complaints and significant reduction in oxygen requirement over the following days.

Follow-Up Care:
At 1-year follow-up, TTE showed no right ventricular dilation and absence of pulmonary hypertension. From an oncological perspective, stability was also observed during her niraparib maintenance therapy with absence of new lesions at a 1-year follow-up abdominal CT.

Discharge Medications:
None

Discharge Disposition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital due to anorexia and dyspnea. The patient had a history of surgery for appendicitis and mild intellectual disability. The patient's ECG revealed a short PR interval with pre-excitation and negative T waves. Echocardiography showed hypertrophic dilated left ventricle with poor systolic function. Doppler parameters indicated a restrictive filling pattern and severe mitral and tricuspid regurgitation. The patient had Grade 3 left ventricular diastolic dysfunction according to the American Society of Echocardiography/European Association of Cardiovascular Imaging guidelines and references. The patient had elevated total bilirubin, indirect bilirubin, and aspartate aminotransferase levels. 

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient experienced sudden cardiac death at the age of 33 years.

Discharge Condition:

Deceased.

None.

None.

None.

None.

Discharge Summary:

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to progressive vision loss and neurological symptoms. Medical history included follicular lymphoma, which was treated with chemotherapy in the past. Brain CT initially showed a cortical and subcortical lesion, which was confirmed by MRI. Brain biopsy suggested an inflammatory demyelinating process, but subsequent imaging and laboratory tests suggested progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy. The patient's neurological symptoms continued to worsen despite treatment, and the patient was transferred to a hospice for palliative care.

The patient presented to the hospital with progressive vision loss and neurological symptoms.

Hospital Course:

The 19-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital in December 2017 with a recent diagnosis of histiocytic sarcoma. The patient presented with pharyngeal pain and a left neck mass with fever for 2 months. The patient received a tracheotomy because of airway obstruction resulting from a large mass arising from the left parapharyngeal space at a local clinic. PET/CT scan shows a large solid mass located in the left parapharyngeal space with compression of the pharyngeal cavity and multiple enlarged lymph nodes in the left neck. The histopathological review confirmed diagnosis of histiocytic sarcoma. 

Treatment and Management:

Chemotherapy was initially started with the aim of stabilization of the fulminate disease course; however, the lesions did not shrink and pain and dysphagia were heavier caused by the compression of the pharynx. In order to relieve the compression, irradiation to the lesions of pharyngeal and neck was started. After irradiation, the size of lesions became a little bit smaller.

Next-generation sequencing (NGS) of tumor tissue was performed and showed the presence of oncogenic mutations. The patient began to take a specific medication. After one month of treatment, a partial response was observed. The medication was continued for two months, however, the patient could no longer afford such an expensive drug. 

NGS was done again and the patient was treated with a medication that was more affordable. Two months after the treatment, excellent PR was observed compared with tumor size in March 2018. Four months later the re-evaluation showed a nearly complete remission. 

Follow-Up:

The patient took maintenance medication for two years and stopped the treatment in March 2020. To date, 45 months after HS diagnosis, she is still alive without tumor recurrence.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Confidential]

Date of Admission: [Confidential]

Date of Discharge: [Confidential]

Admission Diagnosis: Severe hypertensive disorder of pregnancy and fetal growth restriction (FGR)

Clinical Course: At 19 gestational weeks, the patient was diagnosed with severe hypertensive disorder of pregnancy and fetal growth restriction (FGR). An emergency cesarean section was performed at 23 6/7 gestational weeks due to worsened hypertensive disorder of pregnancy and non-reassuring fetal status. A male infant was delivered with a birthweight of 293 g. Endotracheal intubation and surfactant replacement were performed immediately after birth in the delivery room. Initial examination revealed anemia, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and slight ascites on ultrasonography, suggesting intra-abdominal bleeding. Intensive treatment, including HFOV, inotropes, steroids, and massive blood and plasma transfusion for the progressive anemia and DIC, was started. Liver and adrenal bleeding gradually became evident on ultrasonography, and the patient continued to suffer from refractory hypotension and further progressive anemia. Throughout the course, the patient's parents hoped to switch to palliative care, seeing the patient's irreversible worsening clinical condition. The patient eventually died of hemorrhagic shock at 3 DOL.

Discharge Diagnosis: Hemorrhagic shock

Hospital Course: The patient was treated for severe hypertensive disorder of pregnancy and fetal growth restriction (FGR). The patient's condition worsened, and an emergency cesarean section was conducted. Despite intensive treatment, the patient experienced liver and adrenal bleeding and suffered from refractory hypotension and further progressive anemia. The patient eventually passed away from hemorrhagic shock at 3 DOL.

Discharge Medications: N/A

Follow-Up: N/A

Condition at Discharge: Deceased

Discharge Instructions: N/A

Provider: [Confidential]

Hospital Course:

This 40-year-old primipara woman was transferred to our hospital and diagnosed with fetal growth restriction at 19 gestational weeks. At 22 gestational weeks, she was admitted due to severe hypertensive disorder of pregnancy. An emergency cesarean section was performed at 22+6/7 gestational weeks, and a female infant was born with a birthweight of 279 g. Endotracheal intubation and surfactant administration were administered in the delivery room, and UAC and PICC placement were successful. Prophylactic indomethacin was given once, with PDA closure at 1 day of life. The patient's circulatory status stabilized successfully within 72 hours of life without intraventricular hemorrhage. Mean fluid intake during the first weeks of life was 143.0 ml/kg/day. Enteral feeding with breast milk was initiated at 3 days of life; however, the breast milk secretion was insufficient. Therefore, enteral feeding was increased slowly and hydrolyzed formula milk was used at 23 days of life. No necrotizing enterocolitis was detected throughout her clinical course. Despite requiring HFOV, five-time repeated surfactant replacement, and systemic hydrocortisone to manage the severe bronchopulmonary dysplasia, the patient was successfully extubated at 73 days of life. Oral feeding was started at 101 days of life, and the patient was discharged at 146 days of life with home oxygen therapy, without tube feeding. She did not develop intraventricular hemorrhage or periventricular leukomalacia. Despite the diagnosis of ROP (right; stage II, left; stage III), no therapy was required. She is now 8 months of corrected age and stays healthy in the outpatient clinic without signs of developmental delay; she already sits, rolls over, and pulls up to standing.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Confidential
Gender: Female
Age: 53

Admission Date: June 2020
Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted to the BCG-DENMARK-COVID trial in early June 2020 and was randomized to receive intradermal BCG vaccination in the right deltoid region. Following the vaccination, the patient reported a strong local skin reaction with yellowish serous secretion and swollen lymph nodes in the axil on the vaccinated side lasting for 4-5 months. In January 2021, the patient received the first Moderna Covid-19 vaccination, followed by the second after three weeks. The patient experienced fever, muscle pain, redness and inflammation around the site of the Covid-19 vaccine, and itching at the BCG vaccination site scar several days after both vaccinations, but no secretion or significant symptoms observed. The patient did not receive any other vaccines during follow-up and did not require any treatment. 

Medical History:
As per participant's mother, she had received the childhood BCG vaccination and reacted strongly to it. The patient has no known history of tuberculosis or current medication.

Summary: 
The patient was admitted to the BCG-DENMARK-COVID trial and was randomized to receive intradermal BCG vaccination in the right deltoid region. Following vaccinations, the patient experienced strong local skin reactions with additional symptoms like swollen and sore lymph nodes and itching. The patient received two Moderna Covid-19 vaccinations, after each of which she experienced fever, muscle pain, redness, inflammation and itching. No secretion was reported, and no further treatment was required. The patient's medical history is notable for a reaction to the childhood BCG vaccination with no other significant medical history identified.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: N/A

Medical Record Number: N/A

Discharge Date: Day 18 of Hospitalization

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 48-year-old male with a history of syphilis and sickle cell trait, was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of mantle cell lymphoma with multiple lymphomatous polyposis. The patient underwent three cycles of R-Maxi CHOP and three cycles of R-High Dose-Ara-C with complete response. His PBSC were mobilized and harvested on his last cycle of R-High Dose Ara-C with G-CSF and plerixafor. Seven months after his diagnosis and two months after his last chemoimmunotherapy, he underwent the BeEAM protocol for an autologous HCT.

On day –8, the patient started the BeEAM protocol and received his first dose of intravenous bendamustine. From day –6, the patient's urine output, serum sodium, and serum creatinine started to increase. Forced diuresis with furosemide was stopped, and oral hydration was optimized. On day –1, the patient started complaining of polyuria, nocturia, and thirst. Despite the normal range of urine osmolality, a nephrology consultation team suspected nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI) along with concomitant dehydration in absence of other identified causes of polyuria. A desmopressin challenge was administered intravenously and showed a 33% increase from baseline urine osmolality with a decrease in diuresis. The patient remained polyuric and highly dependent on fluids due to his hypernatremia. Intranasal desmopressin was started and increased until it reached 40 mcg twice daily intranasally. A brain MRI was then performed to rule out central lymphomatous infiltrates, which came back negative and reinforced a diagnosis of partial NDI. The patient's natremia returned to normal range along with decreased diuresis and intravenous dextrose 5% was stopped. Desmopressin was weaned off and then stopped. The patient was discharged from the hospital on day 18 and remains in remission of his lymphoma.

Diagnoses:
- Mantle cell lymphoma with multiple lymphomatous polyposis
- Partial NDI

Condition at Discharge:
Stable

Recommendations:
Follow up with the nephrology team and monitor the patient's fluid intake and output closely. No further treatment is needed for the lymphoma at this time.

Instructions:
N/A

Attending Doctor:
N/A

Disposition:
Home.

Discharge Summary: 

Patient Identification: 
- Name: [Patient's Name]
- Gender: Female
- Age: 38 years
- Address: [Patient's Address]
- Hospital Admission Number: [Admission Number]

Hospital Course: 
- The patient was admitted to the hospital due to sudden onset of pain, cold and functional impotence of the lower limbs at 32+2 weeks of gestation. Fetal death was observed during obstetric evaluation. 
- Given the suspicion of lower limb ischemia, low weight molecular heparin was started and the patient was transferred to our hospital.
- On admission to our ED, the patient presented with tachypnea, absence of pulses and cold of the lower limbs, minimal neurosensory deficit and muscle weakness.
- Computed Tomography angiography (Angio CT) showed bilateral pulmonary embolism (PE), deep venous thrombosis of the inferior vena cava and left iliac axis, areas of splenic and right kidney infarction and multiple arterial and venous thrombosis.
- Lower extremity revascularization surgery was performed under general anesthesia to regain lower limb perfusion. Bilateral thromboembolectomy of the lower limbs, axillary-bifemoral bypass procedure with synthetic prosthesis were performed.
- The patient was transferred to an intermediate care unit for further treatment and monitoring.
- The patient maintained therapeutic anticoagulation, underwent a total of six sessions of plasmapheresis and the first dose of rituximab (1000 mg) was administered.
- The patient showed improvement during treatment: platelet count, hepatic enzymes and serum creatinine normalized.
- Histological examination of the placenta showed areas of small vessel infarction.
- Six months after discharge, the patient has resumed her day-to-day activities and remains under warfarin therapy.
- The patient has taken repeated tests for antiphospholipid antibodies, thrombophilia, autoimmune diseases and infectious diseases. The results were all negative and within normal range.
- CD19 positive cells are still depleted (0,1%; normal 7–23%), due to previous rituximab infusions.

Diagnosis: 
- Acute Limb Ischemia, Grade IIA-B
- Bilateral Pulmonary Embolism (PE)
- Deep Venous Thrombosis (IVC, Left Iliac Axis, etc.)
- Areas of Splenic and Right Kidney Infarction 
- Multiple Arterial and Venous Thrombosis
- Presumptive Catastrophic Antiphospholipid Syndrome (CAPS)

Summary: 
The patient was admitted to the hospital with sudden onset of pain, cold and functional impotence of the lower limbs at 32+2 weeks of gestation. Fetal death was observed. Given the suspicion of lower limb ischemia, low weight molecular heparin was started and the patient was transferred to our hospital. On admission to our ED, the patient presented with tachypnea, absence of pulses and cold of the lower limbs, minimal neurosensory deficit and muscle weakness. Computed Tomography angiography (Angio CT) showed bilateral pulmonary embolism (PE), deep venous thrombosis of the inferior vena cava and left iliac axis, areas of splenic and right kidney infarction and multiple arterial and venous thrombosis. The patient underwent surgery under general anesthesia to regain lower limb perfusion. Bilateral thromboembolectomy of the lower limbs, axillary-bifemoral bypass procedure with synthetic prosthesis were performed. The patient was transferred to an intermediate care unit for further treatment and monitoring. The patient maintained therapeutic anticoagulation, underwent a total of six sessions of plasmapheresis and the first dose of rituximab (1000 mg) was administered. The patient showed improvement during treatment: platelet count, hepatic enzymes and serum creatinine normalized. Six months after discharge, the patient has resumed her day-to-day activities and remains under warfarin therapy. The patient has taken repeated tests for antiphospholipid antibodies, thrombophilia, autoimmune diseases, and infectious diseases. The results were all negative and within normal range.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 24 years
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]
Reason for admission: Sepsis of unclear etiology

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with a fever and chest pain that radiated to the upper back associated with multiple episodes of vomiting and progressive dyspnea. Initial evaluation revealed subcutaneous emphysema in the cervical and thoracic regions and dullness to percussion in both lung bases. Investigation results showed sepsis of unclear etiology, although there was a suspicious of esophageal perforation predisposing mediastinitis and sepsis. A contrast-enhanced thoracic CT showed a pneumomediastinum, cervical emphysema, bilateral pleural effusion, as well as extraluminal oral contrast surrounding the gastro-esophageal junction. An endoscopy revealed a distal esophageal linear tear above the Z line with irregular edges. The patient underwent initial treatment including intravenous fluid, nothing per oral (NPO), broad-spectrum antibiotics, and analgesia. Due to the clinical condition of the patient, the thoracic surgery and gastroenterology teams decided on a non-operative approach based on endoscopic therapy. The patient underwent endoscopy and was found to have a distal auto-expandable esophageal prosthesis placed. The thoracic surgeon decided to put a bilateral pleural tube oriented toward the perforation preventing future complications. Biopsies of the esophageal mucosa were obtained confirming the clinical suspicion of eosinophilic esophagitis.

Five days after admission, a new endoscopic procedure was performed, revealing migration of the esophageal stent into the stomach, a persistent perforation defect in the lower third of the esophagus with granulation tissue and two small cavities suggesting a fistulous tract. An endoluminal vacuum-assisted closure with sponge was placed in the area of perforation with the fistula to control both complications. Over the next few weeks, three dressing changes of endoscopic vacuum-assisted closure with sponge were performed before esophago-pleural fistula resolution was evident. The sponge and the OTSC® was retired due to a complete fistula resolution. A follow-up endoscopy performed three days after the last vacuum-assisted closure with sponge was removed, revealing epithelialized esophageal mucosa with granulation tissue.

The patient was discharged after 46 days with food elimination diet and prednisone base therapy as a measure of control of his eosinophilic esophagitis. An asymptomatic patient was presenting at a follow-up appointment two months after being discharged.

Hospital Course:

The patient was a 50-year-old male truck driver who was admitted with severe retrosternal chest pain, vomiting, and hypertension. He had a history of high cholesterol levels and the loss of consciousness while driving due to acute chest pain. He was initially evaluated for acute coronary syndrome, but tests ruled out the diagnosis.

On the second day of hospitalization, he experienced bloody vomiting and difficulty swallowing. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) revealed multiple mucosal ulcerations in the esophagus and erosions in both stomach and duodenum. The diagnosis of Doxycycline-induced esophageal ulcerations was made, and doxycycline was discontinued. The patient was treated with ceftriaxone and omeprazole intravenously, along with an antacid suspension. Parenteral analgesics were added as required.

The patient's pain and fever gradually subsided. After six days, he was discharged in improved condition, with instructions to take omeprazole orally twice daily for four weeks. He was advised to swallow pills in an upright position and with water to prevent recurrence of similar problems. 

At his three-week follow-up, the patient was asymptomatic, and liver transaminases were normal. He was found to have chronic hepatitis B infection, which was managed accordingly.

Impression:

The patient had Doxycycline-induced esophageal ulcerations with acute chest pain, vomiting, and hypertension. EGD revealed multiple mucosal ulcerations in the esophagus and erosions in both stomach and duodenum. He was discharged in improved condition and was advised to take omeprazole oral medication for four weeks. The patient was also found to have chronic hepatitis B infection but was asymptomatic at his follow-up visit.

- Hospital Course:

The patient is a 55-year-old male who presented to the hospital with sudden onset of dizziness, diplopia, difficulty closing eyes, and trouble chewing. He was diagnosed with bilateral horizontal gaze palsy, gazed-evoked upbeat nystagmus (UBN), and bilateral peripheral facial paralysis with predominance on the left. Mild ataxia was also noticed on the left upper extremity. Brain MRI revealed new infarction in the right middle cerebellar peduncle and bilateral dorsal pontine tegmentum. CT angiography showed no evidence of significant stenosis of the vertebrobasilar artery. CSF examination was normal, and CSF analysis for oligoclonal band, myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein antibody, and aquaporin-4 antibody were negative. Contrast-enhanced transcranial Doppler showed evidence of potential right-to-left shunt. Further transesophageal echocardiography revealed a patent foramen ovale (PFO) with a tunnel length of 12.6 mm. No significant arrhythmias were captured during Holter monitor examination in hospital.

- Medical Management:

The patient was prescribed Rivaroxaban 15 mg/d at discharge. Closure of PFO was then administrated.

- Follow-Up:

The patient's symptoms improved, with follow-up MRI at 6 months showing an old infarction of the same region without other evidence of demyelination.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 69-year-old man with a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia, was admitted with complaints of chest distress and shortness of breath after stress for four months. He was diagnosed with resistant hypertension with chronic renal disease and renal dysfunction. During his hospitalization, he was diagnosed with a suspected left renal infarction.

Diagnostic and Therapeutic Interventions:

Abdominal enhanced computerised tomography (CT) demonstrated a suspected left renal infarction. Abdominal enhanced CT was reperformed and showed that his left renal artery was nearly occluded, his right renal artery had mild to moderate stenosis and his left kidney had atrophied. An invasive angiography with angiographic catheter JR 4.0 further demonstrated a 95% stenosis of the proximal segment of the left renal artery, and the middle segment was blurred with multi-channel-like blood flow. A lesion of the middle segment of the left renal artery was sequentially dilated by a 1.5 × 15 mm balloon, 2.5 × 10 mm balloon, and 4.0 × 15 mm balloon at 8–12 atm, and an express SD 5.0 x 19 mm stent was implanted at 12 atm successfully, overlapping with the proximal segment of the left renal artery.

Clinical Course:

Following successful medical intervention, the patient recovered well, and during the three months of follow-up, the patient achieved complete remission of chest distress, shortness of breath, and waist pain. Blood pressure was well controlled, and renal function was recovered.

Recommendations:

The patient is recommended to continue taking atorvastatin, ezetimibe, aspirin, clopidogrel, Sacubitril Valsartan Sodium, and metoprolol succinate, as prescribed, to maintain control of his conditions.

Discharge summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Patient Name]
Gender: Male
Age: 14 months
Medical Record Number: [MRN Number]

Hospital Course:
[Patient Name], a 14-month-old Congolese male child with oculocutaneous albinism and sickle cell disease, was admitted to the pediatric clinic with fever and fatigue. The patient had a significant history of episodes of fever with monthly frequency of two episodes. Physical examination showed generalized pallor with subicteric conjunctivae and stage III splenomegaly.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
Laboratory testing showed a hemoglobin level of 48 g/L and white blood cells at 13,200/μl. The diagnosis of sickle cell disease was confirmed through the positive rapid test and hemoglobin electrophoresis. The diagnosis of albinism was proven through molecular genetics on a blood sample and identification of the mutation involved. The patient was treated with a blood transfusion and antibiotic treatment (ceftriaxone and amikacin).

Follow-up and Recommendations:
After discharge, routine prophylaxis with folic acid and oral penicillin was initiated for the patient. Advice on crisis prevention and medical monitoring was given to the parents. A dedicated patient monitoring program was set up for sickle cell anemia and albinism with hygiene advice and sun protection measures. The patient received a hat, sunglasses, and sun protection cream. Ophthalmologic follow-up has also been set up. 

Conclusion:
The patient's evolution remains dermatologically stable with no observed skin lesions. Treatment with hydroxyurea was initiated for the patient, and only one infectious episode and one vaso-occlusive crisis were observed over the past year. The patient will continue to receive medical monitoring and follow-up care for his sickle cell anemia and albinism.

Electronic Health Record: Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [MRN]

Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]
Admitting Diagnosis: Asymptomatic Proteinuria
Discharge Diagnosis: Focal Segmental Glomerular Sclerosis (FSGS)

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with asymptomatic proteinuria which was discovered during a urinary screening test when she was three years old. She had no family history of renal or neurological disorders. During the hospitalization, the patient developed nephrotic syndrome and experienced polyuria and polydipsia. Urine tests were conducted and revealed abnormal protein levels. The patient underwent a kidney biopsy, which confirmed a diagnosis of Focal Segmental Glomerular Sclerosis (FSGS). Cystic dilatations of the tubules and interstitial fibrosis were also observed during the biopsy. The patient did not present with any neurological manifestations.

Whole-exome analysis revealed the presence of a novel heterozygous C to A transition in the last exon of TRIM8. Genetic testing confirmed that the variant was de novo and not present in either of the patient's parents. This variant was classified as pathogenic based on the criteria developed by the American College of Medical Genetics and Genomics.

Subsequently, the patient received pre-emptive kidney transplantation from her mother, which was successful. The patient was discharged from the hospital with the patient's primary care physician to monitor the patient's condition closely. No recurrence of proteinuria has been observed post-transplantation.

Conclusion:

The patient was admitted with asymptomatic proteinuria which progressed to nephrotic syndrome. The patient underwent a kidney biopsy which found that the patient had Focal Segmental Glomerular Sclerosis (FSGS) and eventually had pre-emptive kidney transplantation. The patient was discharged with primary care physician follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Sex: Male
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Brief Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with progressive subungual melanosis in the hallux of the right foot lasting more than 4 years. No pseudo-Hutchinson signs were noted during the initial evaluation. After resection, the tumor was pathologically diagnosed as subungual melanocytic nevus, and the defect of the nail matrix was repaired with a lateral toe pulp island flap based on the plantar digital artery. A thorough clinical evaluation and follow-up tests were carried out to monitor the patient's recovery after surgery.

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with subungual melanocytic nevus.

Treatment Provided:

The patient underwent surgical resection of the tumor and subsequent repair of the nail matrix with a lateral toe pulp island flap based on the plantar digital artery. During the postoperative period, the patient was monitored and subjected to a series of follow-up tests.

Patient Condition on Discharge:

The patient was discharged in a stable condition and made a full recovery after surgery.

Follow-Up Plan:

The patient will be recommended to undergo routine follow-up procedures to avoid any potential negative consequences in the future.

Instructions Given at Discharge:

Instructions were given to the patient and their family regarding postoperative care and follow-up procedures.

After surgical resection of the tumor and repair of the nail matrix with a lateral toe pulp island flap, the patient made a full recovery and was discharged in a stable condition.
