Hospital Course Summary:

Patient: 1-year-old boy

Diagnosis: Subungual melanocytic nevus on right index finger

Treatment: Nail plate removal, split-thickness excision of pigmented nail bed lesions, and flattening of residual nail bed

Outcome: Satisfactory 20-month monitoring

Summary:

This 1-year-old male patient was diagnosed with a subungual melanocytic nevus on his right index finger that had been progressively worsening over the course of half a year. To treat this condition, nail plate removal was performed, followed by split-thickness excision of the pigmented lesions on the nail bed while observing under a microscope. The residual nail bed was then flattened for best results.

The patient was monitored for a total of 20 months post-treatment and was found to have a satisfactory outcome. 

In summary, the patient was diagnosed with a subungual melanocytic nevus on the right index finger and treatment was administered by removing the nail plate, excising the pigmented nail bed lesions, and flattening the residual nail bed. The patient was monitored for a 20-month period and had a satisfactory outcome.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: Confidential
Gender: Female
Age: 25 years old
Medical Record Number: Confidential

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital for infertility lasting over a year. A physical examination was conducted and was found to be normal, but computed tomodensitometry (CT) revealed a cyst in the left ovary along with abundant peritoneal ascites indicating mucinous material. Pelvic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) confirmed the presence of ascites and revealed a heterogeneous mass in the left ovary with adipose, solid, and cystic regions similar to a dermoid cyst. The patient underwent surgical intervention by left oophorectomy with appendicectomy and omentectomy without the need for additional hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC) three months after her initial consultation, without complication. The follow-up based on clinical and imaging surveillance revealed no complaints, and the patient was able to pursue her plan of having a child.

Medical History:
The patient had no previous medical history.

Diagnosis:
The histological analysis indicated that the ovarian cyst corresponded to a mature pluritissular teratoma with intermingled skin and pilosebaceous annexes, serous and mucinous glands, respiratory epithelium, adipose tissue, and smooth muscle. A thick muscularis propria was also observed. The area that represented around 20% of the ovarian cyst had the appearance of a colon, comprising colonic mucosa, submucosa, and muscularis mucosae, to the depth. Further pathological studies suggested that the patient was suffering from acellular PMP caused by a ruptured appendiceal-like mucocele accompanied by LAMN, in a left ovarian teratoma.

Treatment:
The patient underwent surgery by left oophorectomy with appendicectomy and omentectomy.

Follow-up:
The follow-up based on clinical and imaging surveillance revealed no complaints.

Hospital Course:
This 45-year-old woman presented to the pulmonary clinic with worsening dyspnea, cough, and hypoxemia. Her medical history was notable for pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, and interstitial lung disease. Dual therapy (tadalafil and macitentan) had been effective for her PAH management. However, her condition worsened 3 months prior to presentation. Her right heart catheterization showed PAH worsening, requiring initiation of subcutaneous treprostinil. Additionally, it was discovered that the patient ingested Necator americanus larvae and other related symptoms started thereafter. The patient was treated with albendazole and corticosteroids for presumptive Löffler’s syndrome, which provided temporary relief. She was admitted to the hospital with progressive hypoxemia, decompensated right heart failure, and worsening pulmonary fibrosis in a pattern consistent with non-specific interstitial pneumonia. The patient experienced refractory hypoxemia and right heart failure despite aggressive medical therapy, including diuresis and treprostinil. The patient was considered for lung transplantation, but it was deemed not feasible due to comorbidities. The patient decided to transition to comfort-focused care and passed away shortly thereafter.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with worsening dyspnea, cough, and hypoxemia due to limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, pulmonary arterial hypertension, and interstitial lung disease. The patient had previously been well-controlled through dual therapy and had been able to wean from oxygen supplementation. However, her condition significantly worsened 3 months prior to her presentation, necessitating subcutaneous treprostinil therapy. The patient disclosed that she had ingested Necator americanus larvae, and treatment for Löffler’s syndrome was initiated shortly thereafter, providing temporary relief. However, the patient’s respiratory status continued to deteriorate despite aggressive medical therapy, including diuresis and treprostinil. The patient was evaluated for lung transplantation but was not considered due to severe esophageal dysmotility and renal dysfunction. The patient elected comfort-focused care and passed away shortly thereafter.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted], Age: 52 years, Sex: Female
Admission Date: [redacted] | Discharge Date: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Recurrent plasmacytoma arising from the anterior elements of C1 and C2 vertebrae

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of dysarthria and was diagnosed with a recurrent plasmacytoma arising from the anterior elements of the C1 and C2 vertebrae. The patient had a history of a similar tumor 16 years ago, which was diagnosed as plasmacytoma at that time. The patient underwent cervical spine fusion and mass reduction surgery, followed by additional radiotherapy. However, the patient dropped out from the treatment course.

During the current admission, the patient underwent excisional biopsy of the tumor, which revealed diffuse proliferation of plasmacytoid tumor cells with pale paranuclear area and dense chromatin. The tumor cells showed dual expression of kappa and lambda light chains. Bone marrow biopsy showed no evidence of plasmacytes showing dual expression or deviation of kappa and lambda light chain. CT and MRI revealed no skeletal abnormality except for the primary lesion, and absence of end-organ damage attributable to proliferative plasma cell disorder.

After diagnosis, the patient underwent nine courses of VRD therapy, which reduced the size of the lesion. The patient's condition improved, and two years after diagnosis, the lesions have not increased in size. Bone marrow examinations have shown no progression to plasma cell myeloma.

Hospital Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition and was advised to follow-up with the oncology clinic regularly. The oncology team provided medication management and other treatment advancements for the patient's diagnosed condition. Further monitoring of the patient's condition, including a follow-up MRI was recommended for future health management.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 19-year-old male, was admitted to the hospital due to severe excretory kidney function decline. Upon physical examination, he presented with dyspnea, lack of appetite, moderate itchiness, and an overall reduced physical condition. He reported a upper respiratory tract infection with persistent fatigue, and experienced pain in his right eye accompanied by redness and blurred vision. An ophthalmological examination led to the diagnosis of anterior uveitis. The initial laboratory tests indicated impaired kidney function and mildly increased parathormone (PTH), C-reactive protein (CRP), haptoglobin, and total serum immunoglobulin-G (IgG). Immune diagnostics revealed positive findings for anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA) titer and anti-La. The patient was diagnosed with tubulointerstitial nephritis with anterior uveitis (TINU) syndrome of no specific or suspected origin.
 
Course in the Hospital:
Upon admission, the patient was started on intravenous glucocorticoids (prednisolone) for three consecutive days, followed by oral prednisolone, and placed on renal replacement therapy (RRT, hemodialysis). The course was complicated by a fever and general weakness that required transfer to the local intensive care unit (ICU). Once in the ICU, a central vein catheter was removed due to localized pain around the insertion area. The patient was continued on oral prednisolone therapy and received intravenous antibiotics (piperacillin and tazobactam) and was subsequently transferred out of the ICU to the general ward. RRT was continued with the establishment of a new central vein catheter. The patient developed generalized rash including moderate itchiness two days after the initial fever attack, which was treated with an adjustment of antibiotic therapy to meropenem. The last dialysis treatment session was performed 1 week before discharge from the hospital, and the kidney excretory function continuously improved, with a last serum creatinine concentration of 214 µmol/l. The ocular manifestation resolved almost completely after local corticosteroid eye drop treatment for 7 days.
 
Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with tubulointerstitial nephritis with anterior uveitis (TINU) syndrome of no specific or suspected origin.
 
Disposition:
The patient was ultimately discharged after a three-week hospital stay. The further management plan was designed to be carried out in the outpatient area.
 
Condition at Discharge:
The patient's kidney excretory function had improved, and the ocular manifestation had almost fully resolved. No plan of follow-up therapy was provided.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Confidential

Patient ID: Confidential

Sex: Female. Age: 61

Admission Date: Confidential

Discharge Date: Confidential

Admitting Diagnosis: Intestinal Behçet’s disease (BD), refractory anemia.

Discharge Diagnosis: Secondary pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (SPAP)

Major medical procedures: Whole lung lavage

Hospital course:
The patient was admitted with a 3-year history of oral aphthae and genital ulcers, which were diagnosed as Intestinal Behçet’s disease (BD). Mesalazine, colchicine, and prednisolone were administered but the symptoms reoccurred upon steroid tapering. A bone marrow examination revealed refractory anemia, and infliximab was initiated as a treatment. She developed secondary pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (SPAP) at the age of 61, with diffuse ground-glass opacities in both lungs. The patient received whole lung lavage to improve respiratory symptoms, and infliximab was continued for the active intestinal BD.

Condition at discharge:
The patient's SPAP symptoms were improved, and she was discharged with the intention to undergo bone marrow transplantation for definitive cure.

Discharge medications:
No medications were prescribed at discharge.

Follow-up instructions:
The patient is advised to continue attending clinical follow-up consultations for further evaluation and management.

Attending physician: Confidential

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 36-year old nulliparous woman, was referred to our tertiary unit at 29+5 weeks of gestation due to fetal cardiomegaly and mild ascites. Upon arrival, the patient was found to have a middle cerebral arterial (MCA) peak systolic velocity (PSV) value above 1.5 Multiples of the Median (MoM). The patient underwent an uncomplicated in utero fetal blood transfusion (IUT) at 30+3 weeks of gestation with pre-transfusion fetal haemoglobin of 4.4 g/dl and post-transfusion fetal haemoglobin of 14.1 g/dl. The MCA-PSV and fetal cardiomegaly improved, but at 35+3 weeks of gestation, the MCA-PSV increased and necessitated another IUT. A second IUT took place with pre-and post-transfusion fetal haemoglobin of 9.7 and 15 g/dl, respectively. The patient was advised regarding the need for delivery and likely need for exchange transfusion in the neonatal period. Delivery of a female infant via caesarean section due to breech presentation was performed at 37+4 weeks. The birth weight was 3150 g, and Apgar scores were 8 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Subsequently, the infant became anaemic requiring regular 3-4 monthly blood transfusions, but she is making good developmental progress.
 
Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with fetus with anemia and heterozygous variant in ALAS2 gene.

Treatment:
The patient underwent two in utero fetal blood transfusions to treat the fetal anemia.

Follow-up:
The patient should continue to be monitored for iron levels to detect the need for chelation therapy in future care plans, since iron toxicity is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in XLSA.

Hospital Course:
A 31-year-old Saudi male presented to the neurology clinic at King Faisal Specialist Hospital and Research Centre in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, complaining of recurrent rhabdomyolysis. The patient had no previous medical history and denied using any medications or herbal agents. He reported smoking one pack of cigarettes a day for 10 years, but denied any alcohol intake or illicit drug use. 
The patient was diagnosed with reversible recurrent rhabdomyolysis after a thorough workup which included a complete medical history, physical examination, and laboratory studies. The underlying cause of his rhabdomyolysis was determined to be his tobacco use; therefore, the patient was advised to quit smoking and avoid exposure to second-hand smoke.
During his hospitalization, the patient received supportive care and was advised on the importance of a healthy lifestyle, including regular physical activity and a balanced diet. He was evaluated by the neurology team with a negative result for any neurological diseases/disorders. The patient was discharged after his condition improved and was advised to follow up with his primary care physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 80 years old
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was an 80-year-old Japanese woman who presented with abdominal pain and bloody stools, 4 months after her first hospital admission for TTS (Takotsubo syndrome) complicated by ischemic enteritis. The patient's examination and tests revealed negative T waves on the electrocardiogram, elevated brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) and troponin I levels, and wall motion abnormality, suggesting the recurrence of TTS. The patient was treated with a small amount of oxygen (2 L/min), 10,000 units/day of continuous intravenous heparin for 2 days to prevent left ventricular thrombosis, and fluid replacement of 1500 mL/day to treat TTS. Although the patient's body weight increased temporarily, the urine volume was normal, oxygenation was stable, and exacerbation of heart failure was not observed. The BNP level also showed a downward trend; hence, diuretics were not administered and hydration was continued. The patient was discharged on the 22nd day, after the differentiation of ischemic heart disease, a coronary angiography, and acetylcholine provocation test showed a significant multivessel coronary spasm in the left coronary artery, leading to coronary vasospastic angina pectoris associated with TTS. The patient was treated using β-blockers, calcium channel blockers, and nicorandil. The patient was also treated in gastroenterology and psychiatry, and was prescribed probiotics and anxiolytics. The patient's ischemic enteritis remained stable without abdominal pain. Subsequent follow-up showed no recurrence of TTS over 3 years.

Discharge Diagnoses:
- Takotsubo Syndrome
- Ischemic Enteritis
- Coronary Vasospastic Angina Pectoris

Discharge Medications:
- β-blockers
- Calcium Channel Blockers
- Nicorandil
- Probiotics
- Anxiolytics

Patient Information:
Name: N/A
Sex: Female
Age: 63

Reason for Hospitalization:
Intermittent epigastric abdominal pain for the past three months. Weight loss of about five kg in the past two months.

Hospital Course:
Patient underwent several tests including physical examination, CA19-9 measurement, pelvic ultrasound, gastroscopy, colonoscopy, and contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the upper abdomen. Results showed chronic non atrophic gastritis, multiple polyps in the large intestine (basically removed), intrahepatic calcifications and a more homogeneous thickening of the gastric wall in the antrum. Patient underwent laparoscopic S7 segmentectomy, during which a brown turbid fluid, a smooth inner wall, and greyish red, greyish yellow, and soft section surfaces of other liver tissues were observed.

Diagnostic Findings:
Contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging showed a long T1 and long T2 cystic signal with a diameter of about 4.7 cm in the right lobe of the liver, high signal intensity on diffusion-weighted imaging sequence, and enhancement of the cyst wall on the enhanced scan. Space-occupying lesion of the right lobe of the liver had been considered to be more likely a hepatic hydatid cyst. On postoperative pathology, a mass was observed immediately adjacent to the liver capsule, with a low-grade mucinous cystic neoplasm (volume 5 × 5 × 4.5 cm) in the S7 segment of the liver.

Treatment:
Patient underwent laparoscopic S7 segmentectomy.

Follow-up:
Patient was discharged in stable condition.

Instructions:
N/A

Summary:
A 63-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital with intermittent epigastric abdominal pain. Patient underwent several tests which revealed a low-grade mucinous cystic neoplasm (volume 5 × 5 × 4.5 cm) in the S7 segment of the liver. The patient underwent laparoscopic S7 segmentectomy and the mass was removed. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary 

Patient: 29-year-old Peruvian male 

Admission Date: [Insert]

Discharge Date: [Insert]

Hospital: [Insert]

Admitting Diagnosis: Chronic cough with haemoptysis, fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, and back pain 

Significant Findings: 

- Chest X-ray demonstrating right-sided apical cavitation with prominent bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy 
- Positive sputum specimen for acid-fast bacilli 
- Moderate fibrosis on chest radiograph consistent with inactive TB following successful treatment 
- History of contact with brother with TB, the causative MTBC agent not identified 

Hospital Course: 

The patient was started on a 4-drug anti-TB antibiotic regimen consisting of rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol for two months. Rifampicin and isoniazid were continued for a further four months. The patient had significant improvement in his symptoms with negative sputum smears after the first month of treatment. Six subsequent sputum smear samples were negative, and a repeat chest radiograph demonstrated right-sided apical fibrous reticular infiltrates consistent with treated inactive TB. The patient was considered to be in remission and remained asymptomatic thereafter. 

Social History: 

The patient shared one bedroom with his wife, son, and parents-in-law and had a history of contact with his brother who had TB. The patient denied any other contact with domestic or wild animals and did not report ingesting unpasteurized dairy products. 

Follow-up: 

The patient should follow up with his primary care physician and continue to monitor his symptoms. It is essential to adhere to the prescribed medication regimen to prevent the recurrence of TB. The patient was educated on infection control measures to prevent the spread of TB to family members and close contacts. 

Discharge Medications: None 

Discharge Status: Discharged 

Discharge Diagnosis: Inactive TB following successful treatment with anti-TB antibiotics 

Discharge Condition: Stable 

Patient and Family Education: 

The patient received education regarding the infection control measures that needed to be implemented to prevent the spread of TB to family members and close contacts. The patient was instructed on the importance of adhering to the prescribed anti-TB medication regimen to prevent the recurrence of the disease. 

Follow-up Appointments: Follow-up with primary care physician 

Primary Care Physician: [Insert]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification: 
The patient is a 64-year-old Peruvian male with a history of tuberculosis (TB).

Hospital Course: 
The patient presented with a productive cough with blood and shortness of breath. His sputum smear was positive for acid-fast bacilli, and a chest radiograph demonstrated apical cavitation of the left upper and middle lung lobe. Treatment with 4-drug regimen for 6 months led to a decrease in the symptoms and negative sputum smears. However, one month after the patient stopped treatment, he deteriorated clinically and had three positive smears. The patient was treated with a second-line anti-TB regimen for 18 months. Despite initial improvements in symptoms, the patient relapsed on second-line therapy and died of respiratory failure in 2012.

Medical History: 
The patient had spent two months visiting family in a region with high density of cattle farms and grazing cows in Peru, though denied consuming unpasteurized dairy products.

Diagnosis: 
The patient was diagnosed with tuberculosis caused by Mycobacterium bovis.

Treatment: 
The patient underwent treatment with both first-line and second-line anti-TB regimens over a total duration of 24 months.

Follow-Up: 
The patient was under clinical surveillance until his death from respiratory failure.

Instructions: 
None specified.

Discharge Medications: 
None specified. 

Attending Provider: 
Unknown.

Hospital Course:
The 2-year-old female patient was admitted to the Neurological department with repeated, prolonged seizures that were only responsive to intravenous injection of diazepam. She was diagnosed with Dravet syndrome (DS) based on the clinical picture and neurological examination. The patient had a history of absence seizure with apnea at the age of 4 months, and prolonged generalized myoclonic seizure with no provoking factors at 5 months. Brain MRI showed periventricular leukomalacia, which was considered as a result of ischemic brain injury, and routine EEG did not show any epileptiform activity in the interictal period. The patient was treated with carbamazepine, topiramate, and clonazepam, but these medications had no effect on seizure frequency and duration. The patient exhibited delayed language development and mild gait ataxia.

Hospital Course Summary:
The 2-year-old female patient presented with a history of repeated, prolonged seizures that were only responsive to intravenous injection of diazepam. The patient was diagnosed with Dravet syndrome (DS) based on the clinical picture and neurological examination. Hospital Course Summary:

Admission: 7-year-old male patient admitted with left knee arthritis and right ankle arthritis, triggered by local trauma. Past medical history revealed odontogenic abscesses and pyoarthritis in the right elbow at age 4 and 5, respectively. Patient underwent arthrotomy with surgical drainage and broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy during both episodes. Magnetic resonance imaging of the left knee showed significant inflammatory arthropathy, radiological reports suggesting focus of incipient osteomyelitis. Target gene panel identified a mutation in PSTPIP1 gene in both the patient and mother.

Hospital Course: Prednisone 1 mg/kg over 3 weeks was administered during the current hospitalization and a satisfactory response to treatment was observed, followed by gradual withdrawal. The patient did not receive anti-IL1 blockers due to unavailability in Brazil. No pyoderma gangrenosum episodes were noted during the 2-year follow-up. The patient will continue to receive genetic counseling and monitoring of symptoms related to PSTPIP1 gene mutation.

Course at Discharge: The patient was discharged with instructions for close follow-up with a pediatric rheumatologist. A comprehensive genetic counseling session was scheduled for the patient and his family to address the potential for hereditary transmission of the PSTPIP1 gene mutation.

Discharge Summary

Patient: Caucasian male, 45 years old, admitted for Gram-positive coccus infection.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with acute worsening of chronic lower back pain and chills. Upon admission, blood cultures were positive for Granulicatella adiacens. The patient did not have any recent history of dental treatment, respiratory infection, or gastrointestinal complaints. The patient was treated with penicillin and gentamicin intravenously for possible endocarditis, but endocarditis was ruled out after transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiograms showed mitral valve insufficiency based on a prolapse, but no vegetation or other echocardiographic signs of infectious endocarditis. Lumbar MRI confirmed vertebral osteomyelitis at discus L2 and L3.

Treatment:
The patient received intravenous penicillin for Granulicatella adiacens osteomyelitis for three weeks, followed by two weeks of oral clindamycin. Clindamycin was chosen for its high bone tissue penetration.

Outcome:
Six weeks after the cessation of antibiotic treatment, the patient had fully recovered. Low inflammation markers and negative follow-up blood cultures supported the patient's recovery.

Recommendations:
The patient should follow up with their gastroenterologist for their Crohn's disease. There should be close monitoring for recurrent infections and pain management for chronic lower back pain.

Discharge Condition:
Stable.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 11 years

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented to the office with a complaint of left knee pain that first occurred 5 years ago after falling off a bike. She had a low level of pain in the knee, which had worsened in the last month with increased soccer activities. The pain was located in the anterior medial aspect of her knee, worsened by running, squatting, kneeling, and climbing stairs. She experienced infrequent effusions with no radiation, numbness, tingling, popping or locking in the affected limb. X-ray results showed an osteochondritis dissecans (OCD) lesion of the lateral trochlear groove, and an MRI was done, which confirmed the diagnosis and stability of the lesion. Nonoperative management of weight-bearing in a locked knee brace for activities of daily living was advised, and the patient followed the treatment regimen. At the 8th week of follow-up, there was occasional pain with mild flexion, and X-ray showed bone formation of the trochlear groove without subchondral collapse or loose bodies. The patient continued in the locked knee brace for an additional 4 weeks. At the 12th week follow-up, the patient was pain-free and taken out of the knee brace. Physical therapy was initiated to strengthen the lower limb, and by the 16th week, the patient regained strength and was participating in soccer drills. The patient was transitioned to a home exercise program, and at the 20th week follow-up, the patient was cleared to resume all activities without complication. 

Summary of Hospitalization:
The patient presented with a known history of left knee pain following a fall from a bike. An x-ray confirmed diagnosis of an osteochondritis dissecans (OCD) lesion of the lateral trochlear groove, and an MRI confirmed the stability of the lesion. The patient was managed with nonoperative measures, including weight-bearing in a locked knee brace for daily activities, and restriction from athletics; followed by physical therapy to regain strength. Comprehensive follow-up and treatment allowed the patient to resume normal activities without complication.

Instructions:
The patient was discharged in good condition with instructions to complete and adhere to the home exercise program initiated during physical therapy to maintain strength and to avoid overuse or further injury. A follow-up appointment was scheduled to reassess the patient's progress at a later date.

Hospital Course:
The patient was a previously healthy 6-year-old girl of northern European descent who presented to the hospital with a grand mal seizure and apnea. Initial physical examination revealed short stature, chronic constipation, and slow growth. Further evaluation revealed primary hypoparathyroidism, Howell-Jolly bodies consistent with autoimmune hyposplenism, and positive serology for adrenal autoimmunity and atrophic gastritis. Genetic testing for AIRE gene variants showed that the patient was a compound heterozygote for 2 known disease-causing variants. She subsequently developed additional autoimmune conditions, including autoimmune hepatitis, Sjögren syndrome antibodies, and patches of alopecia. Methotrexate was initiated and proved effective in regrowing her hair. A bone mineral density study revealed metaphyseal dysplasia. The patient underwent fertility preservation due to low ovarian reserve and achieved a successful outcome. The patient also presented with apparent mineralocorticoid excess and multisystem inflammatory syndrome.

Discharge Summary:
The patient, a 6-year-old female of northern European descent, was admitted to the hospital following a grand mal seizure and apnea. During her hospital course, she was diagnosed with primary hypoparathyroidism, autoimmune hyposplenism, and positive serology for adrenal autoimmunity and atrophic gastritis. She was subsequently found to be compound heterozygote for 2 known disease-causing variants in the AIRE gene. Further, she developed additional autoimmune conditions, including autoimmune hepatitis, Sjögren syndrome antibodies, and patches of alopecia. Methotrexate was initiated and proved effective in regrowing her hair. A bone mineral density study revealed metaphyseal dysplasia. The patient underwent fertility preservation due to low ovarian reserve and achieved a successful outcome. Finally, she presented with apparent mineralocorticoid excess and multisystem inflammatory syndrome, which were managed successfully during her hospital stay. The patient is currently stable and is being monitored closely.

Hospital Course: The patient, a 3-year-old boy, was admitted with severe respiratory distress and tachypnea after an upper respiratory tract infection. He had dyspnea, cough, orthopnea, respiratory rate about 43 /min, and mild plethora. Physical examination revealed a 5 x 4 cm mass on the left supraclavicular area and neck, firm and non-tender. Skin examination revealed multiple café-au-lait spots.

Medical History: The patient is the only child of non-related parents and was born through normal vaginal delivery. He had no developmental delay, but his weight and height were under 3 percentiles of growth. There were no significant findings in his past medical history.

Diagnostic Findings: Laboratory data showed hemoglobin 10.9 g/dL, WBC 13300 /µL, neutrophil 29%, eosinophil 7%, monocyte 8%, lymphocyte 56%, platelet count 262000/µL, urea 21mg/dL, creatinine 0.6 mg/dL, uric acid 3.9 mg/dL, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) 754 U/L. Beta-HCG was 0.66 m IU/ml, and alpha-fetoprotein was 1.01 IU/ml.

Imaging: Chest radiograph showed a large mediastinal mass, and chest CT scan revealed a heterogeneous mass on the left mediastinum with extension from thoracic inlet to the neck. The mass compressed the neck vessels and airway.

Diagnosis: Incisional biopsy was taken from the neck mass, indicating proliferation of spindle cells within wire-like collagen fibrils in loose background, in favor of neurofibromatosis.

Management: Corticosteroids were started because of respiratory distress and superior vena cava syndrome. After three days, the patient became stable enough to be discharged. The patient is to be followed up in the outpatient clinic for ongoing management of his condition.

Condition on Discharge: The patient was discharged in a stable condition, and arrangements were made for outpatient management.

Discharge Summary:

Patient ID: [REDACTED]

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The 7-year old male patient from Miandoab, Iran was admitted to the Shahid Abbasi teaching Hospital with febrile serial generalized tonic-clonic seizures. He was stabilized using bolus doses of phenobarbital and phenytoin, but his consciousness level decreased, necessitating endotracheal intubation and assisted ventilation. He was then transferred to Urmia’s Motahari Hospital. 

Upon evaluation, the patient was suffering from a deep coma, but his vital signs were normal. His pupils were dilated with inadequate response to light, the liver was palpable about 4cm below the costal margin; his muscular tone severely diminished, and deep tendon reflexes were undetectable. Routine laboratory tests revealed nonketotic hypoglycemia and elevated liver enzymes. 

Further investigations were conducted to ascertain the cause of hypoglycemia. The endocrinology consultation ruled out lipid malabsorption, respiratory chain disorder, adrenal insufficiency, hypopituitarism, and hyperinsulinemia. Laboratory tests suggested by our pediatric gastroenterologist to detect the viral or immune cause of hepatitis revealed nothing, and the urine toxicology screening test was negative. 

Further investigation was conducted to rule out inherited inborn errors of metabolism. Dried blood spot samples were sent to a lab in Germany for tandem mass spectrometry, which revealed elevated levels of medium-chain acylcarnitines, consistent with medium-chain acyl-coA dehydrogenase deficiency (MCADD). 

The patient's older male sibling had also passed away five years ago due to similar symptoms, which further strengthened the possibility of MCADD. Unfortunately, the patient died two days after admission due to multiple organ system failures. Molecular genetics verification was impossible due to the patient's death.

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with MCADD, a rare but potentially life-threatening metabolic disorder. This condition is characterized by a deficiency in the enzyme responsible for breaking down medium-chain fatty acids for energy production. The condition can lead to a decreased production of glucose, leading to hypoglycemia and subsequent multiple organ system failures.

Discharge Instructions:

Given the sudden and tragic nature of the patient's passing, there was no opportunity to provide discharge instructions. 

Follow-up Care:

There is no requirement for follow-up care as the patient passed away. 

Signed,
[REDACTED]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 10-year-old girl, was admitted to our center due to lack of balance and urinary incontinence that the patient experienced from three weeks ago. Upon examination, cerebellar tests indicated abnormalities as well as deep tendon reflexes were diminished, and Babinski sign was detected bilaterally.

Further tests performed included brain and cervico-thoraco-lumbar magnetic resonance imaging and Lumbar puncture, which turned out to be normal. Biochemical tests, however, revealed high concentration of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and anemia. Upon examination, elevated mean corpuscular volume (MCV) with hyper segmented neutrophil in peripheral blood smear was noted, and the diagnosis of megaloblastic anemia was established. Consequently, vitamin B12 and folate levels were assessed, and the serum level of vitamin B12 was found to be significantly lower than the normal range, whereas the range of folate was normal.

To rule out various other diseases, gastrointestinal transit evaluation, endoscopy, biopsy, and other specific tests were carried out. Finally, the diagnosis of Imerslund-Gräsbeck syndrome was established owing to the investigations and hematologic and nephrological findings.

The patient was treated with high-dose of vitamin B12 daily injection leading to improved balance. In one-month follow-up, the patient was completely recovered, had no incontinency, however, proteinuria persists.

Hospital Course Summary:

- Admitted due to lack of balance and urinary incontinence.
- Cerebellar tests and physical examination indicated abnormalities.
- Brain and cervico-thoraco-lumbar magnetic resonance imaging and Lumbar puncture were performed, with normal results.
- Biochemical tests revealed high concentration of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and anemia.
- Elevated mean corpuscular volume (MCV) with hyper segmented neutrophil in peripheral blood smear was noted, and the diagnosis of megaloblastic anemia was established.
- Fibroptic evaluation, endoscopy, biopsy, and other specific tests were carried out to rule out various diseases.
- The diagnosis of Imerslund-Gräsbeck syndrome was established owing to the investigations and hematologic and nephrological findings.
- The patient was treated with high-dose of vitamin B12 daily injection.
- The patient was completely recovered, had no incontinency, however, proteinuria persists.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 22
Gender: Male
Admitted: [REDACTED]
Discharged: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 22-year-old male, was admitted to the Department of Emergency Medicine with complaints of sudden onset right flank pain and gross hematuria. Vitals were within normal limits. Urine microscopy demonstrated multiple red blood cells suggesting hematuria. After being referred to the Department of Radiology, the patient was diagnosed with a well-circumscribed, heteroechoic, cortical based lesion located in the upper pole of the right kidney. The patient was then referred to the Department of Urology and underwent laparoscopic partial nephrectomy of the right kidney and tumor resection. The resection margins were free of tumor, and there was no evidence of perinephric invasion or lymphadenopathy. Furthermore, a well-defined heteroechoic mass was noted at the dependent portion of the urinary bladder leading to a diagnosis of giant retained clot. The patient was catheterized, and urinary bladder irrigation with clot retraction was performed. The patient recovered well with no complications and was discharged home seven days post-surgery. At 3-month follow-up, the patient was free of symptoms and had no signs of recurrence.

Diagnosis:
Renal oncocytoma with symptomatic hematuria leading to giant clot retention in the urinary bladder.

Procedure:
Laparoscopic partial nephrectomy of the right kidney and tumor resection.

Follow-Up:
At 3-month follow-up, the patient was free of symptoms and had no signs of recurrence.

Conclusion:
The patient was admitted with complaints of sudden onset right flank pain and gross hematuria. After being diagnosed with renal oncocytoma and giant retained clot, the patient successfully underwent laparoscopic partial nephrectomy and tumor resection. The patient was discharged with no complications and was doing well at 3-month follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Patient Name]
Age: 50 years
Sex: Male
Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with complaints of hematuria, increased frequency, and burning sensation during micturition, accompanied by left flank pain. He had a history of generalized weakness, weight loss, and loss of appetite over the past two months. On examination, a palpable left-sided abdominal mass was detected. The ultrasound of the abdomen showed the presence of a right ectopic kidney and left-sided hydronephrosis. The contrast-enhanced computerized tomography (CECT) of the abdomen revealed L-shaped crossed fused renal ectopia, a left-sided renal mass, and a polypoidal mass in the urinary bladder. 

The patient underwent a transurethral resection of the bladder lesion, which showed noninvasive papillary urothelial carcinoma. The previous diagnosis of multifocal transitional cell carcinoma, renal cell carcinoma (RCC)- mucinous adenocarcinoma variant with multifocal spread, and renal sarcoma was ruled out.

The patient then underwent surgery for resection of the renal mass, and a left nephrectomy with partial right nephrectomy was also performed. Post-operative results showed that the capsule was intact, and the patient had an uneventful recovery.

The patient was discharged after an appropriate follow-up and was advised to come for regular check-ups.

Hospital Discharge Diagnosis:

Primary chondrosarcoma in crossed fused renal ectopia involving both moieties.

Significant Findings:

- Ultrasound of the abdomen showed the presence of a right ectopic kidney and left-sided hydronephrosis.
- CECT of the abdomen revealed L-shaped crossed fused renal ectopia, a left-sided renal mass, and a polypoidal mass in the urinary bladder.
- Histopathology examination showed chondrosarcoma, marked pleomorphism and mitotic activity along with areas of chicken-wire calcification and hemorrhage.

Treatment Provided:

- Transurethral resection of the bladder lesion.
- Surgery for resection of the malignant renal mass, and a left nephrectomy with partial right nephrectomy was performed.

Medical Condition at Discharge:

The patient’s condition was stable at the time of discharge.

Follow-up Care:

The patient was advised to come back for regular check-ups.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not provided
Medical Record Number: Not provided

Admission Date: Not provided
Discharge Date: Not provided
Length of Stay: Not provided

Diagnosis:
-Multi-system inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C)

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 25-month-old boy, was admitted to Mofid Children's Hospital with fever and maculopapular rashes spreading from his feet to his thighs and genital area. Despite taking antihistamines, the fever and rashes persisted along with poor feeding, mucosal involvement of the mouth, lips, and conjunctiva, and ulcer and bulla formation. Upon arrival, his vital signs revealed a temperature of 39.5°C, blood pressure of 82/10 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28, and pulse rate of 86. The patient was diagnosed with Stevens-Johnson Syndrome/Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (SJS/TEN) due to blistered skin lesions and mucosal involvement, and received supportive care, steroids, and intravenous immune globin (IVIG). During admission, laboratory work up and a COVID-19 PCR test were performed, which revealed low white blood cells count with an abnormal differential count, low platelet count, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) levels, and elevated ferritin and fibrinogen levels, along with a positive COVID-19 PCR test result. Chest CT scan showed no abnormalities. Based on the patient's clinical condition, laboratory findings, and positive COVID-19 PCR test, he was diagnosed with Multi-system inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C) and was administered atazanavir.

Treatment:
-Supportive care
-Steroids
-Intravenous immune globin (IVIG)
-Atazanavir

Outcome:
The patient's fever subsided, and he was able to eat and drink. After four days, he was discharged from the hospital with minimal skin lesions and a normal condition. A one-week follow-up indicated that the patient's laboratory test results were within normal ranges, and his condition was stable.

Recommendation:
-The patient should continue all prescribed medications and follow-up with his primary care physician.

Discharge Condition:
Stable.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- A 53-year-old female with a history of lumbar disc herniation

Admission:
- Presented to the clinic with waist and back pain, and numbness of lower limbs for over 1 month
- CT of chest revealed scattered pulmonary nodules with calcifications associated with a soft tissue mass measuring 3.3 cm × 2.4 cm and without pleural thickening at the superior lobe of the right lung
- Enlarged lymph nodes of the right hilar evident
- Abdominal contrast-enhanced CT revealed diffuse lesions with massive calcifications in the liver, which shows faint peripheral enhancement in the arterial phase and low enhancement in the portal phase
- Osteolytic lesions with a massive thick sclerotic rim in the right second rib, 11th thoracic vertebra, and first lumbar spine observed on CT examination
- Bone scintigraphy showed multiple hypermetabolic activities in the involved bones
- Cerebral MRI revealed no anomalies
- Transthoracic needle biopsy of the largest pulmonary lesion located in the right superior lobe showed epithelioid cells arranged in a glandular pattern with clear cytoplasm
- Immunohistochemical staining showed that the neoplastic cells were positive for CD31, CD34, CAMTA1, and EMA, but negative for ERG, TFE3, PCK, and desmin, with a Ki-67 index rate of 10%
- Histopathological examination indicated a rare low-grade malignant vascular neoplasm, confirming the diagnosis of EHE

Treatment:
- 4 cycles of chemotherapy with paclitaxel liposome and carboplatin administered over 8 months
- No changes in disease status observed on CT at the 8-month follow-up visit

Follow-up:
- Follow-up appointments recommended as per the treating physician's instructions

Discharge Planning:
- No further hospitalization needed at this time
- The patient was advised to continue with prescribed medications, maintain regular follow-up appointments, and to seek medical attention in case of any new or worsening symptoms
- Patient education provided regarding EHE and its management

Medical Team:
- Primary care physician
- Oncologist
- Radiologist
- Pathologist
- Clinical Nurse Specialist

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Janice

Medical Record Number: 123456

DOB: January 1, 1935

Admission Date: ___________

Discharge Date: ___________

Hospital Course Summary:

Janice, an 85-year-old female with mild dementia, was admitted for ongoing care due to her worsening health and function related to her progressing dementia. During the hospital stay, she was evaluated for her physical and mental capabilities, which revealed a decline in her function. She had difficulty with short and long term memory and had problems with orientation. She was able to perform basic activities of daily living but had difficulty with complex tasks and planning. The patient received care from Gwen, her daughter and primary caregiver, who also reported that Janice had developed paranoia and visual hallucinations. She experienced weight loss due to stopping cooking and relying on microwave-ready meals and easy snacks. Janice had incontinence issues, occasional bowel incontinence, her pericare had declined, and she suffered from bilateral hearing loss.

Family and social history revealed that Janice has limited finances, is widowed for 20 years, and relies on her children to assist with her finances. Her daughter Gwen was her primary caregiver, and during the hospital stay, showed signs of caregiver stress. The patient is fond of her belongings and wishes to remain independent. She does not want to leave her home and has promised Gwen not to be relocated to a nursing home. She acknowledges the support provided by her daughter but is not empathic towards her stress.

Discharge Instructions:

1. Continue with current medications.
2. Hand hygiene and general hygienic care is advised.
3. Ensure that she is monitored for any signs of cognitive decline.
4. Allow proper ventilation within the residential area.
5. Provide appropriate support to Janice to manage her incontinence issues.
6. Ensure that all her belongings, including her paintings and collectibles, are retained without damage.
7. Arrange ongoing care from home-care providers to help with complex tasks and planning as well as medication reminders.
8. Encourage communication with the daughter Gwen to monitor how she is handling the burden of caregiver stress.  Consider connecting her to a local caregiver support group. 

Follow-up Instructions:

1. Schedule a follow-up appointment with primary care provider.
2. Schedule an appointment with an audiologist for hearing aid adjustment. 
3. Schedule a follow-up visit with geriatrician to monitor patients' health and well-being and evaluate compliance with the care plan.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:
A 58-year-old female patient presented with a large recurrent ventral hernia. The patient previously underwent a simple repair operation for an umbilical hernia six years ago, without a mesh. She had a history of morbid obesity, COPD, and was an active smoker. During hospitalization at the gastroenterology department, a diagnostic workup was performed due to the patient's clinical picture of chronic small bowel obstruction. The patient complained of frequent abdominal cramps, swelling, and pain in the area of the hernia. The physical examination showed a large irreducible ventral hernia in the lower abdomen, which was quite painful on palpation and without signs of incarceration or strangulation at that time. The surgeon opted for semielective surgery, considering the clinical picture with threatening hernia incarceration.

An operative procedure was performed, and hernial content consisting of the greater omentum, part of the transverse colon, and a cluster of small bowel loops with signs of chronic obstruction were found. After adhesiolysis, the hernial defect was revealed, measuring about 7 cm in diameter and about 15 cm in the vertical line with significant rectus diastase in the supraumbilical part of the abdomen. The Rives-Stoppa technique was used to create a wide retromuscular space, and a 30 × 25 cm polypropylene mesh was placed in the retromuscular space to ensure adequate mesh overlap over the edges of the hernia defect.

During the operative procedure, the surgeon opted for rectus mobilization by the ACS method to avoid bridging, considering the anterior fascia's decreased abdominal wall elasticity. Four redon drains were placed postoperatively. The postoperative course was complicated by skin ischemia, requiring necrosectomy to remove the skin's necrotic foci. Primary wound closure was performed, and negative pressure wound therapy with the “Renasis Ez Max VAC® system” was initiated after inflammation subsided. After two months of NPWT administration, wound closure was achieved in 7 months, with the patient continuing regular changing of silver-impregnated antimicrobial wound dressing in ambulatory care.

Diagnoses/Treatment:
Large recurrent ventral hernia
COPD
Morbid obesity
Preoperative diagnostic workup for chronic small bowel obstruction
Operative procedure: Rives-Stoppa technique and rectus mobilization by the ACS method
Negative pressure wound therapy with the “Renasis Ez Max VAC® system”

Condition at Discharge: 
The patient's condition upon discharge is fair, with complete wound closure achieved. Regular changing of silver-impregnated antimicrobial wound dressing was continued in ambulatory care.

Follow-up Plans: 
The patient will schedule a follow-up appointment with the surgeon for a routine check-up and wound care.

Hospital Course:

This 16-year-old male patient was admitted to our institution for hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) due to Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL) and DOCK8 deficiency. He was homozygous for the DOCK8 variant NM_203447.3:c.4153+1G>A. Prior to HSCT, the patient experienced complications from chemotherapy-associated grade III BKV-HC managed with cidofovir and third-party donor-derived quadrivalent anti-cytomegalovirus (CMV), -Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), -adenovirus (ADV), and -BK virus specific T-cells (VSTs).

Following HSCT, the patient's course was complicated by gross hematuria, acute kidney injury (AKI), and hydroureter/hydronephrosis. Despite interventions such as bilateral nephrostomy tube placement and coil embolization, bleeding persisted and the patient required regular blood transfusions. Weight gain, fluid retention, and hematologic complications further complicated his course.
