Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 77
Gender: Male

Medical History:
The patient had a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). The patient also had severe aortic stenosis (AS) and received transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR).

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent TAVR with a 29mm Edwards Sapien 3 valve and had an uneventful recovery. One year later, the patient suffered from worsening heart failure with pulmonary edema. The patient was diagnosed with new-onset atrial fibrillation (Af) and experienced increasing mean transcatheter heart valve (THV) pressure gradient. Response to standard heart failure treatment was poor. A CT scan revealed HALT and RLM. 

Treatment:
The patient was prescribed a non-vitamin K antagonist oral anticoagulant (NOAC), rivaroxaban, for the new-onset Af and leaflet thrombosis. Follow-up revealed a continuous drop in the THV pressure gradient, MR, and PH with rehabilitation using diuretics. The HALT and RLM were resolved with NOAC treatment.

Outcome:
Heart failure symptoms improved gradually, but atrial fibrillation persisted. The patient had an episode of upper gastrointestinal bleeding after concomitant use of clopidogrel and rivaroxaban. The patient received a therapeutic endoscope, proton pump inhibitors, and blood transfusions for stopping gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient discontinued clopidogrel but kept on using rivaroxaban. The patient was free of heart failure symptoms and bleeding events thereafter.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged and advised to continue with anti-coagulants, monitor closely at regular intervals, and follow up on a regular basis with a cardiologist.

Follow-up:
The patient was instructed to follow up with a cardiologist regularly and have a comprehensive blood test to monitor conditions and receive appropriate counseling if necessary. The patient's medical history and treatment were thoroughly documented and available to all healthcare providers in EHR.

[Patient Name] was admitted for diarrhea, vomiting and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) following the administration of nivolumab. Physical examination revealed a pleural effusion and normal abdomen. Biologically, he had normal plasmatic values and negative stool cultures. Endoscopic evaluation via ileocolonoscopy and EGD were performed and biopsies were obtained. Results revealed that he had celiac disease (CeD) induced by immune checkpoint inhibitors and an inflamed duodenum with diffuse superficial ulcerations. The patient was subsequently treated with proton pump inhibitors, methylprednisolone, and a gluten-free diet. Nivolumab was discontinued and the patient was discharged following an improvement in symptoms, with plans for a control EGD in 6 months and lifelong adherence to a gluten-free diet. In an oncological perspective, the patient has had stable disease for 7 months post-infusion without requiring additional systemic treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient:

 A 78-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune hepatitis and hypothyroidism.

Admission:

Patient presented to the hospital via emergency medical services with left arm weakness and jerky movements that were witnessed by family members while she was eating. No recent trauma or fall.

Hospital Course:

Upon evaluation, she was diagnosed with left temporoparietal intraparenchymal hemorrhage, right frontal sulcal subarachnoid hemorrhage, and left parietal sulcal subarachnoid hemorrhage. Vessel images revealed extensive venous sinus thrombosis involving superior sagittal sinus, bilateral transverse, and sigmoid sinuses. Patient was started on levetiracetam for symptomatic treatment of focal seizures with left upper extremity shaking. Anticoagulation therapy with heparin drip was initiated. After a multidisciplinary team discussion, patient underwent a successful mechanical venous thrombectomy using the INARI FlowTriever system with large clot burden extracted. She remained clinically stable after the procedure. During the 3-months follow-up, MRI brain with and without contrast revealed near complete resolution of the clot burden in superior sagittal sinus and left transverse-sigmoid complex.

Treatment:

Patient was started on levetiracetam for symptomatic treatment of focal seizures with left upper extremity shaking. Anticoagulation therapy with heparin drip was initiated. Novel oral anticoagulation was switched prior to discharge.

Condition at Discharge:

Patient's left upper extremity weakness improved at day 5. Her 3 months modified Rankin score was at 0.

Follow-up:

Patient was resumed on apixaban for 12 months with follow-up brain magnetic resonance venogram planned.

Summary:

Patient's presentation with left arm weakness and jerky movements led to the diagnosis of extensive venous sinus thrombosis involving superior sagittal sinus, bilateral transverse and sigmoid sinuses, which was successfully treated with mechanical venous thrombectomy. Patient remained clinically stable during hospitalization and improved significantly at discharge with near complete resolution of the clot burden. Patient was recommended for follow-up treatment with apixaban and brain magnetic resonance venogram testing.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 44-year-old male with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted for induction chemotherapy (IC) on day 0 and experienced bone marrow suppression with fever and septic shock on day 10. Broad-spectrum antibacterial and antifungal prophylaxis were used empirically, with little success in controlling the patient's recurrent fever. The patient then experienced hemiplegia and hemiconvulsions on the right limb and was diagnosed with cerebral infarction in the right parietal lobe and small hypodense areas in the left and right parietal lobes. CT scans also showed multiple hyperdense lesions in the patient's lung on day 18. After a positive result for the test of (1,3)- β-D-glucan on day 22, treatment was changed to voriconazole (VRC) and imipenem, but the patient's fever persisted and the lesions in the brain and lung worsened.

On day 25, Rhizomucor miehei infection was shown by metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) of peripheral blood (PB) with high relative abundance, and liposome-associated amphotericin B was administered as antifungal therapy. The patient's fever subsided, and his complete blood count (CBC) returned to normal on day 28. Infection with Rhizomucor miehei was also detected by mNGS findings in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) on day 28 and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) on day 35. Antifungal therapy using liposome-associated amphotericin B was continued until day 55, and the patient's general condition improved, with partial recovery of the right limb function.

After discharge, the patient continued antifungal therapy with amphotericin B and posaconazole for 2 months and received a new chemotherapy for ALL. Follow-up imaging tests showed a significant reduction in the size of the lesions. The antifungal drug regimen was well-tolerated and achieved a remarkable effect. 

Important Findings:

The patient had a series of infections caused by Rhizomucor miehei, which were detected by mNGS findings. The antifungal therapy using liposome-associated amphotericin B was an effective treatment for the patient's condition. The recurrence of fever in febrile neutropenia patients after chemotherapy with cerebral symptoms may be highly indicative of infections in the brain.

Disposition:

The patient was discharged and requested to continue antifungal therapy at a local hospital due to family reasons.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 2 years old
Gender: Male

Medical History:
The patient presented to our pediatric emergency department with acute unilateral sixth nerve palsy. The patient had a medical history that was unremarkable for chronic diseases and did not take any regular medication. The vaccination status was complete according to national recommendations.

Hospital Course:
The patient experienced a sudden dysfunction of lateral movement of his left eye and was diagnosed with left abducens nerve palsy. The cranial magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed an hypoplastic left abducens nerve and atrophy of the corresponding left lateral rectus muscle compared to the contralateral side. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis yielded no oligoclonal bands, normal routine CSF laboratory parameters, and negative results from multiplex-PCR for several viruses.

The Real-time reverse transcriptase PCR (rRT-PCR) test for SARS-CoV-2 from oropharyngeal swab sample was negative on admission, while Serology detected positive for SARS-CoV-2 anti-spike IgG in the patient's serum and CSF. Pathogen-specific antibody index as an indicator for potential intrathecal antibody production was negative, suggesting involvement of central nervous system being secondary to systemic infection rather than direct viral infection.

Diagnosis:
Post-infectious abducens nerve palsy secondary to SARS-CoV-2 infection.

Treatment:
No therapeutic measures were taken during the inpatient stay. The patient showed spontaneous mild improvement, and three months following the onset of abducens nerve palsy, the family noticed a distinct improvement in eye movement, and the child made a full recovery 2 weeks later.

Follow-up Plans:
The patient was regularly seen for ophthalmologic follow-ups after discharge.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Admission: September 2018
Date of Discharge: N/A

History of Present Illness:
The patient, a 42-year-old Chinese man, presented to the outpatient clinic complaining of right ear discharge accompanied by discomfort for 3 years. The patient had a history of seawater contact and noticed a small volume of clear drainage from both ears. As the condition progressed, the drainage from the left ear vanished and the drainage from the right ear increased and became a thick, purulent exudate containing debris. The ear canal became obstructed by the thick excretion, which caused the patient to experience mild hearing loss, coupled with intermittent tinnitus, and a sensation of ear fullness. The patient did not use any medications to relieve symptoms, but instead removed debris from the right ear using cotton swabs, which resulted in a return to normal hearing and relief of symptoms. Within a few days, new thick drainage would obstruct the ear canal causing the symptoms to reappear. The patient sought health care twice at local hospitals in Xi’an City from Shaanxi Province; however, the underlying illness remained unidentified and did not improve. The discharge from the right ear gradually reduced and turned from brown to white until March 2018, when a low-concentration hydrogen peroxide solution was used to rinse the right ear canal at a local hospital.

Past Medical History:
The patient denied any history of infectious diseases, diabetes, or any immunocompromising condition.

Physical Exam:
The patient underwent audiometric and otoscopic examinations as well as radiological examinations using computed tomography imaging to examine the temporal bone. The exudate was collected from his right ear using a sterile swab and was transferred to the clinical microbiology laboratory for examination.

Diagnostic Studies:
The exudate from the right ear was analyzed by the clinical microbiology laboratory. All specimen processing and bacteriological analysis procedures were performed with approval from the ethics committee. The patient provided written informed consent prior to participation in this project.

Assessment and Plan:
The underlying illness causing the right ear discharge and discomfort was not identified, despite seeking health care twice at local hospitals prior to presentation at our clinic. Further testing and evaluation will be needed to determine the cause of the patient's symptoms. 

Summary:
The patient presents with a history of right ear discharge and discomfort for 3 years, which was not resolved after seeking health care twice at local hospitals prior to presentation at our clinic. The patient has no history of infectious diseases, diabetes, or any immunocompromising condition. The exudate from the right ear was analyzed by the clinical microbiology laboratory to determine the underlying cause of the symptoms. Further testing and evaluation will be needed to determine the underlying illness.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [CONFIDENTIAL]

Age: 52

Sex: Female

Date of Admission: [CONFIDENTIAL]

Date of Discharge: [CONFIDENTIAL]

Admission Diagnosis: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 52-year-old woman who was diagnosed with SLE eight years ago. She was admitted to the hospital with elevated ANA levels and mild clinical symptoms such as oral ulcers, urticarial vasculitis lesions, and joint pain. Her pharmacologic treatment lasted three years and consisted of steroids in combination with other non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medication. The patient did not tolerate antimalarials, and she refused further immune suppressive therapy.

During regular check-ups between the first diagnosis and admission, the patient had minor clinical disease manifestations related to SLE such as oral ulcers, urticarial vasculitis lesions, joint pain, fatigue, tiredness, and fever. These symptoms did not require steroidal or immunosuppressive drug therapy and were treated symptomatically.

At admission, the patient's ANA was elevated with the mild clinical symptoms mentioned earlier, which did not require steroid treatment. During her hospital stay, she received supportive care and counseling, and her symptoms improved. The patient was discharged from the hospital with instructions to continue symptomatic treatment and regular follow-up appointments.

Discharge Diagnosis: SLE

Outcome and Plan: The patient's symptoms improved during her hospital stay, and she was discharged home with instructions to continue symptomatic treatment and regular follow-up appointments. The patient should continue to monitor her ANA levels and report any new or worsening symptoms to her healthcare provider.

Patient Information:
This is a discharge summary for a 60-year-old female patient with a continuously enlarged neck mass, hoarseness, and dyspnea, who underwent surgery for a thyroid tumor.

Hospital Course:
The patient was diagnosed with a thyroid tumor that invaded the anterior cervical muscle group and left recurrent laryngeal nerve. She underwent en bloc resection and left central lymph node dissection to remove the affected tissue. Postoperative histopathological findings revealed that SaPC widely invaded the ipsilateral thyroid, and 1/6 of the lymph nodes showed metastasis.

The patient recovered postoperatively, but experienced progressively aggravating dyspnea and a gradually growing neck mass three months later. Clinical examinations suggested regional relapse and multiple pulmonary metastases. Enhanced MRI showed extensive local organ and tissue invasion by the recurred tumor.

The patient ultimately decided to discontinue medical treatments.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Thyroid tumor with extensive local organ and tissue invasion, pulmonary metastasis, and relapse.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient should continue follow-up with their primary care physician for ongoing care. Further treatment options can be discussed if desired.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 75-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease and Enterococcus faecalis bacteremia, was admitted to our hospital for subacute functional decline and encephalopathy. On admission, he had a leukocytosis and bilateral pleural effusions. Imaging and testing revealed left ventricular and right ventricular systolic dysfunction, mild pulmonary hypertension, and no visible valvular vegetations. Thoracentesis of the patient's pleural effusions identified Enterococcus faecalis growth, leading to the performance of a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE).

During the TEE procedure performed on hospital day nine, the patient received 70 mg of propofol administered over the first ten minutes of the procedure. The patient's blood pressure dropped precipitously, and he experienced a PEA cardiac arrest. After four rounds of chest compressions and epinephrine administration, the patient achieved ROSC. However, the patient's cardiac rhythm deteriorated into ventricular fibrillation, which required defibrillation and further chest compressions. ROSC was achieved again, and the patient was transferred to the intensive care unit.

Upon review of the TEE images, it was noted that the patient's RV was severely dilated with minimal contractile function, and a small pericardial effusion was found. Due to the critical nature of the patient's condition, comfort measures were implemented, and the patient's family opted for transition to end-of-life care. 

Discharge Instructions:

The patient has been discharged to hospice care. Due to his end-stage renal disease and critical condition, it is not appropriate to provide further medical therapy. Comfort measures and end-of-life care will be provided in this setting. The patient's family has been informed about his condition, and they have agreed to this course of action.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: TS Tsai
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
TS Tsai, a 48-year-old man, was admitted to the hospital after being bitten on the right palm near the base of the index finger by a snake. The patient had visited a local hospital 30 minutes after the snakebite and had received monovalent antivenom for D. siamensis at the emergency department within 1 hour of the bite. However, the swelling and redness had progressed to the wrist approximately 9 hours after the bite. Therefore, the patient received 4 more vials of antivenom, for a total of 8 vials within 10 hours. Blood tests showed acute kidney injury, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and coagulopathy. No leukocytosis or anemia was observed, and antibiotics were prescribed.

On admission, TS Tsai's right hand showed the most obvious swelling and pain for the first 2-3 days. The swelling and pain extended to the right elbow, and the patient's fingers were almost unable to bend. Ice pillow packing was used to relieve the pain, local heat, and swelling. Fortunately, there were no blisters, hemorrhagic bullae, or finger ischemia. The patient received two courses of hyperbaric oxygen treatment on days 3 and 4, and the swelling of the hand quickly subsided after that. The patient's fingers were able to bend slightly on the third night and were able to bend more than 90° on day 4.

During hospitalization, the patient's daily stool was soft or fluid and dark blue-green but not black, whereas the urine color was normal. The patient was discharged from the hospital on day 5.

Follow-up:
On day 8 after the discharge, TS Tsai reported to experience a large area of elevated red skin rash and itching of the body at home. After administration of antihistamines, the symptoms disappeared. The patient still sometimes experienced mild numbness and painful sensations at the bite site for up to one month after the snake envenomation.

Signatures:
Primary Care Physician: [REDACTED]
Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 41-year-old female, presented with chest pain two hours prior to admission. The pain was dull, left sided, substernal, and radiated to her left arm. Upon arrival, an ECG showed 1mm ST elevations in inferior leads. The patient was taken to the Cath Lab for an emergent coronary angiogram where a saddle clot in the distal left main artery, left circumflex, and proximal LAD was discovered. The patient was started on acute coronary syndrome treatment and admitted to the cardiac care unit. Over the course of the hospital stay, troponin levels peaked at 11ng/mL, and the patient received 2 units of PRBC due to persistent vaginal bleeding. Thrombophilia testing was performed, and placement of an IUD was recommended by the OBGYN team. After 48 hours, heparin was discontinued, and the patient's EKG showed resolution of ST elevations prior to discharge.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient presented with chest pain and was diagnosed with a saddle clot in the distal left main artery, left circumflex, and proximal LAD. She was treated with acute coronary syndrome treatment and admitted to the cardiac care unit. During her stay, she received two units of PRBC due to persistent vaginal bleeding. Thrombophilia testing was performed, and placement of an IUD was recommended by the OBGYN team. Heparin was discontinued after 48 hours, and the patient's EKG showed resolution of ST elevations prior to discharge.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: N/A
DOB: 01/01/1990
Date of Discharge: N/A (Hospitalized but discharged to psychiatric hospital)

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient is a 29-year-old male with a history of alcohol abuse and treatment-resistant schizoaffective disorder. He presented to our facility from a psychiatric hospital with chest pain and troponin elevation after recently initiating clozapine therapy. He had a history of multiple suicide attempts and was hospitalized for intensive treatment, including initiation of clozapine therapy. 

Upon admission, the patient complained of substernal chest pain that worsened with deep inspiration. His electrocardiogram showed ST elevations most prominent in V2-V3. The patient's serum labs were notable for leukocytosis and elevated troponin, brain natriuretic peptide, and inflammatory markers. The patient was transferred to the cardiology service and cardiorespiratory examination was within normal limits.

Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) imaging showed global hypokinesis with a left ventricular ejection fraction (EF) of 45%. He was diagnosed with myopericarditis, likely drug-induced. The respiratory viral panel was negative. Clozapine was discontinued, and he was started on metoprolol, colchicine, and ibuprofen to manage impaired LV function and pericarditis. Repeat EKG revealed resolution of ST-elevation and no arrhythmic events on telemetry. The patient was discharged back to the psychiatric hospital with planned cardiology follow-up for echocardiogram and repeat laboratory testing.

DIAGNOSES:
1. Myopericarditis, likely drug-induced
2. Treatment-resistant schizoaffective disorder
3. Alcohol abuse

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient is advised to follow up with his primary care provider or cardiology team for further evaluation and management regarding potential cardiac involvement associated with clozapine therapy. He is recommended to avoid alcohol use and comply with prescribed medications and psychiatric treatments. Patient education was provided regarding healthy lifestyle choices and symptom management to prevent future exacerbations of myopericarditis. 

FOLLOW-UP PLANS:
Follow-up with primary care provider or cardiology team for echocardiogram and repeat laboratory testing.

SINCERELY,
Dr. [Last Name], MD

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 60-year-old male, was admitted with sudden left leg pain in L4 nerve root area. He demonstrated neurogenic paralysis on left quadriceps femoris muscle with manual muscle testing 3, hyporeflexia on left patella tendon, and positive left straight leg raising test. MR images revealed left L4-5 foraminal herniated disc without a fragment in the spinal canal. Left L4 selective nerve root block remarkably affected the patient. He was diagnosed with left L4 nerve root entrapment by left L4-5 foraminal disc herniation.

Diagnosis:

Left L4 nerve root entrapment by left L4-5 foraminal disc herniation.

Treatment:

The patient underwent discography for presurgical imaging diagnosis. Herniotomy was performed by osteoplastic approach. Observing the neural foramen, the herniated disc fragment was migrated from the neural foramen to cranial central canal. A 2.5 g-weighted disc fragment with annulus fibrosus was extirpated with one piece. 

Outcome:

After surgery, the patient's neurological status was fully recovered immediately. 

Discharge Instructions:

The patient is advised to take proper rest and avoid any strenuous physical activity. He is also advised to follow up with his primary care provider for further evaluation.

DETAILED DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: N/A
MRN: N/A
Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A
Admitting Diagnosis: N/A
Discharge Diagnosis: Herniated fragment migrated from neural foramen to cranial central canal with no neurological deficit.

Hospital Course:

- Patient presented with right leg pain in L4 nerve root area
- Previous clinic diagnosed right L4-5 foraminal disc herniation, and treated with a disc block procedure
- Patient experienced worsening of right leg pain after the procedure
- Patient was admitted to our facility and MR images revealed a herniated fragment that had migrated from the neural foramen to the cranial central canal
- Transforaminal lumbar interbody fusion with right L4-5 facetectomy was performed to remove the herniated fragment
- Post-operative course was unremarkable
- No neurological deficit was observed
- Patient was discharged in stable condition

Summary:

A 74-year-old male presented with right leg pain in the L4 nerve root area. Previous clinic diagnosed right L4-5 foraminal disc herniation, and the patient was treated with a disc block procedure. The patient reported worsening of right leg pain after the procedure and was admitted to our facility. MR images revealed that the herniated fragment had migrated from the neural foramen to the cranial central canal. Transforaminal lumbar interbody fusion with right L4-5 facetectomy was performed to remove the herniated fragment. No neurological deficit was observed, and the post-operative course was unremarkable. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Gender: Male
Age: 65
Hospital Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]
Diagnosis: Poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma
Procedures Performed: Right posterolateral thoracotomy, double sleeve lobectomy of right upper and middle lobes, systematic mediastinal lymph node dissection, resection of the superior vena cava (SVC) with interposition of a ringed graft of 12mm in diameter, reconstruction of right pulmonary artery (PA) trunk and right lower PA

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our department for a continuous irritable cough over 15 days and was diagnosed with poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma by transbronchial tumor biopsy. The tumor was located in the right upper lobe and directly invaded the arch of the right PA, a wide range of SVC and the left brachiocephalic vein. Magnetic resonance imaging, CT scan and bone nuclear scans revealed no detectable metastases in other organs.

A right posterolateral thoracotomy was performed, with resection of the tumor and SVC, and reconstruction of the right PA trunk and right lower PA. The left brachiocephalic vein bifurcation was not observed. A ringed graft of 12mm in diameter was interpositioned between the right brachiocephalic vein and the origin of the SVC. The double sleeve lobectomy of right upper and middle lobes was performed, followed by systematic mediastinal lymph node dissection. 

Postoperatively, the patient was given low molecular heparin on the operative day and switched to warfarin when thoracic drains were removed. The patient recovered in an uneventful manner and was discharged from the hospital on the 12th postoperative day.

Follow-up:

After 4 cycles of chemotherapy (Gemzar and cisplatin) and 1 cycle of radiotherapy, chest MRI showed patency of the graft and PLSVC. The patient died 21 months after the operation due to remote metastasis.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient has been discharged with follow-up instructions from their oncologist. Please follow-up regularly with your medical team.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

PATIENT NAME: [REDACTED]
AGE: 15 years

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient [name redacted] was admitted to our hospital with a 2-month history of fever, decreased appetite, and nonproductive cough. Despite being prescribed antibiotics for presumed community-acquired pneumonia a few weeks prior to admission, his cough and fever continued to worsen. 

Upon admission, he presented with fever, tachycardia, respiratory distress, and splenomegaly. Further laboratory investigations revealed pancytopenia, and a sputum gram stain showed gram-positive cocci. HBsAg and Anti-HCV and Anti-HIV were negative, and ANA, Anti ds-DNA, p-ANCA, and c-ANCA were requested but all showed negative results. Chest X-ray and CT-scan of the thorax showed bilateral and peripheral nodular and alveolar patterns, predominantly in the lower lobes of the lung, with no mediastinal lymphadenopathy or pleural effusion observed. Abdominal sonography and CT showed observed hepatosplenomegaly, with splenomegaly being more pronounced than hepatomegaly. Para-aortic lymphadenopathy was not observed.

Two days after admission, the patient was observed to have a few small brown nodular lesions on the left leg, which necessitated the removal of a skin excisional biopsy. Meanwhile, his condition continued to worsen, with the onset of right hemiplegia, seizure, and aphasia one day later. A brain CT scan revealed a broadly hypo dense area on the left temporal and basal ganglia with little enhancement post-injection of IV contrast. The resulting skin biopsy showed severe infiltration of lymphocytes and histiocytes, with atypical lymphocytes observed on the subcutaneous and deep parts of the dermis. The primary aggregation of the cells was found around the vessels and nerves and appendices of the skin. The endothelial layer of the vessels showed signs of inflammation with no pattern of vasculitis observed.

The final diagnosis was lymphomatoid granulomatosis (LG), and the patient was treated with steroid pulse therapy and oral cyclophosphamide. However, he did not display any clinical improvement and eventually expired after 12 days of treatment.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
Lymphomatoid Granulomatosis (LG)

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient has been discharged from the hospital but requires post-mortem funeral arrangements. No further medical attention is necessary.

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENTS:
No further follow-up appointments are necessary.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
N/A

[DISCHARGE SUMMARY]

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 51
Gender: Female

Admission Date: July 2012
Discharge Date: N/A
Hospital Name: [REDACTED]

Chief complaints: Edema at the left lower extremities and painful left inguinal mass for 6 months

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted to the hospital in July 2012 with the chief complaints of left lower extremity edema and left inguinal mass. Physical examination revealed matted bilateral inguinal lymph nodes up to 9 cm in size with hard consistency, erythema, and tenderness without fluctuation or ulcer. Marked swelling at both lower extremities was observed. An incisional biopsy of the left inguinal lymph node revealed metastatic round cell tumor with characteristics consistent with malignant melanoma.

Further investigation was conducted to locate the primary tumors in the patient's lower extremities, abdominal cavity, and anogenital organ, but no evidence of lesion was found. A Computerized Tomography (CT) scan of the patient's abdomen showed multiple enlarged lymph nodes throughout the abdominal and pelvic cavity, along with compression of both iliac veins.

The patient was diagnosed with metastatic melanoma of unknown primary, and underwent 20 Gy of palliative radiotherapy for bilateral inguinal lymph nodes. Subsequently, chemotherapy was prescribed with carboplatin (AUC5) and paclitaxel 175 mg/m2 for 6 cycles. After the completion of chemotherapy, the patient's symptoms improved, and the CT scan showed a gradual decrease in the size of the tumors.

During the follow-up period, the patient developed multiple depigmented patches around the lips, trunk, and periorbital and inguinal area, which are typical of vitiligo.

Given the reimbursement issue, the patient could not access an immune checkpoint inhibitor or targeted drug according to a national reimbursement policy.

As of the latest follow-up in November 2017, the patient remains stable with gradual tumor regression.

Note: The patient has not been discharged. This document serves as a hospital course summary.

Electronic Health Record - Discharge Summary

Patient Name: John Doe
Medical Record Number: 123456

Admission Date: DD/MM/YYYY
Discharge Date: DD/MM/YYYY

Medical History
The patient has a history of cervical trauma that occurred 30 years ago. The patient removed a visible glass shard from his neck and did not seek medical attention. Additionally, the patient presented with mild back pain and right leg weakness for two weeks, which worsened significantly during the last 24 hours.

Hospital Course
The patient presented to the hospital with right leg weakness, numbness, and urinary retention. On neurological examination, the patient's right leg was weaker than the left, and sensory loss was present in the leg and below the Th8 dermatome on the right side. On the left side, sensory loss was present below Th10 dermatome and distal loss of temperature sensation. The CT scan of the lumbosacral and thoracic regions showed a mild convexity of the L5-S1 intervertebral disc. The MRI of the C1-L2 segment revealed a thickened and hyperintense spinal cord at the level of C4-Th3, consistent with myelitis. At the level of C6-C7, an oblong lesion 1.6 x 0.4 cm in size was found, and a foreign body was suspected. The CT scan of the C1-Th3 levels was further performed, and it demonstrated a hyperdense lesion in the spinal canal plus the left intervertebral foramen, confirming the presence of the foreign body.

The patient received medical management with methylprednisolone 500 mg intravenously daily for 6 days. Neurosurgeons were consulted; however, surgical treatment was not indicated due to the risks involved in removing the foreign body, which would potentially cause further spinal cord complications. During treatment, the patient's condition improved, and the right leg strength improved to 4/5 on Lovett test, but urinary retention remained. Intermittent catheterization was prescribed. 

Follow-up
The patient returned for follow-up 10 months later with a stable and improved neurological state. At this time, lower limb strength was 3/5 proximally and 4/5 distally, with positive bilateral Babinski sign. Minimal intermittent urinary retention remained but did not significantly impair the patients' quality of life. The patient continued his activities of daily living and returned to work.

Final Diagnosis
The patient was diagnosed with acute transverse myelitis, a spinal cord disorder characterized by bilateral sensory, motor, and autonomic spinal cord dysfunction.

Summary
The patient presented to the hospital with right leg weakness, numbness, and urinary retention. CT and MRI scans were performed, and a glass shard was found lodged in the spinal canal. The patient received medical management, and surgical treatment was not indicated. The follow-up visit 10 months later showed improved neurological state, with minimal intermittent urinary retention that did not impair the patient's quality of life. 

Discharge Instructions
The patient has no specific discharge instructions; however, follow-up appointments are recommended every 6 to 12 months to monitor for any further demyelinating lesions that may develop.

HOSPITAL COURSE: 

This is a 51-year-old female who presented with fatigue, nausea, and vomiting. She had a medical history of metastatic melanoma to pelvic nodes treated with ipilimumab and nivolumab and radiation therapy combined with pembrolizumab for disease progression. During her hospitalization, she developed acute abdominal colitis and was initiated on methylprednisolone with infliximab for emergent bowel resection. The histologic sections confirmed the presence of transmural necroinflammation and multifocal ulceration consistent with fulminant colitis and no evidence of metastatic melanoma to the bowel was identified.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS: 

Acute abdominal colitis

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS: 

The patient is discharged in stable condition with instructions to follow the recommended diet and take prescribed medications as directed. She is to return for a follow-up appointment with her primary care provider in 3 months. She is advised to continue routine monitoring for any changes in bowel movements or blood and to seek emergency medical attention if any concerning symptoms arise.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Admitting Physician: [REDACTED]
Attending Physician: [REDACTED]

History of Present Illness: The patient is a 65-year-old African American male who presented to the emergency department (ED) via emergency medical service with left arm pain that he described as “cramping”. The patient reported that the pain was so intense that he became weak causing him to fall onto the ground. The pain made him feel like “jumping out of the window”. The patient denied any head injury and he had no loss of consciousness (LOC). The patient had no chest, shortness of breath, or dyspnea on exertion. The patient denied any neck, back, or abdominal pain. The patient admitted to intermittent cocaine abuse.

Past Medical History: The patient's past medical history is significant for diabetes, hypertension, hepatitis C, sick sinus syndrome, high cholesterol, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, deep vein thrombosis, chronic kidney disease, hilar mediastinal adenopathy, diastolic heart failure, valvular heart disease, and cardiac arrhythmia of nonsustained ventricular tachycardia with a permanent pacemaker.

Physical Exam: The patient had a strong left radial pulse and brisk capillary refill of the left hand with no tenderness or deformity. The patient was noted to have left arm weakness and what looked like choreiform or clumsy left arm movements. His left leg was also noted to be weak. There was no numbness. Interestingly, light touch to any part of the left arm produced significant discomfort to the point where he did not want anything touching the left arm. He was noted to have decreased rapid alternating movements on the left upper extremity as well as mild difficulty with fine motor control. His left arm and left leg motor strength was 4/5. His cranial nerves II to XII were grossly intact. There were no visual fields cuts noted. Extraocular motility was intact. The grimace was symmetric. There was no evidence of double simultaneous extinction.

Diagnostic Studies: The electrocardiogram (ECG) showed sinus tachycardia with first degree atria-ventricular block, as well as ST and T wave abnormality suggestive of lateral ischemia. This is however unchanged compared to his ECG from two years previously. His cardiac enzyme was negative. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the head without contrast showed an acute 2.2 cm intraparenchymal hemorrhage with vasogenic edema in the posterior right parietal lobe. X-rays of the upper extremity were unremarkable. The chest X-ray showed normal cardiac silhouette and pulmonary vasculature. The carotid ultrasound showed no hemodynamically significant carotid stenosis and antegrade flow was present in the bilateral vertebral arteries. A CT angiography of the head and neck did not show any aneurysms. His serial cardiac enzymes remained negative throughout his hospitalization. A cardiac catheterization was not performed as the patient had it done one year previously showing angiographically normal coronaries.

Hospital Course: The patient was placed on a continuous nicardipine infusion to maintain a systolic blood pressure of 140 mm Hg as per neurosurgical consultation. He was transferred to a neurointensive care unit. His left arm pain resolved after 24 hours. A cardiology consult was obtained and the patient was found to have no evidence of acute coronary syndrome (ACS) or ischemia. He was subsequently discharged to a rehabilitation facility.

Discharge Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with acute left arm pain due to cocaine use, high blood pressure, and an intraparenchymal hemorrhage with vasogenic edema in the posterior right parietal lobe.

Discharge Instructions: The patient was discharged to a rehabilitation facility where he can receive continued medical care and physical therapy to help him recover from his left arm pain and intraparenchymal hemorrhage. The patient was advised to continue taking his medications as prescribed by his physician and to follow-up as scheduled. The patient was advised to avoid using cocaine and other illicit drugs.

Follow-up: The patient was advised to follow-up with his primary care physician and specialist physicians as scheduled.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 42-year-old male with a 9-year history of productive cough, fevers, chills, and night sweats with a recent diagnosis of left lung base stenosis and metallic foreign body

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with a productive cough, fevers, chills, and night sweats. He was diagnosed with left lung base stenosis and metallic foreign body on chest radiograph, chest CT scan, and bronchoscopy. The foreign body was removed successfully, and the patient reported immediate improvement in his symptoms. Granulation tissue occluding the LMSB was treated with argon plasma coagulation, and the patient underwent rigid bronchoscopy and radial incisions by electrocautery knife and balloon dilation to restore luminal patency. Follow-up surveillance bronchoscopy demonstrated persistent endobronchial stricture in the distal LMSB.

Course of Treatment:

The patient was given a seven-day course of levofloxacin, which temporarily improved his symptoms. The foreign body was removed using rigid bronchoscopy forceps, and granulation tissue occluding the LMSB was treated with argon plasma coagulation. A repeat CT scan one month after endobronchial therapy showed resolution of the left lung tree-in-bud opacities and consolidation and restored patency of the LMSB. The patient's chronic cough resolved, and he remains asymptomatic.

Follow-up Care:

The patient will continue to undergo surveillance bronchoscopy to monitor his endobronchial stricture in the distal LMSB. He will also be advised to quit smoking and avoid any further inhalation of foreign bodies. The patient will be referred to a specialist for further evaluation of his diabetes mellitus. He will be given a referral to a pulmonologist for his persistent cough. Follow-up will be coordinated by his primary care physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 66-year-old Caucasian male

Diagnosis: Actinic Keratosis

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the primary care clinic with a raised, scaly lesion on the dorsum of his left hand with marginal erythema. The lesion was diagnosed as Actinic Keratosis, and the possibility of Basal and Squamous cell carcinoma was considered due to the patient's medical history.

The patient had a previous history of Basal Cell Carcinoma, Seborrheic Keratoses, and Actinic Keratosis. The previous Basal Cell Carcinoma had been treated successfully with topical imiquimod treatment in six weeks.

The patient was then enrolled in a clinical trial that examined the use of Kanuka honey on rosacea. The patient opted for topical application of Honevo® medical grade Kanuka honey (90% Kanuka honey, 10% glycerin) once daily. A small amount of honey was applied on the fingertip and rubbed into the lesion and surrounding normal skin for 10-30 seconds. It was left on for 30-60 minutes and then washed off with water. The patient followed this regimen for three months, with a two-day treatment break due to tenderness of the lesion. The lesion gradually reduced in size, with an initial rapid reduction in its dry, crusted nature.

After three months, the residual lesion measured 20mm by 17mm with no elements of hypertrophy, crusting, or loss of skin integrity. At six months, there were no signs of recurrence, and at nine months, the appearance of the skin had fully returned to normal.

Follow-up:

A telephone follow-up was conducted at two years after treatment, and the patient reported completely healthy skin in the area, with no signs of recurrence.

Summary:

The patient was diagnosed with actinic keratosis, and topical application of Honevo® medical grade Kanuka honey (90% Kanuka honey, 10% glycerin) was used as a treatment approach. The patient followed this regimen for three months, with a two-day treatment break. After three months, the lesion gradually reduced in size, with a complete resolution of the lesion at nine months. At two years after treatment, the patient reported completely healthy skin in the area with no signs of recurrence.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 66-year-old female
Reason for Admission: Outpatient colonoscopy for evaluation of iron deficiency anemia, diarrhea, and rectal bleeding.
Medical History: Gastroesophageal reflux disease and chronic low back pain.

Hospital Course:

The patient underwent a colonoscopy which revealed four diaphragm-like strictures with scarring and ulceration, interspaced with normal mucosa in the cecum and ascending colon. Biopsies obtained from the strictures showed ulceration, acute inflammation, and reactive changes. Upon further examination, the patient was advised to discontinue naproxen and avoid any other NSAIDs.

At the three-month follow-up colonoscopy, both endoscopic and pathologic resolution of the diaphragm-like proximal colonic strictures were observed. The patient continued to do well and was discharged with proper instructions and follow-up care.

Details:

Discharge Date: (insert discharge date)

- Diarrhea
- Rectal bleeding

Procedures:

Medications:
- None prescribed

Follow-up Care:
- Follow-up colonoscopy in three months to monitor resolution

Discharge Condition:
- Discharged in stable condition

Discharge Instructions:
- Avoid NSAIDs
- Follow-up care as directed

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 19-year-old male with severe primary sclerosing cholangitis, underwent orthotopic liver transplantation and required a retransplant 5 weeks later due to liver insufficiency caused by ligation of ruptured arterial pseudoaneurysm. The patient's postoperative course after retransplant included prolonged hemodialysis (8 weeks) due to acute kidney injury, cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, hepatitis E infection, and hepatic artery stenosis in the anastomosis area, treated by angioplasty and stent insertion. The patient's condition stabilized eight months after transplantation with medications and underwent liver biopsy which confirmed early mild chronic rejection. The patient underwent genetic testing and compound heterozygosity for C282Y/H63D mutations were detected, indicating the presence of hereditary hemochromatosis (HH) elicited by genetic defect in the donor tissue.

Hospital Course:
The patient's laboratory and radiologic evaluations showed no abnormalities, aside from iron-related parameters, serum iron, 110 ng/ml, ferritin, 3170 mg/dl (versus 29 mg/dL before transplant), transferrin, 119 mg/dL, and transferrin saturation, 66%. Repeated liver biopsy revealed sinusoidal fibrosis with mild cholangiolar proliferation. Iron staining showed significant accumulation of iron in macrophages and hepatocytes, consistent with marked hemosiderosis. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) performed or iron assessment revealed mild hepatic iron overload consistent with 5 mg/gr and did not show accumulation of iron in other organs: pancreas, adrenals, spleen, and heart. 

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with HH elicited by genetic defect in the donor tissue.

Treatment:
The patient was enrolled in a phlebotomy program.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition improved and stable at the time of discharge.

Follow-up:
The patient's follow-up care should include ongoing phlebotomy to manage HH. Further genetic testing for HH is not indicated, as the patient's DNA has been previously tested and shown to not possess common HFE mutations (C282Y or H63D).

Hospital Course: 

The patient, a five-year-old male, presented with a history of sudden popping sensation accompanied by warmth and pressure along the base of the skull. The symptoms radiated bilaterally and lasted for a few seconds. The patient also reported numbness of the posterior tongue and difficulty speaking. These episodes were triggered by abrupt lateral movements of the head and occurred five to ten times a year. Between the ages of eleven and fifteen, the patient experienced similar symptoms while competing in fencing. As a result, the frequency of episodes increased to one to two times weekly. At the age of nineteen, during military training, the patient experienced similar symptoms following minor trauma to the head. Episodes further increased to about fifteen episodes during the combat. The patient denied experiencing any episodes in the six months that followed his discharge from service. The patient was reassured that his symptoms were not indicative of any underlying serious pathology. 

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with dysplastic enlargement of the anterior arch of C1 vertebra and mild degenerative changes of the atlantoaxial junction leading to compression of the hypoglossal nerve. The diagnosis was made based on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine. 

Treatment and Follow up:

The patient was advised to avoid extreme lateral movements of the head that triggered his symptoms. The patient was informed that the condition was not life-threatening and that no medical intervention was necessary. The patient was also informed that his grandmother has the same condition. The patient was discharged and advised to seek follow-up care if symptoms recur or worsen.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Reason for Hospitalization:
The 72-year-old female patient was admitted to our hospital with pancreatic head and neck carcinoma for evaluation and surgical operation. She had several symptoms, including abdominal pain, icterus, and generalized itching.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent several imaging procedures, including abdominal computed tomography, endosonographic imaging, and diagnostic ampullary biopsy, to evaluate her condition. The results revealed that the patient had a hypodense mass in the head and neck of the pancreas, periampullary lesions, and a slightly dilated main pancreatic duct in the body of the pancreas.

During the Whipple procedure, it was found that the tumor had spread, and total pancreatectomy was performed. Postoperative pathological studies revealed that the tumor extended to the duodenum and invaded the venous, lymphatic vessels, and perineural sites, although no distant metastasis was found. The patient was diagnosed with undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (UPS).

Treatment:
The patient was started on insulin and Creon after surgery to maintain long-term health. Contrast-enhanced thoracic high-resolution CT scans and multidetector CT scans of abdominopelvic were conducted at 6, 12, 18, 24, and 36 months after the operation to evaluate metastasis occurrence, but no evidence of metastasis was detected.

Follow-Up:
The patient was disease-free during the 5-year follow-up period and tolerated total pancreatectomy well. Further follow-up investigations were done regularly by periodic CT scan and ultrasonic imaging.

Diagnosis:
Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (UPS), pathologic stage II A.

Conclusion:
The patient was referred to our hospital with pancreatic head and neck carcinoma and underwent total pancreatectomy for undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (UPS). The patient was started on insulin and Creon after surgery and was disease-free during the 5-year follow-up period. Further follow-up investigations were conducted regularly to ensure the patient's long-term health.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a medical history of micropapillary thyroid cancer and stage IIIb lung adenocarcinoma who presented with subjective complaints of fatigue, nausea, scalp tenderness, and xeroderma. A screening MRI revealed a new hypovascular pituitary mass measuring approximately 1 cm by 0.8 cm, which, upon further analysis, was discovered to be metastatic lung adenocarcinoma with a positive identification of cytokeratin 7, TTF-1, Ki-67, and epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) positive with EGFR gene nucleotide change demonstrating T790M and L858R positivity. The patient underwent transsphenoidal resection of his pituitary mass and subsequent whole-brain radiation. 

Presenting Symptoms:
The patient's subjective complaints included new onset fatigue, nausea, scalp tenderness, and xeroderma.

Physical Examination:
On physical exam, xeroderma was appreciated in all extremities. Finger size was proportional and no significant abnormalities were noted.

Diagnostic Tests:
A screening MRI revealed a new hypovascular pituitary mass measuring approximately 1 cm by 0.8 cm, which was identified as metastatic lung adenocarcinoma. Further histologic analysis revealed the presence of cytokeratin 7, TTF-1, Ki-67, and EGFR gene nucleotide change demonstrating T790M and L858R positivity. 

Treatment:
The patient underwent transsphenoidal resection of his pituitary mass and subsequent whole-brain radiation. The patient was started on prednisone 20 mg by mouth daily, which was later switched to hydrocortisone 20 mg in the morning and 10 mg in the evening for chronic steroid replacement therapy. The patient was instructed to increase his hydrocortisone to 90 mg daily if acutely ill.

Follow-Up:
After transsphenoidal resection and subsequent whole-brain radiation, the patient's low morning cortisol and testosterone levels persisted. The patient's testosterone level was <20 ng/dL and his cortisol was <1.0 mcg/dL. Luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone were also low, and free T4 and thyroid-stimulating hormone were below normal ranges. Prolactin levels were lower than previous but still elevated at 14.9 ng/mL. 

Summary:
The patient presented with subjective complaints of fatigue, nausea, scalp tenderness, and xeroderma. A screening MRI revealed a new hypovascular pituitary mass measuring approximately 1 cm by 0.8 cm, which was identified as metastatic lung adenocarcinoma. The patient underwent transsphenoidal resection of the pituitary mass and subsequent whole-brain radiation. However, the patient's low morning cortisol and testosterone levels persisted.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital Course

The patient, a 32-year-old male, presented with progressive shortness of breath and leg swelling. He had a past medical history significant for HIV disease and metastatic transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and left nephrectomy. He underwent gemcitabine and cisplatin followed by salvage treatment with atezolizumab. He was also on combination antiretroviral therapy with undetectable viral load and CD4 count of 444 cells/mm3.

Physical exam revealed tachycardia, respiratory distress, decreased breath sounds in the right hemithorax, and lower extremity swelling. A chest X-ray showed a right-sided pleural effusion and an enlarged nodular density in the left upper lobe. Laboratory data revealed anemia and an elevated troponin I.

After receiving a blood transfusion and undergoing therapeutic thoracentesis, the patient's symptoms resolved partially. Transthoracic echocardiography revealed normal left ventricular function and a large, mobile, cystic mass in the right and left atrium. Transesophageal echocardiography revealed a large mass composed of solid and cystic components. The solid component had invaded the basal half of the interatrial septum and the cystic component was found to protrude into the left atrium. 

Multiple enhancing neoplastic masses in the muscular compartment in both calves were detected on MRI of the lower extremities, which were in favor of neoplastic lesions. Given the extent of disease, the patient was not a candidate for surgery and he expired few days after presentation.

Diagnosis(es)

1. Metastatic transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis
2. HIV disease

Complication(s)

1. Pleural effusion
2. Anemia
3. Elevated troponin I
4. Cystic mass in the right and left atrium
5. Neoplastic lesions in the muscular compartment in both calves

Disposition

The patient expired in the hospital.

Follow-up

N/A

Signed,

[Redacted], MD
[Redacted] Primary Care Group

Hospital Course:
This 75-year-old female patient was admitted to our hospital following a Gasserian ganglion nerve block procedure performed at the Department of Anesthesiology. The procedure aimed to treat postherpetic neuralgia in the right first branch neuralgia of the trigeminal nerve. The patient reported sudden visual acuity decline and hyperemia of the right eye the following day, leading her to seek medical attention. The patient was diagnosed with corneal epithelial defect, conjunctival hyperemia, and Descemet's folds in the right eye by a neighborhood ophthalmologist. The patient was then treated with a variety of ophthalmic medications including ofloxacin ophthalmic ointment, rebamipide ophthalmic suspension, and fluorometholone ophthalmic suspension.
 
Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented with postherpetic neuralgia and underwent a Gasserian ganglion nerve block procedure, which resulted in a sudden visual acuity decline and hyperemia of the right eye. The patient was treated with ophthalmic medications and exhibited gradual improvement over time. However, the patient experienced intermittent corneal erosion, and it was detected that corneal subbasal nerve fibers had regenerated in the right eye. This patient was discharged, and follow-up appointments were scheduled to continue to monitor her recovery.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted due to a 2-day history of mild dysarthria and naming impairment with difficulty finding words and holding a conversation. Furthermore, his family reported at least one-month history of motor awkwardness and gait instability. During the neurological examination, the patient displayed fluent, coherent spontaneous language and had mild dysnomia. He was diagnosed with Parkinsonism.

Further investigations revealed increased signal intensity in the left putamen with diffusion restriction, suggesting lacunar infarction. Parkinsonism was also studied using 123I-ioflupane SPECT, which revealed asymmetrical tracer uptake in the caudate nuclei and a near-complete lack of activity in the putamina, particularly on the left side. 

Progression was poor, and the patient was readmitted to the hospital. An EEG revealed short-interval lateralized interictal epileptiform discharges in the left hemisphere. The patient went into a coma and was admitted to the intensive care unit. An additional MRI revealed progression of the lesions, with a patchy, gyriform hyperintensity predominantly affecting the cortex of the left hemisphere and the right temporoparietal cortex, visible in diffusion sequences only.

A diagnosis of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease was reached based on the patient's rapid neurological deterioration, the presence of myoclonus, and MRI findings. The patient died 5 months after disease onset. Autopsy was not granted.

Discharge Summary:

The patient was admitted with symptoms of mild dysarthria, naming impairment, motor awkwardness, and gait instability. The patient's neurological examination revealed fluent, coherent spontaneous language, mild dysnomia, and clinical symptoms of parkinsonism. Further investigations, including a brain MRI, echocardiogram, Holter monitoring, and Doppler ultrasound of the supra-aortic trunks were performed, which showed no significant abnormalities.

However, the patient's condition deteriorated quickly, and they were readmitted to the hospital. The patient went into a coma and was admitted to the intensive care unit. After further investigations, a diagnosis of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease was reached based on the patient's rapid neurological deterioration, the presence of myoclonus, and MRI findings.

The patient passed away 5 months after the onset of the disease, and autopsy was not granted.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 40 years old
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission date: [REDACTED]               Discharge date: [REDACTED]

Admitted to: Obstetrics and Gynecology Department

Reason for admission: The patient was admitted for elective cesarean section delivery at 38 weeks and 2 days of gestation due to breech presentation.

Hospital Course:

The patient had previously been diagnosed with submucosal fibroids and Asherman's syndrome, for which she underwent hysteroscopic myomectomy and hysteroscopic adhesiolysis, respectively. The patient later underwent in vitro fertilization and became pregnant, but experienced a miscarriage at 7 weeks of gestation. She became pregnant again through IVF and was referred to our hospital.

During the cesarean section delivery, the placenta adhered to the uterine wall, leading to a diagnosis of placenta increta. The patient subsequently underwent cesarean hysterectomy to remove the placenta and address subserosal uterine fibroids and adhesions.

The patient's postoperative course was uneventful, and she was discharged in good health on the 7th postpartum day.

Outpatient Follow-up:

The patient is advised to follow up with her primary care physician for routine postpartum care and to monitor for any potential complications related to her previous history of submucosal fibroids and Asherman's syndrome.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 45-year-old Hispanic male
History: End-stage renal disease of unknown etiology, hypertension, and high cholesterol. Had undergone a living related kidney transplant with induction therapy consisting of basiliximab and solumedrol. Maintenance therapy was with tacrolimus, mycophenolate mofetil, and prednisone.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient presented to the renal transplant clinic complaining of edema that had appeared over the previous three days. He admitted to inadvertently taking less tacrolimus than prescribed for almost one month. On examination, he had periorbital edema and lower extremity edema. Laboratory data showed an increase in creatinine, proteinuria, and hematuria. A renal biopsy was ordered and conducted, revealing evidence of postinfectious glomerulonephritis and minimal residual subendothelial electron dense deposits. Anti-streptolysin O (ASO) was elevated, indicating Streptococcus might have caused the infection.

Treatment:

Prednisone was increased, and the tacrolimus and mycophenolate mofetil dosages were increased, due to acute kidney injury, proteinuria, and hematuria. Given that his AKI did not appear to be due to rejection, tacrolimus was decreased back to the basal dose of 3 mg twice a day and prednisone was tapered to 10 mg daily. Fluid management was achieved with furosemide. No antibiotics were prescribed. A month later, creatinine had decreased and returned to baseline. Proteinuria and hematuria had completely resolved after three months.

Outcome:

The patient's condition improved significantly, and he was discharged in stable condition. Follow-up care was arranged with a recommendation to continue therapy and undergo regular check-ups.

Discharge Summary:

Patient:
2-year-old boy

Presenting Problem:
Progressive painful and difficult voiding with only few drops of urine after straining, fever, agitation, vomiting, urinary retention, and significant abdominal distension.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent an office-based surgical circumcision which resulted in profound bleeding that was ultimately controlled by deep suturing. However, during the postoperative period, the patient started to experience painful and difficult voiding. After about a week, the patient was referred to a district hospital with fever, agitation, vomiting, urinary retention, and significant abdominal distension. Urgent abdominopelvic ultrasound revealed a large volume of free fluid in the abdomen and pelvis with a small amount of urine in the bladder. Catheterization with a 6-Fr feeding tube failed because it did not pass beyond the subcoronal urethra. The patient underwent an emergency midline laparotomy which revealed a small intraperitoneal bladder rupture at the dome of the bladder. The diagnosis of intraperitoneal bladder rupture with urinary ascites was made, likely caused by near-total urethral obstruction. The rupture site was repaired in two layers, and a suprapubic cystostomy catheter was fixed.

Follow-up:
Two months later, at our center, antegrade voiding cystourethrography (VCUG) was performed via the suprapubic catheter which showed terminal urethral obstruction. A decision was made to explore the area and repair the urethra. An end-to-end urethral anastomosis was performed, and the postoperative period was uneventful. The patient was discharged home with a suprapubic and urethral catheter. The urethral catheter was removed seven days following surgery, and the suprapubic catheter was removed four weeks after surgery following normal urethral voiding and normal ultrasound. A VCUG was performed six weeks after surgery that showed normal bladder and urethra with acceptable voiding per urethra. During a 2.5-year follow-up period, the patient was asymptomatic with normal renal function, ultrasound, and voiding pattern. He had a maximum flow rate of 15.3 ml/sec in uroflowmetry study.

Contributing Factors:
The underlying cause of the rupture was likely due to near-total urethral obstruction.

Outcome:
The patient underwent an emergency laparotomy and urethral anastomosis procedure with no complications. The patient has since been asymptomatic with normal renal function, ultrasound, and voiding pattern.

Hospital Course:
The 51-year-old male patient was admitted with hypercalcemia, renal failure, and persistent leg and low back pain. On admission, he reported fatigue, bone pain, and polyuria. Physical examination revealed no specific findings of the lymph nodes, head, neck, heart, lung, abdomen, or joints. Laboratory testing revealed corrected serum calcium of 3.39 mmol/L, phosphorus of 0.84 mmol/L, PTH of 540 ng/mL, serum creatinine of 151 μmol/L (after hemodialysis), and hemoglobin of 120 g/L. Urine calcium was 9.2 mmol/24 h. An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed complete right bundle branch block and a precordial abnormal ST segment and normal corrected QT (QTc) interval. Ultrasonography revealed a nodule at the left lower pole of the parathyroid gland. Single-photon emission computed tomography results indicated an adenoma of the left lower pole of the parathyroid gland.

Treatment:
Hydration with 3000 mL of fluid per day, furosemide at 40 mg three times per day, cinacalcet at 25 mg per day, and RRT were utilized to reduce serum calcium levels. Slow extended dialysis with low-calcium dialysate (1.25 mmol) at bedside was started using a commercially available continuous RRT device (multiFiltrate, Fresenius Medical Care Deutschland GmbH, Bad Homburg, Germany). Due to no family history of such disease and no medication history of thiazide or lithium, a diagnosis of primary hyperparathyroidism caused by a parathyroid adenoma was made. However, due to the high level of troponin T and changes to the ST segment on an ECG, parathyroidectomy was deferred for multidisciplinary consultation.

Outcome: 
After gradual reduction of serum calcium levels and preparation for parathyroidectomy, the patient underwent parathyroidectomy and an untypical parathyroid adenoma was pathologically confirmed. Postoperatively, PTH dropped to 16.9 ng/L and serum calcium dropped to 2.25 mmol/L. Serum calcium was 2.11 mmol/L and serum creatinine was 173 μmol/L at discharge. The patient reported serum calcium of 2.13 mmol/L and serum creatinine of 112 μmol/L without calcium supplementation at 2 months after discharge.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information: A 42 year old male with a history of oligodendroglioma and newly diagnosed metastatic malignant melanoma, who presented with a 20 pound unintentional weight loss over a 3 month period and new left axillary lymphadenopathy.

Hospital Course:

The patient initially received systemic ipilimumab for his metastatic melanoma, followed by treatment with pembrolizumab after experiencing disease progression. Despite multiple lines of therapy, the patient's disease continued to progress. Nine months after receiving his genetically engineered T-cell infusion, he proceeded to treatment with HD IL-2.

During his first course of treatment with HD IL-2, the patient experienced the expected adverse effects but had an uncomplicated recovery. His second course of treatment, however, resulted in diffuse myalgias and a rapid rise in serum CK levels, leading to rhabdomyolysis. Further investigations revealed a rare immune-mediated toxicity causing necrotizing myopathy.

The patient received supportive care and aggressive intravenous hydration, resulting in full recovery from this episode of rhabdomyolysis. Due to this unusual toxicity, a muscle biopsy was performed.

The biopsy revealed rare myofiber necrosis and myophagocytosis and an infiltrate of T-lymphocytes and macrophages, suggestive of an immune-mediated toxicity causing necrotizing myopathy. The engineered T-cells remained detectable in the circulation, but it was difficult to ascertain if they were present in the muscle tissue. The patient was discharged home and follow-up PET/CT imaging revealed a near complete response. At follow-up, the patient was found to have new onset vitiligo involving his neck, upper back, chest, and upper arms.

Outcome:

No further HD-IL2 therapy has been administered to the patient and he continues to experience a durable response on imaging nearly two and a half years since completion of his HD IL-2 therapy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification:
- The patient is a 32-year-old healthy pregnant woman referred to the Medical Genetic Centre of Ganzhou Maternal and Child Health Care Hospital.

Reason for admission:
- The patient was referred due to an increased risk of developing T18 syndrome in the foetus during the second trimester maternal serum screening conducted in another hospital.

Hospital Course:
- An ultrasound examination at a gestational age of 16 weeks was conducted which showed that the foetus was normal.
- An NIPT was offered to further screen for common foetal chromosomal abnormalities.
- The patient's written informed consent was obtained to participate in this research project approved by the Research Ethics Committee of Ganzhou Maternal and Child Health Care Hospital.

Outcome:
- The patient received a comprehensive assessment and evaluation of her condition and was provided with necessary information about her pregnancy.
- It was determined that the foetus was developing normally and the risk of T18 syndrome was reduced following the ultrasound examination and NIPT.
- The patient was discharged from the hospital and advised to continue regular prenatal care with her obstetrician.

Hospital Course:
The 56-year-old Japanese male patient was referred to the hospital due to dyspnea, hypotension, and left-sided chest pain. He had a history of Parkinson's disease with psychosis. Upon examination, he exhibited poor dentition and inadequate hygiene. Laboratory tests showed elevated white blood cell count with a left shift, low hemoglobin, and elevated CRP. Chest radiography revealed a mass in the left upper lung, bilateral pleural effusions, and cardiac enlargement. Chest CT scan showed a wedge-shaped and pleural-based mass in the left upper lobe, a thick-walled cavitary lesion in the left lower lobe, bilateral pleural effusions, and pericardial effusion. The patient underwent pericardiocentesis and pericardial drainage and was diagnosed with bacterial pericarditis and lung abscess in the left lower lobe. Empirical antibiotic treatment with intravenous ceftriaxone was started.

On day 6, the patient was stable, and the pericardial drainage tube, which showed minimal fluid, was removed. On day 9, the patient experienced a fever of 39.0 °C (102.2 °F), and sinus tachycardia occurred, with atrial fibrillation and cardiac arrest with asystole. The patient underwent an immediate cardiopulmonary resuscitation, which restored sinus rhythm and blood pressure. Chest CT scan obtained on the same day showed the remaining thick-walled cavitary lesion in the left lower lobe and the reduced pericardial effusion. Ultrasound-guided pneumocentesis of the cavitary lesion in the left lower lobe was performed, which revealed Actinomyces species growth.

Diagnostic Assessment:
Transbronchial biopsy and bronchial washing of the mass lesion in both the left upper and lower lobes were performed, revealing non-specific inflammation and organization of the lung tissue with no bacteria present. Blood cultures did not show any organisms.

Treatment:
Antibiotics were changed to intravenous penicillin, and the patient's condition remained stable. Upon discharge, the patient was given a total of six months of oral doxycycline therapy. The patient completed the full antibiotic regimen without complications.

Follow-Up:
At a 6-month follow-up, the patient's condition had improved. The patient was feeling well, gaining weight, and showed improvement in CT scans.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to maintain good oral hygiene and to have regular dentist check-ups. The patient was advised to quit smoking and avoid excessive alcohol intake. The patient was instructed to follow up with the healthcare team for further check-ups as needed.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]

Age: 56

Sex: Female

Medical Record Number: [redacted]

Date of Admission: [redacted]

Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Unresectable NSCLC

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our hospital for treatment of unresectable non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The patient had previously received adjuvant chemotherapy, consisting of four cycles of cisplatin-pemetrexed.

Nivolumab therapy was initiated and continued for 20 infusions. A partial response was observed after five doses, and increasing mediastinal node size and a micronodular interstitial syndrome were observed after 20 nivolumab infusions.

Biopsies revealed sarcoid-like inflammation. Nivolumab therapy was discontinued, and the patient experienced a partial response. Mediastinoscopy showed sarcoid lesions, and the interstitial syndrome deteriorated.

Bronchoalveolar lavage was performed, revealing hypercellularity comprising 41% of lymphocytes without pathogens or cancer cells. CT scans were obtained, and normal mediastinal nodes and regression of the interstitial syndrome were observed 348 days later.

PD-1, PD-L1, and PD-L2 expression on PBMC were analyzed at various time-points after stopping nivolumab. The patient exhibited an elevated expression of PD-L1 on B and T cells at day 56, with a peak at day 147, compared to other patients treated with nivolumab without relevant immune related reactions. An elevated expression of PD-L1 was also observed on monocytes at day 147. PD-L1 expression returned to basal levels on day 251.

Discharge Medications:

N/A

Disposition:

The patient was discharged in stable condition. Follow-up appointments were scheduled with the treating physician to monitor the patient's clinical status.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]           Admission Date: [redacted]           Discharge Date: [redacted]

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient, a 56-year-old female with a history of bladder exstrophy and recurrent urinary tract infections, was admitted with a six-month history of rectal bleeding, mucus passage, and a change in bowel habit to more frequent stools. She did not report any abdominal pain and she maintained her weight. Colonoscopy revealed two large sessile polyps near a diverticulum-like structure in the sigmoid colon, along with atypical mucosa around the diverticulum. The polyps both exhibited a type IV pit pattern with areas of irregularity suggestive of focally advanced disease. Biopsy confirmed that both polyps were adenomas containing both low and high grade dysplasia, without submucosal invasion. An open high anterior resection was performed due to suspected intra-abdominal adhesions following extensive pelvic surgery. The patient’s pre-operative request for a permanent colostomy was fulfilled and an end colostomy was formed. The patient’s postoperative recovery was uneventful and she expressed satisfaction with her quality of life following surgery.

MEDICAL HISTORY:
The patient's medical history is significant for bladder exstrophy and recurrent urinary tract infections. There are no other major co-morbidities or risk factors for colorectal malignancy, and no family history of colorectal disease.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
An open high anterior resection was performed, followed by the formation of an end colostomy at the patient’s request. The patient's postoperative recovery was free of notable incidents and there were no complications.

DISPOSITION:
The patient was discharged with status post sigmoid colon surgery and end colostomy formation. She is scheduled for regular follow-up evaluations with her healthcare provider. 

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1. Sigmoid colon adenomas with dysplasia
2. Atypical mucosal changes

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Continue with regular follow-up visits.
2. Notify your healthcare provider immediately if you experience any worsening of your gastrointestinal symptoms.
3. Continue to manage your stoma care in accordance with the guidance of your healthcare provider.
4. Avoid smoking and heavy alcohol consumption.
5. Maintain a healthy lifestyle and diet.
