Discharge Summary

Patient Information
Name: [redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 23 years

Hospital Course Summary
The patient was admitted with a 4-month history of fluctuating weakness of the right upper and lower extremities associated with a band-like sensation of the trunk along with bowel and bladder disturbances. There was also a month-long history of neck movement-related electric-like sensation on the nape. Weakness progressed to the left lower extremity causing difficulty in ambulation and eventually became quadriparetic. The patient's condition deteriorated and she developed dysphagia, dysphonia, difficulty breathing, and projectile vomiting.

Initial Assessment
The patient was hemodynamically stable upon admission with no spinal deformities noted. She had lax sphincter tone and hypesthesia was described. The patient was hyper-reflexic on both the upper and lower extremities along with bilateral extensor toe sign.

Diagnostic Tests
Initial work-up included a cranio-spinal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealing a long expansile contrast-enhancing mass involving the entire spinal cord, from the level of the cervical region to the conus medullaris with extension to the lower medulla oblongata. 

Medical Management
The patient was started on dexamethasone, which provided minimal relief of symptoms. She was referred to the neurosurgery service and was advised for surgery.

Outcome
Unfortunately, on the 20th hospital day, the patient's symptoms progressed to quadriplegia and respiratory failure. She subsequently developed healthcare-associated pneumonia succumbing to septicemia.

Autopsy
On autopsy, all lobes of the lungs were consolidated secondary to pneumonia. There was swelling of the entire spinal cord with white to yellow mucoid material coming out from the central canal. Cut sections showed that the entire spinal cord and caudal medullary region were replaced by mucoid material. Histopathologic examination of the spinal cord revealed a cellular tumor arranged around the central canal of the cord. The cells are generally small, with round to slightly ovoid nuclei. Fibrillary processes were noted in the cytoplasm.

Diagnosis
The patient was diagnosed with holocord oligodendroglioma.

Recommendation
Further genetic characterization of the tumor such as IDH, 1p/19q codeletion, MGMT, EGFR and TP53 mutations were not done because of its unavailability in the institution but its histologic and immunochemical features are consistent with holocord oligodendroglioma.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient was referred to our dermatology clinic due to persistent swelling of the earlobes several months after ear piercing. On clinical examination, symmetrical nodes were detected on both earlobes. Histology showed epithelioid granulomas with a lymphocytic infiltrate. Patients were screened for sarcoidosis and foreign body reactions, with negative findings. Patch testing was performed using the European baseline series and a dental series, which showed positive reactions to nickel sulfate 5% pet. and palladium chloride 1% pet. Four weeks after the patch testing, a persistent reaction on the patient's back remained at the palladium test site. A biopsy showed epithelioid granulomas similar to those previously seen in the excised nodes. 

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with epithelioid granulomas with a lymphocytic infiltrate, palladium allergy, and nickel allergy.

Treatment:

The patient was referred to an allergist for further management of puritis.

Follow-up:

The patient was advised to avoid nickel and palladium in jewelry, dental work, and other products. The patient was given resources to learn about avoiding such materials.

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged in good condition.

Signed,

[Name and Role of Signatory]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: XXX
Sex: Female
Age: 65

Admission Date: XXX
Discharge Date: XXX
Length of Stay: XXX

Final Diagnosis: Locally advanced ascending colon cancer stages T4b, N2a, M0, and IIIC

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of malaise and hematochezia. A physical examination revealed a 10-cm-diameter hard mass at the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. Laboratory findings demonstrated severe anemia and elevated tumor markers. A colonoscopy showed a circumferential neoplastic lesion at the ascending colon, which did not allow the scope to pass through. The biopsy reported a moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma.

The patient underwent 4 cycles of modified FOLFOX6 with panitumumab. An additional 4 cycles of the same regimen were administered, but the tumor actually enlarged. Radiotherapy of 60 Gy in 30 fractions was administered, and the patient tolerated the treatments well.

After the radiotherapy, the tumor shrank, and the patient underwent right hemicolectomy with D3 lymphadenectomy. Metastatic lesions of the liver or peritoneum were not observed. The transverse colon and ileum at 30 cm proximal from the ileocecal valve were cut and anastomosed.

The macroscopic exam of the resected specimen showed a 9.0 × 7.0-cm circumferential tumor with a 4.5 × 3.5-cm ulcer at the ascending colon, which extensively penetrated the colon serosa and infiltrated the ileum and the ovarian vessels. Histopathologically, the primary tumor of the ascending colon and enlarged regional lymph nodes consisted in its totality of granuloma-like or fibrous tissues, and no residual cancer cells were found. Pathological findings revealed complete response, and the final findings were ypT0, ypN0 (0/15), and ypStage0.

The postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Diagnosis: Complete response to locally advanced ascending colon cancer stages T4b, N2a, M0, and IIIC

Discharge Medications: None

Discharge Instructions: The patient is advised to follow up with her oncologist regularly. She should maintain a healthy diet and lifestyle and avoid smoking and alcohol consumption.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]
Patient ID: [redacted]
Sex: Male
Age: 62
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Clinical History:
The patient was admitted for surgical treatment of hepatocellular carcinoma. Imaging findings revealed two tumors in segments 5 and 8. The patient underwent anterior segmentectomy, involving the ligation of each branch of the hepatic artery, portal vein, and biliary duct for the anterior segment as the Glissonean bundle. Postoperative imaging studies indicated an arterioportal fistula and portal vein aneurysm, which were confirmed by angiography. Embolization therapy via IVR was successfully performed to reduce the flow of blood through the APF, and demonstrated perfect interruption of the APF and disappearance of the PVA.

Hospital Course:
The patient had an unremarkable postoperative course and was discharged on postoperative day 14. The patient underwent dynamic MRI three months after surgery to check for recurrent intrahepatic tumors, and an APF and PVA were incidentally detected. The patient was carefully monitored for any symptoms or abnormalities, and a definitive diagnosis of PVA due to an APF was determined. An IVR was then successfully conducted, and the patient continued to have no significant symptoms or issues post-procedure.

Summary:
The patient underwent an anterior segmentectomy for two hepatic tumors located in segments 5 and 8. Further imaging studies demonstrated the presence of an APF and PVA, which were treated via IVR embolization therapy. Since the procedure, the patient has had no further abnormalities or concerns, and has been reintegrated into society.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Hepatocellular carcinoma
Arterioportal fistula (APF)
Portal vein aneurysm (PVA)

Discharge Disposition:
The patient was discharged in good health and reintegrated into society.

Discharge Medication:
None.

Follow-up Instructions:
None.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Patient: 25-year-old male

Reason for admission:
The patient was found dead in his flat. Autopsy determined that the cause of death was acute cardiac failure resulting from chronic focal lesions in the myocardium, possibly due to substance intoxication.

Hospital course:
Due to the circumstances of the patient's death, there was no hospital course to document.

Final diagnosis:
Mixed causes of myocardium lesions with 4-CMC and amphetamine intoxication, resulting in acute cardiac failure.

Treatment:
As there was no hospitalization for this patient, there was no treatment administered.

Follow-up:
There will be no follow-up necessary, as the patient has expired.

Recommendation:
Based on the autopsy report, it is recommended to educate individuals on the potential dangers of substance abuse, as substances like 4-CMC and amphetamines can result in myocardium lesions and acute cardiac failure. Additionally, it is important to seek medical attention immediately if symptoms of substance intoxication are present.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for routine coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) due to left main coronary artery disease. The surgery was successful, and the patient was transferred to the cardiac intensive care unit (ICU) while intubated and unconscious, and remained there until the third postoperative day.

On the second day after CABG, the patient had difficulty moving his lower limbs, and on the third postoperative day, progressive paraparesis developed. Muscle strength and deep tendon reflexes (DTRs) gradually decreased until the patient experienced severe weakness of the lower and upper limbs in the evening. That same night, the patient presented with respiratory failure and was intubated and moved back to the ICU.

On the fourth day, the patient underwent magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and experienced an episode of ventricular fibrillation and cardiac arrest during the scan, requiring resuscitation. The patient remained haemodynamically unstable and received high doses of dobutamine, norepinephrine and adrenaline.

On the sixth postoperative day, the patient's conditions improved and was haemodynamically supported with low-dose norepinephrine. However, the patient presented manifestations of post-cardiac arrest brain injury, including coma, seizures and myoclonus. Unfortunately, the patient died 10 days after surgery due to septic shock.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with left main coronary artery disease, hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidaemia, a history of percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty, and myocardial infarction.

Hospitalization:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for a routine CABG due to left main coronary artery disease. The patient underwent successful CABG and remained in the cardiac ICU for several days

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted to the cardiac intensive care unit for the management of a sudden-onset, severe and intractable retrosternal chest pain. The patient was started on low-molecular weight heparin (LMWH) at a therapeutic dose, aspirin and nitrates. Due to persistence of pain, the patient was referred to our centre. Upon examination, the patient had a systolic murmur in the aortic area and showed severe aortic insufficiency. Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) angiogram of the thorax showed dissection of the aorta from the ascending aorta to the iliac arteries, including the coeliac trunk and left renal artery, and causing splenic infarction. The patient was placed on high-flow oxygen at 5 l/min, nicardipine, bisoprolol, analgesics, and compressive stockings. Blood pressure and heart rate targets were achieved on day six of hospitalisation. On day 10, the patient developed a presumptive diagnosis of severe pneumonia. Blood culture results (which returned after the patient’s demise) were positive for Klebsiella pneumonia. On day 12, the patient died following cardiopulmonary arrest despite life support. 

Hospital Course Summary:
- Admitted with sudden and severe retrosternal chest pain
- Started on LMWH, aspirin, and nitrates
- Referred to our centre due to persistence of pain
- Examinations showed aortic insufficiency and aortic dissection
- Started on high-flow oxygen, nicardipine, bisoprolol, analgesics, and compressive stockings
- Achieved blood pressure and heart rate targets on day six
- Developed a presumptive diagnosis of severe pneumonia on day 10
- Positive blood culture for Klebsiella pneumonia (returned after patient's demise)
- Died on day 12 following cardiopulmonary arrest despite life support.

Hospital Course:

The 18-year-old female was admitted to Peking Union Medical College Hospital with complaints of abnormal limb movements and slurred speech, which worsened 20 days ago. The patient's movements were slower, and her hands were clumsy at the onset of symptoms. Over time, she developed dysdipsia, unsteady gait, dyskinesia, significantly increased involuntary movements of limbs, and fell numerous times. Cranial MRI showed abnormal signals in bilateral basal ganglia and thalamus. EEG demonstrated diffused theta waves. Slit-lamp examination showed Kayser–Fleischer ring in both eyes. Her serum ceruloplasmin concentration was low. 

The symptoms progressively worsened, and she had a fever without chills, cough, or diarrhea. The patient had difficulty in opening her mouth, could only speak one word at a time, and had occasional torsion spasm at the time of admission. The patient's physical examination revealed low-grade fever, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, dystonia, lack of coordination, slight tremor, dysarthria, dysphagia, and right side Babinski sign positive. 

Diagnosis and Treatment:

After admission, the patient was diagnosed with Wilson's disease, lupus, secondary Sjogren's syndrome with aPL antibodies. She had received initial treatment with iv sodium dimercaptopropane sulfonate (DMPS), full dose zinc sulfate for WD, and methylprednisolone, and hydroxychloroquine for lupus. Since the patient had three kinds of aPL antibodies being positive, she was also treated with anticoagulant therapy (low molecular weight heparin, and then aspirin). 

Outcome and Follow-up:

One month later, the patient's neurological symptoms and laboratory tests showed improvement. The patient was followed up every three months at the outpatient clinic. Six months after discharge, her symptoms recurred, and she developed hyponatremia, hematuria, and proteinuria when the steroid was reduced to 2mg/day. Hence, methylprednisolone dosage was increased to 16 mg/day, while the other treatment remained unchanged. Symptoms and abnormal laboratory findings were relieved in the next follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 30-year-old gravida 2 para 0

Hospital Course:
The patient presented at 31 + 3 weeks gestation with sudden onset, unprovoked, epigastric and left sided pleuritic chest pain. She reported no uterine tightenings, urinary symptoms or vaginal loss and normal foetal movements. The patient had a previous presentation of left lower lobe pneumonia at 13 weeks gestation. The patient was diagnosed with a large left diaphragmatic defect with stomach, small and large bowel, and spleen in the chest cavity and planned for an elective caesarean section at 34 weeks gestation. Due to the patient's inability to tolerate sufficient oral intake, an earlier delivery was planned at 32 + 3 weeks gestation.

Procedure:
A lower uterine segment caesarean section followed by a left thoracotomy was performed. The caesarean section was uncomplicated and resulted in the delivery of a liveborn female infant weighing 1731 g. The thoracotomy found a likely Bochdalek hernia involving stomach, small bowel, colon, appendix, spleen and omentum. The contents were successfully reduced and the defect was repaired with four figure of eight Prolene sutures.

Hospital Course and Discharge:
The patient made an uneventful recovery post-operatively and was discharged on day nine. The neonate was admitted to the special care nursery due to issues of prematurity, specifically, mild respiratory distress, difficulty establishing feeds and jaundice.

Follow-up:
The patient is instructed to follow-up with her primary obstetrician and pediatrician. She is advised to monitor her symptoms and contact her medical provider if she experiences any signs of complications.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: N/A
Gender: Male
Age: 69 years old
Medical Record Number: N/A

Chief Complaint:
Occult blood in the urine, proteinuria, and renal dysfunction.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, laboratory testing and renal biopsy were performed to further investigate the patient's symptoms. The patient had a history of untreated dyslipidemia, and no regular medication was being taken at the time of admission. Physical examination findings were unremarkable, with normal blood pressure. A urinalysis showed the presence of red blood cells, protein, and granular casts. Blood analyses showed a normal complete blood count, blood coagulation system, and normal immunoglobulin levels with negative autoantibodies.

Renal biopsy results showed mesangial cell proliferation, endocapillary hypercellularity, and infiltration of neutrophils and eosinophils. C3 and C1q were positive for immunofluorescence along the glomerular capillaries; however, immunoglobulin G (IgG) was negative, which is an unusual finding for immune-type glomerulonephritis (ITG). Electron microscopy showed marked endocapillary hypercellularity with infiltration of polymorphonuclear leukocytes and monocytes, and many tubular structures in parallel arrays with a hollow core in the subendothelial space.

Further testing revealed the presence of monoclonal immunoglobulins in serum and urine. Additionally, monoclonal gammopathy was present in a bone marrow biopsy specimen, with no significant uptake on 18F-fluoro-deoxy-glucose positron emission tomography. 

The patient was ultimately diagnosed with ITG with false-negative IgG staining. No medication or treatment plan was specified in the given case report.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient’s condition remained stable upon discharge.

Follow-Up:
Follow-up appointments with a renal specialist were recommended to monitor and manage the patient's renal dysfunction and proteinuria. 

Discharge Medications: N/A

Conditions for Follow-Up:
-Management of Proteinuria and Renal Dysfunction.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 32
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Length of Stay: 190 days
Discharge Diagnosis: Severe septic and neurogenic shock, abdominal wound dehiscence, and delayed initiation of oral intake

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital with appetite loss. He had a history of traumatic transverse cervical spinal cord injury at the C5 level due to suicide attempt at the age of 18. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) revealed a late-onset traumatic diaphragmatic hernia with strangulated ileum. The patient underwent emergency surgery which resulted in severe septic shock postoperatively. On postoperative days (POD) 3 and 6, cardiac arrest occurred which was treated with cardiopulmonary resuscitation. The patient developed colonic anastomotic leakage with diffuse peritonitis, abdominal wound dehiscence, and collapse of gastrostomy on POD 6. Due to his poor general condition with continuing severe septic and neurogenic shock, he underwent AVS which showed gradual healing followed by contraction and closure of wound dehiscence. The patient resumed oral intake on POD 112 and left the hospital on POD 190 with the gastrostomy balloon catheter and without incisional hernia.

Course of Treatment:
The patient received emergency surgery to replace the incarcerated organs to their original positions. Interrupted sutures with non-absorbable 1–0 monofilament were used to close the diaphragmatic orifice. Wedge resection with primary closure was performed for the colonic necrosis in two places. Partial resection, 45 cm long, with end-to-end anastomosis was performed for the small intestine. The necrotic omentum was removed. In addition, a gastrostomy tube was placed as delayed initiation of oral intake was expected. The patient developed severe septic shock postoperatively, which was treated with AVS through the open abdominal wound. 

Follow-up Care:
The patient was discharged with the gastrostomy balloon catheter which was placed due to the gastric fistula remaining. No incisional hernia was reported, and the patient was advised to follow up with his primary care physician for further monitoring and care.

Discharge Medications:
None were reported.

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Age: 3 years old
Gender: Female
Referring Physician: N/A
Admitting Diagnosis: Hypoplastic Amelogenesis Imperfecta (AIH)

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was referred to the Reference Centre of Rare Diseases in Paris at the age of three due to complaints of pain while eating, moderate sensitivity during tooth brushing and poor aesthetic aspect of her teeth. The intraoral examination revealed a hypoplastic AIH with yellow teeth and rough surfaces, brown extrinsic discoloration in the hypoplastic area, and reduced enamel thickness, giving the idea of a pseudo microdontia with multiple diastemas. Molars were the most affected teeth and showed reduced crown height. In addition, an anterior open bite was noted without thumb sucking.

Treatment was planned with three primary objectives: pain prevention and treatment, protection of dental tissue integrity in order to maintain occlusal function and limit dental biofilm retention, and restoration of smile aesthetics. The choice of treatment for the primary molars was stainless steel crowns (3 M™ ESPE™) due to lost occlusal morphology. This way, vertical dimension was slightly increased and maintained. The incisors and canines were isolated with a rubber dam and direct dental composite restorations were placed using Herculite composite resin with ER2 adhesives Optibond SL. The affected enamel was not removed, but bonding was directly applied to it. As enamel surface appeared rough, a flow composite (Tetric Evoflow, Ivoclar) was applied and served as intermediate material. Tooth morphology of anterior teeth was not severely altered and therefore “Odus” molds were not useful to offer a correct restoration. Composite resins were applied in one layer. Finishing and polishing were achieved with abrasive discs (Sof-lex/3 M ESPE).

Patient follow-ups were done 6 months and 1 year after treatment. Composite sealing and oral hygiene were controlled. The patient was discharged in stable condition after receiving appropriate dental treatment.

Discharge Diagnosis:
- Hypoplastic Amelogenesis Imperfecta (AIH)

Discharge Plan:
- Continue regular oral hygiene care
- Continue follow-ups with a dentist

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Name]
Hospital Admission Date: [Date]
Hospital Discharge Date: [Date]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was referred by her orthodontist to the Reference Centre of Rare Diseases in Paris for full mouth rehabilitation. She had undergone orthodontic treatment to close an anterior open bite and complained of difficulty and pain when chewing. Intraoral examination revealed hypomineralized AI and some hypoplasia.

Hospital Course:
Master impressions of the two arches were recorded and a composite veneer was applied on the incisors and composite full crowns on all other teeth. The restoration was bonded using dual-cured composite resin. The patient was monitored every 6 months and had a direct composite applied 3 years later on the cervical part of the crown due to gingival maturation. The restorations remained satisfactory after five years.

Hospital Discharge:
The patient was discharged with successful full mouth rehabilitation and no complaints of mastication issues. The patient was educated on oral hygiene and instructed to follow up with regular dental check-ups and cleanings.

[Patient Name] Discharge Summary 

Admission Date: [insert date] 
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Patient [insert patient name], a 72-year old male, was admitted to [insert hospital name] hospital for treatment of wet AMD in the left eye. The patient had been on a combination of angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor plus thiazide diuretic for a 20-year history of well controlled hypertension. He was treated with intravitreal injections of 0.5 mg ranibizumab, and the treatment was successful in resolving retinal hemorrhage and edema, leading to an improvement in visual acuity from 8/10 to 10/10. The patient was followed up routinely, but no abnormal findings were documented until May 2014, when visual acuity further reduced to 7/10, then to 3/10 in May 2015, when a reactivation of the neovascular membrane, edema, and pigment epithelial detachment were observed. The patient was managed with intravitreal injections of 0.5 mg ranibizumab, initially on a monthly basis and thereafter using a treat and extend approach, with overall six injections till the end of February 2016. By the time of the latest follow-up visit in May 2016, the neovascular membrane appeared inactive, and the visual acuity was stable at 6/10.

In February 2016, the patient reported an intermittent tremor on the left hand and presented to the Movement Disorders Clinic. Neurological examination revealed resting tremor on the left hand, mild bradykinesia of the left lower limb, and mild rigidity of head and trunk. Magnetic Resonance Imaging of the brain showed rare small subcortical white matter hyperintensities on T2 and some bilateral hypointensities in T1 in the striatum, compatible with small ischemic lesions. Single Photon Emission Computerized Tomography (SPECT) of the Dopamine Transporter (DAT) with 123I-ioflupane documented a significant and clear low uptake of DAT, mostly in the right striatum, consistent with PD.
 
A diagnosis of clinically established PD was made based on new criteria of the Movement Disorders Society. Treatment with levodopa/carbidopa (300 mg/daily) was started at the beginning of 2017, due to worsening of tremor and bradykinesia leading to gait impairment and fatigue. At follow-up examination in May 2017, response to levodopa was demonstrated by improvement of motor symptoms, particularly of gait.

The patient had two more injections of ranibizumab, and the visual acuity reduced to 3/10. At the time of discharge, the patient was in stable treatment with levodopa/carbidopa, with a motor UPDRS of 6/108. 

The patient was advised to follow up with his ophthalmologist and Movement Disorders Clinician regularly. An ophthalmology referral was recommended for the care of his left eye, and a referral to a physical therapist was recommended for continued management of his PD.

Overall, the patient's care during this hospitalization was satisfactory. The patient was discharged in stable condition, with the above recommendations and instructions.

Hospital Course Summary:

This hospital course summary pertains to a 35-year-old male who presented to the Emergency Department with a 10-day history of high-grade fever, shortness of breath, palpitations, and joint pain. The patient was found to have a history of intravenous drug abuse but denied any other medical conditions or allergies. A review of other organ systems was unremarkable. The patient had a known ostium secundum with left-to-right shunt, which was previously diagnosed by transoesophageal echocardiography. Further tests were conducted, including complete blood cell count, malarial and dengue tests, and serology for HIV and hepatitis. The CBC showed a slightly low hemoglobin level and an elevated total leukocyte count. All other tests were insignificant.

Given the persistent high-grade fever, Infective Endocarditis (IE) was suspected, and echocardiography and blood culture were performed. Echocardiography showed no vegetation. However, blood samples were found to be positive for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and treated accordingly with intravenous vancomycin and gentamicin for a period of six weeks. After the fever subsided, surgery for the closure of ASD was performed successfully. The patient was discharged from the hospital after good recovery and referred to a rehabilitation center for drug abuse. Continued monthly follow-up visits have since shown that the patient continues to do well.

Discharge Summary:

Mr. X, a 35-year-old male, was admitted to the Civil Hospital Karachi Emergency Department with a 10-day history of high-grade fever, joint pain, palpitations, and shortness of breath. The patient had a known ostium secundum with left-to-right shunt previously diagnosed by transoesophageal echocardiography. Upon physical examination, the patient was found to be dehydrated but responsive and alert. Blood pressure was slightly low, and respiratory rate was somewhat elevated with high-grade fever. Cardiovascular examination was negative for any murmur, and the lungs were clear on auscultation. Abdominal examination was also normal, except for an enlarged spleen.

The patient underwent a series of laboratory tests, including complete blood cell count, malarial and dengue tests, and serology for HIV and hepatitis. CBC showed a slightly low hemoglobin level and an elevated total leukocyte count. The other tests were negative.

Further, echocardiography and blood culture were performed due to a persistent high-grade fever, to which Infective Endocarditis (IE) was suspected. Echocardiography showed no vegetation. However, blood samples were found to be positive for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and treated accordingly with intravenous vancomycin and gentamicin for six weeks. After the fever subsided, surgery for the closure of ASD was performed successfully.

The patient responded well to treatment and showed good recovery. The patient was discharged and referred to a rehabilitation center for drug abuse. Follow-up visits have shown that the patient continues to do well.

Hospital Course:

The 39-year-old male patient presented with rectal adenocarcinoma with metastases to the liver. He underwent neoadjuvant chemotherapy and long-course chemoradiation, followed by laparoscopic-assisted low anterior resection with colorectal pelvic anastomosis and diverting loop ileostomy. Pathology revealed ypT4N1b rectal adenocarcinoma with lymphovascular invasion. The patient's liver lesions were treated with several courses of microwave ablation and chemoembolization. However, a restaging PET-CT scan five months later showed a new single site of disease within a left pelvic sidewall lymph node. The patient was referred for curative-intent radiation therapy and was treated with MR-guided SBRT. 

Summary:

The patient was treated with MR-guided SBRT to the left pelvic sidewall lymph node. The treatment was delivered in five fractions with no acute toxicity experienced by the patient. One month after completion of SBRT, the patient underwent a successful ileostomy reversal. Repeat MRI at two months post-SBRT showed no evidence of disease.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of right upper abdominal tenderness, nausea, vomiting, and mild to moderate pain radiating to the back. The patient also reported a weight loss of 10 kg over the last two months. Upon evaluation, a palpable, poorly defined, mildly to moderately tender tumor-like firmness was detected in the right upper quadrant. The laboratory evaluations showed elevated white blood cell count, bilirubin, and cancer marker CA 19-9 was within normal range. Imaging techniques, including computed tomography, revealed a large mass replacing the gallbladder body and fundus with an extensive involvement of the adjacent liver segments, the duodenum, the head of the pancreas, and the hepatic flexure of the colon. Advanced stage IIIb-IVa CG was the main differential diagnosis. Surgical exploration revealed a mass occupying the entire subhepatic space adherent to other structures, and an extensive surgical resection of the mass was performed with adjacent liver segments and loco-regional lymph nodes. The surgical pathology revealed an XG tumor with multiple areas of crowding of foamy macrophages and xanthoma cells, alongside foreign body granulomas consisting of cholesterol and tiny bile lakes. Mild to moderate reactive inflammatory changes of the adjacent hepatic tissue were noted with lymphocytic infiltration of portal tracts and fatty degeneration. The enlarged periportal lymph nodes showed a nonspecific inflammatory reaction.

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged home on day seven post-operation in good condition.

Follow-up:

The patient is advised to follow-up for regular check-ups to monitor with their primary care physician.

Primary Diagnosis:  Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis (XG)

Secondary Diagnosis: None

Procedures:

- Extensive surgical resection including adjacent liver segments and loco-regional lymph nodes for proper staging and prognosis.

Summary:

A 67-year-old woman was admitted to the hospital with complaints of right upper abdominal tenderness, nausea, vomiting, and mild to moderate pain radiating to the back. Advanced stage IIIb-IVa CG was the main differential diagnosis, and surgical exploration confirmed a mass occupying the subhepatic space. An extensive surgical resection was performed removing the entire mass with adjacent liver segments and loco-regional lymph nodes for proper staging and prognosis. The postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged home on day seven in good condition.

Hospital Course:
Patient 1, a 13-month-old female with 73% TBSA third-degree burns and an open joint injury in her right knee, was treated with SEF after four skin grafting procedures. A micro-SEF system consisting of K-wires and a 140-mm bar was used for treatment. The patient required one additional skin grafting procedure to her right knee after SEF was in place. The patient had an eight-month follow-up, during which her PT/OT notes reported ROM within normal limits (WNL) and a 5/5 motor strength. The patient did experience continued joint instability after SEF that required eight weeks of knee immobilizer use. However, no long-term complications requiring additional surgeries were recorded. 

Discharge Summary:
Patient 1 had sustained third-degree burns from a house fire and was treated with SEF placement following four skin grafting procedures. The patient was observed for eight months post-injury, with her PT/OT notes indicating WNL range of motion and 5/5 motor strength. Though the patient developed continued joint instability following SEF treatment, immobilization therapy provided relief without requiring additional surgery.

Discharge Summary:

Patient 2, a 10-year-8-month-old male, sustained a severe flame injury after a motor vehicle accident (MVA) resulting in 62.5% third-degree burn wounds in TBSA. The patient underwent seven skin grafting procedures to treat an open joint injury in his right elbow. An external fixator system with Shantz pins and bars was placed following the skin grafting procedures, and the system was locked in full extension. The patient was maintained on this external fixator system for six weeks and required no further treatment for his right elbow. 

The patient had a 10-month follow-up after the injury, and his PT/OT notes indicated no other complications recorded. His final arc of motion was 30–110° in the extension and flexion range, with supination and pronation WNL and a 5/5 motor strength.  

The patient is being discharged in good condition with no further complications observed during the hospital stay and follow-up sessions. Ongoing rehabilitation therapy is recommended to support and encourage the patient's continued recovery. The patient's family was provided with adequate instructions regarding post-discharge care and were advised to follow up with their regular healthcare provider.

Patient Information:
Name: Patient 3
Gender: Male
Age: 4 years and 4 months old

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A
Duration of Stay: N/A

Diagnosis:
The patient sustained a flame injury from a house fire resulting in 41.5% total body surface area third-degree injuries. He also had an open joint injury in his right elbow prior to SEF placement.

Treatment:
The patient underwent two skin grafting procedures before SEF placement, which occurred 43 days after the injury. Shantz pins and bars using the Synthes medium external fixator system were placed which was locked in full extension. The patient had an elbow contracture that was treated with an antecubital soft tissue plastic surgery contracture release.

Outcomes:
The patient did not require any additional skin grafting procedures to his right elbow after SEF placement. Prior to the surgical release, the patient had a range of motion of 0-25° in the extension and flexion arc and 0° in both supination and pronation. After the 13-month follow-up, the patient had a final range of motion of 0°-119° in the extension and flexion arc, 69° in supination, and 80° in pronation. The patient had a 5/5 motor strength with the only complication being the elbow contracture. 

Recommendations:
None.

Follow-Up:
The patient should follow up with his healthcare provider as needed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient 4 is a 17-year-9-month-old male who sustained a flame and electrical injury after a motor vehicle accident involving a power line. He had 30% total body surface area third-degree injuries, including an open joint injury to his right elbow. He underwent several procedures prior to transfer to our institution. Upon admission, he received a small external fixator (SEF) placement for his elbow injury, using 4-millimeter Shantz pins and bars from the Synthes external fixator set.

The SEF was kept in place for 7.5 weeks but failed due to under sizing, resulting in a need for a revision with a large external fixator system. The patient also required three additional skin grafting procedures to his right elbow after SEF placement. 

At the time of discharge, the patient's physical therapy and occupational therapy reports noted a final range of motion of 0°–110° in the extension and flexion arc, 30° supination, and 70° pronation. However, the patient experienced continued weakness with elbow flexion, extension, and pronation/supination motor strength. 

The patient's complications were identified to be SEF failure and weakness. Further follow-up was recommended to monitor the patient's progress and to address any further concerns.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Patient: [Patient name, age, and gender]

Medical History:
The patient sustained a flame burn from an MVA resulting in 25% TBSA third-degree injuries. The left knee had an open joint injury that required three skin grafting procedures prior to external fixator placement.

Hospital Course:
SEF was placed 74 days after injury using Shantz pins and bars. The patient required no additional skin grafting procedures to the left knee after SEF placement. There were no ROM measurements recorded because the left knee was immobilized for an extended period in full extension.

Complications:
The patient experienced several complications, including significant damage to the medial collateral ligament, and spontaneous knee fusion of the medial femoral epiphysis. Due to the growth plate disturbances, the patient developed a varus deformity and leg length discrepancy of 4.0 cm, causing persistent pain requiring an osteotomy and Ilizarov placement for correction and lengthening.

Outcome:
The patient was discharged after a stay of [number] days for continued follow-up care with rehabilitation and orthopedic services. 

Follow-Up:
The patient is to continue follow-up with rehabilitation and orthopedic services.

Discharge Summary:

Patient 7, an 8-year-5-month-old male, sustained a flame burn from an MVA resulting in 79% TBSA third-degree injuries. His right knee sustained an open joint injury and was treated with six skin grafting procedures prior to SEF placement. The SEF was placed 61 days after the injury using the Smith Nephew Richards system with 5.0-mm Shantz pins and bars. The SEF was kept on for five weeks, after which he required no additional skin grafting procedures. 

A 10-month follow-up after the injury recorded the final ROM of 0°–45° in the extension and flexion arc, with the last recorded motor strength being 3+/5. His complication involved residual knee stiffness and weakness. 

The patient's SEF placement was successful in preventing the need for additional skin grafting procedures to the left knee. Further follow-up evaluations may be required to monitor the patient's residual knee stiffness and weakness. Appropriate clinical interventions should be conducted to address this issue.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient 8 is a 16-year-6-month-old male who sustained a 48% TBSA third-degree electrical burn injury to his body, including an open joint injury to his right elbow that was treated with six skin grafting procedures prior to SEF placement. The SEF was placed 53 days after the injury and kept on for six weeks. The patient underwent two additional surgeries after the SEF was removed, including an ulnar nerve transposition, heterotopic ossification removal, contracture release with arthrofibrosis excision, and a flap to cover soft tissue deficit that occurred after the elbow release. The patient presents with a final ROM of 20°–90° in the extension and flexion arc, supination, and pronation were not tested, and a 4-/5 motor strength. Prior to his elbow contracture release, he had an ROM of 0°–30° in the extension and flexion arc, supination of 25°, and pronation 85°, and the motor strength was not tested. The patient experienced complications such as heterotopic ossification, cubital tunnel syndrome, and elbow stiffness.

Summary:

Patient 8 is a 16-year-6-month-old male who was treated for a 48% TBSA third-degree electrical burn injury. The patient underwent several procedures, including skin grafting and SEF placement, to treat an open joint injury on his right elbow. After the SEF was removed, the patient underwent two additional surgeries to address complications such as heterotopic ossification, cubital tunnel syndrome, and elbow stiffness. Although the patient had a limited range of motion before the contracture release, he presents with improvements in his range of motion and motor strength during a 13-month follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Admission Date: [Redacted]

Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Brief Hospital Course:

The patient is a 64-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with worsening dyspnea, cough, and unintentional weight loss. She was started on levofloxacin by her primary physician for suspected pneumonia, but her initial antibiotic therapy failed to alleviate her symptoms. A CT scan of the chest revealed multiple cystic lesions in both lungs and a lesion in the liver.

The patient underwent various diagnostic workups to evaluate her lung and liver disease, including viral, bacterial, and fungal infection workups, hepatitis panel, and expanded connective tissue disease workup. Cancer markers showed an elevated cancer antigen 19-9.

An abdominal ultrasound showed innumerable cystic lesions throughout the liver with intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary and pancreatic duct dilatation. Liver biopsy results were not conclusive for a specific diagnosis, which led to a lung biopsy. Pathological examination of the lung tissue showed metastatic moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe, middle lobe, and lower lobe.

The patient was referred to an oncologist for further management and treatment. She was provided with appropriate education for her condition, including expected symptoms, potential complications, follow-up care, and necessary lifestyle modifications.

Hospital Course Summary:

1. Reason for Admission: Worsening dyspnea, cough, and unintentional weight loss.
2. Diagnostic Workups: Viral, bacterial, and fungal infection workups; hepatitis panel; expanded connective tissue disease workup; cancer markers; abdominal ultrasound; liver biopsy; and lung biopsy.
3. Diagnosis: Metastatic moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe, middle lobe, and lower lobe.
4. Management and Treatment: Referral to an oncologist for further management and treatment; provision of appropriate education for the patient.
5. Discharge Condition: Stable.

Hospital Course:
The patient, an 87-year-old man with a significant past medical history, was admitted to the hospital after being found drowsy and unresponsive. On examination, he was found to have a new onset right hemiparesis and underwent a CT brain which revealed air bubbles within the dural venous sinuses and pneumocephalus. A facial bone CT was done, which showed a minimally displaced fracture of the lateral wall of the right maxillary sinus. Of note, a left middle cerebral artery territory infarct with hemorrhagic conversion was found on the repeat CT brain one month later.

Management:
Given the severity of the stroke, the patient was conservatively managed. Statins were started, and antiplatelets were held off in view of significant hemorrhagic conversion causing midline shift. He underwent physiotherapy but remained bed-ridden. Dual antiplatelet therapy was started one month later, after significant improvement was noted in the repeat CT brain.

Outcome:
Despite medical management, the patient demised one month after the initial presentation. No further interventions were planned or initiated.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with left lower quadrant abdominal pain and elevated creatinine, which was subsequently identified on routine blood draw at a follow-up urology appointment. Computed tomography abdomen revealed hydronephrosis of the left kidney as well as bilateral ureteral thickening. The patient had a right ureter stent placed one month prior after presenting with acute kidney injury.

Diagnostic Assessment:
Urinalysis and pregnancy testing were negative. Further workup, including chest x-ray, sexually transmitted infection testing, complement activity levels, and other autoimmune markers, was negative. Biopsies of ureter specimens showed findings of benign epithelial growth and chronic inflammation.

Treatment and Procedures:
During this admission, a stent was placed in the left ureter and the right ureter stent was replaced. Repeat biopsies of both the right and left ureters showed findings of benign epithelial growth and chronic inflammation.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient was discharged home symptom-free with close urologic follow-up.

Hospital Course:
A two-week-old female was admitted due to multiple masses found on her body since birth. Physical examination revealed two masses on the forehead and the scalp measuring 26 mm by 19 mm and 19 mm by 17 mm and a smaller mass on the abdomen, measuring 11 mm by 10 mm. The masses remained the same size since birth and were confirmed to be congenital hemangiomas through an ultrasound and Doppler examination. No other systemic abnormalities were found.

Diagnostic Assessment:
Full blood count revealed normal results with no masses or lesions observed on ultrasound examination of the liver, spleen, and kidneys. Doppler examination showed a fast-flow vascular lesion consistent with congenital hemangiomas.

Treatment:
A wait-and-watch approach was adopted, and the patient was scheduled for regular visits at three months. The family was educated about the condition and possible complications including the need for surgical treatment if the masses fail to regress or continue to grow.

Summary:
A two-week-old female was admitted for multiple masses found since birth. A diagnosis of congenital hemangioma was confirmed, and a wait-and-watch approach was adopted. The family was educated regarding the condition and possible complications. Regular visits were scheduled to monitor the masses.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 19
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Atlanto-occipital and atlanto-axial dissociation
Discharge Diagnosis: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the emergency department with a complaint of neck pain after being ejected from a motor vehicle during a road traffic accident. Complete spinal precautions were taken at the scene, and the patient was transported to our hospital. Upon arrival, she was found to have an associated comminuted left femur fracture. CT of the cervical spine revealed concomitant atlanto-occipital and atlanto-axial dissociation. Further MRI testing confirmed the diagnosis with total ligamentous disruption at the craniovertebral junction and distraction of the atlanto-axial joints bilaterally.

The patient was immobilized with a crown-halo vest and underwent urgent posterior occipitocervical fusion surgery. She was discharged on a rigid collar and was advised to follow-up with her physician for continuous monitoring. During her one-year follow-up appointment, she reported no neck pain, neurological abnormalities, or dysphagia, and her cervical collar was removed.

The patient's hospital course has been uneventful, and she has been managed well throughout the entire treatment period. She was found to be stable upon discharge and given explicit instructions to rest and refrain from strenuous activities for the next few weeks after discharge to ensure the effective healing of her injury.

Follow Up Care and Recommendations:
The patient is advised to follow-up with her primary care physician and specialists for further evaluation and monitoring of her condition. She is also advised to resume her normal activities gradually, with appropriate guidance from her healthcare professionals.

The patient is advised to follow all instructions and precautions given by her healthcare professionals to ensure optimal healing and reduce the risk of any potential complications or injuries.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Age: 71

Sex: Female

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Date of Procedure: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Right hip fracture

Procedure Performed: Both component revision arthroplasty

Hospital Course: The patient, a 71-year-old female with a history of a right hip intra-capsular fracture and subsequent total hip replacement, presented to the emergency department with a Vancouver B3 peri-prosthetic fracture after a fall at home. She underwent a both component revision arthroplasty procedure which involved removal of the prosthesis and cement from the proximal femur and insertion of a modular endoprosthesis (LPS ® DePuy Limb Preservation System (Warsaw, IN, USA) proximal femoral replacement). The acetabular component was also revised. A trochanteric claw plate was used to re-attach the bone of the proximal femur to the prosthesis to ensure good abductor function. The patient tolerated the surgery well and was able to commence immediate full weight-bearing, protected with a Zimmer frame, on postoperative day one. At her six-week postoperative evaluation, she was ambulating independently, though continued with the use of her walking frame for ‘balance and confidence’.

Conditions at Discharge: The patient was discharged with stable vital signs and overall good health.

Summary: The patient underwent a both component revision arthroplasty procedure for a Vancouver B3 peri-prosthetic fracture of the right hip. She tolerated the surgery well and was able to commence immediate full weight-bearing, protected with a Zimmer frame, on postoperative day one. At her six-week postoperative evaluation, she was ambulating independently, though continued with the use of her walking frame for ‘balance and confidence’. She was discharged with stable vital signs and overall good health.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 71-year-old female, was admitted to the hospital with generalized tonic-clonic seizure activity. During an endobronchial biopsy procedure to evaluate a perihilar mass, the patient developed an initial seizure, followed by mottled discoloration of her skin, spreading from her abdomen to both shoulders. Bag ventilation was started, and she was transferred to the surgical ICU and intubated. A CT head revealed multiple air emboli. Subsequent EEG monitoring showed frequent periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges.
Neurological examination revealed areflexic quadriplegia, sluggish but reactive bilateral pupils and Glasgow Coma Scale was 3(E:1;V:1;M:1). The patient was transferred to the neurological ICU after which her neurological examination remained the same. EEG on day 14 of her admission showed changes indicating severe diffuse encephalopathy. No seizure activity was noted on EEG.
CSF analysis revealed an elevated myelin basic protein but with undetected WBCs, RBCs and negative cytology. MRI of the brain showed progressive diffuse white matter changes in a watershed distribution and centrum semiovale. The patient was eventually weaned from her anti-epileptic regimen to levetiracetam monotherapy. She slowly improved but required tracheostomy and percutaneous gastrostomy tube. She was eventually transferred to an acute rehabilitation facility.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: N/A
Gender: Female
Age: 75 years
Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient with a past medical history of fibromyalgia and Sjogren's syndrome presented to the emergency department with severe hypertension. She was not taking any medication at home. On physical examination, the patient had 2+ pitting edema of lower extremities, and the rest of the examination was unremarkable. The patient's blood pressure was controlled after administering hydralazine and clonidine.

The patient's past medical record in the hospital showed increased creatinine (3.8 mg/dl) with blood urea nitrogen of 29 mg/dl, unlike her creatinine level of 2.5 mg/dl, a year ago. Further workup revealed 24-hour proteinuria of 3.89 grams. Urine dipstick showed 3+ protein, 5-10 red blood cells and 10-15 white blood cells per high power field. The patient was suspected to have acute interstitial nephritis or possible immune-complex-mediated disease due to her past medical history of Sjogren's syndrome.

On light microscopy (LM), moderate interstitial fibrosis and moderate intimal fibrosis were present in vessels with no thrombosis or vasculitis. IF showed diffuse global 3+ smudgy mesangial of the capillary wall noted with IgG. Glomerular staining showed 1+ IgM, C1q, 2+ C3, 1+ staining with both kappa and lambda light chains. EM confirmed the presence of extensive electron dense deposits in the expanded mesangial regions and throughout the thickened glomerular basement membranes.

The patient was monitored, and nephrology was consulted for further evaluation. The patient was discharged once her condition was stable.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient's blood pressure was controlled, and her edema improved. She was discharged in a stable condition with instructions to follow up with a nephrologist.

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Instructions on Discharge:
The patient was instructed to follow up with a nephrologist and continue to monitor her blood pressure and edema.

N/A

N/A

N/A
