Nephrology

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 49-year-old female with a past medical history of hypertension, preeclampsia, anxiety, and bipolar disorder on buspirone.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department with a persistent headache which started one week prior to arrival. She had nausea and vomiting associated with it. She had visited an urgent care facility and outside hospital with similar symptoms but had no relief. The patient was admitted for an elevated troponin level and received a cardiac catheterization without intervention. She was discharged but presented again due to persistent headache. The patient was placed in the observation unit and a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain was ordered which resulted in acute infarction, showing 3 punctate regions of focal restricted diffusion in the left middle frontal gyrus, right parietal lobe, and left temporal lobe.

Diagnosis:
The differential diagnosis was vasculitis versus RCVS.

Treatment:
Neurology was consulted, and the patient was admitted to the stroke service. The patient underwent a stroke workup which included computed tomography angiography of the head and neck, transthoracic echocardiogram, and a transesophageal echocardiogram. The angiogram showed evidence of RCVS. The patient was started on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel, and the patient was discharged to follow up with the stroke clinic and her primary care provider.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition had improved.

Discharge Medications:
The patient's discharge medications were not provided.

Follow-Up:
The patient was instructed to follow up with the stroke clinic and her primary care provider for further evaluation and management.

Hospital Course:

Admitted for suspected LC, CT scan confirmed primary tumor in the right middle lobe and metastases in lymph nodes, brain, adrenal glands, and bones. Histological examination of a needle biopsy of the left cervical lymph node confirmed adenocarcinoma. Patient diagnosed with stage IVB LC and underwent chemotherapy with carboplatin, paclitaxel, and bevacizumab. During the chemotherapy session, patient complained of severe right lower quadrant pain and was diagnosed with appendicitis by enhanced CT scan showing an enlarged appendix and fluid collection near the distal appendix. Laparoscopic appendectomy was performed, and histological analysis revealed invasive adenocarcinoma in the appendix that infiltrated the mucosal, submucosal, and muscular layers. Positive immunostaining of TTF-1 indicated that the appendiceal metastasis was from pulmonary adenocarcinoma. Patient discharged after an uneventful postoperative course. Chemotherapy was resumed after surgery under the supervision of the pulmonary internist. No additional metastases or peritoneal dissemination were found during laparoscopic survey of the abdominal cavity.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A
Duration of Hospital Stay: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 19-year-old primigravida Greek Pomak woman who was recently diagnosed with hereditary antithrombin (AT) deficiency. She had previously suffered two first-trimester pregnancy losses and was referred for thrombophilia testing. Her basic screening for thrombophilia was normal, except for an AT activity of 51%.

Three months after diagnosis, the patient became pregnant again. She was managed with an adjusted dose of low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) throughout pregnancy and monitored monthly with d-dimers, AT activity, and anti-Xa measurements. Her pregnancy was uneventful, and a cesarean section was scheduled at the 39th week due to breech presentation of the fetus.

Prior to delivery, the patient received Kybernin P (human AT III concentrate) prophylactically to overcome the risk of thrombosis. She proceeded to have general anesthesia and received tinzaparin subcutaneously 8 hours later at the conventional dose of 4500 IU. The patient delivered a healthy baby without complications. Functional AT levels were measured daily prior to each dose of AT and levels were maintained between 60 and 100%.

The patient developed an allergic reaction after the fifth dose of AT, so AT was discontinued, and tinzaparin was increased at the prior dose of 14,000 IU/day. She was discharged 6 days after delivery without complications, and tinzaparin 4500 IU daily was continued for 6 weeks postpartum.

Diagnoses:
- Hereditary antithrombin (AT) deficiency
- Previous two first-trimester pregnancy losses

Procedures:
- Cesarean section

Plan:
- Continue adjusted dose of low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) throughout pregnancy
- Monitor monthly with d-dimers, AT activity, and anti-Xa measurements
- Manage with Kybernin P (human AT III concentrate) prophylactically to overcome the risk of thrombosis
- Functional AT levels were measured daily prior to each dose of AT and levels were maintained between 60 and 100%
- Discharge with tinzaparin 4500 IU daily for 6 weeks postpartum

Follow-Up:
- Follow up for further management of hereditary antithrombin (AT) deficiency

Discharge Summary
Patient Name: Not Provided
Medical Record Number: Not Provided
Admission Date: Not Provided
Discharge Date: Not Provided

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of erythematous plaques and pain over the left upper limb and foreign object sensation in the throat when swallowing. She was diagnosed with tetanus and BB accompanied by T1LR. The patient had a 6-year history of leprosy and was treated with MDT resulting in a clinical cure in 2012. Initially, T1LR was suspected, followed by treatment with oral methylprednisolone. However, the patient's symptoms worsened, with neck muscle tension and difficulty in opening her mouth, and the erythematous plaques had spread over most of her left upper limb.

On physical examination, the patient displayed shortness of breath and facial expressions indicating trismus and difficulty speaking. The patient's abdominal muscles were too stiff for palpation of the liver and spleen. There was persistent stiffness in the neck and limbs, together with opisthotonus, and occasional paroxysmal spasms. The patient's bilateral ulnar nerves and right common peroneal nerve were thickened and exhibited tenderness. The patient exhibited right foot drop, atrophy of the extensor of the right lower leg, and an ulcer on the right foot.

Treatment:
The patient was administered 100,000 IU tetanus antitoxin in a 500-ml 5% glucose-saline intravenous infusion daily, 200,000 U penicillin in an intramuscular injection four times a day, and 200 mg of hydrocortisone in a 250-ml 5% glucose intravenous infusion daily. Additionally, 10 mg/day of diazepam and 50 mg/day of phenergan were given by intramuscular injection. The patient was hospitalized in a dark, quiet room to reduce light stimulation and prevent spasms. In addition, a dental pad was placed in the oral cavity to prevent the patient from biting her tongue. The ulcer on her right foot was debrided every day, followed by rinsing with 3% hydrogen peroxide and injection of 20,000 IU tetanus antitoxin around the wound. The paroxysmal spasticity and intensity of the spasms started to decrease after 5 days.

Outcome:
Twelve days later, the patient was discharged from the hospital in stable condition. She was followed up in our outpatient department and treated with MDT and oral prednisone to prevent T1LR for 4 months. The erythematous plaques and neuropathic pain eventually subsided.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented with symptoms of erythematous plaques and pain over the left upper limb and foreign object sensation in the throat when swallowing. She had a history of leprosy and was diagnosed with tetanus and BB accompanied by T1LR. The patient received appropriate treatment and was discharged after 12 days of hospitalization. She was followed up in our outpatient department and was treated with MDT and oral prednisone to prevent T1LR for 4 months. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A	MRN: N/A

Admission Date: N/A	Discharge Date: N/A

Diagnosis:
- Cerebellar Tumor

Hospital Course:
- A 39-year-old Italian man was admitted to the hospital with headache and nausea over the past months.
- CT and MRI scans revealed a 39 × 37 × 29 mm ill-defined tumor in the right cerebellar hemisphere.
- Surgery was indicated, consent was obtained, and performed.
- A postoperative CT scan and MRI showed no residual tumor.
- The patient remained in the neurosurgical intensive care unit for one night and was transferred to a general ward the following day without neurological deficiency.
- He received no adjuvant treatment and there has been no evidence of tumor recurrence over a period of 15 months.
- A neurological examination at last follow-up, 15 months after surgery, revealed no neurological deficits. The preoperative nausea and headache he experienced had stopped.

Medical History:
- The patient did not suffer from any other comorbidities.
- The patient had not undergone any surgeries.
- The patient did not use medication.
- The patient had never consumed alcohol, smoked tobacco, or used other drugs.
- Similar cases were not reported in the patient's family; no relatives had suffered from a tumor in the past.

Laboratory and Imaging:
- Blood pressure, pulse, temperature, and laboratory findings (complete blood count, liver function, renal function, and C-reactive protein) were within normal range.
- CT and MRI scans showed an ill-defined, 39 × 37 × 29 mm tumor that presented as slightly hypointense with poor contrast enhancement.

Histopathology:
- Hematoxylin and eosin-stained paraffin sections showed predominantly small to moderately cellular tumor growing compactly, sometimes diffuse, infiltrating the surrounding cerebellar tissue.
- No significant mitotic activity, < 1 mitosis/20 high-power field (HPF), and no necrosis were observed.
- Some tumor cells showed an astrocytic differentiation.
- NeuN was detected in 80% and synaptophysin was detected in 30% of the non-lipomatous cells.
- Tumor cells were negative for neurofilament and chromogranin A.
- GFAP was observed in 20% of the tumor cells.
- Ki-67/MIB-1 proliferation index, as determined by nuclear MIB1 monoclonal antibody staining, was around 2%.

Follow-Up:
- The patient will follow up as an outpatient with his primary care physician.

Plan:
- Recommend MRI surveillance every 6-12 months.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 42 year-old female

Chief Complaint: Subgingivally fractured permanent maxillary left central incisor

Hospital Course:

The patient was referred to the Master of Endodontics of the University of Santiago de Compostela with a subgingivally fractured permanent maxillary left central incisor as a result of a domestic accident. A thorough clinical examination showed a heavily restored maxillary left central incisor that was tender to palpation. Radiographic examinations revealed an oblique crown-root fracture that extended approximately one-third of the root length. Further radiographic findings showed periapical radiolucencies in the adjacent upper left lateral incisor and canine, both teeth remaining negative to cold testing. The diagnosis was a globulomaxillary cyst, and both teeth were root canal treated and the cyst enucleated. Orthodontic extrusion of the fractured permanent maxillary central incisor was performed to move the vestibular fracture line approximately 6mm above the alveolar crest. Brackets were attached from upper right first premolar to upper left first premolar and an extrusion of approximately 6mm was obtained within 6 months. The root canal retreatment was performed and a fiber post was placed using a dual-cure cement. The tooth was prepared for a crown and a temporary crown was placed until the ceramic crown was created. An external full mouth tooth whitening was performed before determining the shade of the permanent crown, which was subsequently seated to the prepared tooth. The upper right central incisor was restored using composite and good aesthetics were achieved.

Course in Hospital:

1. Comprehensive clinical examination
2. Radiographic examinations performed
3. Diagnosis: Globulomaxillary cyst
4. Orthodontic extrusion of the fractured tooth 
5. Root canal retreatment
6. Tooth prepared for crown 
7. Temporary crown placed 
8. External full mouth tooth whitening 
9. Permanent ceramic crown placed 
10. Upper right central incisor restored using composite 

Outpatient Course:

Following treatment, the patient reported no problems after 4 years of follow-up. 

Final Diagnosis:
Subgingivally fractured permanent maxillary left central incisor due to domestic accident, with associated globulomaxillary cyst requiring root canal treatment and enucleation, followed by orthodontic extrusion and placement of a ceramic crown.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not provided
Gender: Female
Age: 47
Medical History: No significant findings reported.

Chief Complaint: Tender MOD composite restoration tooth with periodic episodes of spontaneous pain.

History of Present Illness: The patient was referred to the Endodontic Clinic of Dental Faculty at the University of Strasbourg for clinical evaluation due to tenderness of the left maxillary premolar with an MOD composite restoration. Radiographic examination suggested an unusual anatomic variation that required endodontic dilacerated anatomy. Endodontic treatment was performed in a single session using a combination of mechanical and manual instrumentation, and final obturation was achieved using Thermafil 2.

Hospital Course Summary:
Day 1: Patient presented with a tender MOD composite restoration tooth with periodic episodes of spontaneous pain. Endodontic access was performed under local anesthesia, and initial instrumentation was performed using OneG and TS1 files.
Day 2: Shaping of the canals was performed using TS1, and apical gauging was confirmed using a 25/02 file. The canal system was irrigated with 6% NaOCl solution and 17% EDTA solution. Obturation was achieved using Thermafil 2 and Kerr EWT pulp canal sealer.
Day 3: The final radiographs showed two well-obturated canals of this single rooted maxillary premolar. The patient was discharged after monitoring for any adverse effects post-therapy.

Follow-Up Recommendations: Follow-up appointments should be scheduled, and regular dental check-ups are recommended to ensure the long-term health of the tooth.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:

Name: [patient name]
Age: 58
Sex: Female
Race: Caucasian

Hospital Course:
The patient was referred to the endodontics clinic for a second premolar retreatment. Endodontic treatment was performed in two sessions. The tooth had a prosthetic metal crown and was tender to percussion with episodes of spontaneous pain.

Results:
Periapical radiographic examination revealed the presence of a single root with an unusual anatomical variation and probable endodontic dilacerated anatomy. The lingual canal was treated with an usual technique of manual scouting, glide path and shaping with a #08 stainless steel K-file. However, after the use of SX opener, a #08 stainless steel K-file was short of the working length (WL). Hence, a mechanical glide-path with Proglider at working length was performed using an endodontic engine followed by root canal preparation with ProTaper Next X1 and X2 and manual 20/02-25/02 NiTi hand file sliding down the glide path up to working length. The buccal canal was treated with a modern step-down technique without initial manual scouting. The initial mechanical preflaring was performed at first with Proglider until above the first root canal curvature, and then the apical scouting, glide path and shaping was done with ProTaper Next X1, X2 and manual 20/02-25/02 NiTi hand file sliding down the glide path up to working length, which was determined using an electronic apex locator. After shaping, both sites were filled with Thermafil 25 after 3D cleaning of the root canal system. 

Outcomes:
The final radiographs showed two well-obturated canals with some lateral canal of this single rooted maxillary premolar.

Impressions:
The endodontic treatment was successful. 

Follow-up plan:
Clinical follow-up was recommended.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [redacted]

Medical Record Number: [redacted]

Date of Admission: [redacted]

Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Diagnosis:
The patient presented with a large, painful perineal protrusion that was found to be a hydrocolpos secondary to an imperforate hymen. This was confirmed by physical exam, blood work, and computed tomography (CT). The remainder of the hymen was removed endoscopically. The patient's symptoms of dysuria, pollakiuria, and perineal swelling resolved after the procedure.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent a vaginal exam which revealed a large, thin-walled, fluctuant structure filling the vaginal lumen. The structure was perforated and drained of approximately 200 mL of brown, mucoid fluid. No bacteria were seen on cytology, and no organisms were cultured from the fluid. A sample was collected for cytology and culture. Vaginoscopy revealed remnants of an imperforate hymen just cranial to the external urethral orifice. The remainder of the hymen was removed endoscopically with grasping forceps and submitted for histopathology. The patient was discharged with instructions to complete the previously prescribed course of marbofloxacin.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was clinically normal at follow-up 2 months after the procedure.

Instructions:
The patient is to complete the previously prescribed course of marbofloxacin. No further treatment is necessary as the patient's condition has resolved.

Follow-up:
The patient should return for a follow-up appointment 2 months after the procedure.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Case 1
Age: 11-Year-Old
Sex: Male
Breed: Border Collie

Hospital Course:

Case 1 was admitted with clinical symptoms of malaise, inappetence, and external signs of internal bleeding. Ultrasonography revealed a large renal mass and the spread of metastasis towards the lungs. The patient was entered into a research protocol that involved high dose oral DHEA and ubiquinone. A rapid improvement in quality of life was observed within a few days of initiation of the protocol.

However, the patient developed a generalized inflammatory condition that affected his nasal passages, skin, and eyes. Skin lesions ranged from nonpruritic maculopapular rash to urticaria, erythema nodosum, and purpura. The oral mucosa was inflamed, and uveitis was prominent. Zinc supplementation did not help alleviate the inflammatory condition.

After studying earlier in vitro work, it was found that inhibition of the mevalonate pathway may have caused the autoinflammatory reaction observed. Administration of oral, encapsulated geraniol led to the rapid clearing of all lesions within 3.5 days. The patient survived 315 days from original diagnosis, with pulmonary metastasis being the cause of death.

Follow-Up Plan:

The patient is no longer under our care and has passed away. No further follow-up is required.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Case 2
Patient Age: Four-and-one-half-year-old
Gender: Female
Weight: 28.4 kg
Breed: Doberman Pinscher
Admission Date: October 2015
Discharge Date: May 2017

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our facility with non-weight bearing lameness and muscle atrophy on the right hind limb in October 2015. Radiology revealed periosteal reaction on the right ischiatic table with a mass-like effect in the adjacent musculature. Ultrasound showed an intramuscular mass, confirmed to be a soft tissue sarcoma. The recommended treatment of amputation followed by traditional chemotherapy was declined by the owners.

The patient was enrolled in our G6PD inhibition protocol and treated with daily doses of DHEA and ubiquinone. During treatment, the patient exhibited an acute inflammatory reaction in the eyes, which was followed by multiple inflammatory cutaneous lesions on the legs, foot pads, and trunk. However, the patient had a complete resolution of symptoms upon oral administration of geraniol.

Of note, the patient underwent a successful pregnancy during treatment, delivering five healthy puppies, demonstrating that G6PD inhibition was nontoxic to the developing fetus.

As of the discharge date in May 2017, the patient remains alive and well with no evidence of tumor recurrence or inflammation.

Summary:

The patient was admitted to our facility due to soft tissue sarcoma and received treatment through our G6PD inhibition protocol. The patient experienced acute inflammatory reactions, but all symptoms were resolved with the administration of geraniol. The patient underwent a successful pregnancy during treatment and remained tumor-free with no further signs of inflammation at the time of discharge.

Medical History:
A six-year-old female boxer dog with a 13-month history of progressive and mildly pruritic skin lesions.

Admission Exam:
Physical examination of the dog revealed no abnormalities. On dermatological examination, nine ulcerated and nonulcerated skin nodules were observed, ranged from 1 to 7 cm in diameter, and distributed mainly over bony prominences of distal extremities and digits of the front legs, left elbow, and right hock. Other skin lesions included footpad hyperkeratosis, crusting, depigmentation, and erosions.

Diagnostic Tests:
Fine needle aspiration (FNA) cytology made from material obtained from nonulcerated skin nodules revealed pyogranulomatous inflammation and numerous mainly extracellular round-shaped organisms, ranging from 20 to 30 μm in diameter, most containing 2 spores of approximately 10 μm in diameter. A culture of FNA material in dermatophyte test medium (DTM) was performed, and smooth, creamy, yeast-like colonies were grown. Histopathology revealed nodular-to-diffuse, pyogranulomatous dermatitis and panniculitis.

Diagnosis:
Cutaneous protothecosis due to Prototheca wickerhamii was confirmed through sequencing of a portion of the 28S rRNA gene following DNA isolation.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with oral fluconazole, which resulted in significant clinical improvement in footpad lesions after one month of administration. However, the progression of skin nodules was not slowed with this treatment regimen. A protocol developed to treat canine cryptococcosis was then applied, which involved subcutaneous infusion of AMB and concurrent administration of itraconazole. Due to nephrotoxicity, AMB was discontinued after seven infusions, and the patient is presently receiving itraconazole alone.

Follow-Up:
Although skin nodules have not shown any improvement with this treatment regimen, footpads remain close to normal.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: Female guinea pig (satin), 2 years old, weighing 560 g.

Admission Date:  [Insert date]

Discharge Date: [Insert date]

Reason for Admission: Anorexia, low weight, cheek teeth overgrowth, incisor malocclusion, left carpal joint immobility, and spinal misalignment.

Hospital Course:

The patient was diagnosed with mandibular deformation, marked bone trabecular pattern, areas of sclerosis, and incisor malocclusion. A radiological study revealed complete loss of mobility of the left carpal joint, malocclusion of the incisors, and Cheek teeth overgrowth. Before sedation, urine was obtained by cystocentesis and blood was collected from the cranial vena cava. A hematological and biochemical panel, hormonal determinations, ionized calcium, and urinalysis were performed. Among other abnormalities, the radiographs showed deformity, double cortical line, marked trabecular pattern, and loss of definition of the medullary cavity in virtually all of the long bones. Left carpal synarthrosis and misalignment of the spine at the L5-L6 level were also observed in the radiographs. 

Treatment: The patient underwent incisor and cheek teeth coronal reduction, leading to remarkable improvement in the guinea pig's health. As long-term management, coronal reduction was performed as needed (approximately 2-3 times per year), and the diet was monitored closely. Annual analytical controls were performed. Three years later, the patient had a good quality of life, analytical values were stable, and radiographs showed hyperostosis, sclerosis, and partial remodeling of the previously affected bone.

Discharge Status: The patient has been discharged in a stable condition. The patient should continue to undergo regular dental examinations to check for recurrence of dental issues. 

Instructions: The owner should maintain a close monitoring of the patient’s diet and weight, especially with respect to the intake of vitamin C. If recurring clinical problems arise, then the patient should visit a veterinary hospital for further diagnosis and treatment.

Follow-up: The owner should schedule annual check-ups to evaluate the patient's weight, and dental examination should be performed regularly.

Electronic Health Record: Discharge Summary

Patient Information:

Name: [Redacted]
Age: 2 years
Sex: Female
Species: Guinea pig

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with repeated loss of material from the uterus and progressive weight loss. On physical exam, tachypnea, vocalization upon manipulation of the tense abdomen, and a dilated abdomen with a palpable mass were noted. Ultrasonographic investigation revealed a large, well-defined 2 x 2 cm mass in the anatomical area of the uterus.

Emergency surgery was performed under sedation with an association of butorphanol, medetomidine, and ketamine administrated intramuscularly. Anesthesia was maintained with isoflurane. During the anesthesia, intravenous fluid was administered via intravenous catheter 24 G. Surgical examination of the abdomen revealed an enlarged and congested ovary and uterus and signs of peritonitis.

The two organs were excised and submitted for histopathology, which revealed characteristic features of endometriosis both in the uterus and in the ovary. The patient was discharged on antibiotic, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and ranitidine.

Follow-up:

The patient recovered from the surgery and was rechecked on a monthly basis. The patient died three months later of unrelated causes. A necropsy was performed at that time and did not show any sign of endometriosis.

Diagnosis:

Endometriosis with adenomyosis in the uterus and cystic endometriosis in the ovary

Plan:

None at this time.

Instructions:

None at this time.

Follow-up:

None at this time.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information: A 3-day-old female alpaca cria weighing 9.5 kg was admitted to the hospital with progressive weakness and dyspnea.

Hospital Course: The patient was tachycardic and appeared to be dyspneic on presentation. Differential diagnosis included septicemia, pneumonia, choanal atresia, meningitis, persistent fetal circulation, and cardiac abnormalities. Standard lateral thoracic radiographs revealed minor abnormalities. An attempt was made to perform upper airway endoscopy; however, the procedure was aborted as the cria became progressively more distressed. An echocardiographic exam revealed severe dilation of the right atrium and ventricle. A large VSD and a PFO were found. Due to the poor prognosis, the owner elected humane euthanasia, and postmortem examination revealed marked dilation of the right atrium, small PFO, large VSD, and single vessel overriding the IVS. 

Diagnosis: Type I common arterial trunk and PFO.

Condition at Discharge: Patient dec

Discharge Summary

Patient: 8-month-old female Staffordshire Bull Terrier
Hospitalization dates: July 2015

Admission: The patient was brought to the veterinary clinic due to frequent and violent sneezing that began after a walk in a rural area.

Medical History: No antimicrobial or anti-inflammatory therapies were being administered to the dog.

Clinical Findings: The patient presented with stertorous and reversal sneezing. Laryngoscopy revealed everted laryngeal saccules, and posterior rhinoscopy showed small mucosal erosions surrounded by mildly thickened and oedematous mucosae in the rhinopharynx. Two and three whitish fusiform organisms were observed in the right and left nasal cavities, respectively. Attempts to catch them using endoscopic forceps failed, and only one was collected via nasal lavage. After rhinoscopy, the larva was identified as a first instar larval stage of O. ovis L. (Diptera: Oestridae).

Treatment: The patient was treated thrice every seven days (days 0, 7, and 14) with subcutaneous administration of ivermectin. Following nasal lavage, the acute and violent sneezing improved considerably. Subsequently, sneezing disappeared completely, and only moderate reversal sneezing remained present, probably due to everted laryngeal saccules.

Summary: The patient, an 8-month-old female Staffordshire Bull Terrier, was brought to the clinic due to frequent sneezing following a walk in a rural area. Clinical examination revealed a first instar larval stage of O. ovis L. (Diptera: Oestridae) which was treated with subcutaneous administration of ivermectin. The sneezing improved considerably following nasal lavage, and the patient's condition continued to improve following treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Red Corn Snake

Age: Approximately 3 years old

Medical Record Number: N/A

Admission Date: N/A

Discharge Date: N/A

Reason for Admission:
Midbody swelling and a three-week history of anorexia.

Hospital Course:
The red corn snake was admitted for evaluation by the Zoological Medicine Service, University of Florida, due to a midbody swelling and a three-week history of anorexia. The snake was diagnosed with a gastrointestinal intussusception and a surgical procedure was recommended. After the surgery, the snake was treated with medications and discharged the following day. The snake was later diagnosed with chronic proliferative gastritis due to Cryptosporidium sp. The snake was treated and discharged with instructions to follow up with the veterinarian regularly. At 15 months after surgery, the snake was found deceased in its enclosure.

Hospital Management:
During hospitalization, the red corn snake was sedated, intubated, and maintained with 1-2% isoflurane, oxygen, and nitrous oxide, with intermittent manual ventilation. The snake was placed in left lateral recumbency while the surgical site was prepped. After the surgery, medications were administered, and the snake was discharged with follow-up instructions.

Condition at Discharge:
The snake's condition at discharge was stable.

Discharge Instructions:
The owner was instructed to provide a warm basking spot and a cooler temperate area in the tank. All bedding was to be removed from the enclosure and only clean newspaper or paper towels were to be used as a substrate. The owner was also instructed on the feeding schedule and the prey items to feed the snake.

Follow-up:
The owner was advised to follow up with the veterinarian regularly to monitor the snake's condition.

Summary:
The red corn snake was admitted to the Zoological Medicine Service, University of Florida, due to a midbody swelling and a three-week history of anorexia. The snake was diagnosed with a gastrointestinal intussusception and treated with surgery, medications, and follow-up instructions. At 15 months after surgery, the snake was found deceased in its enclosure. The owner was instructed on the feeding schedule and prey items to feed the snake and advised to follow up with the veterinarian regularly.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Labrador Retriever

Date of Admission: [Date]

Date of Discharge: [Date]

Hospital Course:

The patient, an eleven-year-old female spayed Labrador Retriever was admitted with multinodular subcutaneous masses in the dorsal cervical area. The masses were diagnosed as grade 3 soft tissue sarcoma, based on the degree of necrosis, cellular atypia, and high mitotic count. The patient underwent surgical excision with 3 cm margins and made a full recovery without any complications. However, ten weeks later, multiple subcutaneous nodules were identified at the same site, confirming a recurrence of the sarcoma. The patient underwent a second, broad excision of the injection site with 3 cm margins.

Subsequently, a small cluster of subcutaneous nodules was identified at the excision site fifty weeks after the first surgery, and a third complete excision with 3 cm margins was performed. The patient was given toceranib, a small molecule inhibitor of VEGFr2 and PDGFrβ, at an orally administered dose of 2.1 mg/kg, which was increased to 2.8 mg/kg on a Monday-Wednesday-Friday schedule. No adverse effects were noted during the course of therapy, and the patient's CBC, serum biochemistry profiles, and thoracic radiographs remained normal. The patient remains in remission ninety-three weeks after initial diagnosis.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with grade 3 soft tissue sarcoma, which recurred twice at the initial injection site.

Treatment:

The patient underwent surgical excision with 3 cm margins during the first two recurrences of the sarcoma. The third recurrence was treated with toceranib, a small molecule inhibitor of VEGFr2 and PDGFrβ.

Follow-Up:

The patient remains in remission ninety-three weeks after the initial diagnosis and continues to receive regular monitoring and check-ups.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: Eight-year-old, female intact Golden Retriever

Chief Complaint: Urinary and faecal incontinence, chronic vaginal discharge

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to undergo magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the lumbar-sacral region under general anesthesia due to urinary and faecal incontinence, along with chronic vaginal discharge. Preanesthetic examination revealed the patient to be in good physical condition but slightly nervous (ASA II). The induction of anesthesia was achieved with fentanyl and propofol, followed by maintenance with isoflurane in 100% oxygen. Shortly after the commencement of isoflurane administration, the patient exhibited a gasping breathing pattern with a respiratory rate of 40-50 bpm and jerk movements in all four limbs. Indications of an underlying pulmonary disease appeared, and MRI was cancelled while thoracic radiographs and arterial blood gas analysis were performed. The patient was allowed to recover from general anesthesia. On the second day, preanesthetic assessment was unremarkable, and the patient was administered Dexmedetomidine and methadone slowly intravenously. When connected to the breathing system again, the patient exhibited gasping and jerking continuously, and hence, isoflurane was immediately turned off with the breathing system flushed with pure oxygen. Anesthesia was then maintained with a constant rate infusion (CRI) of propofol after slow administration of a loading dose. The patient's breathing pattern did not improve, and atracurium was administered intravenously to maintain eucapnia. The rest of the anesthetic time was uneventful, but hiccups restarted as soon as neuromuscular function started to return. An extensive invasive sacrococcygeal neoplasia was found on MRI. The owner decided to euthanize the dog, but a postmortem examination was declined.

Diagnosis and Treatment:

An extensive invasive sacrococcygeal neoplasia was found on MRI.

Condition at Discharge:

Patient was euthanized.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [redacted]       Date of Admission: [redacted]     Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
The 45-day-old male Saanen kid was admitted to the Veterinary Teaching Hospital with a history of an increasing swelling over the prescrotal region. On physical examination, the urine was observed dripping from the prepuce and urethral process. A fluid-filled pocket was seen ventral to the penile urethra. Manual compression of the diverticulum showed subcutaneous urine leakage. The patient underwent needle centesis which revealed urine in the fluid. Ultrasonographic examination was done on the right flank of the patient to visualize the kidneys and the urinary bladder, both of which were normal. Blood sample and urinalysis were within the reference range and no other congenital anomalies were identified.

The patient underwent urethral diverticulectomy by elliptical skin incision around the dorsal border of the diverticulum. After complete evacuation of the urine, two hypospadiac urethral fistulae were identified. One small opening was found in the cranial part of the penis 1 cm ventrocaudal to the urethral process and the other larger opening was found 5 cm caudal to the small one and cranial to the scrotum. The small opening was corrected by urethral catheterization.

Subcutaneous tissues were sutured, and finally, the skin was sutured. After finishing the operation, antibiotic injections were given to the animal for five days. The wound was dressed daily until the stitches were removed after 10 days.

Follow-up:
The patient was discharged in stable condition with no complications. The family was advised to schedule a follow-up appointment to monitor the patient's healing progress. The patient's caretakers were given instructions on proper wound care and medication administration. 

Approved by: [redacted] MD       Reviewed by: [redacted] MD

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 5-year-old female Cownose (Rhinoptera bonasus)

Medical History: Presented at University Veterinary Hospital (UVH) for evaluation and treatment of a left eye globe injury with hyphema and cranial margin abrasions of both pectoral fins. The cause of injury was suspected to be from mating aggression with male rays during the mating season. The patient was managed in Aquaria KLCC's Oceanarium and was fed twice a day with marine chopped fish and Mazuri supplement for vitamins and minerals.

Hospital Course:

On the day of presentation, the patient underwent physical examination which revealed a protruded left eye globe affected by hyphema, as well as multiple abrasions at the cranial margin of both pectoral fins. The patient was treated with immersion anaesthesia using isoeugenol and transferred to a surgical tank for surgical procedure.

Surgical procedure included a ring block using Lidocaine followed by surgical removal of the injured eye globe, remaining conjunctivae fat, and extraocular muscle tissue. The patient's inner and outer muscular attachments were sutured with 2.0 PDS in an interrupted suture pattern to close the orbital space. The periorbital skin was also sutured using 2.0 PDS in an interrupted suture pattern.

Postoperatively, the patient received enrofloxacin intramuscularly and terramycin ointment topically twice a day to prevent a secondary infection of suture site, orbital space, and optic sulcus. Povidone iodine was also applied on the abrasions of pectoral fins twice a day until wound healed to prevent the growth of Fusarium sp.

The patient was isolated from the school in holding areas until surgical wound healed and was monitored daily for secondary infections and suture site break. The caretaker was advised to avoid mating pairs during mating season to reduce the risk of crushing into decorations and to reduce the stress of mating animals to avoid severe injuries.

After 7 days post-operation, the patient was revisited, responded well to the treatment with good appetite, and no clinical abnormalities were observed. The last follow-up was on day 24, and the patient was observed to have an excellent appetite with scars returning to normal skin color.

Instructions:

1. Daily monitoring of suture site for break and possible signs of a secondary infection such as discoloration of skin, and fungal growth on the wound is recommended.
2. Follow strict isolation protocol until the surgical wound is healed completely. 
3. Avoid mating pairs during mating season to reduce the risk of injury.

Medical History:
The patient is a 12-year-old, 12 kg, spayed, female terrier mix who presented with excess tearing and a collection of blood in the left eye. The primary care veterinarian diagnosed anterior uveitis and hyphema and prescribed oral carprofen tablets and ophthalmic suspension. After several weeks without improvement, the patient was referred to a veterinary ophthalmologist who diagnosed bilateral uveitis and development of iris bombe in the left eye, as well as early immature cataract in the right eye.

Hospital Course:
Initial treatment with Dorzolamide and atropine ophthalmic solution was unsuccessful; ultimately, the decision was made to enucleate the left eye. The patient was prescribed clindamycin for 30 days to treat presumptive toxoplasmosis. Further diagnostic work-up included thoracic radiographs and abdominal ultrasound, which revealed the presence of a splenic mass. The patient underwent splenectomy and liver biopsy which confirmed the diagnosis of splenic hemangiosarcoma. The patient was prescribed conventional adjuvant chemotherapy with doxorubicin monotherapy but developed vomiting after the first cycle. The patient's treatment regimen was shifted to I'm-Yunity, metronomic chlorambucil, omega-3 fatty acids, and Yunnan Baiyao. The patient maintained a stable weight and demonstrated an excellent quality of life for the next 24 months.

Discharge Summary:
The patient is being discharged with a diagnosis of splenic hemangiosarcoma and chronic renal disease (IRIS stage 2). While the patient demonstrated an excellent response to treatment, she developed new onset tonic seizures after achieving 24-month survival. Phenobarbital was started but was ultimately ineffective. Euthanasia was advised given the most likely cause of the seizures was a brain tumor.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a recent history of impaired vision in his right eye for about three months due to brain lesions. The patient presented with a diagnosis of liver cancer for which he underwent surgery three months ago. The pathological result states that the patient has hepatocellular carcinoma. The patient received CyberKnife radiosurgery for brain metastasis located in the right orbital part. The patient's physical conditions after the liver tumor resection did not permit surgical excision.

Radiology:
Both the sodium and proton MRI, performed periodically at 7T, were conducted by the time schedule of pre-treatment, 48 hours after SRS, with one week and one month follow-up. The sodium signal in the tumor increased within 48 hours after SRS with the signal intensity decreasing at one week after SRS compared to 48 hours after SRS. However, an increase in the signal intensity was observed at one month. The time course of sodium signal intensity in the tumor showed a dramatic increase in the treated brain tumor compared to the pretreatment and SRS within 48 hours. The T2 magnetic resonance imaging revealed no obvious changes.

Plan:
The patient is now being discharged from the hospital. The discharge summary will be shared with primary care physicians (PCP) assigned to this patient for his further care. The patient is recommended to follow up periodically with his PCP.

Hospital Course:

An 11-year-old male, with no significant medical history, presented to the department of oral and maxillofacial surgery with a chief complaint of swelling over the left cheek. On examination, a well-defined unilocular radiolucent lesion was observed circumscribing the permanent teeth buds of the central, lateral incisor, and canine. Aspiration of the cystic contents revealed a straw-colored fluid. Based on clinical and radiographic findings, a provisional diagnosis of a dentigerous cyst was made. A marsupialization catheter device was inserted through the opening made in the anterior wall of the cyst to maintain its patency. The device was removed after three months when radiographic examination revealed osteogenesis and spontaneous eruption of central and lateral incisors. Later, the patient was referred to the department of orthodontics for assistance in the eruption of permanent teeth into the dental arch. The entire treatment spanned five years for all three impacted teeth to get aligned in the dental arch.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Dentigerous cyst leading to gross facial asymmetry on the left side of the face.

Medical Management:

Marsupialization catheter device was inserted to maintain the patency of cystic cavity and was regularly assessed for its maintenance.

Follow-up Care:

Referral to the department of orthodontics was made for assistance in the eruption of permanent teeth into the dental arch. Treatment spanned five years for all three impacted teeth to get aligned in the dental arch.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient is asymptomatic and comfortable with regular follow-up.

Instructions:

The patient was instructed to return for a periodic follow-up visit with the department of oral and maxillofacial surgery and orthodontics.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Patient Name], DOB: [DOB]
Hospitalization Dates: [Hospitalization Dates]
Admitting Diagnosis: Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome, Elevated INR
Final Diagnosis: Perforated Gallbladder with Hemorrhage and Necrosis, Suspected Cirrhosis
Procedures Performed: Attempted IR-guided Cholecystostomy, Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy, Open Cholecystectomy

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 63-year-old male with a history of left-sided weakness due to a previous cerebrovascular accident, epilepsy, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a recent diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis, was admitted with fever, nausea, vomiting, and tachycardia. Initial tests showed systemic inflammation and consolidation in the left lower lobe of the lung. Further investigations revealeda distended gallbladder with a suspected abscess or hemorrhage. Empiric antibiotics therapy was started for suspected sepsis. The patient was ruled out for surgery initially due to elevated INR levels but was considered a high-risk patient for surgery. An IR-guided cholecystostomy was attempted but was unsuccessful, and the patient's INR continued to rise with a subsequent drop in hemoglobin levels. The patient eventually underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which was converted to an open cholecystectomy due to significant bleeding. During the surgery, the gallbladder was found to have necrosis and perforation with a large amount of old clot and dense adhesions to the liver. Pathology confirmed acute inflammation and necrosis. The patient required additional blood transfusions due to postoperative bleeding from the Jackson-Pratt drain. The patient remained stable for the remainder of the hospitalization and was discharged with an inferior vena cava filter in place due to the high risk of further anticoagulation. The patient was referred to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and recommended follow-up.

Medications at Discharge:
None

Follow-up Instructions:
Follow-up with gastroenterologist for consideration of further treatment.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Age: 25

Gender: Female

Admission Date: [Redacted]

Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Hospital: Local Hospital in Mianeh, Iran

Medical History:

The patient was admitted to the hospital in 2016 with fever, abdominal pain, right upper quadrant pain, and loss of appetite. She admitted to the consumption of local watercress in a rural area. Her medical history was unremarkable.

Diagnostic Findings:

Initial laboratory findings showed eosinophilia, platelets, and elevated liver enzymes. Abdominal ultrasonography revealed splenomegaly. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography revealed an ill-defined lesion at the 4th and 8th segments of the liver.

Treatment:

The patient was diagnosed with fascioliasis and treated with Egaten at a dose of 10mg/kg in a single oral dose.

Follow-Up:

Three months after treatment, the fecal examination was negative for F. gigantica eggs and the patient's liver function tests improved with a decrease in blood eosinophil counts.

Outpatient Plan:

The patient should follow up with her primary care physician and continue monitoring her liver function tests with regular lab work. Additionally, she should avoid consuming local watercress and other similar foods without proper preparation.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 61
Gender: Male

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital due to hepatocellular carcinoma with a tumor of approximately 5 cm diameter at the liver segment IV. The patient underwent partial hepatectomy with segments IV + V and cholecystectomy with cystic duct-tube drainage. During the postoperative day 1, bile drainage was observed from the drain placed in the foramen of Winslow. Fluid collection between the liver and fistula was found through a CT scan. The patient was put under simple drainage to reduce the cavity.

On postoperative day 19, the patient experienced fever and a CT scan revealed an increase in fluid collection. Percutaneous drainage was performed to the cavity near the liver cut surface. The patient was diagnosed with bile leakage from the isolated bile duct of segments V and VIII. Functional remnant liver volume was calculated, which was found to be sufficient for bile leakage management.

The therapeutic strategy involved a combination of percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography drainage (PTCD) tube insertion, percutaneous transhepatic portal embolization (PTPE), and bile duct ablation. PTPE with coil embolization was performed to the part of the portal vein of segments V and VIII by puncturing the part of the portal vein of segment V. Bile leakage decreased to about 50 mL/day. An injection of 1.2 mL pure ethanol was made, which leaked into the abdominal cavity. The PTCD tubes were clamped for 5 min. Another bile duct ablation with 2.0 mL of pure ethanol was performed 1 week after the first procedure. Bile leakage decreased from 50 to 10 mL/day gradually. The patient was reinjected with 2.0 mL of pure ethanol for three times.

The patient was discharged after 139 postoperative days. The drainage tube and bile duct tube were removed. The clinical course was uneventful, and no complications were noted during the combination treatment of PTPE and bile duct ablation.

Diagnosis:

The patient had hepatocellular carcinoma with a tumor of approximately 5 cm diameter at the liver segment IV. The patient had a history of excessive alcohol consumption. Partial hepatectomy with segments IV + V and cholecystectomy with cystic duct-tube drainage were performed. During the postoperative day 1, bile leakage was observed. The patient was diagnosed with bile leakage from the isolated bile duct of segments V and VIII.

Procedure:

The patient underwent partial hepatectomy with segments IV + V and cholecystectomy with cystic duct-tube drainage. Fluid collection was observed through a CT scan during the postoperative day 1. Percutaneous drainage was performed to the cavity near the liver cut surface on postoperative day 19. Bile leakage was managed through a combination of percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography drainage (PTCD) tube insertion, percutaneous transhepatic portal embolization (PTPE), and bile duct ablation.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient was discharged in improved condition after 139 postoperative days. The drainage tube and bile duct tube were removed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Name]
Age: 48
Gender: Male

Medical Report:
The patient was admitted with multiple hepatic tumors, including a giant tumor, superior to the inferior vena cava. A laboratory workup on admission showed mildly increased concentrations of liver enzymes but normal levels of total bilirubin and albumin. Imaging studies revealed well-defined, hypoechoic masses in segment 1, S6, and S2 of the liver. Dynamic CT showed a low-density mass with an irregular margin and peripheral early ring enhancement in the arterial phase and internal heterogeneous enhancement in the delayed phase. MRI showed low-intensity signals on T1-weighted images and high-intensity signals on T2-weighted images. On the basis of these imaging findings, a preoperative diagnosis of multiple scirrhous hepatocellular carcinomas characterized by abundant fibrous stroma was made. However, after a histopathological examination, the tumor was found to be hepatic sclerosing hemangioma, a rare type of hepatic hemangioma composed of abundant acellular hyalinized tissue with small vessels seen occasionally.

Treatment:
Caudate lobectomy of the liver and partial hepatectomy of S2 and S6 were performed, and the patient tolerated the procedure well. Following the surgery, the patient was discharged on the 14th day post-operation and advised for follow-up visits.

Conclusion:
The patient was admitted with multiple hepatic tumors, and after the histopathological examination, it was found to be hepatic sclerosing hemangioma. The patient underwent surgery and was discharged with post-operative instructions. Follow-up visits were advised to assess the patient's condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: October 2016
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:
The 52-year-old Chinese male patient was admitted to our hospital with gross hematuria and a history of clear cell renal cell carcinoma and multiple metastases. The patient underwent left nephrectomy in January 2014 and had declined high-dose interleukin-2. The patient was started on pazopanib in March 2014 and achieved partial response. A series of drug treatments were administered to the patient from May 2015 to October 2016. In October 2016, computed tomography (CT) scan showed widespread metastases. The patient was offered immunotherapy and received a single dose of nivolumab at 100 mg. The patient developed acute renal failure 2 weeks later. Renal biopsy was not performed as this was a single kidney. The patient was referred to the home hospice service. At the 10th week, the patient unexpectedly walked into the clinic, having felt better a week prior with an increase in urine output. The patient continued to improve, and a contrast CT at week 20 showed dramatic improvement in tumor status. At 6 months post-nivolumab, the patient was doing well without further immunotherapy.

Hospital Course Summary:
The 52-year-old male patient was admitted with gross hematuria and a history of clear cell renal cell carcinoma and multiple metastases. Multiple drug treatments were administered to the patient from May 2015 to October 2016. The patient was offered immunotherapy and received a single dose of nivolumab at 100 mg. The patient developed acute renal failure and was referred to the home hospice service. The patient unexpectedly improved and continued to do so, resulting in dramatic improvement in tumor status. Overall, the patient had a complex hospital course with multiple interventions and palliative care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient was a 30-year old pregnant woman who presented with left lower quadrant discomfort during her second month of pregnancy. A mixed cystic and solid left adnexal mass measuring 8.6 × 6.7 × 8.3 cm was discovered during an ultrasound examination. A left salpingo-oophorectomy was performed early in the second trimester. Grossly, an intact 7.5 cm complex cystic-solid mass with nearly half involved by a friable, tan-yellow tumor with papillary excrescences, some of which were freely floating within the cyst cavity was noted. Histologic sections revealed a struma ovarii with over 50% characterized by the classic features of a well-differentiated papillary thyroid carcinoma. The periphery of the tumor impinged on the ovarian capsule and vascular structures, but no definitive evidence of invasion was found on the histologic sections reviewed. Ovarian mature cystic teratoma was also present in other areas of the tumor.

The patient’s tumor expressed positive immunohistochemical staining for thyroglobulin (Tg) and thyroid transcription factor 1 (TTF1), but was negative for BRAF V600E. Serum Tg was found to be elevated after surgical removal of the ovarian mass, which is reasonably expected given the proximity to surgery and the known increase in Tg levels during pregnancy. Thyroid function tests and thyroid ultrasound were normal. Levothyroxine (L-T4) was initiated to suppress thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH).

After delivery, the patient underwent total thyroidectomy to permit evaluation for metastatic disease and monitoring for recurrence by Tg levels. Thyroid pathology was benign. Several months after delivery, cessation of lactation and L-T4 withdrawal resulted in an unexpected rise in Tg levels. A concurrent diagnostic I-131 scan was performed with planar and SPECT/CT imaging. The scan revealed focal central neck activity consistent with thyroid remnant and the presence of iodine-avid skeletal metastatic disease involving the left ninth rib, bilateral proximal femurs and sacrum. High-quality SPECT/CT images eliminated the need for separate dedicated CT and bone scan. The patient was treated with TSH suppression resulting in an undetectable Tg level.

Follow-up evaluations demonstrated a stimulated Tg level and negative diagnostic I-131 scan without focal abnormal radioiodine uptake in the neck or skeleton. A 100 mCi I-131 therapeutic challenge was performed to eliminate any microscopic residual disease and more accurately ascertain the treatment response. The post-therapy I-131 scan demonstrated complete resolution of pulmonary metastatic disease. Faint residual foci of activity were demonstrated in the left ninth rib, sacrum, and left proximal femur, consistent with a partial therapeutic response in the skeleton.

The patient continues to do well, being conservatively managed with active clinical and biochemical monitoring during L-T4 suppression therapy.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 79-year-old woman, was admitted for evaluation of abnormal murmur. She presented with a 3-months history of worsening shortness of breath and orthopnea. Physical examination revealed a soft continuous murmur at the left upper chest with basal crackles in both lungs. Chest radiography showed mild cardiomegaly with mild pulmonary congestion. The ECG showed regular sinus rhythm without evidence of ischemia or prior myocardial infarction.
Transthoracic echocardiography demonstrated a mildly dilated LV with markedly dilated left atrium. The LV ejection fraction was 60% with no wall motion abnormality. Transthoracic echocardiography also showed an unusual, tubular-like structure inside the interventricular septum with a turbulent, predominantly diastolic flow on color Doppler. Transesophageal echocardiography revealed a markedly dilated RCA arising from the right aortic sinus, while the origin of the left coronary artery (LCA) could not be demonstrated. There was a tortuous, abnormal vessel located adjacent to the main pulmonary artery (MPA) emptying into the posteromedial aspect of the MPA. There was an accelerated, continuous flow across the stenotic ostium. Moreover, there was severe MR from a restricted posterior leaflet of the mitral valve (MV) associated with ventricular remodeling in combination with mitral annular dilatation.
Coronary angiography with a single RCA injection revealed a markedly dilated RCA providing multiple intercoronary collaterals of various sizes communicating with the left coronary system. The LCA later opacified the MPA through a stenotic ostium, establishing the diagnostic hallmark of ALCAPA syndrome. The calculated ratio of pulmonary-systemic blood flow was 1.4, confirming a significant left-to-right shunt. Coronary computed tomography angiography clearly identified the ALCAPA with a retropulmonary ostium. Volume-rendered image depicted the course of the anomalous coronary arteries and its inter-coronary collateral pathways along the epicardial surface and where the LCA connected to the MPA. Stress cardiovascular magnetic resonance perfusion imaging demonstrated no myocardial ischemia, suggesting adequate collateral circulation to the LV.

Discharge Summary:
The patient was diagnosed with ALCAPA syndrome, a congenital heart defect, resulting in a left-to-right shunt, and severe MR. No myocardial ischemia was detected through stress cardiovascular magnetic resonance perfusion imaging. The patient's LV and LCA were dilated while also experiencing mitral annular dilatation. The disease was diagnosed and monitored through various tests and imaging, such as Transthoracic echocardiography, Transesophageal echocardiography, coronary angiography, and coronary computed tomography angiography. The patient was referred for appropriate follow-up care and treatment.

[Patient's Name] Discharge Summary

Patient Information:
Name: [Patient's Name]
Age: 73 years
Gender: Male
Admission Date: Late October 2016
Discharge Date: N/A

Admission Diagnosis:
Widely disseminated sebaceous carcinoma including metastases to brain, visceral organs, lymph nodes, and bone.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented for removal of a rapidly growing nodule in the anterior abdominal wall. Two days later, he developed confusion, urinary incontinence, and progressive aphasia. Emergent magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed 4 enhancing gray-white matter junctional lesions, and the patient underwent craniotomy and resection of bilateral frontal lobe tumors. The tumor was diagnosed as sebaceous carcinoma after a histopathologic examination. 

The patient commenced off-label treatment with pembrolizumab (2 mg/kg, every 3 weeks) in December 2016 due to strong PD-L1 expression, a moderately high tumor mutational burden, and a significant rationale for the use of checkpoint inhibitors in several other tumor types. A follow-up PET/CT scan 3 months after the initiation of anti-PD1 therapy revealed remarkable improvement in lymph nodes, lung, and soft tissue. A restaging PET/CT obtained after 6 months of treatment showed further significant improvements in all previously noted lesions. 

After 10 months of therapy, the patient developed severe fatigue and orthostatic hypotension, requiring hospitalization. Laboratory testing showed him to have secondary adrenal insufficiency and received adrenal replacement therapy with hydrocortisone (10 mg/5 mg) during high dose steroid therapy. 

Recent restaging studies demonstrate growth of the mediastinal metastases and a reduction in the size of the hepatic and small bowel metastases, suggestive of pseudoprogression and a durable ongoing response to pembrolizumab.

Discharge Summary:
The patient was thoroughly examined, and the condition was diagnosed as widely disseminated sebaceous carcinoma including metastases to brain, visceral organs, lymph nodes, and bone. He received craniotomy and resection of bilateral frontal lobe tumors. The tumor was diagnosed as sebaceous carcinoma after a histopathologic examination, and the patient commenced off-label treatment with pembrolizumab (2 mg/kg, every 3 weeks) due to strong PD-L1 expression and moderately high tumor mutational burden.

After 10 months of therapy, the patient developed severe fatigue and orthostatic hypotension, requiring hospitalization. Laboratory testing showed him to have secondary adrenal insufficiency and received adrenal replacement therapy with hydrocortisone (10 mg/5 mg) during high dose steroid therapy. Recent restaging studies demonstrate growth of the mediastinal metastases and a reduction in the size of the hepatic and small bowel metastases, suggestive of pseudoprogression and a durable ongoing response to pembrolizumab.

The clinical team will continue to monitor the patient's condition and provide appropriate care as necessary.

Hospital Course Summary

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Patient Information:
Name: [insert patient name]
Gender: Male
Age: 70 years
Admission Diagnosis: Non-ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI)

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with NSTEMI and underwent coronary angiography, which revealed complete occlusion of the native coronary circulation at the proximal segments and tandem calcified lesions of SVG on distal right coronary artery (RCA) and ostial stenosis of SVG on first obtuse marginal branch (OM1). Left internal mammary artery on the mid left anterior descending artery was patent. Ad Hoc PCI of SVG on RCA was attempted but was suboptimal due to the hard and calcified plaque. Elective PCI of SVG on RCA with rotational atherectomy was performed, which involved two runs with 1.25 mm burr and 2 runs with 1.5 mm burr. A drug-eluting stent (DES) was placed on the mid-distal segment of the graft and a second DES was placed proximally to the first one. No embolization was observed during the procedure. The patient experienced a slight elevation of cardiac biomarkers (Hs-Troponin T 564 ng/l and CK-MB 308 U/l) the day after the procedure, which gradually reduced over the next 4 days. The patient was discharged in stable conditions.

Discharge Medications:
[Not applicable]

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to follow a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet, regular exercise, and smoking cessation. The patient is also advised to continue taking any previously prescribed medications and to attend follow-up appointments with his primary care physician.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 9 months
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED] Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Diagnosis:

1. Bilateral diffuse hyperplastic perilobar nephroblastomatosis (DHPLNB) complicated by a left renal mass (likely Wilms Tumour).
2. Resection margins positive, nodal dissection negative.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 9-month-old female who presented with abdominal distension and weight loss. The initial ultrasonographic study revealed massively enlarged kidneys with loss of corticomedullary differentiation and the presence of nephrogenic rests bilaterally, which suggested the presence of DHPLNB. Further CT and MRI studies confirmed the diagnosis of bilateral DHPLNB and a superimposed Wilms tumor. The patient was treated with COG protocol AREN 0534 EE-4A chemotherapy, which included vincristine and dactinomycin for 20 weeks. Following this, the patient underwent a left partial nephrectomy and perihilar lymph node dissection. A left flank radiotherapy was also performed. The resected pathology revealed DHPLNB and a resected Wilms tumor with positive margins but negative nodal dissection.

The patient was followed with MRI every 3 months for a year and every 6 months for 2 years. Currently, the patient is on surveillance with ultrasounds every 3-4 months.

Treatment:

1. COG protocol AREN 0534 EE-4A chemotherapy including vincristine and dactinomycin for 20 weeks.
2. Left partial nephrectomy and perihilar lymph node dissection.
3. Left flank radiotherapy to a dose of 1080 cGy in 6 fractions.

Follow-up:

The patient is currently on surveillance with ultrasounds every 3-4 months.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient is in stable condition and will continue to be followed up by the medical team on an outpatient basis.

Discharge Medications:

None.

Instructions:

The patient is advised to follow up with the medical team as recommended and to report any new symptoms or concerns. Any questions or concerns about the patient's care or treatment plan can be directed to the medical team.

Discharge Summary

Patient Information: 
Name: Mr. (Unidentified) 
Age: 85 
Gender: Male

Final Diagnosis: Thyroid Storm due to Destructive Thyroiditis

History of Present Illness: 
The patient presented to our hospital with a severe case of thyrotoxicosis and poor blood glucose control. He had a history of hypothyroidism due to Hashimoto's disease and type 2 diabetes, for which he had been receiving insulin self-injection therapy. He had also undergone treatment for malignant melanoma of the nasal cavity, receiving one cycle of nivolumab therapy followed by two courses of ipilimumab therapy. His symptoms included fatigue, nausea, and sweating, which progressed to clinical and biochemical thyrotoxicosis after receiving a dual course of ipilimumab as a third treatment. On admission to our hospital, he presented with fever, tachycardia, agitation, and anxiety. He had a diffuse goiter without exophthalmoses and his blood pressure had decreased to 70/50 mmHg.

Hospital Course: 
The patient was treated with intravenously administered insulin infusion and intravenously administered fluid therapy. He was diagnosed as having destructive thyroiditis based on decreased uptake on thyroid scintigraphy. Treatment for thyroid storm was initiated with orally administered potassium iodide and a short-acting beta-adrenoreceptor blocker, landiolol hydrochloride, to control his heart rate. Prednisolone was also given as a treatment for irAE and thyroid storm. On day 5, his tachycardia had resolved, and the landiolol hydrochloride was discontinued. On day 11, his thyroid function had improved and the amount of total insulin used to control his blood glucose was decreased. On day 25, he was found to have hypothyroidism, and thyroid hormone replacement therapy was restarted. He was discharged from our hospital on day 35 on daily maintenance insulin injection and levothyroxine sodium hydrate.

Follow-Up: 
The patient was advised to follow up with his primary care physician for ongoing management of his thyroiditis, diabetes mellitus, and melanoma.

Discharge Medications: 
1. Insulin injection
2. Levothyroxine sodium hydrate

Condition at Discharge: Stable 

Instructions at Discharge: 
1. Follow up with primary care physician for ongoing management of thyroiditis, diabetes mellitus, and melanoma.
2. Continue taking prescribed medications as directed.
3. Report any new symptoms or changes in condition to your healthcare provider immediately.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 20
Gender: Female
Clinical Diagnosis: Acute Traumatic Myocardial Infarction

Hospital Course:

The 20-year-old female patient presented to the hospital with substernal chest pain and breathlessness after being hit by a baseball to her chest. Electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed sinus rhythm with QS complexes in leads V2 to V3. Laboratory tests showed cardiac Troponin I level of 19.03 ng/ml and chest computer tomography (CT) revealed coronary artery calcifications. She had several giant left anterior descending (LAD) aneurysms with diameters ranging from 7.5 to 8.5 mm. Upon further review, it was found that the patient had a history of high fever lasting for several days at the age of 5 which eventually led to a diagnosis of Kawasaki disease.

Treatment:

The patient was managed conservatively due to stable hemodynamic parameters and multiple giant aneurismal dilatations of LAD artery. The hospital course included dual anti-platelet treatment with aspirin and clopidogrel for at least 1 year, and titrations of captopril and metoprolol to prevent ventricular remodeling.

Follow-up:

At the 2-month follow-up, the patient remained asymptomatic. ECG showed QS complex only in V2 and V3 leads and other abnormalities were resolved. Echocardiography revealed normal left ventricular size and no ventricular dilatation or akinesis. She remained asymptomatic two years later.

Impression:

The discharge summary of this patient revealed that she suffered an acute traumatic myocardial infraction caused by an underlying coronary structural abnormality which was most likely originated from KD. The patient was managed conservatively with dual anti-platelet treatment. At the follow-up visits, the patient remained asymptomatic and showed significant improvements in various clinical parameters.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 33-year-old female who was admitted after a motor vehicle accident with major front-end damage. Upon arrival, the patient was unresponsive with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 5 and was intubated for airway protection. There was also noted to be tachycardia and hypotension. A focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) showed no intra-abdominal or pericardial fluid. A chest tube was placed after a left-sided hemothorax was noted on chest X-ray, and 1200 mL of bloody output was initially drained. The patient was urgently taken to the operating room (OR) for exploration.

Operative Summary:

A left anterolateral thoracotomy incision was made with the patient in a supine position. There was significant blood upon entry into the chest cavity. Despite cross clamping the pulmonary hilum, bleeding persisted. The pericardium was opened, and a separate defect in the superior, right side of the pericardium was found, as well as a 3 cm defect in the anterior right atrium. Despite measures to control hemorrhage and resuscitate the patient, the patient did not survive. The blood loss was greater than 6 l.

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient passed away due to complications of her injuries sustained in the motor vehicle accident.

Disposition:

The patient was transferred to the morgue. 

Follow-Up:

There is no further follow-up needed as the patient has expired.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 58-year-old male, was admitted to the hospital after a high-speed motor vehicle collision. The patient had a prolonged extrication from his vehicle and was intubated. On arrival, his Glasgow Coma Scale was 3 T. He was hypotensive, and a large left hemothorax was identified. A chest tube was placed, and the patient was taken to the operating room.

Procedure:
The patient underwent a left anterolateral thoracotomy incision. Approximately 1 L of clotted blood was found within the chest cavity coming from an anterior pericardial laceration. There was brisk bleeding through a 1 cm laceration on the left atrial appendage. The injury was debrided and repaired using a polypropylene suture over a Satinsky clamp. The pericardial defect was closed to prevent cardiac herniation.

Follow-Up:
After the procedure, the patient's condition improved, and he was eventually discharged home.

Diagnoses:
The patient's diagnoses included severe chest trauma, left hemothorax, and an anterior pericardial laceration with left atrial appendage injury.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition at discharge was stable.

Future Care:
The patient will require follow-up care to monitor his recovery from his injuries.
