Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 42
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for evaluation of smooth bilaterally enlarged tonsils, with the right tonsil being slightly larger than the left, which did not respond to two courses of amoxicillin. Upon referral to the otorhinolaryngology department, an MRI was performed which showed that the right tonsil was larger than the left and that the crypts were partly obliterated by a large mass. The patient underwent complete surgical resection of the right tonsil. Histological examination of the specimen revealed a plasmacytoma.

Metastatic workup was performed, which ruled out multiple myeloma/light chain disease. The patient did not require any adjuvant treatment and remains clinically free of disease after 6 months of follow-up.

Diagnosis:
Plasmacytoma

Treatment:
Complete surgical resection of the right tonsil

Follow-up:
The patient remains clinically free of disease after 6 months of follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [Patient Name]
- Age: 29 years
- Gender: Male
- Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]
- Date of Admission: [Admission Date]
- Date of Discharge: [Discharge Date]
- Admitting Diagnosis: Severe abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant

Hospital Course:
- The patient presented to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant that started two months prior and progressed in intensity and frequency.
- The patient reported a surgical history of LRYGB performed nine years ago for OSA and achieved significant weight loss initially but gained weight in the last two years leading up to the presentation.
- After laboratory investigations and an ultrasound examination revealed gallstones and a borderline diameter of the common bile duct, the patient underwent a formal laparoscopic cholecystectomy the following day.
- During the operation, an internal hernia was identified and a mini midline laparotomy was performed for reduction of the hernia and more detailed exploration.
- The hernia was through the mesenteric defect between the alimentary limb and the biliopancreatic limbs. Both limbs of the anastomosis were identified, and complete reduction of the internal hernia was done, in addition to suturing of the defect found in the mesentery.
- Prominent whitish colored vessels were observed in the small intestine's mesentery, and whitish thick fluid was noticed, accumulating in the right paracolic gutter and in Morison's pouch, which was aspirated, and analysis of the fluid showed a triglyceride level of 534 mg/dL and an LDH level of 512 U/L.
- A classic Blake drain 24 F was inserted into the pelvis, and the patient passed a post-operative period without any complications.
- The drain was removed on the fourth postoperative day, and the patient was discharged on the same day after being able to ambulate independently on his own and eat and drink with no complications.
- At the time of discharge, the patient was asymptomatic.

Condition at Discharge:
- The patient was asymptomatic.
- The patient was educated on the importance of regular follow-up visits and advised to continue a healthy lifestyle, including a weight loss plan if needed.
- The patient was provided with a one-week supply of pain medication and instructed to follow up with their primary care physician and surgeon within a week from the date of discharge.

Final Diagnoses:
- Abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant
- Internal hernia following LRYGB
- Chylous ascites post-cholecystectomy

Discharge Medications:
- Pain medication, [Medication Name], [Dosage]

Follow-up Instructions:
- Follow up with primary care physician and surgeon within a week from the date of discharge.
- Maintain a healthy lifestyle, including a weight loss plan if needed.
- Attend all scheduled follow-up visits.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital due to abdominal pain, non-bloody diarrhea and weight loss. Physical examination demonstrated moderate abdominal tenderness with an abdominal mass in the right lower quadrant. Laboratory findings revealed a significantly elevated CRP level. Colonoscopy showed ulcerations localized at the Bauhin’s valve and histological examination of obtained mucosal biopsies were suggestive for active Crohn’s Disease (CD). MR enteroclysis was performed due to inability to intubate the terminal ileum and indicated a predominant inflammatory, short-segment stenosis of the terminal ileum. Medical treatment was switched from prednisolone and azathioprine to adalimumab. 

Course of Treatment:
Twelve weeks after induction of adalimumab therapy, clinical remission was achieved and CRP level returned to normal. Another four months later, the patient presented with severe pain in the mandibular area. A biopsy of the oral lesions was obtained and revealed ulcerative stomatitis with noncaseating granulomas consistent with oral CD. Intensification of immunosuppressive therapy was initiated by shortening the adalimumab administration interval to weekly administration. A follow-up examination after 10 weeks confirmed complete healing of the oral CD lesion. During a follow-up period of 12 months, no signs of active CD became evident under continued therapy. 

Summary:
This 34-year-old man with a 15-year history of Crohn’s Disease (CD) was admitted to our hospital due to abdominal pain, non-bloody diarrhea, and weight loss. The patient underwent MR enteroclysis and was found to have a predominant inflammatory, short-segment stenosis of the terminal ileum. After unsuccessful treatment with prednisolone and azathioprine, the patient was switched to adalimumab and achieved clinical remission after 12 weeks. Although the patient maintained clinical remission and low laboratory inflammation markers, the patient later presented with ulcerative lesions of the buccal-side mucosa of the right mandible consistent with oral CD. Intensification of immunosuppressive therapy was initiated by shortening the adalimumab administration interval to weekly administration. A follow-up examination confirmed complete healing of the oral CD lesion. The patient remained in remission for a 12 month follow-up period under continued therapy.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Patient Name: [Patient Name]
Medical Record Number: [MRN]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient is an 11-year, 7-month-old female with a history of short stature, incomplete cleft palate, and craniosynostosis, who was admitted to Kyungpook National Children’s Hospital for follow up. The patient had a developmental delay and was lost to follow-up after her initial treatment at the Department of Pediatric Neurology.

During her current admission, the patient has been diagnosed with Kabuki syndrome based on characteristic clinical features, including a height of 124.8 cm (standard deviation score [SDS]: − 3.6), distinctive facial features, postnatal growth retardation, and skeletal anomalies such as brachydactyly. Mutational analyses for the KMT2D and KDM6A genes were performed, and the patient had the nonsense mutation of c.8200C > T, p(Arg2734*) in exon 32 in the KMT2D gene.

The patient underwent additional examinations to detect other anomalies associated with Kabuki syndrome. Two-dimensional echocardiography, abdominal ultrasonography, and brain magnetic resonance imaging were normal. Ophthalmological findings were also normal.

The patient exhibited several endocrine problems including a transiently congenital hypothyroidism, a condition of cortisol producing tumors called Cushing's disease, obesity, and a growth hormone (GH) deficiency. She received levothyroxine until she was 3 years old, and normal thyroid function was confirmed after discontinuing the medication. The patient has started GH replacement therapy (Eutropin 0.03 mg/kg/day).    

During her current admission, the patient’s condition stabilized and she maintained normal thyroid function. She was monitored and treated for her endocrine problems. Her family was educated about her chronic condition and was referred for genetic counseling.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

1. Kabuki syndrome
2. GH deficiency
3. Obesity
4. Transiently congenital hypothyroidism
5. Cortisol producing tumors (Cushing's syndrome)

DISCHARGE PLAN:

The patient has been discharged from the hospital and will continue GH replacement therapy (Eutropin 0.03 mg/kg/day) for her GH deficiency. She will continue follow-up care with the Endocrinology and Genetics departments at Kyungpook National Children’s Hospital. 

The patient’s family was instructed on the importance of monitoring her growth hormone levels, and the availability of a genetic counselor. It was advised that they should seek medical attention immediately if there were any changes in her condition. 

The patient was advised to maintain a proper diet plan and engage in regular physical activity to address her obesity. In addition, she was advised to maintain regular screening for thyroid function.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 43
Gender: Male
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

This is the discharge summary for [REDACTED] who was admitted with intermittent pain in his lumbar region. He was diagnosed with a giant duodenal cyst (GDC) which was successfully treated with a total gastrectomy.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with intermittent pain in right lumbar region, and an epigastric mass was palpated on abdominal examination. An abdominal CT scan was performed which revealed a voluminous mass of 24 x 15 x 13 cm3, partially cystic, located in the epigastric region, between the left lobe of the liver, the stomach, the pancreas and the transverse colon. The differential diagnoses included cystic lymphangioma, cystic mesothelioma, non-communicating GD, and cystic GIST.

A decision for laparotomy surgery was made due to the possible neoplastic degeneration and the difficulties caused by the volume of the mass. During the surgery, a GDC of 30 cm of major axis was highlighted and 2 L of mucus was evacuated. A total gastrectomy with a roux-en-y loop oesophago-jejunostomy and a lymphadenectomy was performed. The histological examination revealed a GDC with no signs of dysplasia or metaplasia present. The immune marking of pancytokeratine was normal with little elevated KI67 proliferation. 18 sampled lymph nodes were free of malignancy.

The postoperative course was uneventful, with a discharge after 10 days. The CEA level was 3.06 mg/L on discharge. At the 6-month follow-up, the patient was well.

Final Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with a GDC with no malignant transformation.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient is advised of a follow-up schedule to assess the successful treatment of the GDC and to monitor his levels of CEA, with a proposed follow-up after 6 months. Any changes should be reported and acted upon promptly.

Discharge Medications:
The patient was not prescribed any medications at discharge.

Signed,
[REDACTED], MD

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient presented to our outpatient clinic with complaints of fever and pain in the right upper abdominal quadrant. A clinical examination and ultrasound revealed a thickened gallbladder wall, which was confirmed by computed tomography (CT) as acalculous cholecystitis. Laboratory results showed elevated liver enzymes, generalized lymphadenopathy, and signs of mononucleosis. The patient was hospitalized and put under symptomatic therapy. Throughout the hospital stay, the patient's state improved rapidly and he was discharged on the 17th day after admission in good general condition.

HISTORY AND FINDINGS:
The patient had a history of recent upper respiratory tract infection which was treated with oral amoxicillin. He also had a history of left adrenal gland resection, distal pancreatectomy, and splenectomy due to a large tumor two years ago. Clinical examination revealed tenderness in the epigastric abdomen and a cervical lymphadenopathy.

DIAGNOSES:
1. Acalculous cholecystitis
2. Mononucleosis
3. Elevated liver enzymes
4. Generalized lymphadenopathy

TREATMENT:
The patient was admitted and put under symptomatic therapy. This led to rapid improvement and he was discharged in good general condition.

FOLLOW-UP:
The patient is advised to follow-up with his primary care physician or specialist as advised.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 47-year-old female

Date of discharge: [Insert date]

Reason for admission: Left upper abdominal pain

Hospital course:

On admission, the patient reported left upper abdominal pain, which was accompanied by diaphoresis, nausea, and several episodes of non-bloody, non-bilious vomiting. The pain was moderate to severe with a gradual onset and constant crampiness. The patient's vital signs were stable, and laboratory results were within reference ranges, except for her coagulation profile, which was at a subtherapeutic level. Her past medical history included nonischemic cardiomyopathy with left ventricular thrombus, four previous cerebrovascular accidents, and her condition was being managed with warfarin.

A physical examination revealed significant tenderness in the left upper abdomen, and fine crackles were noted within the left lower lobe. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed septal and apical predominantly transmural infarct. A transthoracic echocardiogram showed a mildly dilated left ventricle with moderate to severe left ventricular dysfunction, an ejection fraction of 30% to 35% with distal anterior, anteroseptal, and apical akinesis with mild mitral regurgitation. Cardiac catheterization findings were unremarkable. A computed tomography (CT) scan of her abdomen showed mild cardiomegaly with previous infarction on the anterior-inferior wall of the left ventricle.

We noted a 37.47 mm calcified thrombus in the left ventricular apex with peripheral calcifications. Additionally, infarction in the spleen and right kidney with bilateral renal scarring were observed.

Treatment:

The patient was started on a heparin drip and later bridged to warfarin on the third day. No surgical intervention was required. Medication compliance was reinforced before discharge.

Follow-up:

The patient was discharged on the seventh day with complete resolution of her abdominal pain. Follow-up appointments were suggested with her primary care physician and cardiology department.

Prognosis:

The prognosis is guarded due to the patient's history of nonischemic cardiomyopathy with left ventricular thrombus, and her recent infarction may aggravate the situation. However, with careful medication management, consistent follow-up appointments, and proactive lifestyle changes, the patient's prognosis can be improved.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]     Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]        Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Cutaneous Vasculitis

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient, a 68-year-old female with a history of seropositive rheumatoid arthritis, common variable immunodeficiency, hypertension, hypothyroidism, and osteoporosis, presented with cutaneous vasculitis. Initial treatment with mycophenolate, hydroxychloroquine, and prednisone resulted in symptom improvement but was followed by worsening joint symptoms and synovitis. Methotrexate was then substituted with leflunomide due to hair loss and inadequate disease control. Cutaneous lesions relapsed, and abatacept was initiated with concurrent therapy of leflunomide, hydroxychloroquine, and prednisone. The patient demonstrated satisfactory response with clearing of lesions several days after the first dose and returned to the office a month later without any recurrence of the cutaneous lesions. 

Hospital Course Summary:
Admit date [REDACTED]: The patient, a 68-year-old Caucasian female with rheumatoid arthritis and a history of multiple comorbidities, was diagnosed with cutaneous vasculitis. Initial treatment with mycophenolate, hydroxychloroquine, and prednisone resulted in symptom improvement. A few months later, she developed worsening joint symptoms and synovitis, with joint pain appearing more frequently. For this reason, her medication was changed to methotrexate which she has been taking for about six months. The patient was switched to abatacept after leflunomide was found to be more effective. Her health improved over time, and she was able to return home.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [name]
Medical Record Number (MRN): [MRN]
Date of Admission: [date]
Date of Discharge: [date]

Reason for Admission:
The patient, a 46-year-old male with a history of HHT and aortic valve replacement due to aortic insufficiency, was admitted to the hospital for a lung transplant.

Hospital Course:
On the fifth day after the transplant, the patient experienced symptoms of mandibular pain, trismus and extrapyramidalism symptoms in the form of oromandibular dystonia. A physical exam revealed signs of bilateral jaw subluxation with reuptake inhibition of the articular condyle–disc complex, contraction at the masticatory muscles level, fascies dolorosa, dystonia of the facial third with articular blocking and incapacity for bucal closure or lateral excursion, and slight dysphagia. A computed tomography (CT) of the craniofacial complex and brain without IV contrast showed dislocation of both mandibular condyles with anterior position to the temporal’s glenoid cavity, without evidence of associated bone injuries.

Treatment:
Analgesia and muscular relaxation of the patient was carried out. The Nelaton reduction maneuver and later placing of Barton bandaging was done following the technique, using an antiseptic. Posterior clinical and radiological reduction is verified through CT, evidencing a normal condylar position. The patient progresses without further subluxations during his hospitalization.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with mandibular pain, trismus and extrapyramidalism symptoms in the form of oromandibular dystonia.

Disposition:
The patient has been discharged from the hospital and will continue treatment on an outpatient basis.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient will follow-up with his healthcare provider as recommended.

Instructions:
The patient should rest and avoid strenuous activity for the next few days. Any symptoms should be reported to the healthcare provider immediately.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 61
Sex: Male
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our burn center due to burn injuries that covered 20% of his TBSA. After successful management with split-thickness skin graft, the patient was discharged. Eight months later, the patient was referred to us for management of infected open wounds in donor sites, both lower and upper limb. Debridement was performed, and daily wound dressing with an antimicrobial alginate dressing and irradiation with water-filtered infrared-A (wIRA) was initiated. The patient tolerated this application well without any complaints. After 5 weeks, the patient was discharged with healed donor sites on the left thigh and left lower leg, and nearly totally healed sites on the left forearm and left upper arm.

Diagnosis:

Infected open wounds on donor sites resulting from neglect and inadequate wound care.

Management:

Surgical debridement was performed to remove the hypertrophic granulation tissue. Daily wound dressing with a non-adherent antimicrobial alginate dressing (Silvercell®) and irradiation with water-filtered infrared-A (wIRA) were initiated. The patient was monitored daily for any signs of adverse reactions or complications.

Follow-up:

The patient is advised to maintain proper wound care and follow up with his primary care physician regularly.

Summary:

The patient was managed for infected open wounds on donor sites caused by neglect and inadequate wound care. Surgical debridement was performed, and the patient was treated with daily wound dressing with an antimicrobial alginate dressing and irradiation with water-filtered infrared-A (wIRA). The patient was discharged after 5 weeks with healed donor sites on the left thigh and left lower leg, and nearly totally healed sites on the left forearm and left upper arm. The patient is advised to follow up with his primary care physician regularly.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Hospital Admission Date: [Date]
Hospital Discharge Date: [Date]

Admission Diagnosis: Cervical canal stenosis due to ossification of the cervical posterior longitudinal ligament resulting in cervical cord compression and complete tetraplegia, progressive restrictive respiratory failure requiring assisted ventilation, and tracheostomy.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent conservative management for cervical cord compression at C3 and C4 vertebral levels due to cervical canal stenosis caused by ossification of the cervical posterior longitudinal ligament. After 58 days of critical care in the ICU, he was transferred to our hospital for further rehabilitation. Upon arrival, he was fully conscious and had total tetraplegia below the shoulder girdle muscles. He also had a urinary obstruction and widespread atelectasis. Intensive care with physical support for expectoration, mechanically assisted removal of tracheal secretions, ventilator muscle training, and management of the spasticity of the abdominal wall was provided. After 131 days of injury, an automated weaning protocol was initiated using IntelliVent®-ASV mode to adjust pressure support based on the ideal minute volume. The patient's expiratory tidal volume increased from 150 mL upon admission to our hospital to 350 mL 22 days after the introduction of the QW and SBT modes in association with intensive pulmonary rehabilitation. The pressure support was eventually withdrawn during nighttime, and the patient's weaning process was completed.

Discharge Diagnosis: Cervical cord compression due to cervical canal stenosis secondary to ossification of the cervical posterior longitudinal ligament, resulting in complete tetraplegia, and restrictive respiratory failure.

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient should follow up with the rehabilitation team for further management of tetraplegia. The patient is advised to continue their respiratory rehabilitation and to seek medical attention immediately if there are any marked changes in their breathing or respiratory function. Regular follow-up appointments with the rehabilitation team and monitoring of their respiratory and neurologic functions are recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Summary:
A 56-year-old male with a history of hypertension presented with an inability to abduct the right eye. Over the past 34 years, he had noted progressive limitation in all movements of the right eye with occasional diplopia. He also had an acute onset of right-sided facial weakness and dysarthria a month ago. The patient had a right horizontal conjugate gaze palsy, limited adduction of the right eye with nystagmus of the left eye on abduction, and a right peripheral facial nerve palsy. Magnetic resonance imaging showed a hemorrhage with a well-defined lesion with a "popcorn ball" appearance that resembled that of a cavernoma at the level of the pons/ponto-medullary junction.

Hospital Course:
The patient was co-managed by neurosurgery and neurology services for possible resection.

Diagnostic Results:
The patient had no relative afferent pupillary defect on presentation. Slit lamp examination was essentially unremarkable except for immature cataracts. Indirect ophthalmoscopy showed hypertensive retinopathy on both eyes. Magnetic resonance imaging showed a hemorrhage with a well-defined lesion with a "popcorn ball" appearance that resembled that of a cavernoma at the level of the pons/ponto-medullary junction.

Final Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with a cavernoma at the level of the pons/ponto-medullary junction.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient was discharged with improved symptoms.

Treatment:
The patient was co-managed by neurosurgery and neurology services for possible resection.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to follow-up with their primary care physician and neurologist after discharge.

Course and Outcome of hospitalization:
The patient had a successful hospitalization with improved symptoms and was discharged with follow-up recommendations.

Discharge Summary:

This is a summary of care provided to a 21-year-old female who presented with visual complaints related to a retinal lesion in the right eye.

Hospital Course:

The patient was diagnosed with a subretinal lesion with subretinal fluid and pigment epithelial detachment in the right eye, sparing the fovea. The patient was also diagnosed with factor VIII deficiency.

Treatment:

Focal laser photocoagulation was performed on an extrafoveal choroidal neovascular membrane (CNVM). The patient was treated with photodynamic therapy (PDT) followed by intravitreal triamcinolone acetonide (IVTA) injection (4 mg/0.1 ml) 2 days later. Thermal laser photocoagulation was done due to persistent hyperfluorescence related to the extrafoveal CNVM. The patient was treated with four intravitreal injections of bevacizumab (1.25 mg/0.05 ml) at an interval of 4–6 weeks.

Course and Follow-Up:

While the patient's visual acuity improved and the CNVM appeared scarred at times, the patient experienced repeated recurrences of the neovascular membrane and was treated with additional injections of bevacizumab. The hyperfluorescence also persistently recurred. The patient was seen 10 years post-injection and remained stable, with a maintained visual acuity of 20/20.

Diagnosis:

Subretinal lesion with subretinal fluid and pigment epithelial detachment in the right eye, factor VIII deficiency, extrafoveal and juxtafoveal choroidal neovascular membrane.

Disposition:

The patient is discharged from the hospital and advised to continue follow-up with their prescribing physician.

Patient Information:
The patient is a 54-year-old female who received BPA in advance of right thumb carpometacarpal arthroplasty with ligament reconstruction. Post-operation, she experienced right thumb pain, and her right hand felt “heavy” with the fingers stacked vertically on top of each other.

Hospital Course:
After surgery, the patient's immobility in her 2nd through 5th digits in the stacked position lasted for approximately 3.5 days and 69 hours after the anesthesia wore off. Although the phantom sensations were uncomfortable, she experienced no pain in her fingers. No nerve conduction studies were performed.

Discharge Summary:
The patient underwent successful right thumb carpometacarpal arthroplasty with ligament reconstruction. She reported pain in her thumb post-operation, but the sensation of immobility in her fingers has since subsided. No additional complications have been reported.

Follow-up:
The patient should be advised to avoid any strenuous activity and should monitor her pain levels in the coming weeks. The development of any new symptoms should be immediately reported to her physician.

Signed,
[Physician's Name]

Hospital Course:
This is a summary of a 70-year-old male patient who presented to the emergency department after experiencing two brief loss of consciousness episodes following a light meal at home. The patient was evaluated in the emergency department for a fall and was found to have tenderness in both the right and left lower quadrants of the abdomen, with some voluntary guarding. CT of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrated moderate hemoperitoneum with splenic laceration as well as a nondisplaced fracture of the 5th metatarsal. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit, where serial abdominal exams and hemoglobin measurements were performed every four hours. His hemoglobin fell to 8 g/dL but eventually stabilized, and the patient was discharged home on hospital day 3 in good condition.

History and Physical:
The patient denies striking his head, chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, or blood in his stools. His past medical history includes coronary artery disease, high cholesterol, and hypertension. On physical exam, the patient had normal head, neck, chest, and neurological exams. However, he had tenderness in the right and left lower quadrant of the abdomen with some voluntary guarding. Orthopedic exam demonstrated tenderness to his right acromioclavicular joint and ecchymosis of his right 5th metatarsal with no deformity and normal range of motion at all joints.

Diagnostic Studies:
Lab studies showed a hemoglobin level of 12.4 g/dL with normal platelets and chemistry studies. Head CT and shoulder and chest radiography were normal. Foot radiography demonstrated a nondisplaced 5th metatarsal fracture. CT of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrated moderate hemoperitoneum with splenic laceration.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit and underwent serial abdominal exams and every four-hour hemoglobin measurements. His hemoglobin fell to 8 g/dL at 48 hours after admission but subsequently stabilized.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
The patient had hemoperitoneum with splenic laceration, which was likely a result of the fall. He was observed in the hospital and ultimately discharged home on hospital day 3 in good condition.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to follow up with his primary care physician for further evaluation of his abdominal pain, with particular attention paid to his colonoscopy.

Discharge Summary: 

Patient Information:
- Name: [REDACTED]
- Age: 36
- Sex: Female

Hospital Course: 
The patient was admitted for revision of left total hip arthroplasty. She has congenital insensitivity to pain with anhidrosis (CIPA) and presented with recurrent episodes of unexplained fever, burns, and bone fractures. She has undergone multiple surgeries for spinal deformity and total hip arthroplasty in both sides. Before the procedure, routine monitoring and bispectral index (BIS) were initiated, and her body temperature was controlled at approximately 36°C. Propofol was given for anesthesia, muscle relaxation was achieved, and trachea was intubated. Surgery was performed for 6 hours and 49 minutes, and the patient lost 3350 ml of blood, which was replaced with 1600 ml of autologous blood, 900 ml of salvaged blood, and 720 ml of fresh frozen plasma. 

Discharge Instructions:
- The patient was discharged at 6 weeks after the operation. 
- She did not complain of pain after surgery, so no analgesics were prescribed.
- No clinical abnormalities were detected.
- Blood samples were collected 3 times for catecholamine fractions and cortisol levels, which were within normal ranges.
- Follow-up with her orthopedic surgeon was scheduled.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a male in his early seventies, was admitted with a diagnosis of recurrent HCC. On abdominal dynamic CT, he presented with a mildly hypervascular and ring-enhanced nodule accompanied by venous wash-out on abdominal dynamic CT in the S5 of the remnant liver. Laboratory data were mostly normal, with the exception of mildly elevated AST, total bilirubin, and CEA levels. The initial diagnosis by the clinicians was recurrent HCC, and a partial S5 hepatectomy was performed. On gross examination, the cut surface of hepatic nodule showed a poorly demarcated portal nodule in lobulated margins with central necrosis. A microscopic examination of the tumor showed an unencapsulated, ill-defined, and expansive/infiltrative nodule, displaying a solid proliferation of atypical epithelial cells, arranged predominantly in solid nests, trabeculae, and/or irregular and fused tubule-like structures, aggressively involving the portal vein with focal perineural invasion. 
The final diagnosis was primary CHC-INT, and the recurrence of CHC-INT in the remnant liver occurred 1 year and 3 months after surgery. The patient remains not worse with follow-up for the postoperative 2 years.  

Summary:
Male in his early seventies presented with recurrent HCC. Partial S5 hepatectomy was performed, and microscopic examination of the tumor showed an unencapsulated, ill-defined, and expansive/infiltrative nodule. Diagnosis was primary CHC-INT, and recurrence occurred 1 year and 3 months later. Follow-up for the postoperative 2 years shows the patient remains stable.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Patient name: [REDACTED]
Age: 62
Gender: Male

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with refractory sacral coccygeal pain and was diagnosed with sacrococcygeal involvement by a thyroid carcinoma, predominantly papillary (follicular variant), however with foci of nondifferentiated (insular) carcinoma. The patient underwent a total sacrectomy with partial excision and reconstruction of the left iliac bone, followed by a total thyroidectomy. Radioactive iodine therapy was performed after the thyroidectomy. Post-therapy scintigraphy showed hyperfixation in the remnants of the sacrum and lower lumbar spine, bilateral iliac bone, and anterior cervical region. TSH-stimulated thyroglobulin was 24490 ng/mL. Follow-up magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed persistence and progression of the pelvic lesion.

Patient Condition:
At the time of discharge, the patient was unable to walk, suffered from fecal incontinence, presented with uncontrolled refractory chronic pain, and had a chronic indwelling bladder catheter.

Final Diagnosis:
Sacrococcygeal involvement by a thyroid carcinoma, predominantly papillary (follicular variant), however with foci of nondifferentiated (insular) carcinoma

Treatment:
The patient underwent a total sacrectomy with partial excision and reconstruction of the left iliac bone, followed by a total thyroidectomy. Radioactive iodine therapy (RAI) was then performed.

Prognosis:
The patient's follow-up magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed persistence and progression of the pelvic lesion. The patient's current condition is poor, suffering from uncontrolled pain, fecal incontinence, and unable to walk. Close monitoring and additional interventions may be necessary to further manage the patient's symptoms.

Hospital Course:

The 64-year-old male was admitted with a complaint of pain in the left iliac region. A pelvic CT was performed, which revealed a lytic lesion of left iliac bone with soft tissue involvement. A biopsy was performed, and the histological examination and immunohistochemical staining showed iliac involvement of a well-differentiated thyroid carcinoma. Thyroid ultrasonography revealed nodules in both lobes.

Management:

The patient underwent total thyroidectomy, which revealed a papillary carcinoma of the follicular variant. Radioactive iodine therapy was performed. Post-therapy imaging did not show any further lesions. The TSH-stimulated thyroglobulin level was elevated.

Discharge:

The patient is waiting for a hemipelvectomy. The hemipelvectomy will be followed by rehabilitation therapy to help him adjust to the new physical limitations. Appropriate referrals have been made to support the patient's care ongoing.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 57-year-old Japanese man, presented with back pain and fever and was found to have an aneurysm of the infrarenal aorta and inflammation of surrounding adipose tissue. The patient was admitted to the hospital and diagnosed with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) based on clinical findings of left maxillary sinusitis, multiple nodular lesions in the lungs, fever, and positive anti-PR3-ANCA. The patient was treated with intravenous semipulse dose of methylprednisolone, followed by oral prednisolone 1 mg/kg (55 mg) per day and intravenous administration of cyclophosphamide (700 mg/body once per month). The patient's symptoms and CT findings rapidly improved, and the PR3-ANCA level promptly decreased to the normal range. The diameter of the aneurysm changed from 34 mm to 21 mm after treatment. On tapering doses of steroids, the patient is currently in remission, and the inflammation and PR3-ANCA elevation have completely resolved.

Findings:

Upon admission, the patient exhibited a fever of 39.6°C, leukocytosis and an elevated C-reactive protein level. A CT scan revealed an aneurysm of the infrarenal aorta, with a diameter of 34 mm, inflammation of surrounding adipose tissue, nodular lesions of the bilateral lungs and left maxillary sinusitis. A thoracoscopic lung biopsy demonstrated granulation tissue with necrosis and multinucleated giant cells.

Treatment:

The patient was treated with intravenous semipulse dose of methylprednisolone, followed by oral prednisolone 1 mg/kg (55 mg) per day and intravenous administration of cyclophosphamide (700 mg/body once per month).

Outcome:

All of the patient's symptoms and CT findings rapidly improved, and the PR3-ANCA level promptly decreased to the normal range. The diameter of the aneurysm changed from 34 mm to 21 mm after treatment. On tapering doses of steroids, the patient is currently in remission, and the inflammation and PR3-ANCA elevation have completely resolved. There has been no disease recurrence for 4 years after initiation of therapy.

Follow-up:

The patient will require lifelong monitoring due to the risk of disease recurrence.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: 
Medical Record Number: 
Age: 55
Sex: Male
Date of Admission: 
Date of Discharge: 

Diagnosis:
- Sinus node dysfunction (SSS)

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department with 2 episodes of unprovoked syncope and nausea, accompanied by somnolence, after being discharged three weeks earlier from the hospital for right frontal nodule resection of his multifocal glioblastoma multiforme. The patient's vital signs at the time of admission were stable, but with a temporary pause on the cardiac monitor that was symptomatic. The patient was diagnosed with SSS, and a pacemaker implantation was performed. After 24-hour monitoring post-procedure, the patient was discharged home to be followed up at the pacemaker clinic. During the follow-up, the patient's hemiparesis did not recover.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient's condition at the time of discharge was stable but showed a rapid progression of all lesions, except the one in the pons, with vasogenic edema and midline shift. The patient was advised to seek immediate medical attention if they experience any further syncope, nausea, somnolence, or general weakness.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient was discharged with a follow-up plan to schedule a repeat CT scan to monitor the progression of the glioblastoma and further management of the illness.

Medications:
No medication information available.

Instructions:
No other Instructions available.

[Physician Name]
MD

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A

Hospital Course:
The 66-year-old female patient from North-Africa had been admitted to our department due to an indolent ulcerovegetative mass on the anterior face of the right thigh. The patient's medical history revealed a hot-water burn to her leg at the age of 11 years, which had been treated conservatively and left a large scar on the skin surface. The patient had noticed a progressive mass in the scar area 2 months prior to admission. The mass was diagnosed as Marjolin's ulcer based on physical examination and histopathologic features of the surgical specimen. The diagnosis of cutaneous extraosseous osteosarcoma was suggested after a computed tomography scan that excluded an origin in bone or other primary tumor sites. Unfortunately, the patient did not accept the proposed definitive large surgical excision.

Hospital Course Summary:
The hospital course of the 66-year-old female patient from North-Africa was marked by the diagnosis of a Marjolin's ulcer on the anterior face of the right thigh. The ulcerovegetative mass was observed to have originated from a hot-water burn scar that had been left untreated. Following physical examination and pathological analysis, the mass was identified as a cutaneous extraosseous osteosarcoma and a therapeutic proposal of definitive large surgical excision was suggested. However, the patient declined the treatment option, and there was no further notice regarding her evolution.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 48-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1
Admission Date: [date]
Discharge Date: [date]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of abdominal fullness and weight loss of 10 kg over the past year. Physical examination revealed a large elastic hard mass extending from the xiphoid to the pubic bone. The magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) examination showed a huge tumor on the uterine corpus with a number of dilated vessels observed between the tumor and the myometrium. Computed tomography (CT) examination showed no lymph node swelling or distant metastasis. Preoperative laboratory testing revealed anemia, for which blood transfusions were administered before surgery. Preoperative serum levels of CEA, CA 19-9, CA 125, and LDH were within normal limits.

The patient underwent a laparotomy, where a huge tumor was identified occupying a space from the pelvis to the diaphragm with a diameter of 30 cm. A total abdominal hysterectomy (TAH) and right salpingo-oophorectomy (RSO) were performed. The excised specimen weighed 7600 g. The intraoperative frozen section report for the uterine tumor was of degenerated myoma with no findings indicating malignancy.

On permanent histological examination, the tumor was mostly comprised of degenerated uterine leiomyoma. However, an area of approximately 2 cm × several mm with atypical cells showing a fine meshwork microvascular structure was observed in the blood vessel cavity, consisting of cubic, polygonal, and short spindle-shaped cells with abnormal mitotic figures indicative of malignancy. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed the atypical tumor cells to be positive for ERG, CD31, and AE1/3, partially positive for Factor VIII, and negative for α-SMA, desmin, H-caldesmon, EMA, CD34, and D2-40. The final diagnosis was epithelioid angiosarcoma arising in a degenerated uterine leiomyoma.

The patient received six courses of combination adjuvant chemotherapy with paclitaxel, epirubicin, and carboplatin after surgery. No recurrence has been observed 10 months after the primary surgery.

Discharge Diagnosis:
- Epithelioid angiosarcoma arising in a degenerated uterine leiomyoma

Discharge Instructions:
- Follow up with your healthcare provider as directed
- Continue any medications or treatments as prescribed
- Avoid strenuous activities and lifting heavy objects
- Report any unusual symptoms such as pain, swelling, or bleeding to your healthcare provider immediately
- Attend all scheduled appointments and recommended screenings for follow-up care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]

Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented with complaints of abdominal pain, distension, and weight loss over the past two months. She was diagnosed with an expansive mass in the right abdominal quadrants on a CT scan.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent laparotomy, and a well-defined partially cystic tumor originating from the fifth and sixth hepatic segments was found. En bloc resection of the mass and a S5-S6 liver bisegmentectomy were performed.

Diagnostic Assessment:
Histological analysis revealed the tumor as a rare type of liver cancer called Undifferentiated Embryonal Sarcoma of the Liver (UESL). Immunostaining also revealed positive expression of CD10, CD68, and vimentin in tumor cells.

Treatment:
Following multidisciplinary evaluation, the patient received an adjuvant therapy of six cycles with vincristine, actinomycin D, and cyclophosphamide. The patient did not experience any major postoperative complications and was discharged on the sixth postoperative day.

Follow-up:
The patient has been doing well 30 months after surgery with no signs of recurrence.

Conclusion:
The patient was diagnosed with UESL, underwent laparotomy, and received six cycles of adjuvant therapy. She was discharged after a successful recovery and has been doing well without any complications. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and follow up regularly with the treating physician.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Medical History:
The patient is a 14-year-old male with DMD who has been on daily oral steroids since the age of 9. He became nonambulatory at the age of 12 and has been participating in wheelchair soccer. He has a body weight of 53 kg (47th percentile) and height of 147 cm (less than 3rd percentile). The patient has had moderate obstructive sleep apnea, and recent echocardiogram (ECHO) revealed normal cardiac function.

Presenting Complaints:
The patient presented to the emergency department following soccer practice with confusion, tachycardia, tachypnea, and fever. The patient's right leg brushed the ground during practice, causing him to fall and become dislodged from his wheelchair. Shortly after, he developed progressive acute hypoxic respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation.

Hospital Course:
The patient was intubated and suffered cardiac arrest requiring 3 minutes of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), with return of spontaneous circulation. Computed tomography (CT) scans were completed, and no acute intracranial pathology was identified. Chest CT scan showed patchy diffuse nodular airspace opacities throughout both lungs. Duplex ultrasound of lower extremities was negative for deep venous thrombosis. X-rays showed femoral neck and fibular metaphysis fractures. Ophthalmological exam revealed Purtscher-like retinopathy. The patient was treated with antibiotics for 48 hours with negative blood, urine, and mini bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) cultures. The patient was also treated with mechanical ventilation and right ventricular afterload reduction therapy for pulmonary hypertension. These treatments were successful, and therapies were weaned off, and the patient was extubated on day five of his admission. He remained admitted to the pediatric floor and was later discharged home without any residual complications.

Discharge Plan:
The patient was given instructions for close follow-up with his primary care physician. The patient was also advised to follow up with his ophthalmologist for further assessment of his Purtscher-like retinopathy. The patient was prescribed pain medications and encouraged to continue physical therapy to optimize his mobility. Follow-up appointments with his pulmonologist were also scheduled to monitor the patient's respiratory status. The patient was discharged in stable condition following an uneventful course.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Length of Stay: [Redacted] days
Attending Physician: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient is an 11-year-old male with Duchenne muscular dystrophy who presented with a nondisplaced Salter-Harris type II fracture of the distal left femur. He underwent surgical fixation and was discharged on the day of the operation. Two days later, he presented to the emergency department with a seizure, tachycardia, tachypnea, and fever up to 38.6 degrees Celsius. He developed acute hypoxic respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation. Shortly after intubation, he developed pulmonary hemorrhage and anemia which were treated with fresh frozen plasma, ventilator adjustments, and blood transfusion. A CT scan of his chest demonstrated bilateral patchy infiltrates; no pulmonary embolism was identified. He was treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics for 72 hours. Mechanical ventilation was able to be weaned, and the patient was extubated on day five of admission. He was later transferred to the pediatric floor and subsequently discharged without any residual effects.

Medical History:
The patient has Duchenne muscular dystrophy and has been on daily oral steroids since 9 years of age. He is able to ambulate without assistance and his forced vital capacity was 1.5 L or 96% predicted. His echocardiogram was normal with cardiac MRI demonstrating normal left ventricular ejection fraction.

Laboratory and Diagnostic Results:
CBC, BMP, coagulation studies, blood, urine, and mini BAL cultures were negative. Fast spin MRI of his head was negative, and CT scan of his chest demonstrated bilateral patchy infiltrates. ECHO showed mildly elevated tricuspid regurgitation velocities representing increased right ventricular and pulmonary artery pressures.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged home with follow-up scheduled with his primary care physician.

Follow-up Plan:
Follow-up with the primary care physician for further management of DMD and to monitor for any potential complications related to the fracture and hospitalization.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Twin 1

Date of Admission: [DATE]

Date of Discharge: [DATE]

Hospital Course: 

Twin 1, a three-year-old Caucasian boy, was admitted to Royal North Shore Hospital due to photophobia and frequent blinking of the left eye. The patient was diagnosed with varicella-zoster virus (VZV) keratitis of the left eye and treated with intravenous acyclovir and topical acyclovir. The condition showed signs of resolution on follow-up examinations.

One year after his initial presentation, Twin 1 reported symptoms of interstitial keratitis and bilateral corneal neovascularization. Further investigation revealed the likely cause to be staphylococcal hypersensitivity/chronic blepharokeratoconjunctivitis (BKC) secondary to meibomianitis. Treatment was initiated using erythromycin, chloramphenicol ointment, and fluorometholone.

Despite these interventions, Twin 1's symptoms and neovascularization persisted, and it became necessary to administer subconjunctival triamcinolone acetonide and bevacizumab. Lid hygiene, Meibomian gland expression, and regular follow-up examinations were also performed. Six weeks after receiving the injections, significant improvement in symptoms was reported, and subsequent EUA showed marked improvement in cornea appearance.

Twin 1 continued on the same medication regimen and received subconjunctival triamcinolone and bevacizumab injections in the left eye. Further EUA showed quiescent interstitial keratitis and the need for diathermy to be applied to feeder vessels of each eye. Binocular BCVA was 20/63.

At EUA 5 months after further bilateral triamcinolone injections, central corneal scarring, and suppressed blood vessels were observed bilaterally. Diathermy was again applied to the limbus of each eye. After two years from initial presentation, Twin 1 was discharged from hospital with binocular BCVA of 20/63. 

Summary:

Twin 1 was diagnosed with VZV keratitis and was treated with acyclovir. One year after his initial presentation, the patient had interstitial keratitis, bilateral corneal neovascularization, blepharitis, and conjunctivitis. Clinical investigation identified staphylococcal hypersensitivity/chronic BKC as the most likely cause. The patient underwent subconjunctival triamcinolone acetonide and bevacizumab injections and received ongoing medication and treatment for DIathermy. After two years, the patient was discharged with binocular BCVA of 20/63.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 15-year-old female with a history of obesity who presented to the emergency department with flexion at the thoracolumbar region and back pain, which progressed over three years following a sexual assault. She had no neurologic complaints but showed tenderness to palpation of the paraspinal muscles. Physical exams and tests showed no abnormality. The symptoms were likely manifestations of Conversion Disorder after exclusion of organic causes. 

Discharge Diagnosis:

Conversion Disorder

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient presented with severe flexion at the thoracolumbar region and constant back pain three years after a sexual assault, which progressed to the point where she was only able to walk using a walker with the axillae on the hand grips. Physical exams and tests were negative for any organic cause, and the symptoms were diagnosed as Conversion Disorder. The patient received social services support and physical therapy, but declined psychiatric outpatient care at this time.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: __________
Medical Record Number: __________
Date of Admission: __________
Date of Discharge: __________
Length of Stay: __________

History and Reason for Admission:
The patient is a 28-year-old female with no significant past medical history who presented with sudden onset periumbilical pain that migrated to the right iliac fossa accompanied by intermittent fever, nausea, and loss of appetite. The examination by two senior surgeons revealed guarding and rebound tenderness at the right iliac fossa. Hematological tests showed polymorphonuclear leukocytosis with left shift. USG could not visualize appendix. An Alvarado score of 9/10 was calculated, leading to the clinical diagnosis of acute appendicitis. Laparotomy was performed, and intraoperatively, the appendix appeared normal.

Hospital Course:
During the laparotomy, a hemorrhagic lesion appeared little deeper in the mid abdomen when the medial edge of the incision was retracted superomedially. To further explore this lesion, the incision was extended transversely from the medial edge. The exploration revealed an ulcerated lesion measuring 7 × 5 cm arising from the antimesenteric border of the ileum 8 feet from ICJ with localized interloop hemoperitoneum and inflammatory exudates. Resection of ileal segment containing the lesion was performed followed by restoration of bowel continuity and peritoneal toileting. Subsequently, the lesion was reported to be an ulcerated malignant ileal GIST. On gross examination, the growth from the ileum had villous lining epithelium with focal ulceration. The submucosal region had a circumscribed nodule with proliferation of loosely cohesive spindle cells; some of which were arranged in vague storiform pattern and others in long fascicles. The patient had an uneventful recovery and was discharged on the 8th postoperative day. She was advised to review a week later at the outpatients but failed to report.

Diagnosis:
The diagnosis in this case is an ulcerated malignant ileal gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST).

Treatment:
The treatment for the patient's condition was surgical resection of the ileal segment containing the lesion followed by restoration of bowel continuity and peritoneal toileting.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient was advised to review a week later at the outpatients but failed to report. All possible contacts were used to trace her, but she remained inaccessible and lost to follow-up.

Summary:
This summary describes a 28-year-old female with sudden onset periumbilical pain that migrated to the right iliac fossa. Hematological tests showed polymorphonuclear leukocytosis with left shift. USG could not visualize appendix, and a clinical diagnosis of acute appendicitis was made. Appendix appeared normal during laparotomy. A hemorrhagic lesion was found little deeper in the mid abdomen during the surgery, and a subsequent transverse incision extended from the medial edge revealed an ulcerated malignant ileal GIST measuring 7 × 5 cm arising from the antimesenteric border of the ileum 8 feet from ICJ. The patient had an uneventful recovery from the surgery, and was discharged on the 8th postoperative day. The patient was advised to review a week later at the outpatients but failed to report, and remained lost to follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 54 years
Gender: Female
Medical Record No.: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with intermittent vaginal bleeding and feeling of a mass in her vaginal area. Upon examination, a 2.0 × 1.5 × 1.3 cm sized pedunculated mass was found on the vaginal wall which was subsequently excised. Histologic examination confirmed clear cell carcinoma with positive CD10, PAX-8, and CA-IX immunohistochemical stains and negative CK7. Radiological studies revealed a left renal mass, bilateral adrenal masses and enlarged retroperitoneal lymph nodes. The patient underwent a left radical nephrectomy and adrenalectomy that confirmed the renal origin of the carcinoma. The final pathological stage was pT3a pNx pM1. 

Treatment and Management:
The patient received targeted therapy (Sunitinib 50 mg) as adjuvant therapy. Multiple pulmonary nodules and a right adrenal nodule were observed on imaging which showed improvement after targeted therapy. However, the patient's vaginal mass recurred and the pathology report of the partial excision of the vaginal wall lesion revealed CCRCC with extensive rhabdoid differentiation.

Follow-up:
The patient is advised regular follow-up visits with their oncologist for further management and evaluation. 

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged to continue her management as an outpatient.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Patient Age: 16

Gender: Male

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis: Drowning in cold river water

Discharge Diagnosis: Complete recovery with no pathological signs

Hospital Course:

Upon admission, the patient presented with somnolence, anxiety, pale skin, tachypnea, and hypothermia. ECG TA, pulse, body temperature, and pulse oximetry were monitored. A nasogastric tube and a urinary catheter were placed. The patient's oxygen saturation was low at 80% but later normalized with oxygen therapy. Chest radiography showed spotty shadows in the middle and inferior lobes with free costodiaphragmatic recess sinuses bilaterally. The patient was immediately warmed up with thermal blankets, and parenteral antibiotic therapy and rehydration were administered. On the fifth day after admission, the patient showed complete recovery, including withdrawal of the chest radiographic symptoms and no pathological signs were visible on physical examination of the lungs.

Follow-up:
During each attempt to get up, atrial fibrillation or individual SVES and VES triplets were registered. A dose of Presolol was included in the therapy, with advice of strict inaction and avoidance of any kind of physical exertion. Two months later, the control echocardiography revealed that heart function had improved further.

Summary:
The patient was admitted after drowning in cold river water. The patient initially presented with symptoms of somnolence, anxiety, pale skin, tachypnea, and hypothermia. The patient was treated with parenteral antibiotic therapy and rehydration. On the fifth day after admission, the patient showed complete recovery. Follow-up care included treatment for atrial fibrillation and advice of strict inaction and avoidance of any kind of physical exertion. Two months later, the patient's heart function had further improved. The patient was discharged with a complete recovery and no pathological signs.

Hospital Course:

Admitted with sudden onset visual loss in right eye. Dilated fundus examinations revealed a normal macula in left eye. Right eye showed retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) alteration and resolved preretinal and subretinal hemorrhages. A diagnosis of Valsalva retinopathy was made based on the history and treatment photographs.

Hospital Stay:

Patient was monitored and screened with fundus fluorescein angiography. At the 1st month of examination, all hemorrhages were resolved but RPE alterations were still present at the margin of the inferior temporal arterial vascular arcade in the right eye. The patient was screened with OCTA and two lesions were identified. En face OCT angiogram of OCTA revealed full thickness retinal hole formation and ellipsoid zone damage at the superior and inferior margin of the inferior temporal arterial vascular arcade. Superficial vascular plexus was also damaged at that region.

Discharge Summary:

27-year-old male patient with acute onset of visual loss in the right eye, diagnosed with Valsalva retinopathy. Resolved hemorrhages were found in the macula in the right eye. The patient was screened for any other vascular pathologies with fundus fluorescein angiography and OCTA. Lesions were identified in the OCTA full thickness retinal hole formation and ellipsoid zone damage with superficial vascular plexus damage. Patient was discharged in stable condition and was instructed to follow-up with a specialist.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient, a 5-year-old boy, was admitted with a 3-month history of recurrent fevers, joint pain, fatigue, and weight loss. The medical evaluation revealed a past history of group A Streptococcus pharyngitis. During the physical examination, a new systolic murmur was noted; therefore, he was further evaluated and admitted for management.

The laboratory evaluation showed acute inflammation, elevated antistreptolysin O titers, and mild anemia. The echocardiographic findings demonstrated moderate left atrial enlargement, severe mitral valve regurgitation, and aortic valve regurgitation. Based on the clinical symptoms, echocardiographic findings, and history of preceding group A Streptococcus infection, he was diagnosed with acute rheumatic fever. The patient was treated with intramuscular penicillin G benzathine and started on glucocorticoids for severe carditis. He also received aspirin for symptomatic management of arthritis.

The patient demonstrated clinical improvement during the hospitalization, and he was eventually discharged with recommendations to continue the secondary prophylaxis with penicillin G benzathine every 4 weeks for the next 10 years. The parents were also instructed to follow up with their pediatrician for further management and monitoring.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

Acute rheumatic fever

CONTACT INFORMATION:

The following physician(s) may be contacted for any further questions or concerns regarding this patient's treatment: [REDACTED]

FOLLOW-UP CARE:

The patient was advised to follow up with his pediatrician for regular monitoring and management of his condition. The parents were instructed to continue the prescribed medication regimen and schedule the next appointment with the pediatrician for further evaluation.

MEDICATIONS:

The patient received intramuscular penicillin G benzathine, glucocorticoids, and aspirin. The parents were instructed to follow the prescribed medication regimen as directed by their pediatrician.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

1. Continue the prescribed medication regimen.
2. Follow up with the pediatrician for regular monitoring and management of the condition.
3. Contact the pediatrician if any new or concerning symptoms arise.
4. Maintain a healthy diet and lifestyle.

Hospital Course:

81-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus, presented with abdominal discomfort and distension. On physical examination, hepatomegaly was noted without jaundice, ascites, or hepatic encephalopathy. Laboratory data revealed platelet count of 101,000/mm3, total bilirubin of 0.9 mg/dL, AST of 33 IU/L, ALT of IU/L, and PT-INR of 1.15. Given the findings of four HCC lesions found in segments II, VI, and VIII, with the largest being near the liver capsule, segmental TACE with epirubicin and iodized oil was performed. Fifteen days after TACE, the patient developed abdominal pain and was transported to the hospital. Emergent CT scan showed intraperitoneal free air and a rupture of the HCC in segment II into the peritoneal cavity adjacent to the gastric wall. The patient was managed nonoperatively with piperacillin and tazobactam to control the formed abdominal abscess and was discharged after 18 days, with continued antimicrobial therapy. 

The patient was readmitted after five weeks with hematochezia and hemorrhagic shock. A contrast-enhanced CT scan showed gastric extraluminal compression by an HCC lesion and extravasation of contrast medium into the stomach. A submucosal tumor with central ulceration was detected on the anterior wall of the gastric body via upper gastrointestinal endoscopy. The hemorrhage from the ulcer was treated after successful hypertonic saline-epinephrine injection. An additional submucosal tumor without ulcer formation was observed in the gastric fundus. The patient's condition stabilized, and he was discharged for palliative care. The patient subsequently expired six weeks after undergoing TACE.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 16
Sex: Female
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Length of Stay: 14 days

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented to the emergency room with altered mental status and emesis. There was a history of polyuria and polydipsia for 2 weeks and 8 to 10 kg weight loss during the previous month. On further investigation, it was found that the patient was suffering from diabetic ketoacidosis.

Hospital Course:
The patient received fluid resuscitation with 30 mL/kg of normal saline and 50 mEq of sodium bicarbonate in the ER. Continuous insulin infusion was started at 0.1 unit/kg/hr. After the patient was transferred to the PICU the patient received isotonic fluid with potassium phosphate and potassium chloride and without any bicarbonate. The patient exhibited severe metabolic acidosis which was managed with close monitoring and serial laboratory evaluations. 

After a few hours of arrival in the PICU, the patient became disoriented and confused and was given one time 5 ml/kg of 3% hypertonic saline due to concern for cerebral edema and she responded well. Afterwards, the patient was given additional doses of 3% hypertonic saline bolus (5 mL/kg) and 0.8 g/kg of 20% mannitol. 

Hyperosmolar therapy was guided with close monitoring of renal function including serum sodium and serum osmolarity. The patient's serum sodium was 135 upon arrival in the ER and 143 at around 11 hrs before the initiation of hyperosmolar therapy and reached to 160 at 71 hrs when hyperosmolar therapy was discontinued. It was normalized to 143 at 131 hrs of admission. Her osmolarity was 298, 305, 335, and 299 at those timings.

MRI brain obtained at 60 hrs of admission showed mild edema of the cortex and sulci and diffuse edema of the pons and midbrain with restricted diffusion in the pons consistent with central pontine myelinolysis also known as osmotic demyelination syndrome. The patient required continued mechanical ventilation and further management in the PICU but eventually required intubation and mechanical ventilation for recurrent apnea.

Hematology workup showed no underlying hypercoagulability. The patient developed bilateral upper extremity deep venous thromboses (DVT) which were attributed as a complication of DKA.

The patient's overall hospital course was complicated, but she became more responsive on day 5, and her support was gradually weaned until extubation on day 7. 

Discharge Condition:
At the date of discharge, the patient was able to ambulate with a walker and speak, and eat without difficulty. The patient exhibited only mild residual dysmetria, trivial ataxia, mild left-sided weakness, and neglect. All deficits subsequently improved.

Follow-Up Plan:
The patient will be needing regular follow-up checks with pediatricians. 

Summary:
The patient was a 16-year-old female with a history of polyuria and polydipsia and with recent weight loss who presented to the emergency room with altered mental status and emesis. Further investigation showed that she was suffering from diabetic ketoacidosis. During the hospital stay, the patient's condition became complicated and was diagnosed with osmotic demyelination syndrome. The patient's overall hospital course was complicated, but at the time of discharge, the patient was able to ambulate, speak, and eat without difficulty. The patient will require regular follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [date]
Discharge Date: [date]

Patient Name: [name]
Medical Record Number: [number]
Date of Birth: [date]

Hospital Course: 

The patient was admitted to the hospital due to pulmonary embolism 24 hours following a caesarian section. Upon arrival, she was hemodynamically unstable with low blood pressure, high heart rate, low saturation, and high breathing rate. Cardiopulmonary arrest occurred during transportation and CPR was immediately initiated. The patient was then transferred to the Intensive Care Unit. She continued to be hemodynamically unstable and a distended abdomen was noted. The patient was transfused with two blood units and a Diagnostic Peritoneal Lavage was positive for intra-abdominal bleeding. An exploratory laparotomy was urgently performed, during which a 5 cm liver laceration was discovered and successfully repaired. Unfortunately, the patient passed away after three hours in the operating room due to massive pulmonary embolism.

Medical Issues:

The patient experienced severe pulmonary embolism following a caesarian section. During CPR, she developed intra-abdominal bleeding caused by a liver laceration. Although liver surgery was successful in repairing the damage and controlling the intra-abdominal bleeding, the patient passed away due to massive pulmonary embolism.

Follow-up Care:

The patient was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit following pulmonary embolism and later underwent emergency surgery for intra-abdominal bleeding caused by a liver laceration. Despite successful surgery and correction of the bleeding, the patient unfortunately expired due to another episode of massive pulmonary embolism. 

Disposition:

The patient expired after three hours of emergency surgery. A full chart review has been conducted.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

DOB: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis: Hemorrhagic shock due to bleeding from vessels originating from the lesser curvature of the stomach.

Admission Physical Examination:
At presentation the patient was hemodynamically unstable (blood pressure= 100/55 mmHg, heart rate= 135 beats/min, and breaths= 25 per min) and afebrile (36.7 C).

Hospital Course: 
The patient was admitted with hemorrhagic shock due to bleeding from vessels originating from the lesser curvature of the stomach. CPR had been instituted in situ by an experienced lifeguard prior to transfer. The patient was transfused with 2 blood units and received fluid resuscitation, however, remained hemodynamically unstable. Abdominal ultrasonography revealed free intra-abdominal fluid and exploratory laparotomy was decided upon. The site of bleeding was found to be vessels originating from the lesser curvature of the stomach, which were successfully ligated. The patient had an uneventful recovery and was discharged on the 12th postoperative day. 

Discharge Instructions: 
The patient is to report to the emergency department or seek immediate medical attention if experiencing any unusual symptoms such as abdominal pain, profuse bleeding, fever, or shortness of breath. The patient is advised to follow up with their primary care physician for further evaluation and to receive care instructions. 

Follow-Up: The patient will follow up with their primary care provider to monitor their progress and ensure they are on track to a healthy recovery.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 49 years
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with a suspected tumor in her pelvis. An MRI examination revealed mobility of the tumor, which led to further investigations. A mass-sized 45 mm on the right side of the pelvic floor was found through a contrast CT image. The tumor was nourished by vessels from the splenic artery to the greater omentum. Based on the diagnostic tests and imaging findings, a preoperative diagnosis of a suspected omental primary tumor or accessory spleen was made. The patient underwent a single-incision laparoscopic-assisted greater omental tumor resection, a surgery to remove the tumor, to prevent torsion and to diagnose and treat the tumor concurrently. The greater omentum and the tumor were removed without any complications.

Diagnosis:
The histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of an omental PEComa, a tumor involving large and small blood vessels. These tumors are rare and originate from perivascular epithelioid cells.

Treatment and Follow-up Plans:
The patient did not face any complications post-surgery, and she underwent a smooth recovery. She was discharged without further complications after the surgery. The patient underwent follow-up at regular intervals, and there has been no recurrence of the tumor observed after 16 months since the surgery.

Final Diagnosis:
Post-operation, the final diagnosis of the patient was an omental PEComa. The patient underwent successful surgery and follow-up, and there have been no complications or recurrence observed to this date.

Abbreviations: 
MRI: Magnetic Resonance Imaging
CT: Computed Tomography
18F-FDG-PET/CT: Positron Emission Tomography/Computed Tomography
CEA: Carcinoembryonic Antigen
CA19-9: Cancer Antigen 19-9
PEComa: Perivascular Epithelioid Cell Tumor
HMB45: Human Melanoma Black 45
Melan-A: Melanocyte-specific antigen A
α-SMA: Alpha-Smooth Muscle Actin

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 26-year-old primigravida, presented to the Muhimbili National Referral Hospital, Tanzania, in active labor at 39-week gestation. A precipitous vaginal delivery occurred and post-delivery, the patient experienced profuse hemorrhaging. She underwent interventions such as vigorous massage of the uterus, administration of 10 IU of intravenous oxytocin, and manual removal of the placenta. Despite these measures, the bleeding persisted, resulting in unconsciousness. An examination revealed that the uterus was well contracted but bilateral vaginal sulcal lacerations were identified with minimal bleeding superior to the cervix. The patient urgently proceeded to the operating theatre for repair of vaginal lacerations. Despite unsuccessful attempts at suture repair, bleeding from laceration sites continued. A senior Obstetrician and Gynecology consultant placed an ESM-UBT device into the vaginal canal and inflated it with 300 ml of water, securing it with vaginal packing. The hemorrhage ceased, and the patient was given antibiotics, intravenous fluids, and blood products. The device was removed after 48 hours, and the patient was discharged home on postpartum day two.
Disposition:
The patient was discharged with fully recovered health, with no further repair necessary. Follow-up care was scheduled for a six-week postpartum visit, at which point the patient had no further complications or adverse events.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 22
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Cervical Pregnancy
Discharge Diagnosis: Resolved Cervical Pregnancy

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 22-year-old pregnant woman, was brought to the hospital for termination of pregnancy via dilation and suction curettage. During the attempted cervical dilation, she experienced profuse bleeding and was immediately referred to our facility. On admission, the patient presented with a blood pressure of 80/30 mm/Hg and heart rate of 145 bpm. Imaging brought with the patient revealed a cervical pregnancy. The patient was taken to the operating theatre, where an ESM-UBT device was placed into the cervix and inflated with 200 cc of water, filling the cervix, and ballooning into the lower uterine segment and vagina to help control the bleeding. Vaginal packing was used to hold the uterine balloon's position. The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit and received isotonic fluids and two units of blood. After 24 hours, the ESM-UBT device was removed, and there were no further episodes of bleeding. The patient was monitored for six weeks, and there were no complications.

Diagnostic Tests and Results:
Outside imaging confirmed a cervical pregnancy.

Final Diagnosis:
Cervical Pregnancy

Treatment:
The patient received an ESM-UBT device that was placed into the cervix and inflated with 200 cc of water, filling the cervix, and ballooning into the lower uterine segment and vagina. Vaginal packing was used to secure the uterine balloon's position. The patient received isotonic fluids and two units of blood. The ESM-UBT device was removed after 24 hours without any resumption of bleeding.

Condition on Discharge:
Resolved Cervical Pregnancy

Follow-up Plans:
The patient was discharged in stable condition and referred to a specialist for further follow-up. No further treatment was required after a six-week follow-up.

Signed,
[redacted]
Attending Physician

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospitalization History: 
The patient was admitted to Government Medical College Nagpur National Hospital, India due to vaginal bleeding. On physical examination, she was found to have a 32-week uterus and a closed cervix. Ultrasound was suggestive of a molar pregnancy. The patient underwent cervical dilation and evacuation under general anaesthesia. Post-evacuation, the patient suffered from atonic uterus and severe hemorrhage, leading to transfusion of blood. The patient eventually regained hemodynamic stability after the insertion of an ESM-UBT device. The device was removed after 24 hours, and the patient remained stable during follow-up visits.

Diagnosis: 
Complete molar pregnancy.

Treatment Provided: 
The patient underwent cervical dilation and evacuation under general anaesthesia after which she developed an atonic uterus and severe hemorrhage. Bimanual uterine massage was performed, the bladder was drained, fluid resuscitation was initiated, and oxytocin (20 IU) and ergometrine (0.4 mg) were administered intravenously. Followed by the insertion of an ESM-UBT device and transfusion of blood which resulted in the cessation of hemorrhage. During the hospitalization, vital signs were monitored and assessed. The device was removed after 24 hours.

Outcome: 
The patient was discharged two days after the removal of the ESM-UBT device. There were no complications on subsequent two-week and six-week follow-up visits. The patient was advised to continue clinical monitoring throughout the year.

Follow-Up Care: 
The patient is advised to continue clinical monitoring throughout the year. No further treatment is required at this time.

Summary:
A 27-year-old pregnant woman presented with vaginal bleeding and was diagnosed with a complete molar pregnancy. After undergoing cervical dilation and evacuation, she suffered from atonic uterus and severe hemorrhage. An ESM-UBT device was inserted, and the hemorrhage was immediately stopped, leading to hemodynamic stability. The device was removed, and the patient remained stable during follow-up visits. The patient is advised to continue clinical monitoring.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:
