The patient, a 67-year-old Caucasian female with a history of polycystic liver disease and portal hypertension, presented to the hospital with a one-day history of hematemesis and melena. She had a previous diagnosis of esophageal varices, which had been successfully banded during an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) one year prior. Upon admission, the patient complained of epigastric pain and had two episodes of bright red emesis and four episodes of dark colored stools, followed by a brief syncopal episode lasting for 10-15 seconds. 

Physical examination revealed the patient to be afebrile but tachycardic, tachypneic, and hypotensive. Cardiopulmonary examination was normal, and abdominal examination showed mild distension with epigastric and right upper quadrant tenderness. Initial laboratory work showed low hemoglobin, hematocrit, and platelet counts, along with nonanion gap metabolic acidosis and elevated total bilirubin level. 

The patient was resuscitated with fluids, pressors, and PRBC transfusion and was electively intubated due to hemodynamic instability and altered mental status. An EGD was performed, revealing varices with stigmata of high risk for bleeding. The procedure was successful, with bands applied starting from cardia up to midesophagus. A CT scan of the abdomen showed an enlarged spleen, ascites, and multiple cysts in the liver, consistent with portal hypertension. The patient was closely monitored, and pressors were weaned off. She did not have any further episodes of hematemesis but continued to have melena and required additional PRBC transfusions. 

Repeat EGDs were performed showing additional esophageal varices with intact bands from the previous procedure. The patient successfully underwent additional banding, and her hemoglobin remained stable for the rest of her hospital stay. 

During her hospital stay, the patient underwent therapeutic paracentesis with normal peritoneal fluid analysis (except for serum ascites albumin gradient greater than 1.1 g/dl) and was prescribed propranolol, furosemide, and spironolactone for management of portal hypertension. She was discharged home with instructions to follow up in the outpatient clinic in 3-4 weeks for further management. 

Diagnosis:

1. Esophageal varices
2. Portal hypertension 
3. Polycystic liver disease

Treatment:

1. Fluids
2. Pressors
3. PRBC transfusion
4. Octreotide
5. Proton pump inhibitor
6. Therapeutic paracentesis
7. Banding of esophageal varices
8. Propranolol
9. Furosemide
10. Spironolactone

Follow-up:

The patient was instructed to schedule a follow-up appointment with the outpatient clinic in 3-4 weeks for further management.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Admission Date: N/A 
Discharge Date: N/A 
Admitting Diagnosis: Duodenal lesion 
Discharge Diagnosis: Pyloric gland adenoma 

Hospital Course Summary:

A 59-year-old Asian male presented for follow-up of a previously found duodenal lesion. His past medical history was significant for atrophic gastritis with patchy areas of intestinal metaplasia and chronic H. pylori gastritis. Two years prior, he had undergone an EGD at an outside facility which showed a 1.2 cm duodenal polypoid lesion. On presentation to our office, upper endoscopy showed atrophic gastritis, duodenitis, and a single 10mm polyp in the second portion of the duodenum. Pathology revealed polypoid gastric metaplastic mucosa with focal epithelial atypia including nuclear enlargement, stratification, nucleoli, and few mitoses. The patient was referred for endoscopic ultrasound to further characterize the lesion and complete resection which revealed a pyloric gland adenoma with mostly low grade dysplasia and small areas of focal high grade dysplasia. The patient was lost to follow-up for over one year but then returned for a surveillance upper endoscopy which revealed no evidence of residual pyloric gland adenoma.

Disposition:

The patient was recommended to follow up for surveillance endoscopy in 5 years in line with the ASGE guidelines for surveillance of gastric adenomatous polyps.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Suspected urinary tract infection with perineal pain and fever

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient, a 56-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled insulin-dependent type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypothyroidism, and meatal stenosis with incomplete bladder emptying, was admitted into the hospital with symptoms of perineal pain and fever. The patient had been seen in the emergency room a week prior to the admission with the same complaints and was placed on a 14-day course of antibiotics. 

Upon admission, the patient was hemodynamically stable, but physical examination showed mild tenderness at penoscrotal junction with induration, elevated white blood cell count, creatinine level, and hemoglobin A1c levels. Emphysematous changes were noted on CT scan, and the patient had a postvoid residual of 320 ml. Thus, a transurethral Foley catheter was placed with withdrawal of 700 ml of clear yellow urine; culture reports are still pending.

The patient was initiated on intravenous meropenem, fluconazole, and daptomycin. A subsequent CT scan showed no significant changes, and the patient remained febrile. Based on the recommendation of the Infectious Disease team, the patient was switched to piperacillin/tazobactam which resulted in a slight decrease in fever. A pelvic MRI with and without gadolinium was obtained, and reduced blood flow to corpus spongiosum compared to corpus cavernosum with gadolinium was discovered.

Due to worsening symptoms, the patient underwent debridement of remaining necrotic spongiosal tissue and placement of a penrose drain. The intraoperative wound culture later tested positive for Candida glabrata, which was identical to the patient's urine culture. According to the recommendation of the Infectious Disease team, the patient was prescribed micafungin for the infection, and he was discharged on a 14-day course of oral voriconazole with the transurethral Foley in place.

Final diagnosis: Candida glabrata infection with necrotizing spongiositis of the penis.

Follow-up:
The patient was instructed to follow-up with his urologist for evaluation of the persistent induration in the penoscrotal junction and the transurethral Foley. He was also advised to monitor his blood sugar levels closely, ensure proper nutrition and exercise, follow up with his primary care physician, and continue taking his prescribed medications. 

Overall, the patient's condition had improved, and he was advised to seek medical attention immediately if he experiences any concerning symptoms or see his urologist if any new symptoms arise.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Sex: Male
Age: 66 years old
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]
Primary Care Physician: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 66-year-old male with a complicated history of cardiac disease, was admitted to the hospital on [redacted]. The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes, dyslipidemia, and prior bilateral carotid endarterectomy. The patient also underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) 15 years ago and redo CABG 2 years ago. The patient presented with limiting angina, despite being on maximally titrated medical therapy of aspirin, prasugrel, carvedilol, ranolazine, isosorbidemononitrate (sustained release), atorvastatin, lisinopril, nitroglycerin patch, and as needed sublingual nitroglycerin.

Four months prior to admission, the patient underwent coronary angiography which revealed a long, 95% stenosis in the mid-left anterior descending artery (LAD). A Synergy drug-eluting stent (Boston Scientific) was deployed at 12 atmospheres, which temporarily improved the patient's symptoms. However, the patient presented again with rest pain, and repeat coronary angiography revealed a stent fracture with 70% in-stent restenosis. The patient underwent coronary intervention and a Xience Alpine DES was deployed inside the fractured Synergy DES with TIMI III flow and no residual stenosis. The patient tolerated the procedure and was discharged in stable condition.

Diagnoses:
This hospitalization was mainly due to the patient's cardiac disease, including extensive coronary artery disease, hypertension, diabetes, and dyslipidemia.

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to follow-up with his primary care physician and a cardiologist. The patient is advised to continue his medications and to make lifestyle modifications to manage his cardiac health.

Summary:
The 66-year-old male with complicated cardiac history was admitted for limiting angina and underwent coronary angiography, stent deployment, and repeat coronary angiography with successful intervention for stent fracture. The patient was discharged in stable condition and advised to follow-up with primary care physician and cardiologist.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 26-year-old female with bilateral retroocular pain, odynophagia, fever, vaginal discomfort, and vulvar ulcers

History of present illness:

The patient presented to our emergency room with bilateral retroocular pain, odynophagia, fever, vaginal discomfort, and vulvar ulcers. She was previously treated with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and valacyclovir for labial herpes. However, the ulcers continued to progress, which led to her admission to the Vulvar Clinic of our institution.

Hospital Course:

Physical examination of the vulva revealed extended vulvar oedema and kissing pattern ulcers on labia minora and majora, vagina, and cervix. Inguinal lymph nodes were also bilaterally swollen. Initial blood tests showed high levels of C-reactive protein. Serologies for various viruses and infectious diseases were negative. Immunological examination revealed positive results for rheumatoid factor, anti-nuclear antibodies, and antibodies to SSA/Ro. The patient had a high IgG level, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate was also high.

Labial salivary gland biopsy revealed focal lymphocytic sialadenitis (FLS), with a focus score obtained by four LSGs. The patient was diagnosed as having pSS on the basis of dry eyes and dry mouth, positive anti-SSA/Ro antibody, and typical histopathological abnormalities on LSG biopsy.

The patient was prescribed Prednisolone 20 mg/day, which led to vulvar healing within two weeks with partial loss of the left labia.

Follow-up Care:

The patient was discharged after the prescribed treatment with Prednisolone was complete. Further follow-up care was recommended and scheduled at a later date.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 25-year-old male

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to our Oral Surgery Clinic with recurrent pain and swelling on his right cheek. He had previously undergone bimaxillary orthognathic surgery in a local hospital. During the operation, an orthodontic appliance was dislodged into his right cheek, which was found during the postoperative period. The appliance was left in-situ with continuous clinical observation due to the absence of sign and symptoms during further follow-up sessions.
After undergoing examination and radiography, a sinus track was found which was suspected to originate from the dislodged orthodontic appliance embedded in the cheek soft tissue. After further investigation through exploration of the site under general anesthesia, the dislodged molar tube was identified lying on the zygomatic bone just beneath the raised flap, which was removed by dividing some surrounding fibrous tissue strands. A titanium straight bone plate with four screws used for fixing the previous Le Fort I osteotomy site was found to be rigidly embedded in normal bone below the removed appliance. Due to the site being infected, the plate and screws were removed.
The patient had an uneventful recovery and was informed of his progress.

Final Diagnosis:
Dislodged orthodontic appliance in right cheek with associated foreign body reaction and infection.

Prognosis:
Good prognosis following removal of dislodged orthodontic appliance and infected bone plate.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient will have continuous clinical observation following surgery, and the orthognathic surgical team who attended him previously was informed of his progress.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Confidential
Medical Record #: XXXXX
Hospital ID: XXXXX

Hospital Course:
The 9-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital due to repeated loss of consciousness, concomitant with a pale face, palpitations, and convulsions. The symptoms had persisted for 2 years and had been aggravated during the previous 2 months. The patient was previously misdiagnosed with epilepsy in another hospital, but no abnormal findings were detected on a 24-h electroencephalogram at our hospital. Her abdominal perfusion CT showed a highly perfused nodule within the pancreatic tail, while a magnetic resonance scan confirmed the location of this nodule. Additionally, 68Ga-exendin 4 PET-CT showed a region in the pancreatic tail with abnormally high metabolism and overexpression of the glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor. Lab testing showed low fasting blood glucose, a high proinsulin level, a normal C-peptide level, a serum insulin level, and a gastrin level. These results confirmed a diagnosis of insulinoma. A minimally invasive insulinoma enucleation surgery under the Da Vinci robot-assisted system with intraoperative ultrasound was performed, and the patient was discharged on postoperative day 6. Pathological examination showed that the tumor was a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor with a Ki-67 index of 4%. This tumor was positive for CgA, Syn, and AE1/AE3, while gastrin, glucagon, and somatostatin staining were negative. Sanger-directed sequencing for the MEN1 gene mutation was also performed, revealing a homozygous pathogenic mutation of c247_250delCTGT (p.Ile85Serfs*33).

Discharge Diagnosis:
Insulinoma

Procedures:
Minimally invasive insulinoma enucleation surgery under the Da Vinci robot-assisted system with intraoperative ultrasound

Follow-Up Instructions:
The patient should follow up with her endocrinologist for blood glucose monitoring and further management of her insulinoma. She should also continue to maintain a healthy diet and lifestyle.

Medications:
None

Allergies or Adverse Reactions:
None

Discharge Condition:
Stable

Discharge Disposition:
Home

Legal Information:
The patient and her family were informed of the risks, benefits, and alternatives of the proposed surgery and gave their informed consent for the procedure. The patient was discharged in stable condition with appropriate follow-up instructions.

Hospital Course Summary: 

Patient is a 41-year-old female who was admitted with symptoms of persistent liver dysfunction, painless xanthochromia and skin itching for 3 months. Physical examination revealed severe icteric sclera and skin without any abdominal tenderness. 

Diagnostic Results: 

Liver function tests showed severe hepatic injury and obstructive jaundice. Ultrasound of the liver showed a cystic mass with sharp margins in the left medial liver lobe and obstruction of the biliary tract. CT and MRI confirmed the presence of a cystic mass with homogeneous water-density lesions, indicating a hepatic cyst. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiography revealed a lump in the common bile duct but no stones were found. A subsequent open procedure confirmed a large pedunculated lump from the liver, which resembled the gallbladder with a capsule wall and capsular space. Histopathologic examination confirmed the lump was a hepatic cyst wall without heterocysts or tumor cells. 

Hospital Course: 

Endoscopic retrograde biliary drainage (ERBD) and endoscopic nasobiliary drainage (ENBD) were performed to drain bile in order to manage severe hepatic injury and jaundice, instead of laparotomy due to coagulation disorders. After these procedures, there was a gradual decrease in icteric sclera and skin, recovery of liver function, and normalization of coagulation disorders. Four weeks later, open operation was performed, and the pedunculated lump from the liver was removed entirely from the lump's root through endoscopic needle-knife electrotomy without active hemorrhage. 

Treatment: 

A T-tube was retained in the common bile duct to prevent bile leakage and observe the recovery of the root incision of the lump and postoperative bleeding. The patient was discharged with appropriate post-operative care instructions. 

Follow-up: 

Epigastric ultrasound and CT two months later showed a normal hepatic duct and unchanged hepatic cyst size. Choledochoscopic examination was performed through a T-tube fistula. The cyst had remained unchanged, and there was no evidence of bile duct tumor. Three years after the procedure, the patient was in good health, without signs of cholestasis or bile duct stones. The cyst had barely changed in size. 

Summary: 

This hospital course summary is for a 41-year-old female who presented with persistent liver dysfunction and painless xanthochromia and skin itching for 3 months. She was diagnosed with a hepatic cyst and managed with endoscopic procedures and open surgery to remove a pedunculated lump from the liver, which resembled the gallbladder with a capsule wall and capsular space. The patient was discharged with post-operative care instructions and continued to follow up in the subsequent years.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: Confidential
Admission Date: XX/XX/XXXX
Discharge Date: XX/XX/XXXX

History of Presenting Illness:
The patient, a 27-year-old woman, was admitted with a one-month history of facial edema, weight loss, and acne. She had previously sought medical attention at a local hospital for facial redness and edema caused by eating a mango, and was treated with dexamethasone for five days. The patient gradually developed severe facial edema, beard, central deposition of fat with slim extremities and atrophic muscles, and no pretibial edema over the course of one month. 

Medical History:
The patient had a history of a 5.5-cm mass located in the right posterior lobe of the liver detected by ultrasound in a routine physical examination 16 months ago at a local hospital. However, the patient did not experience any symptoms at that time.

Physical Examination:
Upon hospitalization, the patient was found to have “moon face” and severe facial edema, beard, central deposition of fat with slim extremities and atrophic muscles, and no pretibial edema. The skin was diffused with acne, and both armpits had hyperpigmentation.

Diagnostic Findings:
Laboratory tests revealed that the patient had marked hypokalemia, which did not normalize with oral and intravenous potassium supplementation until spironolactone was added. A 75-g oral glucose tolerance test confirmed diabetes mellitus. Endocrinological investigation identified severe hypercortisolism with loss of circadian rhythm, and plasma ACTH level was elevated to 1157 pg/mL, confirming ACTH-dependent Cushing’s syndrome. MRI and contrasted MRI revealed no pituitary adenoma. Abdominal contrast-enhanced CT scanning revealed that the mass lesion was located in the right adrenal gland and not in the right hepatic posterior lobe. PET/CT showed moderate fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) uptake in the mass.

Treatment:
Adrenal tumorectomy was performed, and no hypertensive crisis occurred during surgery. A 6.5-cm black mass was found arising from the medial branch of the right adrenal gland. Hematoxylin-eosin staining of the tumor revealed that most of the cells were chromaffin-like cells. Immunohistochemical staining of the tumor showed positive staining for chromogranin A (CgA) and CD56, with a Ki67 labeling index of approximately 16% for chromaffin-like cells. ACTH levels decreased from 715 to 14.3 pg/ml one day after surgery, and serum cortisol levels decreased from more than 50 to 10.4 μg/dl. The patient's signs and symptoms of Cushing’s syndrome gradually disappeared within two months, and the hydrocortisone supplementation was discontinued seven weeks postoperatively. CT revealed that the left adrenal gland was almost reduced to the normal size three months later.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition and is currently under regular follow-up.

Follow-Up:
The patient is currently well nine months after surgery and will continue to be followed up regularly.

Hospital Course Summary: Pediatric Intensive Care Unit Admission for Cardiorespiratory Failure

Admission Diagnosis: Asphyxiating Thoracic Dysplasia (Jeune Syndrome) and End-Stage Renal Disease with Post-Renal Transplantation; Chronic Rejection on Immunosuppressive Therapy

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:
The four-year-old female patient was admitted to our tertiary care pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) with a diagnosis of cardiorespiratory failure. She was intubated and started on mechanical ventilation shortly after admission. The patient had a history of asphyxiating thoracic dysplasia (Jeune syndrome) and end-stage renal disease with a post-renal transplantation. She was chronically on immunosuppressive medications for ongoing renal rejection. Additionally, she was receiving peritoneal dialysis for renal failure and was recently started on dapsone for Pneumocystis prophylaxis. During her 3-week hospital stay, she developed several complications, including sepsis, electrolyte imbalance, and thrombocytopenia. She was prescribed with several medications, including fentanyl, midazolam, mycophenolate, prednisolone, pantoprazole, cefepime, and dapsone. 

On the third week of her admission, the patient developed diarrhea and metabolic acidosis. She was further noted to have cyanosis and low oxygen saturation levels (82%-87%) despite the escalation of inspired oxygen levels to 100%. The patient underwent blood gas analysis, which was consistent with metabolic acidosis and thus prompted a suspicion of methemoglobinemia. Co-oximetry was ordered, and the result showed a methemoglobin level of 21.5% (normal range is 0% to 2%). Hemolysis was ruled out upon conducting laboratory workup. As the patient had end-stage renal disease, methylene blue was contraindicated. As a result, daily ascorbic acid was administered orally via a gastrostomy tube, and dapsone was discontinued. Serial methemoglobin levels on co-oximetry showed an improvement trend. Within 48 hours, the methemoglobinemia resolved, and the level came down to 0.4 mg/dL. The patient continued to receive ascorbic acid for four more days, after which it was discontinued. Following discontinuement of ascorbic acid, the methemoglobin level remained less than 0.3 mg/dL. 

After a thorough review of the patient's medications and workup, it was determined that dapsone was the probable cause of methemoglobinemia. In light of this, the patient was prescribed with pentamidine nebulization for Pneumocystis prophylaxis.

At the time of discharge, the patient's cardiorespiratory function had significantly improved, with a stable methemoglobin level. Further follow-up care is warranted, given that the patient has a history of asphyxiating thoracic dysplasia, end-stage renal disease, and chronic rejection with ongoing use of immunosuppressant medications. 

Discharge Condition: Stable 
Discharge Medications: [None]
Follow-up Care: [Recommended Consultations, Appointments and Medications]

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Admitting Diagnosis:
Guillain–Barre syndrome

Hospital Course:
A 15-year-old female was admitted to the hospital with a history of progressive lower limb weakness, inability to pass urine, and intermittent lower abdominal pain for two days. The patient had no associated symptoms such as fever, rash, headache, backache, or blurring of vision. The patient received neural tissue sheep brain anti-rabies vaccine 24 days prior to developing these symptoms following a dog bite.

Upon admission, neurological examination revealed no facial asymmetry, intact cranial nerves but decreased muscle power in lower limbs with hypotonia and loss of knee and ankle reflexes bilaterally. Urinary bladder was palpable above the symphysis pubis and was tender on palpation. The results of laboratory tests were within normal limits.

Based on physical examination and CSF findings, the patient was diagnosed with Guillain–Barre syndrome. Electrophysiological study supported this diagnosis, and plasmapheresis and physical therapy sessions resulted in a nearly complete recovery over six to eight months.

Disposition and Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in fair condition with instructions for home care and follow-up appointments as needed.

Instructions at Discharge:
The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care physician as needed and encouraged to seek medical attention promptly if her symptoms were to recur or worsen.

Diagnostic Studies:
- Neurological examination revealing facial asymmetry, intact cranial nerves but decreased muscle power in lower limbs with hypotonia and loss of knee and ankle reflexes bilaterally.
- Laboratory investigations revealed hemoglobin of 12.5 g/dl with the hematocrit of 44%; TLC was 6500/cmm and ESR at the first hour using Westergren method was 23 mm.
- Cerebrospinal fluid examination (CSF) revealed clear fluid, normal opening pressure, glucose 75 mg/dl (normal range: 45–100 mg/dl), proteins 2.5 g/l (normal range: 0.18–0.45 g/dl), and WBCs 2/cmm (albuminocytologic dissociation).
- Electrophysiological study revealed demyelinating polyneuropathy consistent with Guillain–Barre syndrome.

Condition at Follow-Up: 
The patient's condition has improved, and she is currently asymptomatic.

Discharge summary:

Identification and demographics:
This is a discharge summary for a 68-year old male who presented with an isolated right axillary mass and was diagnosed with poorly-differentiated neuroendocrine carcinoma of unknown origin.

Hospital course:
The patient underwent six cycles of carboplatin and etoposide chemotherapy and achieved a partial response after three cycles, but showed evidence of tumor growth after cycle 6. He was then referred to the Experimental Cancer Medicine Team and consented to TARGET. In parallel, he underwent surgical resection of the isolated axillary mass in July 2015, which achieved a complete resection and permitted access to fresh tissue for PDX and translational research.

Following a brief disease-free period, the patient relapsed with metastatic nodules within the retroperitoneum in December 2015. He was subsequently treated with capecitabine and temozolamide between March and October 2016. Treatment was then switched to interferon and sandostatin, which has kept his disease stable by RECIST 1.1 criteria at the time of writing.

Summary of hospital stay:
This patient presented with an isolated right axillary mass and was diagnosed with poorly-differentiated neuroendocrine carcinoma of unknown origin. He underwent six cycles of carboplatin and etoposide chemotherapy, followed by surgical resection of the isolated axillary mass. He relapsed with metastatic nodules within the retroperitoneum, which were treated with capecitabine and temozolamide, and then interferon and sandostatin. His current condition is stable by RECIST 1.1 criteria.

Disposition and follow-up:
The patient has been discharged and will continue to follow-up with his oncology team.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital in January 2016 with large volume hematemesis from esophageal varices due to portal hypertension. The patient had a previous diagnosis of PAN, which was based on skin biopsies. The patient also had lymphopenia and hypogammaglobulinemia. He had a history of recurrent mouth and genital ulcers, as well as visual loss in childhood.

During the hospital stay, the patient received appropriate treatment for his symptoms. The patient was monitored closely during his hospital stay, and his condition gradually improved. The patient was discharged in stable condition with appropriate follow-up appointments scheduled.

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with PAN, lymphopenia, and hypogammaglobulinemia.

Discharge Medications:

The patient was discharged on his current medications including prednisone.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient was instructed to follow up with his primary care provider and specialists as recommended. He was advised to continue his current medications and report to his healthcare provider any new symptoms. It was recommended that the patient avoid alcohol and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

Follow-up Appointments:

The patient is scheduled to follow-up with his primary care provider and specialists. It is recommended that he maintains regular follow-up appointments to monitor his condition.

Signed,
[Name], MD

[Hospital Course Summary]

Admitted: [Date of Admission]
Discharged: [Date of Discharge]
Length of Stay: [Number of days]

Patient [patient's name], a 43-year-old Caucasian male, was admitted to [hospital name] with a suspected diagnosis of DADA2, based on the patient's clinical presentation and familial history. The patient's brother, Patient 1, had a similar presentation.

The patient's medical history was significant for juvenile idiopathic arthritis at the age of 5 and stage IV Hodgkin's lymphoma at the age of 8, which was treated with radiation therapy and chemotherapy. The patient achieved remission 1 year later. At the age of 24, the patient developed left-sided persistent numbness followed by bilateral sensorineural hearing loss with near complete left-sided deafness. At the age of 26, he presented with bright red blood in his stool, which required resection of 6 inches of small intestines. By age 29, he developed heart failure and pulmonary hypertension presumed secondary to ABVD treatment. His history was also significant for superior vena cava occlusion, presumed secondary to a port catheter, and esophageal varices.

Immunologic evaluation revealed normal immunoglobulins, lymphocyte proliferation to mitogens, and lymphocyte subsets except for a slightly low CD8 count (83/µl). He had protective antibody levels to tetanus. 

Genetic testing was performed and confirmed the diagnosis of DADA2. Adenosine deaminase 2 levels were tested in Patient 2 and compared to DADA2 patients, adult carriers for ADA2 mutations and adult healthy controls.

The patient was treated with appropriate management and monitoring. The patient was discharged in a stable condition with follow-up appointments scheduled with the appropriate specialists.

The patient was instructed to follow a healthy lifestyle and adhere to the prescribed medication regimen. The patient was advised to seek medical attention immediately if any symptoms develop or worsen.

In conclusion, the patient was admitted with suspected DADA2 and was subsequently diagnosed and treated appropriately. The patient was discharged in a stable condition with appropriate follow-up appointments scheduled.

Discharge Summary

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Age: 35
Gender: Female

Diagnosis:
Craniopharyngioma

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital complaining of an intermittent headache for 5 years, menopause for more than 2 months, and blurred vision and lactation for more than 1 month. She had an irregular cystic solid mass in the suprasellar area that involved the pituitary stalk and the optic chiasm. The patient was evaluated and diagnosed with a craniopharyngioma. She underwent total resection of the tumor from the second gap along the longitudinal axis of the pituitary stalk.

After surgery, the patient had no complaints and did not receive any hormone replacement therapy. One year later, the patient was re-evaluated and was found to have a normal frontal lobe function except for an impaired GH level. The IGF-1 level was 92 ng/ml. Cranial and pituitary MRI showed no expansion of the sellar region, no signs of a local tumor, no abnormal enhancement, a clear boundary of the optic chiasm, and no signs of tumor recurrence.

Follow-up:
The patient was discharged with instructions to follow-up with her endocrinologist for further evaluation of her GH levels and IGF-1 levels. A repeat MRI scan was recommended in 6 months to monitor for recurrence. 

Impressions:
1. Craniopharyngioma
2. Impaired GH level

Discussed with:
Patient and family

Signed,
[Physician's Name]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Male
Age: 54
DOB: [Redacted]
Date of admission: [Redacted]
Date of discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted for further evaluation and monitoring of his respiratory performance due to progressive shortness of breath, intermittent cough with yellowish sputum and dyspnoea upon exertion, and bilateral lung fields infiltration observed on chest X-ray. During hospitalization, the patient had no fever, and respiratory pattern was smooth with  peripheral capillary oxygen saturation (SpO2) being 95% under ambient air. Autoimmune markers, including rheumatoid factor, antinuclear antibody, anti-Smith antibody, anti-ribonucleoprotein antibody, anti-SSA, anti-SSB, and anti-Scl-70, were all negative. Polymerase chain reaction of Pneumocystis jiroveci from induced sputum was negative.

Chest X-ray revealed diffuse interstitial infiltration bilaterally, while chest CT disclosed extensive patchy ground-glass opacities superimposed with thickened interlobular septa and intralobular lines over both lung fields, demonstrating a “crazy paving” pattern. Pulmonary function test showed normal spirometry and moderately reduced diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO) on single breath diffusing capacity test.

Bronchoscopy indicated no endobronchial lesions. A radial probe endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) showed a “blizzard sign”, suggesting ground-glass opacity over the superior segment of the right lower lobe. Pathological report of the four 0.2 × 0.2 × 0.1 cm tissue fragments obtained by forceps biopsy indicated only chronic inflammation. On the other hand, the four 0.5 × 0.5 × 0.2 cm tissue fragments acquired by cryobiopsy revealed periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)-positive granular proteinaceous exudate with mild interstitial lymphocytic infiltration filling the alveolar spaces consistent with PAP.

The patient declined whole lung lavage and opted for close surveillance. He was discharged with outpatient follow up. Later, his shortness of breath spontaneously resolved, and serial chest X-rays showed resolution of the interstitial infiltration of the lungs.

Diagnosis:

1. Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)

Procedure:

1. Bronchoscopy
2. Radial probe endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS)
3. Forceps biopsy
4. Cryobiopsy

Follow up:

The patient will have outpatient follow up.

Dictated by: [Redacted]
Attending Physician: [Redacted]
Date of Dictation: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:

A 5-year-old male was admitted to the hospital with acute behavioral changes, manifesting as uncontrolled aggression, requiring inpatient psychiatric treatment. Basic labs including complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel were normal. Specifically, no cytopenias, no transaminitis, and normal inflammatory markers including CRP and platelet count were noted. MRI of the brain demonstrated multiple small nonenhancing foci on T2 FLAIR sequence, mostly in the frontal lobes and scattered throughout the subcortical white matter. The lesions remained unchanged on repeat MRI at 2 weeks and again at 4 months following presentation. PCR revealed presence of EBV in the blood (2300 copies/ml). CSF also demonstrated EBV (73 copies/ml). CSF was otherwise normal apart from only slightly elevated CSF WBC (8 cells/mm3), of which 79% were lymphocytes and 21% monocytes.

Treatment:

Intravenous gamma globulin 1 g/kg and intravenous ganciclovir 10 mg/kg/day were started immediately. However, despite 14 days of ganciclovir treatment, EBV counts remained significantly elevated. Rituximab was administered on days 16 and 23 of admission. Prednisolone 1 mg/kg/day was given daily on days 16 through 23, and IVIG 1 g/kg was repeated on day 23. Valganciclovir 45 mg/kg/day was continued for 4 months after ganciclovir treatment. Prior to rituximab infusion, EBV counts had reached 2300 copies of EBV genome/mL of blood. Five days after the second rituximab infusion CD19+ and CD20+ lymphocytes and EBV PCR were found to be absent in the blood and remained absent for 5 months.

Discharge Planning:

Hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) was performed after 5 months of treatment with rituximab. IgM to EBV was undetectable at the time of presentation, and the patient never seroconverted. The family was advised on post-HSCT care and the importance of adherence to the post-HSCT regimen. They were also educated on the importance of regular follow-up appointments with the immunology service. Appropriate consults and referrals were arranged for the patient's needs. The family was instructed on safety measures and advised to seek medical attention immediately in case of any adverse events.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Age: 12 Years
Sex: Female
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

HOSPITAL COURSE:
This 12-year-old girl with a history of insulinoma and hyperparathyroidism was admitted to the hospital with an episode of seizure with impaired consciousness. Her blood glucose level at that time was 60 mg/dL (normal value of casual blood glucose: 70–200 mg/dL), for which glucose was administered and she recovered consciousness. Arterial phase images of computed tomography showed a vascularity-rich tumor of 20 mm in diameter located in the head of the pancreas, which was removed by enucleation. No other tumors related to MEN-1 were detected. Her intact parathyroid hormone level was 66.0 pg/mL (normal value: 10–65 pg/mL) and her adjusted serum calcium level was 10.3 mg/dL (normal value: 8.7–9.9 mg/dL). Preoperative examinations were otherwise unremarkable.

On the day before surgery, an Enlite™ sensor of MiniMed™ 620G SCGM system was inserted into her upper arm to monitor blood glucose levels. She was administered general anesthesia using propofol, fentanyl, and remifentanil, and muscle relaxation was achieved using rocuronium. An epidural catheter was inserted, and anesthesia was maintained using sevoflurane, remifentanil, and thoracic epidural administration of levobupivacaine. An arterial catheter was also inserted. Blood glucose levels were monitored continuously throughout the surgery and were managed using intravenous glucose administration.

After surgery, the patient was transferred to the general surgery ward. Her postoperative course was uneventful, and she was discharged on POD 10.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1. Insulinoma
2. Hyperparathyroidism

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

1. Take all prescribed medications as directed by the physician.
2. Follow-up with your primary care provider as recommended.
3. Monitor blood glucose levels as directed by the physician.
4. Contact the physician immediately if you experience any symptoms such as dizziness, confusion, or seizures.
5. Follow any dietary restrictions or recommendations provided by the physician.
6. Avoid strenuous activities for at least one week following discharge.
7. If you have any questions or concerns, please contact the physician.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:
Patient: 83-year-old female with a history of uterine cancer who presented with a left renal tumor 20 mm in diameter in her horseshoe kidney.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent a laparoscopic tumor resection with clamping of four arteries. A histopathological examination revealed clear cell carcinoma (grade 2, INFα, v[−], pT1a). The patient did not experience any urinary tract leakage during the procedure. After coagulation using bipolar forceps, the surgical site was sutured with 1-0 Vicryl and sprayed with Arista AH, followed by the placement of a drainage tube. The patient was discharged after 11 days without any complications. Follow-up visits showed no recurrence of the tumor for 43 months.

Laboratory Data:
The patient had a slight anemia and low liver function (Hb 12.3 g/dL, AST 52 IU/L, ALT44IU/L, and LDH 201 IU/L).

Imaging:
Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) showed a renal tumor covered with a capsule and buried by nearly 30%, supplied by four arteries toward the left kidney.

Diagnosis:
Left renal tumor (20 mm in diameter) in a horseshoe kidney.

Treatment:
Laparoscopic tumor resection with clamping of four arteries, followed by coagulation, suturing, and spraying with Arista AH. A drainage tube was placed, followed by a hospital stay of 11 days.

Follow-up:
Patient was discharged 11 days after surgery and has been free from recurrence for 43 months. Follow-up visits were scheduled to monitor for any potential recurrence of the tumor.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not Disclosed
Age: 32
Sex: Male
Medical Record Number: Not Disclosed

Diagnosis:
1. Difluoroethane Abuse
2. Chronic Kidney Disease
3. Lactic Acidosis
4. Pruritus

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital after a violent outburst following prolonged Difluoroethane abuse during a suicide attempt. The patient had a known history of depression, and on admission, he was confused and verbally abusive. However, within six hours, he became oriented, cooperative, and able to provide a reliable history. The frequency of DFE abuse had increased over the last month, and during this episode, he experienced frightening visual and auditory hallucinations as well as anxiety that persisted even after returning to his self-reported baseline mental status. The patient denied any substance abuse except for DFE. The patient had no known medical problems except for depression, and he reported smoking one-half pack of cigarettes per day for the previous two years.

During his hospital stay, the patient had contusions on his left shoulder and upper extremities due to a physical altercation with police. On admission, the patient had an elevated creatinine level, BUN, GFR, and Lactic acidosis. Initial labs revealed a WBC count with polymorphonuclear predominance, creatine kinase, and a carboxyhemoglobin level. The urinalysis was significant for proteinuria, blood, RBCs, WBCs, and hyaline casts. However, the urine drug screen was negative.

The patient received single renally adjusted doses of Vancomycin and Piperacillin-Tazobactam, intravenous 0.9% saline, and oxygen by nasal cannula while in the emergency department prior to admission. Over the next 24 hours, he received intravenous fluids and oxygen, which normalized his lactic acid levels, creatine kinase, and leukocyte count. His creatinine down-trended to 1.3mg/dL. However, after 36 hours, his serum creatinine inexplicably rose again to 2.3mg/dL, and his carboxyhemoglobin level also increased. A renal ultrasound showed increased echogenicity of both kidneys consistent with medical renal disease, without change in size, atrophy, or cystic lesions.

Ultimately, the patient was transitioned to normal saline at 75 ml/hour after developing pruritus. He continued to receive intravenous normal saline with subsequent improvement of creatinine and normalization of his urinalysis. The patient received appropriate care, and his condition improved over the next three days. He was discharged with a creatinine level of 1.6.

Recommendations:
1. The patient should refrain from Difluoroethane abuse to prevent further kidney damage.
2. The patient should seek mental health counseling to address his depression.
3. The patient should continue to follow up with his primary care physician regarding his chronic kidney disease.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient: 44-year-old female

Admission date: N/A

Discharge date: N/A

Admission diagnosis: N/A

Hospital course:

The patient presented to the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, and Periodontology for placement of dental implants. During the initial examination, it was found that the temporary crown on the right upper central incisor was unsatisfactory and was replaced with a metal core, post, and a new temporary crown. The patient was referred for implant placement in multiple teeth regions.

Following the initial implant placement, it was discovered that the anterior implant was positioned incorrectly, making it impossible to fabricate an esthetically pleasing crown. The implant was subsequently removed using an implant retrieval tool, and a new implant was installed in a different position.

During the osseointegration phase, a temporary fixed partial prosthesis was used on teeth 11 and 14 for esthetic purposes. Prostheses were installed on all implants, and periodic acrylic resin implements were added to improve gingival conditioning and esthetics.

At the end of two months, the implant prosthesis with a mesial cantilever was installed.

This case report was approved by the institution's Ethics Committee on Human Research and followed the ethical principles of the Declaration of Helsinki.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: not provided
Age: 26
Gender: Male
Admission date: not provided
Discharge date: not provided
Clinical diagnosis: Generalized fluorosis

Hospital course:
The patient presented to the restorative dental clinics at King Saud University, Saudi Arabia, with a chief complaint of an unpleasant smile caused by generalized tooth discoloration. Clinical examination revealed generalized fluorosis with loss of the outermost enamel in irregular areas involving less than half of the entire surface, as well as changes in the morphology caused by merging pits and marked attrition. The patient underwent smile enhancement using ceramic veneers on his upper teeth, from his upper right 2nd premolar to upper left 2nd premolar. The entire treatment course was explained to the patient, and he agreed to the recommended treatment plan. Diagnostic models of the patient's teeth were taken, and the patient was provided with treatment options. The patient chose ceramic veneers for his upper teeth due to his desire for an optimum aesthetic and a long-term result. Following tooth preparation, gingival retraction was achieved, impressions were taken, and temporization was performed. Ceramic veneers were fabricated using a lithium disilicate-reinforced glass ceramic material. The veneers were then bonded to the prepared teeth, and final surface polishing resulted in an aesthetically pleasing final result. The patient was satisfied with the outcome of the procedure.

Summary:
The patient was a 26-year-old Yemeni male with a chief complaint of an unpleasant smile caused by generalized tooth discoloration. The patient was diagnosed with generalized fluorosis, for which ceramic veneers were recommended for smile enhancement of his upper teeth. The patient underwent tooth preparation, gingival retraction, impressions, temporization, and bonding of ceramic veneers to the prepared teeth. Final surface polishing was performed, resulting in an aesthetically pleasing final result. The patient was satisfied with the outcome of the procedure.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: Male, 75 years old

Admission date: [Insert date]

Discharge date: [Insert date]

Hospital course: 

The patient was admitted to the hospital due to nocturia. An elevated PSA level was observed, and digital rectal examination showed a diffuse induration of the prostate. Pelvic MRI demonstrated extensive high signal of the prostate in diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI). Fluorodeoxyglucose-positron emission tomography/CT revealed multiple spine and pelvic bone and para-aortic and pelvic lymph node metastases. The patient was diagnosed with metastatic prostate cancer and treated with primary androgen deprivation therapy. 

During the course of treatment, the patient was diagnosed with castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC) and referred to our hospital. CT, bone scan, and WB-MRI revealed discrepancies. CT and bone scan showed multiple osteoblastic lesions in the spine and pelvic bone, while the WB-MRI showed almost no high signal in DWI of osteoblastic lesions. Histopathological examinations of both the prostate and the vertebra demonstrated no malignant cells in the vertebra. 

The patient was treated with enzalutamide for potentially existing micrometastases and added prostate radiotherapy. After this, his elevated PSA levels were immediately controlled. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Final Diagnosis: Metastatic prostate cancer (cT3aN1M1b), CRPC

Summary: 

The 75-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital due to nocturia. The patient was diagnosed with metastatic prostate cancer during treatment with primary androgen deprivation therapy. After a diagnosis of castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC), the patient was treated with enzalutamide for potentially existing micrometastases and added prostate radiotherapy. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary

Hospital Course:
This 64-year-old man presented with a 6-month history of worsening dyspnea, intermittent fevers, chills, cough, and wheezing. He had a significant smoking history, as well as a history of ablation for atrial fibrillation and surgery and radiation for prostate cancer. The patient was initially treated for presumed community-acquired pneumonia with no response. He was ultimately hospitalized, and a CT scan of the chest showed a LLL consolidation with evidence of narrowing of the LLL bronchus. A bronchoscopy showed a "rounded, nonulcerating, pink mass-like growth." He was referred to our center for further evaluation.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
The patient subsequently underwent another bronchoscopy, which revealed a narrow LLL bronchus with a fleshy endobronchial mass lesion. Multiple biopsies revealed an aspirated almond. The foreign body was removed using a Zero Tip Airway Retrieval Basket and biopsy forceps. A bronchoalveolar lavage was performed, and specimens were sent for culture. The patient was given a 10-day course of amoxicillin-clavulanate due to evidence of aspiration pneumonia. On follow-up examination, he reported drastically increased exercise tolerance, and his cough and wheezing had disappeared. Repeat pulmonary function tests showed an increase in FEV1, and a follow-up CT scan revealed complete resolution of parenchymal infiltrates.

Follow-up:
The patient successfully quit smoking and his exercise tolerance had returned to baseline at the 6-month follow-up.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in good condition with instructions to continue follow-up with his primary care physician.

Signed,
[Physician Name]
[Date]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information: 
Name: [Patient Name]
Gender: Female
Age: 11 years old
Date of admission: [Admission Date]
Date of discharge: [Discharge Date]
Final Diagnosis: Pulp necrosis secondary to fractured dens evaginatus and symptomatic apical periodontitis.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted to the National University of Malaysia (UKM) Paediatric Dental Clinic with a referral for further management of pulp necrosis of an immature lower right second premolar (tooth 45), secondary to the fractured tubercle of dens evaginatus. The tooth had undergone root canal therapy by a general dental practitioner (GDP) due to spontaneous and lingering pain following cold and thermal stimuli. During the initial assessment, the pulp chamber was reentered and irrigated with saline, followed by the placement of a nonsetting calcium hydroxide material and a double sealing of the access cavity with Cavit™ 3M and glass ionomer cement (GIC) Riva Self Cure™ SDI.

Two weeks later, the tooth was reassessed and irrigated with a copious volume of 1.5% sodium hypochlorite (NaOCI) to remove the nonsetting calcium hydroxide, followed by irrigation with sterile water. The canal was then irrigated with 17% EDTA for a minute and dried with paper points, before being filled using the EndoSequence (BC RRM-Fast Set Putty, Brasseler, USA) material under the guidance of a dental operating microscope Carl Zeiss Surgical GmbH, S100). The orifice of the root canal was double sealed with a cotton pellet, temporary filling material (Cavit 3M, USA), and GIC (Riva Self Cure SDI, Australia).

Two weeks later, the root canal was reaccessed again, irrigated with 1.5% NaOCl, and dried with paper points. The canal was then obturated with thermoplasticised gutta-perca using the Obtura III Max System (Obtura Spartan® Endodontics). The access cavity was then double sealed with GIC (Riva Self Cure SDI, Australia) and nanohybrid composite (AURA™ SDI, Australia). 

The patient was regularly monitored during the three-month and six-month follow-ups, showing no signs of residual symptoms. At the six-month review, a periapical radiograph showed that the apical root of tooth 45 had grown beyond the apexification level, with a normal periodontal ligament space and lamina dura.

Recommendations: 
Regular annual monitoring of tooth 45 is essential to ensure that the coronal seal is intact, and no apical complication further arises. 

Discharge Medications: None. 

Recommended Follow-up: Annual monitoring. 

Signed, 
[Physician's Name] MD.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [Patient Name]
Gender: Female
Age: 50
Race: African American

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with tenderness and keloids in her right breast that became infected. She had a history of bilateral breast reduction, iron deficiency anemia, and obesity. During the hospital stay, the patient was treated with antibiotics for the suspected infected keloidal scar of the right breast but with minimal improvement. An ultrasound was performed that suggested marked edema and skin thickening suggestive of infection. The patient underwent a right breast partial mastectomy for cosmesis and resection of the infected keloidal area, revealing a high-grade primary angiosarcoma of the breast with negative margins.

DIAGNOSIS:

High-grade primary angiosarcoma of the breast with negative margins.

TREATMENT:

The patient underwent a computed tomography of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis, which did not show any evidence of gross metastatic disease. The patient then underwent completion mastectomy and scheduled for adjuvant chemotherapy with combination gemcitabine and Taxotere, followed by radiation.

FOLLOW-UP:

The patient will require ongoing follow-up for surveillance and monitoring of any recurrence of angiosarcoma.

Hospital Course:
- 41-year-old male patient F.C.F. admitted with symptoms of fever, myalgia, anorexia, vomiting, jaundice, and colure.
- Diagnosed with hepatitis due to clinical signs, laboratory tests, and excessive intake of paracetamol.
- Hospitalized, received intravenous hydration, and discharged after 4 days.
- Readmitted after 15 days with worsening symptoms, including daily high fever, appetite loss, sweating, weight loss, and progressive worsening.
- Received multiple medical tests and was diagnosed with infective endocarditis (IE) confirmed via Transesophageal echocardiography showing prolapsed mitral valve and endocardial vegetation.
- Received intravenous antibiotic therapy with vancomycin, gentamicin, ampicillin, and ceftriaxone for 36 days.
- Signs and symptoms of IE resolved, laboratory tests showed improvement, and blood cultures were sterile.
- Follow-up visits were made, underwent a second TEE, and it showed chordal rupture and moderate mitral regurgitation.
- Patient underwent surgical correction with implantation of a mitral valve prosthesis, and the surgery ended without any complications.
- The patient was prescribed an oral anticoagulant warfarin and in good physical condition.
- Follow-up visits with a cardiologist at the same hospital continued, showing the patient was asymptomatic 18 months after the endocarditis episode.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 50 years

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission: Dyspnea on exertion, orthopnea, and chest tightness.

Hospital Course:
- Patient presented with intermittent flu-like symptoms, dyspnea on exertion, orthopnea and chest tightness.
- Prior EKG showed no abnormalities but upon presentation, EKG showed right axis deviation and abnormal ST-T wave segments in V1 through V3.
- A CT angiogram of the chest revealed moderate bilateral pleural effusions, a mass in the right ventricle, and a mass in the left atrium extending through the mitral valve invading into the left ventricle.
- Echocardiogram exhibited normal LVEF but some mitral valve occlusion due to the mass.
- Cardiac MRI confirmed the masses.
- The patient required debulking of the left atrial tumor, and pathology revealed an undifferentiated high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma.
- The patient was started on pembrolizumab chemotherapy with concurrent radiation therapy to the heart and small bowel due to tumor infiltration into the left pulmonary veins, as well as focal areas of uptake in the small bowel at a site of intussusception.

Discharge Instructions:
- The patient is advised to follow up with their cardiologist for further guidance and monitoring of their condition.
- The patient should continue to take their current medication as directed by their treating physician.
- The patient should seek medical attention immediately if any concerning symptoms arise. 

Follow-Up: The patient is advised to follow up with their cardiologist for further guidance and monitoring of their condition.

Discharge Diagnosis: Undifferentiated high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma.

Note: This discharge summary is provided for informational purposes only and is not a substitute for medical advice, diagnosis or treatment.

Discharge Summary

Patient Summary:
Mr. ____ is a 64-year-old white male with a history of hepatitis C who underwent evaluation for elevated liver transaminases and was found to have a right adrenal mass which was resected. He was seen by the endocrine service after which an open thoracoabdominal approach was chosen due to the large size of the mass and retrocaval extension of the mass medially towards the vertebral body. After the successful surgery, the patient was discharged in good condition.

Hospital Course:
Mr. ____ was admitted for evaluation of an adrenal mass, which was discovered on CT imaging. The patient was thoroughly evaluated by the endocrine service which revealed a normal ACTH level, normal AM cortisol, and normal 24-hour urine metanephrines. Due to its size and atypical features, the right adrenal mass was resected after which the patient had an uneventful postoperative recovery. Histologic examination of the resected specimen revealed a cavernous hemangioma. During his hospital stay, the patient did not develop any complications and was discharged on postoperative day 4.

Follow-Up:
The patient was discharged to home in good condition and had an uneventful recovery. Subsequent follow-up appointments with the endocrine service and surgical team were scheduled to monitor any signs of recurrence.

Discharge Medications:
Not Applicable

Follow-Up Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow up with the endocrine and surgical teams for regular monitoring. Should any concerning symptoms arise, the patient is instructed to follow-up with his primary care provider.

Procedures:
Right adrenalectomy.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in good condition.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Cavernous hemangioma of the right adrenal gland.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 34 years
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Length of Stay: 4 days

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission: The patient presented to the emergency room with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. A through physical examination and laboratory investigations were conducted to rule out any gastrointestinal issues. The MRI revealed a large amount of intraperitoneal fluid and an intrauterine fetus. The patient was transferred to our facility after 12 hours under the joint care of Obstetrics/Gynecology and General Surgery teams.

Course of Treatment: The patient's condition deteriorated upon arrival, and her hemoglobin count fell from 11.7 g/dL to 7.9 g/dL. An emergency laparotomy was performed which resulted in a modified radical hysterectomy with right ureteral lysis and cystotomy with bladder repair. The intraoperative findings revealed placenta percreta, uterine rupture with a 2 x 1 cm defect in the right lower uterine segment and significant intra-abdominal blood. The patient was transferred to the ICU after surgery and eventually discharged four days later. Two more units of PRBC were administered during the postoperative period.

Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with placenta percreta and uterine rupture with a 2 x 1 cm defect in the right lower uterine segment.

Discharge: The patient was discharged on postoperative day 4 after having met her postoperative milestones. A Foley urinary catheter was placed due to cystotomy, and a cystogram was scheduled before removal. The patient was referred for grief counseling.

Follow-up: Follow-up measures with the Ob/Gyn and/or General Surgery services was recommended and scheduled by the patient's family.

Patient Overview:

This is a 26-year-old prelingually Deaf male with a prior history of Tourette's syndrome, bipolar disorder, and HIV. The patient was placed under Baker Act at a local hospital for “acting erratic and psychotic.” Upon initial evaluation, the preliminary diagnosis was “psychosis.”

Hospital Course:

Upon admission, an ASL-interpreter was called to assist. The patient became angry after discovering the truth of his hospitalization. Later, the patient reported having anxiety and physical pain attributed to his Tourette's Disorder. He had been taking carisoprodol and diazepam to help relieve his symptoms, but they were recently stopped. The family was called and stated there was questionable abuse of medications but they were adamant that he was safe for himself and others. 

Further interview excluded OCD as a diagnosis but substance use disorder remained high on the differential for his current and past behavior. The patient admitted to buying oxycodone off the street since his neurologist stopped prescribing medications due to questionable abuse. A clinical opiate withdrawal scale was performed and was only positive for minor anxiety elevation. A full medical workup was performed and excluded any medical causes to his admission.

The patient was kept for observation and discharged the next morning following positive report from staff. He was given extensive education on substance use as well as coping strategies to prevent readmissions. Upon discharge “unspecified psychosis” was given as his diagnosis.

Summary:

A 26-year-old prelingually Deaf male with a history of Tourette's syndrome, bipolar disorder, and HIV was admitted under Baker Act for “acting erratic and psychotic.” Substance use disorder was suspected to be the underlying cause of his behavior. The patient was observed and discharged the next morning with extensive education on substance abuse prevention and coping strategies. Upon discharge, “unspecified psychosis” was given as his diagnosis.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: Not Provided
Medical Record Number: Not Provided
Admission Date: Not Provided
Discharge Date: Not Provided
Total Length of Stay: Not Provided

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient, a 30-year-old Deaf, Hispanic male, was admitted to the hospital after his mother reported that he was behaving oddly and not taking his medication as prescribed. Upon initial psychiatric interview, an interpreter was not present, and the patient was communicating via written responses. He maintained bizarre delusions, but denied current suicidal ideation (SI), homicidal ideation (HI), or auditory verbal hallucinations (AVH).

The patient, who had been diagnosed with schizophrenia as a teenager, had been taking risperidone for several years but was tired of continuing the medication due to side effects of drowsiness and weight gain. He reported that he was in an American Sign Language (ASL) school and learning a career in massage therapy. After meeting a girlfriend, he began to develop a sense of independence that he reported his mother disapproved of. This caused an altercation that precipitated his admission.

With the assistance of an ASL interpreter, the patient was answering questions logically with a linear thought process. He reported that he was feeling fine and not crazy, and that all of these events were happening because his mother does not understand Deaf culture. He also conveyed that he did not like to take his meds because they interfered with him being able to drink alcohol and caused drowsiness.

After a family session was completed, the patient was discharged home with plans to follow up with his community psychiatrist. The patients' diagnosis was changed to delusional disorder upon his discharge.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Delusional disorder

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to keep his follow-up appointment with his community psychiatrist and to continue his prescribed treatment as directed. He is encouraged to communicate effectively with his mother and to discuss any concerns with his treatment.

Hospital Course: 

The 36-year-old male cyclist presented to the emergency department with complaints of lightheadedness and diaphoresis after experiencing a bicycle fall. He denied experiencing any chest pains or shortness of breath, but reported experiencing mid back pain. 

In the emergency department, the patient was noted to be well appearing with marked right thigh swelling and tenderness to his medial thigh. An ECG showed lateral ST segment elevation and a subsequent troponin I test was positive. The patient was subsequently admitted for further evaluation. 

An echocardiogram performed during hospitalization showed normal right and left ventricular function with trace pericardial effusion. A concern for cardiac contusion was initially considered, but coronary angiography revealed that the patient had a spontaneous coronary artery dissection of the left anterior descending coronary artery. 

The patient's CPK and troponin levels trended down with medical management and his back pain resolved, so a stent was not placed. He was loaded with Aspirin and Clopidogrel, as well as a heparin infusion, Lisinopril, and a Beta Blocker for conservative management.  

The patient was advised not to participate in competitive cycling again, and was discharged with instructions to continue the Aspirin and Clopidogrel until a repeat angiography could be performed in 6 weeks. Follow-up with a cardiologist in the patient's home state was also recommended. 

Follow-Up Recommendations: 

Repeat coronary angiography in 6 weeks with consideration of stent placement if the dissection has extended or if the patient becomes symptomatic. Follow-up with a cardiologist in the patient's home state is strongly advised.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [INSERT NAME]
Age: 30 years
Sex: Male
Hospital: [INSERT HOSPITAL NAME]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the cardiology ward for evaluation and management of complete heart block. He was found to have high blood pressure (BP) and was referred to the emergency room (ER) for BP control. In the ER, he was also found to have left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) with strain pattern, absent arterial pulses except the left radial pulse which was weak and 3rd-degree heart block (TDHB). The patient was started on antihypertensive medication for BP control. Further physical exam revealed that BP was significantly different between both upper limbs and between upper and lower limbs and initial blood work showed mild renal impairment.

Diagnostic Evaluation:
Computerized tomography (CT) thoracic aortogram was done to rule out coarctation of the aorta, which was normal; CT coronary angiogram showed no evidence of coronary artery disease (CAD). Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the heart was normal as well. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showed moderate hypokinesia of the left ventricle (LV), ejection fraction (EF) 35–40%, grade 2/4 diastolic dysfunction, and moderate concentric LVH. Holter monitoring did not reveal any pauses. Ultrasound/Doppler of the kidneys showed increased parenchymal echogenicity with poorly defined corticomedullary junction impressive of renal parenchymal disease. CT abdominal aortogram showed large thrombus seen in the abdominal aorta starting at the level of renal arteries completely occluding the aorta and common iliac arteries with no blood flow seen beyond the renal artery level up to the aortic bifurcation; moderate to severe stenosis is noted at the origin of both renal arteries because of thrombus. Multiple abdominal collaterals are seen with multiple collaterals in the anterior and lateral abdominal wall and paraspinal collaterals. Extensive blood work-up including thyroid function test and autoimmune and thrombophilia work-up was all unremarkable.

Treatment:
The patient underwent percutaneous stenting of bilateral renal arteries which was followed by an improvement in the BP and renal function and reduction in doses of antihypertensive medications. The patient also underwent permanent pacemaker insertion for TDHB. The patient was placed on warfarin and was advised to see the vascular surgeon after 3 months.

Discharge Status:
The patient left against medical advice.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 71
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with symptoms of gait difficulties and vertigo. Imaging studies revealed a nodular tumor in the left cerebellar hemisphere and upper vermis. Subsequently, microsurgical resection of the tumor was performed. Histopathological work-up revealed a paucinodular desmoplastic medulloblastoma (WHO grade IV) with some tumor cells expressing the neuronal differentiation marker synaptophysin.

Clinical Findings:

The patient's condition was stable for a week post-surgery. However, he developed a severe pneumonia and subsequently passed away due to respiratory insufficiency.

Final Diagnosis:

Paucinodular desmoplastic medulloblastoma (WHO grade IV) with no detectable MYC or MYCN amplification.

Recommendations:

None.

Follow-up:

Not applicable.

Signature:

[redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 72-year-old male, presented at the hospital with a change of personality and weight loss. Cranial MRI revealed a large low contrast-enhancing mass in the right cerebellar hemisphere. The tumor caused occlusive hydrocephalus but no surrounding edema. The suspected diagnoses were metastasis without presence of any neoplasm in the patient history or medulloblastoma (MB). The possibility of a high-grade glioma was discussed but neglected due to its rare occurrence in the cerebellum of this age group. Prior to surgery, an external ventricular drainage was inserted, and complete tumor resection was performed. Histopathological examination showed a highly cellular cerebellar tumor, which was diagnosed as a classical MB (WHO grade IV) with no nodular or desmoplastic component. The postoperative course was uneventful, and the ventricular drainage was removed without evidence of an enlarged ventricular system. The patient was found dead seven days later in his room, and the cause of unexpected death could not be clarified, since an autopsy was not allowed.

Discharge Summary:
This being said, the patient was not discharged as they were found deceased seven days after MB tumor resection surgery. This conclusion was made after the completion of the hospital course which included diagnostic imaging, surgical intervention and postoperative management.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Gender: Female

Age: 86

Diagnosis: Bilateral Lower Extremity Edema and a Left Lateral Leg Ulceration

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with painful bilateral lower extremity edema and a left lateral leg ulceration, she was admitted to the hospital and started on cefazolin for left lower extremity cellulitis on hospital day one. Plain films and ultrasound did not reveal any evidence of osteomyelitis, fracture, DVT, or abscess to the left lower extremity. At the time of admission, the patient had 3+ pitting edema below the knee bilaterally as well as chronic venous stasis changes.
On hospital day three, the patient's CRP began to uptrend and she became febrile. At this point, her antibiotics were switched from cefazolin to vancomycin to cover MRSA. On hospital day five, the patient was noted to have a new erythematous area over the anterior left knee, inferior to the patella. Ultrasound revealed a small fluid collection superficial to the patellar tendon. The infrapatellar bursa was aspirated and sent for culture. 
An MRI was performed on hospital day seven but did not reveal any evidence of osteomyelitis. On hospital day eight, aspirate cultures returned with Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The patient was clinically improved after starting piperacillin-tazobactam, and vancomycin was discontinued on hospital day seven. She was stable for discharge on hospital day eight and was sent out with a ten-day course of levofloxacin. Close follow-up with infectious disease was also recommended. 

Hospital Stay:

The patient's hospital stay was marked by a switch in antibiotics from cefazolin to vancomycin as a reaction to the uptrending CRP levels and feverish symptoms. This was done to cover MRSA. An MRI was delayed due to the patient's pacemaker. On hospital day eight, the patient was discharged with a ten-day course of levofloxacin after the aspirate cultures returned with Pseudomonas aeruginosa. 

Follow-Up:

The patient was advised to follow up with the infectious disease department after being discharged. A ten-day course of levofloxacin was prescribed to the patient to ensure a full recovery. 

Summary:

The patient presented with bilateral lower extremity edema and a left lateral leg ulceration. The patient was admitted, had imaging done, and was treated with a switch in antibiotics after experiencing uptrending CRP levels and feverish symptoms. The patient was discharged after a course of levofloxacin and advised to follow up with infectious disease.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]

Reason for Admission:
Whole-body computed tomography scan and a bone scintigraphy scan revealed a tumor in the entire right tibia of [Name] with known breast carcinoma.

Hospital Course:
After a thorough discussion of different treatment options with the patient, a custom-made tibia EPR was selected and performed. The tumor was resected with an anteromedial approach and the defect was reconstructed with a silver-coated modular endoprosthesis of the Modular Universal Tumor and Revision System, which was enveloped in a Trevira tube to facilitate attachment of soft tissues and the patella tendon.

A microvascular latissimus dorsi musculocutaneous flap was anastomosed to the tibia artery (end-to-side) and concomitant vein and wrapped around the prosthesis to avoid dead space and allow tension-free closure. Furthermore, a medial gastrocnemius muscle flap was transposed to cover the patellar tendon region.

The knee joint was immobilized in extension for 6 weeks to facilitate patella ligament attachment to the tube, followed by gradual mobilization. The patient achieved a nearly normal gait with mild limping after 6 months. Local MRI and chest radiographs during the 8 years of follow-up showed no signs of local recurrence or distant metastasis. The patient was able to return to work full-time as a kindergarten teacher and maintain a previous active lifestyle (except downhill skiing).

Discharge Diagnosis:
Adamantinoma histology with a tumor in the entire right tibia.

Discharge Medications:
None.

Discharge Condition:
Stable and able to ambulate with mild limping. 

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to continue following up with their treating physician and regular radiological investigations. The patient is advised to monitor any changes in symptoms, such as pain or swelling, and to inform their treating physicians of any concerns.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Name], [Age]-year-old male
Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Chief Complaint:
Sudden onset generalised weakness affecting predominantly lower limbs after eating dinner, multiple similar episodes over the past month, associated with 15-kilogram weight loss over the past three months and a four-day history of nonbloody diarrhoea, which resolved one week prior to presentation.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient was diagnosed with hyperthyroidism associated with TPP secondary to Graves' disease and was treated with intravenous KCl and MgSO4. Further treatment included Carbimazole 20 mg twice a day and Propranolol 20 mg three times a day, with no potassium supplementation prescribed on discharge.

Outcome:
The patient's weakness had resolved during inpatient admission, and he reported no further episodes of weakness upon discharge. His T4 and T3 had normalized, and his potassium was within the normal range. Ongoing monitoring of thyroid function was recommended, with a plan for radioiodine ablation or thyroid surgery if antithyroid medical therapy was unsuccessful. No anticoagulation therapy was advised due to his low risk of thromboembolism.

Follow-up:
Further follow-up information was not attainable as the patient returned to his home overseas. However, the patient was advised to seek medical care immediately if he experienced any further episodes of weakness.

Recommendations:
Based on the patient's symptoms and medical history, his condition seems to have been caused by hyperthyroidism associated with TPP secondary to Graves' disease. The patient was advised to continue medical management of his thyroid function and remain observant of any recurrence of symptoms.
