Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Chief Complaint: Worsening dyspnea and hemoptysis

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 33-year-old male with a history of diabetes and seizure disorder, presented to the emergency department with worsening dyspnea and hemoptysis. The patient admitted to vaping for the past 2 months with increased exposure time and has experimented on new flavors. CT scan of the chest showed diffuse ground glass opacities and bilateral patchy consolidation. The patient had worsening hypoxia that required noninvasive ventilation. Bronchoscopic examination failed to demonstrate airway lesions. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) revealed increasing blood in four sequential aliquots confirming diagnosis of DAH. The patient underwent right wedge resection lung biopsy which revealed evidence of bland pulmonary hemorrhage with no evidence of capillaritis or diffuse alveolar damage (DAD). His symptoms improved with complete resolution of alveolar hemorrhage on chest CT scan. He did not use a personal vaporizer since then.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with Diffuse Alveolar Hemorrhage (DAH).

Treatment:

The patient was treated with pulse dose steroids after DAH was confirmed with BAL aliquots.

Follow-up:

The patient showed improvement in his condition after treatment and has not used a personal vaporizer since then.

Summary:

The patient, a 33-year-old male with diabetes and seizure disorder, presented to the emergency department (ED) with worsening dyspnea and hemoptysis. He was diagnosed with Diffuse Alveolar Hemorrhage (DAH) which was confirmed by BAL. The patient underwent right wedge resection lung biopsy which revealed evidence of bland pulmonary hemorrhage with no evidence of capillaritis or diffuse alveolar damage (DAD). The patient was treated with pulse dose steroids and showed improvement in his condition. He has not used a personal vaporizer since then.

Discharge Summary

Admission Date: [insert date of admission]
Discharge Date: [insert date of discharge]

Patient Information:
The patient is a 41-year-old man who was admitted with spontaneous gum bleeding, epistaxis, and lower limb ecchymosis. The patient was diagnosed with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) with PML-RARα.

Hospital Course:
The patient's laboratory data upon admission showed leukocytosis, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and an abnormal coagulation profile. The patient received treatment with ATRA and idarubicin, and later ATO infusion was initiated. However, the patient developed complete AV block with a heart rate (HR) of 40-50 bpm during ATO infusion, and treatment was immediately discontinued. The patient developed bilateral pulmonary edema and signs of cardiac tamponade, and a temporary pacemaker was inserted. After stopping ATRA for three doses, the patient's HR partially recovered, and ATRA was rechallenged. However, the patient developed sinus bradycardia with a first-degree AV block and diffuse ST elevation, and arta treatment was delayed. A temporary pacemaker was removed after the patient's condition stabilized, and ATRA was resumed with gradually increasing dosage. The patient achieved complete molecular remission and received three cycles of consolidation with ATRA-based chemotherapy before being discharged.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) with PML-RARα.

Treatment:
ATRA and idarubicin were administered initially, and later ATO infusion was initiated before being discontinued due to complications. The patient received a temporary pacemaker and steroid treatment was switched to dexamethasone. After discontinuing ATRA, the patient's pacemaker was removed, and ATRA was resumed with gradually increasing dosage.

Discharge Condition:
The patient achieved complete molecular remission and received three cycles of consolidation with ATRA-based chemotherapy. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Plan:
The patient will be followed up regularly to monitor for any potential complications or recurrence of disease.

Discharge summary

Patient Name: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]
DOB: [redacted]
Admission date: [redacted]
Discharge date: [redacted]
Admitting diagnosis: Heat stroke
Principal diagnosis on admission: Heat stroke complicated by seizures and posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome

Hospital course:
The patient presented with sudden collapse after running in a marathon competition under hot sun in high ambient temperature. The patient was transferred to ICU in a confused state with a rectal temperature of 42.2°C. The patient was treated with intravenous fluids and rapidly cooled with ice pillow and ice water-soaked towel. Fluid resuscitation was commenced, however, he remained oliguric and hemodialysis was initiated. On day 4, the patient developed severe headache, which progressed to six episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, each lasting for 1-2 minutes, in a one-hour time. The episodes were associated with drooling of saliva, tongue biting, and postictal drowsiness. The patient was intubated and started on intravenous midazolam infusion, intravenous phenytoin, and intravenous levetiracetam. He was diagnosed with posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES). The patient's condition improved, and he was transferred to the general ward on the seventh day of admission. The patient's seizure was well-controlled with oral medication and repeat MRI showed near complete resolution of the previous vasogenic oedema.

Condition on discharge:
The patient was discharged home with oral medications. Oral valproic acid and levetiracetam were prescribed to control seizures. Instructions were given to avoid exposure to high ambient temperature and to remain well-hydrated. The patient was advised to have regular follow-up with a primary care physician and neurologist.

Summary of hospital course:
A 20-year-old man presented with heat stroke after running in a marathon competition in high ambient temperature. He was treated with intravenous fluids and rapidly cooled with ice pillow and ice water-soaked towel. He required hemodialysis following persistent oliguria. On day 4 of admission, the patient developed seizures and was diagnosed with posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES). The patient's condition improved, and he was discharged on oral medications to control seizures.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to have regular follow-up with a primary care physician and neurologist. The patient was instructed to avoid exposure to high ambient temperature and to remain well-hydrated. The patient received no further treatment at our hospital.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient, a 63-year-old woman, was transferred to our department from the internal medicine clinic of the hospital with a diagnosis of acute abdomen due to possible rupture of the bladder. She had a known medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes and cirrhosis of the liver with extensive ascites. On admission to the internal medicine clinic, she was diagnosed with acute abdominal pain, urinary retention, and high white blood cell count and CRP levels. The patient was immediately started on empiric antibiotic treatment with good recovery until the third day when her condition worsened.
On the third day, the patient presented with rebound tenderness, involuntary guarding, and a completely rigid “washboard” abdomen with percussion tenderness. She was haemodynamically unstable. Blood pressure was low and heart rate was high. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen indicated the presence of gas within the bladder wall and extravasation of contrast solution in the peritoneal cavity. Emergency surgery was decided and a partial cystectomy with debridement of the necrotic tissue, preservation of both ureters, and peritoneal lavage were performed. A suprapubic catheter and two surgical drains were used.
The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit in a critical condition and unfortunately, succumbed 12 hours later due to multiple organ dysfunction and septic shock. Histology revealed extensive necrosis of the entire bladder wall.

DIAGNOSES:

1. Acute abdomen due to possible rupture of the bladder
2. Urinary retention
3. High levels of white blood cell count and CRP
4. Extensive necrosis of the entire bladder wall

DISPOSITION:

The patient unfortunately passed away in the intensive care unit due to complications of her condition.

FOLLOW-UP:

N/A

FOLLOW-UP DIAGNOSTIC TESTS:

N/A

MEDICATIONS:

N/A

ALLERGIES:

N/A

CONDITION ON DISCHARGE:

Deceased

Discharge Summary

Patient: 46-year-old Japanese woman with a known history of SLE

Admission Date: [insert]

Admission Diagnosis: DAH-induced hypoxemia accompanying SLE

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was initially admitted with sudden weight loss and respiratory distress. After admission, the patient was immediately given 50 mg of oral prednisolone. Approximately three weeks after the start of treatment, the dosage was reduced to 45 mg/day, but the patient suddenly developed hemoptysis and respiratory distress. The chest X-ray showed infiltrative shadows in both lung fields, with greater density in the right lung. The CT scan showed pulmonary infiltrates along the peripheral bronchovascular bundles and ground-glass opacities. The patient was diagnosed with DAH-induced hypoxemia accompanying SLE and high-dose corticosteroid therapy (methylprednisolone 500 mg/day) was initiated. However, respiratory distress worsened, and immunosuppressive therapy (cyclophosphamide 750 mg/day) was also started three days after the start of high-dose corticosteroid therapy. The patient was transferred to the ICU and placed on mechanical ventilation.

Although the patient produced copious quantities of bloody secretions after intubation, the secretions were reduced when APRV was set to the highest airway pressure (35 cmH2O). We administered oxygen through an oxygen mask (flow rate: 6 L/min) while in the ICU.

Under these conditions, the patient's respiratory function substantially improved, with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 0.60 and a PaO2 of 117.6 mmHg. During approximately three consecutive weeks of APRV and steroid therapy, the patient demonstrated gradual improvements in respiratory function, and a CT scan after extubation showed that the pulmonary infiltrates and ground-glass opacities had disappeared. Mechanical ventilation was discontinued 25 days after admission to the ICU. The patient was moved to the general ward and continued on oral steroid therapy (methylprednisolone 16 mg/day).

The patient's respiratory and hemodynamic parameters showed gradual improvement over the course of hospitalization. The patient was successfully discharged 102 days after admission to the ICU.

Instructions on Discharge:

The patient is advised to continue taking oral steroid therapy (methylprednisolone 16 mg/day for the next [insert time period]) and to schedule follow-up appointments with the attending physician. The patient should also adhere to a healthy lifestyle regimen and avoid exposure to environmental triggers that may exacerbate her respiratory condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name:
Gender: Male
Age: 38
Date of Admission: [Date of admission]
Date of Discharge: [Date of discharge]
Admitting Diagnosis: Painless scrotal mass

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to [Hospital Name] with a chief complaint of a painless left scrotal mass. The patient had no significant past medical history and reported discovering the mass one month prior to admission. Physical examination revealed a 2 cm well-defined mass in the upper pole of the left testis with a firm consistency. Palpation of the right testis and lower pole of the left testis were normal. Routine blood tests were unremarkable. A bioassay of testicular tumor markers was ordered which revealed normal levels of Alpha-fetoprotein, human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). An extratesticular mass was observed on scrotal ultrasound, attached to the upper pole of the patient's testis. The mass was isoechoic to the testis parenchyma and poorly vascularized on Doppler. The patient underwent a radical inguinal orchiectomy. Histological examination of the operative specimen confirmed the presence of regular splenic tissue in the suspect mass without any signs of malignancy. The splenic proliferation had a preserved capsule, demarcating from the testis. Testicular pulp, the albuginea, and the tunica vaginalis had a preserved microscopic architecture. The patient was discharged on the second postoperative day.

Discharge Diagnosis: Painless scrotal mass

Summary:
A 38-year-old North African man presented with a painless left scrotal mass. A scrotal ultrasound showed an extratesticular mass, attached to the upper pole of his testis. The patient underwent a radical inguinal orchiectomy which confirmed the presence of splenic tissue in the suspect mass without any signs of malignancy. The patient was discharged on the second postoperative day and was examined again after 3 weeks and 2 months in our out-patient unit, where his spleen was found to be of habitual location with standard measurements and a regular aspect.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 62 years
Sex: Female
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the surgical oncology unit for a planned transanal excision of a large polyp of the mid rectum. The procedure was performed under general anesthesia without any intraoperative complications. Postoperatively, the patient received prophylaxis for venous thrombosis with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). On day 3, the patient developed a spike in temperature without any suspicious clinical evidences. The laboratory data showed deranged coagulation profile with marked prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), raised white blood cells count (WBC), and procalcitonin level. A computed tomography (CT) of abdomen and pelvis was performed which did not show any pelvic abscess, but there was evidence of perirectal fat suffusion related to the recent procedure. A rigid proctoscopy was performed showing the evidence of the partial dehiscence of rectal wall defect suture; no other abnormalities were noticed. Antibiotic therapy was started with intravenous ciprofloxacin and metronidazole three times a day. For prophylaxis of venous thrombosis, LMWH was resumed. In the next 7 days, the patient had no more fever and laboratory data improved while APTT was still prolonged. The patient was discharged home with no further intervention. The histopathological report demonstrated a tubular adenoma with low- and high-grade dysplasia with free excision margins. 45 days later endoscopy showed a complete mucosal healing.

Diagnoses:

1. Lateral spreading tumour granular type (LTS-G) - mid rectum.
2. Tubular adenoma with high-grade dysplasia.

Summary:

The patient was admitted for a planned transanal excision of a large polyp of the mid rectum which was diagnosed as LTS-G with biopsy showing a tubular adenoma with high-grade dysplasia. The surgical excision was performed as planned, and postoperative prophylaxis for venous thrombosis was started. On day 3, the patient developed a fever, and the laboratory data showed deranged coagulation profile, raised WBC count, and procalcitonin level. A CT scan and rigid proctoscopy were performed which showed perirectal fat suffusion related to the recent procedure and the partial dehiscence of rectal wall defect suture. The patient was treated with antibiotics and LMWH was resumed for prophylaxis of venous thrombosis. The patient improved in the next 7 days and was discharged home with no further intervention. Histopathological examination showed tubular adenoma with low- and high-grade dysplasia, and endoscopy 45 days later showed complete mucosal healing.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 20-year-old male with acute liver failure of unknown origin

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our hospital with symptoms of indolent jaundice and fatigue-syndrome. On physical examination, he showed signs of jaundice and hepatic encephalopathy grade I. Laboratory studies revealed elevated transaminases and impaired liver synthesis parameters. The patient was diagnosed with cryptgenic acute liver failure (ALF) and treated with supportively.

The patient's clinical condition worsened, and he fulfilled the Kings College Criteria for non-acetaminophen-induced ALF. Urgent liver transplantation was considered, and the patient's MELD score increased to 40 points. However, a suitable donor organ was not available. The patient developed hepatic encephalopathy grade III-IV, accompanied by increasing inflammatory parameters, respiratory insufficiency, and bilateral pneumonia. Antibiotic and antifungal therapy was initiated, and Staphylococcus aureus bloodstream infection was identified concurrently. Due to pulmonary Staphylococcus aureus sepsis, the patient was no longer suitable for urgent liver transplantation.

Despite the worsening clinical condition, the patient's enzymatic liver function showed improvement under mechanical ventilation, indicating liver regeneration. The patient's condition slowly improved as inflammatory parameters declined, urine excretion resumed, and extubation was possible after six days of mechanical ventilation. Laboratory tests also showed improvement in liver synthesis parameters. The patient was moved out of the intensive care unit after 21 days and discharged after 38 days.

Diagnosis:

Cryptogenic acute liver failure

Treatment:

The patient was treated with supportive therapy and substitution of vitamin K, ursodeoxycholic acid, and lactulose.

Outcome:

The patient showed complete clinical recovery during outpatient follow-up after three months.

Summary:

A 20-year-old male patient was admitted to our hospital with acute liver failure of unknown origin. Despite worsening clinical condition and a high MELD score, a suitable donor organ for liver transplantation was not available. The patient's enzymatic liver function improved under mechanical ventilation, indicating liver regeneration. The patient's condition slowly improved, and he was discharged after 38 days of treatment. The patient showed complete clinical recovery during outpatient follow-up after three months.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted] 
Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Hospital Course: The patient is a 5-year old boy who presented to the hospital for evaluation of shortness of breath and fatigue during physical activity. He was diagnosed with haemodynamically significant ASDs and a slightly dilated right ventricle. He underwent corrective surgery, which was successful.

Medical History: For the first few months after birth, the patient had gastroesophageal reflux. The mother had two previous spontaneous abortions, and there was no other significant family history. The patient showed mild hypertonus and related mild motor delay, and he sat independently at 9 months of age and began walking at 20 months of age.

Physical Exam: At the age of 4, the patient weighed 16.1 kg (46th percentile) and had a height of 99.2 cm (17th percentile). The head circumference showed macrocephaly (53.8 cm; >97th percentile), but the patient's other physical exam findings were unremarkable.

Diagnostic Testing: The patient underwent a microarray analysis that revealed a de novo microduplication of 2.06 Mb in the chromosome 2p16.1p15 region, but no other pathogenic genomic imbalance was detected in the proband’s sample. Additionally, tests of acylcarnitine profiles and amino acids in blood as well as organic acid in urine were normal.

Management: The patient underwent corrective surgery for the haemodynamically significant ASDs and dilated right ventricle. The surgery was successful, and the patient's postoperative course was unremarkable.

Discharge Condition: The patient was discharged in stable condition with recommendations for routine follow-up care and monitoring.

Follow-up: The patient will require ongoing follow-up care to monitor his cardiac health, growth, and development. The family will be advised to continue monitoring for any signs of gastroesophageal reflux and to seek medical attention if any concerns arise. The patient may benefit from early intervention services to address any mild motor delay and hypertonus. The family will also be educated on the importance of genetic counseling and future reproductive planning.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 43
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for a non-painful, mobile mass of the right inguinal fold that had been evolving over a period of 7 months. The patient's medical history included childhood asthma, chronic tonsillitis, seven pregnancies, four children, caesarean section, and abortions. Pelvic ultrasound showed a suspicious non-circumscribed mass measuring 5 cm in its longer axis. CT scan confirmed the presence of this inguinal mass, measuring 5.8 × 4.9 × 3.2 cm and extending within the right femoral triangle in contact with the long adductor muscle, without enhanced contrast, and without locoregional lymph node. Histologically, the patient was diagnosed with a granular cell tumor (Abrikossoff's tumor) without any malignant signs. Tumorectomy of this inguinal mass was performed three weeks later.

At the gross pathology examination, the tumoral tissue was homogeneous with a greyish stain. The margin was not well defined, and the hypodermic, dermic were involved. One lymph node was discovered and was invaded. Due to microscopic resection and the nodal status, it was decided at the oncology committee to perform a large surgical revision with an inguinal curage. Pathological evaluation did not reveal tumor tissue in the tumorectomy region but showed metastatic invasion by granular cells in four of twelve lymph nodes, without capsular rupture. Adjuvant chemotherapy was excluded because of very low mitotic activity. To reduce the risk of local recurrence, adjuvant radiotherapy on the tumor bed and right inguinal area of ​​50 Gy in conventional fractionation was delivered. After 10 months after the end of radiotherapy, the patient is in complete remission.

Follow-Up Plan:
Due to the unpredictable tumor, the follow-up strategy is a physical examination with a CT scan every 4 months for the first 2 post-operative years, then every 6 months for up 5 years and yearly thereafter, as a sarcoma. 

Diagnosis:
Granular cell tumor (Abrikossoff's tumor)

Recommendations:
The patient should continue to receive regular physical examinations and CT scans as outlined in the follow-up plan. Any concerning symptoms or changes should be immediately reported to the patient's healthcare provider. 

Discharge Condition:
Stable, with no acute concerns.

Discharging Provider:
[REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The 9-year, 7-month-old Japanese girl was admitted to our facility with complaints of severe deformity of her right femur associated with a pathological fracture. The patient's past medical history was unremarkable. At the age of 4-years, 6-months old, the patient experienced a pathological fracture of her right femur due to a bone tumor, which was treated with lesion curettage and fixation by her previous physician. The patient experienced a recurrence of the fracture at the same site within a week of removing the fixator, which was treated with conservative management and a hip spica cast. Subsequently, the patient developed two more fractures, following a fall, and underwent steel wire skeletal traction, followed by functional brace and hip spica cast applications. The patient followed up with regular outpatient monitoring, and during the follow-up period, a severe bowing of her right femur developed, which was progressive.

Clinical Management:
The patient was treated with resection of a 7-cm portion of the bone, which included the SBC, corrected the alignment and applied an Ilizarov fixator to gradually lengthen the thigh. A portion of healthy bone from the proximal femur (approximately 10 cm from the resected lesion) was cut, for use as bone extension at the site of resection. Extension of the bone was initiated at a speed of 1 mm/day, completing the process in 4 months. Fixation was maintained until the callus matured. Once callus maturation was achieved, the external fixator was gradually removed to prevent re-deformation.

Histopathologic Examination:
On histopathologic examination of the surgically resected bone, fibrillation of the medullary cavity was increased, and a small formation, identified as inorganic-like material, was scattered throughout; these findings were consistent with a fracture due to a bone cyst.

Physical Examination:
On the first examination at our facility, the femur was deformed, with a bowing of approximately 90° in the central area of the femur and an internal rotation of 60°, with incomplete fractures observable in the same area. At present, 3 years after surgery, correction of the deformity has been maintained, and the patient does not experience any limitations in daily activities or regular exercise.

Diagnosis:
Severe femur deformity in a 9-year, 7-month-old Japanese girl associated with a pathological fracture due to bone cyst and recurrent fractures in the same location.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient will follow up at regular intervals for monitoring of the healed bone and to ensure that the patient does not experience any limitations in daily activities or regular exercise.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 27-year-old woman who underwent an emergency caesarean delivery six months prior, presented for a transvaginal ultrasound at 13 weeks of gestation as part of a research study "Vaginal delivery after caesarean section". The ultrasound revealed a duplex pregnancy, with one viable intrauterine fetus and a small gestational sac with yolk sac without embryo located in the caesarean scar. Expectant management was chosen, and the patient returned for ultrasounds at 18 weeks, 22 weeks, and 30 weeks of gestation. The ectopic gestational sac was not visualized at 18 weeks and the niche in the scar appeared unchanged at all visits.  Vaginal delivery was planned after the ultrasound at 30 weeks indicated no contraindications, and saline contrast sonohysterography at 6 months postpartum showed no signs of the previous CSP.
 
Hospital Course:
A healthy male neonate weighing 2985 g was delivered vaginally at 37 weeks and 0 days after a 6.5-hour active labor with oxytocin augmentation. The patient had no complications during labor and delivery, and total blood loss was 250 ml. She was discharged home the next day postpartum.
 
Follow-up:
At a follow-up visit 6 months postpartum, saline contrast sonohysterography showed no signs of the previous CSP, and the remaining myometrium over the hysterotomy scar defect was 5.7 mm.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 60 years
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Sub-trochanteric and Femoral Neck Fracture

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our hospital for further treatment after a road traffic accident. On presentation, she was conscious, oriented and stable hemodynamically. The radiographs revealed fractures of the right ulna olecranon, left femoral neck and sub-trochanteric fracture. The patient was treated with a long Gamma3 nail and ORIF for sub-trochanteric fracture, and the femoral neck fracture was treated with closed reduction. Fluoroscopy was used to ensure proper screw placement during treatment. After 12-month follow-up, the fracture was union and had no evidence of avascular necrosis. However, at the 4-year follow-up, the patient began to complain of pain. The X-ray showed evidence of necrosis of the femoral head. One year later, she had a total hip arthroplasty for the severe pain.

Hospital Course Summary:

A 60-year-old female patient was admitted to our hospital for the treatment of fractures following a road traffic accident. She underwent a series of treatments including a long Gamma3 nail and ORIF for sub-trochanteric fracture with closed reduction performed for femoral neck fracture. After initial follow-up, the fracture was union and had no evidence of avascular necrosis. However, at the 4-year follow-up the x-rays revealed necrosis of the femoral head, causing severe pain. She had a total hip arthroplasty to relieve her symptoms. The patient was discharged in stable condition with follow-up appointments scheduled as needed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [redacted]
Age: 28 years
Sex: Male
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to our hospital with a one-year history of right ankle pain following trauma due to a car accident. The patient had previously undergone open reduction and internal fixation in his right ankle for a fracture at another hospital. His ankle pain persisted despite the intra-articular injections, arthroscopic synovectomy, and fixation implant removal performed at our hospital. The patient was diagnosed with progressive osteoarthritis caused by an osteochondral defect on the anterolateral surface of the distal tibial plafond. A surgical repair of the osteochondral defect was recommended, and three months later, the patient underwent an osteochondral graft procedure on his right ankle. The patient had an uneventful postoperative course, and a range of motion exercises were initiated immediately after cast removal at 4 weeks, with partial progressive weightbearing allowed during the next 4 weeks. The patient was able to return to standing work 10 months after surgery. The most recent magnetic resonance imaging scans at 2 years after surgery showed that the cartilage in the anterolateral joint surface was almost intact, and there was no osteonecrosis. The patient remained asymptomatic with respect to the donor sites of the right knee. On the latest physical examination, the patient complained of mild pain in his right ankle while walking, but could walk for 30 min. The postoperative AOFAS ankle score was 80. The patient was able to return to carpenter's work on a five-day week, but remained with minor ankle pain on standing up and walking for more than half an hour over the 3-year observation period.

Findings:
The radiographs showed moderate narrowing of the ankle joint and forward displacement of the talus, and the computed tomography of the right ankle showed an osteochondral defect on the anterolateral surface of the distal tibial plafond. The osteochondral defect was diagnosed as grade 2 according to the classification of the International Cartilage Repair Society.

Diagnosis:
Progressive osteoarthritis caused by an osteochondral defect on the anterolateral surface of the distal tibial plafond.

Treatment:
Surgical repair of the osteochondral defect performed via an osteochondral graft procedure. The patient underwent range of motion exercises immediately after cast removal at 4 weeks, with partial progressive weightbearing allowed during the next 4 weeks.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's mild ankle pain while walking persisted, but has been able to return to carpenter's work on a five-day week without major concerns. 

Follow-up Care:
A scheduled follow-up appointment with the physician in 6 months is recommended.

Hospital Course:
The 35-year-old male patient was admitted with a right distal tibial non-union, which had developed into varus deformity after sustaining a high-energy, multifragmentary compound fracture 4 months earlier. The patient was treated with a below-knee, weight-bearing Sarmiento cast which was later replaced by a retrograde expandable nail. The non-union was successfully treated, and the patient had uneventfully returned to work. However, 9 months later, there were signs of calcaneal resorption around the nail, which warranted its removal. The first attempt to remove the nail failed when it fractured at the junction between the valve and metal fins. Subsequent attempts using various methods like grabbers and mole wrench were unsuccessful. The nail was later removed piecemeal through a tibial window with a burr. The patient's tibia was protected in a below-knee walking cast for 6 weeks, and the patient had an uneventful recovery.

Hospital Course Summary:
35-year-old male with right distal tibial non-union developed varus deformity after sustaining a high-energy, multifragmentary compound fracture. Patient treated with a below-knee, weight-bearing Sarmiento cast then later, retrograde expandable nail which successfully treated the non-union allowing the patient to return to work. Nine months later, signs of calcaneal resorption around the nail led to its failed removal. A second attempt to remove the nail was successful only when it was removed piecemeal through a tibial window with a burr. Patient's tibia was protected with a cast for 6 weeks post-operation. Uneventful recovery reported.

Hospital Course:
This is a summary of the hospital course of a 67-year-old female who was referred for right distal tibial non-union with progressive valgus deformity after a fragility fracture.

History of Presenting Illness:
The patient initially received locked antegrade intra-medullary nailing, which was unsuccessful. An expandable retrograde nail was then inserted, followed by an Ilizarov frame two months later. Three months after that, the non-union had united and the frame was removed. The nail was left in place for an additional six months to allow further consolidation of the non-union. 

Past Medical History:
The patient has neither reported nor been diagnosed with any past medical history.

Hospital Course:
The first attempt to remove the expandable nail was unsuccessful, as the nail fractured at the junction between the valve and the fins. Subsequent attempts were made later and were successful, with the nail being successfully pushed out using an antegrade nail. The patient recovered well after the procedure.

Discharge Plan:
The patient is recommended to follow-up with a specialist for further monitoring regarding possible future complications.

Medical History:
The patient is a 73 year-old male who presented to our unit with a multifragmentary Pilon fracture. The patient was treated with primary retrograde expandable Fixion® nail and underwent regular follow-up.

Hospital Course:
At 22 weeks, the patient demonstrated good union and was able to walk without significant pain. It was recommended to remove the nail, however, the patient declined.

Two and a half years later, the patient returned with chronic heel pain due to slight prominence at the bottom end of the nail. An attempt was made to remove the nail using the standard extraction technique but resulted in the fracture of the nail at the junction of the valve and fins. The end cup and valve were successfully removed, but the remaining part of the nail could not be extracted despite attempts to remove it with grabbers. The procedure was abandoned and the patient was advised to keep the nail remnant unless symptoms arise.

FOLLOW-UP:
The patient is currently asymptomatic and will continue to be under follow-up. No further intervention is required at this time.

SUMMARY:
The patient presented to our unit with a Pilon fracture which was successfully treated with primary retrograde expandable Fixion® nail. Follow-up revealed good union, however, after two and a half years the patient requested removal of the nail due to chronic heel pain. Despite an unsuccessful attempt at nail removal, the patient remains asymptomatic and will continue to be monitored.

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

Admission: The patient, a 79-year-old male, with a history of pancreatic pseudocyst secondary to idiopathic acute pancreatitis diagnosed two years ago, was admitted with severe acute gastrointestinal bleed presenting with melena and a hemoglobin level of 5.8 g/dL. The patient was admitted to the ICU for supportive care including pantoprazole infusion, blood transfusion, and close monitoring.

Assessment: CT scan of the abdomen revealed a complex pancreatic mass representing a bleeding pancreatic pseudocyst, which had increased in size when compared with the previous CT scans. EGD/EUS showed submucosal bulging likely from extrinsic compression on the proximal gastric body and fundus with a small clean-based ulcer on the top of this bulge. EUS confirmed the presence of anechoic lesion with hyperechoic shadowing suggestive of cyst/pseudocyst with bleeding located in the tail of the pancreas. The patient continued to have melena and a decrease in hemoglobin to 6.3 g/dL for which an additional two units of PRBCs were provided.

Intervention: Interventional Radiology was requested to perform a mesenteric angiogram with hope that it may help identify and control the source of bleeding; however, angiogram did not demonstrate any active bleeding vessel. Ultimately, the bleeding stopped spontaneously. The patient had another EGD/EUS which again noted two openings over the greater curvature of the stomach suggestive of fistulous communication of the lesion with the stomach lumen. A bullet-tipped catheter was inserted into the lumen, and aspiration showed blood consistent with hemorrhagic pancreatic pseudocyst fistulizing into the stomach and causing severe upper gastrointestinal bleed.

Follow-up: Follow-up CT abdomen one year later revealed calcification in the head and uncinate process of pancreas along with scarring in the uncinate process, consistent with chronic pancreatitis. Additionally, the pseudocyst that was abutting the stomach wall had resolved.

Diagnosis: Pancreatic pseudocyst with bleeding and fistulous communication with the stomach.

Condition at Discharge: Stable.

Discharge Instructions: The patient is advised to follow up with a gastroenterologist and continue management of chronic pancreatitis. The patient is also instructed to monitor for any signs of gastrointestinal bleeding, such as melena, hematemesis, or general fatigue.

Follow-up Care: The patient has been advised to follow up with a gastroenterologist and undergo regular screening tests. The patient is also instructed to monitor for any signs and symptoms of gastrointestinal bleeding.

Discharge Medications: None.

Follow-up Appointments:

- Gastroenterology follow-up in 2 weeks.

- PCP follow-up in 4 weeks.

Discharge Summary

Patient Information:
Name: [First Name] [Last Name]
DOB: [MM/DD/YYYY]
Admission Date: [MM/DD/YYYY]
Discharge Date: [MM/DD/YYYY]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our ICU with a diagnosis of saddle PE. Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) was administered, and the patient was started on a heparin infusion for 3 days until he improved enough to be weaned to 3 L oxygen via nasal cannula. He was transferred to intermediate level of care on hospital day 2. Hematology recommended indefinite anticoagulation due to the massive PE. However, on the day of discharge, the patient had sudden onset of right leg numbness and weakness below the level of his hip. Physical examination revealed decreased sensation to light touch and right hip flexion and right knee extension and flexion, and loss of right patellar reflex. An emergent head CT was negative for infarction or hemorrhage, but an MRI revealed a left psoas hematoma. A CT of his pelvis showed a right psoas and iliacus hematoma, and hematology recommended discontinuing enoxaparin and reverting to a low intensity heparin infusion, as well as placement of an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter. An additional complicating factor was the risk of further thrombosis due to the presenting saddle PE. After speaking with his wife, our patient decided to undergo the procedure. The low intensity heparin infusion was stopped 3 hours beforehand and the IR team then performed drainage of the right retroperitoneal hematoma, placing two pigtail catheters in his right flank. In total, the hematoma was drained of 215 milliliters of blood, 10 milliliters of which were drained during the procedure itself. The patient tolerated the procedure well, and the heparin infusion was restarted 6 hours after it was completed. A repeat neurological examination demonstrated improved lower extremity strength bilaterally as well as the return of sensation to light touch. Hip flexion improved bilaterally, but deep tendon reflexes remained absent. Four days later, the pigtail catheters were removed, and our patient's recovery was complicated by anemia requiring blood transfusions. A repeat CT on hospital day 10 showed a stable right-sided hematoma, and the patient did not experience any further neurologic deficits. He was transitioned again from the heparin infusion to enoxaparin after 3 more days of monitoring. Follow-up was scheduled with neurology and hematology. On hospital day 18, he was safely discharged.

Diagnoses:
1. Saddle PE
2. Left psoas hematoma
3. Right psoas and iliacus hematoma

Procedures and Treatments:
1. Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP)
2. Supplemental oxygen
3. Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)
4. Heparin infusion
5. Inferior vena cava (IVC) filter placement
6. Hematoma drainage
7. Blood transfusions

Follow-up:
The patient was discharged with follow-up scheduled with neurology and hematology. No further recommendations were made at this time.

Instructions for the Patient:
The patient was instructed to follow-up with his primary care physician and discuss any further concerns or questions regarding his treatment plan. He was also advised to continue taking his medication as prescribed and keep his scheduled follow-up appointments.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]

Patient Name: [NAME]
Gender: Male
Date of Birth: [DOB]
Breed: Greyhound

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for head trauma following a collision with a park bench. Examination showed the presence of subcutaneous emphysema between the eyes and a superficial cut to the right dorso-orbital region. The patient was ambulatory and showed no signs of overt distress or proprioceptive deficits. Thorough radiographic and computer tomography imaging showed a comminuted depressed fracture of the frontal bone with a suspected communication with the sinonasal cavity. After three days of admission, surgical repair of the defect was carried out using a malleable highly porous Ti mesh, contoured to the patient’s skull, to secure the frontal bone. A sheet of gentamycin-impregnated collagen was overlaid on the implant to prevent infection and achieve a pneumatic seal. The patient was discharged two days after surgery with a course of oral antibiotics and analgesics.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Comminuted depressed fracture of the frontal bone.

Discharge Instructions:
1. Continue course of oral antibiotics and analgesics as prescribed.
2. Limit physical activity and rest the patient for at least a week.
3. Monitor the surgical site for swelling, hyperthermia, and infection.
4. If any concerning symptoms develop, contact a veterinarian immediately.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in six weeks and two years.

Follow-Up Plan:
The patient's follow-up will continue at regular intervals to reassess the surgical site and ensure no complications occur. At the six-week recheck, radiographs and CT scan showed a slight uplift of the mesh at its most rostral aspect from the frontal bone, which was corrected with a procedure that was uneventful. Radiographs and CT scan at six months revealed soft tissue swelling between the rostral mesh portion and the skull with no clinical concern. At two years assessment, radiographs and CT scan confirmed the adequate contouring and positioning of the Ti mesh with a bone-dense opacity between the rostral part of the mesh and the skull. No further complications were noted, and the owners did not raise any further concerns regarding the patient's ability to participate in normal lifestyle and activity.

Signed,
[NAME], DVM

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Cavalier King Charles Spaniel (10 years, female, neutered)

Hospital Dates: [Admission Date] - [Discharge Date]

Reason for Hospitalization:
The patient presented with a gradually enlarging mass on the right frontal bone. CT imaging revealed a neoplastic process, and surgery was performed for mass excision.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent craniotomy with resection margins guided by a customized template. Following tumour resection, a pre-contoured Ti mesh was firmly seated to the patient's skull, covering the defect. Prophylactic intravenous antibiotic cover was given before surgery and every 90 minutes thereafter. Post-operative analgesia was provided, and the dog was discharged six days after surgery.

Follow-up:
Two weeks post-discharge, the patient returned for suture removal. The surgical wound had healed, and physical examination was within normal limits. At the ten weeks recheck, physical examination was unremarkable, and the owner reported no restrictions on the patient's activities. The patient presented a small bone-like mass near the resection site at 7-months assessment. A CT scan identified the region of proliferation as dorsal and to the right side of the Ti mesh. Further examination of the mass was declined by the owner.

Recommendations:
A histological diagnosis of multilobular osteochondrosarcoma was made, with potential for local recurrence advised. Long-term follow-up is recommended, and the owner should continue to monitor for any changes in the patient's behaviour or physical examination.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Patient's Name]
Gender: Male
Age: 44-year-old
Medical Record Number: [MRN]
Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 44-year-old male, was admitted following investigation for chest pain and dyspnoea. Subsequent physical examination, echocardiography, and computed tomography angiography (CTA) revealed aortic root aneurysm of approximately 9 cm, severe aortic regurgitation, and severe aortic coarctation. A multidisciplinary team meeting took place and a consensus was agreed to proceed with a two-staged hybrid approach, with the first phase involving an endovascular approach to stent the coarctation, followed by a second stage to perform the surgical repair of the aortic root aneurysm. The first stage to stent the coarctation was unsuccessful, and the decision was then made to proceed to a single-stage surgical approach to treat both lesions.

Following induction of anesthesia, the patient underwent a right infraclavicular and right groin incision. The aortic root, valve, and ascending aorta were excised, and the coronary ostia were noted to be significantly displaced. Root replacement was performed with a 25 mm biological valved-conduit, and an end-to-side anastomosis was fashioned between the 20 mm extra-cardiac graft (attached to the descending thoracic aorta) and the ascending portion of the valved-conduit. Following rewarming and de-airing, the patient was successfully weaned off cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB). The patient remained in ICU for less than 48 hours and made excellent progress on the ward. At 3 months follow up the patient underwent a repeat CTA scan which showed complete patency in the extra-anatomical graft and resolution of the collateral arterial network.

Diagnoses:
- Aortic root aneurysm
- Severe aortic regurgitation
- Severe aortic coarctation

Procedures:
- Surgical repair of the aortic root aneurysm
- Root replacement
- End-to-side anastomosis

Consultations:
- Multidisciplinary team meeting

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged on 8th postoperatively neurologically intact and independent. Minimal anti-hypertensives were required.

Follow-Up Plans:
The patient will continue to follow-up with their primary care provider for further management and monitoring.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 79-year-old Japanese woman with a weight of 72 kg

Admission: The patient was admitted to the hospital with elevated creatinine levels, proteinuria, and microscopic hematuria.

Hospitalization: The patient was diagnosed with pauci-immune necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis and was initially considered to have hydralazine-induced myeloperoxidase-antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody-associated vasculitis. The serum creatinine level decreased gradually after discontinuation of hydralazine. However, the patient experienced a relapse of the condition 16 months later, which was treated with prednisone. The patient achieved remission after five months of treatment.

Investigations: The patient's serum samples were obtained at different stages to assess the involvement of neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs). The NET degradation activity was entirely low in all serum samples compared to the healthy control. The NET induction activity of IgG isolated from the serum samples was high in the initial serum samples and decreased with treatment. The results of immunofluorescent tests were consistent with the ELISA titers of myeloperoxidase-antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies.

Follow-Up: The patient has remained in remission after successful treatment. Further follow-up is recommended to monitor the patient's condition.

Discharge Diagnosis: Pauci-immune necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis, initial hydralazine-induced myeloperoxidase-antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody-associated vasculitis and subsequent relapse.

Discharge Medications: None.

Discharge Plan: The patient is advised to continue with follow-up appointments to monitor her condition. Lifestyle modifications, including a healthy diet and exercise, should be adopted. Additional treatment options, if necessary, will be discussed with the patient during follow-up appointments.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Hospital Admission Dates: [Redacted]

Admission Diagnosis: Frequent premature ventricular beats of high grade and repeated episodes of bidirectional non-sustained ventricular tachycardia without syncope, enlarged left ventricular dimension, local ventricular wall thinning

Discharge Diagnosis: Congenital heart defect with associated physical abnormalities including bilateral fifth finger camptodactyly, breast hypoplasia with inverted nipples, facial abnormalities (wide-set eyes, broad nasal tip, thin upper lip vermilion, and strabismus), and dental abnormalities. Intellectual deficit was also noted and included mild mental retardation and learning disabilities.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient, a 25-year-old woman, was hospitalized due to the diagnostic findings listed in the admission diagnosis section above. During her hospital stay, she received appropriate medical monitoring and management for her cardiac condition, including medications and procedures as deemed necessary by the medical team. Throughout her hospital course, the patient's vital signs remained stable and within normal limits, and no significant adverse events or complications were identified or reported.

In addition, the patient was referred to specialists for evaluation of her physical abnormalities. The fifth finger camptodactyly, hypoplastic breasts with inverted nipples, facial abnormalities, dental abnormalities, and intellectual deficit were noted and further evaluated. Given the patient's family history and the unique combination of physical abnormalities, a genetic disorder was suspected, though no diagnosis was confirmed during her hospital stay.

The patient was discharged in stable condition with appropriate follow-up plans in place for her ongoing medical care and management. She was advised to continue her medications and to follow up with her care team as directed. Her family was also advised of the importance of genetic counseling for future family planning purposes.

Electronic Health Record

Patient: 52-year-old female

Admission Date: September, 2016

Admitting diagnosis: Colon cancer

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted due to space-occupying lesions in the colon found during medical examination. Histopathological examination of endoscopic biopsy specimens confirmed moderately differentiated colonic adenocarcinoma. Contrast-enhanced computer tomography (CT) of the abdomen detected several small lymph nodes scattered around the intestine. Laparoscopic examination confirmed the tumor was located in the hepatic flexure of the colon. The clinicopathologic stage was pT3N0M0. Laparoscopy-assisted colectomy was performed to resect the right colonic mass and its surrounding tissue followed by ileocolonic anastomosis.

Family History:

The patient's mother, sister, and brother were diagnosed with colon cancer.

Diagnosis:

Based on Amsterdam II criteria, the patient was diagnosed with Lynch syndrome (LS). A pathogenic variant in MLH1 (c.1852_1854delAAG, p.K618del) was identified in the patient's blood samples. All the siblings and offspring carrying the MLH1 mutation in this family will be monitored on a long-term basis.

Treatment:

No adjuvant chemotherapy was given after surgery.

Discharge Plan:

All individuals carrying the MLH1 mutation in this family will receive long-term follow-up care. The patient will be advised to undergo regular colonoscopy and urine test once a year, and gastroscopy every 3~ 5 years after 35 years old. An asymptomatic carrier of the MLH1 mutation showed signs of dysplasia during endoscopy. The individual received oral administration of aspirin as a preventative treatment, and was advised to undergo regular colonoscopy examination.

Discharge Summary:

Patient:

Patient 2, a 1-year-old boy, was admitted with microcephaly and abnormal arm extension attacks. His physical examination showed truncal hypotonia and he was diagnosed with a short and hypoplastic corpus callosum which affects his development, but the EEG results were normal. A de novo nonsense variant was found that leads to a premature stop codon.

Hospital Course:

During his stay, the patient was treated for his symptoms and monitored for any changes. He received appropriate care from the medical staff and his condition improved gradually. The patient remained stable throughout his hospitalization.

Diagnostic Results:

The MRI showed a short and hypoplastic corpus callosum as well as an upward slant, small and somewhat sloping forehead, depressed nasal bridge, small and upturned nose tip and nostrils, elongated philtrum and a thin upper lip.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with microcephaly and a short and hypoplastic corpus callosum, leading to developmental delays and truncal hypotonia.

Recommendations:

The patient's family was advised to continue regular follow-up visits with their pediatrician and specialists to monitor his progress and development.

Discharge Summary:

Patient was admitted with mild to moderate speech and developmental delay and attention deficit disorder (ADD). No structural brain anomalies were seen on MRI. His OFC was 52.5 cm and he was 156 cm tall. Patient had retrognathia, mild hypertelorism, and a slightly elongated philtrum and thin upper lip. Hands were broad and short. Mild syndactyly of the second and third toe with a sandal gap were seen in both feet.

WES analyses showed a de novo frameshift variant Chr1(GRCh37):g.244217335del, NM_205768.2(ZBTB18):c.259del(p.(Leu87Cysfs*21)), that leads to a premature termination codon located more than 400 codons upstream of the canonical termination codon.

Patient will be discharged with follow-up recommended at regular intervals with genetics and developmental specialists.

Discharge Summary

Patient 4, a 4-year-old boy, presented with severe speech delay, motor delay, and hypotonia. MRI showed agenesis of the splenium of the corpus callosum. At the time of discharge, the patient's condition had improved. The patient showed progress in his speech and motor skills but still exhibited hypotonia.

The patient's OFC was measured at 49 cm (−1 SD) and his height was 98 cm (0 SD) at the time of admission. The patient displayed dysmorphic facial features including hypertelorism, a prominent nasal tip, and a bulbous nose, a small mouth and retro- and micrognathia, along with broad fingertips.

The patient carried a missense variant in ZBTB18. This variant has not been found in individuals from the ExAC database. The patient's missense variant is predicted to be deleterious and affects a highly conserved amino acid residue located in the ZNF domain of the ZBTB18 protein (conserved up to Tetraodon).

The patient's medical history and diagnostic tests revealed developmental delay, prominently in speech. Clinical evaluation for congenital anomalies revealed dysmorphic facial features, epilepsy, hypotonia, and dystonia. The patient underwent an MRI scan, which showed corpus callosum abnormalities. 

In conclusion, Patient 4, a 4-year-old boy, presented with severe speech delay, motor delay, and hypotonia, which improved over the course of treatment. Dysmorphic facial features and corpus callosum abnormalities were observed through imaging. The patient was diagnosed with developmental delay and carried a heterozygous de novo missense variant in ZBTB18, which has not been found in individuals from the ExAC database, and is predicted to be deleterious. The patient will require long-term follow-up care to monitor their progress.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 60-year-old male with chest distress and wheezing for 3 days.

Hospital Course:

The patient reported to have no significant comorbidities except for a 3-year history of hypertension. Upon examination, the patient had rough breath sounds over both lungs and a few moist rales were heard. Laboratory findings showed elevated values for serum creatinine, blood urea, white blood cells count, red blood cells count, and B-type natriuretic peptide. Chest computed tomography (CT) indicated inflammatory areas in both lungs and bilateral pleural effusion. Urinary tract color ultrasonography showed no abnormalities in the ureters or bladder while a physical examination revealed a tender mass in the lower abdomen. Urgent bedside urinary tract ultrasonography showed a large amount of fluid in the bladder. CT revealed hematomas in the prevesical space and bilateral rectus sheath, which were managed with bed rest, ice bag application, and compression bandaging.

Management and Treatment:

Abnormal blood coagulation function was observed, and the patient was transfused with 180 mL fresh frozen plasma. Heparin-free continuous renal replacement therapy was performed for three times per week, and after six sessions, the hematoma was slightly reduced without recurrence. The patient was closely monitored and given 2500 IU LMWH without complications. The heparin dose was then increased to 5000 IU.

Outcome:

The follow-up clinical examination conducted after six months reported that the abdominal mass had completely resolved.

Hospital Course:
Patient 1, a 74-year-old male, underwent HoLEP for bladder outlet obstruction and bladder stones. During the procedure, there was an area of capsular perforation at the 5 o'clock position in the mid gland, and significant abdominal distention was noted upon removal of the operative drapes. General surgery was consulted, and a subumbilical minilaparotomy was performed to address the abdominal distention, revealing retroperitoneal extravasation without intraperitoneal bladder injury or perforation. A 10F Jackson-Pratt drain was placed in the pelvis, and the patient was transferred to the ICU for hemodynamic monitoring and observation.

On POD 1, the patient was progressing well and transferred to the floor in stable condition. The Jackson-Pratt drain output decreased significantly from 710 cc on POD 0 to 81 cc on POD 1 and was subsequently removed on POD 2 after draining 20 cc. Cardiology was consulted in the ICU because of prolonged PR interval and bradycardia, which ultimately warranted no further work-up.

Outcome:
The patient had no significant complications during the hospital stay, was discharged on POD 3, and had his catheter removed on POD 10. Pathologic analysis of the specimen revealed no evidence of malignancy, and the patient's recovery was uneventful.

Discharge Summary:

Patient 2, a 78-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease and pneumonia, underwent a holmium laser enucleation of the prostate (HoLEP) due to persistent lower urinary tract symptoms. Preoperative cystoscopy showed an enlarged prostate and severe bladder trabeculations. During the procedure, extraperitoneal extravasation of saline irrigation was suspected due to capsular perforation, as noted in a similar case (Case 1). The patient was monitored overnight and underwent a CT scan, revealing a moderate amount of free pelvic and abdominal fluid in the extraperitoneal region. Bladder irrigation was continued, and the patient was given Lasix. The patient did not experience any acute events during his hospital stay and was discharged on postoperative day 1 with a catheter. The catheter was removed on postoperative day 9. Final pathology revealed 30 grams of benign prostate tissue, and the patient underwent cystourethroscopy and laser incision of bladder neck contracture four months after the procedure.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 19 days
Sex: Male

Hospital Course:
The patient was brought in for evaluation of vesicoureteral reflux via the insertion of a 6F infant feeding tube, which was followed by a VCUG. During the procedure, it was observed that the catheter could not be successfully removed. The patient was referred to [redacted] for further evaluation and treatment.

Treatment:
Under fluoroscopic guidance, a guidewire was inserted to uncoil the knotted catheter; however, this procedure did not work. A plan was made to remove the knot endoscopically after the patient was placed under general anesthesia. During cystoscopy, it was decided to attempt to remove the catheter by gently pulling it rather than using the endoscopic method. The catheter was successfully removed with ease, and the knot was observed to be at the tip of the catheter. The patient was then closely monitored for any potential injury to the urethra.

Findings:
The mucosal integrity of the urethra was found to be undamaged during the patient's medical evaluation using cystoscopy. A short follow-up period was then observed, and the patient was discharged from the hospital after spontaneously micturating.

Diagnosis:
None

Summary:
The patient's catheter was successfully removed following the VCUG procedure, and no urethral injury was detected during medical evaluation. The patient was observed for a short period of time before being discharged with no follow-up required.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a complaint of bloody stool. Subsequent investigations led to a diagnosis of sigmoid colon adenocarcinoma. The patient underwent primary laparoscopic colon resection, which was unremarkable. However, on the 6th postoperative day, the patient noticed a large amount of yellow fluid coming out of a left side abdominal drain indicating urine leakage. An abdominal ultrasonography showed a collection of fluid in the patient's pelvis. The patient underwent ureteroscopy on the 8th postoperative day, which revealed a complete severing of the left ureter about 4 to 5 cm from the ureteral orifice. Two Double-J ureteral stents were inserted, which led to a quick subsiding of abdominal drainage.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented to the hospital with a complaint of bloody stool. The patient got diagnosed with sigmoid colon adenocarcinoma and underwent primary laparoscopic colon resection without any complications reported initially. But on day 6 of the postoperative period, the patient experienced a large amount of yellow fluid discharge from the abdominal drain. The patient underwent investigations, which led to a diagnosis of a collection of fluid in the pelvis. Further investigations suggested the urine leakage as a result of the complete severing of the left ureter about 4 to 5 cm from the ureteral orifice. The patient underwent ureteroscopy on the 8th postoperative day. Two 4.5F Double-J ureteral stents were inserted, which led to a quick subsiding of abdominal drainage. Follow-up investigations showed excellent healing and realignment of the disrupted ureter, and the stents were removed after 4 months. Follow-up contrast-enhanced CT scans taken 8 and 14 months after the initial endoscopic treatment showed mild but unchanged residual dilation of the renal pelvis and ureter with good drainage. The patient had an asymptomatic urinary tract infection that was treated and resolved.

Patient Identification:
- Name: [REDACTED]
- Sex: Female
- Age: 52 years
- Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of intermittent vaginal spotting for 1 month. Transvaginal ultrasound revealed a 10-cm multi-lobular cystic pelvic mass containing the mixed heterogeneous solid component, fluid and papillary growth in the inner surface of cystic wall. The patient underwent optimal debulking surgery, including total hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, omentectomy, pelvic lymphadenectomy, and para-aortic lymphadenectomy. Histologically, sections of the left ovarian tumor showed a clear cell carcinoma. Right ovarian tumor showed metastatic clear cell carcinoma. Combination of all findings made a diagnosis of AFP-producing clear cell type EOC with fetal gut differentiation, FIGO IIIc. After surgery, the patient received adjuvant multi-agent chemotherapy (carboplatin and paclitaxel).
After treatment, CT showed a 2-cm hypodense nodule at the right subphrenic region and wedge-shaped hypoperfusion over segment 7 of the liver, suspicious tumor seeding, and liver metastasis. Tumor excision for liver metastasis was done. Dose-intensity chemotherapy with weekly paclitaxel was given. CT scan, 1 year later, showed a lobulated mixed solid and cystic lesion at the right paracolic gutter measuring 5 cm in size in favor of peritoneal seeding. Exploratory laparotomy was done, including the use of Cavitron Ultrasonic Surgical Aspirator. After operation, chemotherapy was given through intraperitoneal route. After additional 18 months, tumor recurrence was found, including persistent liver metastases, with increasing serum level of AFP. The patient finally died of disease.

Summary:
The patient was a 52-year-old menopausal woman who complained of intermittent vaginal spotting and was diagnosed with AFP-producing clear cell type EOC with fetal gut differentiation, FIGO IIIc. The patient underwent optimal debulking surgery and received adjuvant multi-agent chemotherapy. Tumor recurrence was found, including persistent liver metastases, and the patient passed away due to the disease.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Diagnosis: Snoring, OSA, myoclonus

Hospital Course:
The 31-year-old patient was admitted to the neurology department for consciousness disorder and fainting. Her major complaints were obesity, snoring, and suffocation during sleep. Her intraoral examination revealed a large soft palate with a class III score based on the Mallampati classification. The EEG showed focal dysrhythmia during hyperventilation with scattered sharp waves, and the patient had sleep disorders such as sleep apnea and myoclonus, especially at the onset of sleep. The patient was feeling depressed and had a history of complete loss of consciousness during swimming and at work. 

The patient underwent a minimally invasive Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty (UUUP) surgery to correct the snoring problems. Before the surgery, craniofacial and pharyngeal airway morphology were evaluated using a lateral cephalogram. 1cm of the soft palatal mucosa was removed under general anesthesia and the patient’s tonsils were also removed during the surgery. The anterior and posterior tonsillar pillars were sutured together. The symptoms were notably reduced, and the patient no longer had sleep apnea or required treatment for depression or epilepsy.

Follow-up:
The 10-year follow-up showed no recurrence of symptoms related to sleep apnea or loss of consciousness. The patient did not lose any weight during the follow-up period.

Recommendations:
The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and to avoid excessive alcohol consumption. Further regular follow-up with the neurologist is recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Admitting Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission:

The patient was admitted to the Emergency Department with worsening right shoulder pain, radiating down the right arm, and accompanied by intermittent fevers for the last two days.

Hospital Course:

The patient had mild leukocytosis with predominant neutrophilia and an elevated C-reactive protein level. The initial shoulder aspirate analysis was negative for any organisms, but showed some scanty pus cells. The patient was started on intravenous flucloxacillin due to her continuing temperature spikes, and an MRI was ordered, which confirmed subscapularis abscess formation as the cause of the patient's presenting symptoms. The patient underwent surgical open drainage of the right subscapularis abscess under general anaesthesia that yielded PVL- positive S. aureus sensitive to flucloxacillin.

The patient was given a two-week course of flucloxacillin and was followed up after six weeks, during which the wound had healed well, and the shoulder pain had resolved with no signs of infection recurrence. The patient still exhibited limited range of movement of the shoulder for which she was referred to physiotherapy.

Discharge Summary:

The patient was discharged with a referral to physiotherapy to address the limited range of movement of the shoulder and advised to continue with the follow-up appointments with their healthcare provider as scheduled. The patient was instructed to monitor their wound and watch for any signs of infection recurrence, and advised to seek medical attention if any symptoms occur. The patient was also given information about the management of cellulitis and Bartholin's cysts as per their significant medical history and advised to adhere to follow-up appointments.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 50-year-old female with right shoulder pain

Medical History:
- Non-insulin-dependent diabetes
- Hypertension
- Anxiety
- Depression
- Fatigue
- Intermittent low-grade right shoulder pain attributed to subacromial bursitis

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the clinic with worsening right shoulder pain, which was attributed to a small full-thickness tear of the supraspinatus tendon. MRI revealed multiple lesions within the proximal humerus that were suggestive of metastases or multiple myeloma. Biopsy confirmed noncaseating granulomatous inflammation, confirming osseous sarcoid of the humerus. Surgical treatment was done by JGS and included arthroscopic debridement, bursectomy, and acromioplasty. Recovery was prolonged due to flares of pain and shoulder stiffness, which were treated with oral corticosteroids and corticosteroid injections. The patient consulted with a rheumatologist who prescribed adalimumab subcutaneous injections once every other week, which improved her fatigue and enhanced her ability to participate in physical therapy. At final postoperative follow-up, the patient reported complete pain relief and restoration of full range of motion and strength.

Summary of Care:
The patient's right shoulder pain was attributed to a small full-thickness tear of the supraspinatus tendon. Biopsy confirmed osseous sarcoid of the humerus. Surgical treatment was done by JGS and included arthroscopic debridement, bursectomy, and acromioplasty. Recovery was prolonged due to flares of pain and shoulder stiffness, which were treated with oral corticosteroids and corticosteroid injections. Adalimumab injections once every other week greatly improved the patient's fatigue and enhanced her ability to participate in physical therapy. At final postoperative follow-up, the patient reported complete pain relief and restoration of full range of motion and strength.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [INSERT PATIENT NAME]
Age: 40-year-old male
Date of Admission: [INSERT DATE OF ADMISSION]
Date of Discharge: [INSERT DATE OF DISCHARGE]
Admitting Diagnosis: Right common carotid artery dissection with C1-C4 fractures
Discharge Diagnosis: Successful carotid artery stenting

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted after sustaining a deep penetrating wound on the right side of the anterior neck from a slip and fall at his work site. Upon arrival, the patient was conscious and alert but acutely ill with his neck fixed in cervical collar. Initial neurological examinations revealed normal pupils which reacted normally to light. Cranial nerves examination was unremarkable, and power on four limbs as well as reflexes was normal. Routine laboratory, ECG, and CXR investigations were normal.

The patient had a CT-scan at the local hospital and an explorative 3D reconstruction plain and enhanced scan imaging of the cervical spine, chest, and abdomen done at our facility, which revealed several fractures and blockages in the cervical area, along with a right common carotid artery dissection. A working diagnosis of right common carotid artery dissection with C1-C4 fractures was made.

After preoperative education and counselling of the patient and relatives, surgery was scheduled the next day. Intraoperative cerebral angiography showed right carotid artery dissection and right vertebral artery occlusion. Carotid artery stenting was successfully performed, with no neurological complications.

The patient recovered significantly and was discharged a week after the procedure. Scheduled outpatient visits every 6 months for two years revealed no neurological complications.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient is advised to continue scheduled outpatient visits every six months to monitor for any neurological complications.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 45-year-old male who presented with a painless right parotid swelling that was progressively increasing in size, which was accompanied by occasional jaw lock. The patient had no significant family medical history or prior history of radiation. Physical examination revealed a tender swelling below the ear lobule, which was firm, diffused, nodular, and fixed to the underlying muscles.

Imaging and Diagnosis:
The patient underwent a neck CT scan and MRI of the parotid glands, which revealed a well-defined altered signal enhancing mass measuring 3.5 × 2.2 × 2.0 cm at the posterior aspect of the superficial part of the right parotid gland, likely to be a benign pleomorphic adenoma. However, a fine-needle aspiration cytology of the mass was non-conclusive. The patient underwent a superficial parotidectomy, which was performed in piecemeal as the mass was unexpectedly adherent to the skin and underlying fascia. Histopathologic examination revealed a widely infiltrative tumor involving the parotid parenchyma and extending into the surrounding adipose tissue and skeletal muscles, which was diagnosed as a low-grade MPNST arising in a diffuse neurofibroma.

Management and Follow-Up:
The patient was evaluated clinically for features of NF1, and multiple café au lait macules were subsequently discovered on his trunk. The patient was referred to a cancer center for further management and follow-up. Further clinical examination and MRI revealed no distant metastasis. The patient underwent several courses of radiotherapy and is currently eighteen months disease-free.

Summary:
The patient presented with a progressively increasing right parotid swelling, which was initially suspected to be a benign pleomorphic adenoma. However, histopathologic examination revealed a low-grade MPNST arising in a diffuse neurofibroma. The patient was evaluated clinically for NF1, and multiple café au lait macules were subsequently discovered on his trunk. The patient underwent several courses of radiotherapy and is currently eighteen months disease-free.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with an assault injury to the right shoulder. The physical examination revealed a wound of around 20 cm on the posterior aspect of the right shoulder extending to the glenohumeral joint. The patient complained of right shoulder pain and bleeding due to the injury by a cleaver. On further examination, there was a minimally displaced coronal-oblique fracture at the base of the acromion. The patient underwent a CT scan with 3D reconstruction to confirm the diagnosis.

Treatment Given:
The patient was given appropriate pain management medication and was closely monitored by the medical staff. The patient's passive motion and active motion of the shoulder were painful and limited. The wound was cleaned and dressed, but there was no active bleeding. No vascular or neurological injuries were found.

Outcome:
The patient was discharged in stable condition with adequate pain management medication. The patient was advised to follow up with the orthopedic clinic for further treatment. 

Follow-Up:
The patient was scheduled for a follow-up appointment with the orthopedic clinic. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
Shoulder pain and bleeding due to the assault injury by a cleaver. Minimally displaced coronal-oblique fracture at the base of the acromion. 

Discharge Medications:
No medications were prescribed at the time of discharge.

Discharge Instruction:
The patient was advised to follow up with the orthopedic clinic for further treatment.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with acute nonpruritic painless erythematous papules over the upper torso, accompanied by subjective fevers, chills, nausea, vomiting, and frontal headache for 2 days. The initial concern was for sepsis, and the patient was started on antibiotics with ceftriaxone and azithromycin for suspected lower respiratory tract infection. The chest X-ray showed a possible new left lower lobe basilar opacity. The patient was managed with antimicrobial therapy broadened to vancomycin, piperacillin/tazobactam, and intravenous acyclovir. A diffuse 1 cm papulopustular rash erupted over the scalp, head, neck, thorax, abdomen, and upper and lower extremities including the palmar and dorsal aspects of the hand. Given the return of symptoms along with rash after rechallenge of azathioprine, drug hypersensitivity was suspected. The azathioprine was discontinued, and the symptoms subsided with the pustules reduced in size and number. A biopsy of the pustules showed suppurative folliculitis. All pustule stains, bacterial, viral, including herpes zoster and varicella zoster, and periodic acid-Schiff-diastase (PAS-D) stains, were negative. The patient's azathioprine hypersensitivity reaction was evaluated utilizing the Naranjo algorithm. The discharge diagnosis was azathioprine hypersensitivity reaction with spontaneous resolution of symptoms. The patient was managed with supportive care and observation with plans for follow-up as an outpatient.
