The patient was discharged in stable condition with no major complications, and the patient and family were provided appropriate education and follow-up instructions upon discharge.

Patient Information:
- Name: [redacted]
- Age: 80 years
- Gender: Female
- Date of Admission: [redacted]
- Date of Discharge: [redacted]
- Reason for Admission: Mass over the superior aspect of the right scapula

Hospital Course:
The patient, an 80-year-old female, was admitted to the clinic with a mass over the superior aspect of the right scapula. The mass, though achy, did not interfere with performing activities of daily living, but had been enlarging over the previous few months. The patient had no local injuries or recent surgeries on the affected side, and denied having weakness in the left arm or trouble with overhead activities. A similar mass on the contralateral side was excised 10 years previously with favorable results. Inspection of the area was unremarkable, but palpation revealed a firm, nonmobile, and nonpulsatile mass, which was slightly tender upon deeper pressure. Shoulder examination showed no signs of rotator cuff weakness or shoulder pain. X-ray revealed narrowing of the posterior glenohumeral joint space, which was consistent with osteoarthritic changes. MRI revealed an elongated cystic lesion arising from the AC joint and tracking medially to superficial and within the trapezius muscle. The lesion measured 2 cm (AP) × 13 cm (transverse) × 1.8 cm (craniocaudad), and had peripheral enhancement. There was also suspected full-thickness tear of the anterior fibers of the supraspinatus.

Treatment:
The patient underwent excision of the mass via a general anesthetic. Careful dissection revealed a stalk emanating from the AC joint, which was identified and dissected free. The mass was removed en bloc, and a distal clavicle excision was performed using an oscillating saw. After the cyst was excised, it was incised revealing thick mucoid content. Postsurgery, the patient reported immediate pain relief and continued to have full and pain-free range of motion with no signs of recurrence during follow-up visits at three weeks and three months.

Diagnosis:
- Elongated cystic lesion arising from the AC joint and tracking medially to superficial and within the trapezius muscle

Course:
- Excision of cyst
- Distal clavicle excision

Condition at Discharge:
- Improved

Discharge Instructions:
- Avoid heavy lifting or strenuous physical activity for the next few weeks.
- Keep the surgical incision site clean and dry.
- Take pain medication as prescribed.
- Follow-up with the clinic at the recommended intervals.

Follow-up Recommendations:
- Follow up with the clinic at the recommended intervals.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [MRN]
Date of Admission: [Date of Admission]
Date of Discharge: [Date of Discharge]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient, a 74-year-old male, was admitted in March 2017 to undergo liver resection for a malignant hepatic lesion diagnosed on CT and PET. The lesion was found in the VIII segment of the liver with three smaller hypodense liver lesions. The case was discussed with radiologists, oncologists, and pathologists of our hospital. Due to the proximity/doubtful infiltration of the lesion to the biliary tree, an explorative staging laparotomy and possible palliative surgery were performed.

As per our internal protocol, a routine liver function test with ICG was conducted to determine the most appropriate surgical procedures. The patient was injected with 45mg of ICG to test hepatic function ten days before the surgery and an adjunctive dose of 9mg of ICG was given the day before the surgery.

During the surgical procedure, the lesion was easily identified and defined on the liver surface using the fluorescent imaging system. The fluorescent imaging also revealed a large area of fluorescent parenchyma that extended from the periphery of the lesion up to the portal pedicle such as the neoplasia would interest the right biliary tree in the form of neoplastic lymphangitis, a datum that was not pre-operatively known.

An atypical segmental resection of S8 associated with cholecystectomy and lymphadenectomy of the hepatic pedicle nodes, including the area of impaired biliary excretion was performed. At the histological examination, the lesion, the lymph nodes of the hepatic pedicle region, and the right biliary branch, respectively, resulted in hepatic metastases from squamous cell carcinoma and sites of metastatic location. As expected, the resection margin was affected by neoplasia.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

Hepatic metastases from squamous cell carcinoma

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

The patient is advised to have their post-operative follow-up with their primary care physician. The patient is advised to report any symptoms such as pain, fever, or any drainage from the site of surgery. The patient is advised to follow a healthy diet and maintain physical activity and not to smoke.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:

None

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENTS:

Follow-up with the primary care physician

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 45-year-old woman

Hospitalization Dates: [Insert dates]

1. Admission: The patient was admitted to the emergency department with dyspnea and swelling on her hands and face.

2. Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with MRS, after presenting with recurrent spontaneous facial paralysis, orofacial edema, fissure on the tongue, and peripheral facial paralysis.

3. Treatment: The patient was initially treated with noninvasive mechanical ventilation, then invasive mechanical ventilation, lung protective MV strategies, fluid replacement, antibiotics, and other medical treatments. During her stay, intravenous steroid treatment was added to her therapy by the neurologist.

4. Imaging: A chest X-ray showed bilateral nonhomogenous infiltration at middle and lower zones. Cranial computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) did not show any pathological imagination.

5. Complications: During her stay, an oral secretion increase and left nasolabial sulcus wipe out were observed, leading to the diagnosis of peripheral facial paralysis (PFP).

6. Dermatology: The patient also presented with oedema on her face, pustular lesions on her skin, and fissure on her tongue. A labium mucosal biopsy was taken and mucositis was reported.

7. Discharge: The patient was transferred from the ICU to the department of neurology and then discharged from the hospital.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: [Name]

Medical Record Number: [Number]

Date of Admission: [Date]

Date of Discharge: [Date]

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 7-year-old girl of Indian descent presented with complaints of hypochromic linear bands in two regions, which had persisted for one year. The lesions were present on the right forearm and left leg and buttocks without any associated pruritus, pain, hair loss, or nail involvement. No biopsies were taken at the request of the patient's parents. The patient was diagnosed with Lichen striatus and advised observation with explanation of the disease course. A follow-up visit was scheduled but the patient did not return to the clinic.

Final Diagnosis:

Lichen striatus (LS).

Recommendations:

The patient was advised to keep a watch on the hypopigmented lichenoid macules. The parents were offered the option of a biopsy to confirm the diagnosis or follow-up visits. If the lesions had progressed, medical management could be considered after appropriate evaluation.

Patient Education:

The diagnosis, LS, was explained to the patient's parents. The natural course of the disease was reviewed, and it was explained that the condition is self-limiting and resolves spontaneously within a year or two. The parents were advised to avoid traumatic stimuli to prevent Koebnerization.

Follow-Up:

A follow-up was scheduled at a convenient date for the patient.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Gender: Male
Age: 58

Hospital Course Summary:

- Admitted for presenting symptoms of fever and upper abdominal pain with hepatobiliary enzyme elevation.
- Underwent double-balloon endoscopy (DBE) revealing benign anastomotic stenosis causing cholangitis.
- Balloon dilation and biliary stenting with a plastic stent (PS) were performed.
- Experienced relapsing cholangitis occurring six times a year leading to the decision to undergo EUS-HGS with MS
- EUS-HGS performed, using the GF Type UCT 260 (Olympus Medical Systems, Tokyo, Japan) endoscope.
- Puncture the bile duct with a 19-G needle (EZ shot 3; Olympus), introduced a 0.025-inch guidewire (VisiGlide 2; Olympus) antegradely into the jejunum and dilated the puncture site with a 3.6-Fr double-lumen catheter (Uneven Double Lumen Catheter; PIOLAX, Tokyo, Japan).
- Placed an 8mm covered MS (Niti-S; TaeWoong Medical Inc., Seoul, Korea).
- Experienced no adverse events during the EUS-HGS.
- Post EUS-HGS, hepatobiliary enzyme elevation normalized, and cholangitis has not recurred for 5 months.

Discharge Diagnosis:

- Cholangitis due to benign anastomotic stenosis.

Discharge Medication:

N/A

Discharge Condition:

- The patient is stable and is discharged from hospital care.

Discharge Instructions:

- Need for regular follow-up appointments with treating physician.
- Contact treating physician if any symptoms occur.
- Proper maintenance of wound sites.
- Avoid any strenuous physical activity.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 68-year-old man, was admitted for relapsing cholangitis caused by anastomotic benign stenosis after extended right hepatectomy and bile duct resection with choledochojejunostomy for hilar cholangiocarcinoma. Biliary stenting with PS had been performed, but the stenosis did not improve. Thus, he underwent EUS-HGS with MS. The procedure was successful, and the patient experienced no adverse events. Nine months after EUS-HGS, cholangitis occurred only once due to debris and granulation. We performed balloon sweeping for debris and placed a PS into the MS. Twelve months after EUS-HGS, we replaced the PS with an MS. The patient's hepatobiliary enzymes normalized, and cholangitis has not recurred in 11 months.

Hospital Course:

Admission Date: 
Discharge Date: 

Diagnosis:

Relapsing cholangitis 

Procedures:

Extended right hepatectomy, bile duct resection with choledochojejunostomy, biliary stenting with PS, EUS-HGS with MS.

Course of Treatment:

Biliary stenting with PS was performed for the patient, but it did not improve the stenosis. EUS-HGS with MS was conducted, which successfully treated the anastomotic benign stenosis. The patient experienced no adverse events. Nine months after EUS-HGS, the patient experienced cholangitis only once due to debris and granulation. We performed balloon sweeping and placed a PS into the MS. Twelve months after EUS-HGS, we replaced the PS with an MS. The patient's hepatobiliary enzymes normalized, and cholangitis has not recurred in 11 months.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient was discharged in a stable condition.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: L2 vertebral fracture with disruptions of the posterior ligamentous complex
Procedure: L1-L2 single-level instrumented fusion using a posterior approach

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 33-year-old male involved in an automobile accident, was admitted to our hospital after being brought by ambulance, reporting severe back pain but showing no neurological deficit. Radiographs of the spine showed a vertebral fracture in the L2 vertebra with an increased gap between the 1st and 2nd lumbar spinous processes. Magnetic resonance imaging revealed disruptions to the posterior ligamentous complex between L1 and L2, combined with an extensive subcutaneous hematoma. After checking the patient's general condition, and excluding intra-abdominal injury, the patient underwent L1-L2 single-level instrumented fusion using a posterior approach. A rigid fixation was achieved with monoaxial and polyaxial pedicle screws, resulting in good reduction of the fracture.

Postoperative Period:
The postoperative period was uneventful. Although rigid fixation was obtained with this procedure, a thoracolumbosacral orthosis (TLSO) was applied for 6 weeks, as this was the first experience performing the procedure. Physical activities were not restricted with the TLSO. Sagittal CT and 3D-CT obtained at 6 months and 1 year postoperatively showed proper trajectory of the CBT pedicle screw and complete bone union.

Follow-up:
The patient was discharged in stable condition. The patient will be advised to follow-up with their primary care physician for further evaluation and care as needed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Age: 20

Gender: Male

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Moderate left-sided UC

Principal Diagnosis: Chronic inflammation with architectural distortion and cryptic abscess

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with a complaint of bloody diarrhea, cramping abdominal pain, and weight loss. The patient was diagnosed with moderate left-sided UC and started on oral and topical 5-ASA treatment without any response. High dose steroids therapy was initiated and the patient showed marked improvement. However, steroid tapering caused a recurrence of symptoms and anemia. Infliximab was initiated, but the patient did not show any improvement after 4 months of treatment. The patient was switched to combination therapy with Adalimumab plus Azathioprine with only partial response. The patient continued to have severe colicky abdominal pain and distension with weight loss and was diagnosed with chronic inflammation with architectural distortion and cryptic abscess. The patient underwent total colectomy with ileoanal anastomosis and J pouch.

Discharge medications:

N/A

Followup:

The patient is advised to followup with his gastroenterologist.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

PATIENT NAME: [patient name]

AGE/SEX: 71-year-old male

DATE ADMITTED: [date admitted]

DATE DISCHARGED: [date discharged]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was admitted with complaints of diarrhea and rectal bleeding. He was diagnosed with chronic active colitis and prescribed Mesalamine 4g per day. However, the patient was lost to follow-up and did not continue the medication regimen. Four years later, he was seen again with the same symptoms, and an obstructive giant pseudopolyp was found in the transverse colon through colonoscopy. The biopsy confirmed chronic inflammation with architectural distortion and granulation tissue formation. The patient underwent segmental colonic resection and was diagnosed with colonic Crohn's disease complicated by an obstructive giant pseudopolyp. 

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

Colonic Crohn's disease complicated by an obstructive giant pseudopolyp.

CONDITION AT DISCHARGE:

Stable.

FOLLOW-UP:

The patient is advised to follow up with his healthcare provider for continued monitoring of his symptoms and to discuss treatment plans. 

SIGNATURE:

[Physician signature]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Record Number: [redacted]
DOB: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Significant Findings/History of Present Illness:
The patient is a 32-year-old male who presented to the emergency department with the complaint of retrosternal chest pain radiating to the left shoulder, shortness of breath, and sweating. He had no history of any cardiovascular risk factors such as diabetes or hypertension. On physical examination, the patient was noted to have cystic acne. Further investigations revealed that the patient had a self-reported diagnosis of hypothyroidism for which he was administering Armour Thyroid. 

Hospital Course:
An electrocardiogram revealed ST-segment elevations in leads aVL, I, and v1-v6 and ST segment depressions in leads II, III, and aVF, suggestive of an acute ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). Initial lab work reported high levels of cardiac troponin. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) displayed increase in left ventricular (LV) wall thickness, reduced ejection fraction (EF) of 40%, grade 1 diastolic dysfunction, and hypokinetic anterior and anteroseptal walls in the distribution of the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery. Emergent left heart catheterization was performed, and a coronary angiogram revealed a complete occlusion of the LAD at the ostium. Manual thrombectomy of the LAD was performed, and a drug-eluting stent was positioned, leading to the return of TIMI-III flow. The patient was started on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel, in addition to heparin and eptifibatide infusions.

Medical Management:
Following the patient's admission, a focused investigation revealed that the patient participated in recreational bodybuilding and self-administered exogenous testosterone therapy and used Armour Thyroid as a weight loss supplement. The patient's testosterone levels were elevated, and free triiodothyronine was high with a suppressed total thyroxine, confirming Armour Thyroid administration.

Discharge Medications:
The patient was discharged on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel.

Follow-up:
The patient was instructed to follow up with his primary care physician and/or endocrinologist for further evaluation and management of his hypothyroidism.

Instructions:
The patient was advised to follow a heart-healthy diet, maintain a healthy lifestyle, and attend follow-up appointments with his healthcare provider.

Signed,
[redacted]
MD

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
DOB: N/A
Sex: Male
Admitting Diagnosis: Elevated PSA
Discharge Diagnosis: Irritative Urinary Symptoms
Hospital Course:

The patient presented with an elevated PSA and underwent a systematic biopsy, which revealed prostate cancer in the left apical region. After discussions with the multidisciplinary team, he opted for definitive treatment with prostate SBRT. A diagnostic multi-parametric prostate MRI was done, and three gold fiducial markers were placed in the urology office via a TRUS-guided approach. After the simulation CT scan was completed, axial T2-weighted and post contrast T1-weighted MRI were fused with the CT images using radiation therapy planning software. Target volumes of the prostate and the high-risk lesion were then generated on the CT based on MRI segmented regions of suspicion. The high-risk volume received 40 Gy SIB in five fractions while the entire prostate received 36.25 Gy. He was placed on tamsulosin during radiation therapy after developing irritative urinary symptoms. These symptoms were his only radiation-associated side effects. Six months after his treatment, he continues to have irritative urinary symptoms and remains on tamsulosin.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient presented with an elevated PSA and underwent a systematic biopsy, which revealed prostate cancer in the left apical region. After discussions with the multidisciplinary team, he opted for definitive treatment with prostate SBRT. The treatment was done without complications, and the patient developed irritative urinary symptoms, which were managed with tamsulosin. Six months after treatment, the patient continues to have these symptoms.

Hospital Course: 

The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presented with an elevated PSA and history of negative prostate cancer biopsy from three years ago. Despite an overall benign appearance on MRI, there was a small focal area of hypointensity concerning for malignancy which was confirmed on biopsy to represent GS 4+3 prostate adenocarcinoma. The patient elected to undergo SBRT radiation therapy for treatment of this intermediate-risk prostate cancer. Treatment planning was done using CT/MRI fusion to target the SIB volume in the posterior peripheral zone while minimizing exposure to the rectum and neurovascular bundle. The patient experienced mild dysuria and self-limited diarrhea during radiation therapy, which resolved by one month follow-up visit. 

Hospital Course Summary: 

Admission date: [INSERT]  Discharge date: [INSERT]

Patient's primary issue: Intermediate-risk prostate cancer 

History of present illness: 

The patient's PSA had been steadily increasing since his last prostate biopsy three years ago, peaking at 8.98 ng/mL. MP-MRI showed a small focal area of hypointensity concerning for malignancy which was confirmed on biopsy to represent GS 4+3 prostate adenocarcinoma. The patient underwent SBRT radiation therapy and had mild dysuria and self-limited diarrhea during treatment. 

Medical/surgical history: 

The patient had a history of mild lower urinary tract symptoms but no other significant past medical or surgical history. 

Hospital course: 

The patient underwent TRUS-guided fiducial markers placement followed by radiation therapy with SBRT. Treatment planning was done using CT/MRI fusion which allowed targeting of the SIB volume in the posterior peripheral zone. The patient experienced mild dysuria during the final two fractions of radiation therapy which was managed with increased tamsulosin. He also had self-limited diarrhea one week after treatment which resolved by one-month follow-up visit. 

Discharge medications: 

None 

Follow-up instructions: 

The patient should follow-up with his multidisciplinary team to monitor response to treatment and PSA levels.

Patient Name: N/A

Reason for Admission: New-onset jaundice, general weakness, fatigue, and itching

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for 2.4 cm Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST) and s/p laparoscopic partial gastrectomy, who presented to the emergency department with new-onset jaundice. The patient reported no previous history of alcohol consumption, drug use, or any liver diseases. The patient was taking imatinib, prescribed by her hematologist-oncologist, for the past four months. The medication was discontinued on hospital admission because of the concern of hepatotoxicity. During the hospital course, initial laboratory testing showed significantly elevated transaminases with aspartate aminotransferase (AST) of 1450 U/L and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) of 1632 U/L. The patient underwent an interventional radiology (IR)-guided liver biopsy. After seven days, the patient’s transaminases began to decrease, ultimately falling to AST of 483 U/L and ALT of 544 U/L. The patient was discharged from the hospital after her transaminases, as well as the rest of the LFTs, continued to trend downwards and were within normal range two months later.

Diagnoses: 
1. Elevated transaminases

Procedures:
1. Interventional radiology (IR)-guided liver biopsy

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition upon discharge was stable.

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient was instructed to follow-up with her primary care physician.

Discharge Disposition:
The patient was discharged to home.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Admission Date: [Redacted]

Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Sleep Apnea

Principal Diagnosis at Discharge: Narcolepsy

Hospital Course:

The six-year-old African American female was admitted to our care for the evaluation of sleep attacks and apnea during sleep. A nocturnal polysomnogram (NPSG) was conducted for further investigation, which showed that the patient experienced cataplexy episodes with laughter. During the evaluation, the patient demonstrated decreased sleep latency and spent a considerable amount of time in the supine position. The results confirmed mild obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) by pediatric criteria. The patient underwent another NPSG with a multiple sleep latency test (MSLT) for persistent symptoms, which confirmed three central apneas, six mixed apneas, nine obstructive hypopneas, and an apnea-hypopnea index of 2.9 events/hour. Laboratory workup for HLA-DR15 and DQ0602 was positive, and the patient had documented cataplexy.

Medical Management:

The patient had a positive laboratory workup for HLA-DR15 and DQ0602 and documented cataplexy. Considering all these outcomes, the patient was diagnosed with narcolepsy. Additionally, polysomnography was suggestive of mild obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) by pediatric criteria. Medical management was focused on lifestyle modifications and sleep hygiene. The patient and her parents were counseled on maintaining a regular sleep/wake schedule, avoiding activities that could interfere with sleep, and avoiding caffeine before sleep. The patient was discharged with follow-up appointments.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient was stable and admitted clinical outcomes were addressed. The patient was discharged with follow-up appointments.

Follow-Up Care:

The patient was discharged with a follow-up appointment for sleep monitoring and necessary investigations. Additionally, the patient and family were advised to follow proper sleep hygiene practices. Follow-up appointments were scheduled to keep a check on the patient's progress. Counseling was also provided to the patient and her family regarding the importance of sleep hygiene and its effects on health. 

Discharge Medications:

None

Discharge Instructions:

The patient and her parents were instructed to follow a regular sleep schedule and avoid fun activities that may interfere with sleep. Additionally, no long-term medication was prescribed in this particular case. Follow-up appointments were scheduled, and any concerns or issues were discussed with patient/family before discharge.

Discharge Condition:

Stable.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was admitted for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and constrictive bronchiolitis. The patient's lung function tests revealed an obstructive pattern, and CT scan showed mild ground glass infiltrates in the lung bases.

The patient underwent a lung biopsy via assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) in December 2011. She was diagnosed with constrictive bronchiolitis and diffuse idiopathic neuroendocrine cell hyperplasia with carcinoid tumorlets and was treated with octreotide.

The patient's hospital course was complicated by insurance and transportation issues, leading to several interruptions in treatment. The patient re-started treatment in our hospital in May 2014.

The patient's CT scans taken every six months show a stable disease. She currently has stable radiographic disease with no new complaints during over two years of follow-up.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:

Patient is discharged in a stable condition.

FOLLOW-UP:

The patient is advised to continue regular follow-up appointments with her primary care provider and pulmonologist for monitoring of her obstructive lung disease and constrictive bronchiolitis.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:

None.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

1. COPD
2. Constrictive bronchiolitis
3. Diffuse idiopathic neuroendocrine cell hyperplasia with carcinoid tumorlets

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

1. Discharge instructions were discussed with the patient and were understood.
2. The patient will continue to use her prescribed inhalers.
3. The patient will continue to avoid smoking and exposure to air pollutants.
4. The patient will follow up with her primary care provider and pulmonologist regularly for monitoring and management of her obstructive lung disease and constrictive bronchiolitis.

DISCHARGE DISPOSITION:

Discharged home.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient, a nine-year-old female, was admitted to the Emergency Department with complaints of abdominal pain and distention for the past one week, with sudden increase in intensity of pain for the last four hours. Upon initial examination, there was a palpable mass occupying the right side of the abdomen, which was suspected to be an appendicular mass. A computed tomography (CT) scan was ordered, which revealed a large soft tissue mass measuring approximately 80 x 150 x 170 mm in the right mid and lower quadrant, suggestive of left ovarian tumor with torsion.

The patient underwent an exploratory laparotomy and left salpingo-oophorectomy along with partial omentectomy. The surgically resected specimen was sent for histopathological analysis, which revealed mature ovarian dysgerminoma that was limited to the left ovary without capsular invasion (TNM stage: T1A, N0, M0 according to FIGO staging). The excised left fallopian tube, omentum, and peritoneal washout were all negative for malignancy. 

Postoperatively, the patient showed satisfactory progress and was discharged from the hospital in a stable condition. The patient is planned for follow-up visit with an oncologist as an outpatient.

Conclusion:

The patient presented with abdominal pain and distention, which was identified as a soft tissue mass in the right mid and lower quadrant, suggestive of left ovarian tumor with torsion. The patient underwent successful surgical intervention and was discharged from the hospital in stable condition. Follow-up visit with an oncologist is planned for the patient as an outpatient.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: _____________
Discharge Date: _____________

Admitting Diagnosis: Generalized weakness, dizziness, polyuria, dyspnea on exertion

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 68-year-old Caucasian man, was admitted with complaints of generalized weakness, dizziness, polyuria, and dyspnea on exertion. He had a medical history of hypertension, high cholesterol, and coronary artery disease. Physical examination revealed a grade IV/VI systolic murmur over the apex radiating to the left axilla and back, and a grade III/VI systolic murmur at the aortic area. He was found to have an increased urinary protein excretion, but not in the nephrotic range. Laboratory data showed hemoglobin of 6.5 g/dL and BUN/creatinine of 71 md/dL/6.3 mg/dL. Urinary protein excretion was increased but not in the nephrotic range, and all other laboratory values, including white blood cell count, platelet count, and LDH levels, were normal.

Subsequent transthoracic echocardiogram demonstrated severe mitral regurgitation and multiple hyperechoic masses on the tips of both mitral leaflets with a small mobile mass on the posterior mitral leaflet. It also showed aortic regurgitation and a mobile echogenic structure, attached to the ventricular side of aortic valve. Streptococcus parasanguinis was isolated from blood cultures, and the organism was sensitive to penicillin and ceftriaxone. Antibiotics treatment for endocarditis was initiated. Despite this, the patient's kidney function worsened, and he required hemodialysis.

Electron microscopy of renal biopsy showed crescent formation, and immunofluorescence showed immune complex deposition. The patient was then treated with corticosteroids and cyclophosphamide. Double valve replacement surgery was performed due to severe aortic and mitral valve regurgitation, and echocardiogram after surgery did not demonstrate mitral or aortic valve regurgitation. The bioprosthetic mitral and aortic valves were normally functioning. 

The patient remained on hemodialysis despite treatment with antibiotics, steroids, and cyclophosphamide. An AV fistula was placed in the left arm, and maintenance hemodialysis was recommended three times per week. At one-year follow-up, the patient remained on hemodialysis and was in an otherwise stable condition.  

Discharge Diagnosis: Endocarditis

Discharge Medications: N/A

Discharge Instructions:
-The patient is advised to continue regular hemodialysis treatment.
-The patient should follow-up with his treating physician as directed.

Follow-Up Care: Follow up with treating physician as directed.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 53-year-old man, presented to our Department with a 2-month history of a painful and moderately swollen left wrist. Standard anteroposterior and lateral X-rays of his left wrist revealed two osteolytic lesions involving the distal ulna and the lunate fossa of the distal radius without any joint involvement. Subsequent biopsy of his left ulna under regional anesthesia produced brown spongy material, histologically characterized by the presence of large numbers of multinucleated giant cells and spindle cells in a dense collagenous background. These findings were histologically consistent with a diagnosis of Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) and correlation with the clinical and radiological findings was recommended by the pathologist. As he had no other skeletal manifestations, a complete resection of the distal ulna followed, along with curettage and cementoplasty of the distal radial metaphysis, to support the articular surface.

Two weeks postoperatively, he was re-admitted to our orthopedic department with diffuse musculoskeletal soreness, anorexia, constipation, nausea, and localized abdominal pain. He also reported weight loss of approximately 5 kg. On palpation, he had tenderness in the thoracic wall, the second and fifth metacarpals of his right hand, the left tibia, the pelvic ring, and the left shoulder girdle and humerus. Plain radiographs revealed multiple osteolytic lesions in his ribs, right hand, left tibia, and scapula. A histopathological examination of both the resected ulna and the curettings of the radius revealed similar findings: numerous, multinucleated, osteoclast-type giant cells were noted amid a mononuclear, spindle cell, histiocytoid component. Based on the similar findings of both lesions and the rarity of multifocal GCT of bone, the histopathology report included in the differential diagnosis a Bone Tumor of hyperparathyroidism, either primary or in the setting of a paraneoplastic PTH-like protein production and suggested further patient evaluation.

Our patient’s laboratory examination showed high total serum calcium, low serum phosphorus, and low 25-hydroxyvitamin D. Primary Hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) was suspected and confirmed by the elevated PTH levels. Serum potassium and sodium concentrations and thyroid hormone levels were in reference range, as well as the main cancer indicators. His human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) was elevated. An isotope bone scan showed multiple sites of uptake over his ribs bilaterally, the lower pole of both scapulae, multiple foci in his pelvis, the metacarpal bones of his right hand, and his right tibia. At subsequent radiological work-up, both computed tomography (CT) and ultrasonography of his neck revealed a mass emanating from the right lobe of his thyroid gland. Parathyroid subtraction technetium-99m (99mTc) sestamibi (MIBI) scintigraphy showed extensive uptake in his right lower parathyroid gland. Multiple endocrine neoplasia was excluded because of the normal MRI imaging of his pituitary gland.

Appropriate medical care was given to our patient including hyperhydration and high doses of diuretics and diphosphonates. After his health status improved and his serum calcium nearly normalized, a specialist surgeon was consulted for further surgical treatment. Surgery consisted of extensive resection: total thyroidectomy with removal of the parathyroid glands. A mass abutting the thyroid gland was documented at surgery. The mass was surrounded by a thick capsule, had a tan-brown, solid, and microcystic cut surface, and rubbery consistency. On histologic examination, the tumor comprised small cells with minimal to scanty cytoplasm and round nuclei, arranged in an organoid pattern, with frequent perivascular pseudorosettes. Thick fibrous septa emanating from the capsule were noted within the tumor. There was capsular invasion, with extension of neoplastic groups in the surrounding loose connective tissue adjacent to striated muscle, and foci of vascular invasion in the tumor capsule. The histologic findings were consistent with a parathyroid carcinoma. The neoplasm did not appear to invade the adjacent thyroid lobe and did not involve the margins of resection.

The patient experienced postoperatively persistent hypocalcemia requiring calcium and vitamin D replacement. His condition was characterized as “hungry bone syndrome.” He is now recovering 12 months after surgery, with a serum PTH level of 7.1 pg/mL and serum calcium level of 10.7 mg/dl and he is under calcium and vitamin D replacement therapy. The lytic bone lesions have almost disappeared, and no other additional orthopedic intervention is necessary. He is closely followed by general surgeons, oncologists, and endocrinologists.

Diagnoses:

1. Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) of bone
2. Primary Hyperparathyroidism (PHPT)
3. Parathyroid Carcinoma

Procedures and Treatments:

1. Biopsy of left ulna
2. Complete resection of the distal ulna
3. Curettage and cementoplasty of the distal radial metaphysis
4. Total thyroidectomy with removal of the parathyroid glands
5. Hyperhydration and high doses of diuretics and diphosphonates
6. Calcium and vitamin D replacement therapy

Follow-Up:

The patient is closely followed by general surgeons, oncologists, and endocrinologists. No additional orthopedic intervention is necessary.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Demographics:
- Name: [REDACTED]
- Age: 56 years
- Gender: Male
- Race: Caucasian
- Occupation: Truck Driver

Admission Details:
- Admitted in March 2017 for asthma exacerbation and poor control of symptoms
- Relevant medical history includes hepatitis, nasal polyposis, chronic sinusitis, and gastroesophageal reflux disease
- Diagnosed with non-allergic asthma in 2016
- Required systemic corticosteroids for over 6 months and 7 unscheduled visits in the previous year
- Received bronchial thermoplasty in September and October 2017

Clinical Course:
- Developed persistent haemoptysis in October 2017 and was admitted to the ward
- CT scan showed mild varicoid bronchiectasis and distal parenchymal infiltrate in the left lower lobe with mild airway inflammation in the right lower lobe
- Fibreoptic bronchoscopy revealed two small nodular neoformations in the sub-segmental branches of the left lower lobe
- Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) showed peripheral infiltrate and four trans-bronchial biopsies were taken
- Histological examination showed mild non-specific inflammation with haemorrhagic necrosis, blood and fibrin, hemosiderin deposits and organizing pneumonia
- Treated empirically with co-amoxiclav and azithromycin for 6 days and prednisone for 10 days
- Follow-up CT scan in December 2017 showed complete resolution of the parenchymal opacities
- Underwent third session of bronchial thermoplasty in January 2018

Discharge Planning:
- Recommended follow-up appointments with specialist for ongoing asthma management
- Prescribed formoterol/fluticasone inhaler, tiotropium bromide inhaler, and montelukast for asthma control

Follow-up Instructions:
- Continue prescribed medication regimen as directed
- Return for follow-up appointments and testing as recommended by the specialist

Summary:
The patient, a 56-year-old male truck driver, was admitted in March 2017 for asthma exacerbation and poor control of symptoms. He had a history of hepatitis, nasal polyposis, chronic sinusitis, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. He was diagnosed with non-allergic asthma in 2016 and received bronchial thermoplasty in September and October 2017. He developed persistent haemoptysis in October 2017 and was diagnosed with mild varicoid bronchiectasis and distal parenchymal infiltrate. He was treated empirically with antibiotics and prednisone and had a complete resolution of the parenchymal opacities in December 2017. He underwent a third session of bronchial thermoplasty in January 2018 and was recommended to continue his prescribed medication regimen and follow-up appointments with his specialist for ongoing asthma management.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 54-year-old male with a past medical history significant for alcoholism, tobacco abuse, noninsulin-dependent type 2 diabetes mellitus and osteoarthritis. He presented with an enlarging right-neck mass in November of 2015, which was found to be a malignant squamous cell carcinoma on fine-needle aspiration. No further treatment was pursued at that time due to socioeconomic issues. However, the patient experienced three flares of painful neck adenopathy over the next sixteen months, each of which was treated with short courses of antibiotics and steroids.

The patient returned in March of 2017 when his latest flare of right-sided neck adenopathy failed to respond to the usual treatment. A CT scan revealed multiple low-density cystic structures in the right neck consistent with necrotic lymph nodes. A PET-CT scan showed right neck hypermetabolic uptake, and a CT scan of the chest showed no obvious disease and no evidence of lymphadenopathy. Further testing revealed an ALK+ LBCL diagnosis based on H&E- stained mass excisional biopsy material. Additionally, NGS testing confirmed the absence of any significant genetic mutations associated with myeloid malignancies. The patient was subsequently admitted for further workup and management.

The patient underwent three cycles of CHOP chemotherapy and radiation therapy under a treatment protocol. Currently, the patient is doing well and is expected to follow up with his medical team in the near future.

Hospital Course:

The 41-year-old male patient was admitted to Gaffreé and Guinle University Hospital's immunology clinic with complaints of continuous epigastric burning pain without irradiation and diffuse abdominal pain. He also experienced intense hematochezia, daily hyperthermia with intermittent high fever, and over 10% body weight loss. The patient's physical examination revealed oral candidiasis, bleached mucous membranes, and cachexia. Blood counts showed thrombocytopenia, neutrophilia, lymphopenia, anemia, microcytosis, and anisocytosis. 

Diagnostic Testing:

The medical team ordered upper digestive endoscopy and colonoscopy which revealed the presence of ulcer with irregular and raised edges, fibrinonecrotic base, and mild antrum gastritis. Additionally, swollen, irregular, and fibrinous ulcers were found in the ileocecal valve, descending colon, and all other segments. The histopathological report confirmed the diagnosis of tuberculosis and cytomegalovirus coinfection of the gastrointestinal tract with Ziehl–Neelsen staining of acid-fast bacilli, CMV intracytoplasmic inclusions in Giemsa staining, and immunohistochemical study with positive labeling for CMV in cells with clear halos. 

Treatment:

The patient was prescribed prophylactic sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim and fluconazole for treatment of oral candidiasis. Following the diagnosis of tuberculosis and cytomegalovirus coinfection, treatment was initiated with an RIPE regime and ganciclovir. The patient demonstrated clinical and laboratory improvement, with a weight gain of 4 kg. After being discharged, the patient was referred to clinical follow-up for tuberculosis and HIV/HCV coinfection monitoring. At the end of the treatment for tuberculosis and 6 months after ART was restarted, the patient's viral load was <40 copies/dL and the CD4+ T-cell count was 356 cells/dL, and the patient was asymptomatic upon discharge.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not disclosed
Medical Record Number: Not disclosed
Date of Admission: Not disclosed
Date of Discharge: Not disclosed

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was a 45-year-old male with a history of panic disorder who presented to the clinic after gazing directly at the sun during a baseball game, which resulted in bilateral central scotoma and decreased vision. The initial examination showed a best corrected visual acuity of 0.8 in the right eye and 0.7 in the left eye, with slit lamp examinations revealing no abnormalities in the anterior segment. Fundus examinations showed a small, yellowish spot in the fovea bilaterally. OCT imaging demonstrated an elevated and blurred ellipsoid zone and loss of the interdigitation zone at the foveal area in both eyes, consistent with a diagnosis of solar retinopathy.

The patient was started on oral prednisolone therapy (30 mg per day) and underwent a posterior sub-Tenon triamcinolone injection in the right eye. Over the course of 12 weeks, the prednisolone therapy was tapered down. The patient showed improvement in visual acuity to 1.2 in the right eye and 1.0 in the left eye at 9 weeks after starting medication, which was sustained throughout the follow-up examinations at 12 and 21 weeks.

Fundus examinations performed at 12 weeks after initial treatment showed the small, yellowish spots to have diminished in both eyes. Sequential OCT imaging obtained during the follow-up examinations indicated improvement in the blurred ellipsoid zone, with nearly normal levels at 4 weeks in the right eye and 21 weeks in the left eye. However, loss of the interdigitation zone was observed after 12 weeks in the right eye and 21 weeks in the left eye.

Following the completion of the tapering of the prednisolone therapy regimen, the patient was discharged from the clinic with a recommendation for follow-up examinations in six months with an ophthalmologist.

Hospital Course Summary:
The 55-year-old female patient had a history of type 2 diabetes, hyperlipidemia, obesity, and depression. The patient was referred to an endocrinologist due to complaints of weight loss, diarrhea, and palpitations. The patient was found to have Graves' disease and was treated with radioactive iodine. Ten days after the treatment, the patient was admitted to a local hospital with symptoms of lightheadedness, abdominal pain, and bilious emesis. The patient was hypotensive, pale, bradycardic, and febrile. Upon arrival, the patient received intravenous infusions of dopamine, norepinephrine, fluid resuscitation, and underwent endotracheal intubation. The patient was transferred to another facility and was still hypotensive and bradycardic. Laboratory findings showed multiple abnormalities including anion gap metabolic acidosis, electrolyte imbalances, and elevated liver enzymes. Thyroid function testing showed thyroid storm and the patient was treated with propylthiouracil, potassium iodide, and hydrocortisone. The patient improved and was extubated 25 hours after the initial presentation. During her stay in the intensive care unit, the patient exhibited fever, tachycardia, and tremulousness which resolved after 22 hours. The patient was discharged in satisfactory condition on the fourth day of hospitalization on 100 mg of propylthiouracil orally every 8 hours. Outpatient testing days later demonstrated that her thyroid function tests were normal.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Facility: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 69-year-old Caucasian man with a history of schizophrenia who was admitted to our facility with catatonia and altered mental status. The patient had been transferred to our facility from a psychiatric hospital where he was on high-potency first-generation antipsychotics such as fluphenazine and haloperidol, which had worsened his agitation and behavioural dysregulation. He had subsequently been started on chlorpromazine prior to transfer to our facility.

Upon arrival at our facility, the patient was started on standard treatment, which involved discontinuation of antipsychotics and initiation of parenteral benzodiazepines such as lorazepam. During the hospital course, the patient exhibited fluctuating motor symptoms, which were accompanied by autonomic hyperactivity, diaphoresis, and droning vocalizations. The patient was also noted to have severe rigidity in both upper and lower extremities, waxy flexibility, posturing, negativism, automatic obedience, and the presence of mitgehen. An electroencephalogram performed during the hospitalization was notable only for increased beta waves, reflecting the high-dose benzodiazepines the patient was receiving at the time.

After the patient received three sessions of electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) without complications, his condition improved, and he was started on amantadine, which helped to manage his motor symptoms. The patient's urinary tract infection was also treated with antibiotics during the hospitalization, which resolved delirium.

Towards the end of the hospitalization, the patient was gradually lysed of catatonia and normalized lab values. The patient was given a three-week washout period before starting on clozapine, which was titrated without recurrence of NMS or catatonia. Subsequently, the patient was discharged back to the inpatient psychiatric unit after a month-long hospitalization.

Discharge Diagnosis:

1. Schizophrenia

Discharge Plan:

The patient has been advised to discontinue the use of any neuroleptics. The patient has also been recommended for long-term therapy and rehabilitation to manage his condition. Follow-up care has been scheduled with the patient's primary care physician. Further recommendations include a low-stimulus environment designed to suit the patient's needs. The patient is also advised to adhere to a supervised and guided plan of care from his healthcare provider. The patient has been given a detailed discharge summary with all the necessary instructions.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: _____________

Date of Admission: ______________

Date of Discharge: _____________

Admission Diagnosis: Postmenopausal vaginal bleeding, presence of localized anterior intrauterine mass with deep myometrial invasion.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 67-year-old female with a medical history of psoriasis and bipolar affective disorder, was admitted with postmenopausal vaginal bleeding. Physical examination found an 18-week sized uterus without palpable groin lymph nodes. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the pelvis and computed tomography (CT) with contrast of the abdomen and thorax demonstrated a localized anterior intrauterine mass with deep myometrial invasion. Histologically, the uterine curettage showed carcinosarcoma composed of mixed endometrioid adenocarcinoma, chondrosarcoma, and a hepatoid component, with the hepatoid tumor cells being positive for AFP, HepPar-1, and arginase-1. The patient underwent total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. Following the surgery, the patient was planned to receive adjuvant chemotherapy with Taxotere and Cyclophosphamide (TC). 

Discharge Diagnosis:
The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of carcinosarcoma with endometrioid adenocarcinoma, hepatoid adenocarcinoma, and sarcomatous components consisting of chondroid and spindle cell components. The patient exhibited histological recurrence and general metastases of malignancy.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was discharged with instructions to continue regular visits with her oncologist. In addition, she was provided instructions for calm surroundings, physical exercises, controlled edibles, and any medication as needed to keep her in a comfortable state.

Follow-up:
The patient succumbed 11 months after the surgery, subsequent chemotherapy, and post-chemotherapy treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 62 years
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Diagnosis: Retroperitoneal tumor (AML)

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 62-year-old Japanese female, was admitted to our surgical outpatient clinic due to a left abdominal mass. A clinical examination revealed a painless, child-head-sized tumor located in the left upper abdomen and abdominal CT demonstrated a child-head-sized mass with heterogeneous contrast. Subsequent MRI revealed a heterogeneously hyperintense mass on T1-weighted imaging, a relatively uniform and hyperintense mass on T2-weighted imaging, and a hypointense mass with an enhanced border on gadolinium-enhanced imaging. Laboratory data indicated slightly elevated levels of ACTH, but otherwise normal electrolytes and hematological markers.

The patient underwent tumor resection surgery and the multilobular yellow mass was found to weigh 1500 g with bleeding in places. Histopathological examination revealed that the tumor was composed of a proliferation of mature and variable-sized adipocytes admixed with aggregates of hematopoietic elements, associated with adrenal gland tissue in the peripheral region within the tumor. These findings were compatible with AML.

The patient had an uneventful recovery and was discharged on the 6th day after the operation. She has been followed up in our outpatient clinic without recurrence for approximately 12 years since undergoing the operation.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Retroperitoneal tumor (AML)

Treatment:
Tumor resection surgery

Condition on Discharge:
Stable with no recurrence

Follow-Up Recommendations:
The patient should continue to follow up with our outpatient clinic regularly to ensure that there is no recurrence of the AML.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Age: 41
Sex: Male
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis:
Left wrist volar dislocation with rotatory deformity of the proximal pole of the scaphoid

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department following a motorcycle accident with complaints of left wrist pain. Radiographs revealed a volar dislocation and rotatory deformity of the proximal pole of the scaphoid. Closed reduction failed and the patient elected to proceed with operative management. A dorsal approach was used to access the radiocarpal joint. The scapholunate joint was completely disrupted and the lunotriquetral joint was unstable as well. The scaphoid dislocation was reduced using K-wires with no complications. The patient was discharged in stable condition postoperatively.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Left wrist volar dislocation with rotatory deformity of the proximal pole of the scaphoid

Discharge Medications:
No medications prescribed at discharge

Follow-up:
The patient was brought back to the operating room eight weeks after surgery for hardware removal. He received occupational therapy and has regained his wrist range of motion. At five months post-injury, the patient has returned to work with no complaints and has resumed all desired activities.

Instructions:
Resume normal activities as tolerated. Follow up with primary care provider as needed.

Signed,
[REDACTED]

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient is a 56-year-old female with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with nephritis and hypothyroidism. She presented to the hospital with fever and chills after traveling to Jamaica. Blood cultures were positive for Salmonella enteritidis. She was treated with aztreonam and discharged on trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) for two weeks. She returned with fever, nausea, and dysuria. Blood and urine culture again grew Salmonella enteritidis. She was treated with aztreonam and discharged home with TMP/SMX for two weeks. She was then admitted for a lupus flare and was treated with steroids. She had incidental findings of pancreatitis. She was managed supportively and discharged to a rehabilitation facility. She was readmitted with fever, chills, nausea, and vomiting. Blood and stool culture grew Salmonella enteritidis. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen showed enlargement of the pancreatic head. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed an 8 cm mass below the level of the pancreas. She was given aztreonam and then switched to intravenous ceftriaxone. CT-guided drainage was performed with purulent fluid identified. Fluid culture grew Salmonella enteritidis. The patient was transitioned to an oral ciprofloxacin. The patient was followed up as an outpatient and was doing well.

Hospital Course:

This 30-year-old primipara arrived at our emergency department 5 hours after delivering a baby at a clinic due to postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) with severe tachycardia, hypotension, and agitated consciousness. The patient received transfusions of packed red blood cells, fresh frozen plasma, apheresis platelets, and whole blood. She was diagnosed with uterine atony and an ischemic uterus, which required an emergency subtotal hysterectomy. Intraoperative blood loss was reported as 800 mL, and the patient was shifted to the ICU after surgery. A liver abscess or focal necrosis due to ischemic change was discovered, and a liver transplantation was indicated. A living donor liver transplantation was performed 28 days after PPH. Unfortunately, the patient died of an intractable infection the day after an emergency colostomy and perianal debridement. 

Discharge:

The patient passed away due to an intractable infection after a living donor liver transplantation.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Mr./Mrs. X]
Medical Record Number: [XXXXX]

Hospital Course:
Mr./Mrs. X was admitted to our hospital with complaints of mild epigastric pain, regurgitation, and heartburn. He/She was diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and was prescribed a proton pump inhibitor. The patient had a history of liver hemangioma, hypertension and was found to have mild esophagitis and Barrett's esophagus with a polyp at the gastroesophageal junction on upper GI endoscopy. Infused computed tomography (CT) of the chest and abdomen revealed a large heterogeneously enhancing mass in the upper abdomen, which was highly suggestive of GIST and originated from the gastric antrum. The patient underwent a wedge resection of the gastric mass and transgastric submucosal resection of the GEJ polyp with negative margins. Histopathological examination confirmed a GEJ polyp with invasive adenocarcinoma involving the superficial submucosa of the polypoid lesion and a high-grade epithelioid GIST tumor with negative margins.

Hospital Course Summary:
Mr./Mrs. X was admitted to our hospital with complaints of mild epigastric pain, regurgitation, and heartburn. He/She was diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and was prescribed a proton pump inhibitor. The patient had a history of liver hemangioma, hypertension and was found to have mild esophagitis and Barrett's esophagus with a polyp at the gastroesophageal junction on upper GI endoscopy. Infused computed tomography (CT) of the chest and abdomen revealed a large heterogeneously enhancing mass in the upper abdomen, which was highly suggestive of GIST and originated from the gastric antrum. The patient underwent a successful wedge resection of the gastric mass and transgastric submucosal resection of the GEJ polyp with negative margins. Histopathological examination confirmed a GEJ polyp with invasive adenocarcinoma involving the superficial submucosa of the polypoid lesion and a high-grade epithelioid GIST tumor with negative margins. The patient had a smooth postoperative course and was discharged home in a stable condition. He/She was started on adjuvant imatinib treatment, along with endoscopic surveillance every six months and proton pump inhibitors.

Instructions: 
The patient should be scheduled for follow-up care with the gastroenterologist for endoscopic surveillance. He/She should continue the prescribed treatment and medications as per the discharge instructions. If the patient experiences any changes in symptoms or has any concerns, he/she should report back to the hospital immediately.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information: A 25-year-old female with a singleton pregnancy, G3 P0020, at 36 3/7 weeks of gestational age.

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted with acute-onset, severe back pain and fever. She had a significant prenatal history of left antecubital abscesses requiring drainage, and was diagnosed with MRSA. Initial blood cultures were positive for MRSA, and treatment with vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam was initiated. MRI revealed an epidural abscess and a collection in the left psoas muscle. Cesarean delivery was performed followed by laminectomy and decompression of the epidural abscess. Neonate was treated for suspected sepsis. Repeat MRI revealed residual abscess and cord compression, and re-exploration and laminectomy were performed. Later in her clinical course, the patient admitted to previous illicit drug use but denied current use.

Summary: The patient was admitted with acute-onset, severe back pain and fever. She had a significant prenatal history of left antecubital abscesses requiring drainage with a diagnosis of MRSA. Treatment with vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam was initiated. Cesarean delivery was performed followed by laminectomy and decompression of the epidural abscess. Repeat MRI revealed residual abscess and cord compression, and re-exploration and laminectomy were performed. Later in her clinical course, the patient admitted to previous illicit drug use but denied current use.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Gender: Female
DOB: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 32-year-old female who presented with a 2-day history of a diffuse rash. On admission, she was febrile, tachycardic, and hypotensive. The patient had a medical history significant for schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and hepatitis C antibody positive. She was started on clozapine 10 days prior to admission. Pertinent admission labs included leukocytosis, eosinophilia, and elevated liver enzymes. Imaging studies showed small left-sided pleural effusion, minimal bilateral atelectasis, and cholelithiasis. Blood cultures were initially positive for staphylococcus coagulase negative, but it was later determined to be a contaminant. The patient was started on broad-spectrum antibiotics, which were later discontinued due to no further concern for infectious etiology.

Differential Diagnosis and Treatment:
There was a concern for infectious etiology on admission, and antibiotics were started as a prophylactic measure. However, further investigation ruled out any infectious etiology. Dermatology was consulted and agreed that this was DRESS syndrome. Methylprednisone IV 125 mg three times daily was started along with clobetasol twice a day. After starting prednisone, fever and white blood cell count improved. Eosinophils trended back down to normal limits and liver enzymes started trending down. The patient was discharged on an oral prednisone taper for 12 days.

Outcome:
Outpatient follow-up did not show any further eosinophilia, white blood cell elevation, or elevated liver enzymes. The rash improved and disintegrated. The patient was discharged with instructions to continue the prednisone taper and follow up with her primary care physician.

Impression:
The patient was diagnosed with DRESS syndrome based on the classic signs of eosinophilia, skin rash, lymphadenopathy, and elevated liver enzymes. The treatment plan included a 12-day oral prednisone taper. The patient's follow-up did not show any further complications.

Hospital Course:
The 23-year-old woman presented with progressive headache, nausea, and vomiting for 1 week. Imaging revealed an enhanced brain tumor with necrotic cystic change located at the left temporal lobe with upward extension to the left basal ganglion and periventricular region, causing perifocal edema and midline shift. The patient underwent an emergent craniectomy for tumor removal in December 2006. 

Diagnosis:
The pathology revealed pleomorphic, hyperchromatic cells with glassy, astrocytic cytoplasm, as well as hypercellularity, microvascular proliferation, and necrosis. These findings confirmed the diagnosis of classic GBM.

Treatment:
The patient underwent radiotherapy 1 month later and followed by chemotherapy with temozolomide for 6 months. She showed improvement in performance status and clinical condition; however, follow-up imaging in June and October 2014 revealed a new enhanced nodular lesion that required surgical removal.

Post-op Findings:
The pathology report showed features of the oligodendroglial component. The neoplastic cells expressed isocitrate dehydrogenase 1 (IDH1), p53, and O6-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) as revealed by immunostaining. During her follow-ups, signs of increased intracranial pressure were noted in May 2015, leading to the third debulking surgery. The third pathology revealed both GBM- and PNET-like components, with the PNET-like component exhibiting positivity for synaptophysin and CD56 and focal weak positivity for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP).

Outcome:
One month post-surgery, the patient's condition rapidly deteriorated, and she was referred to hospice care. She passed away with a total 9-year survival since diagnosis.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The 4-year-old male patient was admitted to the pediatric department due to newly occurred hypertension, which was a result of his right heminephrectomy of neuroblastoma. Computed tomography angiography (CTA) scan revealed renal artery severe stenosis and right kidney atrophy. Due to refractory hypertension, he underwent Transcatheter Arterial Embolization of the right renal artery four days ago. Subsequently, the patient was stable until five hours before admission to the ICU when he developed anxiety, became breathless, and spitted frothy sputum. The patient suffered an episode of cardiac arrest, which was followed by intubation and 20 minutes of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), leading to restoration of spontaneous circulation (ROSC). 

Following CPR, the patient was treated with cortisone as transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) was suspected. After treatment, the patient was transferred to the ICU for respiratory support and further treatment. On admission, the patient had high heart rate and blood pressure. A lot of flesh-colored aqueous sputum was identified from the endotracheal tube. The tidal volume was lower than normal on invasive ventilation with PI and PEEP. Due to the stiff lung, manual ventilation with balloon and sputum suction were performed constantly for one hour. The arterial blood analysis showed low pH level, low PO2, low PCO2, high lactate, and high BE. The FiO2 was 100%, and there was no urine output in the first hour.

Course in Hospital:
Given the patient's medical condition, critical care ultrasound using the 7-step approach workflow was performed to help diagnose the underlying issue. The results of the ultrasound showed that the patient required further support and monitoring. After this diagnosis, continued care was given for the duration of the patient's hospital stay.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was stabilized after receiving the necessary critical care support and treatment. Consequently, he was discharged from the hospital in stable condition.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was referred for follow-up care and monitoring to ensure that he continued to recover from his critical condition.

Overall, the patient's hospital admission and treatment provided necessary care and support to address his condition, leading to a positive outcome and discharge from the hospital.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission:

A 61-year-old male patient was admitted to the liver surgery department due to the discovery of a liver mass for 6 days. The initial alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) level was 1009 ng/ml, and liver contrast CT scan indicated hepatic cell cancer in the right lobe. The patient underwent an ALTPS surgery for the same.

Hospital Course:

In the postoperative days, the patient developed fever and abdominal pain and eventually experienced shock followed by hypoxia. He was intubated and transferred to the ICU where further examinations revealed WBC 0.63×109/L, PLT 7×109/L and PCT 45.88 ng/ml in addition to the presence of ascites. Doctors treated him with fluid resuscitation and norepinephrine (1.8 mcg/Kg.min) and managed the pathological fluid accumulation by culturing and draining the ascites which revealed the presence of Escherichia coli. The patient was placed on Imipenem and Vancomycin for treatment and subsequently underwent a second surgery to remove the right half of his liver as signs of necrosis were found in the CT scan. Over the next three days, he experienced significant improvements with no fever, reduced norepinephrine (0.4 mcg/Kg.min), and maintained urine output. However, on the 5th day, the patient experienced recurrent fever (>38.8°C), an increase in the norepinephrine to 2.0 mcg/Kg.min, and worsening of liver function, coagulation, and oxygenation. An arterial blood gas test showed pH 6.988, PaO2/FIO2 154, PaCO2 147.7mmHg, BE -19 mmol/L, and lactate 9.7 mmol/L. A critical care ultrasound was ordered to evaluate the patient's condition.

Discharge:

The patient has had a long hospital course marked by significant challenges, which he has overcome with the help of his medical team. After 15 days of hospitalization, he has been discharged in a stable condition.

Diagnosis, Management, and Outcome:

The patient was diagnosed with hepatic cell cancer with subsequent surgeries to remove his liver's right half and control ascites. He also contracted Escherichia coli during his hospitalization, which was managed with antibiotics, and recurrent fever. The critical care ultrasound helped evaluate and manage his condition as it unfolded. After 15 days of hospitalization, the patient's condition improved, and he has made a stable recovery.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the outpatient clinic at the Department of Nephrology due to treatment-resistant hypertension, rapidly developing edema, and overt proteinuria. The patient had previously been followed up at the outpatient clinic at the Department of Endocrinology for poorly controlled type 1 diabetes with microvascular complications, including retinopathy and albuminuria. The patient's plasma creatinine levels had been within normal range, and hypertension was well-controlled using ACE inhibitors. However, blood pressure had increased progressively, accompanied by edema. Despite increasing doses and numbers of antihypertensive agents and diuretics, blood pressure continued to be severely elevated, combined with progressive fluid overload and proteinuria. Upon referral to the Department of Nephrology, a renography revealed no perfusion of the right kidney, and ultrasound confirmed the presence of a rudimentary right kidney. The patient was diagnosed with NS assumed to be related to diabetes.

Treatment and Outcome:

A loop diuretic was initiated to reduce blood pressure, but there was no effect on edema and blood pressure. Furosemide was then stepped up to 160 mg/day with minimal results. To address this, the ENaC blocker amiloride was initiated, resulting in the effective resolution of edema, concomitant weight loss of 7 kg, and the reduction of blood pressure. The patient was immediately hospitalized for cardiac monitoring and treatment of hyperkalemia. Amiloride and spironolactone were both discontinued. At follow-up, a combination-drug containing 2.5 mg amiloride and 25 mg hydrochlorthiazide was successfully reinitiated due to increased blood pressure and edema. At the last visit to the outpatient clinic, the patient received several antihypertensive/diuretic drugs and maintained stable body weight.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 67 years
Sex: Male

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted following a fixed oral prosthesis surgery. He had a past medical history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Amiodarone and Acenocumarol were prescribed to manage the condition. The implantation procedure was performed without any complications under local anesthesia. Acenocumarol was discontinued two days prior to surgery and switched to LMW heparin. The patient was discharged with antibiotic therapy and instructed to restart oral anticoagulant therapy after two days.

Forty-eight hours after the procedure, the patient presented with hiccup, which failed to resolve. The patient was prescribed Baclofen, Metoclopramide and Bromazepam, but no significant improvement was observed. The patient arrived at the emergency department three days later, but no abnormalities were found in the ENT, neurological examinations, blood tests or brain CT scan. Chlorpromazine 25 mg b.i.d. was administered for two weeks, and the patient was advised to schedule a brain MR scan and chest imaging, which produced negative results. The hiccup persisted despite removal of the stitches seven days after the surgery, resulting in significant distress and sleep deprivation. Fortunately, it spontaneously ceased after 18 days. No relapses or neurological symptoms were reported.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with persistent hiccup following fixed oral prosthesis surgery, which spontaneously resolved after 18 days.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient is advised to follow up with his healthcare provider for routine care.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 32-year-old Caucasian woman, was admitted to the West Virginia University Hospital Emergency Department via Emergency Medical Services after presenting with neck pain, diaphoresis, and subsequent cardiac and respiratory arrest following neck manipulation by a chiropractor. Upon arrival, the patient was intubated and a CT stroke protocol was performed revealing dissection of bilateral severe distal cervical vertebral arteries with acute thrombotic emboli seen in the left cervical vertebral artery. Endovascular intervention was performed using a Penumbra 5 Max ACE distal aspiration catheter and Trevo 4 mm x 30 mm stent retriever, which demonstrated recanalization of the basilar apex and proximal posterior cerebral arteries. Following endovascular therapy, the patient underwent an MRI Brain that confirmed extensive areas of restricted diffusion accompanied by perfusion abnormalities consistent with acute infarction of the posterior circulation, specifically within the bilateral cerebellar hemispheres, right medulla, pons bilaterally, midbrain, thalami, and left occipital lobe. The following day, additional CT Brain imaging was acquired and demonstrated an elevation of intracranial pressure with hydrocephalus, worsening of cerebral edema diffusely, hemorrhagic transformation of the left occipital lobe, continued infarct evolution within the posterior circulation, and cerebellar tonsillar herniation.

Diagnosis:

Acute infarction of the posterior circulation.

Hospital Course:

The patient received endovascular therapy using a Penumbra 5 Max ACE distal aspiration catheter and Trevo 4 mm x 30 mm stent retriever with recanalization achieved of the basilar apex and proximal posterior cerebral arteries. Following therapy, the patient was immediately transported for MRI Brain with and without contrast, which confirmed extensive areas of restricted diffusion accompanied by perfusion abnormalities consistent with acute infarction of the posterior circulation, specifically within the bilateral cerebellar hemispheres, right medulla, pons bilaterally, midbrain, thalami, and left occipital lobe. The patient's hospital course was complicated by an elevation of intracranial pressure with hydrocephalus, worsening of cerebral edema diffusely, hemorrhagic transformation of the left occipital lobe, continued infarct evolution within the posterior circulation, and cerebellar tonsillar herniation.

Follow-up:

The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit for further management.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A
Discharge Diagnosis: N/A

Hospital Course:

This patient, a 51-year-old woman with a history of morbid obesity, obstructive sleep apnea, and diabetes, presented to the urgent care clinic with a chronic headache that persisted for almost a year. A CT scan of the head revealed no abnormalities, and other potential causes of the headache were ruled out through laboratory tests and imaging. The patient reported a history of head trauma one year prior to symptom onset, but there was no loss of consciousness, and the headache was thought to be related to post-concussion syndrome.

Over the course of the year, the patient visited the emergency department several times with severe headaches, but no underlying cause was identified. The headache was rated as 7/10, intermittent, non-radiating, and throbbing, with frontal location. Treatment with NSAIDs, acetaminophen, tramadol, and Fiorecet had been ineffective.

Upon reconciliation of the patient's medications, it was found that she had been switched from metformin to metformin-sitagliptin almost a year prior to the onset of symptom. Given the temporal association of the medication change and symptom presentation, sitagliptin was discontinued as a trial treatment, and the patient was switched back to metformin. Two days after discontinuation of sitagliptin, the patient reported resolution of her headache.

The patient was subsequently discharged with instructions to follow up with her primary care provider and to report any recurrent symptoms.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 57
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with a worsening, diffuse, bullous eruption that started four weeks prior and was distributed mainly on her lower extremities. Initial treatment by her primary care physician with doxycycline and sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim was unsuccessful. On admission, the patient presented with diffuse and erythematous tense bullae ranging from 1.5 to 2 centimeters in diameter on her face, neck, back, chest, abdomen, and extremities. Some of the lesions were pruritic and painful. The patient was afebrile and without leukocytosis, but C-reactive protein was elevated at 97.8 mg/L.

DIAGNOSIS AND TREATMENT:
An initial punch biopsy was performed and returned negative for a definitive diagnosis. A repeat punch biopsy four days later showed a subepidermal blister with eosinophils and neutrophils. Direct immunofluorescence (DIF) of the skin revealed the linear deposition of immunoglobulin G (IgG) and complement C3 along the dermo-epidermal junction. The patient was diagnosed with bullous pemphigoid and was treated with prednisone 60 mg daily. The patient responded well with a decreased number of bullae, along with an improvement of the erythema and pruritus. The patient's medication regimen included oral sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim 160 mg daily for prophylaxis of Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia. The patient was referred to a dermatologist to discuss adding a steroid-sparing agent such as methotrexate or azathioprine.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:
The patient was discharged in satisfactory condition with a tapering regimen of prednisone 60-40-20 mg for one month per dose. Follow-up care was arranged with the patient's primary care physician and dermatologist, and the patient was advised to seek medical attention if the condition worsens or any new symptoms arise.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
Bullous pemphigoid

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
Oral sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim 160 mg daily for prophylaxis of Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia.

FOLLOW-UP INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient was advised to continue the prescribed medication regimen and to follow up with her primary care physician and dermatologist as directed. The patient was also instructed to seek medical attention if the condition worsens or any new symptoms arise.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 49
Sex: Male
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
