The patient was admitted with longstanding back and left leg pain that was resistant to pain management. He suffered a fall with a left wrist fracture and developed shortness of breath, which led to an emergency room visit. He was diagnosed with two right retroperitoneal masses, which were confirmed to be a benign nerve sheath tumor. A genetic evaluation revealed a large contiguous deletion of chromosome 9p21.3, extending beyond the cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 2A (CDKN2A) gene and spanning approximately 25 genes. The patient had a family history of multiple melanomas and other malignancies and was monitored for three years, during which the retroperitoneal masses remained stable. However, he developed progressive back and radicular abdominal pain, and the right prevertebral and right paraspinal lesions continued to grow. Given the patient’s condition and predisposition to malignancy, he was referred to interventional radiology for image-guided RFA. Six weeks after the procedure, there was a decrease in the size of the right prevertebral and right paraspinal lesions. The patient reported an improvement in pain and no longer required methadone for pain control. Follow-up imaging four years later showed stable regression of the anterior prevertebral lesion and further decrease in the size of the posterior paraspinal lesion.

Diagnosis/Conditions:
-Longstanding back and left leg pain
-Left wrist fracture
-Shortness of breath
-Two right retroperitoneal masses
-Benign nerve sheath tumor
-Contiguous deletion of chromosome 9p21.3 extending beyond the CDKN2A gene
-Multiple melanomas and other malignancies
-High HgA1C (11.0)
-Neuropathy
-Renal insufficiency
-Two prior cerebral vascular accidents (CVA)
-Mild residual left hemiparesis
-Peripheral vascular disease involving iliac stenting
-Tobacco abuse
-Obesity

Treatment:
-Percutaneous biopsy of the retroperitoneal masses
-Excision of the left sciatic tumor
-Image-guided RFA
-Methadone for pain control

Condition at Discharge:
The patient’s condition has improved since the procedure, and he has reported less pain. Follow-up imaging showed stable regression of the anterior prevertebral lesion and further decrease in the size of the posterior paraspinal lesion.

Follow-up Care:
The patient should continue to follow up with his primary care physician and undergo regular imaging to monitor the progression or recurrence of the retroperitoneal masses.

Signed,
[REDACTED]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Hospital Identification Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Medical History:
The patient was a 19-year-old male with no significant medical history.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with complaints of palpitations, chest pain, and shortness of breath, which started during his work on a Christmas tree farm. The patient reported a history of similar episodes for the last six years, usually triggered with mild exertion. He noticed increased frequency and severity of symptoms for the last six months, occurring at least twice per week. The patient also reported feeling more fatigued and tired for the last few months. On admission, vitals were normal, and the patient was anxious and appeared to be in distress. A chest X-ray showed a right perihilar mass of 3.1 x 3.4 cm, and a computed tomography scan of the chest revealed stippled-type calcified mediastinal lymphadenopathy of 1.6 cm x 2.1 cm and a right hilar mass of 3.8 x 4.8 cm.

Diagnostic Results:
The patient had a bronchoscopy with fine needle aspiration (FNA) of mediastinal mass and lymph nodes, which came back negative for malignancy. However, histological examination showed predominant necrosis with rare benign lymphoid tissue. Urine histoplasma antigen and serum Aspergillus galactomannan antigens were negative. The patient had a mediastinoscopy with lymph node biopsy, which showed an inflammatory granulomatous process. Pathology report showed lymphoid tissue with necrotizing granulomatous inflammation, and positive fungal stain and morphology consistent with Histoplasma species. Fungal and acid-fast bacilli (AFB) cultures remained negative.

Discharge Condition:
The patient experienced chest discomfort and dyspnea after the bronchoscopy but improved after regular infectious disease clinic follow-up. The patient was started on oral itraconazole, which had to be discontinued due to diffuse rash after two weeks of treatment. The patient was then switched to oral fluconazole, which he tolerated without any problems.

Discharge Diagnoses:
The patient was diagnosed with inflammatory granulomatous process, with positive fungal stain and morphology consistent with Histoplasma species.

Discharge Medications:
The patient was prescribed oral fluconazole 400 mg once daily at the time of discharge.

Instructions:
The patient was advised to follow up with their primary care physician and infectious disease specialist for further monitoring and management of the inflammatory granulomatous process. The patient was also advised to seek medical attention if they develop any new symptoms or if their symptoms worsen.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Hospital Name: [Redacted]
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Admission Diagnosis: Enlarging rhinophyma, glabellar and forehead lesions

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 69-year-old male, was admitted to our hospital with the chief complaints of a growing mass on his nose, concomitant nasal airway obstruction, visual field impairment, and an inability to wear glasses. Upon physical examination, the patient was found to have a rhinophyma measuring 6.7 centimeters in diameter, with nodular tumors, telangiectasia, and sebum inspissation. The glabellar lesion measured 3.0 cm in diameter and appeared as a discrete erythematous tumor with central ulceration and necrosis, suggesting non-rhinophymatous lesion and raising suspicion for malignancy. An additional 1.5 cm lesion of the right forehead region appeared as a round, telangiectatic nodule with a waxy border. A preoperative diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma for this separate lesion was confirmed by the pathological report. Surgery was performed on the nasal lesions, and the rhinophyma was excised and debulked, then closed with adjacent cheek flaps, while the glabellar lesion was treated with wide local excision and closed with forehead flaps. Frozen section analysis of the glabellar specimen revealed a diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. 

Postoperatively, the patient was closely monitored, and after three weeks, the basal cell carcinoma of the right forehead was removed, and closure was accomplished with double opposing V-Y advancement flaps. The final pathology report confirmed the diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) with BCL6 positivity. The patient was referred to an oncologist for further treatment, and subsequent oncological workup revealed several positive lymph nodes in the anterior cervical chain. One such node was biopsied by a general surgeon and was found to be positive for diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Intensive combination chemotherapy, including Rituxan®, Cytoxan®, Oncovin®, Adriamycin®, and prednisone, was initiated.

Discharge Diagnosis:
- Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) with BCL6 positivity

Discharge Condition:
The patient's condition improved during hospitalization, and the patient was discharged with instructions to continue oncological treatment with an oncologist. 

Discharge Medications:
None

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to continue oncological treatment as recommended by an oncologist and scheduled for a follow-up visit. The patient was also advised to follow a balanced and low-sodium diet and to avoid any physical exertion until further notice. 

Follow-up:
The patient is scheduled for a follow-up visit with the oncologist.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 64-year-old African American female with a past medical history of insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, prior history of stroke, hypothyroidism, and family history of coronary artery disease.

Admission Date: [DATE]

Discharge Date: [DATE]

Admission Diagnosis: Unstable angina

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of typical chest pain. On admission, the physical examination and initial electrocardiogram were unremarkable, and cardiac enzymes were negative. However, the patient was started on aspirin, statin, and nitroglycerin for the chest pain.

Cardiology was consulted, and they decided to do left heart catheterization and echocardiography to evaluate the patient's condition. The echocardiogram showed a normal ejection fraction with no wall motion abnormalities. Left heart catheterization showed anomalous coronaries, with all three coronaries arising from the right coronary cusp with a separate ostium. The left anterior descending artery had an anomalous origin with a separate ostium from the right coronary cusp. There was focal moderate to severe 70%-80% disease in the mid vessel. The left circumflex artery had an anomalous origin with a separate ostium from the right coronary cusp, and mild luminal irregularities were present. The right coronary artery was a large dominant vessel with mild luminal irregularities.

The patient received medical management to treat the chest pain and was monitored during the hospital stay. The patient's health gradually improved, and the patient was discharged from the hospital.

Discharge Condition:

The patient's chest pain decreased in severity and was stable at discharge. The patient was advised to follow up with a cardiologist, take prescribed medications, and maintain a healthy lifestyle.

Follow-Up Recommendations:

The patient was advised to follow up with a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of the anomalous coronaries and chest pain. The patient was instructed to take prescribed medications appropriately, including aspirin, statin, and nitroglycerin, maintain a healthy diet, exercise regularly, and avoid smoking. The patient was also advised to comply with regular follow-up appointments with the primary care provider for monitoring of diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia.

Discharge Medications:

[N/A]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Diagnosis: Desmoplastic/Nodular Medulloblastoma with SHH Activation and IDH1 R132C Mutation

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with headache, nausea, and vomiting, and was diagnosed with a left cerebellar expansive lesion. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain and spinal cord revealed no metastasis, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examination showed no evidence of dissemination. The patient underwent complete surgical resection and was confirmed to have a desmoplastic/nodular medulloblastoma (MB) with SHH activation and IDH1 R132C mutation through histopathological analysis, next generation sequencing, and methylation array. The patient was started on the HIT-SIOP PNET 4 protocol for treatment, receiving cranio-spinal radiation therapy and adjuvant chemotherapy without any major life-threatening adverse events or dose limiting toxicities. To date, the patient is in complete remission more than 2 years since diagnosis.

Summary:
This is a 13-year-old patient with a history of headache, nausea, and vomiting, who was diagnosed with a left cerebellar expansive lesion. The patient underwent complete surgical resection and was confirmed to have a desmoplastic/nodular MB with SHH activation and IDH1 R132C mutation with no evidence of metastasis. Treatment was initiated with the HIT-SIOP PNET 4 protocol, including cranio-spinal radiation therapy and adjuvant chemotherapy, which was well tolerated. The patient is currently in complete remission.

Hospital Course:

A 10-year-old male was admitted to the endocrinology clinic due to obesity, rapid weight gain, and growth deceleration. The patient had previously been tall for his age, but had recently experienced a decrease in height to well below average. The patient's weight was consistently high and had recently increased significantly. Additionally, the patient's medical history was unremarkable. The patient's mother reported the patient had previously displayed hyperactive behavior, but that this had decreased over time. No other medical or personal information was noted in the patient's medical records.

Physical Examination:

On physical examination, the patient appeared well with a normal affect. The patient's thyroid was palpable and smooth with no lymphadenopathy. The patient's chest, heart, abdomen, genitalia, and skin were all normal. The patient's Tanner stage 1 genital development and 3 cc testes were noted.

Diagnosis:

Based on the patient's medical history and physical examination, the patient was diagnosed with extreme obesity.

Follow-Up:

The patient was referred for further follow-up and treatment with an endocrinologist. No other follow-up was noted in the patient's medical records.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Patient Name: [Name]
Date of Birth: [DOB]
Gender: [Gender]
Medical Record Number: [MRN]

Clinical Presentation:
The patient presented with tooth discoloration, diastema, unsatisfactory esthetics and slight tooth sensitivity. Clinical examination showed insufficient enamel thickness with discolored anterior and posterior teeth. The panoramic radiography showed thin enamel that could not be distinguished from the underlying dentin. The patient also presented with short crowns, multiple diastema, occlusal wear, poor contact points and dental caries. Root length and form were normal. Pulp chambers were regular in size. Oral hygiene was acceptable with no signs of gingivitis.

Medical History:
The patient reported no relevant medical history. The patient's family was not affected by any inherited disorders. A renal ultrasound scan was normal with no evidence of nephrocalcinosis. Laboratory findings, including serum electrolytes, calcium, phosphate, urea, creatinine, alkaline phosphatase and parathormone levels, were all normal.

SEM and Histologic Analysis:
SEM analysis of the extracted maxillary and mandibular left third molar teeth showed an insufficient enamel layer. Histological findings revealed that dentin structure was intact with no irregularities in tubular structure.

Treatment:
Diagnostic casts were attached on a semi-adjustable articulator in centric occlusion, and the occlusal vertical dimension was increased. The patient underwent ostectomy and gingivectomy procedures to address insufficient crown length and gingival asymmetry. The impressions for provisional casts were made and provisional crowns were fabricated and assessed in terms of esthetics and phonetics. Definitive impressions were then made, and a metal alloy-ceramic fixed partial denture was created for the posterior regions, with zirconia ceramic crowns used for the anterior regions in both upper and lower jaws. The restorations were cemented with appropriate cement. A maxillary protective occlusal splint was also manufactured for the patient to prevent chipping or fracture due to bruxism.

Follow-up:
The patient was asymptomatic during the 1, 2, and 3 month checkups following the provisional crowning procedure. The criteria for the success of the increased vertical dimension were met, with the absence of pain, no sensitivity in facial and masticatory muscles, phonetic and swallowing satisfaction. Dental hygiene instructions were given to the patient.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in a stable condition with no reported clinical issues or concerns.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient was advised to continue practicing proper oral hygiene practices and attend regular dental check-ups for further monitoring.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A		Admission Date: March 2017
Patient Age: 20		Discharge Date: N/A
Gender: Female		Length of Stay: N/A


Hospital Course:

A 20-year-old virgin female patient was referred to the hospital in March 2017 due to chronic pelvic pain and severe menstrual cycle pain with a VNRS of 9 lasting for almost a year. The patient had no history of dyschezia, pain during or post-urination, or other symptoms related to diaphragmatic endometriosis.

The patient was diagnosed with endometriosis involving the anterior and posterior cul-de-sac, both pelvic side walls, both ovaries, and sigmoid colon following laparoscopy. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was conducted to exclude left mass from adenocarcinoma, while the results revealed normal upper abdominal organs, lungs, and endometrium in both adnexae.

During laparoscopy, the patient underwent pelvic Die correction, and a 2-cm endometriotic nodule attached to the rectovaginal septum was shaved. There was no evidence of endometriosis in the ureters.

Endoscopic fulguration was performed using bipolar energy for endometriotic lesions of the diaphragm when the patient was placed in a reverse Trendelenburg position. There were five to six areas of superficial endometriosis on the anterior and center of the right hemi-diaphragm, but the left hemi-diaphragm was intact.

Anatomy of pelvis was restored, and the patient was discharged in a stable condition.

Procedures:

1. Laparoscopy
2. Fulguration of endometriotic lesions on the diaphragm using bipolar energy
3. Pelvic Die correction

Diagnoses:

1. Endometriosis involving anterior and posterior cul-de-sac, both pelvic side walls, both ovaries, and sigmoid colon


Hospital Course Summary:
The 20-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital due to chronic pelvic pain, and severe menstrual cycle pain. The patient underwent laparoscopy, pelvic Die correction, and endoscopic fulguration to correct the diagnosis of endometriosis involving the anterior and posterior cul-de-sac, both pelvic side walls, both ovaries, and sigmoid colon. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Sex: Male
Age: 50

Summary:
This 50-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital with RUE pain and swelling ten days after receiving his first cycle of R-CHOP through a peripheral IV in the right hand. The patient's medical history included HIV, ESRD on PD, and HTN. Upon examination, the patient was found to have mildly tender, deeply hyperpigmented veins and edema of the dorsum of the right hand without warmth or erythema. An ultrasound was performed to rule out DVT, and the patient was diagnosed with serpentine supravenous hyperpigmentation (SSH). The patient was discharged home with supportive care on hospital day 2.

Follow-Up:
The patient visited the office four months later and reported improvement in the original SSH in his right arm. However, he developed new SSH in his left arm where he was currently receiving his chemotherapy infusions. There was no report of pain or discomfort from the darkened veins.

Conclusion:
The patient's SSH was diagnosed and managed during his hospital stay. The patient was discharged home with support care and was able to follow up in the office four months later. No significant changes were reported during the follow-up visit.

Discharge Summary:
 
Patient Name: Not specified 
Age: 20
Gender: Female
 
Admission Date: Not specified
Discharge Date: Not specified
 
Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented with a complaint of lower incisors protruding out of the mouth, which was caused by Class III skeletal pattern and the presence of two lower supernumerary incisors. The patient exhibited a mandibular asymmetry and concave facial profile. The aesthetic of the smile was impaired due to the anterior crossbite. The patient was diagnosed with Angle Class I malocclusion, moderate anterior crowding of the mandibular arch, and anterior contraction of the maxillary arch on the right side. The patient had inferior excess as per Bolton's analysis. Radiographs showed two fully erupted supernumerary incisors and light horizontal bone loss in the lower arch. Cephalometry confirmed the Class III skeletal pattern with horizontal growth pattern and compensatory inclinations of the incisors, contributing to unfavorable tegumentary relationship that impaired the patient's facial aesthetics. 
 
The patient was treated for the malocclusion and the anterior crossbite. The treatment plan was not specified. The patient had good oral health.
 
The patient was discharged in good health and appropriate follow-up care was recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with recurrent headache, blurred vision, and progressive memory loss. The initial headache started 5 years before admission, which progressively worsened over time. A year and a half before admission, she developed blurred vision. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed hydrocephalus. Repeated lumbar punctures showed increased pressure, elevated protein and pleocytosis. Two months before admission, she developed progressive memory loss. Brain computed tomography (CT) scan showed scattered parenchymal calcified lesions in her brain. Further investigation with MRI revealed the presence of numerous cystic lesions and diffuse T2-weighted hyperintensity in the juxta-ventricular white matter, together with enhancement of the meninges, especially the basal meninges. CSF cytology showed increased eosinophils, and NGS of CSF identified T. solium DNA sequences. Plain x-rays showed scattered “cigar-shaped” calcified lesions in the legs. With this knowledge of her medical condition, she was diagnosed with NCC (basal subarachnoid NCC and parenchymal NCC with calcified cysts).

Hospital Course Summary:
A 53-year-old woman presented with a recurrent headache, blurred vision, and progressive memory loss. She had a history of recurrent grand mal seizures about 20 years ago. During admission, a head CT scan showed scattered parenchymal calcified lesions in the right frontal lobe, right parietal lobe, right thalamus, left temporal lobe, left occipital lobe, and bilateral basal ganglia area. Brain MRI showed hydrocephalus and diffuse T2-weighted hyperintensity in the juxta-ventricular white matter, together with enhancement of the meninges, especially the basal meninges, and multiple cystic lesions in the prepontine cistern, ambient cistern, and suprasellar cistern. After further investigation, CSF cytology revealed increased eosinophils, and NGS of CSF identified T. solium DNA sequences. Plain x-rays showed scattered “cigar-shaped” calcified lesions in the legs.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
The diagnosis was NCC (basal subarachnoid NCC and parenchymal NCC with calcified cysts). The patient was treated with albendazole and dexamethasone and underwent an endoscopic third ventriculostomy (ETV) because of severe hydrocephalus. After treatment, her symptoms, neuroimaging and CSF findings improved markedly.

Follow-up Recommendations:
The patient is recommended for follow-up care with her primary care physician for continued monitoring to ensure complete resolution of her symptoms.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Male
Age: 57 years
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Admission Details:
Date of admission: [Redacted]
Admission Diagnosis: Possible tuberculous meningitis
Antibiotic Therapy: Empirical anti-tuberculous treatment

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of paroxysmal blurred vision, which he had been experiencing for two months. Upon admission, he underwent lumbar puncture, which showed increased opening pressure, pleocytosis, elevated protein level, and reduced glucose level. CSF cytology showed lymphocytic inflammation. Cryptococcus antigen test and Mycobacterium PCR of the CSF were negative. He was initially diagnosed with possible tuberculous meningitis, and empirical anti-tuberculous therapy was initiated.

However, he was readmitted one month later when his symptoms persisted. A repeat lumbar puncture and NGS of CSF were performed, which yielded negative results. Serum and CSF samples, however, were positive for C. cellulosae IgG, and Head CT revealed a single calcified lesion in the left frontal lobe. Brain MRI showed no obvious abnormalities, including hydrocephalus. He was diagnosed with parenchymal NCC (calcified cyst) and possibly extraparenchymal NCC or spinal NCC without radiological evidence.

Albendazole and dexamethasone treatment was started, but the patient's symptoms and CSF findings worsened initially. A repeat NGS of CSF was performed 1.5 months later, which identified T. solium DNA sequences, validating the diagnosis of NCC. The albendazole and dexamethasone were continued, and the patient's symptoms and CSF findings improved.

Conclusion:
In summary, the patient was diagnosed with NCC and discharged after receiving appropriate care. Close monitoring will be required as the diagnosis of extraparenchymal NCC or spinal NCC cannot be completely ruled out. Appropriate follow-up is recommended to assess the patient's response to medication and determine the long-term prognosis.

Hospital Course:
A 58-year-old man with recurrent headache, transient loss of consciousness, and progressive memory loss was admitted to the hospital. Eight years before admission, he was diagnosed with possible tuberculous meningitis, for which he received empirical anti-tuberculous treatment for more than 1 year. Six years ago, he was diagnosed with possible cryptococcal meningitis and received fluconazole and amphotericin B treatment. Three months before admission, he developed progressive memory loss. 

Diagnostic Studies:
Brain MRI showed an enhanced lesion posterior to the medulla and hydrocephalus. Nucleic acid sequencing of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) identified T. solium DNA sequence. Plain x-rays showed scattered “cigar-shaped” calcified lesions in the legs and thoracic wall. Serum and CSF samples were both positive for C. cellulosae IgG antibodies. 

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with intraventricular neurocysticercosis (NCC), likely resulting from Taenia solium infection.

Therapeutic Interventions:
The patient was treated with albendazole and dexamethasone, both of which led to improvement in his symptoms and CSF findings.

Follow-up:
The patient was discharged with instructions to complete his course of medications and to follow up with his primary care physician for further evaluation. 

Prognosis:
The patient is expected to make a full recovery from his intraventricular NCC with appropriate medical management.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The 31-year-old male patient was admitted for progressive blurred vision for 3 weeks. Brain MRI revealed multiple cystic lesions in the suprasellar cistern. Lumbar puncture was performed, which showed an increased opening pressure, elevated white blood cell count, elevated protein level, and decreased glucose level. Cerebrospinal fluid cytology revealed increased eosinophils. Cryptococcus antigen tests and an Xpert-MTB assay of the cerebrospinal fluid were negative. Next-generation sequencing of the cerebrospinal fluid identified T. solium DNA sequences. Serum and CSF were positive for C. cellulosae IgG antibodies. The patient was diagnosed with basal subarachnoid NCC and was treated with albendazole, dexamethasone, and ETV. Significant improvement was observed in the patient's symptoms and CSF findings after treatment.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Basal subarachnoid NCC.

Discharge Medications:
Albendazole, Dexamethasone, and ETV were administered.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to carefully follow up with the treatment for the condition as prescribed. It is recommended to avoid exposure to any uncooked pork or contaminated water. The patient is advised to seek medical attention immediately if there are any new or worsening symptoms.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to complications after a laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy. On presentation, he was septic and in distress. An upper GI series and CT scan of the abdomen showed a contained gastric fistula with perigastric fluid collection. The patient was kept NPO, started on parenteral nutrition, intravenous antibiotics and was well-hydrated to control the sepsis. He underwent CT-guided drainage of the collection. One week post-drainage, upper GI series was repeated, which showed a well-drained gastric leak. After 10 days of stabilization, the patient underwent a Baltazar procedure to uncover the gastric tube, which was covered with omental adhesions. Two leak sites were unexpectedly identified along the staple line. The Double Baltazar procedure was performed, and two fistulo-jejunostomies were created using the same jejunal limb, followed by a Jejuno-jejunostomy (Brown anastomosis) to divert the biliary secretions. All quadrants of the abdomen were drained.
 
Hospital Course:
The patient was initially septic and required surgical intervention due to complications after a laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy. The patient was monitored closely and treated with parenteral nutrition, intravenous antibiotics, and fluids. Drainage of the perigastric fluid collection was performed, and the patient showed improvement in their condition. A Baltazar procedure was performed after 10 days of stabilization. During the procedure, two fistula sites were found along the staple line. The Double Baltazar procedure along with Jejuno-jejunostomy (Brown anastomosis) was performed to divert the biliary secretions, and all quadrants of the abdomen were drained. After the procedure, the patient remained stable and was monitored until discharge. 

Summary:
The patient presented with complications following a laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy and required surgical intervention. The Double Baltazar procedure with Jejuno-jejunostomy was performed due to two leak sites found during the surgery. The patient remained stable and was discharged following close monitoring.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 50-year-old male

Medical History: T6 AIS A SCI from a gunshot wound, chronic pain, left hip and knee heterotophic ossification, chronic right hip dislocation

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency room with a right shoulder mass in September 2014, which was causing acute pain, weakness and paresthesias in the right arm. He was admitted to the general medicine service for pain management and underwent an evaluation for his right shoulder mass. Physiatry was consulted due to his functional deterioration that precluded him from returning to his previous independent living arrangement. The MRI revealed a 6.9 cm heterogeneously enhancing mass involving the right deltoid and pectoralis major muscles, and the core biopsy showed a high grade spindle cell sarcoma.

Treatment Approach:
The oncology department recommended neo-adjuvant radiation therapy followed by gross total resection with wide margins. Physiatry conducted a pre-operative evaluation to focus on functional prognostication. The patient's personal values combined with physiatric assessment determined the pre-surgical planning. A decision was made to take a narrower surgical margin around key muscle group (pectoralis major and deltoids) in order to help maintain the man's manual wheelchair mobility and his ability to independently transfer himself. In November 2014, he completed neo-adjuvant radiation therapy and underwent radical excision of his right shoulder mass with flap closure in December 2014.

Rehabilitation:
The patient began intensive inpatient rehabilitation after he was allowed to weight bear through his arm about 8 weeks later. Initially he required total assistance for most Activities of Daily Living (ADL), including transfers, manual wheelchair propulsion, dressing and toileting. Despite the extensive surgery and radiation treatments, the gentleman was able to return to a functional level, approaching his pre-morbid status (modified independence).

Discharge Plan:
The patient was in a stable condition and was successfully discharged home to live alone in his accessible apartment complex. 

Follow-up Care:
The patient requires regular follow-up care with the oncology and physiatry departments. He needs to attend scheduled appointments for close monitoring of his condition and to ensure that his medication is adjusted accordingly if needed. He should be encouraged to follow a proper diet and exercise routine and attend physical therapy as recommended.

Hospital Course Summary:

Service: Hematology/Oncology
Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Patient: [Patient Name]
Age: 70
Sex: Female

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL) with Ann Arbor Stage IIIA and developed complications of Haemorrhagic Cystitis (HC) associated with BKV and ADV viral infection after relapsing from chemotherapy. She underwent auto-PBSCT and later had BK Viraemia with complications and BKV pneumonia.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital in 2017 for auto-PBSCT after salvage chemotherapy. On the day of transplantation, she developed grade 3 haematuria, and we diagnosed her with haemorrhagic cystitis (HC) associated with BKV and ADV viral infection. Although the patient received immunoglobulin and adenine arabinoside, the HC symptoms did not improve. The patient's ADV DNA load became negative, but the BKV DNA load in urine did not decrease. The patient also developed respiratory failure and elevated serum C-reactive protein levels. Chest CT showed ground-glass opacity (GGO) in the bilateral upper lobe, and we performed BAL. In BAL, although BALF was not macroscopically reddish, BAL slightly detected red blood cells on cytology. Although we could not perform lung biopsy because of low blood platelet count, we diagnosed the patient with BKV pneumonia. After re-administering cidofovir, respiratory symptoms and GGO in CT abated, although HC symptoms persisted.

Discharge Summary:
The patient's DLBCL and complications of HC, BK viraemia with complications and BKV pneumonia were treated during this hospital stay. The patient's respiratory symptoms and serum C-reactive protein levels abated, and the GGO in the chest CT resolved. The patient has not experienced a relapse of BKV pneumonia and DLBCL even after 11 months. Discharge was considered appropriate given the patient's stable condition.

Follow up:
Follow up was arranged to assess the resolution of the HC symptoms and for long-term follow-up of her DLBCL. The patient was educated about necessary steps to prevent recurrence of these complications.

Hospital Course Summary:

This report discusses the case of a 6-month old African boy who was admitted to the hospital following an out-of-hospital cardiac arrest. He had three brief episodes of peri-oral cyanosis and pallor, and presented to the ED twice with increased work of breathing. Paramedics found him to be in asystole upon initial assessment, but he was resuscitated until spontaneous circulation returned at 36 minutes. Initial investigations revealed low ionised calcium, requiring repeated intravenous calcium boluses followed by continuous infusion. Cefotaxime was administered for presumed sepsis, and oseltamivir was added upon isolation of influenza A in a nasal swab. Intravenous fluids and inotropes were also administered. 

The patient was found to have severe dilated cardiomyopathy with poor left ventricular ejection fraction, and fractional shortening was poor as well. He exhibited dyskinetic septal motion, global hypokinesia and moderate to severe mitral regurgitation. Radiographic evidence of rickets was present, with elevated serum ALP and PTH concentrations and low 25OHD. Cholecalciferol was commenced, and intravenous calcium was administered until the serum calcium level normalised. Cardiac failure was treated with diuretics and vasodilators. 

Brain MRI revealed severe hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy, correlating with clinical observations of the patient being unresponsive to external stimuli. The clinical team and family elected to withdraw life support, and the patient expired 6 days after admission.  

Autopsy results demonstrated severe rickets with a rachitic rosary, craniotabes, soft ribs, and dilated cardiomyopathy. The heart weight was considerably high, and histological analysis of the rib growth plate showed typical rickets findings. Histomorphometric analysis of a transiliac bone sample revealed severe osteomalacia, with increased osteoid thickness and volume. The mother of the patient had received antenatal multivitamin supplementation and took the patient to all of their post-natal child surveillance and vaccination appointments, but was not informed about the need for infant vitamin D supplementation. The mother and a sibling of the patient also had suboptimal 25OHD concentrations.

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: Not Provided
Medical Record Number: Not Provided
Service: Pediatrics
Date of Admission: Not Provided
Date of Discharge: Not Provided

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
A 6-month-old Somali boy presented to the emergency department following respiratory arrest and seizure. He was found pale, floppy, and not breathing while held by his sibling. The patient responded to pain, and had a grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur. Labs showed low ionised calcium. The patient had a chest radiograph, which showed cardiomegaly, and an echocardiogram, which demonstrated a structurally normal heart with severely dilated left ventricle, global hypokinesia and moderate mitral regurgitation, confirming hypocalcemic dilated cardiomyopathy. Nutritional rickets due to vitamin D deficiency was confirmed. 

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient received diuretic and ACE inhibitor therapy, intravenous calcium, and oral cholecalciferol. Alfacalcidol was temporarily administered to improve calcium absorption. The patient had another seizure with respiratory arrest in hospital, requiring mechanical ventilation and intensive care. Intravenous calcium was recommenced, and a head computed tomography was normal. The patient was extubated 24 hours later and continued intravenous calcium for five more days. He was discharged home on day 17 and three months later showed slow recovery.

FAMILY HISTORY AND SOCIAL HISTORY:
The patient's mother had been provided with one bottle of vitamin D for the baby at birth but was not informed to continue supplementation, and adherence was not assessed. She and three of the infant’s four siblings were vitamin D deficient, with elevated ALP and PTH.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1. Hypocalcemic dilated cardiomyopathy due to nutritional rickets caused by vitamin D deficiency.

RECOMMENDATIONS:
1. Recommend the patient to continue taking calcium and vitamin D supplements as prescribed by the physician or primary care provider.
2. Encourage the patient to attend regular follow-ups with the physician or specialist.
3. Educate the patient and the patient’s caregiver regarding vitamin D supplementation and proper nutrition. 
4. Recommend the patient’s siblings and mother to undergo vitamin D level testing, and for those found to be deficient, a prescription of vitamin D supplementation be given.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]

Admission Date: [Date] 
Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:
[Patient name] was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of cough, difficulty in breathing, and poor feeding. She was diagnosed with bronchiolitis. However, during further investigations for faltering growth, hypocalcemia was identified. The patient's hypocalcemia was then evaluated, which revealed a diagnosis of rickets in the knee and low 25OHD levels. An echocardiogram revealed dilated cardiomyopathy, and it was confirmed that the patient had severely dilated left ventricle (LVEF of 25%, FS of 15%, and global hypokinesia).

Treatment and Management:
[Patient name] was provided with oral calcium supplements (500 mg/day in divided doses) and cholecalciferol (initially 3000 IU daily, later increased to 6000 IU daily) to treat the hypocalcemia and rickets. In addition, the patient was transferred to a tertiary center for specialist cardiology care, where diuretics and ACE inhibitors were prescribed.

Discharge Instructions:
Upon discharge, [patient name] should follow up with a pediatrician for ongoing care. The mother of the patient should be educated on the importance of vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy and infancy. It is essential to continue administering oral calcium and cholecalciferol as per the specialist's advice. In addition, monitoring of the patient's growth and development should be monitored closely.

Follow-up:
The patient should follow up with a pediatrician for regular visits until the condition is stable.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Patient Age: 45 years
Gender: Male
Date of admission: [REDACTED]
Date of discharge: [REDACTED]
Diagnosis: Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL)

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with symptoms of intermittent fever, chills and rigors along with night sweats, loss of appetite, and weight loss. The patient also had a transient macular rash and generalized painful lymphadenopathy. Synovitis involving lower limb small joints was noted following the presentation that progressed to larger joints in the lower and upper limbs. Laboratory investigations revealed high white cell counts, normocytic anemia and high inflammatory markers which were in a rising trend following the onset of arthritis. The patient was diagnosed as a case of DLBCL following a lymph node biopsy.

Treatment:
The patient was started on non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents and colchicine for the arthritis but there was no response to treatment. Treatment with RCHOP chemotherapy commenced which showed a marked response in the synovitis following the first cycle of therapy. The patient completed the chemotherapy with intermittent infections.

Summary:
The patient presented with symptoms of intermittent fever, chills, and rigors along with night sweats, loss of appetite, and weight loss. The patient had synovitis involving the small and large joints of the upper and lower limbs with a lower limb predominance. Laboratory investigations revealed high white cell counts and anemia. A lymph node biopsy was positive for DLBCL. The patient underwent RCHOP chemotherapy which resulted in the complete resolution of synovitis. The patient was discharged in stable condition with a follow-up plan for further evaluation and management.

Discharge Summary:
 
Hospital Course:
The patient, a 33-year-old nulliparous woman, was admitted to our institution with complaints of lower abdominal pain. She reported a history of 5 weeks and 4 days of amenorrhea and had undergone intrauterine insemination (IUI) 27 days previously. Physical examination revealed diffuse lower abdominal tenderness. The serum beta-chorionic gonadotropin level was 3154 mUI/mL. Transvaginal ultrasound revealed a large hyperechoic mass, a suspected hematoma, in the cul-de-sac. Emergency laparoscopy was performed due to the provisional diagnosis of ruptured ectopic pregnancy with hemoperitoneum. 

Hospital Course:
Intraoperatively, an approximately 2 × 2 × 1.5 cm unruptured ectopic pregnancy was found in the right fallopian tube, while the left fallopian tube appeared to be normal. Minimal bleeding from the proximal pole of the left ovary was observed where there was a 1.0 × 0.5 × 0.5 cm hemorrhagic mass with surrounding blood clot suggestive of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. We resected the mass from the left ovary and performed a right salpingectomy. After intraperitoneal irrigation with 3 L of saline, we placed drains into the cul-de sac and finished the operation. 

Hospital Course:
Histopathological analysis confirmed the presence of left ovarian pregnancy with chorionic villi within the ovarian tissue, along with a right tubal pregnancy. She was monitored for a few days postoperatively and subsequently discharged with regular follow-up appointments.

Hospital Course:
The patient's postoperative course was uneventful without any complications. She was advised to avoid strenuous activities for a week and instructed to attend regular follow-up appointments. The patient was referred for further counseling to discuss fertility options and possible future pregnancies. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Ruptured ectopic pregnancy with hemoperitoneum 
2. Left ovarian pregnancy with chorionic villi incidentally found intraoperatively 
3. Right tubal pregnancy 

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition with regular follow-up appointments.

Patient Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Summary:

After being diagnosed with metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma to liver, lung, and skeletal, the patient underwent several therapies. However, due to the progression of the disease despite these therapies, the patient was started on an unapproved medication called pembrolizumab.

After the second administration of pembrolizumab, the patient reported fatigue and dyspnea and exhibited a saturation of 83% in an open environment. The chest tomography revealed infiltrated interstitial to left and bilateral pleural effusion without signs of pulmonary thromboembolism. In addition, the patient's blood count showed leukocytosis.

Thoracocentesis was performed for the patient, and antibiotic therapy was initiated with ceftriaxone and clarithromycin. However, there was no improvement in the patient's condition. After reassessment of chest computed tomography, the patient was diagnosed with acute interstitial pneumonitis pattern.

Despite several therapies, the patient showed no improvement in the conscious level and respiratory pattern, and hence, sedation was initiated for the patient's comfort.

Upon careful consideration, and in consultation with the patient's family and healthcare team, it was decided that the patient was to be discharged from the hospital. The patient's respiratory status was stable at the time of discharge.

The patient was referred to an appropriate healthcare specialist to manage their care. The hospital provided the patient with comprehensive instructions on their medications and post-discharge care, as well as the need for follow-up visits.

The patient was advised to take care and report to the hospital immediately if there was any deterioration of their condition.

Further details regarding the patient's diagnostic and treatment procedures, as well as other medical details, are available in the patient's medical records.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 73 years
Gender: Male
Diagnosis: Metastatic lung melanoma

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital with a diagnosis of metastatic lung melanoma. The initial treatment with dacarbazine followed by ipilimumab was ineffective, and after careful consideration, we initiated pembrolizumab 2mg/kg administration every 3 weeks.

On day 14 following the first cycle of pembrolizumab, the patient reported a dry cough but did not exhibit fever or other symptoms. No changes in blood count were observed. A chest computed tomography revealed ground-glass opacities in both lungs, and the patient was diagnosed with presumptive pembrolizumab-induced pneumonitis. However, histological confirmation via lung biopsy was not performed.

The patient was treated with 1mg/kg of prednisone in conjunction with antibiotic therapy, which resulted in rapid and significant improvement in symptoms. Two months later, a staging computed tomography showed complete resolution of clinical features, and the patient maintained treatment with pembrolizumab without any adverse effects.

Final Condition:
The patient was discharged with improved symptoms and no additional concerns.

Discharge Medications:
None specified.

Follow-up Information:
The patient is scheduled for regular follow-up appointments with our oncology department to monitor response to treatment and any potential side effects.

[Patient Name:] [DOB:] [MRN:] [Admission date:] [Discharge date:]

[Admitting Diagnosis:]
Untreatable stage IIIA lung adenocarcinoma without mutation.

[Hospital Course:]
Patient underwent surgery followed by radiotherapy and adjuvant chemotherapy with carboplatin and pemetrexed. After 4 months of follow-up, the patient evolved with local recurrence. The affected site was irradiated but no response was seen, therefore, palliative chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel was initiated. A progression of the disease was also observed. Epidermal growth factor receptor mutation was negative. Subsequently, immunotherapy with pembrolizumab 2mg/kg every 3 weeks was initiated. After four cycles, the patient had dyspnea and dry cough with oxygen saturation of 80%. Chest tomography showed extensive bilateral pulmonary infiltration. Blood count showed leukocytosis. No lung biopsy was performed to confirm pathology. Corticosteroid therapy was introduced with metilprednisolone 2mg/kg and antibiotic therapy.

[Summary:]
The patient was admitted for untreatable stage IIIA lung adenocarcinoma without mutation. The patient underwent surgery, radiotherapy and adjuvant chemotherapy. Palliative chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel was initiated after a local recurrence was observed. Immunotherapy with pembrolizumab was initiated after a progression of the disease was observed. The patient had dyspnea and dry cough after four cycles of immunotherapy. Chest tomography showed extensive bilateral pulmonary infiltration. Leukocytosis was observed in blood count. Corticosteroid therapy was introduced with metilprednisolone and antibiotic therapy was given. With this, the patient showed clinical improvement and resolution of CT findings was observed.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient’s hospital course was complicated by metastatic pulmonary large-cell neuroendocrine carcinoma that had progressed from the initial diagnosis and resulted in the patient receiving chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and immunotherapy with pembrolizumab. After 5 cycles of immunotherapy, the patient presented with dyspnea and cough but no fever. Clinical examination revealed oxygen saturation of 84%, and thorax angiotomography showed bilateral ground-glass opacities. Pulmonary thromboembolism was ruled out, and treatment with metilprednisolone and piperaciline-tazobactam was started for the suspicion of pneumonitis. The patient showed significant clinical improvement within 24 hours, and a controlled computed tomography performed 1 week after treatment showed almost full resolution of pulmonary opacities.

Discharge Summary:

The patient, a 54-year-old man diagnosed with pulmonary large-cell neuroendocrine carcinoma, has been discharged in good condition after the treatment of complications related to immunotherapy with pembrolizumab. The patient responded well to treatment with metilprednisolone and piperaciline-tazobactam for pneumonitis. The patient is advised to follow up with their primary care physician and specialists as needed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
