Hospital Course:

The 70-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital due to mental confusion, dyspnea, and dry cough. Blood count results were normal, and a chest tomography revealed infiltrated areas in ground-glass. After ruling out possible causes, the working diagnosis was pembrolizumab-induced pneumonitis.

Treatment:

The patient received methylprednisolone 60mg every 8 hours and antibiotic therapy. Within a few hours, his clinical condition improved, and he was eventually discharged after three days of hospitalization. 

Diagnosis:

Metastatic lung epidermoid carcinoma with multiple liver injuries.

Follow-Up Care:

The patient is advised to follow-up with his care team to monitor his condition and discuss further treatment options. 

Conclusion:

The patient was hospitalized due to suspected pembrolizumab-induced pneumonitis in the context of undergoing treatment for metastatic lung epidermoid carcinoma with multiple liver injuries. The patient's mental confusion, dyspnea, and dry cough improved with methylprednisolone and antibiotic therapy, leading to his eventual discharge. He has been instructed to follow up with his medical team for continuing care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Admission Diagnosis:

Lung metastasis from hepatocellular carcinoma in the upper lobe of the left lung

Hospital Course:

The patient received radiotherapy to the lung metastasis according to the method described hereinafter. Planning CT images were acquired under deep inspiration breath-hold condition with a commercial gold coil marker, Visicoil 21G slim line (IBA Dosimetry, Schwarzenbruck, Germany) of diameter 0.5mm and length 10mm, implanted using CT guidance as close as possible to a tumor. A single-arc coplanar VMAT plan (gantry rotation from 320° to 100°) was created with an isotropic planning target volume (PTV) margin of 5mm and a prescribed dose of 60Gy in 20 fractions. Multiple breath-holds were required to complete the delivery.

During the segmented VMAT beam delivery, the implant marker stayed at the planned breath-hold position, and a DRR image at the gantry start angle was created for each segment. Breath-hold training was given to the patient for optimizing the breath-hold and the following free-breathing periods to successfully complete each segmented breath-hold VMAT delivery.

Subsequently, two lateral lines were manually copied onto a fluoroscopic image window of the XVI display using a transparent sheet. Each line was used as a tolerance limit for the breath-hold beam delivery. During the beam delivery, the breath-hold status was continuously monitored to ensure that the marker position stayed within the tolerance range. If the marker moved outside the tolerance range, beam delivery was interrupted, and the procedure was repeated.

Breath-hold CBCT imaging was performed to confirm that the marker position relative to the tumor remained unchanged. The total VMAT delivery time for a prescribed fraction dose of 3Gy was approximately 115sec, with three beam interrupts and a 25 sec segmented beam delivery followed by 20 sec free breathing.

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of lung metastasis from hepatocellular carcinoma in the upper lobe of the left lung.

Disposition:

The patient was discharged to an outpatient clinic for follow-up and further treatment. 

Patient Condition at Discharge:

The patient was in a stable condition, with no complications reported during hospitalization.

Follow-Up Recommendations:

The patient was advised to undergo regular monitoring and follow-ups to track the progress of their condition. An appropriate management plan was recommended, depending on the patient's condition during follow-up visits.

Signed,

[Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the emergency department with complaints of pain and swelling on the lateral side of the ankle after sustaining an ankle sprain. The patient was unable to bear weight upon admission. Physical examination showed that the patient had a displaced distal fibular fracture (Weber type A) that required fixation. The fracture was successfully reduced and fixed with a single, 3.2 mm, intramedullary, magnesium headless compression screw in a retrograde manner. The patient was placed in a short-leg plaster cast for four weeks and encouraged to do ankle joint exercises.

Clinical Findings:
On the final follow-up examination, two years after the operation, the patient's symptoms had resolved entirely, and her American Orthopaedic Foot & Ankle Society (AOFAS) score was 100 points. Radiographic follow-up showed that a radiolucent zone was seen around the screw, but on the final follow-up radiograph, this radiolucency had almost completely disappeared.

Conclusion:
The patient had successful fracture fixation, and the fracture healed without any complications. At the final follow-up examination, the patient had returned to the pre-injury level of activity. The patient was discharged and advised to continue with ankle joint exercises and to report any future concerns.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [Name]
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]
Diagnosis: Gunshot wound to the right lower extremity.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 16-year-old male, was admitted to our institution with a gunshot wound to the right lower extremity. On physical examination, two bullet entry points were seen at the right popliteal fossa and dorsal soft tissues of the distal right leg. Initial radiographs were normal, but a Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) showed a retained bullet fragment, an 8 mm soft tissue density, and a 10 cm occlusion of the peroneal artery. An angiogram was done, which showed an abrupt cutoff of the popliteal artery adjacent to the bullet fragment. Repeating the angiogram with the patient's right leg in a different position demonstrated mild short segment narrowing of the popliteal artery.

Treatment:
The patient was subsequently taken to the operating room for exploration and removal of the bullet fragment. An intraoperative angiogram was normal, and the anterior and posterior tibial arteries were patent without any evidence of injury or flow-limiting stenosis.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions to take rest and follow-up with outpatient physical therapy for wound care.

Follow-up Plans:
The patient will follow up with an orthopedic surgeon and an interventional radiologist for evaluation and ongoing management of the injury.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification:
Name: Anonymous
DOB: Unknown
Gender: Male
Medical Record Number: 0000000

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: Unknown
Discharge Date: Unknown

Chief Complaint:
Anemia and Thrombocytopenia

History of Presenting Illness:
The patient, a previously healthy 3-year-old Moroccan boy, presented with anemia and thrombocytopenia. The initial symptoms appeared three weeks prior to admission, when he developed a febrile erythematous rash. Fever recurred a week before admission, associated with lethargy, vomiting, and non-bloody diarrhea. The patient appeared pale, with bruises on the abdomen, back, and lower extremities. Laboratory work-up revealed hemolytic anemia with marked reticulocytosis, the presence of schistocytes, profound thrombocytopenia, elevated uric acid, and normal serum creatinine concentrations. 

Hospital Course:
The patient was diagnosed with aHUS and treated with a single dose of eculizumab (~ 900 mg/m2) two days after admission. The patient was vaccinated against N. meningitidis and started amoxicillin prophylaxis. Platelet count, Hb, and LDH started to improve after 4 days and normalized within 17 days. The diagnosis was corrected to TTP several days after discharge from hospital, when the ADAMTS13 activity in the pre-treatment plasma sample was found to be unmeasurably low. Due to rapid clinical and laboratory improvement following treatment with eculizumab, PLEX, and immunosuppressive therapy were not necessary. ADAMTS13 activity normalized completely after 15 months. A moderate, temporary increase of plasmatic sC5b-9 was noted > 2½ years after presentation in the absence of clinical symptoms or hematological evidence of TMA. 

Past Medical History:
Unknown

Clinical Findings:
The patient had microscopic erythrocyturia and mild proteinuria.

Medical Management:
The patient was treated with a single dose of eculizumab (~ 900 mg/m2), vaccinated against N. meningitidis, and started amoxicillin prophylaxis.

Disposition:
Unknown

Discharge Diagnoses:
Anemia and Thrombocytopenia (corrected to TTP)

Follow-up:
The patient underwent comprehensive re-testing that confirmed the diagnosis of TTP and excluded mutations of diacylglycerol kinase-epsilon (DGKE), plasminogen (PLG) and methylmalonic aciduria and homocystinuria, cblC complementation type (MMACHC), but identified a homozygous deletion of CFHR3/1. No anti-CFH antibodies were demonstrated during active disease and follow-up, and there was no documented relapse of TTP or TMA over the 4 years of observation. A moderate, temporary increase of plasmatic sC5b-9 was noted > 2½ years after presentation in the absence of clinical symptoms or hematological evidence of TMA. At the time, ADAMTS13 activity had normalized, and anti-CFH antibodies were undetectable.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: November 2016
Discharge Date: Day 8

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted with asymptomatic hypoglycemia that persisted despite glucose infusion and was found to have type B lactic acidosis with an elevated blood lactate level, which prompted a suspicion of Wernicke Encephalopathy (WE) secondary to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML).

Clinical Course:
Chemotherapy with doxorubicin 60 mg/m2 and cytarabine 100 mg/m2 was initiated, resulting in a slight tumor lysis syndrome but without kidney injury. The patient's pH normalized, blood lactate levels decreased, and hypoglycemia did not recur, allowing for ICU discharge on Day 8.

Significant Events:
Type B lactic acidosis with an elevated blood lactate level, suggestive of the presence of Wernicke Encephalopathy (WE) secondary to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML); asymptomatic hypoglycemia was observed but had resolved by Day 5 post-treatment initiation.

Procedures and Interventions:
The patient received doxorubicin 60 mg/m2 and cytarabine 100 mg/m2 for chemotherapy initiation.

Consultations:
The patient was transferred to the Intensive Care unit upon diagnosis of the condition.

Discharge Diagnosis:
The patient suffered a relapse of AL, which was associated with new hyperlactatemia and asymptomatic hypoglycemia related to a recurrence of WE, which was treated with cytarabine 1,500 mg/m2 and gemtuzumab 3 mg/m2. Unfortunately, the patient later developed septic shock as a complication of chemotherapy-induced aplasia and digestive infection and died in the Intensive Care unit in a state of multiple organ dysfunction due to septic shock.

Prognosis:
The patient's prognosis was poor due to AML and the complications that arose during chemotherapy treatment, including WE recurrence and septic shock.

Hospital Course:
54-year-old male from Southwest Iran was admitted to the Emergency Ward with a 3-week history of continuous, throbbing headache, general fever, chills, weakness, anorexia, and weight loss. The patient also had a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and hemorrhoid.

Exam Findings:
Upon examination, the patient's body temperature was 38 °C, and blood pressure was 130/82 mm Hg. Mild tenderness in the right upper quadrant and moderate splenomegaly were observed, but all other examinations were normal.

Laboratory Findings:
Hemoglobin was 8.1 (gr/dl), white blood cell count 1900, retic count 0.5%, and platelet count 20000. ESR was 56 (mm/h), alanine aminotransferase 84 (Iu/l), aspartate aminotransferase 67 (Iu/l), alkaline phosphatase 401 (Iu/l), albumin 3.4 (gr/dl), conjugated bilirubin 0.6 (mg/dl), ferritin 658.6 (mcg/dl), serum iron 23 (mcg/dl), and total iron binding capacity (TIBC) 116 (mcg/dl). Other laboratory tests such as creatinine, blood sugar, partial thromboplastin time, prothrombin time, urinalysis, stool exam, sputum exam, wright test, 2ME, calcium, phosphorus, magnesium, and prostate-specific antigen were within normal range. Serologic tests for HBV, HCV, and HIV were negative.

Imaging Findings:
Abdominal ultrasonography revealed mild hepatomegaly and moderate splenomegaly. Doppler ultrasound of the abdomen showed dilation of splenic veins such as superior mesenteric vein (15 mm) and portal vein (15 mm). A computerized tomography (CT) scan of the brain revealed no abnormal finding. Axial fluid-attenuated inversion recovery MRI image (FLAIR) revealed an increase in signal intensity of the central part of the right side of the pons. Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy revealed macrophages with numerous Leishmania amastigotes.

Treatment:
Amphotericin B was initiated as the treatment protocol, and the patient showed complete resolution of symptoms. Second bone marrow exam showed no amastigote.

Outcome:
Five months after initial presentation and treatment with amphotericin B, our patient had no neurological morbidity and disability.

Summary:
54-year-old male presented with a 3-week history of headache, fever, chills, weakness, anorexia, and weight loss. Examination revealed mild tenderness in the right upper quadrant and moderate splenomegaly, and laboratory tests showed anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, elevated liver enzymes, and elevated markers of iron metabolism. Leishmania infection was suspected due to the presence of amastigotes in bone marrow, and treatment with amphotericin B was initiated which resulted in the complete resolution of symptoms. The patient has not reported any neurological morbidity or disability five months after treatment.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 78-year-old male from a rural area in western Iran, was admitted to the Razi Hospital Dermatology Clinic, Tehran, with multiple ulcerative and exudative lesions on mid-face, dorsal aspect of hands, and posterior aspect of heels. Lesions had been present for three years and had progressively enlarged above the upper lip, anterior portion of the nasal fossa, above the eyebrows and heels, and become ulcerative. 

History and Physical Examination:

The patient's past medical history was unremarkable, with no comorbid conditions, drug use, systemic symptoms, weight loss, fever, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, or any signs of systemic involvement in physical examination and laboratory survey.

Diagnostic Assessment:

Multiple treatments were attempted for potential differential diagnosis, including pyoderma gangrenosum, sarcoidosis, and leishmaniasis, but with no improvement in the lesions. Skin biopsy revealed necrotizing and palisading granulomatous tissue pattern that suggested infectious etiology. The smear of lesions for fungal and mycobacteria and Leishmania was negative. PPD test with 27 mm induration was positive, and anti-tuberculosis treatment including isoniazid, rifampin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide was started.

A month after initiating drugs for tuberculosis, the smear of leishmaniasis repeated that was positive this time, the second biopsy revealed pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia and infiltration of the dermis by mixed inflammatory cells and Leishman bodies compatible with leishmaniasis, and RFLP PCR was carried out on DNA extraction that confirmed L. major as the pathogenic agent.

Hospital Course:

Upon confirmation of L. major as the pathogenic agent, treatment initiated with 3 gr per day of meglumine antimoniate (Glucantime®) until 1 wk followed by 4.5 gr per day for another week. Despite a good response to meglumine antimoniate after 2 wk of treatment, we were forced to discontinue the drug due to cardiac toxicity. 

Patient Education and Follow-up:

The patient was informed about publishing his figures with covering eyes. The patient received education and counseling regarding the diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up. The patient was discharged in stable and satisfactory condition.

Electronic Health Record (EHR)

Patient: 24-year-old male

Hospital course:

The patient presented with photophobia since birth. Myopia with astigmatism and nystagmus were identified when the patient was 8 months old, but strabismus was not observed. At the age of 3, the patient's parents reported difficulties distinguishing colors and a diagnosis of achromatopsia was suspected. Ocular therapy, including occlusion therapy, was conducted but was unsuccessful. The patient's visual acuity deteriorated over time. At the time of the latest examination, the patient exhibited subnormal amplitude under scotopic conditions and extinct responses under photopic conditions. Color vision test showed protan-deutan confusion errors.

Diagnostic test result:

Full-field light- and dark-adapted electroretinogram (ERG) recordings displayed subnormal amplitudes under scotopic conditions and extinct responses under photopic conditions in both eyes of the patient in comparison to normal controls. Spectral domain optical coherence tomography (SD-OCT) showed normal retinal architecture with thinned photoreceptor layer. Mutation screening of the OPN1LW/OPN1MW gene cluster revealed a large deletion, NC_000023.11:g.154,118,184_154,191,311del.

Discharge diagnosis:

Based on the patient's case report, the discharge diagnosis is congenital achromatopsia with myopia and astigmatism. 

Plan:

The patient will be referred to an ophthalmologist for further evaluation and management. Genetic counseling may also be suggested.

Follow-up:

The patient is advised to schedule follow-up appointments with the ophthalmologist and a genetic counselor as recommended. 

Disposition:

The patient was discharged with an outpatient status.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with lower abdominal pain and was diagnosed with rectosigmoid colon cancer. Endoscopic stent placement was performed as a bridge to surgery for large bowel obstruction. CT scan revealed multiple lung metastases and a horseshoe kidney. Laparoscopic anterior rectal resection was performed with a five-port conventional technique identifying and preserving the IMA, left ureter, left gonadal vessels, and hypogastric nerve plexus. The root of aberrant renal artery was not visualized. Following the surgery, intraperitoneal reconstruction was performed and the patient recovered uneventfully.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
The patient had rectosigmoid colon cancer and was diagnosed with multiple lung metastases and a horseshoe kidney. The surgery involved laparoscopic anterior rectal resection and intraperitoneal reconstruction was performed. The IMA, left ureter, left gonadal vessels, and hypogastric nerve plexus were preserved.

Imaging Results:
CT scan revealed multiple lung metastases and a horseshoe kidney. 3D-CT angiography showed an aberrant renal artery at the isthmus from 3 cm under the IMA branch of the aorta.

Follow-Up Plan:
The patient recovered uneventfully and was discharged on postoperative day 16. Pathological examination demonstrated no metastasis of the lymph node. The patient may require follow-up imaging and further treatment for lung metastases and horseshoe kidney.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 69-year-old man who presented as an emergency outpatient with sudden epigastric pain. The patient has a history of laryngoesophagopharyngectomy, bilateral lymph node dissection for hypopharyngeal cancer, and esophageal reconstruction with a free jejunum flap six years prior.

Physical examination revealed tenderness in the epigastric region with elevated values in blood biochemistry (creatinine, lactate dehydrogenase, and creatine phosphokinase). Abdominal contrast computed tomography (CT) revealed twisted mesentery with the small intestine around the point of torsion, and the superior mesenteric artery as the axis (whirl sign). Small bowel volvulus was suspected.

Emergency surgery was performed on the same day. Laparoscopic examination revealed the entire part from the upper jejunum to the terminal ileum twisted clockwise, with the superior mesenteric artery and vein as the axes. The surgery involved the separation of adhesion between different sections of the intestinal tract, and tracing of the bowel from the small bowel in the region of the ligament of Treitz toward the anus to confirm the absence of adhesions or torsion up to the terminal ileum. The color of the small bowel improved, and no resection of any intestine was required.

The patient made good postoperative recovery, resumed oral intake on day 2, and was discharged on day 5 after surgery. No recurrence has been reported 1 year postoperatively.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient: 7-month-old male, neutered Maine Coon cat

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Small Animal Teaching Hospital at the University of Bern with acute neurological signs consistent with unilateral otitis media/interna. Otoscopic and cytologic examinations revealed brown-colored fluid in the external canal with numerous extra- and intracellular rod-shaped bacteria and neutrophils. A deep ear swab was submitted for culture and subsequent antimicrobial susceptibility testing. The patient received treatment with oral and topical glucocorticoids and topical ofloxacin (Floxal, Bausch & Lomb Swiss AG). The ear swab was cultured on sheep blood agar at 37 °C for 2 days, producing a pure culture of small white colonies (strain number 17KM38) Gram-positive in nature. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
Unilateral otitis media/interna due to Corynebacterium provencense SN15.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was treated with oral chloramphenicol palmitate solution (Cloropal, Dr. E. Gräub AG) twice daily for three weeks and an ear cleaner containing chlorhexidine digluconate (Otodine®, Ufamed AG) twice daily for two weeks. The cytology of the ear canal does not show any bacteria or neutrophils after three weeks of therapy. 

Follow-up:
Follow-up by a local veterinarian in one month was recommended for further evaluation. 

Conditions treated during the hospitalization:
Unilateral otitis media/interna due to Corynebacterium provencense SN15. 

Treatments during hospitalization:
Oral and topical glucocorticoids and topical ofloxacin (Floxal, Bausch & Lomb Swiss AG) for three weeks.
Oral chloramphenicol palmitate solution (Cloropal, Dr. E. Gräub AG) twice daily for three weeks. 
Ear cleaner containing chlorhexidine digluconate (Otodine®, Ufamed AG) twice daily for two weeks.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED] Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our hospital with complaints of epigastric pain and was subsequently diagnosed with lower esophageal squamous cell carcinoma. His medical history was notable for mild hypertension and dyslipidemia. The patient was treated with 2 cycles of cisplatin and 5-fluorouracil chemotherapy over 2 months. The primary lesion demonstrated a disappearance of fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) uptake, and the mediastinal and bilateral hilar lymph nodes displayed a slightly reduced FDG uptake.

Subsequently, the patient underwent video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery esophagectomy (VATSE) with gastric tube reconstruction via the retrosternal route. Pathological diagnosis revealed moderately to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the lower thoracic esophagus, and the resected lymph nodes showed granulomatous reactions, histiocytes, multinucleated giant cells, and scar-like fibrosis. Based on the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM staging system (7th edition), the tumor was classified as pT1N0M0, pStage IA.

Follow-Up:

The patient was discharged in improved condition 49 days after surgery. Follow-up FDG-PET/CT performed 15 months after surgery revealed bilateral FDG accumulation in the hilar lymph nodes without tumor recurrence.

Discharge Diagnoses:

- Lower esophageal squamous cell carcinoma, pT1N0M0, pStage IA

Plan/Recommendations:

The patient should continue to receive regular follow-up and monitoring.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Age: 72

Gender: Female

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

History of Presenting Illness

The patient was admitted to our hospital due to dysphagia. Endoscopic examination revealed a circumferential tumor with ulceration in the cervical esophagus, and biopsies confirmed squamous cell carcinoma. Contrast-enhanced CT showed extensive tumor growth in the esophagus with suspected tracheal invasion and enlarged lymph nodes extending from the cervical region to the upper mediastinum. FDG-PET/CT revealed abnormal FDG accumulation in the primary lesion and lymph nodes from the cervical to upper mediastinal region. However, due to the patient's past medical history of sarcoidosis, it was challenging to determine whether the multiple lymphadenopathy was benign or metastatic.

Hospital Course

The patient received definitive chemoradiotherapy to preserve the larynx. After 2 months of treatment, the patient had complete disappearance of FDG uptake in the primary cancer in the esophagus. However, there was only a slight reduction in FDG uptake in the mediastinal lymph nodes, which was likely affected by sarcoidosis. The primary lesion of the esophagus relapsed 3 months later, and the patient underwent thoracoscopic and laparoscopic total laryngopharyngoesophagectomy with gastric tube reconstruction via the posterior mediastinal route. The pathological diagnosis was moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the cervical esophagus. The resected lymph nodes demonstrated no tumor metastasis, but some lymph nodes showed granulomatous reactions and contained several small epithelioid cell granulomas, suggesting the presence of sarcoidosis. The final stage was determined as pT2N0M0, pStage IB (UICC 7th).

Hospital Course Summary

During the hospital course, the patient received definitive chemoradiotherapy to preserve the larynx. However, the primary lesion in the cervical esophagus relapsed 3 months later, and the patient underwent thoracoscopic and laparoscopic total laryngopharyngoesophagectomy. The final pathological diagnosis was moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the cervical esophagus with no lymph node metastasis. The patient was discharged 27 days after surgery, and a follow-up CT performed 6 months after surgery showed no tumor recurrence. However, the patient died of a myocardial infarction 1 year after surgery.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]

Hospital Course: 
The [Age] [Gender] patient was admitted to our hospital for itching around her anus. Physical examination showed an erythematous, inflamed skin lesion in the perianal region. The patient had a history of sigmoidectomy for diverticulitis and Sjögren's syndrome. However, no gastrointestinal symptoms, change in bowel habits, weight loss, or family history of malignancy was reported.

Investigations: 
Colposcopy, cystoscopy, nor colonoscopy revealed any abnormality of the cervix, bladder, or rectum. Computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging showed no evidence of malignancy in the genitourinary or gastrointestinal tracts. Histopathological examination of biopsy specimens showed many Paget’s cells within intraepithelial lesions of the perianal skin but no malignant cells in the rectal or vaginal mucosa. 

Diagnosis: 
Primary extramammary Paget’s disease (EMPD) of the anogenital region was suspected. 

Treatment: 
Anal-preserving wide local excision deep to the subcutaneous fat with 1-cm negative margin from the positive sites confirmed by frozen section examination and mucosal resection of the anal canal that extended 1 cm proximal to the dentate line of the anal canal. Reconstruction was performed using a bilobed gluteal fold flap. 

Histopathological examination of the resected specimen showed Paget’s cells within the epidermis. Immunohistochemical markers revealed that the Paget’s cells were positive for cytokeratin 7, cytokeratin 20, and caudal-related homeobox gene nuclear transcription factor 2 and negative for gross cystic disease fluid protein 15. Additional histopathological examination of the resected specimen showed well-differentiated adenocarcinoma in an anal gland, continuous with the Paget’s cells in the anoderm but limited in the basement membrane without a desmoplastic change. Immunohistochemical staining of the resected specimen revealed secondary EMPD due to adenocarcinoma arising from the anal gland.

Due to the possibility of residual adenocarcinoma in the anal gland, possibly extending to the sphincter, a radical laparoscopy-assisted abdominoperineal resection was performed. No reconstructive plastic surgery was needed.

Discharge Diagnosis: 
Anal gland adenocarcinoma in situ with pagetoid spread in the perianal skin.

Disposition: 
The patient was discharged and recommended to follow up with their primary care physician.

Discharge Instructions: 
The patient was advised to follow the current medication prescribed by the primary care physician and further advised to limit physical activity. Regular hygiene was recommended. In case of any worsening symptoms, the patient was advised to contact their primary care physician. The patient was also advised to come for follow-up appointments with their primary care physician.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: Not disclosed
Medical Record Number: Not disclosed
Date of Admission: Not disclosed
Date of Discharge: Not disclosed
Attending Physician: Not disclosed

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient presented with a three-month history of numbness on the left side of his face, which gradually progressed and became painful in the month before the initial visit. He also complained about difficulty chewing on the left side. An examination revealed decreased sensation over the distribution of the left trigeminal nerve, associated with dyskinesia of the left masticatory muscles. Past medical history was significant for acute gastritis, duodenal ulcer, and depression, for which brotizolam, flunitrazepam, and paroxetine had been prescribed, respectively.

DIAGNOSTIC ASSESSMENT:
Panoramic radiography identified slight restriction of movement of the temporomandibular joint on the left. MRI of the temporomandibular joint region and brain region revealed a tumor measuring 10 mm in diameter and a homogeneously high signal intensity on axial T1-weighted images compared with gray matter and low signal on axial T2-weighted images. The tumor was found in Meckel’s cave, appeared to be exerting pressure on his trigeminal nerve, and was homogeneously hyperdense compared with gray matter on unenhanced CT.

TREATMENT:
En bloc excision was performed, and immunohistochemistry was positive for melanocytic features of Melan A (MART1; melanoma antigen recognized by T cells-1), human melanoma black-45, vimentin, and S-100 protein and negative for cytokeratin AE1/AE3 and glia fibrillary acidic protein. Cellular proliferation was assessed by staining for Ki-67. Following excision, the patient underwent adjuvant gamma knife radiosurgery with 24 Gy in two fractions to the tumor bed in the epidural space of the middle cranial fossa. No chemotherapy was administered.

IMPRESSION:
A definitive diagnosis of melanocytoma was made.

FOLLOW-UP:
The patient's postoperative course was uneventful, and he had progressive resolution of the neurologic deficits. At follow-up 6.5 years later, he remains well with no signs of recurrence.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
Melanocytoma of Meckel's cave.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
Not disclosed.

Hospital Course:
The patient is an 84-year old male with chronic hepatitis C and liver cirrhosis who was referred to our outpatient clinic for the evaluation of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The patient had previously undergone transarterial chemoembolization and radiofrequency ablation for HCC and had a wedge resection of two nodules in hepatic segments VI and VII in December 2008. Histological examination confirmed HCC grade III with necrosis and microscopic vascular thrombosis.

In September 2009, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed millimetric disease relapse in hepatic segments V, II, III, and I, as well as a 21 × 9 mm adenopathy at the hepatic hilum. A new resection was scheduled but was not carried out due to the detection of a right portal branch neoplastic thrombosis during intra-operative ultrasound.

In January 2010, the patient began systemic treatment with metronomic capecitabine according to a previously described protocol. The therapy was well tolerated, and after 1 month, serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) decreased to 643 ng/mL. After 3 months, serum AFP had drastically decreased to 7 ng/mL, and a marked reduction in liver lesion size was observed by MRI, evaluated as a partial response according to Modified Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (mRECIST).

In August 2010, computer tomography (CT) scanning showed a single hypodense lesion of 13 mm in hepatic segment II without any other liver lesions. Given the presence of a single lesion, the possibility of residual disease ablation was explored using hepatic contrast-enhanced ultrasound. Two suspicious lesions for HCC were detected in hepatic segments II and III, and the lesions were submitted to needle biopsy. Histological analysis identified a nodule of low-grade dysplasia in segment II and micro and macronodular cirrhosis with light activity in segment III.

The patient underwent metronomic capecitabine until July 2013, when the sustained complete response was confirmed, and the treatment was discontinued, and the patient entered a follow-up program. The final MRI (February 2017) confirmed the complete response. To date, the patient is alive and in good health.

Discharge Summary:

Final Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with multiple liver lesions involving 70% of the right liver, multiple nodules in the left lobe, and right portal thrombosis in the setting of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).

Hospital Course:
The patient initially received systemic treatment with sorafenib in December 2012. However, the medication was discontinued after ten days due to G3 skin toxicity (Stevens–Johnson syndrome). In January 2013, the patient started metronomic capecitabine (500 mg twice daily, continuous administration), which was well-tolerated. A new CT scan in March 2013 showed significant intralesional necrosis, and subsequent FDG-PET scanning in April 2013 showed the complete absence of any pathological areas. AFP level had also fallen to 3.3 ng/mL.

In July 2013, a needle biopsy of the principal hepatic lesion revealed fibrous connective tissue with histiocytic inflammation without any tumour cells. An abdominal US scan in January 2014 revealed the presence of a single hypoechoic lesion of 1.4 × 1.3 cm. Subsequent CT scanning in December 2014 also showed a further reduction in the size of the hepatic lesion without any vascular components, for which it was decided to discontinue treatment in the same month.

The most recent US scan in September 2017 showed no hepatic lesion, and serum AFP was 3.6 ng/mL. The patient is currently alive and in excellent health.

Condition at discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition without any significant medical issues.

Follow-up and care plan:
The patient was advised to continue with periodic follow-up appointments with his physician to monitor his condition and AFP levels. In case of any significant change in his medical condition, he was advised to seek immediate medical attention.

Summary:
The patient presented with multiple liver lesions and right portal thrombosis in the setting of NASH. He was initially treated with sorafenib but discontinued due to G3 skin toxicity. He was subsequently treated with metronomic capecitabine, which was well-tolerated and resulted in significant intralesional necrosis. The patient then underwent a needle biopsy, which showed no tumour cells. A subsequent US scan showed the presence of a single hepatic lesion, which gradually resolved over time, and he was finally discharged in stable condition. Follow-up appointments were advised to monitor the patient's condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 70
Gender: Male
Date of Admission: October 2015
Date of Discharge: Ongoing

Medical History:
The patient presented with a history of hepatitis C virus cirrhosis and a binodular HCC diagnosis in July 2006. The patient underwent RFA and PEI treatment. From March 2008 to March 2015, numerous tumour recurrences were managed with locoregional techniques including RFA, PEI and one course of transcatheter arterial chemoembolization (TACE). In October 2015, the patient was seen for HCC progression in the VIII segment associated with an invasion of the inferior vena cava and neoplastic pulmonary embolization.

Hospital Course:
Sorafenib systemic therapy was initiated at a dosage of 400mg daily; however, the patient's clinical presentation prompted a reduction in dosage to 400mg daily in November 2015. At the beginning of February 2016, there was radiological progression (tumoural invasion of the right and median hepatic veins and enlargement of the neoplastic thrombus in the inferior cava vein) and sharp increase in serum AFP (47,137 ng/mL). The patient was switched to capecitabine therapy (500mg twice daily, continuous administration). CT scans were performed every 3 months and showed the progressive reduction of pulmonary metastases, recanalization of the median hepatic vein, progressive improvement in inferior cava vein invasion, and complete devascularization of the tumour mass.

Discharge Condition:
At the time of writing, the patient is in good clinical condition and continues to receive capecitabine treatment (500mg bid), complaining of only modest fatigue.

Follow-up:
The patient will continue to receive treatment and have regular follow-up appointments for the management of his HCC.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: Confidential
Gender: Male
Age: 32

Presenting Complaint:
Elevated level of serum creatinine (Scr) (3.71 mg/dl) and proteinuria (3+).

Medical History:
The patient underwent a successful kidney transplant 26 months ago. He was diagnosed with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and had an unidentified cause. His immunosuppressive protocol consisted of prednisone, mycophenolate mofetil, and tacrolimus. Renal allograft function remained stable and urine analyses were always normal from discharge to 24 months after the operation. The patient was hospitalized previously for fever and a cough treated with azithromycin and ceftazidime. His pulmonary symptoms abated after a week of antibiotic treatment. 

Diagnostic Procedures:
Laboratory workups showed an elevated level of serum creatinine of 3.71mg/dl and proteinuria of 3+. Blood platelet count also decreased to 34 × 109/L. The renal allograft biopsy showed multiple periodic acid-Schiff stain (PAS) positive materials in the capillary lumens. Capillary wall duplication was obvious and diffuse. Masson trichrome stain revealed extensive fuchsinophilic deposits in the subepithelial, subendothelial, and mesangial spaces.

Diagnosis:
C3 glomerulonephritis (C3GN) combined with thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA).

Treatment:
The patient was treated with 2 sessions of plasma exchange, but no clinical improvement was achieved as indicated by persistent nephrotic-range proteinuria and progressive elevation of Scr. The patient was in dialysis after approximately one-year follow-up.

Genetic Testing:
Genetic testing for the major genes in complement pathway related with renal disease was performed. We found two rare missense variants in compound heterozygous form, c.848A > G (p.Asp283Gly) and c.1339C > T (p.Pro447Ser) in the CFI gene (NM_000204.3) in the patient while his father and mother were found to harbor only the c.848A > G and c.1339C > T respectively (Fig. ). Both parents were phenotypically normal. This patient’s unaffected sister had neither of the 2 variants. No variants were identified in the other complement cascade protein genes commonly screened. Nevertheless, quantitative measurement of plasma CFI of the patient and his unaffected family members showed that their plasma CFI levels were all in normal range.

Follow-up:
The patient requires regular follow-up appointments.

Hospital Course:
Patient 1, an 11-year-old boy, was admitted to our care for management of osteoporosis, asthma, epilepsy, and neutropenia. The patient was diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and had previously fractured his fingers. He received 3-monthly pamidronate infusions, melatonin, and midazolam. A bone biopsy had revealed osteopenia. The patient had also undergone successful surgery for undescended testes, left-sided calcaneus talipes equinovarus, and right-sided developmental dysplasia of the hip.

History and Examination:
Patient 1 was born to non-consanguineous parents following a normal pregnancy that was complicated by a caesarean section. The patient was discharged after 2 days following treatment for pyrexia. He walked at 2.5 years and had delayed onset of speech. He had difficulties with fine motor skills and attended a school for children with special needs. The patient took medication for asthma and epilepsy, with intermittent neutropenia as a consequence of sodium valproate. The patient showed ritualistic behaviors and was referred for an assessment of possible obsessive-compulsive disorder. On examination, the patient had low-set ears, blue sclerae, and hyperopia that required glasses.

Investigations:
A DXA scan revealed reduced BMD with Z-scores of -3.4 at the lumbar vertebrae and a total body score of -2.5 adjusted for age and gender. Trio whole-exome sequencing identified a de novo missense variant in NRXN1, which interacts with COL1A1, and is known to be associated with neurodevelopmental disorders/autism.

Impressions and Plan:
The patient was treated for osteoporosis with 3-monthly pamidronate infusions, and melatonin was continued. Midazolam was given in case of a prolonged seizure. Other conditions such as asthma, epilepsy, and neutropenia were managed accordingly. No changes were made in the current management plan. A follow-up appointment with a specialist was scheduled for further monitoring. The patient was discharged from our care in a stable condition.

Discharge Medications:
Melatonin.

Follow-up:
Further specialist follow-up and management is recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient 2, an 11-year old boy, was admitted with a history of poor growth and abnormal clinical features. A thorough evaluation revealed that he suffered from Short Stature, Optic Atrophy, and Pelger-Huet Anomaly (SOPH) syndrome, a rare genetic disorder that caused various clinical manifestations, such as intellectual disability, hypogammaglobulinaemia, lymphopenia, frequent infections, bone fragility, and abnormal liver function tests.

During his hospitalization, the patient received therapy and interventions, including immunoglobulin replacement therapy and pamidronate infusions to improve his bone density and reduce the risk of fractures. The patient's condition improved, and he was clinically stable at the time of discharge from the hospital.

The caregiver received detailed information about the patient's diagnosis, care, and follow-up plans. The patient was scheduled for close follow-up with his primary care physician and appropriate specialists to address any ongoing concerns related to his condition. The caregiver was advised to seek medical attention promptly in case of any emergency or worsening of the patient's clinical condition.

The patient's hospital course was unremarkable, and he was stable at the time of discharge. The caregiver was advised to maintain appropriate infection control measures, nutrition, hydration, and physical therapy to optimize the patient's health and well-being. The healthcare team provided education and resources to the caregiver to help them manage the patient's care effectively and minimize the risk of future complications.

Overall, the patient's hospitalization was successful, and he was discharged in good clinical condition. The patient's long-term prognosis is guarded, and he requires close monitoring of his bone health, immune function, and overall growth and development.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient: 4-year old male, diagnosed with osteogenesis imperfecta and developmental delay.

Hospital Course:
The patient was born by normal vaginal delivery at term. At birth, he had bowing of the long bones and abnormal metaphyses. A skeletal survey showed a normal thoracic cage volume and a fractured ulna. He was subsequently diagnosed with severe osteogenesis imperfecta. He had suffered multiple fractures of his ulnas and humeri, a femoral fracture and multiple vertebral wedge fractures. He underwent bilateral osteotomies and rodding of his femurs and tibias. He received 3-monthly pamidronate infusions.
 
Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with severe osteogenesis imperfecta based on genetic assessment, which confirmed a pathogenic c.902G>A variant in COL1A2 replacing glycine at position 301 with a glutamic acid. He also had a ‘triangular’ face, blue sclerae and high-pitched voice.

Management:
The patient was managed with bilateral osteotomies and rodding of his femurs and tibias. He received 3-monthly pamidronate infusions. Additionally, he required intervention from speech and language therapists for delayed speech and had demonstrated “rocking” behaviour.

Outcome:
The patient was discharged with ongoing care for osteogenesis imperfecta and developmental delay. He will require follow-up appointments with appropriate healthcare specialists. 

Abbreviations used:
- COL1A1/A2: Collagen type 1 alpha 1 and 2 
- ASD: Autism Spectrum Disorder
- OI: Osteogenesis Imperfecta.

Discharge Summary:

Patient 4 is a 14-year old male with global developmental delay and learning difficulties. He was diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) at an early age due to limited eye contact and restricted interests. He was admitted to the hospital for complications related to a fractured forearm and vertebral wedge fractures. During his stay, he was found to have a reduced bone mineral density, joint hypermobility, and brittle nails. He also has incomplete descended testes, a left-sided choroidal coloboma, and myopia.

Hospital Course:

Patient 4 was admitted to the hospital for treatment of a fractured forearm and vertebral wedge fractures. During his hospital stay, he was diagnosed with a reduced bone mineral density and joint hypermobility, which were consistent with secondary osteoporosis. He was treated with 3-monthly pamidronate infusions to improve his bone mineral density. Consultations were obtained from genetics and orthopaedics for further evaluation of his clinical features.

Under orthopaedic care, he was diagnosed with bilateral femoral proximal anteversion and underwent derotation osteotomy surgery. He also suffered from a leg length discrepancy, which was addressed using orthotics. Under genetics care, whole-exome sequencing (WES) was performed, which did not identify any variants of significance. Further genetic analysis is ongoing.

Follow-Up:

Patient 4 will require ongoing follow-up with several specialties, including orthopaedics, genetics, and endocrinology. He will also require regular testing of his bone mineral density and joint stability. Further genetic testing will be conducted as it becomes available. Discharge planning included appropriate referrals for ongoing care.

Hospital Course:

Patient 5, a 13-year-old male, was admitted due to bone fragility and a history of fractures. He had been diagnosed with idiopathic osteoporosis and had received regular infusions of pamidronate. He was found to have a maternally inherited PLS3 pathogenic variant which explained his bone fragility. 

Past Medical History:

The patient had a history of delayed speech and was diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder at 3 years of age. He also had a family history of osteoporosis in his maternal grandfather.

Clinical Examination:

The patient was not dysmorphic. There was hypermobility in the small joints of the fingers, but little evidence of hypermobility elsewhere.

Diagnostic Testing:

DXA scans showed reduced bone mineral density with Z-scores of −2.7 at the lumbar vertebrae and − 2.6 total body measurement adjusted for age and gender. A bone biopsy at 12 years of age demonstrated severe low turnover cortical and trabecular osteopenia.

Treatment:

The patient received 3-monthly infusions of pamidronate.

Summary:

Patient 5 is a 13-year-old male with a history of delayed speech and autism spectrum disorder. He was diagnosed with idiopathic osteoporosis and received regular infusions of pamidronate. The patient was found to have a maternally inherited PLS3 pathogenic variant. DXA scans showed reduced bone mineral density and a bone biopsy demonstrated severe low turnover cortical and trabecular osteopenia. The patient was found to have hypermobility in the small joints of the fingers, but no other evidence of hypermobility.

Hospital Course:
Patient 6 is an eight-year-old boy who was admitted at birth with a diagnosis of severe osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) antenatally. He had multiple long bone fractures and dentinogenesis imperfecta and required treatment in the special care baby unit for three months. He was fed via a nasogastric tube and suffered from gastroesophageal reflux. He developed a right-sided inguinal hernia shortly after birth which was surgically corrected at one month of age. He also suffered from the fusion between the base of his skull and top of his spinal column. He has undergone multiple surgical procedures, with bilateral femoral and tibial rodding procedures undertaken at 4 and 5 years of age, respectively.

Course in Hospital:
During his stay in the hospital, the patient was closely monitored for complications related to his condition. His bone fragility was managed with 3-monthly infusions of pamidronate. The patient was able to make a partial recovery from his condition, although he remained developmentally delayed. He started talking between two and a half and three years of age and started to "commando crawl" at 3 years of age. Despite these challenges, he attended a mainstream school after starting a year later than his peers.

Discharge Condition:
At the time of discharge, the patient's condition had improved. However, he still experienced notable deformities of his long bones, resulting in a pes cavus appearance. A genetic test showed that he carried a de novo pathogenic variant in COL1A1 c.2282G>A in exon 33/34, confirming his clinical diagnosis of OI.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was discharged and advised to continue follow up appointments with his physicians to monitor his condition. He was instructed to avoid activities that potentially lead to fractures such as contact sports. He was also advised to practice safe handling techniques to prevent falls or injuries. The patient was discharged into the care of his parents with instructions to follow up with their pediatrician.

Hospital Course:
Patient 7 is a 6-year old boy with a history of Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) who was admitted to our hospital due to concerns of autistic traits. Genetic testing confirmed the presence of a pathogenic variant in COL1A2 that is associated with OI.

History and Physical Examination:
Patient 7 was born at term and was noted to have multiple fractures and deformities. He was treated with pamidronate with good response. The patient has a triangular face, blueish sclerae, high-pitched voice, dentinogenesis imperfecta, significant limb deformities, and scoliosis. Antenatally, there were concerns with short long bones and bowed femur.

Diagnosis:
Patient 7 was diagnosed with Osteogenesis Imperfecta based on genetic testing that identified a pathogenic variant in COL1A2. The patient also fulfilled the criteria for a diagnosis of autism based on clinical observations.

Treatment:
The patient received treatment with pamidronate for the management of Osteogenesis Imperfecta. No specific treatment was initiated for the autistic traits since the patient was recruited to a study.

Follow-up:
The patient requires ongoing multidisciplinary care given the complexity of his condition, which includes medical management of his OI, and monitoring of his development and autism symptoms.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient was discharged in a stable condition with follow-up appointments scheduled with his medical team. The patient's symptoms of autism were being monitored. Future management and treatment will be based on findings from further evaluation and the results of follow-up testing.

For any further questions regarding the patient's hospital course, please refer to the accompanying medical records.

Discharge summary:
Patient X is a female infant who was born via cesarean section at 37 + 4 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2440 g. She was admitted to the hospital with feeding difficulties by nasogastric tube, requiring oxygen to maintain 90-95% saturation, and dyspnea. The patient had choanal atresia, bilateral low-set ears, triple restriction and systolic murmur. She had also been diagnosed with atrioventricular septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary hypertension, bilateral lateral ventricle dilatation, and severe hearing impairment.

Patient X was in hospital care for four months and was discharged in stable condition. She underwent posterior nostril plasty operation by nasal endoscope and had a silicone tube in one month for transition the postoperative. She also underwent patent ductus arteriosus ligation surgery. No clinical characteristics of CHARGE syndrome were detected in the patient's parents. Molecular analysis of the disease-associated genes CHD7 and EFTUD2 revealed a monoallelic insertion in CHD7, which was confirmed by Sanger sequencing. This mutation leads to a reading frameshift mutation and was not present in the Human Gene Mutation Database or ClinVar, suggesting that it is novel. This heterozygous frameshift mutation was not detected in the patient's parents, suggesting that it is a de novo mutation.

Overall, Patient X's condition improved during the hospitalization. Further management and follow-up care may be necessary to monitor her condition and ensure the optimal outcome.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Admission Date: [Date of admission]
Discharge Date: [Date of discharge]

Patient Name: [Patient’s Name]
Gender: Female
Age: 71

Medical History: The patient was admitted to Gamma Knife center with a meningioma of the sphenoid jugum. 

Hospital Course: The patient underwent hypofractionated irradiation with Leksell Gamma Knife Icon®, which involved five daily fractions of 5 Gy. The treatment was performed using a thermoplastic mask Orfit® (Orfit Industries, Wijnegem, Belgium). During the mask making procedure, the patient reported a burning and tingling sensation on her face, especially on her forehead. She continued to have redness, tickling, and edema of her face for the following 4 days. A serious allergic reaction was observed on her face during the first irradiation session which was associated with an atopic edema. She was provided with intravenous injections of corticoids and orally administered antihistamines and corticoids during the following 5 days. With this medication, the allergic reaction was controlled until the end of the treatment.

Summary of Treatments: The patient was treated for meningioma of the sphenoid jugum through hypofractionated irradiation with Leksell Gamma Knife Icon®.

Discharge Condition: The patient’s allergic reaction was controlled by medication, and there were no further complications reported. The patient was discharged in a satisfactory condition. 

Follow-Up Care: The patient was advised to attend follow-up appointments as scheduled. 

Discharge Medications: None. 

Discharge Diagnosis: N/A

Discharge Instructions: Patient was advised to attend follow-up appointments as scheduled.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Discharge: 13th postoperative day

Admission Date: N/A
Admitting Diagnosis: Incidental finding of mediastinal mass overlapping the aortic arch region

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our hospital by her family doctor after receiving a chest x-ray during routine clinical examination, which showed a mediastinal mass overlapping the aortic arch region. A computed tomography (CT) was performed and revealed incidentally a type B dissection, which was most likely chronic without information of the index date, originating from an aneurysm of a left cervical arch with a maximum diameter of 6 cm. The left renal artery, the celiac trunk and the main part of the superior mesenteric artery branched from the false lumen without a sign of malperfusion of the organs.

Before intervention, the patient received a blood pressure adjustment by ACE inhibitor. Betablocker was not necessary because of a resting pulse under 60 beats per minute. For neurological online monitoring, sensitive and motor evoked potentials were monitored. Spinal drainage was installed 1 day before the procedure.

Surgical access was carried out through median sternotomy and an additional left lateral thoracic incision through the fourth intercostal space (Hemi-Clemshell). Simultaneously to the preparation of the aneurysm, partial cardiopulmonary bypass was installed in the left groin by cannulation of the femoral artery and vein under echocardiographic guidance. During selective ventilation of the right side, the left lung was mobilized by transsection of the Ligamentum pulmonale and preparation of the perianeurysmatic tissue and adhesions.

After identification and preparation of the recurrent and phrenic nerve and the supraaortal branches, the descending aorta was clamped. The left carotid artery originated from the aortic arch with a distance of only 1 cm from the aneurysm. The left axillary artery branched directly from the aneurysm and was dissected and reimplanted with a separate sidegraft to the straight graft between the distal arch and proximal descending aorta.

The procedure was performed with partial cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) of 87 min, aortic clamp time of 62 min under normothermic condition. The patient was extubated on first postoperative day and recovered well.

Biopsy of aortic tissue showed a picture consistent with arteriosclerosis and loss of smooth muscle cells, rupture of the elastic fibers and fibrosis of the media. The intima could not be visualized in detail.

The patient was discharged to cardiac rehabilitation at 13th postoperative day and recovered well.

Follow Up and Recommendations:

Last follow up with computed tomography was performed 3, 5 years after initial operation with a good and stable result of the dissection membrane and a perfusion of both lumina. The patient is able to resume a normal life without limitations.

The patient is advised to follow up with their primary care physician for routine check-ups and to maintain a healthy lifestyle.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not specified
Medical Record Number: Not specified
Date of Admission: Not specified
Date of Discharge: Not specified

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 29-year-old Asian male, was admitted to Xiamen Chang Gung Hospital after undergoing surgical debridement for a perianal abscess at another hospital. On admission, he presented with continuous severe perianal and scrotal pain, scrotal swelling, high fever, and was found to have extensive emphysema around the testicles, epididymis, and perineal subcutaneous tissues. A diagnosis of Fournier's gangrene (FG) complicating a perianal abscess was made, and the patient underwent aggressive fluid administration, hemodynamic support, and intravenous antibiotic therapy.

The patient received immediate surgical debridement under general anesthesia, leaving both testes exposed. Microorganisms were detected in tissue samples taken during the first two debridements. The patient received preoperative antibiotic treatment with combined broad-spectrum antibiotics, which was later adjusted to the culture sensitivity of the microbial isolates. The patient was subsequently administered levofloxacin, and his white blood cell count and C-reactive protein level gradually decreased. 

The patient underwent two subsequent surgical debridements, and his infection gradually subsided. His gas gangrene resolved completely, and good granulation tissue was present 1 week after surgery. Testicles were transpositioned into the scrotum on the eighth postoperative day, and split-skin closures and open drainage from the scrotum and perianal area were subsequently performed. The patient was discharged on the 11th postoperative day with antibiotics adjusted to oral administration of levofloxacin.

Follow-up:
The patient attended the outpatient department four times for follow-up. Both testicles healed, and the open drainage area from the scrotum and perianal area had healed at 10 months after discharge. The patient was healthy as usual, with no complaints or illness. His complete cell count and serum parameters of liver and kidney function remained normal.

Diagnosis:
Fournier's gangrene (FG) complicating a perianal abscess

Plan:
The patient received immediate surgical debridement under general anesthesia, leaving both testes exposed. The patient received preoperative antibiotic treatment with combined broad-spectrum antibiotics, which was later adjusted to the culture sensitivity of the microbial isolates. The patient was subsequently administered levofloxacin. The patient underwent two subsequent surgical debridements, and his infection gradually subsided. Testicles were transpositioned into the scrotum on the eighth postoperative day, and split-skin closures and open drainage from the scrotum and perianal area were subsequently performed. The patient was discharged on the 11th postoperative day with antibiotics adjusted to oral administration of levofloxacin.

Overall, the patient responded well to treatment, and testing following hospital discharge showed no new or continuing medical issues.

Discharge Summary:

Admitting Diagnosis: Dengue fever with encephalitis

Hospital Course:

The 24-year-old Sri Lankan man was admitted to the hospital with fever, vomiting, and reduced level of consciousness. The patient was diagnosed with dengue fever with encephalitis based on the positive dengue IgM antibody and cerebral oedema observed on non-contrast CT brain. The patient's platelet count dropped to a nadir of 31 × 109/L, but subsequently increased. During the course of the hospital stay, he received treatment with intravenous meropenem, vancomycin, aciclovir and dexamethasone. 

Follow-up cranial MRI done 1 month later showed complete resolution of the splenial lesion. The patient was discharged from the hospital on the tenth day of illness with complete clinical, heamatological and biochemical recovery.  

Discharge Diagnosis:

Dengue fever with encephalitis

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged from the hospital in a stable condition.

Discharge Medications:

N/A 

Follow-Up:

The patient was advised to follow-up with his primary care physician for regular check-ups.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Blank]
Date of Admission: [Blank]
Date of Discharge: [Blank]
Reason for Admission: Mandibular pain and swelling
Primary Diagnosis: SAPHO syndrome

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 26-year-old woman, was admitted to our hospital due to worsening mandibular pain and swelling. She had previously undergone root canal therapy for periapical periodontitis in the right lower first molar. However, her symptoms persisted and progressed over a period of 4 months, prompting referral to our hospital. Upon examination, she exhibited swelling and tenderness in the right mandibular region, along with sclerotic changes and periosteal reaction. Blood tests were unremarkable, ruling out inflammation, and dental infection was ruled out as the cause of her symptoms. Scans confirmed active mandibular osteomyelitis/osteitis and revealed bilateral palatine tonsils and reactive lymphadenopathy. Considering the patient's clinical and radiological manifestations, SAPHO syndrome was diagnosed.

The patient had a history of palmoplantar pustulosis, which was treated locally at a dermatology clinic. Tonsillectomy and bone biopsy of the right mandible were performed. The biopsy showed enlarged and sclerotic bone trabeculae with little inflammatory cell infiltration, which was compatible with the diagnosis of SAPHO syndrome. The patient was administered salazosulfapyridine 1000 mg/day and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs as required. Her pain resolved, and there were no signs of recurrence after a 5-month follow-up period.

Summary:
The patient had been diagnosed with SAPHO syndrome, a rare inflammatory disease that affects the skin, bones, and joints. She had been experiencing mandibular pain and swelling that were not associated with dental infection. The diagnosis was confirmed through imaging studies and bone biopsy. Treatment included salazosulfapyridine and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. The patient reported relief from her pain and did not experience any relapse after a 5-month follow-up.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: Unknown
Gender: Female
Age: 30 years
Admission Date: Unknown
Discharge Date: Unknown

Diagnosis:
Metastatic lung adenocarcinoma with involvement of bones, lymph nodes, and liver.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of severe low back pain and generalized body aches. On physical examination, bilateral cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy were noted. The chest X-ray revealed bilateral fluffy hilar opacities, and a CT thorax showed scattered areas of multifocal consolidation in the left lung. Ultrasound neck showed bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, and axillary lymph node biopsy was done, revealing metastatic lung adenocarcinoma. 

Further imaging with PET scan showed progressing pulmonary consolidations and nodules, osseous involvements, and generalized, metabolically active lymphadenopathy involving supra- and infradiaphragmatic regions. The patient was started on chemotherapy with crizotinib and denosumab, which showed good response with favorable treatment response according to new PET scan.

Outcome:
The patient was referred to Cancer Centre for further plan of management. The patient responded well to treatment with chemotherapy and denosumab, showing metabolic resolution of previously seen left lung uptakes, lymph nodes, and bone metastases with increased sclerosis denoting favorable response.

Follow-up:
Appropriate follow-up with Cancer Centre is recommended.

Abbreviations:
CBC - Complete Blood Count
CT - Computed Tomography
ESR - Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate
PET - Positron Emission Tomography
US - Ultrasound

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

The patient presented with heel pain and fever post-surgery. On examination, skin redness, swelling, and pus-like discharge were observed around the surgical site. Imaging tests showed hyperpermeability of the calcaneus, and magnetic resonance images confirmed a diagnosis of osteomyelitis of the calcaneus as well as abscess formation.

Intravenous antibiotic therapy was administered, and the patient underwent irrigation of the surgical site and surgical pus drainage.

On the 12th day after the second surgery, the patient underwent radical debridement of the calcaneal bone marrow using a lateral approach and irrigation with natural saline was performed. Subsequently, calcium phosphate cement was implanted at the defected site of the calcaneus. Intravenous antibiotic therapy was changed to antibiotics per oral and continued for 30 days.

The patient responded well to treatment and the osteomyelitis was considered controllable. Partial weight bearing was started from 14 postoperative days and increased gradually until full weight bearing was achieved on day 35. The fistula was completely closed on the 6th postoperative month, and there was no recurrence of infection.

We now consider the patient to have achieved complete remission of osteomyelitis and is able to walk normally without a cane.

Signed, 

[Redacted]
[Redacted] Hospital

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Name]
Age: 72
Sex: Male
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with a 6-week history of haematuria and was diagnosed with a locally advanced clear cell RCC. He underwent left partial nephrectomy, which was followed by the development of ESRD and initiation of dialysis 3 times/week. The patient later underwent left radical nephrectomy due to local recurrence and subsequent bone and lung metastases. High-dose palliative radiotherapy was given to the renal bed followed by systemic treatment with dose-reduced pazopanib. However, follow-up CT scan 3 months later showed significant disease progression. Consequently, nivolumab 3 mg/kg was initiated, and the dose was later changed to 240 mg flat dose intravenously every 2 weeks. The patient tolerated the treatment well, with no grade 2-4 toxicities observed. 

Clinical Findings:

The patient's pain score improved significantly after nivolumab treatment, reducing from 8/10 to 3/10. His ECOG performance status also improved from 3 to 2. Follow-up imaging indicated a partial response according to RECIST version 1.1, with a considerable reduction in the size of metastases in the lung and renal bed. The patient has now been on nivolumab for 22 months with serial imaging showing an ongoing response.

Disposition:

The patient was discharged from the hospital with instructions to comply with regular follow-up appointments.

Diagnosis:

Locally advanced clear cell RCC with bone and lung metastases.

Treatment:

Left partial nephrectomy, left radical nephrectomy, high-dose palliative radiotherapy, dose-reduced pazopanib, and nivolumab.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Patient Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Female
DOB: [Redacted]
Age: 41 years
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The 41-year-old female patient was admitted to our inpatient facility due to fetal cardiomegaly detected on routine prenatal ultrasound. Fetal ultrasound revealed the absence of ductus venosus (DV) with the umbilical vein (UV) directly draining into the right atrium, consistent with the extrahepatic drainage type of ADV. The patient was monitored for right heart failure, which did not manifest during her stay.

Upon spontaneous labor at 38+3 weeks, the patient gave birth to a 3,096-gram male infant, who showed mildly decreased ejection fraction and mild aortic valve regurgitation according to neonatal cardiac ultrasound. Further ultrasound examination revealed a defect of the hepatic rectangular leaf. The patient's baby was monitored closely and showed normal development at 1.5 years of age. Computed tomography performed at 1 year of age revealed a Morgagni hernia in the liver.

Medical History:
The patient had no remarkable medical or family histories.

Diagnoses:
Fetal cardiomegaly with extrahepatic drainage type of ADV and absence of DV.

Summary:
The 41-year-old female patient was admitted due to fetal cardiomegaly detected on routine prenatal ultrasound. Fetal ultrasound revealed the absence of ductus venosus (DV) with the umbilical vein (UV) directly draining into the right atrium, consistent with the extrahepatic drainage type of ADV. Upon spontaneous labor, the patient gave birth to a 3,096-gram male infant who showed mild aortic valve regurgitation and mildly decreased ejection fraction. Further ultrasound examination revealed a defect of the hepatic rectangular leaf. The baby was closely monitored and showed normal development at 1.5 years of age. Computed tomography performed at 1 year of age revealed a Morgagni hernia in the liver. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 4 years old
Sex: Male
Hospital Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Hospital Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Diagnoses:
- Catheter-related deep venous thrombosis
- Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
- Small bowel obstruction secondary to submucosal hematoma

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our pediatric intensive care unit with a persistent seizure disorder of unknown cause. A right femoral triple lumen central venous line had been placed previously. After five days, he developed an acute occlusive deep venous thrombosis in the right common femoral vein, which was treated with LMWH (enoxaparin) at 1 mg/kg for a planned three-month course, with the CVL being removed five days after initiating anticoagulation. The patient had no personal or family history of thrombophilia or bleeding diathesis. 

During his hospital course, he experienced multisystem organ failure secondary to DRESS syndrome as a result of anticonvulsive therapy. One week after starting LMWH heparin, he developed gross hematuria. In the setting of his anti-Xa levels continuing to rise, LMWH heparin was held, and anticoagulation was switched to unfractionated heparin. The patient required continuous venovenous hemofiltration and eventually, a steady regimen was found with consistently stable and therapeutic anti-Xa levels. 

Unfortunately, on the 15th day of this regimen, the patient developed signs of bowel obstruction with copious bilious vomiting. A CT of the abdomen and pelvis showed a high-grade small bowel obstruction, with 2 areas of small bowel, suspicious for intussusception. An exploratory laparotomy was done, and 30 cm of the distal jejunum was found to be severely compromised and was resected. Pathologic analysis showed an extensive submucosal hematoma causing internal bulging of the mucosa and submucosa, causing attenuation and focal pressure necrosis of the muscularis propria.

Treatment:
The patient's submucosal hematoma was successfully resected, and he recovered in the pediatric ICU without further episodes of emesis or signs of bowel obstruction. Five days after the operation, he was restarted on LMWH, and he completed his 3-month course without any further signs of bleeding. He was discharged from the hospital 3 weeks later with resolution of his seizures to a rehabilitation facility.

Follow-up:
The patient will need to follow up with his primary care physician for further management of his seizure disorder. A referral to a hematologist may be considered for further evaluation of the catheter-related deep venous thrombosis and his complex anticoagulation course. Follow-up with gastroenterology may also be considered for further management of his bowel obstruction. 

Discharge Medications:
None

Follow-up Appointments:
Primary care physician follow-up
Referral to a hematologist (considered)
Referral to gastroenterology (considered)

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]
Date Admitted: [redacted]
Date Discharged: [redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Ocular focusing deficit with suspected Graves' ophthalmopathy

Clinical Course:
This 40-year-old male patient was referred to our department with a two-month history of ocular focusing deficit with double vision on upward gaze, eyelid retraction, and exophthalmos of the left eye. Ophthalmological examination revealed disturbance in upward movement of the left eye with an exophthalmos of 19mm in the left eye and 15mm in the right eye. Although some clinical symptoms suggested Graves’ disease, the thyroid function tests were normal with no presence of thyroid-related diseases. TSAb was marginally elevated at 146% (normal range <120%) while TPOAb, TgAb, and TRAb were all negative. Imaging analysis revealed enlarged inferior rectus muscle of the left eye with active inflammation.

Diagnosis at Discharge: TRAb-negative euthyroid Graves' ophthalmopathy

Hospital Course:
The patient was hospitalized and treated with a combination of corticosteroid pulse therapy and orbital radiation therapy. He underwent this medical therapy with three consecutive cycles of pulse therapy and 20Gy total radiation. After the third cycle of therapy, oral prescription of prednisolone was given, and the corticosteroid doses were decreased every two weeks until cessation. The swelling of the left eyelid disappeared on day three, and the TSAb turned negative (113%) four months after the initiation of corticosteroid therapy. Proptosis, abnormality in ocular movement, and diplopia were unchanged until discharge, with the remaining of the exophthalmoses of 18mm on the left and 16mm on the right.

Follow-up Recommendations:
The patient will be followed up in the outpatient clinic for further evaluation, monitoring, and treatment recommendations as needed.
