Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]

Date of Admission: [redacted]

Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Generalized weakness, unintentional weight loss, cough, night sweats, and nonbloody, watery diarrhea.

Principal Diagnosis on Discharge: Right-sided hydropneumothorax.

Summary of Hospitalization:

The 40-year-old African American male was admitted to the hospital with complaints of generalized weakness, unintentional weight loss, cough, night sweats, and nonbloody, watery diarrhea. He reported prior history of incarceration and resided with his mother, for whom he was the primary caregiver. Initial vitals in the emergency department were significant for tachycardia. Physical examination at the time of admission revealed a thin, nontoxic appearing male.

Initial laboratory workup was significant for absolute CD4 count of 26 (3%). Chest X-ray in the emergency department revealed a cavitary lesion with an air-fluid level within the anterior medial right hemithorax and a loculated hydropneumothorax along the right lateral lung base. CT chest with contrast demonstrated two large, thick-walled cavitary lesions originating within the right lung parenchyma that appeared to communicate. His treatment was initiated with intravenous Ceftriaxone and Metronidazole. The patient's stool PCR isolated a Salmonella species. Diagnostic thoracentesis yielded purulent fluid with WBC 505,000, RBC 0, pH 6.0, protein 3.7, LDH 41,239, and glucose 12. Pleural fluid culture was positive for Salmonella species.

Due to presence of empyema, a right-sided chest tube was placed followed by instillation of tissue plasminogen activator (r-tPA) and DNase twice daily for three consecutive days. CT abdomen and pelvis with contrast demonstrated two rim-enhancing hypodense lesions within the central mesentery of the abdomen. Intra-abdominal drains were placed under CT guidance into the mesenteric abscesses, from which nontyphi Salmonella eventually grew late in hospital course.

On hospital day #4 the patient's right-sided chest tube was noted to have persistent air leak. CT chest without contrast confirmed persistent right-sided hydropneumothorax with centrilobular ground glass opacities with lung entrapment. On hospital day #10, the patient underwent right video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) with decortication. Pleural peel pathology revealed pleural fibrosis, focal chronic inflammation, and mild anthracosis. The patient completed an additional two weeks of antibiotic therapy with intravenous Ceftriaxone from the date of decortication.

On follow-up at four-months, CT chest demonstrated improved but persistent loculated right pneumothorax with resolution of the right lung cavitary lesions. At seven months, the CT demonstrated complete resolution of the right-sided pneumothorax.

Recommendations and Follow-up:

The patient is recommended to follow up with their primary care physician for ongoing management and monitoring of hypertension and substance abuse. Follow up imaging may be necessary to evaluate the persistence of loculated right pneumothorax. Further imaging may also be necessary to evaluate the rim-enhancing hypodense lesions within the central mesentery of the abdomen. The patient is advised to seek medical attention if any new or persistent symptoms arise. Instructions were provided to the patient regarding medication use, lifestyle modifications, and follow-up care. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: 

Medical Record Number:

Date of Admission:

Date of Discharge:

Admitting Diagnosis: Gonococcal ophthalmia neonatorum

Principal Diagnosis at Discharge: S. maltophilia meningitis

Hospital Course Summary:

A 13-day-old male infant presented with left eye purulent discharge and swelling of the left upper eyelid, which was noticed since birth. The patient underwent a full septic workup, including CBC, blood culture, urine analysis and culture, CSF analysis and culture, and left eye swab for culture and Chlamydia antigen. The patient was started on meningitis dose of Cefotaxime and Gentamycin ophthalmic drops while waiting for the results of the cultures. Azithromycin was added as well to cover the possibility of an associated chlamydial infection.

The eye swab culture revealed Neisseria gonorrhea sensitive to Cefotaxime, and the antibiotic was continued while waiting for the results of the CSF culture. Blood and urine cultures were negative. The CSF culture revealed Gram-negative rods, which were identified as S. maltophilia. The organism was sensitive to Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX). The patient was started on TMP-SMX and Ciprofloxacin. The duration of therapy was based on daily cranial ultrasound scans and repeated CSF studies.

The patient recovered from the infection uneventfully, and the last CSF studies were completely normal, with negative culture. The baby's head circumference was measured daily during the hospital stay and remained normal. 

Follow-Up Care: 

The patient had a follow-up visit one week after discharge, which was reassuring. His parents received treatment for gonorrhea and were screened for other sexually transmitted diseases.

Recommendations: 

The patient's parents should be advised to schedule regular well-child check-ups with a pediatrician. Any concerns about the child's health should be reported to the pediatrician immediately. 

Discharge Medications: None

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 33 years
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with a complaint of left knee pain and swelling. The examination showed a moderate-to-severe effusion and synovial thickening. The X-ray showed a joint effusion, and the MRI showed a popliteal cyst.

The patient underwent aspiration of the effusion, and fluid analysis confirmed hemorrhagic fluid with acute and chronic inflammation. Fungal cultures grew branching narrow hyphae with septations and conidia, leading to a presumptive diagnosis of Sporothrix schenkii. Therefore, the patient underwent diagnostic left knee arthroscopy, irrigation, debridement, and major synovectomy.

After the debridement, the patient was started on oral itraconazole. The patient reported that all his symptoms of knee swelling and pain had improved with itraconazole.

During his subsequent follow-up visit, the patient reported continuing to drink excessive amounts of alcohol.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with Sporothrix schenkii infection of the left knee.

Treatment:

The patient underwent diagnostic left knee arthroscopy, irrigation, debridement, and major synovectomy. Additionally, the patient received oral itraconazole 200 mg twice daily for 12 months.

Condition at the time of Discharge:

At the time of discharge, the patient's condition was stable, and he reported improvements in his knee swelling and pain.

Follow-up Care:

The patient was advised to refrain from alcohol consumption and to continue taking itraconazole as prescribed. Additionally, he was advised to follow up with his primary care physician for further evaluation and care.

Disposition:

The patient was discharged to home in stable condition.

Discharge Summary
Admit Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Lithuanian University of Health Sciences Kaunas Clinics Hospital with symptoms of throat discomfort on the left side and dysphagia. Upon arrival, the patient had no fever and there were no other signs of acute infection. Anamnestically, the patient was treated with antibiotics for a suspected peritonsillar abscess on the left side for a period of 1 month. However, prescribed antimicrobial therapy was not effective, and his symptoms worsened over time. 
Pharyngoscopy and fibronasolaryngoscopic investigation revealed a dislocated lateral pharyngeal wall with mild inflammatory changes of the oropharyngeal mucosa. A contrast-enhanced computed tomography study showed a clearly limited, oval-shaped lesion in the left parapharyngeal space, which encased the carotid arteries and the styloid process. A magnetic resonance imaging study suggested schwannoma of the small branch of the mandibular nerve (V3) due to its localization and tumor-specific features. A biopsy with histological verification confirmed the diagnosis of schwannoma. The patient underwent a transoral removal of the tumor under general anesthesia, and no postoperative complications were observed. The wound healed by primary intention, and the patient was discharged for further outpatient treatment on the sixth postoperative day. 

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted with throat discomfort on the left side and dysphagia for approximately 2 months and was treated with antibiotics for a suspected peritonsillar abscess on the left side. Anamnestically, prescribed antimicrobial therapy was not effective, and his symptoms worsened over time. Pharyngoscopy and fibronasolaryngoscopic investigation revealed a dislocated lateral pharyngeal wall with mild inflammatory changes of the oropharyngeal mucosa. Radiological studies demonstrated a tumor in the left parapharyngeal space. A biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of schwannoma. The patient underwent a transoral removal of the tumor under general anesthesia, and no postoperative complications were observed. The wound healed by primary intention, and the patient was discharged on the sixth postoperative day. 

Diagnosis on Discharge:
Schwannoma of the small branch of the mandibular nerve (V3)

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was discharged on the sixth postoperative day with instructions to continue the prescribed antibiotic therapy with penicillin and painkillers. The patient was advised to take necessary rest and avoid strenuous activities. The patient was advised to follow up with their primary care physician as required. 

Follow-up:
The patient has been observed for a period of two years, and there are no signs of schwannoma relapse.

Discharge Summary: 

Patient Name: Unknown
Age: 62
Gender: Female

Admission Date: February 2011
Discharge Date: Unknown

Chief Complaint: Severe hematuria and epistaxis

Past Medical History:
- Multiple myeloma (diagnosed in 2008)
- CKD secondary to myeloma kidney
- Asthma

Hospital Course: 
This 62-year-old female patient was admitted in February 2011 with severe hematuria and epistaxis. The patient had a notable history of multiple myeloma, CKD secondary to myeloma kidney, and asthma. The patient also experienced right flank pain, persistent hypercalcemia, and was admitted several times. Despite multiple chemotherapeutic regimens, the patient continued to progress. During admission, the patient was hypercalcemic and hyperkalemic, and received both zoledronic acid and kayexalate. An extensive coagulation profile was conducted to determine the etiology of the patient's coagulopathy. 

Diagnostic Findings: 
- Hematopathology revealed extensive bone marrow involvement (90%) by plasma cells 
- Cytogenetics revealed an abnormal hyperdiploid karyotype
- Thrombin time was elevated to 32.3 sec 
- Ristocetin cofactor assay revealed the absence of a Von Willebrand Factor deficiency
- PTT was only partially corrected with mixing
- Factor VIII activity was elevated at 273%

Treatment: 
Continuous protamine sulfate IV of 2–7 mg/hour was given, which led to notable improvement and subsequent resolution of the patient's hematuria and epistaxis. No intervention was done for the hematoma that formed after a bone marrow biopsy was performed on the same admission, and resolution occurred spontaneously.

Follow-up and Recommendations: Unknown at this time.


Note: The patient was not discharged as per provided case report, therefore, a hospital course summary has been provided. The discharge summary has been organized according to headings, maintaining medical consistency, and preserving the structure of the EHR.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Gender: Female

Age: 25 years

Admission Date: [Redacted]

Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Reason for Admission: High fever, left flank pain, and gross hematuria

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted with a preliminary diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis due to the presence of left costovertebral angle tenderness, hematuria, and leukocyte esterase and nitrite negativity. Despite initial treatment with intravenous ceftriaxone, the patient's creatinine levels persisted to remain elevated. Based on further evaluation, a diagnosis of IgA nephropathy was made following a kidney biopsy that demonstrated mesangial IgA deposition, C3, and lambda light chains. The patient was subsequently treated with methylprednisolone 1g, lisinopril 5mg, and oral prednisolone 0.5mg/kg every other day for 6 months.

Diagnostic Tests: Urinalysis, microscopic evaluation of urinary sediment, blood culture, urine culture, creatinine, C-reactive protein (CRP), and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR).

Diagnosis: IgA nephropathy

Treatment: The patient was treated with antibiotics, methylprednisolone, lisinopril, and oral prednisolone for 6 months.

Condition at Discharge: The patient's condition improved, and her creatinine levels and spot urine protein to creatinine were normal at follow-up after two months.

Recommended Follow-Up: The patient is advised to continue follow-up with her nephrologist and undergo monitoring of her blood pressure, renal function, and urine protein levels.

Discharge Summary:

Admitting Diagnosis: Complete bifid penis

Medical History: The patient was brought to the Center for Anatomical Science and Education for anatomical dissection purposes, under the Saint Louis University Gift Body Program.

Hospital Course: During routine dissection, it was observed that the patient had a bifid penis that was 9.2 cm long and divided longitudinally into right and left parts, each with its own glans and prepuce. There was no urethra in the phallus, and the urethral meatus was located at the base of the divided phallus, indicating proximal penoscrotal hypospadias.

A histological examination showed that the epithelial lining of the urinary bladder extended to 3.9 cm on the ventral surface of each phallus and resembled stratified squamous epithelium. The scrotum was large, containing left and right testes with a normally routed spermatic cord. There was no epididymis, but the vas deferens continued directly from each testis to the seminal vesicle of the same side.

Pathologic-examination showed a small mass of hard tissue on the left side, measuring 0.5 cm by 0.5 cm, located at the site of the prostate gland. Histologically, it did not resemble prostatic glandular tissue and did not have any connection with the vas deferens or seminal vesicle.

Discharge Diagnosis: Complete bifid penis with proximal penoscrotal hypospadias accompanied by absent epididymis.

Discharge Instructions: Due to the nature of the patient's situation, no necessary discharge instructions were provided. 

Follow-up Recommendations: None.

Discharge Summary:

Identification:
The patient is a 55-year-old man with a complex medical history, including diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, gout, chronic kidney disease with proteinuria, diverticulosis, obesity, and osteoarthritis. He presented to the clinic with umbilical hernia pain and was subsequently diagnosed with advanced adenocarcinoma.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent herniorrhaphy to address his umbilical hernia discomfort. A surgical specimen evaluation did not reveal any masses or lesions, but a subsequent biopsy revealed diffuse infiltration of malignant cells consistent with adenocarcinoma. The patient's imaging studies confirmed multiple lesions and areas of involvement, including the pancreatic tail and body, peritoneum, liver, and iliac lymph nodes. Despite the option of chemotherapy, the patient opted for palliative care and died within two months of his diagnosis.

Reports:
The microscopic evaluation of the biopsy revealed diffuse infiltration by malignant cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, resulting in the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma. Immunohistochemistry identified the neoplastic cells as positive for pancytokeratin and CK7 and negative for CK20, CDX2, TTF-1, and PSA. The laboratory findings revealed elevated levels of CA 19-9 and CEA.

Discharge Condition:
The patient passed away while under palliative care for his advanced adenocarcinoma, despite aggressive treatment options.

Follow-Up:
N/A (Not applicable, as the patient passed away)

Signed:
[Name], MD

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the pediatric ICU with findings of severe anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis with circulating blasts. Initial workup revealed a diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), confirmed by molecular analysis of the peripheral blood. The patient was treated emergently with ATRA, dexamethasone, allopurinol, cefepime, and blood products including packed red blood cells, platelets, and cryoprecipitate. She received several transfusions with platelets, cryoprecipitate, and fresh frozen plasma to manage DIC. She was continued on an induction course of chemotherapy including ATRA, dexamethasone, idarubicin, and arsenic trioxide. A lumbar puncture was performed and intrathecal chemotherapy was administered, which revealed the presence of leukemia cells in the cerebrospinal fluid, confirming the involvement of the central nervous system. The patient's encephalopathy gradually improved and she returned to her baseline mental status by day 7 of treatment. The patient was noted to have elevated opening pressure on lumbar punctures, which worsened over the course of induction, attributed to pseudotumor cerebri secondary to ATRA. Upon completion of the first 28 days of induction therapy, repeat lumbar puncture and bone marrow studies demonstrated no morphologic evidence of acute promyelocytic leukemia, consistent with remission.

The 56-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital due to urachal carcinoma with suspected peritoneal dissemination. The patient underwent systemic chemotherapy with gemcitabine and cisplatin, followed by FOLFIRI. After 11 cycles of FOLFIRI, the patient underwent complete resection of the tumor, partial cystectomy, and pelvic lymph node dissection.

Discharge Summary: 

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Gender: Male

Age: 56

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Diagnosis: Urachal carcinoma with suspected peritoneal dissemination

Hospital Course:

The patient's condition was diagnosed based on a resection of a lymph node in the groin that confirmed adenocarcinoma. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) revealed a 9-cm mass extending from the bladder to the umbilicus with intraperitoneal nodules suggesting peritoneal dissemination. The patient underwent systemic chemotherapy with gemcitabine and cisplatin, followed by FOLFIRI. After 11 cycles of FOLFIRI, the patient underwent complete resection of the tumor, partial cystectomy, and pelvic lymph node dissection. Pathology results indicated urachal mucinous adenocarcinoma with invasion of the omentum and peritoneal dissemination.

Discharge Condition:

At the time of discharge, the patient's serum tumor markers had normalized, and radiological recurrence has not been detected. The patient remains alive 62 months after surgery without any adjuvant chemotherapy.

Discharge Medications:

The discharge summary does not contain information about discharge medications. Please consult the patient's medical record.

Follow-up:

The patient has been advised to undergo regular follow-up with CT scans and tumor marker level measurement every three months for the first three years and every six months thereafter. 

Discharge Instructions:

The patient should maintain a healthy lifestyle and continue to take precautions such as wearing a mask, practicing social distancing, and washing hands frequently to prevent any infection.

Summary:

The 56-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital with urachal carcinoma with suspected peritoneal dissemination. The patient underwent systemic chemotherapy with gemcitabine and cisplatin, followed by FOLFIRI. After 11 cycles of FOLFIRI, the patient underwent complete resection of the tumor, partial cystectomy, and pelvic lymph node dissection. Pathology results indicated urachal mucinous adenocarcinoma with invasion of the omentum and peritoneal dissemination. At the time of discharge, the patient's serum tumor markers had normalized, the patient remains alive 62 months after surgery without any adjuvant chemotherapy. The patient has been advised to undergo regular follow-up with CT scans and tumor marker level measurement every three months for the first three years and every six months thereafter.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]   Gender: Female
Age: 5 years old   Discharge Date: [redacted]
 
Admission Date: [redacted]  Discharge Diagnosis: Ectopic Ureter
 
Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital for investigation of urinary incontinence. She presented with continuous low volume urine leakage that required 4-5 daily pads. The patient had normal voiding habits and no urge to void. On initial physical examination, the external genitalia showed no vaginal pooling of urine, normal urethral and vaginal openings, but intermittent urine leakage through the vaginal orifice. In her medical history, she had recurrent febrile UTIs since infancy, and was diagnosed with vesicoureteral reflux grade III on the right kidney. Despite chronic chemoprophylaxis, she continued to experience urinary incontinence. An abdominal ultrasound was performed which revealed normal kidneys with duplex-system suspicion on the left side and a normal-looking bladder. The VCUG was repeated, but no VUR was detected. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis was performed, which revealed a duplicated collecting system on the left side, and both ureters extended from the kidney to the point of extravesical insertion into the vagina. Both ectopic ureters were in very close vicinity. A diagnosis of ectopic ureter was made, and the patient was discharged with appropriate follow-up care.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to continue with therapy to address her ectopic ureter. The family was also instructed to monitor for recurrent febrile UTI's, signs of renal dysfunction or incontinence, and to seek medical attention if any should appear.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient was scheduled for an appointment with an urologist for further management of her symptoms related to her ectopic ureter. The family was advised to adhere to the urologist's recommendations to ensure optimal management of the patient's condition.

Summary:
A 5-year-old female was admitted for investigation of urinary incontinence. An ectopic ureter was diagnosed through a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis. With appropriate follow-up care, the patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: [Full Name], Age: 41, Sex: Male

Admission Date: [Date], Discharge Date: [Date]
Admitting Diagnosis: Acute Pericarditis with Reduced Ejection Fraction and Moderate Pericardial Effusion
Final Diagnosis: Acute Pericarditis with Improved Ejection Fraction and Resolution of Pericardial Effusion

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with a one-week history of flu-like symptoms, shortness of breath, chest pain, and fatigue. On examination, the patient was found to have tachycardia, hypotension, and ST segment elevations on ECG consistent with acute pericarditis. Other significant findings included reduced air entry at the right lung base and bibasilar crackles on lung auscultation. 
Initial laboratory tests showed troponin I elevation, CK-MB elevation, increased CRP, and elevated Ferritin. The chest X-ray showed pulmonary vascular congestion and right mid- and lower-lung opacity/effusion. Bedside echocardiogram revealed severely reduced ejection fraction and moderate pericardial effusion.
The patient was transferred to the cardiac intensive care unit and was started on vasopressors and inotropes, along with anti-inflammatory therapy. 
After three days, the patient's ejection fraction improved, and he was able to be tapered off vasopressors and inotropes. Repeat ECHO on day nine showed a complete resolution of pericardial effusion with an improved ejection fraction.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with anti-inflammatory therapy to reduce inflammation in the pericardium. He was also started on Oseltamivir after rapid diagnostic test came back positive for Influenza B. The patient was started on heart failure medications i.e. lisinopril, metoprolol. The hospital stay was complicated by paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, which was treated with amiodarone for rhythm control.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's symptoms resolved completely, and he was discharged in stable condition from the hospital to follow up with cardiology outpatient. 

Follow-up Care:
The patient was educated on monitoring his condition at home and the recommended follow-up with cardiology outpatient. 

Instructions:
The patient was advised to take medications regularly and as prescribed. The patient was instructed to seek urgent medical attention in case of recurrence of symptoms.

Hospital Course:
A 22-year-old male with a known hepatitis B infection presented with low-grade intermittent fever, nausea, and decreased urine output. On physical exam, the patient was delirious with scleral icterus, tachycardia, and a temperature of 101°F. Initial investigations revealed elevated serum creatinine and bilirubin levels. Hemodialysis was initiated on the second day of admission. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura was ruled out, and an abdominal ultrasound showed mild ascites and splenomegaly. A head CT scan was negative, but a chest, abdomen, and pelvis CT showed multiple findings including basal consolidation, atelectasis in the lungs, swollen pancreas, thickened colon walls, hepatosplenomegaly, and kidney and peritoneal hemorrhages. Further investigations revealed a serum fibrinogen level of 292 mg/dL, serum triglyceride level of 496 mg/dL, and a serum ferritin level of 30,304 ng/mL. Blood cultures were unrevealing for microbial growth. A bone marrow biopsy on the tenth day of admission showed cellularity and increased hemophagocytic activity, suggesting hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH). Treatment with etoposide and dexamethasone was initiated per HLH protocol, and the patient showed clinical improvement.
 
Hospital Course Summary:
A 22-year-old male with hepatitis B infection presented with delirium, low-grade fever, and nausea. He was found to have elevated serum creatinine and bilirubin levels and underwent hemodialysis on the second day of admission. Workup for thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura was negative, but a CT scan showed multiple findings including consolidations in the lungs, swollen pancreas, thickened colon walls, hepatosplenomegaly, and kidney and peritoneal hemorrhages. Further investigations indicated the presence of HLH. The patient was treated with etoposide and dexamethasone according to HLH protocol and showed clinical improvement.

Discharge Summary for Patient with Fever, Fatigue, and Weight Loss

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital with complaints of a continuous fever, loss of appetite, undocumented weight loss and fatigue for two weeks. Physical examination upon admission revealed a heart rate of 110/minute, respiratory rate of 17/minute, a temperature of 102°F and blood pressure of 140/90 mm Hg. The patient was started on a combination of intravenous vancomycin and intravenous imipenem/cilastatin. Despite initial therapy, the patient remained febrile. Additional investigations revealed moderate hepatosplenomegaly with multiple hypodense lesions in the spleen, and mild enlargement of the left inguinal, paracardiac and subdiaphragmatic lymph nodes. A suspicion of autoimmune hepatitis was ruled out. Viral serologies were all negative, and blood cultures assessed after five days were negative. The patient was started on chemotherapy with rituximab, cyclophosphamide, vincristine, prednisone, and doxorubicin and achieved complete remission on PET/CT scans.

Hematologic:
A bone marrow biopsy revealed normocellular marrow with an increase in dysplastic megakaryocytes. Hyperplastic erythropoiesis with nuclear cytoplasm asynchrony was also noted. Moderate hemophagocytic activity was evident with prominent histiocytes and plasma cells. The patient fulfilled six out of the eight-point diagnostic criteria for HLH according to the HLH-2004 trial.

Imaging Findings:
An abdominal CT scan showed moderate hepatosplenomegaly with multiple hypodense lesions in the spleen. There was a mild enlargement of the left inguinal, paracardiac and subdiaphragmatic lymph nodes. Diffuse omento-mesenteric congestion and pelvic ascites were also noted.

Pathology:
Left inguinal lymph node biopsy revealed reactive hyperplasia but was negative for malignancy, while liver biopsy revealed a T-cell rich, histiocytic B-cell lymphoma.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was started on etoposide and dexamethasone for treatment of HLH and chemotherapy with rituximab, cyclophosphamide, vincristine, prednisone, and doxorubicin after discovery of a T-cell rich, histiocytic B-cell lymphoma. Follow-up care will include PET/CT scans to monitor for remission and surveillance for potential complications related to treatment.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and hypertension who presented with diplopia, right eye pain, and sinus congestion. The patient was diagnosed with mucormycosis, a fungal infection, which was treated with a combination of IV amphotericin B, isavuconazole, and surgical debridement of necrotic tissue. The patient's condition improved, and he was discharged after 19 days with a plan for outpatient follow-up evaluations with the Infectious Disease, Ear, Nose, and Throat (ENT), and Ophthalmology teams. The patient's T2DM was better controlled with oral antihyperglycemic agents, and his HbA1c improved to 5.0% from 12.4% in three months.

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with mucormycosis, a fungal infection.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with complaints of diplopia, right eye pain, and sinus congestion. The patient was diagnosed with mucormycosis and was treated with IV amphotericin B, isavuconazole, and surgical debridement of necrotic tissue. After 19 days of treatment, his condition improved, and he was discharged with a plan for outpatient follow-up evaluations with the Infectious Disease, ENT, and Ophthalmology teams.

Hospital Complications:

None.

Significant Events:

The patient was diagnosed with mucormycosis and received treatment with IV amphotericin B, isavuconazole, and surgical debridement of necrotic tissue. His T2DM was better controlled with oral antihyperglycemic agents, and his HbA1c improved to 5.0% from 12.4% in three months.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient should follow up with the Infectious Disease, ENT, and Ophthalmology teams as planned. The patient's sitagliptin dose should be continued at 50 mg daily for T2DM management.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 58
Gender: Female
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

SUMMARY OF HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient is a 58-year-old non-smoking female with a history of recurrent papillary thyroid cancer, breast cancer, and liver metastases of unclear origin. She was admitted to the medical intensive care unit due to persistent seizures requiring intubation for airway protection. Brain MRI revealed multifocal white matter edema affecting the occipital and parietal lobes with patchy gadolinium enhancement, predominantly affecting the posterior distribution, but also with frontal lobe lesions with associated vasogenic edema and patchy enhancement. A small acute infarct in the left centrum semiovale on diffusion-weighted imaging was also noted. She developed a fever early in her hospitalization, and extensive workup for infectious causes revealed right lower lobe pneumonia treated with vancomycin and cefepime. Her cerebrospinal fluid studies were not consistent with signs of meningitis or systemic vasculitis.

Based on her clinical findings, a presumed diagnosis of PRES was made, and the patient was treated accordingly. She also developed stress cardiomyopathy with tachycardia, and was started on captopril and metoprolol. However, ultimately, a decision was made for the patient to stop using lenvatinib and continue with lacosamide for epilepsy management. Despite her improved clinical condition, the patient's cancer progression resulted in non-resolving lactic acidosis without systemic signs of poor organ perfusion. The patient was advised to follow up with oncology and neurology for continuation of care.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:

1. Recurrent papillary thyroid cancer
2. Breast cancer
3. Liver metastases of unknown origin
4. PRES
5. Right lower lobe pneumonia
6. Stress cardiomyopathy

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:

1. Captopril
2. Metoprolol
3. Lacosamide

FOLLOW-UP:

The patient was advised to follow up with oncology and neurology for continuation of care.

Hospital Course:

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Patient's name]
Date of Admission: [Admission date]
Date of Discharge: [Discharge date]

Hospital Course:

The patient [Patient's name] was admitted to the hospital with complaints of headache, bilateral pelvic sensitivity and a mass painful to touch in a plastic texture in the Douglas' pouch. During the examination, a mass was detected which was evaluated in favor of leiomyoma. The patient's laboratory reports, including ß-hcg, wbc, hgb, htc, and plt were within the normal range. Ultrasonography revealed a mass consistent with a degenerated myoma measuring 77x82mm, of which subserous component was greater in the posterior wall. The MRI scan also revealed a mass with a hypovascular appearance following a heterogeneous and hypointense IV contrast material with a diameter of 8 mm, which appeared to displace the posterior cervix.

Following necessary preparations, laparoscopic myomectomy was performed. Myoma was removed by morcellating in an isolated bag, and surgery was uneventful. The pathology report, however, revealed a marked cellularity and pleomorphism, extensive necrosis, mitosis >5/10BBA, KI67 proliferation index >%50, weak positivity for p53, and LMS with no detectable lymphovascular invasion. The patient was informed about the pathology report and interned again to perform transabdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salphingoopherectomy. The pathology report revealed an atypical pleomorphic fusiform cell proliferation area in a focal area within the cavity consistent with residual LMS when evaluated together with laparoscopic myomectomy material.

After 3 months from her 1st surgery, PET-CT was performed, and fluoro-2-deoxyglucose (FDG) uptake was noted in the area above rectosigmoid mesentery towards the left abdominal wall in pelvic floor. The patient was referred to a gynecologic oncologist, and a 3rd operation was performed. A mass about 4-5 cm of size in defined localization was excised; there was not any other mass and lymphadenopathy detected during the surgery. The pathology result was high grade malign mesenchymal tumor with high cellularity, extensive necrosis, mitosis 40/10 BBA, and moderate atypia. There was no tumor in surgical margin. The patient is now being followed up by the gynecologic oncologist with appropriate medical treatment. 

Discharge Diagnosis:

Leiomyoma with LMS found in pathology reports.

Discharge Instructions and Follow-Up:

The patient [Patient's name] was discharged with instructions to continue her medications as prescribed. She was advised to follow up on the recommended course of medical treatment. The patient should attend her follow-up appointments with the gynecologic oncologist. If the patient experiences any unusual symptoms or side effects, it is recommended that she contact her gynecologic oncologist.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 75-year-old woman with hypertension, rheumatoid arthritis, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, was admitted to the emergency department for evaluation and pain control for dental pain. On re-evaluation, she was noted to have diplopia and facial droop, which prompted an MRI to rule out a cerebrovascular accident (CVA). A CVA was ruled out, but bone marrow lesions involving the left and right clivus, right Meckel's cave, and posterior margin of the right cavernous sinus were found on imaging. Further imaging revealed a diffusely infiltrative endometrial carcinoma with bilateral adenopathy. Cervical biopsies were obtained and revealed LCNEC of the cervix. Palliative radiation was administered to control brain symptoms, and the patient was scheduled for outpatient oncology for further treatment discussions. However, due to decline in functional and mental status, the patient was no longer a candidate for chemotherapy and comfort care was pursued. The patient passed away two months after diagnosis.

Hospital Course Summary:

This is a summary of the hospital course for a 61-year-old female patient who was admitted with a 2-week history of diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. The patient was diagnosed with Crohn's disease based on colonoscopy findings and treated with intravenous methylprednisolone. However, she developed fevers, chills, and parotitis with MSSA bacteremia. After successful treatment with cefazolin and drainage of abscesses, the patient developed abdominal pain and hemodynamic instability indicating colitis complicated by perforation. A subtotal colectomy was performed, and the patient developed intra-abdominal sepsis. Tissue cultures from the surgical biopsy showed evidence of herpes simplex virus type 2 infection, and the patient was treated with intravenous acyclovir for three weeks. The patient had a prolonged stay in the ICU spanning 42 days due to various complications, including catheter and line-related infections, poor nutrition, and muscle atrophy. The patient was discharged from the hospital on day 122.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient: 56-year-old male with abdominal distension and diarrhea

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

History of Present Illness: The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of abdominal distension and diarrhea that had been present for several days. Physical examination revealed no abnormality. Routine laboratory examinations, bacterial and parasitic stool examinations and viral serology were negative. Chest and abdomen X-ray showed no obvious abnormality. However, endoscopic examination disclosed scattered bubble-like or cystoid nodules, which distributed in transverse colon. Narrow band imaging (NBI) showed clear texture of intestinal wall vessels. The patient was treated with high frequency electrosurgical resection of the gas cysts, and the cysts were collapsed after the gas was discharged. Subsequently, the patient's symptoms improved and he was treated with Bifidobacterium (420 mg/bid) to improve his intestinal function. No antibiotics were administered.

Hospital Course: The patient's symptoms improved after one week of treatment. The lesions disappeared completely after three months of follow-up.

Condition at discharge: The patient was symptom-free.

Discharge Plan: The patient was discharged in good condition. No further follow-up was deemed necessary.

Follow-up: The patient was advised to continue avoiding gas-producing foods and maintain a healthy diet. A follow-up visit was not deemed necessary.

Summary: The 56-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital with abdominal distension and diarrhea for several days. He was treated with high frequency electrosurgical resection of the gas cysts, and the cysts were collapsed after the gas was discharged. His symptoms improved after one week. The patient was discharged in good condition and advised to continue avoiding gas-producing foods. A follow-up visit was not deemed necessary.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Patient Name: [Name]
Sex: Female
Age: 48 years

Diagnosis: Gastrointestinal disease

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with a complaint of constipation for 5 days, followed by diarrhea with abdominal distension. Upon admission, she presented with extensive abdominal tenderness and a fecal occult blood test was positive. Serological markers for autoimmunity and viral serology were normal, as were stool examinations for bacteria and parasites.

Abdominal X-ray revealed multiple intraluminal gas pockets in the left colon, and colonoscopy revealed grape-like or beaded subepithelial lesions with erythematous mucosa distributed in the sigmoid. The endoscopic ultrasonography showed low echo of cystic below the mucosal layer.

High frequency electrosurgical resection of the gas cysts was performed but only partial treatment was necessary due to the risk of infection. The patient was placed on a restricted diet and given parenteral nutrition. Ornidazole and vitamin B2 were administered to regulate intestinal anaerobes, and bifidobacterium was given to aid in digestion.

One week later, the patient was able to consume a half-fluid diet. Her condition steadily improved over the next two weeks, with the lesions disappearing completely one month later. NBI showed patchy erythema and yellow nodules. After four months of follow-up, the patient remained asymptomatic with normal colonoscopy findings.

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged in stable condition. Instructions were provided to avoid gas-producing foods and to maintain a low-diet. She will receive follow-up care with specialists in gastroenterology and nutritional therapy.

Discharge Medications:

The names of the medications given to regulate intestinal anaerobes and aid in digestion are not disclosed in the case report.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 66
Gender: Female

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the gastroenterology ward for muco-bloody stools and diffuse pain in the abdomen due to alternate constipation and diarrhea. She had a history of undifferentiated connective tissue disease (UCTD) for 20 years and aplastic anemia (AA) for 1 year. Physical examination showed extensive abdominal tenderness. The patient had cytopenia due to AA and no obvious abnormality in stool culture for pathogens. Blood cultures were also negative. A computer tomography (CT) scan showed no portal venous gas embolism. Colonoscopy revealed line or pebble-like sessile cysts and irregular forms, mainly in sigmoid. The colonoscopy was incomplete due to the narrowing of the lumen secondary to these lesions. Pathologic findings revealed submucosal cystic structure. 

Treatment:
The gas cysts were treated with high frequency electrosurgical resection. The patient was advised to eat less gas-producing foods and was treated with aluminum phosphate and bifidobacterium, but no antibiotics were prescribed due to her history of AA.

Outcome:
The patient's symptoms of diarrhea improved significantly after one month, and gas-filled cysts became flattened. After ten months of follow-up, the clinical symptoms were still resolved. 

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to continue with a low-gas diet and a follow-up appointment with the gastroenterologist in three months is recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Age: 72 years
Date of discharge: [Date]

Medical History:
The patient has a history of diabetes for 10 years and was mainly treated with medications.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to complaints of constipation and diarrhea. She also had muco-bloody stools and severe abdominal distension. Upon physical examination at admission, extensive abdominal tenderness was observed. Routine laboratory examinations, bacterial and parasitic stool examinations and viral serology were negative.

Diagnostic Findings:
Abdominal X-ray showed multiple intraluminal gas pockets in sigmoid and ascending colon. Computer tomography (CT) examination showed multiple polypoid lesions of the colon. Colonoscopy showed irregular forms of lesions that were covered with mucosa of normal appearance in sigmoid and ascending colon. The narrowing of the lumen secondary to these lesions caused the colonoscopy to be incomplete. NBI showed mucosal redness, which appeared as punctate labelling, and the blood vessels of intestine were clear.

Treatment and Outcomes:
The patient was treated with high frequency electrosurgical resection of the gas cysts. She was also advised to eat less gas-producing foods. The patient showed improvements after one month of treatment with ornidazole and bifidobacterium, which was later changed to rifaximin. After 6 months of follow up, the cysts gas disappeared.

Recommendations:
The patient is advised to continue using insulin treatment for diabetes and to avoid using medications that can produce gas. She is also advised to follow a healthy diet and exercise regularly.

Follow-Up:
The patient's condition has improved and she was discharged from the hospital in stable condition. A follow-up visit is scheduled after 3 months to monitor progress.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [insert patient name]
Date of Admission: [insert date of admission]
Date of Discharge: [insert date of discharge]

Hospital Course:
Admitted for wheezes, exertional dyspnea, and double diffuse rales with a history of emphysema pulmonum. Serological markers for autoimmunity and viral serology were normal, and stool examination was negative. Chest CT showed centrilobular emphysema, and a chest X-ray and CT examination confirmed improvement of emphysema pulmonum. Endoscopy revealed stenosis due to gas cyst in duodenal descending. The patient was treated with seretide for emphysema as a primary disease. PCI was treated successfully with intensive oxygen therapy and bifidobacterium. Follow-up endoscopy after eight months showed improvement.

Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Emphysema pulmonum
2. Gas cyst in duodenal descending

Course of Treatment:
1. Seretide for emphysema as a primary disease
2. Intensive oxygen therapy
3. Bifidobacterium

Follow-up Plan:
Continue follow-up of endoscopy to monitor for any further improvements or changes.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of admission: [REDACTED]
Date of discharge: [REDACTED]

Medical History:
The patient was admitted due to ascites and abdominal pain for 3 months. Previous diagnosis of Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS). Upon physical examination, abdominal tenderness and abdominal mass were observed.

Diagnostic Tests:
Routine laboratory examinations, bacterial and parasitic stool examinations, and viral serology were negative. Serum C125 levels were significantly increased to 1560 U/ml. Abdominal X-ray and CT showed a large presence of ascites in the abdomen, massive hydrops of abdominal cavity, multiple intraluminal gas pockets in rectum, and an ovarian mass which was limited to the ovarian surface without invasion. Abdominal ultrasonography revealed massive hydrops in the abdominal cavity. Colonoscopy showed grape or beaded lesions. Peritoneal biopsy was conducted and diagnosis of primary peritoneal carcinoma (PPC) was confirmed.

Summary of Hospital Course:
The patient was given nutritional support while hospitalized. Unfortunately, the patient's condition deteriorated and was subsequently transferred to a hospital near their home where they passed away.

Follow-up Care:
No follow-up care requested.

Analysis and Conclusion:
Based on the patient's medical history and diagnostic tests, a diagnosis of primary peritoneal carcinoma (PPC) was confirmed. Although the patient received nutritional support while hospitalized, they unfortunately passed away after being transferred to a hospital near their home.

Discharge Summary:


Hospital Course:
The patient is a 70-year-old female with past medical history significant for arthritis and right total hip arthroplasty approximately 9 years ago. She was admitted to our hospital with septic shock, fevers, chills, lethargy, altered mental status, and blood and urine cultures positive for E. coli. On admission, a CT scan of her right hip revealed two partly calcified soft tissue masses associated with the right iliopsoas and obturator internus muscles. Following further investigation, the patient was diagnosed with an iliopsoas abscess and a periprosthetic infection. The hepatic abscess was managed with IV antibiotics and IR placed drainage catheter.

Treatment:
The patient was managed in multiple surgical stages. In the first stage, an irrigation and debridement of the right hip and explantation of components were performed with temporary components replanted with an antibiotic impregnated cement spacer system. The intrapelvic iliopsoas collection could not be fully debrided through the anterior approach, and IR was consulted for drain placement and serial debridements. Four weeks following her explantation, the patient underwent placement of a second temporary weight-bearing custom-fitted prosthesis made from methyl methacrylate with gentamicin-impregnated antibiotics.

Follow-Up:
Approximately 18 months later, the patient presented with hip and thigh pain with ambulation. The temporary prosthesis was removed, and a long porous coated system was inserted. The patient was discharged and followed up monthly in our clinic with no clinical signs or symptoms of recurrent infection.

Functional Status:
The patient continues to have a moderate limp but ambulates without assistive devices. Her pain is much improved.

Final Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with an iliopsoas abscess and a periprosthetic infection following a laparoscopic cholecystectomy with bacterial infection complications.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient is clinically stable and was discharged home in good condition.

Instruction at Discharge:
The patient is advised to complete a 6-week course of IV antibiotics.

Follow-Up with:
The patient was advised to follow up on a monthly basis in our clinic.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Patient Name]
Age: 50 years
Gender: Female

Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the hospital with a complaint of decreased vision in the left eye. She had a 15-year history of seropositive RA and was on methotrexate and deflazacort until 8 months prior to admission when she was initiated on etanercept.

On presentation, the patient showed BCVA of 0.8 OD and 0.1 OS. Funduscopic examination revealed granular infiltration at the temporal macula in the right eye and the foveal area in the left eye. SD-OCT showed swollen ellipsoid zone and RPE irregularities in both eyes. Autifluorescence revealed parafoveal granular hyperautofluorescence in both eyes.

Based on the negative results of various blood tests, the patient was diagnosed with noninfectious uveitis and started on oral prednisolone. However, there was mild improvement a month after treatment, and the patient later experienced a visual loss to 0.1 in the right eye with swollen ellipsoid zone in the fovea and newly developed subRPE yellow-white deposits in the inferotemporal area. 

The patient underwent a 25-gauge microincision vitrectomy of the right eye, which revealed atypical mononuclear cells with positive CD20 immunostaining. PCR of the vitreous fluid was negative for herpes and cytomegalovirus. Given the potential causal relationship between PIOL and anti-TNFα agents, etanercept was discontinued.

The patient was then treated with high-dose systemic methotrexate as well as intravitreal methotrexate injections for induction, and once weekly for eight weeks followed by once monthly for nine months in the right eye. 

Three months after the treatment, the patient showed a decrease in subretinal infiltration and subRPE deposits, which further resolved at 6 months following treatment. Over the course, her left eye showed gradual improvement in funduscopic examination and SD-OCT findings without intravitreal methotrexate injection, potentially due to systemic chemotherapy. The final BCVA of the patient was 0.1 OD and 0.4 OS. 

Medical Diagnoses:
- Noninfectious uveitis
- Primary intraocular lymphoma 

Medications:
None stated in report 

Follow-up Care:
The patient is advised to have regular follow-up care with the physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]
Length of Hospitalization: 14 days

Reason for Hospitalization:
The patient was admitted to the psychiatric facility for psychosis, which was accompanied by disorganized thought processes, paranoid delusions, and hallucinations. Additionally, the patient had a history of dopa-responsive dystonia, which led to an antalgic gait.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient exhibited symptoms of depression, restricted affect, auditory hallucinations, persecutory nightmares, and frequent night awakenings. Urine toxicology screening was negative. The patient's history revealed a diagnosis of dopa-responsive dystonia at the age of 11, and schizoaffective disorder bipolar type at the age of 15.
The initial physical examination indicated left lower extremity dystonia, which improved by the second day, and subsequently resolved by the third day. The patient encountered an aggressive episode on the third day. Thus, intramuscular administrations of haloperidol, diphenhydramine, and lorazepam were given. The physical exams did not show any further parkinsonian or dystonia symptoms. On the sixth day, the patient reported hearing good voices and bad voices, and then on the seventh day, the patient's auditory hallucinations were only "mumbling" voices. By the tenth day, all psychotic symptoms resolved, and the patient slept normally with euthymic mood and full range affect. No further psychotic symptoms were noted during the remainder of the hospitalization.

Condition upon Discharge:
The patient was compliant with medication throughout the whole hospital course and no further dystonia or parkinsonian symptoms were noted since the third day of the hospitalization. On the day of discharge, the patient had no psychotic symptoms, slept normally and had normal spontaneous speech. The patient was discharged with appropriate outpatient follow-up.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was provided with outpatient follow-up for further treatment and medication management. Please refer to the outpatient clinic for further medical assistance.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient should adhere to their new medication regimen and follow-up with their appointed outpatient clinic as prescribed by the physician. The patient shall refrain from using illicit drugs that are not prescribed by their respective physician. Also, in case of any emergence of psychotic symptoms, alert the designated medical personnel immediately.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 82-year-old Caucasian male
Admission: December 2016
Discharge: January 2017 (36 days)

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with dyspnea, hemoptysis, and impaired general condition. On admission, the patient was septic with fever, showing pulmonary congestion and bilateral edema in his lower limbs. The patient had a history of chronic medical conditions including ischemic heart disease, atrial fibrillation, low malignant prostate cancer, gout, and diabetes mellitus type II. The patient had a history of dental complications, including severe inflammation, treated with oral antibiotics. Blood cultures showed growth of Gram-positive cocci. Matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization-time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) was performed, revealing S. equi subspecies zooepidemicus. The patient was diagnosed with aortic valve endocarditis without indication for acute operation. Antibiotic treatment, intravenous benzylpenicillin, and intravenous gentamicin in intervals were initiated. On day five, arthroscopic revision of the left shoulder was performed. Ten days later technetium-99m bone scintigraphy showed intense activity in the left shoulder, suspicious of osteitis. On day 17, control transesophageal echocardiography was performed. None of the subsequent examinations indicated signs of recurrence. The patient recovered from his left shoulder pain and regained normal function. The patient was discharged with oral antibiotics for two months.

Follow-up: The patient was followed up in the Out-Patient Clinics for Infectious Diseases and Cardiology and remained asymptomatic with normal shoulder function.

Diagnoses: The patient was diagnosed with aortic valve endocarditis and osteitis.

Conditions on admission: Dyspnea, hemoptysis, impaired general condition, sepsis, pulmonary congestion, bilateral edema in his lower limbs, ischemic heart disease, atrial fibrillation, low malignant prostate cancer, gout, and diabetes mellitus type II.

Treatment: Antibiotic treatment including intravenous benzylpenicillin and intravenous gentamicin, arthroscopic revision of the left shoulder, and oral antibiotics for two months, was initiated.

Procedures: Arthroscopic revision of the left shoulder was performed.

Condition on discharge: The patient's condition improved, he regained normal function in his left shoulder, and he remained asymptomatic with normal shoulder function.

Medications on discharge: Oral antibiotics for two months. Specific medication information is not available.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: 
Sex: Male 
Age: 34
Admitting Diagnosis: Myocarditis 

Hospital course: The patient was admitted to the hospital with recurrent episodes of retrosternal chest pain, fatigue, and shortness of breath with an elevated troponin T. He had a previous episode of myocarditis four years ago, which required hospitalization. The patient underwent ECG, chest X-ray, and routine blood tests, which came back normal, except for elevated cardiac troponin T. Further extensive screening was done, including inflammatory, viral, autoimmune, and coronary angiogram tests, which all came back negative. The patient underwent a course of steroids and anti-inflammatory medication that resolved his myocarditis symptoms. The patient was discharged with plans for follow-up and a repeat cardiac MRI in six months.

Follow-up: The patient returned for follow-up as an outpatient, where he reported stiffness and aching in his calf muscles. An MRI of the lower legs was performed, which showed active myositis involving the gastrocnemius muscles bilaterally. The patient was referred to rheumatology for further investigation. The patient was diagnosed with ongoing myositis despite minimal symptoms, and given the significant myocardial scarring from his previous episodes of myocarditis, the medical team prescribed long-term immunomodulatory therapy in the form of methotrexate and prednisolone. Clinically, the patient reported significant improvement in his symptoms, and MRI results showed interval improvement in his skeletal muscle myositis. Six months later, a repeat of the cardiac MRI showed resolution of myocarditis, along with persistent, stable, and extensive myocardial fibrosis and preserved LVEF. The patient is tolerating the immunomodulatory therapy well without major side effects, and he has returned to full-time work. 

Diagnosis on discharge: Resolution of myocarditis with persistent stable and extensive myocardial fibrosis

Discharge Instructions: The patient is advised to continue following up with rheumatology and continue with long-term immunomodulatory therapy in the form of methotrexate and prednisolone as prescribed. The patient is advised to report any adverse effects, including signs of infection, new or worsening symptoms, or any questions or concerns.

Follow-up Appointments: The patient is to follow up with rheumatology regularly, and repeat cardiac MRI and assessment in the future, as clinically necessary.

Primary Care Physician: The patient's primary care physician has been notified of the patient's hospitalization, diagnosis, and discharge plan. 

Patient instructions: The patient is advised to follow instructions provided by the treating physician and report any new symptoms or concerns. The patient can resume daily activities as long as it does not affect his health.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:

Name: [Patient Name]

Age: 39

Sex: Male

Medical Record Number: [Unique ID]

Hospital Admission Dates: [Date of Admission] - [Date of Discharge]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with a painless mass in the left neck. The patient underwent a needle biopsy, followed by referral to our hospital. A physical examination was conducted, which revealed a well-defined and lobulated mass measuring approximately 10 × 10 cm. The plain X-ray radiographs showed a soft tissue mass in the left neck with no calcification.

A MRI scan was performed, which revealed heterogeneity with higher signal intensity than muscle on T1-weighted images, low-signal intensity in the septum on T2-weighted images, complete suppression of the signal on T2-weighted fat-suppressed images, and enhancement of the signal on gadolinium-enhanced T1-weighted images. A PET scan was also conducted, showing a Single-Unit Vehicle Maximum (SUVmax) of 1.84, with no abnormal uptake except in the mass. Another needle biopsy was performed, and subsequent evaluation resulted in a final diagnosis of chondroid lipoma.

The mass was removed surgically since it was considered a low-grade tumor. The surgical procedure performed was a resection that was marginally successful, as the mass was encapsulated and markedly harder than a well-differentiated liposarcoma, with a yellowish and lobulated cut-surface. Upon histological examination, the tumor was seen to be composed of myxoid and cartilaginous matrix, and mature fat cells as well as lipoblast-like cells. Immunohistochemical analysis showed that the tumor cells were negative for CDK4, MDM2, MIB1, and Sox9. There was no recurrence observed a year after surgery.



Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with a chondroid lipoma.

Condition on Discharge:

The patient was discharged in good condition.



Instructions and Medication:

No medication instructions are necessary.



Follow-up:

The patient is advised to attend a follow-up appointment to monitor his progress.

Hospital Course Summary:

This 20-year-old female of Salvadoran descent was referred to nephrology at 22 weeks' gestational age due to deteriorating kidney function and the nephrotic syndrome. The patient endorsed pre-conception use of intranasal cocaine and cigarettes, which was not continued during pregnancy. The patient presented with progressive lower limb edema and a history of tea-colored urine, epistaxis, and sinus pressure. On examination, the patient had pitting edema bilaterally with no active joints or rash.

Various tests were conducted, including a 24-hour urine test for protein, urine albumin to creatinine ratio, serum albumin, antinuclear antibody, double stranded DNA, extractable nuclear antigen, C3, C4, rheumatoid factor, cyclic citrullinated peptide, C-reactive protein, HIV, Hepatitis B and C serology, and ANCA serology. The results showed proteinuria and a diagnosis of pauci immune glomerulonephritis was given after a renal biopsy was performed urgently. The patient was counselled about her options and chose to continue with the pregnancy. She was treated with methylprednisolone followed by oral prednisone and rituximab. The patient developed diffuse striae distensae. Her serum creatinine continued to rise throughout pregnancy and at 27 weeks' gestational age, she became hypertensive, necessitating labetalol therapy. She developed thrombocytopenia, which was thought to be immune-mediated in nature. Delivery occurred at 29 weeks' gestational age via caesarean section due to worsening headache, visual disturbance concerning for preeclampsia, and worsening renal function. Maternal CD19+ cells were depleted at the time of delivery. The neonate's birth weight was 1010 grams and spent 10 weeks in the neonatal intensive care unit before discharge in healthy condition.

After delivery, the patient’s creatinine continued to rise, and she was initiated on azathioprine maintenance therapy. At the time of maintenance therapy initiation, the MPO titer was elevated. The patient’s creatinine continued to rise to a level indicating severe renal insufficiency during follow-up. The patient has been counselled regarding kidney transplant as her best long-term option.

Patient Information:
- Age: 33
- Sex: Female
- Admission Date: [date]
- Discharge Date: [date]
- Admitting Diagnosis: Total placenta previa with myometrial invasion to the urinary bladder

Hospital Course:
- Admitted at 37th week of gestation for delivery, with a history of gravidity six, parity two, and abortion three
- Preoperative hemoglobin was 10.8 g/dL, prothrombin time (PT) 10.5 seconds, activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) 29 seconds, international normalized ratio 2.3, and platelet count 385x109/L
- Cesarean section delivery performed for transverse baby with total placenta previa, and a 5-6 cm area of tissue loss was detected at the anterior wall of the uterus, leading to bleeding from the cervix and posterior wall of the bladder
- Pelvic packing applied on the pelvic vessels, bleeding sites sutured with 1.0 polyglactine sutures, and Sengstaken-Blakemore balloon catheter placed in the uterus before suturing
- Bilateral uterine and hypogastric artery ligations performed due to hemorrhage
- Accidental holding and bonding of left external iliac artery released within a minute after distinguishing the vessels
- Patient lost about 2000 cc of blood due to intraoperative hemorrhage and received erythrocyte suspension (3 units preoperatively and 4 units postoperatively) and 3 packs of fresh frozen plasma
- No findings of hypotension or shock at any time
- Patient reported severe pain in both legs in the recovery room with left dorsalis pedis and femoral artery pulses absent
- Diagnostic angiography performed and both external iliac arteries were found to be occluded
- Intravenous heparin (100 IU/kg) administered and angioplasty performed to both external iliac arteries
- Patient and her child discharged on the 4th postoperative day with no further events

Follow-Up Recommendations:
- Patient advised to avoid heavy lifting and strenuous activity for 4-6 weeks
- Follow-up appointments with obstetrician and cardiologist recommended
- Instructed to seek immediate medical attention if any signs of bleeding, infection, or pain in legs occur

Discharge Medications:
- None prescribed

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]  
Sex: Male  
DOB: [REDACTED]  
Admission Date: [REDACTED]  
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]  

Hospital Course:  

The patient, a 73-year-old Japanese man with a history of hypertensive nephrosclerosis, presented with worsening abdominal pain and cloudy peritoneal fluid. He had previously undergone continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) and had a PD catheter removed and inserted on the opposite side due to infection. The peritoneal equilibration test had resulted in high values, and local bowel adhesions were detected by computed tomography (CT) after PD-associated peritonitis. 

During this admission, the patient was diagnosed with PD-associated peritonitis and suspected adhesive small bowel obstruction. As such, he was advised to stop eating and switched from CAPD to hemodialysis. Intravenous vancomycin and cephtazidime were administered, and the PD catheter was flushed to prevent obstruction. Improvement was noted, and oral intake was resumed on day 8. 

However, on day 15, the patient's abdominal pain resumed, and the peritoneal fluid became cloudy with high levels of fibrin and white blood cells. Additionally, fecal material was identified in the PD catheter on day 23. Enterococcus faecalis and Bacteroides caccae were positive on culture. CT indicated intestinal contents had leaked into the abdominal cavity. As a result, the patient underwent ileocecal resection with colostomy creation. The PD catheter was removed. Pathological examination showed inflammatory cells associated with peritonitis in the intestinal wall, but no signs of EPS or amyloidosis. 

The patient's postoperative course was uneventful. He underwent left arteriovenous fistula surgery and has been on maintenance hemodialysis since with no recurrence of peritonitis.  

Diagnoses:  
1. PD-associated peritonitis  
2. Suspected adhesive small bowel obstruction  
3. Intestinal perforation  

Discharge medications: None  

Follow-up: Follow up with nephrology as an outpatient.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

The patient is a 5-year-old female who was admitted to our center for surgical intervention due to anomalous left coronary artery from the right coronary sinus (ALVT) with bicuspid aortic valve (BAV). The condition was discovered accidentally nearly one year ago, and the patient presented no identifiable symptoms before the surgery.

During the hospitalization, the patient underwent surgical repair for ALVT under general anesthesia and cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB). The surgery was successful, and the patient recovered well without any complications. The continuous intravenous pumping of low-dose dopamine lasted for 7 h post-operatively, but no other inotropic drugs were administered.

At discharge, the patient had a trivial aortic regurgitation and normal left ventricular function with a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 65%.

A long-term follow-up for the patient is highly recommended to detect the potential aortic regurgitation and aortic stenosis caused by BAV in the future.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Confidential
DOB: Confidential
Sex: Female

History of Present Illness:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with locally advanced papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) that had invaded the trachea, esophagus, and left recurrent nerve. The patient underwent total thyroidectomy with bilateral modified radical neck dissection, followed by a window resection of the trachea. The patient was then diagnosed with PTC, pT4aN1bM0, stage IVA. A one-stage reconstruction was performed using an auricular deltopectoral flap. 

Hospital Course:
The operation was successful, but a final histopathological estimation of the tracheal margin was positive. Three months after the operation, a recurrent tumor was detected outside the left piriform fossa and was given 100 mCi of I-131 therapy. Nine months after the operation, the patient experienced apparent dyspnea and a dull pain in the right shoulder. A CT scan revealed prominent tumor progression in both the neck and the lung, and bone scintigraphy showed bone metastasis in the right scapula. The patient underwent EBRT for the recurrent neck tumor (60 Gy) and the right scapula (36 Gy), and docetaxel was administered once per 3 weeks for 24 months. The lung metastasis was exceptionally enlarged, but the docetaxel was temporarily very effective for the local recurrence. Three years after the operation, the patient was started with the newly emerged TKI sorafenib. However, because of the exacerbation of lung metastasis, it was terminated in 9 months. Therefore, 45 months after the operation, lenvatinib was started, which showed remarkable improvement for the tumor and lung metastasis. 

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with PTC that had invaded the trachea, esophagus, and left recurrent nerve. The patient underwent total thyroidectomy with bilateral modified radical neck dissection, followed by a window resection of the trachea. The operation was successful, but a final histopathological estimation of the tracheal margin was positive. The patient was then diagnosed with PTC, pT4aN1bM0, stage IVA. Three months after the operation, the patient underwent I-131 therapy. Nine months after the operation, the patient underwent EBRT and docetaxel for the recurrent neck tumor and bone metastasis. Three years after the operation, the patient underwent TKI sorafenib. However, because of the exacerbation of lung metastasis, it was terminated in 9 months. Therefore, 45 months after the operation, lenvatinib was started, which showed remarkable improvement for the tumor and lung metastasis. The present status of the patient regarding diabetes, hypertension, and urinary protein as adverse events were well controlled by drugs and nutrition counseling. The patient was discharged with plans to continue treatment under surveillance.

Hospital Course:

The 54-year-old Chinese male was admitted to our hospital for further investigation of an incidental liver mass. The patient had a history of hypertension for ten years and diabetes mellitus for five years. The patient also had a surgical history of splenectomy. The patient denied any liver cirrhosis and was negative for both hepatitis B virus (HBV) and hepatitis C virus (HCV).

Diagnostic and Therapeutic Interventions:

The patient underwent abdominal ultrasonography (US) and abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan, which revealed a 5cm iso-echoic lesion in the left hepatic lobe, and an oval, slightly hypodense mass located in segment IV of the left liver, measuring 4.5 × 3.3cm. The patient was then subjected to abdominal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), which showed a slightly hypointense mass on both T1- and T2-weighted images, appearing slightly hyperintense on diffusion-weighted images. A partial hepatectomy and cholecystectomy were performed, followed by a postoperative hematoxylin and eosin staining that revealed sinusoidal structures and lymphoid tissue hyperplasia. Detailed immunohistochemical staining showed positivity for CD3 and CD20, specific markers for lymphocyte T cells and B cells, respectively.

Diagnoses:

The patient was diagnosed with intrahepatic splenosis, which was confirmed by the detection of a capsule separating the spleen tissue from liver tissue.

Condition on Discharge:

The patient was discharged home in good condition.

Discharge Medications:

No medications were prescribed on discharge.

Follow-up Care:

The patient was advised for regular follow-up after discharge.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient Information: The patient is a 43-year-old Latin-American male with a degree-level education.

History of Present Illness: The patient was brought to the medical consultation by his wife due to two-year progressive forgetfulness, mental confusion, disorientation, difficulty in finding the right words, changes in mood, sleep changes, and apathy. He also experienced anxiety symptoms. Initially treated for major depression and later as type II bipolar disorder, no changes in behavior were observed. The skin examination showed multiple skin blemishes, mostly on the trunk, which the patient and his wife saw as normal. Neuropsychological tests were done and showed cognitive, emotional, and memory declines. No further neurological signs or stroke-like episodes were observed.

Diagnostic Findings: Laboratory studies for venereal disease, hepatitis B and C, protein C and protein S, C-reactive protein, and rheumatoid factor were normal except for undetermined anticardiolipin antibodies, besides the weak presence of lupic anticoagulant. Imaging studies revealed multiple areas of signal changes with cerebral atrophy disproportionate for his age, diffuse cerebral hypoperfusion in parietal and frontal areas, and vasculitis suggestive of slowed distal blood flow of cerebral arteries with the vessel diameter decreased and parietal irregularities.

Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with SS.

Treatment: The patient was discharged from the hospital with acetylsalicylic acid, corticoids, and oral anticoagulants. 

Follow-up: The patient was advised to visit the healthcare provider for a follow-up appointment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Gender: Female
Age: 54

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Admitting Diagnosis: Incidentally discovered thyroid nodule

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted in April 2017 with a 1 cm thyroid nodule that was incidentally discovered during an ultrasound performed for another indication. Further tests revealed slightly elevated Ct levels, leading to a stimulation test with iv calcium, which showed the need for surgical treatment. The patient underwent total thyroidectomy and central neck dissection (level VI) on the side of the tumor. The postoperative course was uneventful, with only a slight hypocalcemia recorded in the first postoperative day, which completely recovered 48 hours after surgery when the patient was discharged.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with a polilobulated medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) of 1 cm that was composed of cells with eosynophilic cytoplasm, agglomerated in solid nests with a predominantly expansive growth pattern. Immunohistochemistry tests showed that the tumor cells were positive for different proteins, such as Ct, Cromogranin A, Synaptofisin, and TTF-1, and negative for the presence of amyloid. Focal foci of C-cells hyperplasia were spread in the whole gland. No metastases were found in any lymph nodes of the central compartment.

Clinical Features:
The patient presented an incidental thyroid nodule that was investigated further and diagnosed as a medullary thyroid cancer.

Treatment:
The patient underwent surgical treatment with a total thyroidectomy and central neck dissection (level VI). There were no complications associated with the surgery.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was discharged in good condition and will require routine follow-up care with an endocrinologist to monitor the thyroid levels, recurrence of the MTC, and any potential future complications related to the surgery.

The patient resided in an area endemic for Lyme disease in eastern Canada and did not recall an erythema migrans rash. On examination, filamentous inclusions were observed within the skin lesions.

The patient was treated with antibiotics during hospitalization and continued with naturopathic remedies. The patient's symptoms were monitored during hospitalization.

The patient's symptoms persisted despite ongoing treatment. Recommendations were made for follow-up care with primary physician for further management.

None.
