The patient was advised to follow up with her primary physician for further management. No additional discharge instructions were given at the time of discharge.

Follow-up Appointments:
The patient was advised to follow up with her primary physician for further management of persistent symptoms of Lyme disease.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Lyme disease, Babesia and Bartonella co-infection, and Morgellons disease

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 54-year-old Caucasian woman with a history of outdoor recreational activity in Western Canada, was admitted with joint pains, muscle aches, headaches, memory loss, fatigue and skin lesions. The patient had a history of an EM-like rash several years previously and had not received treatment. On admission, initial testing for Lyme disease was negative, but the patient was clinically diagnosed by a Canadian healthcare provider. Later, the diagnosis was confirmed by an American healthcare provider. The patient had positive serological tests for Babesia and Bartonella. She also had ulcerative lesions on her face and torso consistent with Morgellons disease upon examination with a handheld microscope. Filamentous inclusions were observed in the patient's lesions.

The patient was aggressively treated over the last few years with antibiotic combinations including intravenous ceftriaxone, metronidazole, telithromycin, doxycycline, amoxicillin, ciprofloxacin, tinidazole, and atovaquone with little benefit. Upon discharge, the patient's condition remained stable.

Follow-Up Plans:
The patient is advised to follow-up with her healthcare provider regularly and get tested for Lyme disease, Babesia, and Bartonella infections to monitor her condition. The patient should contact her healthcare provider immediately if any new symptoms develop.

Summary:
The patient was diagnosed with Lyme disease, Babesia, and Bartonella co-infection and Morgellons disease. Despite aggressive therapy with multiple antibiotics, treatment has not been effective. The patient should follow up regularly with her healthcare provider to monitor her condition and report any new symptoms immediately.

The patient was admitted with complaints of musculoskeletal pain and extreme fatigue. Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Reason for Hospital Admission:
The patient, a 71-year-old woman, was admitted to the hospital for right retrosigmoid craniotomy and tumor resection.

Hospital Course:
The patient's operation was uneventful, and she was discharged on dexamethasone 6 mg daily for 3 days. Three weeks later, she was readmitted to the hospital with persistent fever and chills, and occasional headaches for five days.

Diagnostic Assessment:
On admission, her vitals were notable for a fever of 38.5 °C, heart rate of 83 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and blood pressure of 158/83 mmHg. A CT scan was ordered, which showed a subgaleal collection overlying the craniotomy site and hypodense areas in the right cerebellum that likely represented postoperative changes. A hypodense extra-axial collection was noted along the right cerebellum. These findings raised concern for postsurgical meningitis, and the patient was started on antibiotics for a presumptive urinary tract infection. However, the patient's condition continued to deteriorate, with the development of nuchal rigidity, altered mental status, and seizures in the next 24 hours. A lumbar puncture was performed, which showed significant inflammation in the cerebrospinal fluid. The patient was then taken to the operating room for placement of an external ventricular drain and intrathecal antibiotic administration. A pathology report revealed fungal elements, and further testing confirmed Aspergillus fumigatus as the causative agent.

Treatment:
The patient was started on liposomal amphotericin and voriconazole for the treatment of CNS aspergillosis, which was eventually transitioned to oral voriconazole 250 mg every 12 hours to complete three months of therapy. The patient's mental status improved markedly over the following days, and she was transferred to a rehabilitation facility for physical therapy.

Follow-Up:
The patient was followed up at four months, during which time she was fully alert, and her verbal communication was almost back to baseline. No focal or meningeal signs were noted on examination, and a brain MRI showed complete resolution of leptomeningeal enhancement with no collections.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with CNS aspergillosis.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged to a rehabilitation facility for continued physical therapy.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient information:
Name: [Patient Name]
Age: 67 years
Gender: Male
Medical Record Number: [MRN]
Hospital Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 67-year-old man admitted due to acute liver failure which resulted in a high bilirubin, acute kidney injury, and altered mental status. His records indicate that he had a history of latent tuberculosis and a recent reduction in the dose of losartan due to fatigue and hypotension. He was treated with INH and pyridoxine for LTBI before presenting to his local hospital.

On admission, the patient was noted to have jaundice, icteric sclera, and altered mental status. He was transferred to the intensive care unit and listed for a liver transplant as Status 1A. He underwent orthotopic liver transplant surgery successfully, but had a sudden aspiration event which led to a fatal cardiopulmonary arrest.

Diagnostic Studies:
Elevated liver function tests were observed initially, and a CT scan and abdominal ultrasound were performed to investigate the extent of liver dysfunction. Autoimmune and viral serologies, acetaminophen levels, serum ferritin, and urine toxicology screening were all tested. The final diagnosis was cholestatic hepatitis due to a drug or toxin.

Treatment:
Potential contributory medications including INH and apixaban were discontinued, and the patient was put on albumin, midodrine, and octreotide for acute kidney injury. Cholestyramine was introduced to treat pruritis. He underwent a successful orthotopic liver transplant surgery.

Discharge Condition:
Unfortunately, the patient experienced a sudden cardiopulmonary arrest resulting in fatal outcomes on post-operative day three. The patient was not discharged as a result.

Follow-up Care:
There is no follow-up care required.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 79
Sex: Female
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Epigastralgia

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Emergency Department with complaints of epigastralgia with two weeks of evolution and aggravation last night. She denied another accompanying symptomatology. Objective examination showed tachycardia, confirmed on electrocardiogram. Analytically, had leukocytosis and eosinophilia and elevation of markers of myocardial necrosis. Transthoracic echocardiography revealed severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction with ventricular septal hypocontractility and an increase in the concentric thickness of the ventricular walls. Valvular disease was not evident. Anti-ischemic therapy was started but coronary angiography did not reveal epicardial coronary disease. After this, the diagnosis of eosinophilic myocarditis in a patient with a known atopic component was likely. The patient was admitted to the hospital for treatment and study. Neuro-humoral, beta-blocker and diuretic therapy were initiated, maintaining aspirin. On the third day of hospitalization, cardiac magnetic resonance was performed which identified subepicardial foci of edema and late enhancement in the left ventricular myocardium and a small pericardial effusion in the free wall of the right ventricle. The ejection fraction was quantified. On the same day, she underwent an endomyocardial biopsy and collection of right ventricular infarct fragments, which confirmed the diagnosis of eosinophilic myocarditis. Systemic corticosteroid therapy was started with progressive improvement of general condition. On the 12th day of hospitalization, the echocardiogram showed a slight improvement in left ventricular global systolic function. She was discharged to home with prednisolone in weaning, and with follow-up consultation of cardiology and autoimmune diseases.

Discharge Conditions:
The patient's clinical condition improved during hospitalization and was stable upon discharge. She was discharged with prednisolone in weaning and was advised to continue the medication as per the instructions provided. She was advised to follow up with consultations of cardiology and autoimmune diseases.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to follow up with consultations of cardiology and autoimmune diseases on a regular basis. She was advised to continue the medications as per the instructions provided.

Discharge Medications:
Prednisolone [REDACTED] mg – [REDACTED] days

Hospital Course:
This is a case report of a 44-year-old female patient who was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2006 and underwent modified radical mastectomy after excisional biopsy revealed invasive ductal carcinoma. The patient was found to have metastatic lung cancer secondary to breast cancer in June 2010, which was treated with an ovariectomy and exemestane. The patient complained of severe cough in March 2014 and was found to have metastases in the lungs and mediastinal lymph nodes, as well as a malignant renal mass. Various chemotherapy regimens were employed, but all failed. A biopsy of the metastatic lesion was performed, confirming lung metastasis of breast cancer with increased expression of ER. The patient was started on fulvestrant and zoledronic acid injections in August 2015, and a partial response was achieved with shrinking of the renal mass and improvement in subjective symptoms. The patient was stable for 16 months until December 2016 when she decided to stop taking fulvestrant. The patient died of epilepsia gravior due to brain metastases in November 2018 after being treated with apatinib. 

Hospital Course Summary:
A 44-year-old female developed breast cancer in 2006 and underwent modified radical mastectomy with no residual cancer or lymph node involvement. In June 2010, metastatic lung cancer secondary to breast cancer was discovered and treated with an ovariectomy and exemestane. In March 2014, the patient developed severe cough, and metastases in the lungs, mediastinal lymph nodes, and a malignant renal mass were identified. Various chemotherapy regimens were employed but failed. A biopsy was performed with increased expression of ER, and the patient was subsequently treated with fulvestrant and zoledronic acid injections, achieving a partial response with shrinking of the renal mass and improvement in subjective symptoms. The patient was stable for 16 months until she stopped taking fulvestrant. The patient was treated with apatinib, and while the cough was relieved, she ultimately died due to epilepsia gravior from brain metastases in November 2018.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Admitting Diagnosis: Mass with Bone Erosion

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 25-year-old woman, was admitted for evaluation of a palpable mass in the middle phalanx of her left ring finger. An ultrasound examination was performed, which revealed a hypoechoic mass of 20 mm with unclear boundaries and punctuate or patchy hyperechoic calcification. In addition, a point-like blood signal was observed on switching to Doppler mode. The bone cortex was involved, and there was a broken continuity. Upon examination, active proliferation in the tumor cells was observed. Based on these findings, a diagnosis of mass with bone erosion was made.

Treatment:
The patient was managed by a multidisciplinary team of healthcare professionals who recommended close follow-up and ongoing monitoring to ensure that the disease did not progress. The patient was advised to avoid any activities that could potentially cause further damage to the affected area.

Outcome:
The patient was discharged in stable condition and will continue to follow-up with the recommended management and monitoring plan on an outpatient basis.

Follow-Up:
The patient is advised to follow-up with the multidisciplinary team of healthcare professionals at regular intervals to ensure that the disease remains stable and the patient's overall health continues to be monitored. Any new or concerning symptoms should be reported immediately to the healthcare team. 

Discharge medications:
None

Discharge diagnoses:
Mass with bone erosion

Discharge disposition:
Home

Discharge instructions:
1. Avoid activities that could potentially cause further damage to the affected area.
2. Follow-up with your healthcare team as recommended.
3. Report any new or concerning symptoms immediately to your healthcare team. 
4. Please bring all copies of your medical records to every appointment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 59-year-old male
Admission Date: [date]
Discharge Date: [date]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our institution with a 2-month history of progressive dysphagia, without hoarseness. Physical examination revealed an esophageal MEC. Surgery was performed as the tumor was deemed to be resectable and the patient was medically fit for an esophageal resection. Esophagectomy, 2-field (upper abdominal and mediastinum) lymphadenectomy, and esophagogastrostomy were performed, and the resected esophagectomy specimen contained a fungating tumor. Based on immunohistochemistry, the tumor was diagnosed as a poorly differentiated esophageal MEC. After surgery, the patient received radiotherapy combined with chemotherapy. Subsequent CT scans showed a thickened esophageal wall but no evidence of recurrence.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted with progressive dysphagia and was diagnosed with an esophageal MEC. Surgery was performed and the patient received radiotherapy combined with chemotherapy. No evidence of recurrence was found in subsequent CT scans.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [date]
Discharge Date: [date]

Patient Name: [name]
Medical Record Number: [number]

Diagnosis: TSH-producing pituitary macroadenoma and central hyperthyroidism

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 55-year-old man, was admitted to the hospital after being transferred from a local hospital due to incidentally discovered AF. After receiving radiofrequency ablation for his AF, the patient was found to have hormonal imbalances indicating thyrotoxicosis, a positive result for TSH receptor antibody, and a thyroid gland that was diffusely enlarged with a nodule located in the left lobe. Fine needle aspiration biopsy suggested that the nodule was benign. Upon further examination, an MRI of the sella region revealed a pituitary tumor measuring 2.3 × 1.7 × 2.2 cm3 in the sella, involving the cavernous sinuses and extending into the suprasellar cistern. Based on these findings, the patient was diagnosed with TSH-producing pituitary macroadenoma and central hyperthyroidism.

One week after diagnosis, the patient underwent transsphenoidal neurosurgery to remove the pituitary macroadenoma. The resected pituitary adenoma cells were found to be positive for TSH and PRL antibodies, with the percentage of positive Ki-67 being less than 2%, indicating that the tumor was benign. After surgery, the patient's TSH levels and thyroid hormone levels returned to within the normal ranges.

One year after surgery, the patient's thyroid hormone levels increased beyond the normal ranges, although no residual tumor was found on MRI. Additionally, positive results were obtained for TRAb, and both TgAb and TPOAb were elevated beyond their normal ranges. The patient was prescribed thyrozol 10 mg/day, which was effective in keeping thyroid function tests within normal ranges during 3 years of follow-up.

During the patient's hospital course, there were no significant complications. The patient was discharged with instructions to continue taking thyrozol 10 mg/day and to follow up with an endocrinologist for further evaluation and treatment.

Disposition:

The patient was discharged to home in stable condition with instructions to follow up with an endocrinologist. The patient was prescribed thyrozol 10 mg/day, and instructed to continue taking the medication as prescribed. The patient was advised to return to the hospital if there were any concerns or changes in symptoms.

Hospital Course:

The 66-year-old male patient underwent a left total knee arthroplasty due to left knee osteoarthritis and varus deformity. The surgery was performed using conventional surgical procedures, and the patient was draping using standard aseptic procedure. During the surgical incision sterilization, there was a skin avulsion, which was approximately 6.5 × 30 cm in the posterior part of the patient's left crus. Petrolatum gauze was used for dressing the areas of epidermal avulsion. Routine postsurgical dressing was done, including gauze, cotton pad, and bandage. The patient was advised to raise the affected leg, keep the wound dry, and sulfadiazine cream was applied to the area of epidermal avulsion. On postoperative day 3, oral cefixime therapy of 100 mg BID was initiated for anti-infection treatment. The wound healing process was observed daily, and dressing changes were performed accordingly.

Hospital course summary:

The patient had an elective left total knee arthroplasty for left knee osteoarthritis and varus deformity. During surgery, the patient suffered a skin avulsion, which was approximately 6.5 × 30 cm in the posterior part of the patient's left crus. The wound was appropriately treated by initially using petrolatum gauze for dressing. Daily dressing changes were performed, and sulfadiazine cream was applied to the area of epidermal avulsion. Oral cefixime therapy was initiated on postoperative day 3 for anti-infection treatment, and the patient was observed daily. After 6 weeks of treatment, the avulsed wound showed no signs of infection and had undergone re-epithelialization. The patient was discharged from the hospital after 2 weeks and was advised to change the dressing every 3 days until the avulsion area was dry. There were no significant abnormalities or complications observed during the hospital course.

Discharge Summary:

Name: Patient X
Age: 82
Sex: Male
Admission Date: November 24, 2014
Discharge Date: N/A

Hospitals Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to difficulty in urinating spontaneously and was later diagnosed with prostatic adenocarcinoma after undergoing a transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) and postoperative pathological examination. The patient had multiple bone metastases as revealed by a SPECT/CT scan. Initial PSA and free PSA (FPSA) levels were elevated. Radiotherapy and chemotherapy were not effective treatment options for the patient. Therefore, Alloreactive CTL treatment was started on December 16, 2014.
 
The patient received two cycles of ACTL treatment from December 16, 2014 to February 10, 2015. The PSA levels significantly decreased after 28 cycles of continuous ACTL immunotherapy. The patient exhibited undetectable PSA and FPSA levels on May 12, 2016. A SPECT/CT scan revealed fewer bone metastatic lesions in December 2016, and no metastatic lesions were detected in other organs, including the lung, liver, and brain, by a PET-CT scan.

Although the patient was initially diagnosed with metastatic lesions at multiple sites of the body, he was still alive after receiving 2 years of immunotherapy. The withdrawal of the ACTL immunotherapy was accompanied by a gradual increase in PSA levels in the patient.

The patient did not exhibit any apparent cardiovascular system-related symptom or graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) during the immunotherapy treatment, despite being diagnosed with high blood pressure and Type II diabetes at the beginning of the treatment.

General condition on discharge:
The patient was not discharged but continues to receive medical attention.

Hospital Course:
The 72-year-old male patient was admitted with persistent pain in the left side of the waist for 2 years. He was diagnosed with schistosomiasis 40 years ago and was also found to have hypertension 1 year ago. The patient had pain on movement of the spine with bilateral Grade IV motor strength in both lower extremities and was diagnosed with a spinal cord and nerve root compression caused by an expanding mass partly protruding into the vertebral canal.

Diagnostic Findings:
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and computed tomography (CT) scans were performed which showed an elliptical abnormal signal shadow in the left side of the vertebral body and left peritoneum indicative of a dumbbell growth. The MRI scan showed an area of increased signal intensity on T2-weighted images in the T12-L4 paravertebral region. At discovery, a slightly longer T1/T2 signal was observed with a size of 8.6 × 8.4 × 12.4 cm on the left side of the L1 vertebral body. The boundary was clear, and an uneven separation was observed. The lesion protruded into the erector spinae muscles and behind the retroperitoneum. The spinal cord was compressed, and the boundary was clear. Bone destruction was observable on the left lateral transverse process of L2, and the left kidney was significantly compressed.

Treatment:
The patient underwent surgical resection of the total tumor followed by spinal internal fixation of L1 to L2 with pedicle screws. Total laminectomy was performed for L1 and L2. Histopathological examination showed the presence of a lobulated neoplasm in a prominent extracellular myxoid matrix. The neoplastic cells were composed of syncytial cords of "physaliphorous cells" that contained abundant pale septated and vacuolated clear to bubbly cytoplasm with mild nuclear pleomorphism. Overt mitosis was not identified. Immunohistochemical examination showed that the lesional cells were positive to CK (+++), S100 (++), CD65 (+), neuron-specific enolase (++), epithelial membrane antigen (+++), and vimentin (+++). The coexpression of epithelial and mesenchymal immunohistochemical markers supported the notochordal lineage of the lesional cells. Ki67 was 3%+ in the lesional cells. The above histomorphological features in conjunction with the immune-phenotype observed confirmed the diagnosis of chordoma.

Outcome:
No heavy ion radiotherapy was performed because the tumor massively invaded into spinal canal and foramen, compressing the spinal cord and nerve root directly. After 5-month follow-up, recurrence was found in the original lesion through the post-operative CT. Due to the complexity and size of the recurrence, a second operation was not possible. At the 15-month follow-up, the patient was deceased after various doctor visits.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted due to a stroke resulting in an infarction lesion in the left frontal lobe, insula, and basal ganglia. The patient received a 5-month speech therapy composed of spontaneous speech, auditory comprehension, repetition, naming, writing, reading training, and calculation. The therapy was carried out for 1 hour per session, twice a day, 5 days a week. The Aphasia Battery of Chinese (ABC) and Boston Diagnostic Aphasia Examination (BDAE) were used to evaluate the language function and the severity of aphasia before and after the speech therapy.

Medical History:

The patient has no history of brain damage.

Summary of Findings:

After the speech therapy, the patient achieved further language functional improvements in spontaneous speech, auditory comprehension, repetition, and naming. The severity of aphasia was rated as level 3.

Diagnostic Assessment:

Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed an infarction lesion in the left frontal lobe, insula, and basal ganglia. Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) was carried out before and after the speech therapy. The corpus callosum was tracked using the self-prepared software package (Functool 9.4.05a). Fiber tracking was initiated at the center of a seed voxel with a fractional anisotropy (FA) of >0.18 and apparent diffusion coefficient of >0.01.

Results:

Results of the follow-up DTI fiber tracking demonstrated that the fiber pathway between the splenium of corpus callosum and the left superior temporal gyrus (Wernicke's area) had been established. In addition, the fiber connections between the genu of corpus callosum and the right inferior frontal gyrus (the mirror region of Broca's area) were increased.

Plan:

The patient was discharged and will continue with follow-up appointments to monitor progress.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Admission Date: February 23, 2014
Discharge Date: September, 2014
Hospital: Not disclosed

DIAGNOSIS:
- Squamous-cell carcinoma with multiple metastases to the stomach and small bowel
- Post-primary pulmonary tuberculosis

HOSPITAL COURSE:
A 61-year-old man presented with progressive abdominal distention. A gastroscopic examination and biopsy suggested the diagnosis of gastric squamous-cell carcinoma in the body of the stomach. The patient transferred to our hospital for further management. Physical examination revealed right upper quadrant pain and tenderness with no peristaltic waves. The patient had a history of active tuberculosis 5 years ago, and laboratory tests showed increased WBC count, and a chest x-ray showed patchy infiltrates and masses in the right lower lung fields. CT scans confirmed the changes of post-primary pulmonary tuberculosis. An enhanced CT scan showed that the primary tumor was not in the lung. An urgent surgery was performed on March 5, 2014, for acute abdomen, and the patient underwent a laparotomy with curative gastrectomy for gastric cancer and small bowel partial resection. Postoperative histopathology confirmed a moderately-differentiated squamous-cell carcinoma with full-thickness infiltration and vessel invasion in the stomach and small bowl. The margins of resection were free of tumor in the specimens, and no regional lymph node metastasis was found in perigastric and perienteric area. The patient was recommended with combination chemotherapy of carboplatin and paclitaxel for 3 cycles. However, in September 2014, the patient succumbed to respiratory failure.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:
The patient was discharged with poor prognosis.

FOLLOW-UP RECOMMENDATIONS:
None.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
None.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 96-year-old female, was admitted to our hospital due to a 7-day history of fever and vomiting. The patient had a 1-month history of abdominal pain, nausea, and lack of appetite. Initial clinical examination revealed full mental consciousness, dehydration, local tenderness in the right upper abdomen without muscular defense, and leukocytosis with neutrophilia. Abdominal ultrasound (AUS) revealed gallbladder stones and widening of the common bile duct. Intravenous antimicrobial therapy, intravenous rehydration, alimentation, and spasmolytic drugs were initiated.

Diagnostic Findings:
The patient's CT scan revealed gallbladder stones, widening of the common bile duct, as well as abdominal aortic aneurysm, left suprarenal tumor, and esophageal hernia that had not previously been diagnosed. MRI confirmed calculous cholecystitis and pancreatitis, likely with inflammatory tumor of the pancreas.

Hospital Treatment:
The patient was treated with meropenem intravenously three times a day for three weeks. The patient did not consent to undergo surgery.

Discharge:
The patient's condition significantly improved, and after three weeks of hospitalization, the patient was discharged home. The patient received restricted dietary recommendations and was administered pancreatic enzymes twice a day at a dose of 10,000 units before meals. At discharge, the patient had no fever or abdominal pain.

Follow-up:
Four months after hospitalization, the patient's laboratory tests showed improvement, and the patient has had no recurrence of fever or abdominal pain.

Discharge Summary
Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Gravida 1, para 0, in labor at 36 weeks of gestation
Principal Diagnosis: Intrahepatic cyst
Other Diagnoses: Low weight for gestational age

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 17-year-old woman, was admitted to our hospital in labor at 36 weeks of gestation. She had not attended any check-ups during her pregnancy. Physical examination revealed a 60% to 70% effaced and 3-cm dilated cervix, cephalic presentation of fetus and an isolated anechoic hepatic cyst measuring 1.32/1.47 cm. The baby was vaginally delivered in cephalic presentation shortly after her mother was admitted. The newborn was diagnosed with low weight for gestational age.

Initial laboratory testing showed slightly elevated aspartate aminotransferase level of 43 U/L and slightly greater than the upper limit of normal (37 U/L) in hepatic function panel. The total bilirubin level was of 5.2 mg/dL. The newborn was referred to the pediatric surgery unit, where further evaluation by abdominal sonography confirmed the presence of a 1.6/0.93 cm intrahepatic cyst situated to the left of the gall bladder, without communication with the gall bladder or the common bile duct. The multidisciplinary team recommended periodic ultrasound monitoring of the cyst.

At 18 months after birth, the baby was reevaluated. Laboratory evaluation showed normalization of hepatic function panel and sonography showed complete resolution of the hepatic cyst.

Discharge Instructions:
The baby was discharged from our hospital with recommendations for continued follow-up with the multidisciplinary team.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Insert Name]
Medical Record Number: [Insert MRN]
Admission Date: [Insert Date]
Discharge Date: [Insert Date]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to severely impairing dizziness and anemia.

Hospital Course:
Upon initial examination, the patient was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and had been treated with oral corticosteroids, methotrexate (MTX) 10 mg weekly, and/or a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug. Her condition had been steady for 16 months, but she experienced multiple symptoms in the following 8 months, leading to hospital admission.

Laboratory results showed normocytic anemia, with hemoglobin (Hb) count of 34 g/L and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 138 mm/h. Additional tests showed rheumatoid factor of 223 IU/mL, anti-cyclic peptide containing citrulline of 885.6 RU/mL, and vitamin B12 of 368 pmol/L. MTX was discontinued and glucocorticoids were administered for 12 weeks. However, the patient's hemoglobin level declined to 32 g/L, and additional red blood cell transfusions were required.

Re-examination revealed dysplastic features on hematopoietic lineages on bone marrow aspiration, leading to a diagnosis of treatment-related myelodysplastic syndrome (t-MDS). The patient's medical history and laboratory parameters suggested MTX was responsible for bone marrow toxicity. Tocilizumab was added to the treatment regimen, which resulted in clinical benefit and improvement in the patient's symptoms. The patient was discharged from the hospital after one month of treatment.

Follow-up visits showed no obvious abnormalities in the patient's laboratory results and bone marrow aspiration results. The prompt resolution of the patient's serological, physical, and pathological abnormalities was achieved with tocilizumab treatment. After six months of treatment, the patient refused further injections, leading to symptoms returning. Despite relapse, the patient's laboratory examination was stable, and symptoms significantly improved after treatment was resumed.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Treatment-related myelodysplastic syndrome (t-MDS)

Discharge Medications:
[Insert medications]

Follow-up:
The patient requires follow-up visits with their rheumatologist and hematologist to monitor their condition.

Instructions:
1. The patient should follow the prescribed medication regimen.
2. The patient should avoid alcohol consumption and smoking.
3. The patient should follow up regularly with their healthcare providers.
4. The patient should contact their healthcare provider if they experience any unusual symptoms or side effects.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: XXX
Age: 20 years
Gender: Male

Chief Complaint:
Abdominal pain in the epigastric region, weight loss, and fever for 2 months.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of abdominal pain in the epigastric region, weight loss, and fever. He had a past medical history of low back pain. Physical examination was normal. Sacroiliitis was detected on X-ray, and human leukocyte antigen B27 was positive. PET/CT scan revealed multiple malignant lymphadenopathies, peritoneal implants, and gastric wall thickening suggestive of linitis plastica. Upper GI endoscopy detected a gastric ulcer at the incisura angularis. Biopsies were conducted, which revealed granulomatous gastritis, Langhans-type giant cells, granulomas composed of epithelioid histiocytes, ulceration, and exudates in the two samples. Exploratory laparotomy revealed granulamatous lymphadenitis with granulomas including giant cells, mostly suspecting TB. Ankylosing spondylitis was diagnosed as well. The patient was put on ATT consisting of (2HREZ/7HR) regimen. At the 6th week of treatment, he gained weight about 6 kg, and he was feeling healthy. Hemoglobin was 12.6 gm/dL. Follow-up F-18 FDG PET/ CT revealed a complete response to ATT with no residual disease.

Summary of Diagnoses:
1. Abdominal pain in epigastric region, weight loss, low back pain
2. Sacroiliitis
3. Gastric ulcer at the incisura angularis, granulomatous gastritis
4. Granulamatous lymphadenitis with granulomas including giant cells, suspecting TB
5. Ankylosing spondylitis

Summary of Treatment:
The patient was put on ATT consisting of (2HREZ/7HR) regimen. At the 6th week of treatment, he gained weight about 6 kg, and he was feeling healthy. Hemoglobin was 12.6 gm/dL. Follow-up F-18 FDG PET/ CT revealed a complete response to ATT with no residual disease.

Condition at Discharge:
Patient is discharged in good condition. Follow-up appointments were scheduled with the treating physicians.

Hospital Course:
An 11-year-old girl was admitted to the hospital with complaints of upper abdominal pain and recurrent vomiting. An abdominal examination revealed a nontender lump in the epigastric region. Laboratory results indicated microcytic hypochromic anemia. The patient had a history of disturbed behavior and decreased appetite for the past few months. A sibling reported observing the patient occasionally chewing on her hair, but did not report it as a significant issue.

Diagnostic Tests:
Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy was performed to assess the patient's condition. The procedure identified a large blackish mass in the stomach with a hair-stuffed material sample. Diagnosed with trichobezoar, an unusual condition where a trapped hairball in the stomach causes digestive issues. Surgery was performed, an anterior gastrotomy, and the large hairball occupying the whole stomach and extending into the duodenum was removed.

Treatment and Outcome:
After the surgery, the patient was discharged following psychiatric consultation. She received routine follow-ups for six months, and the current condition is good as there have been no significant complications or health issues.

Conclusion:
The case study indicates Trichobezoar is a rare digestive disorder usually found among young adults predominantly in females. It is caused by hair ingestion and leads to digestive issues requiring surgical management.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [insert name] 
Date of Admission: [insert date]
Date of Discharge: [insert date]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 19-year-old man, was admitted with complaints of polydipsia, polyuria, muscle weakness, vomiting, and paralysis. He was hospitalized with severe hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis due to renal tubular acidosis and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI). The patient was diagnosed with precursor B-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) with acquired NDI. Leukemic infiltration of the kidneys may have led to polydipsia and polyuria. The patient showed an excellent response to standardized combination chemotherapy and achieved complete remission (CR) at the end of induction. 

The patient refused the best therapy of allogeneic stem-cell transplantation (allo-HSCT) but received haplo-SCT from his father after relapse. A graft-versus-leukemia effect was induced with the intervention of donor lymphocyte infusion, which achieved sustained remission. However, the patient reported a fungal pulmonary infection and was found to have bilateral renal enlargement with low density. On returning to the hospital, he presented with muscle weakness, paralysis, polydipsia, and polyuria and eventually succumbed to NDI and subsequent medullary relapse. 

Final Diagnosis: Precursor B-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia with acquired NDI

Discharge Medications: N/A

Follow-Up Instructions: None.

Consultants: N/A

Signed,
[insert physician name]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 15-month-old girl, was admitted to Peking Union Medical College Hospital (PUMCH) with high fever, irritability, and refusal to walk. She was initially seen at a local clinic for fever and constipation but was treated with ibuprofen. Later, she presented to Haikou People's Hospital with persistent high fever and a lumbar puncture was performed revealing an opening pressure of 140 mm H2O and clear CSF with 120 × 106/L white blood cells. The patient was treated for viral meningitis with an antiviral for 2 weeks but her fever persisted and she refused to walk. 

Clinical Findings:
On physical examination, the patient had a weight of 11.5 kg and a temperature of 40°C. Rashes, lymphadenectasis, and joint redness were not observed. Skin sensation could not be evaluated because the patient responded to any skin contact with exaggeration and crying. The patient's muscle strength and tone were normal even though she refused to stand or walk. The jerk reflexes of her limbs were symmetrical, and her pathological reflex was negative. Laboratory tests showed a peripheral blood leukocyte count of 12.6 × 109/L with an increased eosinophil count of 21.3%. 

Diagnosis:
Parasitic eosinophilic meningitis was highly suspected because of the patient's increased blood and CSF eosinophil count and persistent neurological symptoms. The mother reported that the child had played with slugs. Reference laboratory in Beijing Tropical Medical Research Center reported that the patient's serum sample tested negative for antibodies against A cantonensis. 

Treatment and Outcome:
Empiric treatment with 2.5 mg/(kg/day) levamisole and 1.5 mg/(kg/day) prednisone together with mannose was initiated to reduce intracranial pressure. The patient exhibited rapid recovery, and all of her symptoms resolved approximately 72 hours after the commencement of treatment. Another lumbar puncture performed 4 weeks after the first lumbar puncture revealed that the eosinophil levels in the child's CSF had decreased to 0. The patient was discharged from the hospital and completed 4 weeks of treatment with levamisole and prednisolone. At the 6-month follow-up, the patient showed normal growth and development without sequelae.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Gender: Female
Date of Birth: [DOB]
Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]
Discharge Diagnosis: Organizing right lower lobe pneumonia with a small effusion

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 10-year-old female, was admitted to the hospital with complaints of right-sided flank pain that had been persistent for the last two days. The pain had worsened when the patient was laying down but was relieved to some extent with paracetamol. The initial examinations revealed no abnormalities in the observations, blood tests, or urine tests. Because of the lack of any surgical or medical cause of pain, it was assumed that the pain was musculoskeletal in origin and was associated with playing netball.

However, the patient represented the next day with further complaints of pain, and additional examinations revealed that she was tachycardic and tachypnoeic with a respiratory rate of 32 breaths per minute. In addition, the patient was found to have guarding with rebound tenderness in the right flank and hypochondrium. She was then admitted to the hospital because of repeated presentations with abdominal pain and a rising CRP and white cell count.

A computed tomography (CT) scan was arranged, which revealed an organizing right lower lobe pneumonia with a small effusion. The patient was started on intravenous antibiotics for the silent pneumonia. Nevertheless, the pneumonia progressed, and the patient developed a large parapneumonic effusion. Further, the CRP and white cell count in the blood continued to rise, and the patient showed signs of sepsis and respiratory distress. 

The patient was stabilized and transferred to a tertiary hospital. At the tertiary center, a chest drain was inserted, and intrapleural urokinase therapy and intravenous antibiotics were given. After 2 weeks of treatment, the patient was discharged.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow the prescribed course of antibiotics as directed by the physician until the course is completed. She is also advised to continue regular analgesia and to avoid playing netball until fully recovered. In addition, the patient has been instructed to follow up with her primary care physician within 1-2 weeks to monitor her progress. 

Adverse Reactions:
No adverse reactions have been noted during this hospitalization.

Follow Up:
The patient has been advised to follow up with her primary care physician within 1-2 weeks to monitor her progress and assess any new symptoms.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 41 years
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with symptoms of hemoptysis and chest pain. Chest CT scan diagnosed bronchiectasis combined with infection. The patient responded well to treatment with intravenous antibiotics and hemostasis therapy. The patient experienced recurring disease about once or twice per year and was diagnosed with bronchiectasis with infection every time. Prior to presentation at our department, the patient's symptoms became worse with increased hemoptysis, chest pain, and difficulty breathing.

Laboratory tests showed high white blood cell count, neutrophil percentage, neutrophil count, and low lymphocyte percentage and counts. The test for tuberculin was negative. Blood gas analysis revealed a low oxygen concentration and pH within the normal range. Coagulation time, liver function, and kidney function were all normal.

After admission, the patient received a 7-day course of intravenous antibiotics and hemostasis therapy which resulted in improved symptoms. Enhanced chest CT scans showed an overall increase in texture in the 2 lungs, widening of the bronchus of the lower portion of the left lower lobe, thickening of the adjacent left lower pulmonary veins and arteries, and an increase in patchy blur density around the trachea. There were no lymph nodes seen in the mediastinum and no obvious effusions in the chest. A left lower lobe lobectomy was performed, and postoperative pathology confirmed the presence of a hemangioma of the left lower lobe without any bronchiectasis. 

Outcome and Follow-up:
Following surgery, the patient reported no hemoptysis, sputum, or dyspnea. Lung CT scans showed expected postoperative changes and no abnormal shadows or bronchiectasis. The patient was discharged on [Redacted] and advised for regular follow-up appointments with the treating physician. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
Hemangioma of the left lower lobe of the lung without bronchiectasis.

Discharge Condition:
Stable.

Discharge Medications:
None.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to follow up with the treating physician on a regular basis and perform regular health check-ups. If any symptoms arise, the patient was advised to seek medical assistance immediately.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY 

Patient: 44-year-old woman 

Admission Date: [Date] Discharge Date: [Date] 

Diagnosis: Dilated common bile duct, cholecystectomy history, and splenic heterogeneous subcapsular hematoma 

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted to the hospital with intractable nausea and vomiting associated with severe epigastric pain. Physical examination was only notable for mild epigastric tenderness. Laboratory tests showed mildly elevated liver enzymes, and a right upper quadrant ultrasound showed dilation of the common bile duct, which was later confirmed on magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography as well as a 7-mm common bile duct stone. The patient underwent ERCP with sphincterotomy, which demonstrated a dilated common bile duct with no obvious cause. She subsequently experienced severe epigastric and left upper quadrant abdominal pain with hypotension after the procedure. Repeat laboratory testing at the time showed elevated lipase as well as a decline in hemoglobin. A CT scan of the abdomen illustrated a large splenic heterogeneous subcapsular hematoma and peripancreatic stranding. The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit and managed conservatively with fluids and blood transfusions. The hematoma regressed, and her hemoglobin remained stable. With clinical improvement, she was discharged home. 

Follow-up Care: The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care provider for further management and was instructed to return to the emergency department if she experiences any further symptoms. 

Discharge Medications: N/A 

Discharge Instructions: 

1. Rest and avoid strenuous activities 
2. Keep the incision areas clean and dry 
3. Take prescribed medications as directed by your healthcare provider
4. Follow up with your primary care provider for further management of your condition 
5. Return to the emergency department if you experience any further symptoms. 

Discharge Disposition: Home 

Attending Physician: [Physician's Name] 

Dictated By: [Physician's Name] 

Keywords: Dilated common bile duct, cholecystectomy history, splenic heterogeneous subcapsular hematoma.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]
Patient Name: [NAME]
DOB: [DOB]

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 25-year-old male, right hand dominant and manual labourer by occupation who was admitted to our facility with a chief complaint of pain and stiffness of right elbow for last 2 years. He had mild tenderness along the anterior aspect of the elbow, and restriction of both flexion and extension with elbow range of motion from 30 to 90°. Supination and pronation were normal. Computed tomography (CT) with 3D reconstruction revealed a 4 mm radio-dense ring in the coronoid fossa of humerus with a thin bony shell in the anterior aspect of the lesion, consistent with sub-periosteal osteoid osteoma.

Treatment:
The patient underwent arthroscopic excision of the lesion. The lesion was localized in the coronoid fossa, and it appeared as a hyperaemic bony protuberance covered with hypertrophied synovium. Synovium was shaved with an arthroscopic shaver. Thin cortical shell over the lesion was removed with an arthroscopic shaver. The nidus was exposed and it shelled out easily upon manipulation with a curette. It was delivered through the anteromedial arthroscopic portal and sent for histopathology.

Outcome:
Histopathology of the nidus was consistent with an osteoid osteoma. There was an interlacing network of osteoid and bony trabeculae with some mineralization. Histopathology of the synovium only showed features of non-specific chronic inflammation. Gram stain and culture results were negative. Complete blood counts, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and C-reactive protein were within normal limits. Pain relief after the procedure was remarkable, and he had no pain after 3 days. At the latest follow-up of 1 year, the patient is completely pain-free and has full range of motion of the elbow (0–150°). 

Discharge Plan:
The patient was discharged in a stable condition. A follow-up appointment with the treating physician was scheduled to ensure his continued recovery. He was advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and to avoid repetitive activities that might exacerbate his symptoms.

Signed,
[Name], MD
[DATE]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification:
- Name: Anonymous
- Age: 25
- Gender: Female
- Admission Date: [INSERT DATE]
- Discharge Date: [INSERT DATE]

Admission Summary:
The patient is a 25-year-old female with a history of obesity who had undergone RYGB 2 years prior to admission. She presented with frequent episodes of hypoglycemia causing tachycardia, sweating, and neuroglycopenic symptoms, including confusion, dizziness, and blurred vision. These symptoms occurred during the day and night and impacted her work and quality of life negatively. 

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent Continuous Glucose Monitoring (CGM) with Dexcom G4 PLATINUM for seven days, which revealed ample blood glucose excursions throughout the day with glucose peaks above 200 mg/dL after meals, followed by a rapid fall below 55 mg/dL. CGM also showed low glucose levels during the night, as demonstrated by significant time spent below 55 mg/dL. Based on the continuous glucose profile, the diagnosis of PBH was posed. Glucose variability indexes with coefficient of variation (CV), standard deviation (SD), and mean amplitude of glycemic excursions (MAGE) increased. 
The patient was prescribed a normocaloric high-fiber, low-carbohydrate index diet with multivitamin and mineral supplements to address deficiencies of vitamin D and iron. After nutritional therapy, the symptoms improved, but the patient continued to report early morning asthenia and tiredness, associated with glucose levels below 70 mg/dL. A starting dose of uncooked cornstarch, gradually increased from 30 g to 85 g over time, administered before going to bed, resulted in a remarkable reduction in glucose variability indexes and postprandial glycemic peaks. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with Post-Bariatric Hypoglycemia (PBH) related to Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass (RYGB). 

Discharge Medications:
No medication reportable at this time.

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient should continue the prescribed normocaloric high-fiber, low-carbohydrate index diet with multivitamin and mineral supplements, along with the uncooked cornstarch supplementation before bedtime, which was incrementally increased to 85 g for PBH management. Further follow-up for RYGB and PBH management is recommended with endocrinology consultation due to ongoing symptoms of hypoglycemia. 

Disposition and Condition on Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient:
The patient is a 50-year-old female who underwent radical resection of left renal carcinoma and renal hilar lymph node dissection.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with a left renal mass, which was identified during an ultrasound examination. Subsequent imaging revealed a 7.9 × 7.6 cm mixed-density mass in the upper pole of the left kidney. The mass demonstrated a slightly high- and low-density necrosis with an uneven enhancement pattern. The left renal pelvis was obscured by the tumor, and an enlarged lymph node was observed in the left renal hilum.

Surgery:
The patient underwent radical resection of the left renal carcinoma and renal hilar lymph node dissection. The resection involved the perirenal fascia, perirenal fat, kidney, ipsilateral adrenal, ureter above the iliac blood vessel bifurcation, and abdominal aorta and inferior vena cava lymph node from the angle of diaphragm to the bifurcation of the abdominal aorta. On incision of the kidney, a 9 × 8 × 8 cm gray-white tumor and atrophied renal parenchyma were observed.

Pathology:
Pathological examination of the resected mass revealed XP11.2 translocations/TFE3 gene fusions associated renal cell carcinoma with a size of 9 × 8 × 8 cm. Vascular regions displayed evidence of invasion by carcinoma. Left renal hilar lymph nodes were found to have metastases (2/2).

Immunohistochemistry:
Immunohistochemical analysis of tissue samples revealed positive expression for CAIX, CD117, Ki67, Melan-A, TFE3, AE1/AE3, and CK8/18. The analysis further demonstrated negative expression for CD10, CK7, HMB, P504 s, Vimentin, EMA, PAX-8, and SMA.

Follow-up:
Following surgery, the patient was prescribed sorafenib 400 mg bid. A follow-up PET-CT scan did not reveal any indications of lymph node or organic metastases. The tumor was staged as T2N2M0 and IV stage based on the AJCC Cancer Staging Manual. The patient was discharged in good condition and is expected to continue follow-up consultations with the healthcare provider.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Name]
Age: 31
Gender: Female
Admission date: [Date]
Discharge date: [Date]

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient was admitted for radical resection of right renal carcinoma after CT scans revealed a solid cystic and low-density foci in the right kidney. The surgery was performed under general anesthesia. The kidney was opened, and a white mass of 4 cm size and fine papilla on the surface of the lump in the right kidney was observed. Postoperative pathology revealed Xp11.2 translocations/TFE3 gene fusions associated with renal cell carcinoma. The patient did not receive any other treatments and tolerated the surgery well.

IMPRESSION:
The patient underwent the successful resection of renal cell carcinoma associated with Xp11.2 translocations/TFE3 gene fusions. A follow-up examination one month after the operation showed no recurrence.

PLAN:
The patient will be monitored for any signs of recurrence of renal cell carcinoma. Further follow-up and imaging studies will be recommended as necessary.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient should continue her hemodialysis without any changes. The patient should make sure to attend all scheduled follow-up appointments and imaging studies. Any unusual symptoms should be reported to their primary care physician immediately.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
Renal cell carcinoma associated with Xp11.2 translocations/TFE3 gene fusions. 

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
None.

DISCHARGE DISPOSITION:
The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 45-year-old male, presented with right lumbago accompanied by a lower echo mass in the lower pole of the right kidney. The patient was admitted to the hospital and underwent B mode ultrasonography, which revealed a tumor with a size of 5.4 × 4.8 cm, a regular shape, and an uneven internal echo. A round tumor of the same size was further confirmed by middle abdomen plain and enhanced CT. Subsequently, laparoscopic radical nephrectomy was performed to open the right kidney to remove the tumor.

Diagnosis:

The tumor was determined to be a translocation of XP11.2 tumor associated with pigment differentiation and showed a low malignant biological behavior. Immunohistochemistry revealed that it was positive for HMB45, Melan-A, S100, Ki67, and TFE3. 

Follow-up:

After the surgery, the patient remained stable with no recurrence or complications within the 3-month follow-up period. No other treatments were administered to the patient at this time. 

Recommendations:

The patient is advised to attend regular check-ups to monitor for any recurrence of the tumor. The patient was also instructed to maintain a healthy lifestyle, including regular exercise and a balanced diet.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 21-month-old previously healthy boy with lower extremity weakness and lumbar pain after an upper respiratory tract infection. He was dismissed with a diagnosis of transient hip arthritis and anti-inflammatory therapy, but returned to the emergency department a few days later due to worsening pain and inability to walk.

Diagnostic Assessment:
Upon admission, a spine radiograph showed slight reduction in the thickness of the L5 soma. A spine MRI revealed T1 post-enhancement increased signals of the anulus L4–L5, opposite end-plates of L4 and L5, adjacent soft tissues, and the osteolytic area of the L5 pedicle. Diagnosis of spinal dysdiaethesia with associated osteomyelitis was made. Blood exams showed an increase in ESR and CRP, but normal WBC and negative Quantiferon TB-gold test. 

Treatment and Management:
The patient was treated with broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics and anti-inflammatory treatment. Ceftazidime was used when the patient developed leukopenia with severe neutropenia. The patient was discharged with oral therapy of linezolid and cefuroxime axetil. After 12 weeks of treatment, the MRI showed complete resolution of the infectious process. 

Follow-up:
The patient remained asymptomatic throughout the 3 year follow up. Blood exams and imaging showed normal results. 

Summary:
This 21-month-old boy presented with lower extremity weakness and lumbar pain after an upper respiratory tract infection. He was diagnosed with spinal dysdiaethesia with associated osteomyelitis confirmed by MRI. Treatment with broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics and anti-inflammatory therapy, followed by oral antibiotics, resulted in complete resolution of the infectious process. The patient has been asymptomatic and showing normal results during the 3 year follow up.

Discharge Summary:

Medical History:
A 3-year-old male patient with intermittent lumbar pain and difficulty walking was admitted to our emergency department. The patient had an uneventful past medical history until 4 months earlier when he had a lumbar trauma. The patient visited an emergency care unit three months after the trauma due to increased lumbar pain and received oral therapy with a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug for a week.

Hospital Course:
Ten days after discontinuation of oral therapy, the patient's lumbar pain worsened, which led to admission to our department. The patient underwent a physical examination, abdominal ultrasonography, and laboratory blood tests, which were normal or only slightly abnormal. The ESR, CRP and procalcitonin were slightly abnormal, but the patient's WBC count was normal. An MRI scan of the spine showed a T1 post-enhancement had increased the signal of the anulus L3–L4 of the adjacent soft tissue, suggesting an infective SD. The patient was started on broad-spectrum, anti-infective intravenous therapy with piperacillin–tazobactam and vancomycin and oral anti-inflammatory therapy.

The patient responded well to the therapy and experienced a rapid clinical improvement. After 4 weeks of therapy, a second MRI was performed, which showed no significant radiological changes. The therapy was modified, and the patient remained on antibiotic therapy for 16 weeks in total. Immunological exams were normal, and no causative infectious agent was documented. The therapy was well-tolerated, and the patient did not experience any side effects.

Follow-up:
During a 3-year follow-up, the patient experienced only one episode of back pain, which promptly resolved. The patient underwent an MRI, which ruled out the possibility of a reactivation of the infection. No lumbar pain was reported after the episode, and the patient maintained normal life.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with infective SD.

Summary:
The 3-year-old male patient was admitted to our department with intermittent lumbar pain and difficulty walking. The patient had sustained a lumbar trauma 4 months earlier but was not investigated at that time. The patient was diagnosed with an infective SD and responded well to antibiotic therapy. During a 3-year follow-up, the patient maintained a normal life without experiencing any lumbar pain.

Patient Information:
Name: [redacted]
Age: 11
Sex: Male
Nationality: Moroccan

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted to the Pediatric Ward of the Perugia General Hospital in July 2016 due to fever, chills, night sweats, dry cough, headache, and weight loss.

Medical History:
The patient had previously experienced an increase in eosinophils and had lost approximately 7 kg in weight over the course of a month.

Diagnostic Findings:
The patient exhibited peripheral eosinophilia with HE on a blood cell count. However, a number of other tests did not reveal an underlying cause, such as parasitological fecal examinations, tests for infections and autoimmune diseases, and radiological studies. A bone marrow aspiration revealed an increase in eosinophils and lymphoid blasts compatible with B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). A hyperdiploid karyotype and increased IL-5 production were also detected.

Treatment:
The patient was initiated on prednisone prophase, which resulted in a marked drop in eosinophil count and significant clinical improvement. The patient was subsequently assigned to the standard risk group of the AIEOP ALL 2009 protocol and is undergoing maintenance therapy.

Disposition and Follow-up:
The patient remains in complete remission and will discontinue maintenance therapy in August 2018.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [redacted]
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

History of Present Illness:
The patient was admitted with complaints of gross hematuria and dysuria. Clinical examination revealed no abnormalities except diffuse skin thickening. Urinalysis showed >100 red blood cells and leukocytes/μL, and cystoscopy revealed a white-yellowish plaque in the bladder. Stain of von Kossa showed Michaelis–Gutmann bodies. 

Hospital Course:
The patient was treated with ciprofloxacin 500 mg orally twice daily for 2 weeks, and no intravenous antibiotics were given. After completing the course of antibiotics, she reported neither hematuria nor dysuria and the urinalysis showed 5–10 leukocytes/μL and 1–2 red blood cells/μL. She continued taking prophylactic dose of trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole as well as prednisolone and methotrexate.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was treated for gross hematuria and dysuria with ciprofloxacin 500 mg orally twice daily for 2 weeks. After completing the course of antibiotics, she reported neither hematuria nor dysuria, and her urinalysis showed decreased levels of leukocytes and red blood cells. The patient continued her preexisting medications and followed up with her physician for further evaluation. 

Disposition:
The patient was discharged in a stable condition and advised to continue taking prophylactic dose of trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole, prednisolone, and methotrexate as prescribed by her physician. She is advised to follow up with her physician for further evaluation regarding underlying systemic sclerosis and possible sequelae of bladder plaque. 

Final Diagnosis:
Gross hematuria and dysuria, with Michaelis-Gutmann bodies detected in bladder plaque. The patient's underlying conditions include diffuse systemic sclerosis and pulmonary fibrosis. No further visceral involvement was established during the current admission.

Follow-Up:
The patient was advised to follow up with her physician for further evaluation regarding the underlying systemic sclerosis and possible sequelae of bladder plaque.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
DOB: [redacted]
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Asthenia and weight loss
Final Diagnosis: Pediatric-onset adult sarcoidosis with liver, splenic, and abdominal lymphadenopathy and mild pulmonary fibrosis

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the general pediatrician with complaints of asthenia and weight loss in the previous month. Physical examination revealed hepatosplenomegaly, abdominal lymphadenopathy, and a hypo-echogenic solid neoformation in front of the celiac artery. She was subsequently admitted to the Department of Pediatrics of the Meyer Children’s Hospital for further diagnostic investigations.

Initial laboratory tests found microcytic iron deficiency anemia, and Chest X-ray was negative. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) examination of the superior and inferior abdomen with contrast medium confirmed increased liver dimensions and its structural inhomogeneity with zones of signal alteration. Suspecting a systemic lymphoproliferative disease, we performed liver and lymph node ultrasound-guided biopsy, which showed non-necrotizing granulomatous inflammation, resembling sarcoidosis, and aspects of non-specific inflammation of the liver.

During hospitalization, the patient's condition remained good, and she exhibited no signs of fever. Considering lymph node hypertrophy and the signs of initial portal hypertension, we started therapy with prednisone 40 mg/day and subsequent cross-therapy with mycophenolate mofetil. The patient came back to our attention a month after discharge for a follow-up visit, where she was found to be in good general condition, with hepatomegaly and without other clinical signs or symptoms. A brain MRI was performed in order to rule out cerebral involvement and it revealed normal findings. One year later, she maintained good clinical condition and normal laboratory tests, and MMF was gradually reduced and definitively suspended after 18 months.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient will have periodic follow-up visits, consisting of clinical and laboratory evaluation every 6 months and annual pulmonary function tests, unless clinical or laboratory new findings. The patient will be advised to promptly notify her healthcare provider of any new symptoms or worsening of current symptoms.

Signed,
[redacted] 
Attending Physician.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Sex: Male
Age: 9 years
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our tertiary care children's hospital in Sri Lanka with a history of abdominal pain and gross haematuria since two weeks. Ultrasonography of abdomen revealed a 2 cm calculus in the right middle moiety of kidney non-obstructing. Subsequent biochemical investigations revealed a persistent hypouricemia and markedly elevated fractional excretion of uric acid (FE-UA). Secondary causes of hypouricemia were ruled out. Genetic analysis of the SLC22A12 and SLC2A9 gene was performed after informed consent, which confirmed the presence of RHUC.

Treatment:
The patient received supportive care during the hospital stay, including pain management and monitoring of urine output and vital signs. The patient was advised to maintain a healthy diet and increase fluid intake to prevent further stone formation.

Follow-up:
The patient was discharged with a referral to a nephrologist for further management of RHUC.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Renal Hypouricemia with Urolithiasis (RHUC)

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was stable at the time of discharge and was advised to follow-up with a nephrologist for further management of RHUC.

Discharge Medications:
None

Discharge Instructions:
1. Maintain a healthy diet and increase fluid intake to prevent further stone formation.
2. Follow-up with a nephrologist for further management of RHUC.

Discharge Condition:
Stable

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of lower back pain who presented to the hospital and was diagnosed with L2/3 spondylitis. The patient had a previous medical history significant for hypertension and diabetes. He also underwent cervical laminoplasty for ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament and diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis 19 years prior. He had no previous history of tuberculosis infection and BCG vaccination history was unknown.

Physical examination revealed vertebral tenderness at the L2/3 level, and laboratory analysis showed a high ESR and CRP level. Imaging studies revealed collapsed endplates of L2/3 and fluid collection in the anterior part of the vertebral bodies.

During his hospital stay, the patient underwent an L2/3 disc biopsy, which was negative for bacteria culture and Ziehl-Neelsen staining. A computed tomography scan showed soft tissue development in the adjacent abdominal aorta at the L3 level.

Treatment:
The patient was started on empirical therapy with intravenous ceftriaxone but later underwent a 2-stage operation due to the suspicion of an infectious aortic aneurysm and spondylitis with adjacent infectious aortic aneurysm.

After the first-stage operation, pathogenic bacteria was considered to be BCG, and therefore, multidrug therapy with antituberculosis drugs, including INH, RFP, and EB, was started. PCR-based genomic deletion analysis was performed using the specimens, which confirmed the diagnosis.

Outcome:
After therapeutic intervention, the patient's WBC count, ESR level, and CRP level were improved, and MRI displayed no active infection in the spine, epidural space, peripheral muscle tissue, or aorta. The patient was discharged from our hospital and transferred to a different hospital for physical rehabilitation.

Follow-Up:
The patient was advised to continue his multidrug therapy and follow-up with his primary care physician for further management of his chronic medical conditions, hypertension, and diabetes. Follow-up appointments were arranged with the rehabilitation team to ensure the patient's recovery progress, and he was provided with detailed written discharge instructions.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]

Medical Record Number: [MRN]

Admission Date: [Date]

Discharge Date: [Date]

Admission Diagnosis: Myocardial infarction

Discharge Diagnosis: Left ventricular free wall rupture

Treatment: Percutaneous coronary intervention, surgical repair of the rupture

Course of Hospitalization:

The patient was admitted to our emergency department with a history of hypertension, insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, and a carotid endarterectomy. He complained about persisting and progressive angina for two hours, general malaise, and decreased exercise tolerance in the week before hospital admission. His physical examination showed normal cardiac sounds on auscultation, blood pressure of 110/60 mmHg, and a heart rate of 90 bpm.

The patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, aVF and V5-V6 and ST-segment depression in leads V1-V2. Serum troponin T was significantly elevated at 956 ng/L, creatine kinase myocardial band (CK-MB) was within normal limits and creatine kinase (CK) was slightly elevated. The patient's coronary angiography revealed single-vessel coronary artery disease, and he underwent a percutaneous coronary intervention of the circumflex coronary with placement of a drug-eluting stent. Following the procedure, the patient achieved a Thrombolysis In Myocardial Infarction (TIMI) grade 2 flow in the AMI culprit coronary artery.

The patient was discharged after a successful percutaneous coronary intervention. However, fifty days after the procedure, the patient experienced progressive fatigue and chest pain with haemodynamic instability. Transthoracic echocardiography revealed a covered left ventricular free wall rupture (LVFWR) of the lateral wall and extensive pericardial fluid and inflow obstruction.

The patient was brought to the operation room for an emergent repair of the rupture. The surgical technique avoided damage to the anterolateral papillary muscle (ALPM) and did not result in significant mitral regurgitation. Postoperative recovery was uneventful, and the patient was discharged 12 days after the operation.

Result/Follow Up:

More than a year later, the patient did not experience any subsequent cardiac events, and his functional status was similar to the level before the episode of myocardial infarction and rupture.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:

Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 23
Gender: Male
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our clinic with a midshaft anterior cortex tibial stress fracture that had failed to heal. He had previously undergone immobilization, electromagnetic field therapy, and an operation with an im nail insertion that did not result in fracture consolidation. A tension band plate fixation with bone grafting was performed to address the nonunion of the fracture. The necrotic bone and callus at the fracture site was debrided, transverse drilling was performed around the fracture site, bone marrow was inserted, and a tension band plate was applied over the im nail. Postoperatively, the patient was advised to wear an orthotic boot and avoid weightbearing for 6 weeks, followed by progressive weight bearing and range of motion exercises.

Clinical Findings:

On examination, the patient had pain and swelling at the fracture site and required crutches for ambulation. However, no pathologic findings were identified in the peripheral nervous system of his lower extremities or laboratory tests for possible endocrine or metabolic disorders.

Treatment:

The patient underwent a tension band plate fixation with bone grafting and without removal of the nail. A 6-hole, 4.5 mm locking compression plate was used, which was prebended and applied in a compression manner to achieve a tension band effect to the fracture site. Cortical and unicortical locking screws were inserted, bypassing the nail in order to minimize pressure at the periosteum.

Outcome:

After 6 weeks of non-weightbearing, the patient progressively resumed weight bearing, range of motion exercises, and physical activities. He was pain-free at 3 months postoperatively and returned to full training with no symptoms and complete radiologic union of the fracture at 6 months postoperatively. The patient was able to resume his preinjury high competition level in football.

Recommendations:

The patient was advised to continue physical therapy and activity modifications as needed for the prevention of future fractures. He was also instructed to seek medical attention should he experience any recurrence of fracture symptoms.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Gender: Male
Age: 16 years
Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A 

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented to the oral and maxillofacial surgery department of Tehran University of Medical Sciences with bilateral TMJ ankylosis that had been induced due to trauma when he was 4 years old. The bilateral TMJ ankylosis had relapsed after two unsuccessful surgeries. The patient was experiencing sleeping disorders and mostly slept in a prone or a sitting position due to respiratory problems. Due to old injuries and unsuccessful surgeries, the mandibular deficiency had developed, and lateral and forward motions of the mandible were restricted.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent a two-step treatment plan, starting with the gap arthroplasty method, followed by DO. After the gap arthroplasty surgery, physiotherapy was started, which was followed by a soft diet to aid in jaw-opening exercises. A normal diet was started after three to four weeks, and the patient was evaluated once a week to track changes.

Four months later, the osteodistractor was installed with a custom-made device called the Sh-device to prevent upward and backward shifts of the proximal mandibular segment. Recommended displacement rate of the Sh-device was 0.5mm per day, which was carried out for a month. The mandible moved about 15 to 20mm forward, and the patient's breathing and sleeping improved.

At the 8-year follow-up, the patient's profile was satisfactory, and the maximum incisal opening had increased to 38mm.

Summary:
The patient, a 16-year-old boy, presented with bilateral TMJ ankylosis that had relapsed after two unsuccessful surgeries. A two-step treatment plan was performed, starting with the gap arthroplasty method, followed by DO. After the successful installation of the osteodistractor, a custom-made device called the Sh-device was used for a month for recommended mandibular displacement. The patient's breathing and sleeping improved, and at the 8-year follow-up, his profile was satisfactory, and there was an increased maximum incisal opening. The patient was advised to continue physiotherapy and follow the recommended diet plan.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

DOB: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Nonspecific abdominal symptoms

Principal Diagnosis: Neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 71-year-old male with a history of insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, initially presented to our emergency department with nonspecific abdominal symptoms consistent with bloating and a feeling of abdominal enlargement. He had no history of neoplasms or previous abdominal examination. Following a computed tomography (CT) scan, the patient was referred to our clinic due to the detection of a tumor in the pancreatic head. On physical examination, the patient presented with a soft, non-tender abdomen without palpable masses, icterus, or lymphadenopathy. The patient’s vital signs, with the exception of some abnormal laboratory values, were within normal limits. An ultrasound and endoscopic ultrasound of the abdomen revealed a tumor in the area between the neck and body of the pancreas. A contrast-enhanced CT showed an almost 3 cm round, well-defined and homogeneous tumor in the same location. A biopsy, histopathological, and immunohistochemical examination confirmed the diagnosis of a well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas. The patient underwent pancreas resection and a 68gallium-DOTATOC positron emission tomography (PET)/CT scan four months after the surgery did not show increased metabolic uptake.

Hospital Course:

On admission, the patient’s blood glucose was controlled with insulin glargine. On discharge, the patient’s most recent glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) was 8.7% and his diabetes medication was modified to a combination of insulin glargine, insulin glulisine, and metformin due to his elevated HbA1c reading.

Discharge Medications:

Insulin glargine, insulin glulisine, and metformin

Follow-up:

The patient was advised to follow up with his healthcare provider in 1 to 2 weeks to monitor any changes in his condition.

Summary:

The patient was admitted to our facility with nonspecific abdominal symptoms that led to the diagnosis of a neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas. Following pancreas resection and imaging, the diagnosis was confirmed and the patient was treated accordingly. The patient’s diabetes medication was modified based on follow-up HbA1c readings. The patient was advised to follow up with his healthcare provider for any changes in his condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 26-year-old right-handed white woman with a history of multiple sclerosis (MS), was admitted to the hospital on [Redacted]. She was diagnosed with progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) based on a surveillance MRI of her brain that showed asymmetric confluent non-enhancing hyperintensities in the bilateral subcortical precentral gyri consistent with PML.
