Cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) showed quantitative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for JC virus (JCV) and a diagnosis of PML was made based on compatible neuroimaging findings along with the presence of JCV DNA in the CSF. 

Treatment was initiated with orally administered mefloquine loading dose followed by 250 mg weekly and mirtazapine 15 mg daily. Repeat MRI after two months showed no changes in her brain lesions, but mild dysmetria of her left hand was noticed by the patient at three months after diagnosis. A repeat brain MRI revealed a few small enhancing lesions in her left frontal lobe suggestive of immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). She was treated with intravenously administered immunoglobulin followed by high-dose methylprednisolone and restarted on glatiramer acetate for MS treatment.

Five months following the diagnosis, a repeat brain MRI showed interval development of T2 signal abnormality with mild enhancement in multiple areas including the brainstem, cerebellum, and bilateral cerebral hemispheres. Given the MRI findings, she was treated with high-dose intravenously administered methylprednisolone for a total of six courses until there was significant resolution of enhancement on her brain MRI. The patient was then transitioned from glatiramer acetate to ocrelizumab for MS treatment.

At 1-year follow-up, the patient reported residual left-hand dysmetria and tremor and right upper extremity phasic spasms. Her Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) score was 2.0.

Diagnoses:
1. Multiple Sclerosis
2. Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy 

Procedures:
None.

Medications:
1. Mefloquine
2. Mirtazapine
3. Glatiramer acetate
4. Ocrelizumab
5. High-dose intravenously administered methylprednisolone

Follow-up:
The patient will follow up with her neurologist for ongoing care and treatment of MS. She will be closely monitored for recurrence of PML and further development of IRIS.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]     Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Acute onset jaw tremor

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient, a 67-year-old female, was admitted to the out-patient department with a history of acute onset jaw tremor, with tremor predominantly in both upper limbs. The symptoms had progressed over a period of 24 to 48 hours and remained static until consultation.

During the neurological examination, the patient presented with hypomimia of the face, cogwheel rigidity, and bradykinesia bilaterally (right more than left), predominantly in the upper limbs without pyramidal signs. She had a marked tremor of the jaw at rest. CT scan of her brain revealed an infarction in the region of the putamen on the left with no evidence of diffuse subcortical white matter ischemia or extension to the caudate nucleus.

The patient was treated with a trial of levodopa (300 mg per day) and anti-platelet therapy which resulted in marked reduction in her jaw tremor and other extrapyramidal symptoms after 1 month of follow-up. There was no history of previous stroke or vascular risk factors for stroke, and a vascular screen for stroke risk factors was negative.

The rest of the neurological examination was normal which included cognition, speech, cerebellar function, and bladder function. The patient did not have features of non-motor symptoms to suggest a diagnosis of idiopathic PD. There were no pyramidal signs. The Unified Parkinson’s Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) Part III; item 18–32 was 36 while the scale improved from 36 to 24 after the trial of levodopa. A DAT scan was unavailable due to lack of resources and financial constraints.

The patient was discharged in a stable condition with follow-up to be continued on an outpatient basis.

Discharge Diagnosis:

- Acute onset jaw tremor
- Marked tremor of the jaw at rest

Condition on Discharge:

The patient's extrapyramidal symptoms were markedly reduced after a trial of levodopa (300 mg per day) and anti-platelet therapy. The patient was discharged in a stable condition.

Follow-Up Plan:

The patient will continue to receive follow-up on an outpatient basis.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Patient was discharged from our hospital following treatment for right-lateral chest and back pain. The patient's medical history includes concurrent bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and total hysterectomy for right ovarian tumor.

Physical examination findings included deep-tendon hyperreflexia in the lower extremities but no muscle weakness. Blood test results were unremarkable, apart from a high serum concentration of cancer antigen 125. Imaging studies revealed a mass in the right arch of Th12 vertebral bone that protruded into the spinal canal. Fine-needle aspiration cytology of the mass revealed no evidence of malignancy.

Pathological examination of a CT-guided needle biopsy of the paraspinal lesion demonstrated papillary proliferation of epithelial cells. The neoplastic cells showed positive results for paired box 8 (PAX8), estrogen receptor (ER), and Wilms’ tumor 1 (WT1), but negative for thyroglobulin, thyroid transcription factor 1 (TTF1), progesterone receptor, S100 protein, and calretinin. Staining for P53 showed a non-mutational “wild type” pattern. It was concluded that the paraspinal lesion was a bone metastasis of transformed LGSC originating from the previous SBT/APST in the right ovary.

The patient underwent radiotherapy for the paraspinal lesion, followed by chemotherapy treatment with paclitaxel and carboplatin plus bevacizumab. The treatment successfully relieved the patient's pain. Currently, the patient presents with right-sided pleural effusion and suspected metastases in the Th3 and Th4 vertebrae, 168 months after the initial surgery.

In regards to diagnosis, the patient was evaluated with physical examination, blood tests, imaging studies, and pathological examination. The patient was diagnosed with a bone metastasis of transformed LGSC originating from the previous SBT/APST in the right ovary.

The patient was treated with radiotherapy followed by chemotherapy treatment with paclitaxel and carboplatin plus bevacizumab. The treatments were effective in relieving the patient's pain.

The patient is to continue follow-up appointments with their provider as scheduled.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 35
Gender: Female
Diagnosis: Rhabdomyolysis

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency room with worsening abdominal pain approximately 24 hours after completing an extreme conditioning competition. She was found to have a serum CK of 43,322 U/L and was treated with Tenoxicam, bed rest, and increased water intake. However, her pain and muscle swelling did not subside and she returned to the emergency room on the third day post-competition. At this stage, her CK concentration was tested again and was found to be 77,590 U/L. The patient was diagnosed with rhabdomyolysis and was treated with aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation. Her liver enzymes were elevated, but her kidney function was normal. She was discharged on the fourth day of hospitalization and advised to avoid intense exercise. A follow-up examination revealed that her serum level of CK was still elevated but decreased gradually over time. The patient reported myalgia even 25 days after the ECP competition. 

Course in the Hospital:
The patient was treated with intravenous fluid resuscitation to manage rhabdomyolysis. Her kidney function was normal, but her liver enzymes were elevated. On the fourth day of hospitalization, the patient was discharged and advised to avoid intense exercise.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was instructed to follow up with her primary care physician for regular monitoring of her CK levels and to avoid intense exercise until her condition improved. She reported myalgia even 25 days after the extreme conditioning competition.

Summary:
The patient was diagnosed with rhabdomyolysis following completion of an extreme conditioning competition. She was treated with intravenous fluid resuscitation and was advised to avoid intense exercise. The patient followed up with her primary care physician for monitoring of her CK levels and reported persistent myalgia.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course: The patient, a 46-year-old female, presented to our department with complaints of continuous urinary incontinence following a laparoscopic hysterectomy for uterine myoma. Complete blood count, routine biochemistry parameters, urinalysis, urine culture, and urinary system ultrasonography results were all normal. A 5-mm wide fistula between the bladder trigone and the upper part of the vaginal vault was identified with flexible cystoscopy and the patient underwent transvesicoscopic bipolar sealing of the vesicovaginal fistula (TBSF) three months after her primary gynecologic surgery. The operation was conducted under spinal anesthesia, and the operative time was 65 minutes. Blood loss was minimal, and there were no intraoperative or postoperative complications. An oral anticholinergic was given for the duration of Foley catheterization. The Foley catheter was removed after 3 weeks of placement and the patient remained continent during a 3-month follow-up, with normal laboratory results.

Hospital Course:

Chief Complaint: Continuous urinary incontinence following laparoscopic hysterectomy.

History of Present Illness: The patient's medical history included laparoscopic hysterectomy 2 months prior. She presented with complaints of continuous urinary incontinence, and complete diagnostic workup results were normal. A 5-mm wide vesicovaginal fistula was identified via flexible cystoscopy.

Diagnostic and Therapeutic Information: The patient underwent transvesicoscopic bipolar sealing of the fistula (TBSF) under spinal anesthesia, with minimal blood loss during the 65-minute operative time. Foley catheterization was continued for 3 weeks, and an oral anticholinergic was administered for the duration of Foley catheterization. The Foley catheter was removed, with normal laboratory results during a 3-month follow-up.

Clinical Findings: The patient presented with continuous urinary incontinence, with normal diagnostic workup results. A 5-mm vesicovaginal fistula was identified via flexible cystoscopy.

Hospital Course Summary: The patient underwent successful transvesicoscopic bipolar sealing of a vesicovaginal fistula. Foley catheterization was continued for 3 weeks, with a successful outcome. During a 3-month follow-up, the patient remained continent with normal laboratory results.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Chief Complaint:
The patient presented with severe fatigue and expressed concern about the possible effects of taking too many drugs.

Hospital Course:
The 65-year old female patient had been on dialysis for 17 years and had a complex medical history, which included a history of heavy smoking, obesity, hypertension, diabetes, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and various cancers. Upon initial clinical examination, the patient had good psychophysical balance, a moderate impairment in nutritional status, and signs of chronic bronchitis. The clinical examination was unremarkable aside from her heart bruit and mild orthostatic hypotension. Her arterial blood pressure was high, and her heart rate was normal. The patient was on various medications, including antihypertensive drugs, antipsychotics, thyroid hormone, vitamin D supplements, bicarbonate and calcium supplements, potassium, phosphate binders, and darbopoietin.

Diagnostic Workup:
A biochemical control revealed a relevant increase in thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels, which was likely caused by interference from the patient's sevelamer dosage. The patient's levothyroxine dose was already high for her body weight, and a reduction in absorption should have been suspected. The TSH levels returned to normal once the sevelamer dosage was discontinued, and timing of levothyroxine treatment was modified.

Hospital Course:
The patient's fatigue improved after the interference was discontinued, and the patient was discharged from the hospital in a stable condition with instructions to continue monitoring her medication interactions.

Final Diagnosis:
The patient experienced severe fatigue due to drug interference caused by sevelamer dosage.

Discharge Condition:
Stable condition.

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care physician to reassess her medication regimen and to continue monitoring potential drug interactions.

Signed,
[REDACTED], MD

Discharge Summary:
Patient: 23-year-old Asian man
Admission date: [date]
Discharge date: [date]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to Xiamen Chang Gung Memorial Hospital with a 1-day history of right-sided chest pain with subsequent diagnosis of right-sided PSP associated with right TP. A right thoracostomy tube was placed under sterile conditions, and approximately 50 mL of light red pleural effusion was drained out. While in the respiratory department, approximately 420 mL of blood was drained from the thoracostomy tube over 15 minutes, and emergency surgery was performed for resection of the bullae, ligation of the bleeding adhesion, and irrigation of the pleural cavity, and mechanical pleurodesis was implemented. His recovery was uneventful. Subsequently, the drainage from his chest tube became minimal, and a standing CXR performed on day 6 of admission after removal of the thoracostomy tube showed complete re-expansion of his right lung. He was discharged 6 days postoperatively after confirmation of full expansion of lungs.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted with a short history of right-sided chest pain with associated dry cough. Physical examination revealed slightly tender right posterolateral chest wall, and a right-sided PSP with a small amount of pleural effusion was confirmed by a standing CXR. The thoracostomy tube was placed and he was referred to the respiratory department. He had hemodynamic instability with hypovolemic shock due to significant blood loss from the thoracostomy tube that was managed with fluids and blood transfusions. He underwent emergency surgery, and a primary SHP associated with right TP was confirmed based on radiographic findings. After resection of the bullae, ligation of the bleeding adhesion, and irrigation of the pleural cavity, mechanical pleurodesis was implemented. He had an uneventful recovery, and his condition stabilized. Full expansion of lungs was confirmed, and he was discharged without further complications.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with fever, dry cough, progressive shortness of breath, and decreased exercise tolerance. He had a history of recto-sigmoid carcinoma, neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy, and Modified De Gramont regimen plus Oxaliplatin. Panitumumab was added to his treatment plan in May 2016, which was continued for 18 cycles. 

Diagnostic Assessment:

Computed tomography (CT) scan and positron emission tomography (PET)/CT after neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy showed a favourable response to the rectal tumour, but there were six small new liver lesions. In September 2016, reassessment CT scan, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and PET scans showed that the liver and rectal primary lesions had responded well to the Modified De Gramont regimen plus Oxaliplatin and Panitumumab with complete response of rectal disease found on pathology after resection. 

Treatment:

After recovery from surgery, the patient continued on systemic chemotherapy and early March 2017, received three more cycles of Panitumumab. 

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with fever of unknown origin.

Recommendation:

Further investigations were recommended to determine the cause of the patient's fever. No specific follow-up recommendations were given.

Patient Information:

The patient is a 54-year-old man who was diagnosed with primary myelofibrosis in 2004.

Hospital Course:

The patient was enrolled in a clinical trial utilizing a JAK2 inhibitor, fedratinib, in 2011. A repeat bone marrow biopsy nearly one year into the trial showed a decrease in cellularity with MF-3 fibrosis only in the cellular areas. The patient was discontinued from the trial in 2013 and started on ruxolitinib.

Results:

Repeat bone marrow biopsies were conducted in 2016 and showed a marrow comprised entirely of adipose tissue with osteosclerosis. Quantitative fat magnetic resonance (MR) imaging was utilized to show replacement of the marrow with fat. A representative pseudocolor display that depicts 100% fat as dark red and 0% fat as dark blue was shown. The percent fat seen in the bone marrow imaging approximates that in subcutaneous fat. A repeat bone marrow in 2017 showed a hypocellular marrow with histopathologic findings consistent with the patient's initial diagnosis of primary myelofibrosis.

Summary:

The patient presented with primary myelofibrosis in 2004 and was enrolled in a clinical trial utilizing a JAK2 inhibitor in 2011. Repeat bone marrow biopsies were conducted in 2016 showing unique histopathologic findings, and a repeat bone marrow in 2017 showed comparable findings to the patient's initial diagnosis of primary myelofibrosis.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 61-year-old male with oral cavity SCC and previous surgical treatment of stage I disease in 2011, presented with cervical and left axillary lymphadenopathy. The patient had been lost to follow-up for over 4 years prior to this presentation. Biopsy of the lymph nodes revealed metastatic SCC. The patient was enrolled in a trial and treated with carboplatin, 5-FU, and pembrolizumab at a dose of 200 mg. After 4 cycles, the patient showed signs of partial response, but presented with fatigue and hypotension to systolic blood pressure of 70 seconds. The patient was diagnosed with immune-related central adrenal insufficiency and was started on high-dose dexamethasone and later transitioned to hydrocortisone. Brain MRI did not show any inflammation of the pituitary stalk and was without metastatic lesions. The patient's fatigue was resolved ten days later and was restarted on pembrolizumab. The patient continues to take hydrocortisone.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [date of admission]
Discharge Date: [date of discharge] 

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 77-year-old male with stage IV lung SCC and metastasis to the liver, was admitted to the hospital for fatigue complaints after being treated with nivolumab. The patient had previously responded partially to carboplatin and nab-paclitaxel, but disease progression was observed. The patient had continued to show stable disease while on nivolumab, until day 1 of cycle 8 when he complained of profound fatigue. 

Investigations:
The patient's random cortisol level was found to be 1.3 μg/dL and did not satisfactorily respond to the ACTH stimulation test. His ACTH level was <5 pg/mL.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with immune-related central adrenal insufficiency.

Treatment and Management:
As the patient's symptoms were resolved immediately after dexamethasone and hydrocortisone were administered, he was started on hydrocortisone and opted to discontinue nivolumab. Repeat scans 3 months after he discontinued nivolumab showed no evidence of progression and the patient continued to be asymptomatic while on hydrocortisone.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition and advised to continue taking hydrocortisone as prescribed. Follow-up appointments were scheduled with the primary care physician to monitor the patient's condition.

Final Diagnosis:
The final diagnosis for the patient was immune-related central adrenal insufficiency.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:

Name: [REDACTED]                   
Age: 8                  
Gender: Female                 
Hospital ID: [REDACTED]

Admission Information:

Admission Date: [REDACTED]             
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]         
Reason for Admission: Idiopathic central precocious puberty             
Treatment Provided: Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) analogue therapy with triptorelin i.m. 3.75 mg every 28 days                

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 7-year and 6-month-old girl, was admitted to our hospital due to premature thelarche. She had no significant medical history. Upon examination, her height was 131.5 cm, and breast development was found to be at Tanner stage 3. Diagnostic test results revealed that she had idiopathic central precocious puberty. Treatment with GnRH analogue therapy with triptorelin i.m. 3.75 mg every 28 days was initiated. After 6 months, a follow-up LHRH test showed suppressed gonadotropin peaks, confirming the effectiveness of the treatment.

On the day the patient turned 8 years and 4 months old, she was readmitted to our Emergency Department for the occurrence of abdominal pain, burning sensation at neck and dyspnea that developed two hours after the previous injection of the GnRH analogue therapy. She was found to have pruriginous whistles all over her body, and a diagnosis of anaphylactic reactions was made. Treatment with systemic epinephrine and intravenous hydrocortisone was administered, and the symptoms were effectively resolved. Skin prick tests conducted the following day indicated a positive result at very low dilution of the drug (1:10.000); consequently, therapy with triptorelin was discontinued.

The patient was closely monitored for 6 months following the incident, and no further instances of anaphylactic reactions were reported at any point. Moreover, there was no significant progression of puberty in the six months of follow-up.

Follow-up and Recommendations:

The patient is recommended to avoid the use of GnRH analogue therapy with triptorelin i.m. 3.75 mg. If any further signs of precocious puberty are observed, please contact a medical professional for alternative treatment options.

Overall, the patient’s condition has been managed effectively with the timely treatment of GnRH analogue therapy with triptorelin i.m. 3.75 mg. The patient’s anaphylactic reaction to the therapy is a documented and significant problem, and it is important for medical professionals to take note of this and keep this information on record.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 73-year-old man

Clinical Diagnosis: Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS)

History of Presenting Illness: The patient was complaining of an urge to move his legs that was accompanied by unpleasant sensations that worsened during rest and before sleep. He was experiencing difficulty in falling asleep and nonrestorative sleep, and had an IRLS score of 11. The patient reported feeling uncomfortable even after prolonged sleep, and claimed no relief from fatigue. Physical examination and laboratory test results indicated normal findings.

Hospital Course: A full-night diagnostic PSG recording was obtained when the patient was on hypnotic medication (zolpidem, 5 mg). It was revealed that the patient was experiencing difficulty in initiating and maintaining sleep due to discomfort associated with periodic leg movement bursts. The patient received 4W-acuinjections of normal saline doses (0.25 mL each) supplemented with pentazocine (0.5 mg per dose) in both legs after the first 115 min of PSG. Light PLM bursts reappeared 124 minutes later, but the patient reported remarkably restorative sleep in the morning. Most of the PLMs were observed during stage wakefulness periods, where slow eye movements were observed while EEG was alpha-rhythm dominant, thus, discomfort accompanied by PLMs during drowsy periods, rather than wakefulness, seemed to disrupt his attempts to fall asleep. After 4W-acuinjections, the patient's PLM index (number of PLMs/total recording h) decreased and his percent sleep efficiency increased.

Discharge Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with RLS.

Discharge Medications: None prescribed.

Follow-up Care: The patient is advised to follow-up with his primary care physician for further evaluation and management of his RLS.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Age: 81 years

Sex: Male

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Restless Leg Syndrome (RLS), Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA)

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital due to symptoms of interrupted sleep, excessive daytime sleepiness, and intolerable fatigue throughout the day. He was experiencing unpleasant paresthesia of the left leg, urging to move. The symptoms worsened at rest and during the evening and night and were relieved by mobilization. Diagnosis of RLS was confirmed based on the patient's symptoms meeting the RLS diagnostic criteria and an IRLS score of 16. The patient involuntarily tapped his right heel once every few seconds but did not report any discomfort related to this. Additional diagnostic PSG revealed a high baseline obstructive apnea-hypopnea index in the supine position and a PLM index of 32.2 associated with EEG arousals.

The patient was treated with at-home continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) treatment with an auto-titrating device. The treatment resulted in the patient experiencing comfortable sleep and a decrease in the severity and frequency of his symptoms. During the one month following the CPAP treatment, the patient reported experiencing discomfort in the left leg, right foot tapping, and nonrestorative sleep, despite compliance with the CPAP treatment.

The patient received 4W-acuinjections of normal saline doses supplemented with pentazocine in both legs in the sitting position while tapping his right heel, and immediately afterward, he felt warmth to both legs with a pleasant sensation, and his left lower leg discomfort and involuntary right leg movements were completely relieved. During the second diagnostic PSG under auto-titrated CPAP treatment obtained 2 months after the first PSG, the patient's PLMs were almost completely suppressed except for one leg movement. The 4W-acuinjections caused no major change in percent sleep efficiency, but the patient reported remarkably restorative sleep upon waking up in the morning.

Discharge Condition:

The patient's condition improved remarkably with at-home continuous positive airway pressure treatment with an auto-titrating device, supplementation with 4W-acuinjections, and the cessation of pentazocine in both legs. The patient's PLMs have been suppressed, and his left lower leg discomfort and involuntary right leg movements have been completely relieved. The patient's symptoms and condition have improved to the point where he is suitable for discharge.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient has been instructed to continue at-home continuous positive airway pressure treatment with an auto-titrating device. The patient has received instructions to follow up with his treating physician for further evaluation and management of RLS and CPAP treatment. The patient received additional instructions to maintain a healthy diet and exercise regularly as well as follow up with his mental health therapist for management of panic disorder. The patient also received recommendations to return to the hospital for further evaluation and management if any further complications arise.

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 34-year-old Caucasian male who presented with chronic diarrhea due to norovirus infection. He had undergone intestinal transplantation twice in the past, with the second transplant being performed 18 months ago. The patient developed mild acute rejection in the colon, which was successfully treated with intravenous steroids. Follow-up biopsies were normal. The patient's chronic diarrhea persisted, and he was diagnosed with norovirus gastroenteritis two months later. Treatment with oral immunoglobulin did not result in improvement, and the norovirus infection continued. Four days after the end of the immunoglobulin treatment, the patient was readmitted to the hospital due to fever, increased diarrhea, and abdominal pain. Severe biopsy-proven rejection grade 2-3 was diagnosed in the small-bowel and colon. The acute rejection was treated with a 10-day course of intravenous antithymocyte globulin, which resolved both symptomatically and in graft biopsies. The patient was discharged with persistent signs of colitis and distal ileitis but has remained rejection-free now 10 months later. Nitazoxanide 500 mg twice daily was started for the persistent norovirus infection, but without any clear clinical or virologic response. Bacterial, other viral, and parasitic samples were negative.

Hospital Course Summary:
- 34-year-old Caucasian male with chronic intestinal pseudo-obstruction due to familial visceral myopathy
- Underwent intestinal transplantation twice with the second transplant 18 months ago, with rejections and viral gastroenteritis occurring in follow-up
- Norovirus infection diagnosed causing symptoms of chronic diarrhea
- Treatment with oral immunoglobulin did not improve symptoms
- Four days after immunoglobulin treatment, readmitted with fever, increased diarrhea, and abdominal pain
- Severe biopsy-proven rejection grade 2-3 was diagnosed in the small-bowel and colon
- Acute rejection resolved with 10-day course of intravenous antithymocyte globulin
- Persistent signs of colitis and distal ileitis resolved at 3 months after starting immunoglobulin therapy
- Discharged with persistent signs of colitis and distal ileitis, with nitazoxanide 500 mg twice daily started for persistent norovirus infection

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [Patient's Name]
- Age: 55 years
- Gender: Male
- Admission Date: [Date of Admission]
- Discharge Date: [Date of Discharge]

Medical History:
- Mildly elevated arterial pressure for 1 year, managed with low-dose amlodipine

Presenting Complaint:
- Right hypochondrium pain
- Abdominal distention
- Early satiety

Diagnostic Findings:
- Abdominal ultrasound imaging revealed a huge cystic mass posterior to the pancreas, compressing the stomach
- Abdominal CT confirmed the presence of a huge cystic retroperitoneal lesion, which measured 22 x 22 x 10 cm
- Endoscopic ultrasound fluid aspiration was negative for CA19-9 and amylase
- Biopsy samples were inconclusive on the nature of the lesion
- 24-hour urine catecholamine levels were normal
- Vital signs and blood CEA and CA19-9 were normal

Treatment:
- Complete excision of the cystic mass

Diagnosis:
- Pheochromocytoma, arising from adrenal tissue and demonstrating immunohistopositivity to chromogranin and synaptophysin
- Categorized as malignant due to lesion size and microvascular invasion

Follow-up:
- Recommended regular follow-up with an endocrinologist for ongoing management of hypertension and screening for recurrence or metastasis of pheochromocytoma.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 26
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Exercise-related syncope
Final Diagnosis: Anomalous origin of the RCA from the left sinus of Valsalva

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 26-year-old male, was admitted to the hospital with a clinical history of exercise-related syncope. Coronary CT angiography revealed an anomalous aortic origin of the right coronary artery (RCA) from the left coronary ostium. The proximal portion of the RCA seemed to be coursing along the aortic vessel wall before running between the aorta and pulmonary artery. CT-based fractional flow reserve (FFRCT) in the RCA was 0.77 (ischemic cutoff ≤0.8), suggesting significant ischemia. Coronary angiography suggested the presence of a slit-like ostium of the anomalous RCA. Invasive FFR evaluation confirmed significant ischemia. The treating physicians decided on surgical treatment.

Summary:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with clinical history of exercise-related syncope. During the course of his hospital stay, he was diagnosed with an anomalous aortic origin of the right coronary artery (RCA) from the left coronary ostium. CT-based fractional flow reserve and invasive FFR evaluation confirmed significant ischemia. The patient underwent surgical treatment.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admit Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date] 

Chief Complaint: Severe pneumonia with possible abscess

History: 
A 53-year-old female with a history of breast cancer, vulvar and rectal cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and respiratory failure with tracheostomy was admitted with complaints of fever, diarrhea, shortness of breath, and increasing oxygen demands. The patient presented with pneumonia in the left upper lobe and was treated with antibiotics. However, the patient failed to respond to treatment and developed a pulmonary abscess with bronchopulmonary fistula. 

Hospital Course:
The patient was transferred from an outside facility requiring a higher level of care and cardiothoracic surgery (CTS) consultation. The patient was diagnosed with a pulmonary abscess with bronchopulmonary fistula by CTS. The patient was deemed a poor surgical candidate and continued medical management and drainage via chest tube was recommended. The patient continued to have persistent MDRPA growth and eventually developed Acinetobacter, which was resistant to ceftolozane-tazobactam. After 14 days of meropenem and colistin without improvement, all therapy was stopped, and the patient was transitioned to comfort care and subsequently expired. 

Course in hospitalization:
Despite aggressive medical management, the patient was unable to overcome the respiratory failure and succumbed to the illness. 

Discharge:
The patient expired due to severe pneumonia with possible abscess and multiple comorbidities and complications that made her a poor surgical candidate. The patient's family was notified and offered grief counseling.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient: 53-year-old male with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis

Hospital course:
The patient was admitted with severe generalized muscle weakness and myalgias. He had been diagnosed with Grade 2 esophageal varices, ascites, and hepatic encephalopathy in 2016. The patient was afebrile, tachycardic, and mildly hypertensive on presentation. Physical examination was remarkable for symmetrical proximal muscle tenderness and weakness. Laboratory findings showed elevations in creatinine, aspartate aminotransferase (AST), white blood cells (WBC), and creatine kinase (CK).
The etiology of patient’s rhabdomyolysis was unclear, but infectious, autoimmune, and malignant causes were investigated and excluded. The patient was aggressively treated with intravenous fluid resuscitation, and his myoglobinuria resolved soon after. Further medication review revealed that the patient had been recently started on rifaximin for hepatic encephalopathy prophylaxis. Rifaximin has been occasionally reported to cause rhabdomyolysis in patients with hepatic insufficiency. The patient improved dramatically after cessation of the drug.
The patient’s strength continued to improve with therapy, and he was discharged on day 16 with a diagnosis of rifaximin-induced rhabdomyolysis.

Diagnoses:
1. Alcoholic cirrhosis
2. Rifaximin-induced rhabdomyolysis

Discharge medications:
Please refer to the medication list provided at discharge.

Follow-up:
The patient should follow up with his primary care physician.

Instructions:
1. Avoid alcohol and other hepatotoxic agents.
2. Avoid exertion.
3. Follow a low sodium diet.
4. Take all prescribed medication as directed.
5. Call 911 or go to the nearest emergency department immediately if you experience any difficulty breathing, chest pain, or weakness.

Discharge condition:
Stable.

Hospital Course:

The 59-year-old male patient had presented with nausea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. He had previously been diagnosed with a stage T1A nonsmall cell lung cancer in the right upper lobe. The patient had refused surgery and completed Stereotactic Body Radiation Therapy (SBRT). Serial surveillance imaging showed no abnormalities until the current presentation. 

Diagnostic Assessment:

A total body PET-CT scan was ordered due to the patient's prior history of cancer. The results showed thickening of the wall of the gastric fundus and a mass in the tail of the pancreas. Additionally, a 1.1-cm filling defect within the splenic vein was observed. Upper endoscopy revealed a 5-cm infiltrative and ulcerated mass in the gastric fundus. Gastric biopsies showed poorly differentiated carcinoma. EUS confirmed a hypoechoic round mass in the pancreas with local vascular involvement and splenic vein thrombus and was diagnosed with neuroendocrine carcinoma.

Treatment:

Treatment options, including palliative care, were discussed with the patient and his family, and the patient elected to receive symptomatic treatment.

Conclusion:

Metastasis of the primary lung tumor to the stomach is infrequent and sporadic. Symptomatic cases present with epigastric pain, chronic anemia, signs of GI bleed (hematemesis, melena), and gastric perforations. The patient's case illustrates the potential for cancer to spread via hematogenous and lymphatic routes. EUS-FNA in combination with immunohistochemistry is useful in diagnosing metastatic lesions and differentiating those from synchronous primary lesions.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Patient Name: [Name]		MRN: [Number]
Date of Birth: [Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 65-year-old man admitted due to repetitive drug-resistant VT episodes and decompensated heart failure. He had a history of cardiac sarcoidosis and a cardiac resynchronization therapy device implanted. Despite the administration of multiple medications, VTs could not be controlled, and he was admitted to our hospital. Electroanatomical mapping and RFA were performed to manage the VT storm, targeting low voltage zones and/or abnormal electrograms such as those with fragmented and double potentials. After the procedure, the clinical VT could not be induced. However, a different VT emerged two days later, and he required intubation, sedation, and cardiopulmonary support. A second ablation session was performed, and the VT was eliminated. The patient, however, died from deterioration of his heart failure 12 days after the procedure. A postmortem examination of the heart was performed revealed ablation lesions that were mainly located on the interventricular septum and inferior wall of the left ventricle.

Diagnosis:
-Cardiac sarcoidosis
-Repetitive drug-resistant VT episodes
-Decompensated heart failure

Procedure:
-Radiofrequency ablation (RFA) targeting low voltage zones and/or abnormal electrograms on the inferior and infero-septal walls of the left ventricle and interventricular septum from both the LV and RV endocardium

Hospital Course Notes:
-Initial resuscitation due to decompensated heart failure and VT storm
-RFA resulted in temporary VT control until a different morphological VT arose
-Second RFA resulted in complete elimination of the VT; however, the patient died from deterioration of heart failure 12 days after the procedure

Follow-Up:
-Family notified of patient's death
-Postmortem examination of the heart was performed

Hospital Discharge:
-The patient was discharged after his death, and no further follow-up was required.

Hospital Course Summary:
The 22-year-old edentulous female patient with hypodontia and amelogenesis imperfecta was referred to the Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery Department of Tehran University of Medical Sciences in 2012. She had class III malocclusion, facial deformity, and several impacted teeth. The patient underwent cosmetic surgery to correct her mid-face deficiency, jaw deviation, class III discrepancy, and alveolar ridge deficiency followed by dental implant placement and full mouth prosthetic rehabilitation. The patient's surgery involved sagittal split ramus osteotomy and LeFort I osteotomy. A mandibular setback procedure by 7mm and repositioning of the maxilla by 2mm superiorly and 5mm anteriorly on surgical casts were planned by the surgeon. Alveolar ridge augmentation was performed by harvesting a graft from the iliac crest. After two weeks, temporary complete dentures were delivered. Six months later, an impression was made, and a radiographic stent was fabricated for implant placement. Proper diagonal length and angle of 16 implants (Dentium, Implantium, Korea, Seoul), eight in each jaw, were determined. The implants were inserted using a surgical stent and healing abutments were tightened. Porcelain crowns with A2 shade were fabricated followed by the implant-supported crowns being cemented with a temporary cement (Kerr, Toronto, Canada). Patient was fully satisfied with the results at the six-year follow-up.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 38-year-old male

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Admission Diagnosis: Primary antiphospholipid syndrome with end-stage renal failure

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with end-stage renal failure secondary to primary antiphospholipid syndrome. He underwent a tissue-matched renal allograft transplant, with optimized anticoagulation prior to surgery. During the early postoperative period, he developed a peri-renal hematoma which was managed by withholding anticoagulation and he recovered well. He was discharged with his urethral catheter and ureteric stent removed and warfarin restarted.

Three weeks after the surgery, he presented with reduced urine output and progressive abdominal distension. An ultrasound scan showed a large perigraft collection, and during surgical exploration, a completely sloughed off allograft ureter was found with an intact allograft renal pelvis. An allograft pelvis-native ureter ureteropyelostomy was performed with a stable postoperative recovery.

At 6 months following reconstructive surgery, the patient developed a perirenal abscess around the graft kidney which was successfully drained. A 99 m-Technetium DTPA renography was performed 9 months after surgery with normal uptake and excretion and no evidence of obstruction. At 1 year following the reconstructive surgery, the patient had good urine output with a stable serum creatinine.

Discharge Diagnosis: Sloughed off allograft ureter and perirenal abscess

Discharge Medications: N/A

Discharge Instructions:
The patient should follow up with their primary care physician, and should report any symptoms of increased abdominal pain, fever, or reduced urine output. They should also be aware of proper wound care and infection prevention techniques.

Follow-up Appointments: To be determined by the primary care physician.

The patient's features were thought to resemble his father who had a history of constitutional delay and 2-3 toe syndactyly. At the age of 16 years, the father was 4′8″ but then had a growth spurt in high school. The parents reported an early miscarriage. Maternal family history was noncontributory. Consanguinity was not reported.

The patient was evaluated by a multidisciplinary team including a geneticist, developmental pediatrician, and other specialists. During his stay, the patient was closely monitored and managed with proper supportive care. The patient was discharged with proper instructions for follow-up care with his primary care physician and specialists.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 70-year-old male with pseudoprogression of PPC 

Hospital Course:

The patient was initially admitted in December 2014 with a suspected lung cancer and underwent a pulmonary resection of the right lower lobe. A diagnosis of PPC was made, and the patient received adjuvant chemotherapy. In April 2015, bilateral adrenal gland metastasis was detected, and several chemotherapy regimens were administered. Nivolumab therapy was initiated as the fifth-line therapy in October 2016, and the right adrenal gland metastasis was reduced while the pleural effusion and pulmonary metastasis were exacerbated. These lesions improved after continuous nivolumab therapy, and serum CYFRA 21-1 levels decreased.

Clinical Evaluation:

During hospitalization, the patient's left ventricular ejection fraction was measured to be 70%, and the brain natriuretic peptide level was within normal range. The respiratory variation in the IVC was more than 50%. Based on these findings, malignant pleural effusion and heart failure were deemed unlikely.

Disposition:

The patient has achieved a partial response with continuous nivolumab therapy without exacerbation or adverse effects. Follow-up is ongoing to date (June 2017). 

Diagnosis:

Pseudoprogression of PPC 

Summary:

The patient presented with a history of PPC and bilateral adrenal gland metastasis. Nivolumab therapy was initiated as the fifth-line therapy and showed improvements in the right adrenal gland metastasis. Although the pleural effusion and pulmonary metastasis were exacerbated initially, the lesions have improved with continuous nivolumab therapy. The patient has achieved a partial response without significant adverse effects.

Patient Name: _______________ 
Gender: _______________ 
Age: 48 years 
Admission Date: _______________

Discharge Diagnosis: Sarcoidosis 

Hospital Course: 
The patient was admitted to our hospital due to increased abdominal size, daily fever, significant weight loss, and cholestatic jaundice initiated about 2 years previously. The patient also reported dyspnea under moderate stress. Physical examination showed hepatomegaly and erythematous plaques on the face and left inferior limb. Laboratory evaluation demonstrated elevated hepatic enzymes, hyperbilirubinemia, anemia, and polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia. Imaging studies including abdominal MRI and chest CT scan were also performed. Abdominal MRI revealed hepatosplenomegaly with hypointense nodules, as well as lymph node enlargement at the splenic hilum. Chest CT demonstrated pulmonary nodules predominating along the bronchovascular bundles, with bilateral hilar enlargement. 

The patient underwent liver and cutaneous biopsies, and histologic samples revealed granulomas with epithelioid cells and multinucleated giant cells which lead to the final diagnosis of sarcoidosis. 

Treatment during the hospitalization included the management of symptoms with supportive care. Consultation with a specialist was also initiated for the further management of sarcoidosis. 

The patient's condition improved during the hospitalization, and after a period of observation, she was discharged in stable condition with the instructions to continue the follow-up with the specialist for further treatment and monitoring of the disease progression. 

Follow-up plan: 
The patient will continue to follow-up with the specialist for further treatment and monitoring of the disease progression. She is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and follow the prescribed treatment plan. She is also instructed to report any new symptoms immediately to the physician.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 49-year-old male

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented to the hospital with spontaneous bruising and mucosal bleeding. He had a platelet count of 2 × 10^9/L, which improved with the administration of prednisone. Despite laparoscopic splenectomy and various treatments, the patient experienced cyclic thrombocytopenia for over 10 years, with platelet counts fluctuating with a statistically significant period of 39 days.

Hospital Course:
The patient received treatment with corticosteroids, intravenous immunoglobulin, danazol, pulse dexamethasone, and rituximab, but none were effective in resolving the persistent thrombocytopenia. Serial measurements of thrombopoietin (TPO) levels were taken, which revealed undetectable levels during periods of extreme thrombocytosis and increased levels when platelet counts were low.

Treatment:
Treatment with the TPO receptor agonist eltrombopag was started and timed with anticipated periods of thrombocytopenia. The patient received 50 mg of eltrombopag daily during specific periods, resulting in extreme thrombocytosis that did not alter the cycle pattern or period. Therefore, eltrombopag was discontinued thereafter.

Summary:
The patient presented with thrombocytopenia, which improved with prednisone and laparoscopic splenectomy. However, the thrombocytopenia relapsed and persisted for over 10 years. Serial measurements of TPO levels were taken, and treatment with eltrombopag was started and then discontinued due to its ineffectiveness in resolving the cyclic thrombocytopenia.

Discharge Summary

Patient Identifiers:
Name: [Redacted]
Age: 53
Sex: Male

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with severe thrombocytopenia in 1999 and underwent splenectomy. Following the procedure, the patient was prescribed a combination of immunosuppressant medications but continued to require frequent doses of intravenous immunoglobulin and corticosteroids due to persistent severe thrombocytopenia. 
In April 2003, the patient experienced periodic oscillations in platelet count levels with a statistically significant period of 23 days. The patient frequently reported bleeding with oral mucosal blood blisters during episodes of severe thrombocytopenia. Despite the addition of danazol to the treatment regimen, the patient's platelet count levels remained unstable.
After six years, eltrombopag was introduced and led to extreme thrombocytosis. As a result, all immunosuppressant medications were stopped and the patient experienced a period of severe thrombocytopenia for approximately 4 weeks. Subsequently, eltrombopag was slowly reintroduced and the cyclical thrombocytopenia became less severe over time. At the last follow-up in May 2015, the patient was prescribed eltrombopag 75 mg daily along with low doses of azathioprine and mycophenolate.

Diagnosis:
Severe thrombocytopenia 

Clinical Findings:
Platelet count levels began oscillating periodically with a statistically significant period of 23 days from a nadir of <10 × 109/L and a peak of 300-400 × 109/L. During episodes of severe thrombocytopenia, the patient frequently had bleeding with oral mucosal blood blisters. 

Treatment:
The patient was previously prescribed a combination of immunosuppressant medications, intravenous immunoglobulin, and corticosteroids. Following the introduction of eltrombopag, all immunosuppressant medications were stopped and the patient's condition improved. At present, the patient is prescribed eltrombopag 75 mg daily along with low doses of azathioprine and mycophenolate.

Prognosis:
The cyclical pattern of thrombocytopenia gradually resolved over time and the patient's condition is currently stable. Please continue monitoring the patient's condition and adjusting the treatment plan as necessary.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Age: 85
Sex: Male

Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with recurrent, unexplained syncope. The baseline electrocardiogram (ECG) and telemetry monitoring showed atrial fibrillation and conduction abnormalities. Electrophysiology (EP) study with possible device implantation was recommended due to concern over paroxysmal AV block or ventricular arrhythmia as the cause of his syncope.

An octapolar catheter was positioned near the His-bundle location during the EP study. Intracardiac electrograms revealed infra-Hisian block at baseline, and there were no inducible ventricular arrhythmias during the EP study. Pacing from the His catheter in this location resulted in QRS narrowing, and it was decided to implant a permanent His-bundle pacemaker. The PHB lead was directed toward the membranous septum using a fixed-curve delivery sheath.

High-output unipolar pacing from the PHB lead resulted in a narrow QRS complex with resolution of the conduction abnormalities. However, intracardiac EGMs on the octapolar catheter revealed that the recorded His-bundle potential was not captured during PHB lead pacing. The octapolar catheter was advanced beyond the PHB lead tip to ensure there was not capture of the distal His bundle. Pacing at lower outputs resulted in non-selective His capture.

The patient remained stable throughout the hospital course. The thresholds for His-bundle capture and RV septal capture remained stable, and the patient was discharged the next morning.

N/A

Stable

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 73-year-old overweight male who presented with mild right subcostal abdominal pain and worsening dyspnea upon exertion. The physical exam revealed decreased breath sounds and a solid mass in the right lung base. Imaging was consistent with a giant subdiaphragmatic hepatic lesion centrally located in the liver with segments IVa, VIII, VII, and partially IVb and V. The suspicion of hepatocellular adenoma was raised. The patient underwent an atypical central hepatic resection with postoperative course remaining uneventful. Histological examination revealed a well-differentiated HCC arising from nonalcoholic steatohepatitis, resected in clear margin (R0). The patient remains in excellent general condition with no evidence of recurrence 38 months postoperatively. 

Impression:
The patient's progressive dyspnea was due to a rare phenomenon of symptomatic elevation of the right hemidiaphragm caused by a silent hepatic tumor. The patient underwent a successful atypical central hepatic resection, resulting in clear margins of a well-differentiated HCC.

Summary:
73-year-old overweight male presented with mild right subcostal abdominal pain and worsening dyspnea upon exertion. The physical exam revealed decreased breath sounds and a solid mass in the right lung base. Imaging revealed a giant subdiaphragmatic hepatic lesion. The patient underwent an atypical central hepatic resection with postoperative course remaining uneventful. The histological examination revealed a well-differentiated HCC arising from nonalcoholic steatohepatitis. The patient remains in excellent general condition with no evidence of recurrence 38 months postoperatively.

Sex: Male

Admitting Diagnosis: Postoperative gastro-colic fistula

Hospital Course:
[Redacted] was admitted to the hospital with left pleuritic chest pain, nonradiating in nature, left shoulder pain, dyspnea, fever, chills, and decrease food intake. He had undergone LSG at another institution before being admitted to our hospital. After examination and investigations, a proximal stomach (gastro-esophageal junction) staple line was found to have caused a GC fistula that was draining into a left upper quadrant abscess, leading to a left pleural effusion. A chest tube was immediately placed, and the patient was started on ceftriaxone and levofloxacin. Later, antibiotics were switched to piperacillin/tazobactam and fluconazole. Conservative management was continued, and total parenteral nutrition was started. The patient's antibiotics were subsequently switched to co-amoxiclav. After 8 weeks of serial CT scans and outpatient visits, the GC fistula had completely resolved, and the patient was started on a progressive oral diet.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in good condition, with adequate nutrition and good quality of life, after being carefully monitored for 8 weeks with serial CT scans and outpatient visits.

Discharge Medications:
The patient was started on antibiotics, which were later switched to co-amoxiclav under consultation. No other medications were prescribed on discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient should be careful in maintaining his diet and should follow up with his primary care physician regularly. In case of any worsening symptoms, the patient should immediately seek medical attention. The patient was advised to avoid smoking and minimize his alcohol intake.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient was advised to follow up with his primary care physician regularly to monitor his condition.

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Sex: Male
Age: 37 years
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Admission Diagnosis: MeOH poisoning

Hospital Course:
A 37-year-old man was admitted to the hospital following ingestion of a fuel alcohol product containing 70% MeOH and 30% EtOH in a suicide attempt. On admission, he presented with elevated blood pressure and altered mental status. The patient was treated with repeated doses of fomepizole, an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor, and hemodialysis was intermittently carried out twice for 4 hours each. Plasma osmolality was measured to be 359 mOsm/kg, the osmolal gap (OG) was 75.8 mOsm/kg, and the anion gap was 13.8 mOsm/kg. OG and eMeOH decreased to 1.9 mOsm/kg and 6.0 mg/dL, respectively, after the second round of HD. The patient did not develop any serious signs or symptoms due to toxic metabolites of MeOH and was discharged on hospital day 4.

Hospital Course Summary:
Upon arrival at the hospital, the patient presented with elevated blood pressure and altered mental status due to the ingestion of a fuel alcohol product containing 70% MeOH and 30% EtOH. The patient underwent treatment with repeated doses of fomepizole and hemodialysis was carried out twice. There were no significant changes in the patient's clinical status during the hospitalization period. The patient was discharged on hospital day 4 without any notable sequelae.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient was referred to a counselor and provided with information on support groups for individuals with substance-use disorders. Instructions were given to the patient regarding follow-up with primary care provider in 1 week. The primary care provider was advised to monitor the patient's mental and physical health.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient was in stable condition upon discharge, with no significant clinical or laboratory abnormalities reported. The patient was advised to abstain from alcohol consumption and to keep follow-up appointments with the primary care provider.

Discharge Diagnosis:
MeOH poisoning.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 60-year-old male with nuclear cataract in right eye 15 years after myopic LASIK surgery.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent femtosecond laser-assisted cataract surgery (FLACS) in his right eye to implant a multifocal intraocular lens (IOL) with negative spherical aberration (SA). The procedure was successful and uneventful, and the patient was prescribed topical dexamethasone tobramycin for 2 weeks and pranoprofen for 1 month postoperatively. Anterior segment optical coherence tomography (AS-OCT) showed a smooth corneal flap 1 week after FLACS. At 3 months postoperatively, the patient's IOL was well-centered in the capsule and his corneal astigmatism and SA slightly decreased. The patient's uncorrected visual acuity was 0.00 LogMAR for distance, 0.10 LogMAR for intermediate at 80 cm, and 0.10 LogMAR for near at 40 cm. Despite a mild halo, the patient reported being very satisfied with his vision.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Nuclear cataract in right eye

Discharge Instructions:
The patient should continue to use the prescribed topical medications as directed. Follow-up appointments with the ophthalmologist should be scheduled as recommended.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: N/A (Case Report)

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 59-year-old overweight man who was diagnosed with stage III mantle cell lymphoma. The patient received four cycles of R-DHAX regimen followed by high-dose therapy and autologous stem cell transplantation. The patient had a persistent fever after the transplant which required antifungal treatment. No signs of invasive aspergillosis were detected. On Day +8, the patient experienced oligoanuria and physical examination revealed hepatomegaly, fluid retention, ascites, and weight gain. Thrombocytopenia was noted as well. On Day +9, the patient's serum transaminase concentration increased explosively. Similarly, the bilirubin level had reached a high value accompanied by elevated creatinine level within 24 hours. Alkaline phosphatase levels were progressively increased along with SOS/VOD syndrome. The patient developed coagulation disorders and was diagnosed with hepatic VOD. The patient was admitted to the Intensive Care unit and a treatment with Defibrotide was immediately initiated. Neutrophils recovery was achieved on Day +11 and liver dysfunction gradually improved from Day +13 to Day +15 with decreased transaminases levels. Although the patient's overall condition was progressively recovering, the patient presented sudden hemodynamic instability with acute respiratory distress syndrome on Day +16. The patient was diagnosed with acute mesenteric ischemia with hepatic and renal ischemic injury. The patient died a few hours later due to multi-organ-system failure.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient underwent oxaliplatin-based polychemotherapy followed by high-dose therapy and autologous stem cell transplantation for stage III mantle cell lymphoma. The patient developed hepatic VOD syndrome after the transplant and was admitted to the Intensive Care unit. Despite the treatment with Defibrotide, the patient died a few hours later due to multi-organ-system failure caused by acute mesenteric ischemia with hepatic and renal ischemic injury.

Patient: 46-year-old Caucasian male with Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD)

Hospital Course:
The patient was assigned to tolvaptan treatment as part of the TEMPO 3:4 trial in 2008. In 2015, the patient developed hypertension despite use of losartan and metoprolol, for which HCT was started and later increased. - Developed hypertension in 2015 despite losartan and metoprolol use
- HCT started and later increased
- 24-h urine production declined during tolvaptan treatment
- Decline in eGFR over time during tolvaptan treatment
- Copeptin highest during tolvaptan-HCT combination therapy

- Serum creatinine level: 94 μmol/L (2008) to 57 mL/min/1.73m2 (2017)
- eGFR: 83 mL/min/1.73m2 (2008) to 57 mL/min/1.73m2 (2017)
- Total kidney volume (TKV): 2351 mL
- Height adjusted TKV: 1292 mL/m
- Urine showed microalbuminuria
- Pre-tolvaptan, 24-h urine volume was 1300 mL

- After initiation of HCT, 24-h urine production declined to 2878 mL and later to 2699 mL
- Mean 24-h urine volume had declined during HCT co-treatment by 2078 mL (43%)
- 24-h creatinine excretion was similar before and after start of HCT

- Copeptin levels ranged from 11.1 pmol/L to 29.7 pmol/L

Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) with PKD2 mutation

Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) with PKD2 mutation

Continued management of ADPKD with consideration of current treatments and ongoing monitoring of kidney function.
