Follow-up with healthcare provider for ongoing management and monitoring of kidney function.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Male
Age: 58
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted by the rheumatology department with a diagnosis of IgG4-RD after a submandibular gland biopsy. Upon examination, the patient had an uncorrected visual acuity of 20/20 OU, with orthotropia at distance and near in the primary position. Ductions and versions were full without limitation. Exophthalmometry indicated 14.5 mm OU. During the one-year follow-up examination, the patient remained orthotropic.

Diagnostic Imaging:
Orbit CT images revealed the enlargement of lymph nodes in multiple areas, including peribronchial regions, right level I/III, right superior rectus, right medial rectus, left lateral rectus, and left inferior rectus muscles. Additionally, infiltrative lesions were observed in both lungs and perirenal space.

Summary:
This is a discharge summary for a 58-year-old male patient who was referred for ophthalmologic evaluation after being diagnosed with IgG4-RD by the rheumatology department. During his examination, the patient showed no limitation of ductions and versions, full ocular movements, and orthotropia at both distance and near. The imaging findings revealed lymph nodes enlargement and, infiltrative lesions in both lungs and perirenal space. Further treatment plans and follow-up recommendations were not mentioned in the case report.

Hospital Course:
This 62-year-old female patient presented with left upper eyelid swelling and recurrent conjunctival injection. On initial examination, her uncorrected visual acuities were 20/20 OU. Ductions and versions were full. Orbit CT showed a 2.5 cm sized enhancing mass in the left lacrimal gland and enlargement of the left lateral rectus muscle belly like a spindle shaped mass. Anterior orbitotomy and lacrimal gland biopsy confirmed increased positive IgG4 cells and positive CD3, CD20 and Ki-67. Serum IgG4 level was 74.0 mg/dL and IgG2 level was 770.0 mg/dL. This was consistent with a diagnosis of IgG4-related ophthalmic disease (IgG4-ROD).

Discharge Summary:
The patient was treated with oral steroids and showed improvement in the left upper eyelid swelling and recurrent conjunctival injection. The team provided extensive information about the diagnosis and importance to follow-up regularly with their primary care physician. Recommendations were given for necessary follow-up testing and a regimen of oral steroids for continued management of the condition. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms and seek medical care promptly if any related symptoms appear. Follow-up appointments were scheduled and the patient was provided with documentation of her condition and care provided while in the hospital.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

DOB: 01/01/1955                   Sex: Male

Admission Date: [Redacted]    Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Enlarged extraocular muscles

Final Diagnosis: IgG4-related ophthalmic disease (IgG4-ROD)

Hospital Course:

The patient was referred from an outside hospital for further evaluation of enlarged extraocular muscles which were incidentally found on CT during evaluation of sinusitis. Upon examination, the patient was noted to have 4 Δ of exotropia (XT) and 3 Δ of right hypertropia (RHT) in the primary position, with intermittent diplopia observed. Orbit MRI showed enlarged muscles, including the left lacrimal gland, right medial rectus, right inferior rectus, right lateral rectus, and right inferior oblique. The patient’s serum IgG4 level was elevated and demonstrated increased positive IgG4 cells on biopsy (>50-70 cells/HPF), indicating a diagnosis of IgG4-ROD. 

The patient was treated with oral steroids and demonstrated improvement in symptoms.  

Physical Exam Findings:

On examination, the patient’s corrected visual acuities were 20/30 OD and OS. Automatic refraction showed +0.00 Dsph − 0.25 Dcyl x 110A OD and +0.25 Dsph − 1.00 Dcyl x 75A OS. The patient showed 4 Δ of exotropia (XT) and 3 Δ of right hypertropia (RHT) in the primary position, as well as with head tilt. Ductions and versions were full, and MRD were +2 mm OU. Exophthalmometry showed 18 mm OD and 16.5 mm OS. 

Laboratory and Imaging Results:

Orbit MR imaging showed enlargement of the left lacrimal gland, right medial rectus, right inferior rectus, right lateral rectus, and right inferior oblique. Serum IgG4 level was elevated to 429.0 mg/dL (normal range, 6.1~ 121.4). Anterior orbitotomy and lacrimal gland biopsy showed increased positive IgG4 cells (>50–70 cells/HPF), and focally positive CD3, CD20, and Ki-67 (6%).

Course of Treatment:

The patient was treated with oral steroids and demonstrated improvement in symptoms.

Summary:

A 66-year-old male was referred from an outside hospital for further evaluation of enlarged extraocular muscles. After a thorough examination and imaging, the patient was diagnosed with IgG4-ROD, most likely causing the enlargement of extraocular muscles. The patient received oral steroid treatment, which led to improvement in symptoms. The patient was discharged after the satisfactory response to the treatment and was recommended for monitoring by an ophthalmologist.

Hospital Course:
A 74-year-old male presented with sudden onset right exophthalmos 15 days ago. Orbit MR imaging showed an infiltrating mass involving both orbits, especially the lacrimal gland and both lateral rectus muscles, foramen rotundum, infraobital groove and foramen, trigeminal nerve, and midline anterior skullbase. Lacrimal gland biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of lymphoplasmacytic infiltration with increased IgG4-positive cells (> 50–100 cells/HPF, IgG4/IgG ratio > 80%), consistent with IgG4-ROD. 

Three years later, the patient reported right facial edema, itching, right visual decrease, and vertical diplopia. Orbit MR imaging showed a decreased extent of infiltrative mass-forming lesions in both orbits, especially in both lacrimal glands, but significant remnant mass lesions were found in the right inferior extraconal space involving the right medial, lateral, and inferior rectus muscles, left lateral, and inferior rectus muscles, with perineural spread along both foramen rotundum and infraorbital foramen. Serum IgG4 level was elevated at 788.0 mg/dL. After taking oral prednisolone 20 mg a day, diplopia resolved and ductions and versions were full with orthotropia at distance and at near in the primary position on follow-up. 

At the time of discharge, the patient's condition had improved. Serum IgG4 level decreased to 249.9 mg/dL after three months of treatment with oral prednisolone. The patient was advised to continue follow-up with his primary care physician and specialists for monitoring and potential management of his diagnosis.

Discharge Summary:

Identification:
Patient name – Not disclosed
Age – 76
Gender – Female 
Admission Date: Not Provided 
Discharge Date: Not Provided 

Hospital Course:
76-year-old female patient was admitted with a complaint of shortness of breath when lying in the left lateral decubitus position. She had also experienced dyspnea after mild exercise for the past 9 months and a sense of abdominal fullness. The patient had an 8-year history of atrial fibrillation (AF) and severe Tricuspid Regurgitation (TR). 

Diagnostic Assessment:
The electrocardiogram showed AF with low fibrillatory wave amplitude. Echocardiography showed an enlarged right ventricular (RV) cavity and mild paradoxical motion of the ventricular septum. She had no L-R shunt disease. Computed tomography (CT) findings showed that the maximum size of the right atrium (RA) reached 121 mm with RA enlargement over time. 

Treatment:
Surgery was performed via median sternotomy using cardiopulmonary bypass and intraoperative transesophageal echocardiography due to the thin pericardium and enlarged tricuspid valve annulus with no structural abnormality. Tricuspid annuloplasty was performed using a 28-mm Carpentier-Edwards Physio tricuspid annuloplasty ring. Plication of the enlarged RA was performed, mainly at the interatrial septum, the free RA wall, including the appendage, and the space between the inferior vena cava and the tricuspid ring, in addition to the free RA wall, including the appendage. Additionally, closure of the left atrial appendage from the outside was performed to prevent left atrial thrombus formation. 

Recovery:
Post-operative course was uneventful. Postoperative X-ray and CT showed a reduced cardiac silhouette and RA volume, and postoperative echocardiogram showed an ejection fraction of 58% and mild TR with a pressure gradient of 29 mmHg. The patient’s symptoms were completely resolved, and she was discharged 3 weeks after surgery. 

Follow Up:
The patient is doing well 2 years after surgery. 

Summary:
76-year-old female with an 8-year history of atrial fibrillation and severe tricuspid regurgitation underwent surgery to correct her condition. She had experienced shortness of breath, dyspnea, and abdominal fullness, and her diagnostic assessments showed an enlarged right ventricular (RV) cavity, mild paradoxical motion of the ventricular septum, and an enlarged RA over time. Surgery was successful, and postoperative assessments showed a reduced cardiac silhouette and RA volume. The patient showed no symptoms post-surgery and was discharged after three weeks, with a follow-up after two years.

Patient Name:
Age: 67
Gender: Male

Admission Date: 

Discharge Date: 

Diagnosis: Renal Oncocytoma

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted for postoperative follow-up management after receiving a renal allograft from a deceased  donor. During the routine examination, a 2.4-cm lesion was serendipitously discovered on the upper pole of the renal allograft. Biopsy confirmed the lesion to be consistent with a renal oncocytoma. The eosinophilic variant of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma was ruled out following negative immunohistochemical staining.

Treatment and Care Plan:

Given the low risk of malignant transformation in an oncocytoma, the decision was made to monitor the tumor with active surveillance. The patient received mycophenolate-mofetil, tacrolimus, and prednisone throughout the 5-year follow-up period, and the regimen for immunosuppression was not changed despite the presence of the renal mass. The patient underwent ultrasonography every 2 months for the first year, followed by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) every year. The renal oncocytoma displayed no growth, regression, or any other interim morphological changes.

Patient Outcome:

After 60 months of active surveillance, radiological studies have shown no growth, regression, or any other morphological changes to the renal oncocytoma. The patient is alive and well. 

Recommendations:

The patient should continue to undergo annual MRI monitoring to ensure that the tumor remains stable. In case of any changes, further evaluation and treatment will be advised.

Hospital Course:

The 40-year-old male patient with refractory classical Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) was enrolled in a study of anti-PD-1 therapy. After receiving the third dose of anti-PD1 antibody (SHR-1210, 200 mg) within 30 days of initial treatment, the patient developed severe proteinuria. The therapy was discontinued, and the patient was monitored. His urine protein excretion initially decreased but subsequently increased, leading to hospital admission. Diagnostic tests revealed hypoalbuminemia, elevated total serum cholesterol, and podocyte foot process effacement consistent with minimal change disease (MCD). Treatment with prednisone (1 mg/kg/day) for 8 weeks resulted in full remission of proteinuria and improvement in serum albumin. 

Summary:

The 40-year-old male patient with refractory HL developed severe proteinuria after the third dose of anti-PD1 antibody therapy. The patient was subsequently diagnosed with MCD and was treated with prednisone for 8 weeks, resulting in full remission of proteinuria and improvement in serum albumin levels.

Discharge Summary

Admission Date: May 2013 
Discharge Date: July 2013 
Principal Diagnosis: MDS with excess blasts: refractory anemia with excess blasts-1 (RAEB-1)

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 75-year-old Caucasian man, was admitted for bicytopenia in May 2013. His initial blood cell count showed hemoglobin 8 g/dl, platelets 87 × 109/l, and leukocytes 6.1 × 109/L. He had a medical history of T2D treated with biphasic insulin aspart and triple-bypass surgery for coronary disease in 2010. No family history of hematological malignancies was noted. He was hospitalized in an intensive care unit for grade IV anemia and then transferred to the hematology department after blood transfusions. Bone marrow aspiration showed multilineage dysplasia with 8% of blasts, consistent with a diagnosis of MDS with excess blasts: refractory anemia with excess blasts-1 (RAEB-1).

The patient was initially treated with darbepoetin 300 μg per week, without response. A second bone marrow aspiration two months later showed 29% of blasts, consistent with the diagnosis of AML progression. He consented to participate in a phase I–II clinical research study assessing the combination of 5-azacitidine with idarubicin in July 2013. He showed a partial response with 8% of bone marrow blasts after six cycles, and transfusion independence.

However, the patient reported higher blood glucose levels 2–3 days after the start of each 5-azacitidine cycle, requiring an increased dose of self-administered insulin. Further monitoring confirmed higher blood glucose levels from days 4 to 12 of each 5-azacitidine cycle. No change in diet or in physical activities was noted. Our patient experienced such dysregulation during all the additional 15 cycles until a fatal progression of AML.

Impression:

The patient was admitted with bicytopenia and diagnosed with MDS with excess blasts: refractory anemia with excess blasts-1 (RAEB-1). After no response to initial treatment, he participated in a clinical research study and experienced a partial response. However, he had blood glucose dysregulation during the treatment cycles. Unfortunately, he experienced a fatal progression of AML.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a previously healthy full-term 15-day-old male who initially presented with poor feeding, fever, irritability, and rash. On Day 4 of illness, he developed recurrent apnea and was transferred to the pediatric intensive care unit due to ongoing fever. A suspected infectious etiology was ruled out, and on Day 7 of illness, the patient was diagnosed with incomplete Kawasaki Disease (KD) and was treated with IVIG. Over the following 48 hours, the patient's extremity edema resolved, and fever did not recur. He had persistent thrombocytosis followed by typical extremity desquamation. Echocardiograms on weeks 1, 2, and 6, and at 12 months were normal with no carditis or coronary artery abnormalities.

Diagnosis:
Incomplete Kawasaki Disease.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with IVIG (2 g/kg) for  incomplete Kawasaki Disease and low dose aspirin in the subacute phase.

Follow-Up:
The patient had normal echocardiograms at weeks 1, 2, and 6, and at 12 months with no carditis or coronary artery abnormalities. Regular follow-up appointments are recommended as per standard protocols.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Medical History:
The patient presented with severe headache and elevated blood pressure. A cardiac biopsy via catheterization was not conclusive regarding the precise nature of the lesion. After informed consent, the patient underwent surgery to remove a biphasic synovial sarcoma mass. Unfortunately, after the patient received chemotherapy (Ifosfamide/Mesna) for 4 cycles over a period of 3 months, the tumor increased, and multiple pulmonary metastases developed. As a result, the patient received a SynCardia total artificial heart, but ultimately passed away a year and a half after the initial surgery.

Hospital Course:
The patient had surgery that discovered a 3 x 4 cm mass in the right atrium that extended into the right ventricle, adhering to the septal surface of the leaflet and infiltrating the adjacent interventricular septum. The exophytic intraatrial and intraventricular components of the mass were removed. Definitive histological examination showed a malignant neoplasm characterized by epithelial cells, positive for cytokeratin, forming glandular structures, admixed with a spindle cell component.

Summary:
The patient presented with a large, solid right intraventricular mass of 7.1 × 2.2 × 4.7 cm that originated from the middle-inferior ventricular septum and extended into the right atrium, with systo-diastolic fluttering. A cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) study confirmed the presence of the solid, intracavitary mass. After a cardiac biopsy via catheterization was not conclusive, the patient underwent surgery to remove the tumor. Subsequently, the patient received chemotherapy, but an increase in the residual ventricular tumor was detected. The patient received a SynCardia total artificial heart, but ultimately passed away due to multiple pulmonary metastases.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 32-year-old white male, presented to our department with a 1 month history of eye redness (left eye). In the initial ophthalmic evaluation, the patient presented with two ocular lesions, which were identified as a chalazion and a subconjunctival hemorrhage, respectively. A blood dyscrasia and KS were initially suspected due to the duplicity of lesions. The patient was subsequently diagnosed with ocular KS after a positive HIV-1 test, consistent with the presence of facial seborrheic dermatitis (a characteristic of HIV-AIDS). The patient underwent excisional biopsy of the conjunctival mass and incisional biopsy of the right superior eyelid and was staged for HIV-AIDS based on a CD4 cell count of 23/mm3 and a viral RNA load of 427,000/ml. Further multidisciplinary assessments showed diffuse KS with skin and supraglottis involvement.

Medical History:

The patient did not have any significant medical history other than presenting with facial seborrheic dermatitis at the time of presentation.

Hospital Course:

The patient was initiated on HAART and systemic chemotherapy under medical supervision for AIDS and diffused KS.

Discharge Summary:

The patient completed their hospital stay with uneventful postoperative evaluations and no signs of recurrence noticed during the 6-month follow-up. The patient was initiated on a treatment plan for AIDS and Diffused KS. Educational counseling was provided for the patient regarding safe sex practices and follow-up visits. The patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions to continue their prescribed treatment regimen, engage in appropriate follow-up medical care, and to adhere to all recommended lifestyle modifications.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of admission: [REDACTED]
Date of discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with severe ARDS that developed from TB pneumonia, for which standard anti-tuberculous drugs were administered. During hospitalization, the patient's respiratory and circulatory conditions deteriorated despite high-frequency oscillating ventilation, vasopressor support, and administration of immunoglobulin. On the third day after admission, the patient's DIC score had increased, and for the treatment of DIC, rTM was administered as an intravenous drip infusion for 6 consecutive days. DIC score gradually decreased, and the patient was extubated on the 27th day after admission. After being moved to the infectious disease department, the patient's fever was reduced, her respiratory condition was stable, and she was discharged from hospital on the 33rd day after admission.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented with severe ARDS that developed from TB pneumonia and was admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit. Despite treatment, the patient's respiratory and circulatory conditions deteriorated, and DIC score increased on the third day of admission. Treatment with rTM was administered for six consecutive days, and DIC score gradually decreased. The patient was eventually extubated and moved to the infectious disease department, where her fever was reduced and her respiratory condition was stable. The patient was discharged from hospital after 33 days of admission.

Discharge Summary
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Sex: Male
Link to full EHR: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 42-year-old Cameroonian man, presented to our hospital with a 1-week history of fever, headache, joint pains, and anorexia, and a 4-day history of no bowel movements. He self-medicated an undocumented orally administered antimalarial medication but symptoms persisted. Three days later, he developed generalized abdominal pain, colicky in character, with a severity of 5/10 on a visual analogue scale. This was associated with progressive abdominal distension and an altered bowel pattern initially characterized by an inability to pass stool and flatus over 4 days but he denied any vomiting. A worsening of his symptoms prompted his visit to our hospital. 

On examination, his mucous membranes were dry, his conjunctivae were pink, and his vital signs were normal. His abdomen was mildly distended with mild diffuse tenderness. There was neither guarding nor rebound tenderness. Percussion note was tympanic and bowel sounds were hyperactive. His rectum was empty per digital rectal examination and his prostate was not enlarged. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.

Diagnostic tests revealed that the patient had malaria. Also, his complete blood count values were within normal ranges. His metabolic panel was within the normal range except for elevated alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminotransferase levels. His HIV serology was negative, and his test for typhoid fever was also negative. There was mild free intra-abdominal fluid in all four quadrants on abdominal ultrasound.

A working diagnosis of functional bowel obstruction secondary to malaria was established. The patient received three doses of intravenously administered quinine base infusion and intravenously administered crystalloids. He followed "nothing by mouth" instructions and passed a small quantity of feces 48 hours after initiation of antimalarial medication, with complete resolution of the abdominal pain, distension, and bowel movements on the fourth day of hospital stay.

A stool examination was done with no organisms identified. The patient was discharged on an orally administered artemisinin-based antimalarial combination and instructed to follow up in 2 weeks. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
Sub-acute intestinal obstruction secondary to malaria.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient should continue to take the prescribed antimalarial medication as directed. He should maintain a balanced diet and drink plenty of fluids. The patient should avoid strenuous activities until further instructions from his physician. He should follow up with his primary care provider in 2 weeks to monitor for any potential complications. In case of any concerning symptoms, the patient should contact his physician immediately.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 20-year-old female with no significant medical history other than presenting with fever, fatigue, anorexia, vomiting, and systemic myalgia. She was transferred to this hospital for further evaluation and treatment. Laboratory investigations showed elevated liver enzyme and creatine phosphokinase (CPK) levels. Imaging studies revealed minimal pericardial effusion, diffuse swelling, and internal heterogeneous image in the liver, which led to acute hepatitis diagnosis. On day 2 of hospitalization, the patient became hypotensive and presented cyanosis of the lips, distended external jugular veins, cardiorespiratory distress, and coarse crackles over both lung fields. Electrocardiography showed diffuse ST-segment elevation, and cardiac imaging studies revealed a spherical, dilated ventricle with pericardial effusion. The patient underwent endomyocardial biopsy, which showed lymphocyte infiltration of the myocardium and intranuclear inclusions confirmed as acute myocarditis. Intravenous dobutamine administration was started on day 3, and the patient's condition improved significantly. CPK, AST, ALT, and BNP levels were normalized on day 18. The patient was discharged on day 19 without any further complications.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with acute myocarditis combined with hepatitis arising from herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. The diagnosis was based on the presence of HSV-specific immunoglobulin M (IgM) detected upon admission, which increased at 2 weeks and returned to normal 6 months later. Additionally, HSV-specific immunoglobulin G (IgG) increased from hospital admission to 2 weeks.

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to follow up with her primary care physician and cardiologist regularly. She should avoid strenuous physical activities until further notice. The patient has been educated about the importance of taking care of her health and following up with her medical providers. She has been provided with discharge instructions as well as all of the necessary paperwork for her follow-up appointments.

Medications:
[Redacted]

Instructions:
- Limit physical activity and rest as needed.
- Follow up with your primary care physician and cardiologist regularly.
- Follow all medication instructions and take your medication as prescribed.
- Monitor signs and symptoms of any new health issues, and report them immediately to your healthcare provider.
- Avoid alcohol and drug use.
- Maintain a healthy diet and exercise regularly, as recommended by your healthcare provider.

Discharge Disposition:
The patient was discharged to her home in stable condition.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [XXX]

Age: 70-year-old
Sex: Female
Admission Date: [XXX]
Discharge Date: [XXX]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of cecal submucosal mass identified during a routine screening colonoscopy. The patient's medical history was significant for surgically treated squamous cell carcinoma of the nose. An abdominal CT scan revealed a well-circumscribed hypervascular anterior cecal wall mass with no metastases or other distant lesions.

After multidisciplinary team discussion, the decision was made to perform an exploratory surgery, and a wedge resection including the appendix was performed. The final pathology report revealed a benign spindle cell tumor diagnosed as cecal schwannoma with a reactive lymph node.

The post-operative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged on day 5 with pain killers. The final multidisciplinary committee decision was follow-up without further treatment needed.

FOLLOW-UP:

The patient was advised to follow-up with regular screenings and check-ups. At 1-year follow-up, the patient is disease-free, and no further treatment is indicated.

DIAGNOSIS:

Cecal schwannoma with a reactive lymph node.

SUMMARY:

The 70-year-old female patient underwent an exploratory surgery for a submucosal cecal mass and was diagnosed with cecal schwannoma with a reactive lymph node. The final pathology report revealed a benign spindle cell tumor. The post-operative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged on day 5, and no further treatment is indicated. Follow-up is recommended for regular screenings and check-ups to track the patient's medical condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Sex: Male
Age: 39
Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course: 

The patient was admitted with a severe injury to his right elbow, which showed swelling and tenderness. Radiographs showed a fracture of the ulna coronoid process, which was displaced by about 4 mm. The patient underwent a minimally invasive arthroscopic osteosynthesis 7 days after the injury. Surgery was performed under general anaesthesia, and a 3.5 mm cannulated cancellous screw (CCS) and two 1.5 mm K-wires were used to fix the fracture. Postoperatively, he wore an immobilizing splint for 1 week and then began physical therapy to increase the range of motion. After 3 weeks, the K-wires were removed, and bone union was achieved after 4 months. At 1-year postoperatively, he had no pain, and a physical examination revealed a complete range of motion.

Discharge Diagnosis: 

Coronoid process fracture, Regan-Morrey type 2

Medical History: 

Not available

Medications on Discharge: 

Not available

Follow-up Instructions: 

The patient was able to resume his normal daily activities without any pain. He will continue physical therapy for several weeks to maintain and increase the range of motion. The patient did not require further hospitalization. 

Signed,

Physician's Name: N/A
Date: N/A

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]

Patient Information:
Age: 40
Gender: Male
Medical History: None reported

History:
The patient was admitted to our hospital after sustaining an injury whilst walking resulting in a coronoid process fracture, Regan-Morrey type 2. Our medical team performed arthroscopic osteosynthesis 10 days after the injury. The fracture was determined to be comminuted and could not be fixed using CCS, so osteosynthesis was performed using three K-wires.

Treatment:
Postoperatively, the patient was instructed to wear an immobilizing splint for 2 weeks and then began physical therapy to improve elbow range of motion. The patient returned for follow-up appointments after 4 months, where complete bone union was confirmed, and after 8 months where the K-wires were removed. A follow-up at 10 months showed that the patient no longer had pain, and a physical examination revealed complete range of motion, indicating a good clinical course.

Discharge Condition:
The patient's discharge condition was improved, with a good clinical course, no pain, and complete range of motion.

Recommendations:
The patient is recommended to continue physical therapy and to take measures to prevent further injury, such as avoiding activities that may cause harm.

Follow-Up:
The patient should be advised to schedule regular follow-up appointments to monitor progress and prevent complications.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 62-year-old male

Admitted: with dyspnea and chest pain

Diagnosis: Cardiac tamponade caused by metastatic urothelial carcinoma (UC) with pericardial effusion

Hospital Course: 

The patient was admitted with progressive dyspnea and chest pain. On examination, he had a heart rate of 136 bpm, blood pressure of 122/74 mm Hg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths/min, and O2 saturation of 98% on room air. Heart sounds were muffled, and heart rhythm was irregularly irregular. Distention of the jugular veins was observed, and Kussmaul's sign was present. Although pulsus paradoxus was not observed, other physical findings were extremely concerning for cardiac tamponade. Bibasilar crackles were present on lung auscultation. Laboratory data was remarkable for a creatinine of 1.42 and INR of 3.6 (on warfarin for a history of pulmonary embolism). His electrocardiogram revealed atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular rate (RVR) and electrical alternans. Chest radiograph showed enlargement of the cardiac silhouette.

A bedside transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was obtained, which showed a large pericardial effusion with diastolic compression of the right ventricle, suggestive of cardiac tamponade, as well as mild left ventricular systolic dysfunction (see Figures and ). The patient's INR was reversed to <1.5, and he underwent emergent subxiphoid pericardial window with the removal of 700 ml of turbid, dark, bloody pericardial fluid. He had significant improvement in hemodynamics and respiratory distress. The pericardial fluid cytology and pericardial biopsy were both positive for malignancy, consistent with metastatic UC (see ).

One week after the pericardial window, the patient underwent a computerized tomography (CT) scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis, which did not show evidence of metastatic disease elsewhere. Given the recurrence of UC with metastasis to the pericardium, he was started on atezolizumab. Subsequently, he was noted to have recurrent pericardial effusion suggesting failure of treatment (see ). He was then started on pemetrexed, a folate antimetabolite chemotherapy drug, for metastatic UC with plans to complete 6 cycles.

Recommendation:

The patient requires close follow-up with his oncology team to monitor response to treatment and recurrence. He should receive regular cardiovascular evaluations due to his history of cardiac tamponade. It is recommended that the patient be advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and follow-up with his healthcare provider as needed.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient was instructed on the importance of following up with his healthcare provider and oncology team. He should continue taking his medications as prescribed and should not miss any scheduled appointments. It is recommended that the patient seek medical attention immediately if he experiences any symptoms of shortness of breath, chest pain, or palpitations.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Length of Stay: 10 days

Admitting Diagnosis: Pyogenic liver abscess with sepsis

Principal Diagnosis: Pyogenic liver abscess

Other Diagnoses: Acute tubular injury due to sepsis, normocytic anemia, bilateral pleural effusions, moderate right upper quadrant tenderness, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, fever, tachycardia, and bilateral pleural effusion

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with a five-day history of moderate RUQ abdominal pain associated with fever, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Upon admission, he was found to have normocytic anemia, leukocytosis, and elevated liver function tests. Imaging studies revealed a multiloculated right hepatic mass measuring 8.4cm with soft tissue extension into the upper pole of the right kidney. Interventional radiology performed successful image-guided percutaneous drainage of the liver abscess.

The patient also developed bilateral pleural effusions, which required thoracentesis. Acute tubular injury secondary to sepsis was suspected to be the etiology of acute kidney injury.

Upon antibiotic therapy with Nafcillin, the patient's condition improved. Blood cultures obtained on day four were consistently positive for MSSA, and repeat blood cultures were negative on day six. A midline catheter was inserted for continued IV antibiotic therapy.

Follow-up in the general surgery clinic one month after discharge revealed the resolution of the pyogenic liver abscess and consistently normal laboratory values. The patient reported a return to baseline functional status with no residual symptoms.

Discharge Medications:
Nafcillin IV therapy

Discharge Instructions:
1. Continue all prescribed medications as directed.
2. Follow up with your primary care physician.
3. Return to the emergency department immediately if symptoms worsen or if new symptoms develop.
4. Maintain regular follow-up visits to monitor your condition.

Discharge Summary
Patient Name: Anonymous
Medical Record Number: ######

Admission Date: ######
Discharge Date: ######

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
A 35-year-old nulliparous African-American female presented with a history of five first and one second trimester recurrent pregnancy losses. In addition, she had a nine-year history of irregular heavy bleeding associated with dysmenorrhea.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
The patient's past medical history was not significant.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient was scheduled for hysteroscopy and diagnostic laparoscopy. She also gave consent for possible open Strassmans metroplasty.

On hysteroscopy, a normal looking endometrium was visualized with a right-sided tubal ostia and a small tubal ostia on the left that did not appear to be patent. Laparoscopically, a bicornuate uterus was found with associated endometriosis at the vesicouterine fold. Open metroplasty was done. A copper intrauterine device was left in situ to separate the uterine walls and possibly reduce the chances of uterine synechiae. In addition, endometriotic deposits discovered at the vesico uterine fold were ablated.

The patient had an unremarkable follow-up after surgery with no complications reported. A HSG 6 months after surgery revealed unification of the uterine horns but both tubes were not delineated.

Patient was lost to follow-up but two years later she presented having conceived spontaneously and a TVS revealed a single intrauterine pregnancy at 13 weeks. Her antenatal workup was as highlighted in the medical record.

At 33 weeks, the patient presented with a history of lower abdominal pain worsening over the past few weeks and right-sided fundal tenderness pain score of seven out of ten on the pain assessment scale. The patient did not have any features suggestive of bowel obstruction and had a normal NST and an obstetric ultrasound that was done showed a single intrauterine pregnancy with normal biophysical profile and no features of placental abruption or slower uterine segment site dehiscence. The pain was significant enough to warrant an admission for which she subsequently received antenatal steroids for lung maturity and opioid analgesia for pain relief. However, the pain did not completely resolve and she underwent a cesarean delivery at 33 weeks and 5 days due to persistent lower abdominal pain. The outcome was a live male infant with a birth weight of 1950 grams and APGAR of 9, 10, 10. There was no evidence of uterine rupture although she had venous congestion and massive varicose veins bilaterally at the cornual areas. The previous metroplasty scar was intact.

The patient had a resolution of the abdominal pain postoperatively and had an unremarkable postoperative recovery. She was discharged on the fifth postoperative day.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1. Bicornuate uterus
2. Endometriosis
3. Pregnancy complicated by abdominal pain

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Take prescribed medications as directed
2. Rest at home and avoid heavy lifting or strenuous activity.
3. Attend all scheduled follow-up appointments with the obstetrician.
4. Monitor any unusual or persistent abdominal pain and report to the obstetrician immediately.

Discharge Summary for Case 1:

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 40 years
Gender: Male

Admission Information:
The patient was admitted to the hospital on [REDACTED] with symptoms of general malaise, arthralgia in his extremities, facial cyanosis, and fever (39°C). A medical history of post-traumatic splenectomy was reported.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, empirical antibiotic therapy was started with ceftriaxone and vancomycin as the patient was diagnosed with secondary sepsis caused by meningitis from Streptococcus pneumoniae. Due to a severe hemodynamic instability, the patient was transferred to the ICU where they exhibited persistent hypotension and an inflammatory state with high levels of CRP and PCT.

The patient underwent continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) in hemodiafiltration mode for a total of 68 hours along with Cytosorb cartridge. During this treatment, a general improvement was observed in terms of the patient's hemodynamic and metabolic stability as well as reducing levels of PCT and CRP. The patient's norepinephrine demand decreased significantly throughout the treatment and the patient could be stopped from CRRT after 12 days.

Discharge Information:
After further treatment and observation, the patient was discharged on [REDACTED]. At the time of discharge, the patient was alert, collaborative, tracheotomized, and spontaneously breathing with a recovery of diuresis. The patient was advised to continue with follow-up appointments according to the recommended medical protocols.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with secondary sepsis caused by meningitis from Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Recommendations:
The patient was advised to follow up with medical appointments as per recommended medical protocols.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Case 2
Sex: Female
Age: 66

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date+2 months]

Medical History:
- Treated with beta-blockers for tachyarrhythmia
- Appendectomy
- Colon cancer 
- Splenectomy for colonic metastases

Reason for Admission:
- Fever (40°C)
- Hypotension
- General illness

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient presented with skin ischemic lesions with rapid deterioration to whole body cyanosis and metabolic and lactic acidosis. Blood cultures confirmed the diagnosis of sepsis from Streptococcus pneumoniae paralleled with severe purpura fulminans. Empirical antibiotic therapy started with ceftriaxone (2 g every 12h) and levofloxacin (500 mg every 12h) for 11 and 7 days, respectively, with adjustments due to renal function changes. 
The patient later became oligoanuric, severely hypotonic with hemodynamic instability (epinephrine 0.4 μg/kg/min), and thrombocytopenic, presenting severe bleeding. A CVVHDF treatment in combination with one 24-hour session of Cytosorb hemoadsorption was started immediately after the ICU admission. 
This combined treatment resulted in a clear and progressive hemodynamic stabilization accompanied with a marked reduction of epinephrine to 0.1 μg/kg/min and a reduction of CRP from 17.5 mg/dl to 13 mg/dl. Lactacidemia, elevated at the admission (15 mmol/l), decreased until 4 in the first 24h. At the same time, PCT decreased from 18.35 ng/ml to 2 ng/ml after 6 days.
However, the patient experienced a recrudescence of the septic state and was diagnosed with Enterobacter aerogenes, which colonised the body through the injured intestine wall. Due to her severe injuries at the extremities, the patient needed amputations. Two months after the first admission, the patient passed away due to the reoccurrence of the second septic episode.

Discharge Diagnosis:
- Severe purpura fulminans
- Recurrent septicemia from Enterobacter aerogenes

Discharge Condition:
- Deceased

Discharge Instructions:
- N/A

Follow-Up Care:
- N/A

Signed,
[Doctor's Name]
[Date]

Discharge Summary:

History and Admission:
A 47-year-old male with a fever, asthenia, and lumbar pain with signs of diffuse petechiae was admitted to the hospital. He became severely hypovolemic and tachycardic, showing also metabolic acidosis with high lactate levels. Blood cultures were taken, and empirical antibiotic therapy was administered. The diagnoses confirmed septic shock secondary to Neisseria meningitidis infection (Serotype C).

Hospital Course:
The patient was transferred to the ICU and underwent norepinephrine and epinephrine infusions. Inflammation was controlled with PCT test, which showed extremely high levels. The patient's condition worsened with a bleeding disorder, severe hypotension, and oligoanuria. Hemofiltration treatment was necessary, followed by the installation of Cytosorb to the CVVH circuit the next day.

Discharge:
Within the course of 72-hour Cytosorb treatments, the patient's condition improved. The hemodynamic state stabilized, lactate and inflammation values decreased. The patient showed decreased disseminated intravascular coagulopathy, demarcation of skin necrosis areas, and a recovery of vital functions. The patient was extubated 10 days after admission and weaned from CVVH 12 days after the ICU admission. After 23 days from recovery, the patient was transferred to rehabilitation medicine, waiting for plastic surgeon consultant for amputation of some phalanges.

Age: 36

Gender: Female

Date of Admission: [Date]

Date of Discharge: [Date]

Admission Diagnosis: Bacterial meningitis infection

Discharge Diagnosis: Bacterial meningitis infection caused by Neisseria meningitidis (Serotype C), thrombocytopenia, acute renal failure, and inflammation

Hospital Course:

Mrs. [Name] was admitted to the ICU with a suspected diagnosis of sepsis secondary to meningitis. The patient presented hypotension, requiring the administration of inotrope drugs within the next day. Lab tests confirmed the diagnosis of bacterial meningitis infection, underlined a condition of thrombocytopenia, acute renal failure, and inflammation. After ICU admission, treatment with CVVHDF (Prismaflex, Oxiris, Baxter, USA) and Cytosorb was started to manage the patient's condition.

During the course of hemoadsorption treatments, a hemodynamic stabilization was observed, and symptoms improved significantly. Norepinephrine could be stopped after 78 hours, and dobutamine after 48 hours of treatment. Petechiae and skin lesions were stable already after the first day of treatment. A complete recovery of renal function and diuresis was observed after [Number of] days from admission, and the patient could be transferred to medicine after 7 days. 

Follow-Up:

The patient was followed by dermatologists and vascular surgeons for the outcome of the septic embolism complication, evaluating the possible amputation of one toe.

Mrs. [Name] is being discharged with instructions to monitor symptoms and follow up with necessary medical specialists. The patient should ensure strict adherence to follow-up appointments and recommended medical interventions for the successful management of her condition.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital after being struck by a motor vehicle, which resulted in multiple injuries, including bilateral knee injuries. Upon arrival at the hospital, the patient underwent a series of diagnostic tests, including a FAST exam, chest radiograph, and computed topography (CT) of the head and cervical spine, which were negative. Further examination identified bilateral knee injuries, including a left knee Segond fracture and multiple ligamentous injuries to both knees, with the right knee showing more severe injuries than the left knee.

The patient was placed in bilateral hinged braces with the left knee unlocked and the right knee in locked extension. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was performed on both knees to evaluate for ligamentous injuries, requiring multiligamentous reconstructions on both knees, with the left knee addressed first to explore and decompress the common peroneal nerve. Intraoperative findings of the left knee included a positive lateral gutter drive-through sign indicative of a PLC injury. The procedure consisted of ACL reconstruction with a hamstring autograft, augmented with an allograft, PLC reconstruction utilizing a TA allograft, and repair of the native avulsed LCL and ALL with suture anchors. The patient was placed in a hinged brace locked in extension after the surgery.

The decision was made to proceed with the right knee reconstruction one week later, during which surgery included ACL reconstruction with a bone-tendon-bone autograft, PCL reconstruction with an Achilles allograft, MCL primary repair with additional Achilles allograft reconstruction, PLC reconstruction with TA allograft, and repair of the posterior horn of the medial meniscus. Both knees were kept in a brace locked in extension with minimal weight bearing for the first six weeks.

The patient underwent physical therapy rehabilitation at six months post-op. On the physical exam, both knees demonstrated full range of motion, with a grade 1A Lachman maneuver in both knees. The patient was able to return to work and recreational activities at ten weeks after surgery and was cleared for straight running at six months post-op.

Impression:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with multiple injuries, including bilateral knee injuries, resulting in multiligamentous reconstructions on both knees. The patient underwent post-operative rehabilitation and physical therapy, which resulted in significant improvement in both knees' range of motion. As the patient meets the discharge criteria, the patient is being discharged from the hospital and advised to continue physical therapy and post-operative care as recommended by the healthcare provider. The patient was provided with discharge instructions, follow-up care instructions, and contact information for their primary care physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 70-year-old female
Admitted: November 2017
Hospital: Skåne University Hospital, Sweden

History:
The patient had a medical history of breast cancer and lymphoedema of her left arm. She had a fever, shivers, and a suspected skin infection upon admission.

Physical Examination:
The patient had a sharply demarcated, warm, swollen, and painful erythema measuring approximately 7x15 cm on her left upper arm. A grade II systolic murmur was heard with punctum maximum I2 dexter. No local portal of bacterial entry was found. She had no signs of septic emboli, oral examination showed no signs of infection, and examination of lymph nodes was normal.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with erysipelas.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with intravenous penicillin followed by an oral penicillin for seven days. The treatment was prolonged for 10 days.

Follow-Up:
Repeat blood cultures were drawn 14 days after discontinuation of antibiotics and they were negative. The patient has been referred to the lymphoedema outpatient clinic as well as to the dentist office to prevent further infections.

Outcome:
On follow-up, the patient had no sequelae to her infection.

Conclusion:
The patient was successfully treated for erysipelas and is stable upon discharge. Further preventative measures have been taken to avoid recurrence of the infection.

Hospital Course:
- 79-year-old male with past medical history significant for hypertension, chronic kidney disease stage IV, dementia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presented to the Emergency Department after being transferred from a correctional facility due to low hemoglobin found on routine labs
- Physical examination showed dry oral mucosa and poor dentition, a 2/6 systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border, and hematomas on both posterior shoulders, bilateral upper arms, and the right medial forearm
- Laboratory studies showed a hemoglobin level of 6.9 g/dL (decreased from his baseline: 10 g/dL), elevated BUN at 99 mmol/L, and creatinine of 3.23 mg/dL (increased from his baseline creatinine: 2.7 mg/dL)
- Intravenous fluids and red blood cell transfusion were initiated, which produced a temporary increase in hemoglobin levels to 7.5 g/dL before gradually dropping
- Fecal occult blood test was positive and CT abdomen showed right perinephric and right paracolic gutter fat stranding surrounding the right iliopsoas muscle which was asymmetrically enlarged without evidence of definite hyperdense intramuscular hematoma, but possible intramuscular hemorrhage or myositis
- Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) and colonoscopy revealed terminal ileum containing hematin (altered blood/coffee-ground-like material) without a clear source of bleeding
- Coagulation studies showed an elevated activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) at 101.5 seconds and mixing study showed only partial correction of the aPTT, suggesting the possibility of a coagulation factor-specific antibody
- Levels of factors VIII, IX, XI, and XII were ordered and showed factor VIII activity of <0.01 unit/mL, factor IX activity of 0.80 unit/mL, factor XI activity of 0.40 unit/mL, and factor XII activity of 0.34 unit/mL
- Bethesda assay was performed and showed an elevated factor VIII inhibitor level at 390 U/mL, which confirmed the diagnosis of acquired hemophilia A
- Patient was started on cyclophosphamide 50 mg QD and dexamethasone 20 mg QD to inhibit the body's immune response against factor VIII, and inhibitor levels decreased to 280 U/mL after 10 days of therapy
- Etiology of the patient's acquired factor VIII inhibitor is unclear, so tumor markers (PSA, CEA, CA 19-9) and CT scans (thorax and abdominopelvic) were ordered in order to rule out the underlying malignancy, all of which were normal
- Patient was started on weekly infusions of rituximab, and the most recent factor VIII inhibitor level was down to 70.4 U/mL with stable hemoglobin at 13.2 g/dL
- Hematology continues to closely monitor the quantity of the inhibitor levels and his response to treatment, and patient is advised to avoid any activity in which he may sustain trauma or fall due to his increased risk of bleeding

Diagnosis:
- Acquired hemophilia A

Discharge Instructions:
- Continue to follow-up with Hematology for monitoring of factor VIII inhibitor levels and response to treatment
- Avoid any activity in which the patient may sustain trauma or fall due to the increased risk of bleeding
- Keep all upcoming appointments and follow-up with primary care physician to manage hypertension, chronic kidney disease, dementia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
- Schedule a colonoscopy follow-up as directed by Gastroenterology
- Continue taking amlodipine 10 mg daily for hypertension
- Take any new medications as prescribed

Discharge Summary:

Patient Details:
Name: (redacted)
DOB: (redacted)
Age: 13 months
Sex: Female
Hospital: (redacted)
Admission Date: (redacted)
Discharge Date: (redacted)

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented to the emergency department for urinary retention. She was born in Mexico at 35 weeks gestation and diagnosed with mild gross motor developmental delay two months prior to admission. The adoptive parents reported about 2 weeks of fussiness and decreased ability to bear weight on her lower extremities. Upon examination, the patient's strength, trunk, and bilateral lower extremities were hypotonic, with 0/5 strength. A CT scan showed complete retrospondylolisthesis of T12 vertebra and multiple rib fractures at different stages of healing. MRI revealed marked compression of the spinal cord at the level of T12 with surrounding cord edema, and very severe thoracic kyphosis or gibbus deformity, consistent with traumatic spinal spondyloptosis with additional findings concerning for physical child abuse. There was no history of previous surgeries, past medical history, or known previous trauma. The patient was stabilized with spinal fusion and underwent intensive rehabilitation post-surgery.

Hospital Course:
The patient was stabilized post-surgery and closely monitored throughout her hospital stay. Imaging studies were completed to confirm the diagnosis, and appropriate interventions were implemented to prevent further injury to the spinal cord. The patient did not regain lower extremity function and remains paraplegic.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged with stable vital signs and with instructions for follow-up with a specialist in child abuse. A consultation with the hospital's child protection team and the state of North Carolina's child protective services were completed.

Instructions at Discharge:
The patient was discharged with a complete plan of care. The discharge instructions included information on the follow-up appointment with the specialist in child abuse and the importance of continuing to monitor for signs of physical abuse. The adoptive mother has been instructed not to shake the child aggressively again. If there are any changes in the patient's condition, the adoptive mother should bring the patient back to the hospital immediately.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to follow up with the specialist in child abuse. The adoptive mother is to continue monitoring the patient at home closely. The patient is expected to visit local clinics and specialist doctors regularly to check for any signs of spinal cord or rib fractures. A rehabilitation specialist will continue to work closely with the patient to maximize function and movement.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 38-year-old female with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC)

Hospital Course:
The patient was referred to Kennedy Krieger Institute one year after being diagnosed with TSC. The diagnosis was based on various TSC-related manifestations, including skin lesions, brain abnormalities, retinal hamartomas, and lung cysts. The patient underwent bilateral nephrectomy due to renal angiomyolipomas and bilateral cysts. She was indicated for lung transplantation due to progressive deterioration of lung function and was started on everolimus to manage pulmonary Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM). The patient experienced hypotension and dizziness with an increased dose of everolimus, which was managed by reducing the dose and initiating midodrine. After a period of self-discontinuation of everolimus and canceled renal transplantation surgery, worsening pulmonary function was observed, likely attributable to everolimus interruption. The patient restarted everolimus at a reduced dose and has reported amenorrhea as the only noted side effect.

Hospital Course Summary:

- Patient with a history of TSC and various related manifestations, including kidney and lung cysts, brain abnormalities, and skin lesions.
- Patient underwent bilateral nephrectomy and was indicated for lung transplantation.
- Everolimus initiated to manage pulmonary LAM, with dose reduction and initiation of midodrine required due to hypotension and dizziness.
- Periods of self-discontinuation of everolimus and canceled renal transplantation surgery.
- Worsening pulmonary function observed, likely attributable to everolimus interruption.
- Everolimus restarted at a reduced dose, with amenorrhea as the only noted side effect.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [OMITTED]
Hospital Number: [OMITTED]
Admission Date: [OMITTED]
Discharge Date: [OMITTED]
Attending Physician: [OMITTED]

Chief Complaint: Facial swelling, dysphagia, hoarseness of voice

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 58-year-old woman who was admitted to the Nyakach County Hospital with edematous swelling of the face, dysphagia, and hoarseness of voice. The patient reported difficulty swallowing and had a swollen tongue that was wedged between her teeth, making it impossible for her to close her mouth. The initial examination revealed a pulse rate of 75 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and blood pressure of 140/72 mmHg. Saliva was pooling and dribbling from the patient's mouth. The medical history of the patient was unremarkable, and no recent use of aspirin, NSAIDs or ACE inhibitors was found.

During the admission, the patient was suspected to have enalapril-induced angioedema. A preliminary diagnosis was made, and the patient was immediately discontinued from enalapril. Intravenous hydrocortisone and chlorpheniramine were administered, and the patient was observed for an hour. The edema was noted to subside, and a further three-hour observation period was allowed. The patient was then discharged on a once-daily dose of nifedipine, chlorpheniramine, and a tapered dose of prednisolone.

Current Status:

At the time of discharge, the patient's facial swelling had resolved, and the blood pressure was found to be 142/78 mmHg. The patient was advised to continue taking her usual doses of metformin, glibenclamide, and hydrochlorothiazide and to report to the hospital immediately if the swelling reoccurs.

Follow-up:

The patient was followed up after one week, and there was a marked change in facial appearance. At three weeks follow-up, the patient was completely symptom-free.

Diagnosis:

Enalapril-induced angioedema

Medications:

Nifedipine, chlorpheniramine, and a tapered dose of prednisolone. The patient was advised to continue taking her usual doses of metformin, glibenclamide, and hydrochlorothiazide.

Instructions:

Patient was instructed to report to the hospital immediately if the swelling reoccurs.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]

Date of Admission: [Date]

Date of Discharge: [Date]

Diagnosis: Enalapril-induced angioedema

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a six-year history of hypertension. On admission to Nyakach County Hospital, he presented with swelling of the upper lip, restlessness, and insomnia. Various examinations, including cardiovascular, respiratory, and abdominal, showed no abnormalities, and vitals were normal. The Naranjo probability scale was used to evaluate the cause of the observed edema, and the results suggested that it was enalapril-induced angioedema. As a result, enalapril was withheld, and the patient received 4 mg of intravenous dexamethasone injection, followed by a peroral dose of prednisolone and cetirizine.

Summary of Treatment:
After one hour of monitoring, the patient's upper lip swelling gradually decreased over the following hours. The patient was discharged five days later and prescribed a thrice daily dose of prednisolone (tapered as 20 mg, 10 mg, and 5 mg), along with a twice daily peroral dose of cetirizine for ten days. The patient was advised to notify the hospital immediately if the swelling re-occurred, and to continue taking the nifedipine and hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension management.

Follow-up:
One week from the date of discharge, the patient was reviewed and observed to be symptom-free. On subsequent follow-up after three weeks, a significant resolution of the swelling was observed, and the patient remained symptom-free. The patient was advised to continue any medication as prescribed and to see a physician if any new symptoms occurred.

Summary: 
The patient was diagnosed with enalapril-induced angioedema, was treated and monitored, and was eventually discharged with a peroral prescription. On follow-up examinations, the patient remained symptom-free and was advised to notify the hospital of any new symptoms.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 54-year-old male with a history of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus was admitted with lethargy and confusion. The patient had a prior hospitalization for orthostatic hypotension and was eventually discharged to a skilled nursing facility but returned to the hospital three days later with an acute change in his mental status. On presentation, he had a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, a heart rate of 62 beats per minute, blood pressure of 121/73 mmHg, a temperature of 37°C, and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Laboratory investigation revealed thrombocytopenia and further workup was significant for an anion gap of 40 and LA of 18.7 mmol/L. He had also developed acute renal injury and liver enzymes were elevated. The patient was initiated on sepsis bundle with IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics as well as microbial cultures, including the collection of two sets of blood cultures.

After several days of hospitalization, the patient developed multiorgan failure with persistent encephalopathy, despite discontinuing all sedation, coagulopathy, worsening liver enzymes, and cytopenia. A bone marrow biopsy was performed to evaluate for marrow erythrocytic phagocytosis as there was a concern for thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) or hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH). Hemophagocytosis was not identified but the bone marrow contained a monomorphic cellular infiltrate with areas of necrosis and cellular degeneration. The infiltrate was positive for CD45, CD20, and CD79a, and negative for CD34, with patchy non-specific staining for TdT. The Ki67 (MIB-1) proliferation rate was up to 60%. The disease was classified as Ann Arbor stage IV due to its presence in the extra-lymphatic organs (liver and bone marrow). The age-adjusted international prognostic index (IPI) score was calculated to be 3, conferring high risk.

Treatment for the diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) was planned, but unfortunately, the patient's condition continued to deteriorate, and he became bradycardic and hypotensive, eventually requiring multiple vasopressors. After discussions with the family, comfort measures were pursued.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), Ann Arbor Stage IV

Discharge Condition:

The patient expired during hospitalization.

Discharge Medications:

Not applicable.

Follow-up Instructions:

Not applicable.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

1. Patient Information:
- Name: [REDACTED]
- Age: 60 years
- Sex: Female
- Admission Date: [REDACTED]
- Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
- Reason for admission: Grand mal seizures followed by coma

2. Hospital Course:
The patient, a 60-year-old female with diabetic nephropathy, was admitted with grand mal seizures followed by coma. She had been undergoing continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) for the past four months with four daily exchanges and 2.0 L fill volume. She had a history of coronary artery disease with an anterior myocardial infarction seven months prior to the start of CAPD, followed by severe congestive heart failure with an ejection fraction of 23%. She had not been seen by her CAPD providers for three months because of transportation difficulties. Upon admission, she was comatose with a blood pressure of 180/74 mm Hg, regular pulse rhythm with a rate of 110 beats per minute, and temperature of 36.5 degrees Celsius. Her weight was 63.6 kg. Physical examination revealed anasarca, ventricular gallop, and crackles in both lung fields.

3. Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with extreme hyperglycemia, severe hypertonicity, hypokalemia, and respiratory acidosis.

4. Treatment:
Over the course of 30 hours, the patient received insulin boluses and had frequent (every 2-4 hours) determinations of serum glucose and potassium concentrations. Serum glucose levels decreased progressively, while serum potassium levels remained between 3.1 and 3.4 mmol/L without administration of potassium salts. Blood pressure progressively decreased during treatment. At the end of treatment, she developed frank hypotension (blood pressure 80/60 mm Hg) and increased tachycardia to a pulse rate of 125 beats per minute while remaining comatose. Chest X-ray revealed worsening pulmonary edema, while electrocardiogram was consistent with a new myocardial infarction and serum levels of cardiac enzymes (creatinine phosphokinase, troponin) were substantially elevated.

5. Discharge Condition:
The patient expired within three hours of developing worsening hypotension.

6. Discharge Plan:
N/A

7. Follow-up:
N/A

8. Signatures:
[REDACTED]
Doctor [REDACTED], MD

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: N/A

DOB: N/A

Admission Date: N/A

Discharge Date: N/A

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY:

The patient, a 23-year-old female with a history of adjustment disorder and previously treated anxiety disorder, presented to the dermatology clinic with painful, cracked, and peeling lips. Physical examination revealed thick, yellow keratinaceous crusting on the upper and lower lips, sparing the mucosal lip and vermilion border, with associated edema, erosion, and tenderness to palpation. A biopsy from the debrided left lower lip was nonspecific; however, the histopathologic pattern of spongiotic mucositis, in conjunction with the clinical features, suggested an exuberant irritant contact dermatitis, which was consistent with factitial cheilitis.

The patient was subsequently treated for secondary impetiginization with anti-staphylococcal antibiotics and topical antibiotic ointment for two weeks. Additionally, the patient was counseled on avoidance of licking her lips and was referred back to her behavioral health specialist for management of her anxiety disorder. The patient's lip symptoms resolved within one month of psychiatric treatment and cessation of lip licking.

In summary, the patient was diagnosed with factitial cheilitis and secondary impetiginization, which was successfully treated with antibiotics and cessation of lip licking. The patient was referred back to her behavioral health specialist for management of her anxiety disorder.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 87 years
Sex: Male
Admission date: [REDACTED]
Discharge date: [REDACTED]

Overall Hospital Course:
The patient, a male with a past history of hypertension and hypothyroidism, was admitted to the telemetry unit for abnormal electrocardiogram (EKG) findings on the Holter monitor. The initial presentation did not show any symptoms of chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, or headaches. Physical examination revealed pulse rate of 36 beats/min, respiratory rate of 16/minute, and blood pressure of 180/70 mmHg. EKG showed new-onset atrial fibrillation with slow ventricular response, frequent episodes of bradycardia to less than 40 beats per minute, and left bundle branch block.

Diagnostic/Laboratory Results
Initial labs, basic metabolic panel, and complete blood count remained within normal limits. Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) was elevated to 74.03 IU/ml, with free thyroxine (fT4) decreased to 0.53 mg/dl. There was also no history of taking any AV nodal blocking agents such as beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, or digoxin that could cause a slow ventricular rate. Baseline EKG two years ago showed left bundle branch block with first degree AV block.

Treatment and course
The patient was admitted to the telemetry unit, and the levothyroxine dose was increased to 50 mcg per oral daily. A repeat EKG showed atrial tachycardia with a variable high-grade AV block. The patient reported symptoms of dizziness with minimal exertion, and it was planned to insert a pacemaker for a high-grade AV block and symptomatic bradycardia. However, a subsequent telemetry review showed complete resolution of the high-degree AV block and pauses were no longer observed four days after increasing the dose of levothyroxine. Permanent pacemaker insertion was avoided, and the patient was discharged on levothyroxine 50 mcg daily, apixaban 5 mg twice daily for new-onset atrial fibrillation, and was advised to follow-up with a cardiologist for repeat thyroid function testing in four to six weeks.

Diagnoses:
-Hypothyroidism
-Hypertension
-New-onset atrial fibrillation
-Bradycardia
-Left bundle branch block

Medications:
-Levothyroxine 50 mcg daily
-Apixaban 5 mg twice daily

Follow-up:
-Follow-up with a cardiologist for repeat thyroid function testing in four to six weeks

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name:
Age: 25
Gender: Male

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the emergency department with complaints of intractable vomiting leading to increasing confusion and progressive difficulty breathing. The patient was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus complicated with DKA, and his laboratory evaluation showed leukocytosis, elevated creatinine, hyperglycemia, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and bicarbonate levels. The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit where he was treated with intravenous normal saline, bicarbonate, and insulin drip. The chest X-ray suggested the presence of pneumomediastinum, and a chest CT confirmed the findings indicating potential esophageal rupture. Due to the facility's inability to manage this diagnosis, the patient was transferred to another facility. The patient was treated conservatively with analgesia and respiratory support, and he was discharged several days later with no complications.

Diagnosis:
1. Diabetes mellitus complicated with DKA
2. Pneumomediastinum with potential esophageal rupture

Treatment:
Intravenous normal saline, bicarbonate, and insulin drip were initiated, and the patient was treated conservatively with analgesia and respiratory support.

Follow-up:
The patient was discharged without any complications, and routine follow-up is strongly recommended to manage the patient's diabetes mellitus diagnosis.

Hospital Course:
A 21-year-old male presented to the emergency with one episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures followed by altered sensorium and repeated episodes of vomiting. He had a history of a minor head injury two months prior, which resulted in an incidental left Sylvian Type II arachnoid cyst. He was observed with symptomatic treatment for headaches until he presented with seizures and altered sensorium. His Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) was seven on admission with left uncal herniation and a computed tomography (CT) scan revealed an acute on Chronic Subdural Hematoma (CSDH) on the left side with bleed into the cyst cavity and a significant midline shift. Emergency surgery was performed and dark machine oil-colored fluid was evacuated through two burr holes. Postoperative period was complicated with cerebrospinal fluid leak from the parietal burr hole on suture removal followed by a pulsatile swelling in the frontal burr hole. He was managed conservatively with acetazolamide and pressure dressing of the wound. The swelling spontaneously disappeared. The patient has been asymptomatic since then. 

Discharge Summary:
The patient was admitted with generalized seizures and altered sensorium with a history of a remote head injury resulting in a left Sylvian Type II arachnoid cyst. Imaging studies revealed an acute on Chronic Subdural Hematoma (CSDH) on the left side with bleed into the cyst cavity and a significant midline shift. He underwent emergency craniotomy with evacuation of the hematoma with good improvement neurologically. The post-operative course was complicated with a cerebrospinal fluid leak from the parietal burr hole on suture removal followed by a pulsatile swelling in the frontal burr hole, which was managed conservatively with acetazolamide and pressure dressing of the wound. The patient's symptoms resolved, and he has been asymptomatic since then. There were no complications noted during his hospital stay, and he was deemed stable for discharge. The patient was discharged in stable condition with follow-up instructions to return to the neurosurgery clinic for further assessment and treatment as needed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Length of Stay: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: High-grade brainstem tumor

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 34-year-old Caucasian female, was admitted to the hospital with complaints of right hemiparesis, numbness, dysphagia, and ataxia. These symptoms began as numbness over her right scapular area two weeks prior, and the numbness later progressed to include the right leg. Additionally, she reported five days of waking up during the night with severe headaches, which were different in nature from her previous migraines. After workup in the emergency department and neurology consultation, the patient was referred to neurosurgery for management of a high-grade brainstem tumor.
On initial presentation, the patient's pupils were equal, round, and reactive to light, and her cranial nerves were grossly intact. Motor testing revealed that strength was 5/5 in both upper and lower extremities, and dysmetria was noted in the right upper extremity during finger-to-nose testing. The patient experienced a progressive decline during her initial admission, to include mild left facial droop, dysarthria, and worsening dysphagia. These symptoms continued until her initial discharge. Upon readmission, the patient displayed similar findings, including left lower quadrant abdominal pain radiating to the shoulder and acute numbness of the left chest and shoulder. These symptoms progressed and worsened until the patient was intubated after deteriorating to a GCS score of 10.
The patient underwent a closed stereotactic needle biopsy, during which biopsy samples were successfully obtained for pathologic examination. Postoperatively, a nasogastric tube was placed to provide nutrition, due to worsening dysphagia. On Day 10 of her hospitalization, a PEG tube was placed. The patient was scheduled for chemotherapy and craniospinal radiation therapy, and was discharged on Day 12. Four days later, the patient returned due to worsening symptoms, and dexamethasone was increased. The patient was started on temozolomide IV, but she developed respiratory acidosis/hypercapnia with a CO2 of 115 and was started on a BIPAP, two days later. As a result, a rapid response team was called to transfer the patient to the ICU. The temozolomide was converted to oral dosing via a PEG tube. The patient's family was consulted regarding the patient's status and their options. The patient chose to update her status to do not intubate. The patient was extubated prior to her discharge to a hospice care facility, where she passed away four days later.

Imaging:
MRI of the brain with and without contrast revealed a heterogeneous T1 hypointense and T2 hyperintense signal abnormality involving the pontine base and extending into the medulla. There was mildly increased relative cerebral blood flow and blood volume within the enhancing portion of the abnormality, suggesting neovascularity. The pontine component of the lesion also showed no abnormal enhancement or significant hyperperfusion. Mild mass effect on the fourth ventricle was noted. There was no peritumoral edema or significant mass effect. A CT scan of the chest with and without contrast enhancement revealed scattered small ground glass and nodular opacities bilaterally.

Pathology:
The brain biopsy was originally interpreted as a classic medulloblastoma (WHO Grade 4). However, the diagnosis was amended at St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital to small cell glioblastoma (WHO Grade 4). Interphase fluorescence in situ hybridization (iFISH) analysis revealed platelet-derived growth factor receptor A (PDGFRA) amplification. No amplification of MYC, NMYC, or epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) was observed.

Follow-up:
The patient passed away at a hospice care facility four days after discharge.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]
Patient Name: [NAME]
