HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was a 34-year-old female with a history of drug abuse who was brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident where she was driving a jeep. Imaging studies revealed multiple fractures in her right foot and ankle, as well as a large hypodense mass identified in the left atrium of her heart. A CT scan of the chest confirmed the presence of the mass.

The patient underwent surgical repair of her fractures and was subsequently treated for a wound infection. She was also referred to cardiology for the evaluation of the left atrial mass. She underwent transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiograms which revealed a myxoma in the left atrium. Cardiovascular surgery was consulted for the excision of the mass using an uncomplicated procedure.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

1. Fracture of the right foot and ankle
2. Left atrial myxoma

DISCHARGE CONDITION:

The patient's postoperative course was uncomplicated, and she was discharged in stable condition on [DATE] with orders for intravenous antibiotics to complete at home. The patient's wounds were monitored and managed appropriately, with recommendations for follow-up to continue on an outpatient basis.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

The patient was advised to rest and avoid strenuous activity until follow-up appointments in the outpatient setting. It was recommended that she continue her antibiotics and attend all remaining scheduled physician follow-up appointments. The patient was also advised to keep her wounds clean and dry, and to avoid immersion in water until fully healed.

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENTS:

The patient was instructed to follow up with her primary care physician and orthopedist on [DATE], with further follow-up care to be arranged by the treating physicians as needed.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Age/Sex: 52-year-old male

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Reason for Hospitalization:
The patient was admitted to the surgery clinic due to mild abdominal pain, yellowing sclera, and dark-colored urine.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent cholecystectomy and choledocus exploration with a T-tube insertion due to semi-obstructing gallstone. The T-tube was removed without any difficulty after six weeks, and the patient was discharged. However, a day after the T-tube removal, he presented to the emergency clinic with symptoms of fever, vomiting, and severe pain in the right upper quadrant. The patient was diagnosed with bile leak from the choledocus, and the tract was embolized with coils. The T-tube was removed after five days of coiling and percutaneous catheter after a control ultrasonography on the sixth day of coiling. The patient showed no further complications during the three-month follow-up.

Final Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with a bile leak from the choledocus after the T-tube removal.

Treatment:
The tract of the bile leak was embolized with eight coils during angiography. Percutaneous drainage of the perihepatic fluid was performed, and the T-tube was removed after five days of coiling and percutaneous catheter placement after a control ultrasonography on the sixth day of coiling.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in a stable condition with no further complications after the successful treatment of the bile leak.

Instructions at Discharge:
The patient was advised to maintain a healthy diet and follow-up care with his primary healthcare provider. 

Primary Healthcare Provider:
[REDACTED]

Follow-up Care:
The patient was advised to schedule a follow-up appointment with his primary healthcare provider as needed.

Signed by:
[REDACTED]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Clinical Diagnosis: Catamenial-pneumothorax possibly associated with thoracic endometriosis

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 24-year-old female with no significant medical history, presented to the emergency department (ED) with a one-day history of shortness of breath (SOB) and left-sided pleuritic chest pain. On physical examination, the patient had diminished breath sounds on the left side. Chest x-ray (CXR) showed a moderate-sized left Pneumothorax (PTX) with a 2.6 cm gap but without a mediastinal shift.

Needle aspiration with the placement of a left-sided pigtail catheter was performed immediately, which led to symptomatic improvement as noted by the patient’s pain reduction. A repeat CXR showed a decrease in the size of the PTX from 2.6 cm to 1.9 cm, and consecutive CXRs over the next two days showed significant improvement. A complete resolution of PTX was noted eventually. Blood work and basic metabolic chemistry were within normal limits, and no significant abnormalities were detected.

Consultants from pulmonary and obstetrics/gynecology confirmed the clinical diagnosis of catamenial-pneumothorax possibly associated with thoracic endometriosis. During hospitalization, the patient received analgesics and was later discharged on day five of hospitalization on an oral contraceptive medication containing ethinyl estradiol and levonorgestrel.

Follow-up care instructions were given to the patient, and she was advised to follow up regarding her symptoms or in case of exacerbation. She was also informed about the possible risks of taking oral contraceptive medication, and that prior to using any medications, she should consult her healthcare provider.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Catamenial-pneumothorax possibly associated with thoracic endometriosis

Instructions for Follow-Up Care:

The patient was advised to follow up regarding her symptoms or in case of exacerbation. She was also asked to consult her healthcare provider before using any medications.

Discharge Summary:
Patient: [Name]
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: Hospital day 3

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 55-year-old female with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, was admitted to the hospital after reporting nausea, vomiting, and polyuria for the past 24 hours. On examination, the patient displayed signs of tachycardia and hypotension. Lab tests revealed acidosis with an anion gap of 32 mmol/L and acute kidney injury. Serum beta hydroxybutyrate concentrations indicated that the patient had diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) despite having a serum glucose concentration of 366 mg/dL (20.3 mmol/L). The patient's lipase concentration suggested that she was also experiencing acute pancreatitis. 

Treatment:
The patient received a continuous insulin infusion and intravenous normal saline resuscitation, resulting in normalization of the anion gap. She was then transitioned to metformin and glipizide. She was discharged on the third day of her hospital stay.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with DKA, indicating poor blood sugar management due to her diabetes. Additionally, she developed acute pancreatitis as a complication of her DKA.

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to follow the prescribed treatment plan, adhere to a proper diet, and monitor glucose levels regularly. She is also advised to return to the hospital should any complications arise.

Summary:
The patient was discharged on hospital day 3, after being successfully treated for DKA and acute pancreatitis. Appropriate medications were prescribed and lifestyle modifications recommended, with instructions for follow-up arrangements.

Diagnosis/Reason for Admission: Left upper lung adenocarcinoma, classified as cT1bN0M0 Stage IA based on the Union for International Cancer Control classification (seventh edition).

Hospital Course:
A 76-year-old female patient was admitted to our hospital for the management of left upper lung adenocarcinoma. A small nodule had been detected in the left upper lobe (S1+2) during a medical checkup, and follow-up CT showed that the nodule was growing in size. The patient had undergone various diagnostic tests including fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG)-positron emission tomography (PET), brain magnetic resonance imaging, and transbronchial biopsy before arriving at our hospital. Video-assisted thoracoscopic left upper lobectomy and lymphadenectomy were performed, and a pulmonary mediastinal branch from the left main pulmonary artery was identified during the surgery. The interlobar fissure was separated safely with preservation of A8. The patient had no complications during the hospital stay and was discharged after seven days.

Summary of Care:
The patient was diagnosed with left upper lung adenocarcinoma and underwent a successful surgical procedure for its management. The interlobar fissure was separated with preservation of A8, and the patient had no post-operative complications during the hospital stay. The patient was discharged home in stable condition. Follow-up appointments with the oncology team were scheduled for further management. 

Instructions:
The patient was instructed to take good care of herself at home. The patient should take rest and avoid strenuous activities for up to six weeks post-surgery. The patient was advised to eat a well-balanced diet and maintain good hydration. The patient was also provided with instructions for wound care and follow-up appointments with the oncology team. In case of any emergent symptoms or concerns, the patient was advised to seek medical assistance immediately.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:

The 70-year-old female patient was admitted to our hospital due to repeated mucous defecation and bilateral leg edema. The patient underwent several colonoscopies and gastroscopy examinations which revealed erythematous polypoid lesions, hyperplastic polyps, and tubular adenomas with low-grade atypia. The patient was diagnosed with protein-losing enteropathy which could not be denied malignant potential. Therefore, laparoscopic low anterior resection of the rectum and the sigmoid colon with diverting ileostomy was performed. During the operation, thick subserosal layer with moderate fibrosis and edematous change was found and surgical specimen revealed more than 100 polyps consisting of elongated and mild adenomatous glands with a thick layer of subserosal tissue. The patient was diagnosed with cap polyposis.

Clinical Course:

The patient's symptoms improved, including return to normal levels of serum total protein and albumin after surgery. Six months later, the patient had no complaints or recurrence of cap polyposis in the remnant colon.

Diagnosis:

Cap polyposis.

Follow-up:

We will continue a tight follow-up surveillance.

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [patient's name]
Medical Record Number: [patient's number]
Age: 73   Sex: Male
Date of admission: [admission date]
Date of Discharge: [Date of discharge]
Discharge Diagnosis: FXTAS

Hospital Course:
A 73-year-old male patient was admitted to the Department of Neurology due to tremors of the head, neck, and upper limbs, along with moderate tremors of the lower limbs. Initial symptoms appeared 20 years prior, primarily as a kinetic tremor of the left upper and lower limbs. During a neurological examination, the patient also presented dysarthria, paresis of the right facial nerve, brisk reflexes on the right side, bilateral dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesis, truncal ataxia, ataxia of lower limbs which was more significant on the left side, and unstable gait. Psychological examination exposed mild cognitive impairment and deficits of executive functions.

An MRI in 2016 revealed bilateral hyperintensity in the cerebellar hemispheres and the MCP. The combination of intention tremor, ataxia, MCP sign, and gait instability of the patient's son and daughter instigated the diagnosis of FXTAS. Use of the Amplide X FMR1 PCR kit for extended molecular examination revealed permutations in the FMR1 gene. The diagnosis of FXTAS with expansion of CGG repeats in the FMR1 gene was confirmed.

Radiosurgical thalamotomy using GK on the VIM of the left thalamus was performed due to insufficient effects of pharmacological treatments (primidone and propranolol) to treat the tremors. The Leksell Gamma Knife Perfexion model was used, and a maximum dose of 130 Gy was delivered with a single, fully opened 4-mm collimator. A control examination was done 6 months after GK thalamotomy, which showed improvement observed 4 months after the procedure.

Comparison of tremor intensity before and after the procedure was done using the FTRS and the Tremor Rating Scale. The case presented in this study showed an improvement in both rating scales. The most significant change was observed in the right side corresponding to the lesion. Neurological examination showed that features remained unchanged or insignificantly changed. Psychological examination did not present any relevant changes. Physiotherapist's examination revealed certain changes in the period before and after thalamotomy. Deterioration in certain features of the examination performed by the physiotherapist were associated with the progressive nature of FXTAS.

Follow-up and plan of action:
Patient was discharged on [Date of Discharge] with instructions to follow up with their primary care physician and Neurologist as needed. Instruction given to join rehabilitation therapy for further improvement in the quality of life.

Electronic Health Record
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient is an 11-year-old male with a history of Alagille syndrome and a liver transplant. The patient presented with a severe headache, nausea, vomiting, and phono-/photophobia without B symptoms. Funduscopic examination revealed bilateral papilledema. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) studies of the brain demonstrated multifocal lesions in the left hemisphere. The patient was diagnosed with EBV-related primary CNS PTLD after a biopsy of the lesion was carried out.

During initial treatment with dexamethasone, symptoms rapidly improved. Immunosuppression was stopped, and immune-/chemotherapy was initiated, including six doses of intravenous (i.v.) rituximab and weekly intrathecal (i.th.) therapy with rituximab (40 mg), methotrexate (12 mg), cytarabine (30 mg), and prednisone (10 mg) over 10 weeks. A partial response was observed after 3 weeks, which evolved into complete remission at the end of immuno-/chemotherapy.

Afterward, the patient underwent a procedure wherein partially HLA-matched EBV-CTLs were transferred due to poor prognosis and the lack of EBV-specific T cells in the patient’s peripheral blood.

The patient was, therefore, discharged in stable condition. Appropriate medications and follow-up assessment were advised, and the family was provided with appropriate instructions for their care at home. 

Diagnosis:
EBV-related primary CNS PTLD

Treatment:
Dexamethasone, Immune-/Chemotherapy, Partially HLA-matched EBV-CTLs Transfer

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient, an 18-year-old Japanese woman with a history of intestinal Behçet’s disease, was admitted to our hospital for abdominal pain. Upon arrival, she was alert, with a regular respiration rate, and blood pressure of 128/90 mmHg. Her medical history included fibromyalgia, for which she was taking medication, and she had no known tobacco or alcohol use. Her physical examination showed upper abdominal tenderness, and her laboratory test results were normal except for mild hepatic dysfunction and elevated d-dimer levels. Although the patient had taken a sub-lethal dose of colchicine, she was admitted for observation.

On the day after admission, the patient developed acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and was intubated using an artificial ventilator. She also developed diarrhea and dehydration, with peripheral circulatory insufficiency gradually worsening despite large amounts of infusion loads. She required multiple medications to maintain her blood pressure, including noradrenaline, vasopressin, and steroids. Additionally, she experienced other organ failures, such as worsening hepatic and kidney dysfunction. The patient's condition began to improve at 36 hours post-admission, and continuous renal replacement therapy was initiated for anuria and metabolic acidosis. She was administered with granulocyte colony-stimulating factor due to myelosuppression.

Approximately one week after admission, the patient's blood pressure stabilized and she was able to respond to verbal commands. However, a head computed tomography showed multiple intracranial hemorrhages associated with disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The patient's hematomas were later absorbed, and a marked hair loss was observed approximately 2 weeks post-admission. Although the patient's overall condition improved, she experienced multiple organ insufficiencies during her hospital course.

Condition at Discharge:
At discharge, the patient's general condition had improved, and all organ insufficiencies had resolved. The patient worked hard at rehabilitation, and experienced no significant disorders within 6 months after discharge.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A
Admitting Diagnosis: Retroperitoneal Hemorrhage

Hospital Course:
A 41-year-old pregnant woman presented to the Emergency Department with left-flank pain, hypotension, and tachycardia. She was found to have a retroperitoneal hemorrhage, suspected to be due to placental abruption. Following resuscitation, she was taken to the operating room where a ruptured left retroperitoneal artery aneurysm was found along with a non-viable fetus. The aneurysm was embolized leading to rapid recovery. A DMSA scan performed 2 weeks later demonstrated reduced function in the treated kidney. A plan for repair of the contralateral RAA, which had a significant risk of rupture, was made. A hand-assisted retroperitoneoscopic nephrectomy was performed, and the kidney was autotransplanted. Three years later, the patient has not experienced RAA recurrence.

Hospital Course Timeline:
- The patient was brought to the Emergency Department with left-flank pain, hypotension, and tachycardia.
- Blood tests were drawn, and an abdominal ultrasound was performed.
- The patient was resuscitated and taken to the operating room.
- A non-viable fetus and a ruptured left retroperitoneal artery aneurysm were found and embolized.
- A DMSA scan was performed.
- A plan for repair of the contralateral RAA was made.
- A hand-assisted retroperitoneoscopic nephrectomy was performed, and the kidney was autotransplanted.
- Histology results were obtained.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient completed two uncomplicated pregnancies. Three years later, the patient has not experienced RAA recurrence.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Retroperitoneal Hemorrhage and Renal Artery Aneurysm (Ruptured)

Discharge Plan:
The patient will receive regular follow-up care to monitor for any recurrence of retroperitoneal hemorrhage or RAA.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 57
Sex: Male
Admitting Diagnosis: Bleeding Dieulafoy lesion with acute kidney injury and mucormycosis
Discharge Diagnosis: Resolved mucormycosis with improvement of acute kidney injury and no evidence of relapse at 12 months since completion of treatment

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 57-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, systolic heart failure, alcohol abuse, and stage-IV sarcoidosis on long-term oral prednisone, was admitted to the medical ICU for hypovolemic shock secondary to massive bleeding. After initial resuscitation, an urgent endoscopy revealed a bleeding Dieulafoy lesion, which was immediately clipped. The patient also presented with acute kidney injury and was started on intravenous liposomal amphotericin-B. However, due to deterioration in renal function, treatment was switched to oral posaconazole. Repeat CT scans showed mild-to-moderate hydroureter with hydronephrosis and bladder wall thickening. A cystoscopy showed distorted anatomy of the bladder lumen with multiple mounds of tissues consistent with mucormycosis. Treatment was switched to intravenous isavuconazonium sulfate, and a three-way Foley catheter was inserted for continuous amphotericin-B bladder irrigation. After three weeks of systemic treatment with antifungals, a third endoscopy showed no evidence of mucormycosis. The patient completed six months of therapy with oral isavuconazonium sulfate and was discharged with full resolution of symptoms and no clinical evidence of relapse at 12 months since completion of treatment.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient's hospital course was complicated by hypovolemic shock, acute kidney injury, and mucormycosis. He underwent initial resuscitation with blood transfusions, isotonic solutions, and initiation of vasoactive medications. An urgent endoscopy revealed a bleeding Dieulafoy lesion, which was immediately clipped. Acute kidney injury was addressed with aggressive fluid resuscitation, and treatment of mucormycosis was initiated with intravenous liposomal amphotericin-B. Treatment was changed to oral posaconazole due to deterioration in renal function. Repeat CT scans showed significant hydroureter with hydronephrosis and bladder wall thickening. A cystoscopy and bladder tissue biopsy confirmed mucormycosis, and treatment was switched to intravenous isavuconazonium sulfate with continuous bladder irrigation. After three weeks of systemic treatment with antifungals, a third endoscopy showed no evidence of mucormycosis. The patient completed six months of therapy with oral isavuconazonium sulfate and was discharged with full resolution of symptoms and no clinical evidence of relapse at 12 months since completion of treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 66-year-old female with a medical history of hypertension, high cholesterol, type 2 diabetes, and obesity, was admitted with complaints of hip pain following a fall. A physical exam revealed proximal muscle weakness which was greater in the lower extremities while the rest of the physical examination was unremarkable. Radiograph of the hip was negative for any dislocation or fracture. Blood work showed elevated CPK, CKMB, aldolase, and liver function tests. After reviewing her medical history and conducting further tests, the diagnosis of statin-induced necrotizing autoimmune myopathy was made. Treatment with prednisone was initiated and the patient was monitored closely.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient, a 66-year-old female with a past medical history of hypertension, high cholesterol, type 2 diabetes, and obesity, was admitted with complaints of hip pain following a fall. Further evaluation revealed proximal muscle weakness which was greater in the lower extremities. Blood work was notable for elevated muscle enzymes and LFTs. After reviewing other medical factors, a diagnosis of statin-induced necrotizing autoimmune myopathy was made, and treatment with prednisone was initiated. The patient exhibited gradual improvement and was discharged with follow-up instructions.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Patient Name: [Name]

Medical Record Number: [Number]

Hospital Course:

Admitted inpatient for surgical management of a right nipple lesion. The patient reports noticing a small yellow bump on her nipple two years prior and becoming concerned due to rapid growth in the last year. A shave biopsy four months prior suggested squamous cell carcinoma. On examination, the patient had a 2.2 cm lesion occupying the right nipple with erythematous and rigid breast along with yellow pus draining from the nipple. An MRI was ordered and revealed no underlying breast malignancy.

A wedge biopsy of the nipple was performed to confirm the initial shave biopsy pathology. Histopathology showed verrucous features with chronic inflammation and underlying abscess with some possibility of cutaneous malignancy and HPV L1 Capsid protein. Due to inadequate sample removal in the initial shave biopsy and positive margins, excision with wide margins was determined to be appropriate for removal of the lesion.

The patient underwent a wide excision of the right nipple-areola complex for removal of the growth without any complications. Following the surgery, the final histologic examination revealed a large tumor with verrucous and hyperkeratotic features, dyskeratosis, nests of keratin pearl formation along with microinvasion of the dermis and loss of basal lamina. However, no tumor cells were found in all margins.

The post-op course was uneventful. During the hospital stay, the patient was treated for an abscess with antibiotic therapy, and the patient's status improved. She was monitored for potential recurrence of the growth during the follow-up period.

Summary:

This was a 49-year-old Caucasian woman with a right nipple lesion diagnosed as a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma arising within the lesion's verruca vulgaris. The patient underwent a successful wide excision. Histopathology revealed no tumor cells in all margins.

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE
The patient presented to the emergency department with acute general weakness. Physical examination showed decreased muscle power in the lower extremities, and laboratory studies revealed marked hypokalemia and mild hypomagnesemia. Renal potassium wasting was indicated by urine potassium excretion, and the patient was treated with potassium chloride infusion. The hormonal profile indicated hyperthyroidism, and Graves' disease was confirmed by the thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor antibody test. The patient was prescribed propranolol and methimazole for controlling the hyperthyroidism. Thereafter, the patient was discharged in stable condition with normal serum potassium levels.

DIAGNOSES
1. Acute general weakness
2. Hypokalemia
3. Hypomagnesemia
4. Renal potassium wasting
5. Hyperthyroidism
6. Graves' disease

TREATMENTS
1. Potassium chloride infusion
2. Propranolol and methimazole

FOLLOW-UP
Outpatient follow-up at 9 days after discharge showed normal serum potassium levels, and no more muscle weakness episode occurred during the one-year follow-up in the outpatient department of endocrinology.

DISCHARGE CONDITION
Stable

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS
None

FOLLOW-UP CARE
Outpatient follow-up as needed

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 30-year-old male

Hospital: Lyon University Hospital, France

Diagnosis: Traumatized and mobile maxillary right central incisor (11) with periradicular bone loss, moderate periodontal disease, and edentulous zones due to upper first premolar extractions.

Treatment: The loose incisor was extracted atraumatically, and a temporary removable partial denture was positioned immediately. The patient selected the denture for economic reasons from the options proposed, including the placement of a dental implant with a provisional crown or a cantilever bridge. Final prosthetic rehabilitation will be initiated only after the treatment of periodontal disease and disappearance of tissue inflammation.

Follow-up: Upon reception of the denture, the removable denture was cleaned, and finishing and polishing were checked. The patient reported no difficulty with mastication and expressed his great satisfaction for aesthetical appearance of the prosthesis. Occlusal integration was checked to prevent any static or dynamic dysfunctional contacts. The initial retention of the denture base was excellent. The patient was recalled after one week to assess wound healing and patient tolerance to the immediate prosthesis. Healing of the oral mucosa was confirmed by the closure of extraction socket and the non-inflammatory aspect of the oral mucosa. There were no adverse and unanticipated events to report.

Recommendations: The patient was informed that final prosthetic rehabilitation will be initiated only after the treatment of periodontal disease and disappearance of tissue inflammation. The patient was advised to maintain good oral hygiene and quit tobacco and cannabis use to prevent further deterioration.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A

Medical Record Number: N/A

Date of Admission: N/A

Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:

The 30-day-old Caucasian baby girl was referred to our hospital due to the detection of an intraabdominal cystic mass during the last trimester of pregnancy. Following a physical examination and imaging studies, the patient was diagnosed with an intraabdominal cystic mass, with no presence of malignancy. During surgery, it was found that the patient had torsion in her left adnexa, and a necrotic ovary was discovered. A left salpingo-oophorectomy was performed along with an incidental appendectomy. An oophoropexy was carried out on her right ovary, with absorbable suture at the level of the pelvic brim of the sidewall of her abdomen after draining peripheral cysts. A pathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of a necrotic ovary, with cysts smaller than 1 cm on her contralateral ovary, which were aspirated during surgery. The postoperative period showed no signs of wound infections or peritonitis, and the patient was discharged on the third postoperative day.

Follow-up:

The patient had regular check-ups with pelvic and Doppler imaging of her ovary after surgery. At 6 months of follow-up, the cysts, which were smaller than 1 cm, redeveloped up to 2 cm and then spontaneously disappeared. Her ovary developed age-appropriately, and she has been following up for 2 years.

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged in a stable condition with an appropriate follow-up plan.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Age: 2.5 years

Gender: Female

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Intraabdominal Cystic Mass

Hospital Course: The patient, a 55-day-old Caucasian baby girl, was admitted to our hospital due to the detection of an intraabdominal cystic mass during prenatal US in the last trimester. The imaging studies confirmed an intraabdominal cystic mass. The patient underwent surgery, during which her right ovary was found to be autoamputated due to torsion, and an incidental appendectomy was performed. Postoperatively, the cysts in the contralateral ovary were drained, and she was found to have cysts smaller than 1 cm, which were aspirated during surgery. The patient developed no wound infections or peritonitis during the PO period, and she was discharged on the third PO day. After surgery, her ovary was checked regularly using pelvic and Doppler imaging. The patient developed no complications during the follow-up period of 1 year, and the cysts in the remaining ovary spontaneously disappeared. She has been followed for 2.5 years uneventfully.

Discharge Diagnosis: Necrotic Ovary

Disposition and Condition at Discharge: The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Follow-Up Care: The patient requires regular follow-up care to monitor her remaining ovary using pelvic and Doppler imaging.

Medications at Discharge: None

Allergies: None

Primary Care Physician: [REDACTED]

Recommendations: The patient's primary care physician should be informed of her hospital course and advised to monitor her for any further complications.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Hospitalization Dates: [Redacted]

Admission Diagnosis: Acute abdominal symptoms

Final Diagnosis: Necrotic right ovary and salpinx due to torsion

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with acute abdominal symptoms 60 hours after experiencing sudden onset of pelvic pain, nausea, vomiting, and tenderness. Upon assessment, the patient was suspected to have appendicitis or ovarian pathology based on her history, physical examination, and laboratory findings. An immediate operation was performed under emergency conditions without prior US investigation. Torsion was detected in the patient's right ovary, which was subsequently found to be necrotic with no improvement in color or appearance following detorsion. A salpingo-oophorectomy was performed, and an incidental appendectomy was conducted, which was found to be normal upon pathology review. The patient did not develop any complications during the postoperative period and was discharged on the fifth postoperative day.

Follow-Up:

After surgery, the patient's remaining ovary was regularly monitored through pelvic and Doppler imaging. Her remaining ovary development was found to be age-appropriate and continued without incident for 6 years after surgery.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 10
Diagnosis: Left adnexal torsion

Hospital Course: 

The patient was admitted to the hospital with acute pelvic pain, nausea, vomiting, and pelvic tenderness. Direct abdominal X-ray images were normal, and she was pre-diagnosed with either appendicitis or ovarian pathology. On exploration, left adnexal torsion was detected, and detorsion was performed. In addition, a nonabsorbable suture was used to shorten the ipsilateral mesosalpinx, and an incidental appendectomy was performed. No complications such as wound infections or peritonitis occurred after the operation.

Follow-up:

After surgery, the patient's ovaries were checked regularly using pelvic and Doppler imaging. In the second month, the affected ovary was similar in size to the contralateral ovary, and normal blood flow was observed on US. The development of her ovaries was also age-appropriate. She has been followed for 6 years, and there have been no complications.

Conclusion:

The 10-year-old Caucasian girl was admitted to the hospital with acute pelvic pain and was pre-diagnosed with either appendicitis or ovarian pathology. However, on exploration, left adnexal torsion was detected. Detorsion was performed, and an incidental appendectomy was conducted. No complications occurred after the operation. The patient was followed regularly after surgery, and her ovaries developed age-appropriately. She has been followed for 6 years and remains uneventful with regular menstrual cycles.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [redacted]
Age: 16-year-old
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Right ovarian torsion with hemorrhagic cyst

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 16-year-old Caucasian female, presented to our hospital with acute pelvic pain, nausea, vomiting, and tenderness approximately 30 hours after symptom onset. Direct abdominal X-ray images were normal, and tumor markers were within normal ranges. Preoperative abdominal US showed minimal pelvic fluid, an increase in diameter of the appendix, and a large right ovary with increased diameter relative to the left ovary, leading to the suspicion of right ovarian torsion.
During surgery, right ovarian torsion with a hemorrhagic cyst approximately 8 cm in diameter was detected. A cystectomy was performed to prevent retorsion, and the ovary was repaired. Aspiration was performed on contralateral ovarian cysts, and the appendix was deemed periappendicitis, leading to its removal. The patient had no complications during the postoperative period, and she was discharged on the fifth postoperative day.
After the surgery, the patient's ovaries were regularly checked using pelvic and Doppler imaging. In the fourth month, her affected ovary showed similar size and blood flow as the contralateral ovary, and her development was age appropriate. She continues to be followed up uneventfully and has regular menstrual cycles.

Discharge Medications:

[No discharge medications prescribed]

Diet: No dietary restrictions.

Activity:
The patient is advised to avoid heavy lifting for the next two weeks.

Follow-up:
The patient will have regular follow-up visits with her gynecologist.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Right ovarian torsion with hemorrhagic cyst, periappendicitis.

Discharge Condition:
Stable, good prognosis.

Hospital Course:

The patient was a 34-year-old man who presented to the urology outpatient clinic with a complaint of swelling in the left testis for the past 3 years. The swelling gradually increased in size but was not associated with pain or fever. Physical examination revealed a firm, nontender mass of 2.5 × 2.0 cm attached near the lower pole of the left testis with an associated lax hydrocele. Baseline hematological and biochemistry workup was normal, as were serum markers for germ cell tumor of the testes. An ultrasound scan showed a well-circumscribed lesion associated with the left testis, which was suspicious for a neoplastic process.

Hospital Course:

The patient underwent an ultrasound of the abdomen, which did not reveal any evidence of lymphadenopathy. Based on the clinical and radiological findings, the patient was diagnosed with a suspicious left testicular mass. The patient was counseled on the different treatment options, including surgical management, and he opted for surgical removal of the left testis. The procedure was uneventful, and the patient had an uncomplicated postoperative course. He was discharged home on the second postoperative day with instructions for wound care and follow-up appointments. The patient was advised to continue to monitor his remaining testis for any changes or abnormalities and to seek medical attention if necessary.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Information:
- Name: [REDACTED]
- Age: 69-year-old female
- Medical History: Penicillin allergy, Left-sided breast cancer treated with mastectomy and axillary node clearance

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with a right-sided breast abscess. Upon admission, the patient was experiencing pain and feeling unwell, but remained apyrexial. Antibiotic therapy was initiated and subsequently two incisions and drainage were performed. After 4 days of IV therapy, the antibiotics were stepped down to a 7-day oral erythromycin course and a 10-day metronidazole course.

Results:

Twenty-one days after the patient was admitted, testing showed the presence of Actinomyces europaeus in the breast abscess pus. Antibiotic sensitivity testing was conducted, and the organism was sensitive to penicillin, erythromycin, vancomycin, tetracycline, and ciprofloxacin.

Treatment and Discharge:

The patient's penicillin allergy prohibited the use of first-line and second-line treatments. The patient was treated with tigecycline followed by 6 months of oral doxycycline. The patient received her IV therapy in the community with OPAT services. After completing the IV tigecycline course, the patient was switched to oral clarithromycin to complete a 6-month course of oral antibiotics.

The patient reported side effects after 6 weeks of oral doxycycline therapy including oral thrush and leg blisters, but there has been no evidence of recurrence to date.

Follow-up:
- Follow-up with the patient is encouraged to ensure the absence of recurrence or related symptoms.

Discharge Instructions:
- Continue with the oral antibiotics prescribed and complete the full course as directed.
- Promptly report any concerns or symptoms to your healthcare provider. 
- Keep the affected area clean and dry. 
- Wear loose clothing to avoid irritating the affected site. 
- Attend follow-up appointments as instructed by your healthcare provider.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification:
Name: [Patient’s Name]
Age: 15
Gender: Male
Hospitalization Dates: [Hospitalization Dates]

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a three-week history of irretractable abdominal pain, vomiting, and anorexia. On examination, there was maximal tenderness in the right upper quadrant along with significant guarding. The abdominal X-ray and routine blood test results were unremarkable except for the raised C-reactive protein of 92. Further evaluation with CT revealed right-sided abdominal mass and a layering effect at the caecal pole consistent with an intussusception. A diagnostic laparotomy was performed, and a right hemicolectomy was performed due to the suspicion of oncological involvement. The histopathology of the excised mass proved to be Burkitt's lymphoma of the terminal ileum causing ileocolic intussusception. The patient had an uncomplicated recovery postoperatively and was discharged three days after the surgery.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Burkitt's lymphoma of the terminal ileum causing ileocolic intussusception

Condition on Discharge:
Stable

Medications on Discharge:
Not Applicable

Follow-up Plan:
The patient will be referred for ongoing care and follow-up with appropriate specialists.

Patient/Family Education:
The patient's family was educated on the diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up plan. They were advised to report any new or concerning symptoms to their medical provider.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was discharged from the hospital with instructions to rest and follow up with appropriate specialists. The patient was advised to refrain from heavy lifting or strenuous activity for at least two weeks after the surgery. The patient was informed to maintain a healthy diet and to drink plenty of fluids. The patient was given a detailed description of their diagnosis and treatment, along with instructions for their follow-up care.

Patient Information:
The patient is a 2-month-old African American infant who presented to the emergency department with respiratory distress and hypoxemia.

Hospital Course:
Upon arrival, the patient was hypoxic with oxygen saturations of 20–30% and hypothermic to 32°C. She received a normal saline bolus, a blood culture was drawn, and a dose of ceftriaxone was administered. A rapid sequence intubation was performed to establish airway support. Despite increasing oxygen administration up to 100% FiO2, her oxygen saturation peaked at 80%. The patient was then transferred to a tertiary pediatric medical center.

Upon arrival at the tertiary center, a brief transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was concerning for Tetralogy of Fallot with critical pulmonic stenosis versus atresia. She received additional normal saline bolus, sodium bicarbonate, midazolam, and fentanyl. The infant was admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) for further stabilization. A prostaglandin drip was initiated with the hope of reopening her ductus arteriosus to increase pulmonary blood flow. Pediatric cardiothoracic surgery evaluated the patient, and the decision was made to perform an emergent Blalock–Taussig (BT) shunt.

The patient underwent modified BT shunt with a 3.5 mm Gore-Tex shunt anastomosing the innominate artery to the main pulmonary artery. There were no complications, and she returned to the PICU for post-op recovery. Daily TTE demonstrated normal biventricular function without pericardial effusion, as well as flow across BT shunt and through both branch pulmonary arteries. On post-op day one, she was extubated and weaned to room air, where she was able to maintain oxygen saturations around 88%. By post-op day two, she was tolerating oral feeds. She was discharged home on post-op day four with 40.5 mg of aspirin daily to help prevent shunt thrombosis.

Outcome:
The patient demonstrated a vast difference in her general appearance and energy level upon discharge.

Plan:
The plan is to take the infant back to the operating room to perform a complete repair with a transannular patch at 4–6 months of life.

Follow-up:
The patient will require continued follow-up with pediatric cardiology.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: Notprovided
Medical Record Number: Notprovided
Date of Admission: Notprovided
Date of Discharge: Notprovided
Admitting Diagnosis: Fever of Unknown Origin

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 75-year-old Chinese male with a medical history significant for hypertension, high cholesterol, coronary artery disease, diabetes, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and osteoarthritis who presented to the emergency department due to unstable gait. At the time of initial examination, he denied headaches, dizziness, shortness of breath, back or chest pain, rashes, focal weakness, or loss of sensation. He was treated in the ED until he was hemodynamically stable and asymptomatic, after which he was discharged. 

The patient returned 4 days later with worsening fever, rigors, chills, myalgias, weakness, malaise, confusion, and decreased appetite. On physical examination, the patient was tachycardic, with a black discoloration of the tongue, and a recorded fever of 102.8 degrees Fahrenheit. His complete blood count revealed decreased white blood cell count and thrombocytopenia. Initial serum ELISA for Lyme disease was negative. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain showed no acute pathologic processes. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen showed acute appearing splenic infarct. 

During hospitalization, the patient experienced severe hemodynamic instability and decompensated respiratory status. Additional sets of serum tests were drawn for multiple possible bacterial, viral, and fungal etiologies, which were positive for Lyme and Babesia microti antibodies. The lumbar puncture resulted in positive tests for Lyme. 

The patient was started on doxycycline for the diagnosis of Lyme neuroborreliosis, after which the patient clinically improved. The patient was treated for five days and was discharged on an oral course of doxycycline for a total of 21 days.

Discharge Diagnosis: Lyme neuroborreliosis
Disposition: Discharged
Summary of Care: The patient was treated for Lyme neuroborreliosis and has clinically improved. The patient was prescribed 21-days oral course of doxycycline upon discharge. It is advised the patient follow up with both their primary care physician and infectious disease specialist. They were instructed to return to the hospital if symptoms should worsen or additional symptoms arise. It is also advised the patient avoid any outdoor exposure to ticks.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Length of Stay: [Redacted] days

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 51-year-old male admitted to our hospital due to progressing renal failure and complaints of lumbar pain. During admission, laboratory results showed a positive Bence-Jones protein and bone marrow aspiration revealed plasma cell proliferation. The patient was diagnosed with Bence-Jones protein type Multiple Myeloma (MM) and was treated with various therapies, including bortezomib-dexamethasone, which was discontinued due to severe heart failure. Maintenance hemodialysis was initiated, and the patient continued with MM treatment with several cycles of chemotherapeutic agents, including lenalidomide-dexamethasone. During treatment, the patient experienced myoclonus-like movement of the lower extremities, pain in both lower legs, muscle atrophy, and well-demarcated ulcers in multiple areas. The patient was diagnosed with secondary hyperparathyroidism (HPT) and ultimately muscle and skin ischemia from calcific uremic arteriolopathy (CUA). The patient was treated with cinacalcet, and the ulcers have achieved epithelialization after topical treatment. The patient is currently undergoing pomalidomide-dexamethasone treatment.

Hospital Diagnoses:

1. Bence-Jones protein type Multiple Myeloma
2. Secondary hyperparathyroidism
3. Calcific uremic arteriolopathy
4. Vitamin D deficiency
5. Iron deficiency anemia

Hospital Procedures:

1. Bone marrow aspiration
2. Muscle biopsy
3. Transbronchial lung biopsy

Hospital Discharge Medications:

1. Acetaminophen
2. Omeprazole
3. Cinacalcet
4. Pomalidomide
5. Dexamethasone
6. Furosemide
7. Ferrous sulfate
8. Mecobalamin
9. Lansoprazole
10. Alfacalcidol

Follow-Up Instructions:

1. Continue with pomalidomide-dexamethasone treatment as prescribed
2. Follow-up with primary care provider for management of secondary hyperparathyroidism and vitamin D deficiency
3. Continue with topical treatment for ulcer management and report any signs of infection
4. Follow-up with nephrologist for ongoing management of renal failure
5. Continue with iron supplementation for management of iron deficiency anemia
6. Follow-up with hematologist/oncologist for ongoing management of Multiple Myeloma.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [date] 
Discharge Date: [date] 

Patient: [Name], 76-year-old male

History of Present Illness: [Name] presented to the office with fractured central incisors. He had partial edentulism in the superior left quadrant and multiple decay and fractured teeth. He was at high risk for caries and eccentric bruxism. The initial approach was conservative aiming to keep the upper front by means of composite fillings. Multiple restorations and implants were placed over the course of several years. In 2017, the patient came back to the office referring to pain of endodontic origin in the upper left canine. Subgingival caries in the six front teeth were found which made prognosis poor. The patient opted for replacement of residual teeth with a new implant-supported bridge.

Hospital Course: The treatment was carried out in a staged approach. The lateral incisors were extracted, and two immediate implants were placed by employing the Socket Shield Technique (SST). Four residual teeth were then prepared to be used as abutments of a temporary bridge for the duration of early osseointegration. After osseointegration, the second provisional bridge was cemented onto the uncovered implants. Three months after, the implants were uncovered, and the four abutment teeth were extracted again with the SST. The first provisional was replaced by a second acrylic bridge screwed onto the implants through temporary abutments. One month later, the prosthodontic phase was undertaken before the definitive prosthesis was placed.

Diagnosis: Fractured central incisors, eccentric bruxism, subgingival caries

Treatment: The patient was treated with the SST. Conservative approaches, composite fillings, implant restorations, and prostheses were performed. The patient had root canal treatment, and the implants were covered by healing abutments. The definitive prosthesis was placed after five months.

Condition at Discharge: The patient's condition was well. The patient was instructed to maintain good oral hygiene and schedule regular follow-ups.

Discharge Plan: The patient was discharged with instructions to take proper care of the newly placed prostheses and oral hygiene. The patient was advised to return for follow-up appointments.    

Discharge Medications: Not applicable.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 25-year-old male

Admission Date: [INSERT DATE]
Discharge Date: [INSERT DATE]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to multi-fragmentary fractures of the lower third of right tibia and fibula following a motorcycle accident.

Hospital Course:
Upon hospital admission, the patient was alert, coherent, and had no motor deficits. However, forty-eight hours after admission, he developed confusion and agitation, followed by a rapid decline in his level of consciousness that progressed to coma with bilateral extensor posturing. A CT scan revealed multiple and bilateral frontal subcortical hypodense areas without a midline shift. Consequently, a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome (FES) was reached, and the patient received supportive therapy with methylprednisolone (10mg/kg/day) for 3 days.

Two days later, the sedation and analgesia were withheld to assess the patient's neurological status. Subsequently, bilateral and spontaneous extensor posturing was observed with mechanical ventilation asynchrony, tachypnea (46/min), profuse and generalized sweating, arterial hypertension (215/112mmHg), and tachycardia (137/min). These manifestations led to the diagnosis of paroxysmal sympathetic hyperactivity (PSH). Consequently, propranolol (120mg/d) and morphine (3mg) every 4 hours were added to the therapeutic regimen.

On the 8th ICU day, remifentanil and propofol were withdrawn and replaced with dexmedetomidine while propranolol and morphine were maintained at the previous doses. The motor responses improved to the localization of the nociceptive stimulus. The episodes of sympathetic discharge became progressively briefer and less severe and reached no more than 2 per day.

Fourteen days after admission, the patient was extubated. The episodes of PSH were sporadic and less severe, leading to a gradual reduction of propranolol and morphine doses without worsening of sympathetic discharges. Twenty-two days after admission, the fracture was surgically fixed. The post-operative course proceeded without complications.

Discharge Condition:
Upon discharge, the patient had normal motor responses and was able to communicate with his family. The episodes of sympathetic discharges were sporadic and less severe with no significant complications. The patient was discharged home to continue ambulatory rehabilitation.

Follow-up Care:
The patient will follow up with the orthopedic surgeon for scheduled appointments related to the fracture.

Diagnostic Tests and Imaging Studies:
-Head CT scan revealed multiple and bilateral frontal subcortical hypodense areas without a midline shift
-Chest CT scan was normal except for small bilateral basal atelectasis with no evidence of pulmonary embolism
-Transthoracic echocardiography revealed normal ventricles, normal valve function and an absence of patent foramen oval or signs of pulmonary hypertension
-Electroencephalogram revealed diffuse slowing without epileptiform discharges
-Brain MRI revealed multiple small lesions in both cerebral hemispheres that were hypointense on T1 and hyperintense on T2 and FLAIR, did not show enhancement after gadolinium injection, and were located in the periventricular white matter of both frontoparietal regions

Final Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with fat embolism syndrome (FES) and paroxysmal sympathetic hyperactivity (PSH). The patient received supportive therapy with methylprednisolone (10mg/kg/day) for 3 days, and propranolol (120mg/d) and morphine (3mg) every 4 hours were added to the therapeutic regimen for PSH.

Outcome and Prognosis:
The patient was discharged home to continue ambulatory rehabilitation. The lesions found in the MRI had disappeared after one year, and neuropsychological testing revealed a mild impairment of executive functions with alterations of short and long-term memory. The long-term prognosis for the patient is expected to be favorable with appropriate follow-up care.

Hospital Course:
The 21-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital due to a closed fracture of the lower third of his tibia following a motorcycle accident. He received skeletal traction and was stable until he became confused and agitated with a progressive depression of consciousness that led to a coma. He exhibited extensor motor response, and a CT scan revealed small and multiple subcortical hypodense lesions in both the frontal and left parietal regions. Further tests revealed he had Fat embolism syndrome. The patient received general critical care supportive measures and IV methylprednisolone to manage his symptoms.

After the removal of sedoanalgesia on ICU day 5, the patient experienced generalized and profuse sweating, tachycardia, arterial hypertension, and tachypnea with asynchrony of mechanical ventilation and bilateral extensor posturing compatible with PSH. These symptoms were alleviated with the restoration of sedoanalgesia but continued to occur 4 times per day and were triggered by physiotherapy maneuvers, aspiration of secretions, and baths with cold water. The patient was treated with propranolol, morphine, and gabapentin to manage the PSH episodes.

The patient was successfully extubated on hospital day 11 without complications. After 20 days, he was transferred to the general ward, where he showed improvement in his condition and was communicating with his family. One month after admission, the surgical fixation of the fracture was performed, and the patient was discharged three days after surgery. A follow-up MRI after 12 months showed that the previously noted lesions were no longer visible, and the patient resumed his normal routine.

Discharge Summary:
21M with a closed fracture of the lower third of his tibia secondary to a motorcycle accident was admitted to the hospital. He developed Fat Embolism Syndrome, which led to PSH episodes following the removal of sedoanalgesia. He was treated with propranolol, morphine, and gabapentin, resulting in progressive reductions of the frequencies, intensities, and durations of the PSH episodes. He was successfully extubated without complications and was discharged three days after surgical fixation of the fracture. Follow-up MRI after 12 months showed that the previously noted lesions were no longer visible, and the patient returned to his routine.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 63-year-old Japanese man and a current smoker of more than 45 pack-years. A routine chest X-ray revealed an abnormal shadow in the left middle lung field. He underwent a chest computed tomography (CT) scan which showed a 3.6 × 2.8 cm pulmonary lesion in the left upper lobe with a clear boundary and heterogeneous contrast enhancement.
In the PET scan, the nodule showed an accumulation of 18F-fluorodexyglucose (FDG) with a maximum standardized uptake value (SUV max) of 4.95 in the early phase and 6.31 in the late phase. The trans-bronchial lung biopsy (TBLB) of the mass in the left upper lobe revealed non-small cell carcinoma.
A left upper lobectomy and mediastinal lymph node dissection were performed. The resected tumor measured 3.8 × 2.8 × 2.8 cm in diameter. The resected specimen showed a well-established grayish lesion with areas of necrosis. The patient's final histopathological diagnosis was H-FLAC.
Both lymphatic and vascular invasion were detected. Microscopically, all margins were free, but mediastinal lymph nodes (#5) showed metastasis. The final pathological staging was Stage IIIA (pT2aN2M0). The patient received cisplatin plus vinorelbine as adjuvant chemotherapy, but it was canceled at two courses because of the dehydration and hyperglycemia induced by the chemotherapy. The patient had relapsed pleural dissemination at 25 months after the surgery. Postoperative serum CEA and AFP were 1.5 and 3.7 ng/mL, respectively. But, serum CEA at the time of relapse was 132.4 ng/mL, and AFP was unfortunately not searched.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Summary of Events:
The patient was a healthy 40-year-old man who presented at the emergency room after a high energetic accident that resulted in multiple fractures and comprehensive soft tissue defects on his left lower leg and foot. A thorough clinical examination, along with diagnostic imaging, revealed numerous fractures, including a Gustilo grade IIIB fracture, a medial malleolus fracture, a Tillaux-Chaput fracture, fractures of the navicular bone, cuboid, and five metatarsal heads, and base fractures of the first and second proximal phalanx.

Within the first thirteen hours after admission, the patient underwent placement of an external fixator and debridement of the proximal medial wound. Subsequently, he underwent two more debridements and was treated with EpigardTM and absorbent dressings.

Within the first 24 hours postoperatively, NIRF imaging was performed, which displayed the area of vital and non-viable tissue. The patient underwent a final debridement approximately 6 days after hospital admission in the same session as definitive soft tissue coverage. Intraoperative imaging showed no difference in the extension of the fluorescent area compared to the previous NIRF imaging.

Throughout his hospital stay, the patient's active extension and flexion of the toes were preserved, as well as sensibility in the toes and forefoot. Disturbed sensibility to touch and pain was identified at the foot sole. No signs of a compartment syndrome were found.

Treatment and Management:
The patient was treated with debridement, external fixation, and temporary wound coverage with EpigardTM and absorbent dressings. Intraoperative NIRF image-guidance was used to identify non-viable skin that needed to be removed. The patient then underwent a free anterolateral thigh flap to cover the defect on the medial malleolus and foot sole, with additional split skin graft placed to cover the superficial defect at the lateral malleolus.

Outcome and Discharge Plan:
The patient was discharged after five weeks postoperatively, and nine weeks later, the patient and flap were doing well. His clinical rehabilitation care was completed, and he was able to mobilize with crutches. At the time of discharge, no complications were recorded.

Follow-Up:
The patient was instructed to return to his primary care physician for further follow-up care and to monitor for any potential complications.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Patient ID: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 50-year-old male who had undergone a right lobe liver transplantation from a living donor due to the presence of ulcerative colitis and sclerosing cholangitis. The patient developed impairment in liver function tests and massive pretibial edema three months after the surgery. A fever of 38.5°C also developed leading to hospitalization for treatment.

During laboratory analysis, the patient exhibited elevated levels of ALT, AST, GGT, direct bilirubin, and a white blood cell count of 25000/µL. Initial treatment involving Meropenem and Teicoplanin was started. CDUS and MDCT angiography were used to detect and confirm the presence of a pseudoaneurysm measuring 8 x 6.5 cm in the portal hilus associated with the hepatic artery. The pseudoaneurysm originated from the hepatic artery anastomosis site, and a loculated fluid collection around the pseudoaneurysm extending to the subdiaphragmatic and perihepatic spaces was observed.

In follow-up appointments, the patient's total bilirubin and direct bilirubin levels increased to 9.3 mg/dL and 6.6 mg/dl, respectively, and the white blood cell count was 30000/µL. The patient was hemodynamically unstable, and stenting of the hepatic artery was planned. Unfortunately, the patient passed away before the procedure.

Final Diagnosis: Presence of a Pseudoaneurysm in the Portal Hilus Associated with the Hepatic Artery.

Disposition: The patient passed away before the procedure could be completed. 

Discharge Medications: None.

Discharge Instructions: None.

Follow-up Instructions: None.
