Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with acute gestational obstructive pyelonephritis, complicated by the intravascular migration of a previously placed right ureteral stent.

Hospital Course:

Upon admission to our institution, the patient underwent an endovascular extraction procedure to remove the migrated stent. The procedure was performed by the vascular surgery department, who successfully removed the stent by puncturing the femoral vein and introducing a curved guide into the vena cava, which was then twisted around the stent to extract it. The patient experienced no complications during or after the procedure.

In addition to her primary diagnosis, the patient complained of insidious onset of palpitations and moderate right flank pain. There was no macroscopic hematuria, which was likely due to intracatheter blood clotting.

The patient was discharged on the following day in stable condition. She was advised to rest and monitor any potential complications related to the stent migration.

Follow-up:

The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care physician for any ongoing symptoms or concerns related to her previous condition.

Conclusion:

In summary, the patient was treated for acute gestational obstructive pyelonephritis with the added complication of a migrated right ureteral stent. An endovascular extraction procedure was performed successfully without complications, and the patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions for follow-up with her primary care physician.

Medical History:
The patient is a 41-year-old man with a history of kidney stones who presented to the emergency department with intense pain in the left upper quadrant after undergoing extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) for a left-sided kidney stone in the upper pole.

Hospital Course:
During the hospitalization, the patient was found to have a large subcapsular hematoma in the spleen, which was confirmed by ultrasound. A CT scan also showed a laceration in the lower pole of the spleen along with a subcapsular hematoma and a small subcapsular hematoma in the left kidney. The patient's therapy was conservative, and they were monitored in the intensive care unit. The patient recovered without any complications.

Physical Examination:
On examination, the patient presented with pain in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen.

Diagnostic Tests:
The ultrasound showed a large subcapsular hyperechoic collection in the spleen, whereas the CT scan confirmed a laceration of the lower pole of the spleen with a subcapsular hematoma and a small hematoma in the left kidney. Additionally, the fragmented kidney stone was visualized in the proximal left ureter (1400 HU).

Discharge Instruction:
The patient is being discharged after normal recovery without any complications. The patient should follow up with their primary healthcare provider for further care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: Not provided
- Sex: Male
- Age: 81 years
- Medical history: Alzheimer’s disease, excess weight, and type-2 diabetes

Admission:
The patient was admitted to the emergency department with a two-day history of diffuse abdominal pain.

Clinical Course:
- A contrast-enhanced abdominal CT scan showed diffuse fluid distention of the small bowel loops indicative of obstruction.
- A profusion of dilated small bowel diverticula along the mesenteric border was observed on the CT scan.
- An isolated jejunal diverticulitis was diagnosed in the right flank.
- The cause of the small bowel obstruction was a 3 cm large enterolith impacted in the distal ileum.
- A Meckel’s diverticulum was also incidentally discovered.
- Laparotomy was performed and the enterolith was manually and proximally retrogradely pushed.
- The inflamed jejunal diverticulum was surgically resected along with the Meckel’s diverticulum.
- The post-surgical period was uneventful.

Diagnosis:
Diffuse Jejuno-Ileal Diverticulosis (DJID) causing a small bowel obstruction due to an enterolith impacted in the distal ileum and an isolated jejunal diverticulitis with incidental Meckel’s diverticulum.

Treatment:
Surgical resection of the inflamed jejunal diverticulum and Meckel’s diverticulum along with manual and proximally retrogradely pushing the enterolith causing the small bowel obstruction.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient’s condition was stable at the time of discharge. No further interventions were necessary.

Instructions:
- The patient should follow a healthy diet plan to manage diabetes and excess weight.
- Follow-up appointments were scheduled to ensure timely evaluation and improvement of the patient's condition.

Disclaimer:
This discharge summary solely provides a brief summary of the patient’s hospital stay and should not be used as a substitute for thorough evaluation and advice by a licensed medical professional.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 66-year-old male with a history of prior spine surgery for a right L4-L5 disc herniation, presented to the clinic with complaints of severe bilateral L5 sciatalgy with paresthesias and mictional delay. An MRI performed in July 2014 revealed a disc herniation originating from the L4-L5 disc, which perforated the common longitudinal ligament and entered the thecal sac.

After undergoing surgery in the prone, antilordotic position under general anesthesia, via hemilaminectomy L4 and L5 on the clinically dominant right side with adjacent hemiflavectomy L3/4 and L5/S1, the patient was found to have a herniation inside the dural sac, causing compression of most adjacent rootlets. The neurosurgeon reported that the disc fragment in the spinal fluid was "spongious" and "softer than the usual extradural herniation."

The patient was discharged asymptomatic on day 5 and had an uneventful recovery.

Hospital Course Summary:

66-year-old male patient with prior spine surgery for a right L4-L5 disc herniation presented to the clinic with complaints of severe bilateral L5 sciatalgy with paresthesias and mictional delay. MRI showed a disc herniation originating from the L4-L5 disc, perforating the common longitudinal ligament, and entering the thecal sac. Underwent surgery in the prone, antilordotic position under general anesthesia, via hemilaminectomy L4 and L5 on the clinically dominant right side with adjacent hemiflavectomy L3/4 and L5/S1. Herniation inside the dural sac caused compression of most adjacent rootlets. Disc fragment in the spinal fluid was "spongious" and "softer than the usual extradural herniation." Discharged asymptomatic on day 5 and had an uneventful recovery.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient, a 47-year-old female, was admitted to the hospital for further evaluation of systemic blood pressure asymmetry. Prior Doppler ultrasonography of the cervical arteries had failed to demonstrate the vertebral arteries. Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) of the supra-aortic arteries was performed to investigate the cause of the patient's symptoms.

CTA revealed major hypoplasia of the vertebral arteries, particularly on the left side. The hypoplastic vertebral arteries were found to be not connected to the basilar artery, which was only fed by a large ascending artery emerging from a large left internal carotid artery. 3D volume rendering views without bone removal showed that this atypical artery was penetrating the skull through the hypoglossus canal. The artery was identified as a persistent hypoglossal artery, which was considered fortuitous.

The patient's condition was monitored and managed by the healthcare team throughout their hospitalization, and they were ultimately discharged in stable condition.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

The patient was instructed to follow up with their primary care physician regarding their blood pressure asymmetry. They were advised to continue their current medications and/or treatments as prescribed. The patient was also informed to report any new or worsening symptoms to their healthcare provider immediately.

FOLLOW-UP:

The patient was advised to schedule a follow-up appointment with their primary care physician within the next 2 weeks to discuss further evaluation and management of their condition. 

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

Systemic blood pressure asymmetry with major hypoplasia of the vertebral arteries and a persistent hypoglossal artery.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:

Stable.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]
Patient Name: [Name]
Gender: [Gender]
Age: [Age]
Admission Diagnosis: Speech problems

Hospital Course:
The patient, an 80-year-old woman with a history of subarachnoid haemorrhage, was brought to the emergency room because of speech problems. Clinical examination at the ER revealed a sensory aphasia without other neurologic deficits. CT scans and MRI were performed, which showed subtle changes in the left parietotemporal region of her brain. An Electroencephalography (EEG) was also performed that showed only interictal epileptiform changes. A diagnosis of postictal sensory aphasia was made and the patient was started on antiepileptic treatment with levetiracetam. There was gradual improvement of the patient's speech difficulties over three days and she was discharged home after six days without residual symptoms. 

Discharge Diagnosis: Postictal sensory aphasia 

Discharge Plan:
The patient was discharged home with antiepileptic treatment continued. Follow-up care was advised to be taken with her primary care physician. The patient was advised to seek medical help immediately if any worsening of the symptoms or any side effects of the medication were observed.

Electronic Health Record - Discharge Summary 

Patient Name: [redacted] 

DOB: [redacted] 

Admitting Diagnosis: Retro-orbital pain, exophthalmia, and palpebral ptosis on the left side 

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient, a 67-year-old woman, was admitted to the hospital due to retro-orbital pain, increasing over one week, accompanied by progressive exophthalmia, and palpebral ptosis on the left side. Physical examination revealed a complete ptosis of the left eyelid and complete absence of extraocular movements of the left eye, which were referable to the third, fourth, and sixth cranial nerve. The patient was being treated for lung cancer that had spread to the liver and cerebellum. Head CT scan showed mucous thickening in the left sphenoid and maxillary sinuses. Brain MRI revealed a new expansive lesion in the left cavernous sinus, which was previously not there in a CT performed several weeks ago. The lesion was inseparable from T2-hypointense changes in the posterior part of the left sphenoid sinus.

The patient underwent endoscopic sinus surgery, which included removal of mucus and fungal debris confirmed as aspergilloma on pathologic examination. Additionally, a mycotic aneurysm of the intracavernous carotid artery from the spread of invasive aspergillosis from the adjacent sphenoid sinus was diagnosed in this patient. Time-of-flight MRA confirmed the presence of a saccular aneurysm of the cavernous portion of the left internal carotid artery, with evidence of turbulent flow within the aneurysm and with an expansion of the aneurysm towards the left side. 

The patient did not undergo endovascular treatment due to the presence of a single hemorrhagic metastasis in the right cerebellar hemisphere, contraindicating antiaggregative drugs. The multidisciplinary team made the decision to refrain from the treatment due to the dismal prognosis of the malignancy. 

The patient died a few weeks later. 

If you have any questions regarding this patient's care, please feel free to contact the hospital.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 8 years old
Sex: M
Hospitalization Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Diagnosis: Osteonecrosis

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with a complaint of left hip pain and a limp. The patient had a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia for 5 years and underwent radiation therapy of the total body and bone marrow transplantation at age 6. Since the onset of the disease, the patient had been receiving steroids. Three months post-transplantation, the patient developed lung disease secondary to graft- versus-host disease and received high doses of steroids. Subsequently, the patient developed autoimmune hemolytic anemia and was treated again with high doses of steroids. Physical examination revealed a small Cushingoid boy with severe loss of muscle bulk due to steroid-induced myopathy.

Radiographic evaluation of the spine and hips revealed compression fractures in the thoracic spine (T11, T12) and mild deformity of the femoral epiphyses. BMD was measured in the lumbar spine (L1-4) and proximal femur using DXA. Trabecular BMD was measured at the 4% distal radius using peripheral quantitative computed tomography (pQCT). On the basis of established pediatric densitometric criteria, a diagnosis of low bone mineral content was made and patient was started on treatment with vitamin D and calcium.

Follow-up DXA studies to determine response to treatment at 12 months demonstrated collapse of the femoral head and an increase in BMD. Sequential follow-up DXA scans at 24 months showed further destruction of the femoral head and an increase in bone mass. Trabecular BMD at the 4% distal radial site by pQCT at 12 and 24 months showed a decrease. The concurrent visual assessment of the DXA images showed progressive deterioration of the left hip joint, beginning as vague osteosclerosis and becoming severe with destruction of the femoral head, suggesting the diagnosis of osteonecrosis.

The patient was discharged after recovery with a comprehensive care plan including management of osteonecrosis, vitamin D and calcium supplements, and regular follow-up appointments with the pediatrician and orthopedic surgeon. The patient's family was educated on the importance of good nutrition, regular exercise, and adherence to medication regimens. The patient was advised to avoid high-impact activities and to report any new symptoms immediately. 

Discharge Medications:

N/A

Follow-Up Appointments:

Pediatrician: Every 3 months
Orthopedic Surgeon: Every 6 months

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A
Admitting Diagnosis: Sulfonylurea overdose

Hospital Course:
The 15-year-old girl was admitted to the pediatric emergency department after attempting suicide with sulfonylurea, an oral hypoglycemic drug. On admission, she had no known previous disease, and vital signs were normal except for a low blood glucose level of 10 mg/dL. A toxicology test was not performed as the patient had confirmed the use of the drug for suicidal purpose. The patient showed neurological responses to painful stimuli.

The medical team injected intravenous dextrose to raise blood glucose levels, followed by glucose infusion and somatostatin treatment. A T2-weighted MRI showed focal hyperintensity in the SCC and a decrease in the apparent diffusion coefficient compatible with diffusion restriction, along with a significant signal increase in the DWI. The patient was treated for 24 hours and became conscious; her blood glucose level returned to normal. Another DWI was conducted two days later, which showed complete resolution of the lesion in the SCC.

Discharge Condition:
The patient is discharged from the hospital in stable condition.  

Discharge Medications: N/A 

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was instructed to follow up with a mental health provider for further evaluation and treatment on her suicidal tendencies. Additionally, the patient was instructed to continue routine follow-up with her primary care provider and advised to abstain from the use of oral hypoglycemic drugs in the future. 

Follow-Up Appointments:
Mental health provider
Primary care provider

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted for evaluation of increasing vertigo with bilateral murmer at his neck. He had a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension. During the hospital stay, the patient underwent bilateral carotid color duplex Doppler examination which showed mild atherosclerotic plaques of the common carotid bifurcation without any hemodynamically significant stenosis. Cerebral MRI revealed chronic ischemic signal changes in pons and nonspesific signal changes in white mater of bilateral frontal lobes. Selective carotid and vertebral angiographies were performed in order to confirm the stenoses in proximal parts of both internal carotid arteries; occipital arteries were arising from the cervical segments of internal carotid arteries on both sides. Selective right vertebral angiography revealed the patency of the artery with hypoplasia of V3–V4 segments and intracranial and intervertebral collateral flow to the left vertebral artery. Left subclavian angiography prior to catheterization of vertebral artery demonstrated severe stenosis of the vertebral artery.

Treatment:

The patient received a baloon-expandable intravascular stent which was placed to the ostium of the left vertebral artery in order to treat the high grade stenosis.

Outcome:

The patient was discharged in a stable condition. Correspondence and instructions will be provided to his primary care physician for further follow up.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with chronic ischemic signal changes in pons and nonspesific signal changes in white mater of bilateral frontal lobes, with atherosclerotic plaques of the common carotid bifurcation and high grade stenosis of the vertebral artery.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Age: 49 years
Gender: Female

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with complaints of episodes of vertigo following stapedectomy done 12 years ago. She reported that symptoms were evoked by pressing and lying on the left ear. On clinical examination, no remarkable findings were observed. Epley maneuvers were attempted but had no effect for treatment of possible benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). Other differential diagnoses were perilymphatic fistula, intravestibular granuloma, labyrinthitis and stapes prosthesis protrusion.

A temporal bone high resolution CT (HR CT) was performed and showed migration of stapes prosthesis into the vestibule. Depth of protrusion was measured 14 millimeters from tip of the prosthesis to the oval window. Based on these findings, the diagnosis of intravestibular stapes prosthesis protrusion related post stapedectomy vertigo was made and revision surgery was proposed.

Plan:

The patient was scheduled for revision surgery to rectify the migration of stapes prosthesis into the vestibule. The surgical team will document intraoperative findings and the patient's recovery progress will be monitored closely.

Disposition:

The patient is to be discharged once all vital signs and laboratory tests are stable. The patient was given appropriate instructions for follow-up appointments and medications.

Hospital course: The patient was admitted to the hospital with a three-month history of ocular-nasal catarrh and myalgia, as well as night sweats, weight loss, and early daily bi-temporal pain. The patient had severe inflammation and a high level of CRP and sedimentation rate. Diagnostic imaging showed a typical inflammatory “halo sign” on the temporal, common carotid, and vertebral arteries. Computed Tomography angiography showed blur homogeneously enhancing wall thickening of the aortic arch and its large emerging arteries. Hypodensity of the intima contrasted with the enhancement of the inflamed media. 

Treatment: After a temporal artery biopsy confirmed giant cell arteritis, the patient received treatment with massive corticosteroids. The patient showed rapid clinical and biological improvements. Nine months after the treatment, CDU and CT showed that the “halo sign” and diffuse arterial thickening had almost completely disappeared.

Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with giant cell arteritis.

Follow-up: The patient is advised to make follow-up visits for monitoring. The patient should seek immediate medical attention if symptoms of inflammation recur or worsen.

Patient Name: Not provided
Medical Record Number: Not provided
Date of Admission: Not provided
Date of Discharge: Not provided

Chief Complaint:
V2-V3 right-sided trigeminal paresthesia

History of Present Illness:
The patient was admitted to the neurosurgery department with a chief complaint of V2-V3 right-sided trigeminal paresthesia, which had developed six months earlier. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed a well-circumscribed, fleshy, 36 mm tumor in the Meckel cavum involving the Gasserian ganglion, following the V3 nerve into the foramen ovale, and generating a mass effect on the temporal lobe. An abnormality was previously detected on a computed tomography (CT) performed two years earlier in the context of otitis, without any alarm in relation to the benign presentation, a well-defined petrous lacunar image, and the fortuitousness of the discovery.

Past Medical History:
No information provided.

Medications:
No information provided.

Allergies:
No information provided.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent a macroscopically complete surgical resection by an exclusive extradural subtemporal approach with excellent symptomatic recovery. The postoperative CT demonstrated no complications. Immunohistochemical examination finally specified the diagnosis of melanotic schwannoma, a very rare pigmented tumor. The clinical course was good. However, a recurrence was detected on the MRI performed at three months. 11C-methionine positron emission tomography (MET-PET) confirmed suspicions, and a new surgical intervention was planned followed by adjuvant radiotherapy.

Discharge Condition and Disposition:
No information provided.

Patient Summary:
A 32-year-old female patient with Leopard syndrome presented at the cardiology clinic with atypical chest pain. Her family history revealed cases of pulmonary stenosis and coronary artery disease.

History and Physical Exam:
On physical examination, the patient was diagnosed with pectus excavatum, multiple lentiginous lesions on the face and hands, ocular hypertelorism, and short height. The electrocardiogram revealed sinus rhythm and left branch block. The echocardiography showed normal heart chambers, left ventricular ejection fraction of 60%, and low-grade pulmonary valve stenosis.

Diagnostic Reports:
The coronary CT angiography showed an atrial septal defect, dilated left pulmonary artery, mild thickening of the pulmonary semilunar valves, and ectatic LMCA and LAD throughout their course. The right coronary artery was dominant and had diffuse ectasia, and the right ventricular branch of the right coronary artery was directly originating from the sinus of Valsalva. The coronary angiography revealed a maximum gradient of 20 mmHg in pulmonary valve hemodynamic study.

Treatment:
As a result of the investigations, it was decided to follow up the patient with medical treatment.

Follow-Up:
The patient will require routine monitoring and follow-up to ensure her condition remains stable.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 39-year-old woman, was admitted to the hospital presenting with symptoms of dizziness and cerebellar ataxia. Computed tomography scanning revealed a large mass located in the left cerebropontine angle with calcifications that was compressing the brainstem and cerebellum. Magnetic resonance imaging confirmed the presence of a large cystic and solid mass extending anteriorly to the 7th cranial nerve and medially compressing the brainstem. Surgery was successful in removing the mass, and a histopathological analysis confirmed that the cystic component was consistent with benign intracranial epidermoid cyst (IEC). The adjacent solid portion consisted of squamous epithelial cells with nuclear pleomorphism and mitotic activity.

Past Medical History:
None reported.

Hospital Course:
The surgery was successful, and the patient's postoperative recovery was uneventful. The patient was monitored closely after the surgery for any signs of complications, and none were observed. The patient was discharged in good health and advised to follow up with their primary care physician.

Follow Up:
The patient is scheduled for a follow-up appointment with their primary care physician.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Cerebropontine angle epidermoid cyst.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 31-year-old nonsmoking woman

Admission Date: [Insert]

Discharge Date: [Insert]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for dyspnea and polyarthralgia following a cesarean section. She was a domestic help worker. Due to her symptoms, she underwent a CT angiogram, which showed diffuse groundglass centrilobular nodules with small centrilobular apical emphysema and condensed areas in the basal segments of the lower lobes. Initial diagnosis was hypersensitivity pneumonitis, but later diagnostic tests failed to identify any causative agent. Bronchial alveolar lavage cytology showed the presence of neutrophils, lymphocytes, and macrophages, for which a surgical pulmonary biopsy was performed. The biopsy revealed the presence of non-caseating granulomatous interstitial inflammation, with macrophages, lymphocytes, multinuclear giant cells, and characteristic needle-shaped birefringent crystalline material in polarized light. On second review of patient history, the patient confirmed the excessive use of talcum powder over several years.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Based on the clinical, radiological, and histological findings, the patient's condition was diagnosed as talc-induced interstitial lung disease (talcosis) due to prolonged use of talcum powder.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition with plans for follow-up care.

Discharge Medications:
None prescribed.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to discontinue the use of talcum powder. She was also instructed to follow-up with her primary care physician for further evaluation and management of her condition.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Hospital Admission Dates: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Metastatic breast carcinoma to the left external auditory canal (EAC)

Course of Hospitalization:

The patient, a 53-year-old female, was admitted to our hospital with a history of swelling in her left EAC for 2 weeks and gradually worsening hearing loss. The patient had been diagnosed with invasive ductal breast carcinoma 4 years prior, which was initially treated with a radical mastectomy and followed by chemoradiotherapy. In the follow-up period, the patient had developed bone and lung metastases and relevant treatment was administered.

On physical examination, a soft tissue mass was observed that completely obstructed the left EAC. No neurologic symptoms were observed. A CT scan of the temporal bone was performed, which revealed that the left EAC had been completely obstructed by a soft tissue density mass. Despite the fact that the mass was located in both bony and cartilaginous EAC, no bony or cartilaginous invasion was observed. MRI showed a well-defined and fusiform soft tissue mass that filled the left EAC and was located in both the bony and cartilaginous EAC. Following the administration of the gadolinium-based contrast agent, homogeneous enhancement was seen. DWI showed slightly hyperintense signal on isotropic trace image and the apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) map revealed slightly restricted diffusion in the mass. There was a small, non-enhancing hemorrhagic fluid collection present between the mass and the tympanic membrane. Middle and internal ear structures were normal on both MRI and temporal CT images. Based on the patient's history and imaging results, the diagnosis of metastatic breast carcinoma to the left EAC was made.

The patient underwent surgical operation by the ENT surgeon and the mass was subtotally removed. Histopathologic examination of specimens revealed metastatic carcinoma that had the same histopathologic features as the primary breast carcinoma. Histopathological findings of the excised lesion showed microscopically a infiltrative carcinoma compatible with a breast origin based on immunohistochemical study results that were positive for Estrogen Receptor (ER), Cytokeratin 7, and E-cadherin but negative for C-Erb-b2 and Progesterone receptor (PR). The tumor was composed of atypical cells with large nuclei and prominent nucleoli in a solid pattern. There was no ductal or tubular structure. The positivity of both ER and E-Cadherin also supported ductal type when compared to lobular carcinoma of the breast.

The patient was discharged with appropriate referrals for further treatment follow-up. The patient's condition was stable upon discharge.

Hospital course summary complete.

Discharge Summary:
This is a discharge summary for the 50-year-old female patient who was admitted to our hospital due to edema. The patient had previously been diagnosed with type B influenza and later developed nephrotic syndrome. She responded positively to rest and sodium restriction and achieved complete remission from nephrotic syndrome in approximately 2 weeks. No recurrence of the condition has been noted in the one year since.

Admission and Hospital Course:
The patient's physical findings on admission showed edema of the face and limbs, along with pitting edema of both lower legs. The laboratory findings revealed proteinuria and a high level of total cholesterol. She was diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome after exhibiting facial edema, decreased urine output, and a high level of proteinuria. A kidney biopsy was performed to confirm the diagnosis, which showed no glomerular basement membrane thickening, endocapillary or mesangial cell proliferation. An immunofluorescence study showed nonspecific granular IgM deposits, and electron microscopy revealed extensive foot process effacement. 

Treatment and Progress:
The patient was prescribed rest and sodium restriction, with no need for any medications. The patient responded positively, with a gradual decrease in proteinuria level and later complete remission from the nephrotic syndrome approximately 2 weeks after onset. No recurrence of the condition has been noted in the one year since.

Follow-Up Recommendations:
The patient is advised to maintain a low-sodium diet to help ensure long-term nephrotic syndrome remission. No further follow-up appointments are currently required, but patients wishing to book an appointment may do so through the hospital's outpatient clinic.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 80
Sex: Male

Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Length of Stay: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:

An 80-year-old male was referred to the radiology department with progressive pain and swelling in the left foot. Clinical examination revealed a bump at the inner sole, which was suspected of causing plantar fasciitis. Plain films showed the absence of inferior calcaneal spur formation, while ultrasound identified normal plantar fascia. However, medially from plantar fasciitis, adjacent to the course of the medial plantar artery, there were hypoechoic tubular structures that were not compressible and had no intralesional flow on color Doppler imaging.

Further examination with MRI confirmed thrombosis of the medial plantar veins. Conservative therapy was administered, including change of footwear and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, which mitigated the symptoms. Follow-up ultrasound 2 months later showed no residual thrombosis in the plantar veins.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Thrombosis of medial plantar veins

Discharge Condition:

Stable

Discharge Instructions:

1. Continue wearing comfortable shoes and avoid wearing shoes that cause discomfort.
2. Take non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs as directed by your primary care physician.
3. Follow up with your physician as scheduled.

Follow-up Instructions:

The patient is advised to undergo a follow-up examination with their primary care physician.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Suicide attempt by hanging

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit after being found in cardiac arrest following a suicide attempt by hanging. Cardiac massage was performed during transfer for 40 minutes. The patient was comatose upon arrival with a Glasgow score of 3/15. Brain computed tomography (CT) was performed after five hours which showed bilateral basal ganglia hypodensity with related decreased gray-white differentiation due to edema. The unenhanced CT after 30 hours showed progression of the brain edema with collapse of the sylvian fissures, basal cisterns, and cortical sulci, along with prominent pseudo-subarachnoid hemorrhage. Subsequent evoked potential testing confirmed brain death after 48 hours. 

Hospital Course Summary: The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit following a suicide attempt by hanging that resulted in cardiac arrest. Despite attempts at resuscitation, the patient remained comatose with evidence of severe brain injury on imaging. Further neurological testing confirmed brain death, and the patient was subsequently discharged from the hospital. 

Course of Treatment: The patient received aggressive resuscitative measures upon admission, including cardiac massage. However, given the extent of the brain injury, no further interventions were pursued.

Follow-Up Plan: There is no follow-up required as the patient is deceased. 

Primary Care Provider: None indicated.

Communication with Consulting Physicians: None indicated.

Discharge Medications: None indicated.

Discharge Condition: The patient expired. 

Discharge Disposition: The patient was transferred to the morgue for further evaluation. 

Attending Provider: [REDACTED]

Summary: The patient was admitted to the hospital following a suicide attempt by hanging that resulted in severe brain injury and subsequent brain death. Despite aggressive resuscitative measures upon admission, no further interventions were pursued given the extent of the injury. The patient subsequently expired, and arrangements were made for evaluation in the morgue.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 48-year-old man with a history of alcohol abuse, presented to the gastroenterology department in November 2006 complaining of severe epigastric pain and nausea for two days. The laboratory findings were suspicious for pancreatitis and the patient underwent computed tomography (CT), which showed an edematous pancreas tail and fluid in the anterior prerenal space and fascia. He had two similar episodes of acute tail pancreatitis in the following months. 

In September 2009, the patient presented with vague epigastric pain of several weeks duration. Serum amylase and lipase levels were normal, but the cholestatic parameters were mildly elevated. A magnetic resonance (MR) study was performed, which demonstrated moderate chronic pancreatitis of the tail with atrophy and irregular bordering of the Wirsung’s duct. Helicobacter pylori gastritis was also diagnosed. 

In February 2012, the patient presented again to the gastroenterologist with epigastric and left upper quadrant pain. Contrast-enhanced CT scan was performed to evaluate the known chronic pancreatitis and other causes of pain. The study surprisingly revealed a hypervascular lesion in the pancreatic tail consisting of a conglomeration of small hypervascular spots and blood vessels. Further examinations were performed in order to differentiate a vascular malformation from a hypervascular pancreatic tumor, especially an islet cell tumor or a hypervascular metastasis. Contrast-enhanced MR study showed a focal area of heterogeneous contrast enhancement without an apparent nodular component. The subsequent angiography showed two large feeding arteries in the early arterial phase, followed by a racemose vascular network, an early transient dense parenchyma stain in the early portal phase and early wash-out of the lesion in the portal phase. Based on these findings, a pancreatic arteriovenous malformation was suggested. 

The patient underwent resection of the pancreas tail and postoperative recovery was uneventful. Histopathologic examination revealed sequelae of chronic pancreatitis and numerous dilated blood vessels accompanied by blood clot formation and intimal hyperplasia. The histopathological findings were consistent with a pancreatic AVM. 

Discharge Summary:

The 48-year-old male patient who was diagnosed with a pancreatic arteriovenous malformation (AVM) and chronic pancreatitis has been discharged. He presented with severe epigastric pain and nausea in November 2006, and underwent computed tomography (CT) which showed an edematous pancreas tail and fluid in the anterior prerenal space and fascia. In September 2009, a magnetic resonance (MR) study was performed due to vague epigastric pain, which indicated moderate chronic pancreatitis of the tail with atrophy and irregular bordering of the Wirsung’s duct. A Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (HPS) gastritis diagnosis was also made. In February 2012, a contrast-enhanced CT scan was performed which revealed a hypervascular lesion in the pancreatic tail, implying the presence of a pancreatic arteriovenous malformation. The patient underwent resection of the pancreas tail and postoperative recovery was uneventful. Histopathologic examination revealed sequelae of chronic pancreatitis and numerous dilated blood vessels accompanied by blood clot formation and intimal hyperplasia that was consistent with a pancreatic AVM. The patient's condition was managed appropriately and he was discharged in a stable condition.

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY:

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Medical History:
The patient had a history of repeated upper airway infections for six months and had undergone functional endoscopic sinus surgery with septal correction and partial reduction of a right-sided hypertrophic concha media bullosa in 2008.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented at the otorhinolaryngology department with symptoms of nasal obstruction, headaches, sneezing, hyposmia, postnasal drip and coughing. Treatment with antibiotics and oral steroids had no effect. Endoscopic nasal examination showed a bilateral oedematous mass located medially and cranially in the nose, originating anteriorly of the attachment of the concha media. A CT scan was performed which demonstrated the presence of a bilateral well-delineated soft-tissue mass in the olfactory cleft. The patient underwent a magnetic resonance (MR) scan for further work-up. On MR, the lesions appeared T1- and T2-isointense compared to white matter. A biopsy was performed and the presence of REAH was histologically confirmed. Endoscopic non-aggressive resection was performed and in the follow-up consultation three weeks later the patient was free of symptoms. Nasal endoscopic control four months after surgery showed no signs of recurrence.

Summary:
The patient presented with symptoms of repeated upper airway infections. A CT scan demonstrated the presence of a bilateral soft-tissue mass in the olfactory cleft, which was confirmed as REAH by biopsy. Endoscopic non-aggressive resection was performed which led to complete symptom resolution and showed no signs of recurrence on follow-up examination four months later.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Anonymous

Date of Admission: [insert date]
Date of Discharge: [insert date]

Medical Record Number (MRN): [insert number]

Hospital Course: The patient, a 25-year-old woman, presented to our radiology department for an MRI examination of the left knee due to a three-month history of “crackling” noise. The physical examination revealed anterior laxity of the knee. The patient had a congenital shortening of the left leg and had previously undergone a leg lengthening procedure.

Diagnostic Findings: The MRI examination indicated various anatomic anomalies, including the absence of the anterior cruciate ligament, hypoplastic posterior cruciate ligament, absence of the lateral intercondylar spine, and hypoplastic lateral meniscus. The patient also had severe trochlear dysplasia due to hypoplasia of the lateral femoral condyle and medial patellar facet hypoplasia. Sequellae of the earlier leg lengthening procedure were observed in the form of absent left fibula and metallic artefacts in the tibia.

Treatment and Management: The patient was managed conservatively and discharged with recommendations for ongoing physical therapy to improve stability and reduce the risk of future knee injuries.

Conditions at Discharge: The patient was stable at the time of discharge and instructed to follow up with her primary care physician for ongoing care and management.

Follow-Up Care: The patient was advised to continue physical therapy and follow up with her primary care physician for ongoing monitoring of her condition.

Impression: The patient's MRI examination revealed multiple anatomic anomalies, and she was managed conservatively. Further evaluation and management may be necessary, and the patient was instructed to follow up with her primary care physician for ongoing care and management.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: XXX
Gender: Female
Age: 27 years
Admission Date: MM/DD/YYYY
Discharge Date: MM/DD/YYYY
Admitting Diagnosis: Sclerosing Lymphocytic Lobulitis

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 27-year-old woman, was admitted to our hospital for further investigation upon referral from another hospital where a routine check-up showed changes in the right breast. The patient had a history of left breast cancer diagnosed at the age of 22 and had undergone wide excision, sentinel node procedure, adjuvant chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and hormonal therapy. A follow-up examination, coinciding with the conclusion of hormonal therapy, showed a multifocal nodular contrast enhancement in the retro-areolar region and the lower-outer quadrant of the right breast. The patient's examination was categorized as BIRADS 4, and follow-up included breast ultrasound every six months and a yearly mammogram and MRI of the breasts.

An ultrasound-assisted core biopsy was performed, which revealed dense lymphocytic infiltrate of predominantly B-lymphocytes surrounding the ductulolobular unit and the vessels, in combination with a fibrous stroma of low cellularity and an increase in fibroblasts. This led to a diagnosis of sclerosing lymphocytic lobulitis, with no signs of malignancy detected. 

The patient's hypoechoic lesion on ultrasonography and the multifocal contrast enhancement on MRI gradually diminished over consecutive examinations to a level where it is barely perceptible. The patient was advised to continue regular follow-up examinations.

The patient was discharged on MM/DD/YYYY in stable condition with instructions to continue follow-up examinations as scheduled. Discharge medications included [ OMITTED ]. The patient was advised to follow a healthy lifestyle, which includes regular exercise and a balanced diet, and to report any abnormal symptoms to her healthcare provider.

Discharge Diagnosis: Sclerosing Lymphocytic Lobulitis

Condition at Discharge: Stable

Follow-up: Continue regular follow-up examinations as scheduled.

The patient, a 46-year-old male with no significant medical history, was admitted to the hospital due to nausea and vague epigastric abdominal pain. The patient had an uneventful hospital stay and received necessary treatment and care under the supervision of the medical staff.

Please ensure that the patient follows up with his haematological specialist to continue treatment and monitoring for recovery.

Myeloid sarcoma

Electronic Health Record

Patient Name: [Name]

Age: 28 years   Sex: Female

Date of Admission: [Date]

Date of Discharge: [Date]

Admission Diagnosis: Idiopathic acute pancreatitis

Brief Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the emergency department with mild abdominal pain associated with nausea, located in the epigastric/left upper quadrant region, and slight worsening with food intake. The patient had a past medical history significant for a similar presentation six months before when she was diagnosed with idiopathic acute pancreatitis, denied alcohol consumption, was not on any medications or herbal supplements. Examination of the abdomen revealed mild tenderness in the epigastric/left upper quadrant region, and also with a palpable mass in the left lower quadrant.

Laboratory workup revealed elevated lipase, unremarkable CBC, normal liver functions tests, lipid panel, and IgG panel. Ultrasound of the abdomen showed minimal sludge in the gallbladder without any obvious stones. CT abdomen with contrast demonstrated a spleen in the anterior left lower abdomen, elongated pancreatic tail coiled in conjunction with the splenic vessels, and with mild inflammation of the pancreatic tail. The patient improved clinically with conservative management with IV fluids.

The patient finally underwent splenopexy at an outside facility. 

Discharge Summary:

The patient, a 28-year-old multiparous female, was admitted to the hospital with complaints of mild abdominal pain associated with nausea. During the hospital stay, the patient was diagnosed with idiopathic acute pancreatitis and underwent treatment to manage her symptoms. The patient had a past medical history significant for similar presentation in the past, also treated for acute pancreatitis.

Laboratory tests revealed elevated lipase levels, and imaging studies showed an elongated pancreatic tail, mild inflammation in the region, and minimal sludge in the gallbladder without any obvious stones. The patient's clinical condition improved with conservative management with IV fluids.

The patient was discharged with information about continuing care and advised to follow-up with their primary care physician. The patient received instructions on home management related to diet, fluids, and monitoring for signs of recurrent symptoms. Overall, the patient had a satisfactory outcome, and the care provided was appropriate for the patient's condition.

Hospital Course:
The 74-year-old woman was admitted for investigation of unexplained pneumobilia on follow-up abdominal ultrasound. Computed Tomography (CT) of the abdomen showed massive pneumobilia and dilation of the common bile duct with suspected lithiasis. T2-weighted magnetic resonance cholangiography (MRCP) further confirmed choledocus calculi and bile duct dilation. A delayed opacification of bile ducts was observed during the second MRI, which finally showed opacification of the intrahepatic bile ducts, gallbladder, upper choledocus and hepatic flexure of the colon via a fistula. Given the patient’s medical history, the endoscopic treatment was favored over surgery.
 
Summary:
This 74-year-old woman, who was treated for breast cancer with bone metastases, was found to have an unexplained pneumobilia. The imaging studies revealed massive choledocus calculi with bile duct dilation and a fistula to the hepatic flexure of the colon. The patient underwent endoscopic treatment and sphincterotomy for common bile duct stone extraction. The patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions for follow-up care.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [patient name]
Medical Record Number: [medical record number]
Date of Admission: [admission date]
Date of Discharge: [discharge date]

Admission Diagnosis:
The patient presented to the emergency department with pain localized to the right costovertebral angle and associated shoulder pain.

Hospital Course:
Laboratory findings showed raised inflammatory parameters (CRP 116 mg/dL). Non-contrast-enhanced CT-scan was performed which revealed a high-density structure in the liver segment 7 surrounded by a hypodense zone of 25 mm, containing small air bubbles suggestive of an intrahepatic abscess. Review of the contrast enhanced CT-scan performed two weeks earlier on the occasion of an acute appendicitis learned that this intrahepatic calcification had the same characteristics as the appendicolith on the previous scan. Based on the patient's medical history and diagnostic tests, the patient had a dropped appendicolith, which had spontaneously migrated into the liver parenchyma causing an intrahepatic abscess. 

Treatment:
During the second laparoscopic exploration, the appendicolith was extracted and the abscess was drained. Microbiology was positive for Escherichia coli. Intravenous antibiotics were administered for four days.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in good condition.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient was advised to follow-up with their primary care physician for further monitoring.

Discharge Medications:
None.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to continue their regular activities and diet, and to seek medical attention if their symptoms persist or worsen. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
Intrahepatic abscess due to dropped calcified appendicolith.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Edentulous left mandible secondary to partial mandibulectomy surgery

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 29-year-old Pakistani male who was admitted to the Oral Surgery Department for rehabilitation of the left edentulous mandible secondary to partial mandibulectomy surgery. The patient has undergone two operations for the left body of a mandible keratocyst odontogenic tumour (KCOT). The patient reported an absence of paraesthesia on the left mandible. He has been reviewed regularly and requested to have a replacement of his missing teeth on the lower left side due to difficulty eating and the effect on his appearance. 

On clinical examination, the patient had an asymmetrical face with a slightly depressed left lower body of the mandible on a class I skeletal pattern. The smile line was high exposing the gingiva on the upper maxillary incisors. Intraorally, the oral hygiene was fair with the presence of mild gingivitis. The dentition on the maxillary arch was unrestored. The left edentulous mandible was irregular basal bone with firm mucosa covering the bone from 41 until 37. There were marked loss of bony structure horizontally and vertically. This has caused the tongue to occupy the space that used to be occupied by teeth and alveolus in the left mandibular segment. The healing of the operation site was uneventful.

An orthopantomogram was taken to evaluate the remaining bony structure of the mandible. Radiographically, the operation site (lower left posterior segment) has no abnormalities. The remaining basal bone was adequate in thickness to support the mandible with an irregular margin. There are no radiopaque abnormalities suggestive of new pathology.

In consideration of the above, and the opinions of relevant healthcare professionals, the patient is clinically stable and able to be discharged.

Discharge Diagnosis: Edentulous left mandible secondary to partial mandibulectomy surgery

Discharge Plan: The patient's discharge plan is to provide referral for replacement of his missing teeth on the lower left side. The patient will be followed up on an as-needed basis and referred to a specialist if new symptoms arise.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: 26th April 2017
Date of Discharge: 25th May 2017

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient, a 21-year-old female, was admitted to the emergency intensive care unit (EICU) of Ruijin Hospital affiliated to Shanghai Jiao Tong University on 26th April 2017. The patient had a history of suffering from chest pain, fever, and coma for a fortnight in the postpartum period. The patient was previously diagnosed with multi-drug resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae (MDR-KP) and treated with piperacillin-tazobactam, meropenem, tigecycline, and colistin. However, these antimicrobial therapies did not work effectively.

During the admission to our hospital, a full-body computed tomography (CT) scan identified thickened pericardium, bilateral pleural effusion with multiple exudative focuses, hepatosplenomegaly, and pelvic effusion in this patient. Empiric antibiotic treatment was started with piperacillin-tazobactam for Klebsiella pneumoniae infection followed by the use of meropenem, tigecycline, and colistin. On 18th May 2017, the treatment was further adjusted to include polymyxin B, as the patient's infection had aggravated in bilateral lungs compared to that upon admission. Four days later, multiple red rashes appeared on the patient's skin. SH with dark round spots was seen on 23rd May 2017, without pain or pruritus. More dark brown spots spread on the skin of the trunk and limbs, especially on that of the lower abdomen, right hand, and right foot.

The patient suffered from diarrhea suddenly with intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) increasing to 19 cm H2O on 21st May 2017. About 500 ml black stool was found in the patient’s excrement. Her serum creatinine was elevated dramatically, and anuria occurred. The laboratory examinations revealed that the patient suffered from coagulation abnormality and hyperfibrinolysis, hence disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

The patient was transferred back to the local hospital for further treatment on 25th May 2017. At that time, her skin color did not recover to the previous state. 

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
MDR-KP infection, coagulation abnormality, and DIC

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient should continue her treatment under the guidance and supervision of her local physician. 

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENT:
None stated.

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 33
Sex: Female
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Length of Stay: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our institution with complaints of progressive hearing loss and persist vertigo. A spiral CT-scan with one millimetre thick sections of the temporal bone was performed, which demonstrated symmetrical extensive lucencies in the pericochlear bony otic capsules, including the promontories. The patient was diagnosed with genetically confirmed osteogenesis imperfecta type I.

An additional 3T MRI was performed, which included axial FLAIR imaging, axial diffusion-weighted imaging, and gadolinium-enhanced 3D fast field echo imaging (3D FFE) through the entire brain. Furthermore, 3D balanced steady-state gradient echo through the skull base completed the exam. The MRI images showed symmetric areas of increased signal intensity in the pericochlear regions on the FLAIR and 3D balanced steady-state images. These areas showed moderate enhancement on the 3D FFE-images after contrast administration.

After a thorough evaluation, the patient received the necessary treatment, and her condition improved significantly. The patient was counseled on her diagnosis and prescribed lifestyle modifications to maintain optimal health. She was discharged in stable condition.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient's condition had improved significantly, and she was discharged in stable condition.

Instructions:

The patient was advised to follow a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet and regular exercise. She was advised to continue medication prescribed by her healthcare provider. The patient was instructed to monitor her condition closely and report any changes or concerns to her healthcare provider.

Follow-up:

The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care physician within [Redacted] weeks. She was instructed to schedule an appointment if she experienced any new symptoms or if her condition worsened.

Hospital Course Summary:

This is a summary of the hospital course for a 42-year-old woman who presented to the emergency department with acute onset right flank pain. The patient had a history of endometriosis and was found to have a right perinephric hemorrhage and an exophytic hypervascular mass arising from the lower pole of the right kidney with a maximum diameter of 5.5 cm, as well as multiple thin-walled cysts in the lung bases. The patient was diagnosed with lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) and treated conservatively for the retroperitoneal hemorrhage. 

The patient underwent a follow-up CT abdomen two months later, which showed complete disappearance of the perirenal blood and an unchanged renal tumor in volume and imaging characteristics. Despite the inability to rule out a hypernephroma based on the CT characteristics, the patient underwent a right partial nephrectomy due to the risk of rehemorrhage and the possibility of the lesion being a benign angiomyolipoma. Pathology confirmed the presence of an angiomyolipoma. The patient was transferred to an academic center with expertise in interstitial lung diseases and lung transplantation for further follow-up.

Summary of Follow-Up Care:

The patient was discharged to the care of her primary care physician with detailed instructions for follow-up care. She was advised to continue her medical treatment plan and attend all scheduled appointments with specialists. The patient was educated on the importance of regular monitoring for both her endometriosis and LAM. She was instructed to report any new symptoms or concerns to her primary care physician as soon as possible. 

The patient's prognosis is guarded due to the presence of LAM and history of endometriosis. Close monitoring and multidisciplinary care by specialists are recommended.

This is a summary of the patient's treatment and plan.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: *Redacted*
DOB: *Redacted*
Sex: Male

Hospital Course:

The patient presented for a check-up with a normal digital rectal examination and a PSA of 1.05 ng/mL. Transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) showed an hypoechoic structure of 5 cm, extending beyond the prostate, interpreted as an utricular cyst. The multiparametric prostate Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) showed a sharply demarcated structure of 5.8 × 6.5 × 5.2 cm originating in the right transition zone of the midprostate, with posterior bulging and no invasive behavior. A benign stromal tumor was suggested. TRUS-guided biopsy was performed, and the tissue diagnosis was a leiomyoma. An imaging follow-up with MRI at six months was advised.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Leiomyoma

Summary of Care:

The patient, a 62-year-old man, underwent TRUS-guided biopsy, which showed tissue diagnosis of leiomyoma. Follow-up MRI was advised in six months for imaging. The patient was discharged in good condition.

Condition at Discharge:

Stable

Discharge Medications:

None

Follow-up:

Follow-up imaging with MRI at six months was advised.

Admission Details:
A 68-year-old male patient was admitted with bitemporal hemianopsia and falling episodes. Computed tomography (CT) revealed a spontaneously hyperdense suprasellar mass. MRI was performed, which showed a well-delineated lesion with a low signal intensity on T2-weighted images. Gadolinium was administered, which showed an inhomogeneous moderate to intense enhancement.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent surgical intervention, and only a partial removal was possible due to the lesion's attachment to the chiasm and optic nerves. Histological examination confirmed the diagnosis of granular cell tumor (GCT). Postoperative progress was uneventful, and the patient showed satisfactory improvement. The patient was monitored for two years, where no evidence of recurrence was identified.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was discharged with instructions to attend regular follow-ups to monitor their condition. Any new symptoms such as headaches or vision changes should be reported immediately to the medical staff. The patient must adhere to all medication and treatment plans provided.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 69
Gender: Female

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis. She had been treated for colorectal cancer seven years prior, which required rectosigmoidectomy and chemotherapy. Four years later, she had bisegmentectomy for a 3 cm liver metastasis and underwent a new scheme of chemotherapy. 

During the recent admission, the patient presented with postprandial epigastralgia and elevated levels of lipase, liver transaminases, alkaline phosphatase and direct bilirubin. Workup with Sonography, Computed Tomography and Echoendoscopy revealed dilatation of the bile ducts containing a dense sludge, for which ERCP was performed. Mucus containing neoplastic cells was aspirated, and sphincterectomy was performed, which resulted in normalization of the blood tests. 

Two months later, the patient was readmitted twice for similar episodes. MRI was performed with gadoxetic acid disodium and revealed a filling defect in the liver, and a biopsy confirmed the lesion as a liver mucinous adenocarcinoma metastasis.

The patient subsequently had a bisegmentectomy with resection of the right intrahepatic biliary duct. The histopathological examination identified the lesion as a liver mucinous adenocarcinoma metastasis.

Discharge Condition:
The patient's overall condition at the time of discharge was poor.

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to continue with the ongoing treatment plan and follow up closely with the primary care physician for any further symptoms or changes in the condition.

Admitting Diagnosis: Severe and sporadic hemophilia A

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 65-year-old male, was admitted due to a large abdominal mass. His medical history revealed a diagnosis of transfusion-related chronic hepatitis C, multiple hemophilic arthropathies, and cerebral hemorrhage. Laboratory findings were significant for a prolonged partial thromboplastin time and decreased factor VIII levels. The patient received treatment for his hemophilia with two weekly injections of plasmatic factor VIII, and his hepatitis C was left untreated.

Diagnostic imaging studies including abdominal computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging were performed upon the patient's referral to our department. No ultrasound was performed. The imaging studies were able to characterize the abdominal lump as a large mass.

The patient was advised on the significance of the mass and the potential treatment options. The patient was advised to pursue follow-up appointments with his primary care physician.

The patient was discharged in a stable condition.
