The patient was advised to follow-up with his primary care physician to monitor his condition and discuss potential treatment options based on his imaging studies.

No additional intervention or intervention plan was determined necessary by the medical team involved in the patient's care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]

Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]

Date of Admission: [Admission Date]

Date of Discharge: [Discharge Date]

Admitting Diagnosis: Acute pain in the left hip

Final Diagnosis: Calcific tendinitis of the gluteus medius tendon

Hospital Course:

The above patient was admitted to our institution in April 2013 with acute pain in the left hip following a skiing accident. Clinical examination showed pain and tenderness of the trochanteric region, a normal but painful range of motion, and perithrochanteric calcifications on radiographs. A CT-scan confirmed a well-defined calcification of low density, 18 millimeters in diameter, in the gluteus medius tendon. Given a history of bilateral recurrent calcific tendinitis of the rotator cuff, an ultrasound-guided needle lavage was proposed, and corticosteroid injection was performed. The patient's symptoms resolved within a few days, and no follow-up imaging was performed.

In November 2014, the patient returned with similar complaints, but on the right side. An MRI showed a hypo-intense, sharply defined structure in the gluteus medius tendon, and a radiograph confirmed a calcification. An ultrasound-guided needle lavage of the calcification with corticosteroid injection was performed, resulting in a similar good clinical response.

The patient was discharged in stable condition with medications to manage pain and instructions for further management and follow-up with their primary care physician.

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged in a stable condition with resolved symptoms of acute pain in the hip.

Follow-up:

The patient was advised to follow-up with their primary care physician for further management and follow-up.

Discharge Summary:
This is a summary of a 52-year-old male patient with a history of a pancreatic pseudocyst who was admitted to the hospital due to coughing with sputum and dyspnea, which was later diagnosed as septic shock following bilateral pneumonia.

Hospital Course:
During the hospital stay, the patient's medical history revealed that he was previously admitted for a pancreatic pseudocyst, which had been treated with endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography. The patient was diagnosed with a pancreaticobronchial fistula based on multiple detector computed tomography (MDCT) findings and bronchial expectoration analysis. Conservative treatment with somatostatin was instaured, and the pancreatic duct was stented with a new 10Fr 5-cm stent. A follow-up CT scan showed improvement, and the patient was discharged on a stable condition.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with pancreaticobronchial fistula, which was identified by CT scan and bronchial expectoration analysis.

Treatment:
The patient was treated conservatively with somatostatin and a new pancreatic duct stent was placed using a 10Fr 5-cm stent. The patient's response to treatment was favorable.

Follow-Up:
A 1-week follow-up CT scan showed improvement, and the patient was discharged in stable condition with a recommendation to follow up with a specialist for further evaluation and monitoring of the pancreaticobronchial fistula.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for management of presumed pelvic infection, following a total vaginal hysterectomy with adnexal conservation. A CT of the abdomen and pelvis showed a 6.2 x 9.7 cm pelvic abscess adjacent to the vaginal cuff, which was drained by interventional radiology. She was started on IV piperacillin/tazobactam and was transitioned to oral amoxicillin/clavulanate potassium after four days of intravenous antibiotics. She was discharged home on hospital day 5 with a two-week course of amoxicillin/clavulanate potassium, pending the results of vaginal wound cultures.

Follow-Up:
The patient returned for her outpatient visit approximately one week later. The results of the vaginal wound cultures revealed a large growth of Actinomyces meyeri. An Infectious Disease (ID) specialist recommended an additional two-week course of amoxicillin/clavulanate potassium. The patient then returned to the ED on postoperative day 25 and 27 with worsening shortness of breath and chest pain, respectively. A repeat chest X-ray showed slight progression of right basilar heterogeneous opacities thought to be infectious. An intravenous antibiotic regimen was preferred, and the patient completed an outpatient two-week course of IV ampicillin/sulbactam as recommended. On postoperative day 37, a repeat CT of the abdomen and pelvis showed near complete resolution of the previous pelvic abscess. 

Discharge:
The patient reported significant improvement of her symptoms and was placed on a six-month course of oral amoxicillin per ID recommendations with plans for continued follow-up in their clinic, as well as with gynecology. She has not shown any signs of recurrent infection after approximately 1 year of follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 52-year-old male

Medical History: Chronic kidney disease, secondary hypertension, chronic hepatitis C virus infection, and arrhythmia

Clinical Presentation: Sudden vision loss in the left eye

Diagnosis: Occlusion of the superotemporal branch of the left retinal artery

Treatment: A single dose of 500 cc intravenous dextran-40 and 200 mg intravenous pentoxifylline

Etiologic Studies: Doppler ultrasonography revealed an atherosclerotic stenosis in the right and left main carotid arteries and a calcified plaque causing luminal narrowing in the left internal carotid artery. Transthoracic echocardiography revealed second- to third-degree aortic valve regurgitation and first-degree tricuspid valve regurgitation.

Follow-up: Peripapillary retinal nerve fiber layer thickness was within normal limits, but thinning was observed in the superior, inferior, and temporal areas. Decreased vascular density in the superficial and deep capillary plexus consistent with ischemia in the regions supplied by the superotemporal branch of the retinal artery was observed. Capillary density was reduced in the superotemporal region, and collateral vessels were present in the area. 

The patient was discharged after treatment. At follow-up, there was no improvement in visual acuity or visual field despite receiving a single dose of intravenous medication. Further diagnostic studies revealed stenosis in the main carotid arteries and aortic valve regurgitation. Follow-up imaging revealed thinning of the peripapillary retinal nerve fiber layer and decreased vascular density in areas supplied by the left retinal artery. Further measures may be needed to address these underlying conditions.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient is a 65-year-old female who presented to the tertiary eye centre with symptoms of painless right eye vision distortion that had been ongoing for six weeks. She reported no history of eye injury or trauma. On examination, the patient's VA was found to be 6/24 in the right eye and 6/5 in the left eye. Following slit-lamp biomicroscopy and fundoscopy, the patient was diagnosed with a right eye full-thickness macular hole, a left eye epiretinal membrane, and posterior vitreous detachment.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient underwent right eye pars plana vitrectomy, internal limiting membrane peeling and cryotherapy with C3F8 12% gas tamponade. The procedure was successful, and the patient's VA had improved to 6/18 with no complications. Unfortunately, seven weeks postoperatively, the patient developed right eye macula-on RD due to proliferative vitreoretinopathy (PVR) in the inferior retina. RD repair was performed, with a silicone oil (Densiron 68) tamponade and retinectomy to release the PVR. After four months, the patient's VA returned to 6/12 with a flat retina and closed macular hole. However, four months later, the patient's VA declined to 6/36 in the right eye. A fundus fluorescein angiogram confirmed severe CMO in the right eye, for which the patient underwent right eye posterior sub-Tenon’s triamcinolone injection and was started on ketorolac trometamol eye drops (Acular) three times a day and oral acetazolamide 250 mg slow-release twice a day.

TREATMENT INITIATED:
The patient received three posterior sub-Tenon’s triamcinolone injections and two intravitreal triamcinolone injections within 14 months, with no complications. Though the CMO initially responded to each triamcinolone injection, it later recurred. The patient then received four intravitreal dexamethasone 0.7-mg implants (Ozurdex; Allergan, Inc.) uneventfully. While the implants maintained a dry fovea for a longer period, the CMO recurred again. A trial of anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (Avastin) was not helpful.

DISCHARGE INFORMATION:
After two years without any successful treatments, the patient decided to receive ILUVIEN intravitreal implant. In the first week, the patient developed mild right eye anterior uveitis with an initial IOP of 27 mmHg in the right eye and 18 mmHg in the left eye, which was successfully managed with dexamethasone drops and latanoprost drops. At the time of this report, it is 20 months since receiving the ILUVIEN implant, and the patient still has a dry fovea with right eye VA at 6/18.

FOLLOW-UP CAREUPON DISCHARGE:
The patient has been advised to attend regular follow-up appointments with her ophthalmologist to monitor her right eye full-thickness macular hole, left eye epiretinal membrane, and posterior vitreous detachment. The patient has been informed about the risks and benefits of any further interventions and is aware that additional treatments may be necessary to manage her condition successfully. The patient has also been advised to report any concerning symptoms promptly. The recommended follow-up interval is three months.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
DOB: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to our clinic with pain and redness in his right eye. Visual acuity using Snellen chart was 20/20 and intraocular pressures were 14 and 15 mmHg in the right and left eyes, respectively. On slit-lamp biomicroscopic examination, minimally inflamed pinguecula was noted on the nasal conjunctiva of the right eye. No pathology was observed in the left eye except pinguecula. Fundus examination revealed no pathology in either eye. The patient reported no disease or drug use in his systemic medical history. Nepafenac eye drops were prescribed four times daily along with a one-week follow-up appointment.

The next day, the patient returned to the outpatient clinic due to redness and itching on his body. He reported a rash had formed on his trunk and arms, approximately 1-2 hours after instilling the nepafenac eye drops. The patient was diagnosed with allergic urticaria by the dermatologist and instructed to discontinue the nepafenac drops. Oral antihistamines were prescribed to treat the urticaria. Preservative-free lubricating drops were recommended as a substitute for the nepafenac drops and a follow-up appointment was scheduled.

At follow-up three days later, the patient's skin lesions and symptoms had completely regressed and his ocular complaints had also improved.

Diagnosis:
Allergic urticaria

Treatment:
Nepafenac eye drops were discontinued and preservative-free lubricating drops were recommended as a substitute. Oral antihistamines were prescribed to treat the urticaria.

Follow-up:
The patient's skin lesions and symptoms had completely regressed and his ocular complaints had also improved at the follow-up appointment.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 42-year-old male refugee, was admitted for bilateral corrective limbal relaxing incisions. Under general anesthesia, a crescent-shaped incision was made in the cornea to remove the thinned corneal stroma, and normal-thickness corneal tissue was reapposed using sutures. The patient experienced good initial response to treatment, with an improvement in uncorrected visual acuity (UCVA) and best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) in the right eye from counting fingers from 4 m to 5/10 and 2/10 to 7/10, respectively, and in the left eye from counting fingers from 2 m to 6/10 and 1/10 to 9/10, respectively.

However, at postoperative 5 months, the patient developed a single loose suture and a stromal infiltrate in the left eye, which were treated with topical fortified vancomycin, ceftazidime, and fluconazole drops. Despite initial good response to therapy, the infection recurred after discontinuing antifungal therapy, leading to the need for lensectomy and synechotomy without intraocular lens implantation. Antifungal therapy was continued during and after the procedures, and a sulcus intraocular lens was implanted in a second surgery. Corneal cross-linking therapy was performed to achieve corneal stability in the left eye.

At 23 months after the first operation, the patient had an improvement in BCVA in both eyes, with refraction of -1.00, +2.00 α 135 and 8/10 in the right eye, and +1.50, -4.00 α 65 and 9/10 in the left eye. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Summary:

The patient, a 42-year-old male refugee, was admitted for bilateral corrective limbal relaxing incisions, which led to an improvement in visual acuity in both eyes, but also complications including a stromal infiltrate. The patient required lensectomy, synechotomy, and sulcus intraocular lens implantation, as well as antifungal therapy, to manage the infiltrate and maintain visual acuity. The patient was discharged in stable condition with an improvement in visual acuity in both eyes.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE
The patient was admitted to our hospital due to a painful mass in the right parotid gland. Physical examination revealed ipsilateral facial nerve palsy. Imaging studies revealed irregularly shaped mass in the right parotid gland. The patient underwent total parotidectomy and reconstruction of the facial nerve. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of oncocytoma of the parotid gland. The patient recovered well after surgery without any complications.

MEDICAL HISTORY
The patient had a history of a right parotid mass for about 10 years which was not treated as it was painless.

HOSPITAL COURSE DETAILS
The patient underwent surgical removal of a total parotidectomy and reconstruction of the facial nerve. Histopathological examination revealed oncocytoma of the parotid gland. There were no intraoperative or postoperative complications. The patient had a slightly weakened nasalis muscle on the affected side; however, it completely recovered at 2 months after surgery. No recurrence was observed during the 18-month follow-up period.

DISCHARGE CONDITION
The patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions for follow-up with an otolaryngologist and periodic imaging studies.

FOLLOW-UP PLAN
The patient was advised to follow-up with an otolaryngologist and undergo periodic imaging studies to monitor the parotid gland. They were also instructed to report any unusual symptoms immediately. 

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS
No discharge medications were prescribed.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS
The patient was instructed to rest at home and avoid strenuous activities for a few days after discharge. They were also advised to follow a healthy diet and seek medical attention if any new symptoms occur.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES
1. Painful mass in the right parotid gland.
2. Ipsilateral facial nerve palsy.
3. Oncocytoma of the parotid gland.

Patient Details:
Patient name: Not specified
Medical record number: Not specified
Gender: Female
Age: 17
Date of admission: Not specified
Date of discharge: Not specified

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with difficulty in breathing, persistent fever, chest pain, dry cough, and general body malaise. On physical examination, the patient was febrile, pale, mildly jaundiced, tachypnoeic, and dyspnoeic with no lower limb edema. ACS was diagnosed, but pneumonia and septicemia could not be excluded.

Treatment:
The patient was placed on oxygen supplementation and started on IV cefoperazone/sulbactam 2 g·bd, IV normal saline (NS) 3 L/24 hours, and oral ibuprofen; hydroxyurea and folic acid were continued. Pain was managed by syrup morphine 5 mg 4 hourly. Two units of packed red cells were cross-matched and transfused. Oral co-trimoxazole was added to her therapy as a cover for possible atypical pneumonia.

Transfusion Reaction:
During the first RCE, the patient developed a febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction which was managed by IV paracetamol 1 g.

Exchange Transfusion:
RCE was performed in two steps 20 hours apart. In total, 950 ml were replaced, corresponding to an estimated 30% of the total blood volume. After the first step, the Hb was 98 g/L and HbS was 57.2%. After the second step, the Hb was 92 g/L and HbS was 48.9%.

Outcome:
The patient was afebrile, with oxygen saturation of 97-100% on room air, RR of 28-30/min and pulse rate of 90 bpm. The patient was weaned off oxygen and moved back to the general ward. The patient attended the outpatient hematology clinic, where she was found to be in good condition, with stable vital signs and a close to normal blood count. In her most recent follow-up (4 months after RCE), she is doing well and has no complaints. She is currently on folic acid 5 mg daily and hydroxyurea 500 mg daily.

Diagnosis:
Sickle cell disease (HbSS)
Acute Chest Syndrome (ACS) 
Febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction

Treatment:
IV cefoperazone/sulbactam 2 g·bd
IV normal saline (NS) 3 L/24 hours
Oral ibuprofen
Hydroxyurea and folic acid
Syrup morphine 5 mg 4 hourly
Co-trimoxazole as a cover for possible atypical pneumonia

Procedure:
RCE was performed in two steps 20 hours apart.
Transfusion of two units of packed red cells. 

Follow-Up:
The patient attended the outpatient hematology clinic and is currently on folic acid 5 mg daily and hydroxyurea 500 mg daily. The patient has no complaints and is doing well.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Admission Diagnosis:
Angiosarcoma of the scalp

Hospital Course:
The 91-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital with a large purplish mass on the skin of the frontal scalp that was identified as angiosarcoma by an incisional biopsy. She had been suffering from pruritic red patches on the scalp for approximately four months after suffering a burn to her forehead by a salon hair dryer. Following several clinical diagnoses, including eczema, cellulitis, and hematoma, and attempts at treatment with topical hydrocortisone, moisturizers, and antibiotics, she was referred to the hospital where she was diagnosed with angiosarcoma. Computerized tomography was ordered for evaluation in case of metastatic disease, which showed frontal scalp swelling with multiple enlarged lymph nodes concerning metastatic disease. 

Treatment:
The patient declined surgery or chemotherapy and agreed to consider radiation therapy to control the bleeding and be comfortable enough to wear a wig. Palliative radiation for symptom control was offered, and she received 4500 centigray (cGy) in 300 cGy daily fractions. She tolerated the treatment with no unanticipated side effects. After the intended course, the tumor was flattened, but residual bleeding persisted.

Discharge Instructions:
As the patient passed away a few weeks after receiving palliative radiation therapy, there are no discharge instructions for this case. 

Follow-Up:
N/A

Signed,
[Redacted]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 73 years
Final Diagnosis: Small invasive appendiceal adenocarcinoma

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to intermittent right-sided abdominal pain and a right-sided abdominal bulge. She had a history of atrial fibrillation and mitral valve prolapse. She visited the emergency department twice before, in 2013 and 2015, for the same symptoms but the evaluations were negative. Her colonoscopy in 2016 and CT scan of the abdomen were also normal. However, the symptoms recurred in 2017 and a CT scan revealed colon interposed between the liver and the abdominal wall along with some mild periappendiceal stranding. Because of the long duration of the symptoms and radiologic findings, it was decided that surgical intervention was necessary. The patient underwent an uneventful laparoscopic right colectomy. It was noted during initial laparoscopic exploration that the colon was no longer interposed above the liver. A very redundant proximal transverse colon was found which could easily be maneuvered into the configuration noted on her CT scan. She was discharged on postoperative day 3 with no complications and without any significant findings.

Brief Hospitalization Summary:
The patient had intermittent right-sided abdominal pain and a right-sided abdominal bulge which had been recurrent over the last 10 years. She visited the emergency department twice before, in 2013 and 2015, for the same symptoms but the evaluations were negative. A colonoscopy in 2016 and CT scan of the abdomen were also normal. However, in 2017, a CT scan revealed colon interposed between the liver and the abdominal wall along with some mild periappendiceal stranding. The patient underwent an uneventful laparoscopic right colectomy. She was discharged on postoperative day 3 with no complications and without any significant findings. The final pathology revealed a small invasive appendiceal adenocarcinoma arising in the background of goblet cell carcinoid with negative lymph nodes and negative margins staged as T3N0.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was instructed to follow up with her primary care physician for postoperative care. She was advised to avoid strenuous activity and heavy lifting for a few weeks. She was also advised to start walking daily and gradually increase her physical activity as tolerated, to help reduce the risk of complications. Pain medications were prescribed for any pain or discomfort.

Patient Status: DISCHARGED

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Summary
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnoses:
1. End-stage renal disease
2. Community-acquired pneumonia
3. Persistent cough
4. Epigastric pain
5. Abdominal distension

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with cloudy dialysate effluent and diffuse abdominal pain. The emergency department had diagnosed the patient with community-acquired pneumonia and prescribed moxifloxacin. Two days prior to admission, the patient had presented with epigastric pain and an intractable cough, yet was discharged with antitussives and analgesics. Upon admission to the inpatient ward, the patient was diagnosed with PD peritonitis and empirically treated with intraperitoneal cefuroxime and amikacin, with a subsequent switch to cefepime. Following an exploratory laparotomy, a 0.3cm rupture was found on the fundus of the gallbladder, which was closed primarily with external drainage. The PD catheter was removed uneventfully, and the patient was discharged after 37 days of hospitalization with maintenance hemodialysis three times a week.

Significant Findings:
During admission, the patient developed elevated WBC counts, and PD effluent culture was positive for Klebsiella pneumoniae. Additionally, the patient's gallbladder was distended, with modest wall thickening and distended bowel noted on enhanced CT imaging.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the inpatient ward and underwent empirical treatment for PD peritonitis with intraperitoneal cefuroxime and amikacin, followed by cefepime upon growing Klebsiella pneumoniae. A yeast-like organism was detected in the PD dialysate, leading to treatment with amphotericin and scheduling of a surgical intervention to remove the PD catheter. An exploratory laparotomy detected a 0.3cm rupture on the fundus of the gallbladder, which was closed primarily with external drainage. No perforation was identified in the intestine or stomach. Following the surgical intervention, the patient recovered without sequelae and was discharged after 37 days of hospitalization.

Discharge Medications:
None.

Follow-Up Recommendations:
The patient is recommended to receive maintenance hemodialysis three times a week and to follow up with his primary care physician. No additional recommendations were given.

Discharge Summary
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED] Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient, a 52-year-old Japanese man with alcoholic liver cirrhosis and a history of previous esophageal varices and hepatic encephalopathy, was admitted to our hospital due to accumulated ascites and abdominal pain. Laboratory data showed hypoalbuminemia, chronic kidney dysfunction, coagulopathy, and dyslipidemia, leading to a diagnosis of spur cell anemia (SCA). The patient was treated with ascites drainage, RBC transfusions, albumin, and FFP infusions, followed by two courses of plasmapheresis. His general condition gradually improved with the disappearance of pleural fluid and ascites, and he was subsequently discharged with Hb concentration >8.0 g/dL without RBC transfusions.

Hospital Course Summary:

History of Present Illness:
The patient reported a history of alcoholic liver cirrhosis, which led to previous esophageal varices and hepatic encephalopathy. He had a complaint of abdominal pain due to accumulated ascites, but had none of the neurological symptoms of neuroacanthocytosis. The patient had been drinking prior to his admission.

Physical Examination:
On admission, the patient was afebrile, icteric, and anemic. He had mild splenomegaly and was found to have pleural fluid, ascites associated with liver cirrhosis, and hypoalbuminemia. He was alert with a blood pressure of 126/66 mmHg, a heart rate of 108/min, a respiratory rate of 20/min, and SpO2 of 95% (room air).

Diagnostic Studies:
Laboratory data showed chronic kidney dysfunction, coagulopathy, and dyslipidemia, leading to a diagnosis of spur cell anemia (SCA). Assessments of serum lipid concentrations showed markedly reduced triglyceride, HDL cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, lipoprotein (a), phospholipid, apo-AI, and apo-AII concentrations. Assessments of coagulation factors showed that factor II, V, VII, and IX activities were all reduced, while factor VIII was not. ADAMTS13 activity was within the normal range.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with ascites drainage, RBC transfusions, albumin, and FFP infusions. Two courses of plasmapheresis were subsequently performed over a 3 week duration.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Spur cell anemia (SCA)

Discharge Condition:
The patient's general condition gradually improved with the disappearance of pleural fluid and ascites, and Hb concentration >8.0 g/dL without RBC transfusions.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to avoid further alcohol intake, follow a healthy diet, and attend regular follow-up appointments with his primary care provider.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 30 years
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Admission Diagnosis: Fever, myalgia, abdominal pain, elevated creatinine kinase, acute renal failure, and rhabdomyolysis.
Discharge Diagnosis: Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of fever, myalgia, and abdominal pain for 3 days. He was found to have significant abdominal tenderness, high-grade fever, and elevated creatinine kinase levels.
The patient underwent various tests to determine the cause of his symptoms, including chest X-ray and CT scans, urinalysis, influenza rapid antigen test, stool culture with ova and parasites, blood cultures, urinary toxicology, HIV, herpes simplex virus, hepatitis panel, Mycoplasma pneumoniae IgM antibody, QuantiFERON® test for tuberculosis, and TSH. All tests were negative except for low IgM antibody titers for Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
The patient was started on empiric levofloxacin and metronidazole treatment for possible gastroenteritis while awaiting test results. He was also given aggressive parenteral hydration to manage his acute renal failure and rhabdomyolysis. His symptoms of myalgia, abdominal pain, and diarrhea resolved by day 3, but he continued to spike fevers until day 4.
Upon retesting, the patient's IgM antibody titer for Mycoplasma pneumoniae had increased, confirming a recent infection. The patient's creatinine, liver function tests, and CK levels all returned to normal ranges after ongoing treatment with levofloxacin.
The patient was discharged on day 9 with planned outpatient follow-up.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was instructed to continue taking levofloxacin as prescribed and to follow up with his primary care physician for further evaluation and treatment of his Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection. He was advised to monitor his symptoms and report any new or persistent symptoms to his healthcare provider. The patient was also instructed to maintain good hydration and a healthy balanced diet to promote a swift recovery.
 
Follow-up Plan:
The patient was discharged with a recommended outpatient follow-up appointment with his primary care physician within one week of discharge. The follow-up appointment was arranged to continue monitoring his progress and ensure appropriate treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: XXXXXX
Age: 49 years old
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]
Diagnosis: Pigmented Villonodular Synovitis (PVNS)

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 49-year-old previously healthy female, was admitted with a 1-week history of posterior-region knee pain that occurred after falling directly onto her left knee from a standing position. Following the fall, she experienced blocked knee joint and limited range of motion of 30 to 60 degrees of flexion. On examination, the patient had good lower-limb alignment and no pain was provoked on meniscal and ligament testing. She also had an absence of muscular atrophy.

Upon examination, the patient's range of motion was limited to only 30 to 60 degrees of flexion with pain on active range of motion. She had pain upon active and passive extension of the knee joint with tingling and numbness over the calf region extending from the knee posteriorly. MRI revealed a multiloculated structure arising from the synovium around the cruciate ligaments within the femoral notch extending beyond the joint capsule posteriorly with moderate anterior joint effusion.

The patient underwent arthroscopic intervention in the left knee under spinal anesthesia. The posterior compartment of the knee was reached arthroscopically through the triangular space formed by the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) laterally, posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) medially, and the femoral notch superiorly. Total resection of the lesion was done through only anterior knee portals without taking the risk of posterior portals preventing potential neurovascular injury. The pathology report confirmed the presence of PVNS.

On 6-month MRI follow-up, the previously described soft tissue enhancement suggestive of residual inflammatory changes noted within the femoral notch along the cruciate ligaments as well as posterior to the distal metaphysis at the site of the previously present lesion has decreased. The synovial fluid had also decreased with no evidence of hemosiderin deposits. There was no evidence of interval appearance of new susceptibility artifacts or blooming effect on the T2 gradient sequence that could correspond to evident recurrence. The compressive effect previously present on the popliteal vessels has completely disappeared with no further tingling sensation and numbness over the calf region. Clinically, the patient regained full range of motion on flexion extension (0° to 135°) of the knee. The previously reported pain no longer exists, with no blocking upon flexion. The patient underwent physical therapy protocol and showed significant muscle strength and balancing improvement. She was scheduled to 1-year clinical follow-up.

Discharge Condition:
The patient's discharge condition is stable and satisfactory. The patient is to follow-up on 1-year clinical check-ups for further evaluation.

Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow the advised physical therapy protocol and take medications as prescribed. The patient is to follow-up for further evaluation at the scheduled 1-year clinical check-up.

Discharge Summary

This is the discharge summary for a 28-year-old male patient who was transferred to our facility due to multiple fractures and crush injuries sustained after a motor vehicle accident. The patient underwent several procedures, including ORIF for a butterfly fracture at the junction of the proximal and middle thirds of the left femur and a left olecranon fracture, partial fasciotomy for a right leg compartment syndrome, and treatment for a right calcaneal fracture, nondisplaced maxillary fracture, and a nondisplaced T12 vertebral body fracture.

The patient also suffered from acute kidney injury and underwent daily dialysis due to myoglobinuria caused by severe rhabdomyolysis. Upon admission, the patient had several skin lacerations and incisions from previous procedures. The patient also had an eye infection and a suspected tibial wound infection that was later confirmed to be caused by Acinetobacter baumannii.

Despite receiving antibiotic therapy, the patient's condition continued to worsen, and he underwent a below the knee amputation and a transhumeral amputation due to necrotic tissues. The patient also underwent an extensive debridement to excise necrotic tissues caused by diffuse pyomyositis in the left thigh and the left upper extremity.

After a diagnosis of advanced unresponsive necrotizing myositis with poor prognosis and low survival rate, the patient's family was notified of his condition. The patient passed away due to refractory septic shock caused by extensive necrotizing myositis and infected wounds by Acinetobacter baumannii, complicated by asystole that did not respond to full adult advanced cardiac medical and mechanical reanimation.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to our emergency department with complaints of neck and shoulder pain, along with fever. Diagnostic tests revealed destruction of the medial extremities of both clavicles, bilateral collections in the soft tissues around the sternoclavicular joints (SCJs) and high levels of erythrocyte sedimentation rate and CRP. CT scans and MRI confirmed the osteolysis of the sternal and clavicular margins of her SCJs, with a subchondral edema and soft tissue collections. Fine-needle aspiration and synovial biopsy were performed, which led to the detection of MRSA on blood and joint fluid culture. 

Treatment:
Intravenous antibiotherapy using teicoplanin and ciprofloxacin was initiated for 1 month, followed by orally administered antibiotherapy combining pristinamycin and ciprofloxacin for 2 months. The patient responded well to the treatment, and all symptoms were resolved after a period of 12 months.

Summary:
The patient, a 71-year-old Tunisian woman, was admitted to our hospital with severe pain in the neck and shoulders, and a fever that had persisted for 4 weeks. The CT scans and MRI detected the destruction of the medial extremities of her two clavicles and bilateral collections in the soft tissues around her SCJs. The fine-needle aspiration and synovial biopsy reports confirmed MRSA, and the patient was treated using a combination of teicoplanin and ciprofloxacin initially, followed by pristinamycin and ciprofloxacin to complete the treatment. The patient's condition improved substantially after 12 months of treatment with no clinical or biological signs of recurrence at the last follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Age: 6 years

Gender: Male

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Medical history: No pathological history reported

Principal Diagnosis:

- Bado type III Monteggia injury with ipsilateral fracture of the distal radius and ulna

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 6-year-old boy with no history of pathological conditions, was admitted to our hospital after suffering an accidental fall from a 3-meter climbing pole. He experienced pain and deformity in the right elbow and wrist joints and was diagnosed with Bado type III Monteggia injury with ipsilateral fracture of the distal radius and ulna.

The patient received manual reduction under nerve block on the day of injury, but due to the difficulty of maintaining the reduction of the radial head, open reduction and percutaneous procedures were performed under general anesthesia. Kirschner wires were inserted for open reduction and fixation of the fractured distal radius and ulna. A long-arm cast was used for external fixation with the elbow in 90° flexion and the forearm in an intermediate position.

After 2 weeks, callus formation at the fractured bone was observed, and therefore, the cast was removed, and range of motion exercises of the elbow and wrist joints were initiated. The Kirschner wires were removed at 6 weeks postsurgery, and pain, range of motion limitation, and lateral instability were not observed in the elbow or wrist joints at 3 months after surgery.

During the 3-year follow-up, radiographs showed a gradual correction in the outward displacement of the radial head. Twenty-one years after surgery, the patient returned to our hospital for another disorder, and radiographs of the previous Monteggia injury were taken. The biocompatibility of the radiocapitellar joint was good, and no malunion was found in the distal radius and ulna.

Follow-up Plan:

The patient reports no spontaneous pain, pain during exercise, tenderness, or range of motion asymmetry, and is currently working as a computer programmer and performs weight training as a hobby without limitations. No further follow-up is planned at this time.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A

Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with asymptomatic right hydroureteronephrosis detected on CT scan during lymphoma surveillance. Cystoscopy confirmed the inability to identify the right ureteral orifice, attributed to prior pelvic radiation. Antegrade and retrograde ureteroscopic procedures facilitated biopsies that showed rare foci of nephrogenic adenoma of the fibromyxoid type. Effective tumor debulking was achieved using a 1.9 French Zero Tip Nitinol basket. The patient elected for long-term management with interval ureteroscopic tumor debulking and ureteral stents. No complications were reported during the hospital stay.

Diagnoses:
  - Asymptomatic right hydroureteronephrosis
  - Nephrogenic adenoma of the fibromyxoid type

Treatment:
  - Antegrade and retrograde ureteroscopic biopsies
  - Tumor debulking with a 1.9 French Zero Tip Nitinol basket
  - Long-term management with interval ureteroscopic tumor debulking and ureteral stents

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to follow up with their healthcare provider for further management and monitoring of their condition.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: ***(redacted)***   MRN: ***(redacted)***

Date of Admission: (date)    Date of Discharge: (date)

Admitting Diagnosis: Intestinal malrotation

Principal Diagnosis at Discharge: Resolved intestinal malrotation with successful duodenoduodenostomy

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 14-day-old female, was admitted to our hospital for ongoing nasogastric bilious aspirates. She was born at 31 weeks of gestation in a poor general condition and required intubation with high frequency oscillatory ventilation, inotropic support, and surfactant administration. She had an antenatal diagnosis of left atrial isomerism, dextrocardia, and a right-sided stomach query situs inversus, which were confirmed postnatal.

During physical examination, no gross phenotypic anomalies were noted and abdominal exam was unremarkable. Plain abdominal X-ray showed normal gas patterns in consistent with situs inversus. An upper gastrointestinal contrast study was suggestive of intestinal malrotation. The patient underwent an emergent laparotomy via a left upper quadrant incision. Exploration of the abdomen revealed a right-sided stomach, adhesion bands between the cecum and duodenum, a broad base mesentery, and a PDPV crossing anteriorly at the level of the second part of the duodenum. Ladd's bands were divided, and a decision was made to perform a duodenoduodenostomy. A diamond-shaped anastomosis was done anterior to the aberrant vein using 6/0 polydioxanone interrupted sutures. 

Postoperatively, the patient had an uneventful course. Enteral feeds were started on the second postoperative day via NG and were gradually built up to full feeds in 2 weeks. The patient was feeding well, opening bowels regularly, without any episodes of vomiting and gaining weight adequately at 3 months and 1 year of age on clinic review.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient was discharged on (date) in good general condition and tolerating oral feeds well. The patient's parents were advised to continue enteral feeds as per the current regimen. They were also advised to monitor the patient's feeding tolerance, bowel movements, and weight gain in regular pediatric check-ups with the primary care physician. The parents were further instructed to seek immediate medical attention in case of any concerns. 

Follow-up appointments:

The patient was recommended to follow up with the pediatrician as per their usual schedule.

Signed,

**(Physician's Name)** MD

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 1-month-old baby girl who presented with recurrent nonbilious vomiting and inability to reach full enteral feeds. She was diagnosed with congenital heart block and complex cardiac structural anomalies, which were managed with a cardiac pacemaker insertion. An upper gastrointestinal contrast study suggested malrotation, which was subsequently confirmed by exploratory laparotomy. Malrotation was treated with the division of Ladd's bands and 50 mL of air injection via NG Tube. The patient recovered from Staphylococcus epidermidis line sepsis/suspected necrotizing enterocolitis with 10-day course of intravenous antibiotics. Feeds were gradually increased, and the patient was discharged home on full enteral feeds on postoperative day 21.

Diagnosis:
Congenital heart block, malrotation, staphylococcus epidermidis line sepsis/suspected necrotizing enterocolitis.

Treatment:
The patient underwent cardiac pacemaker insertion and exploratory laparotomy for malrotation treatment. Ladd's bands were divided, and air injection via NG Tube was administered. The patient was treated with a 10-day course of intravenous antibiotics for staphylococcus epidermidis line sepsis/suspected necrotizing enterocolitis.

Follow-up:
The patient had no clinical symptoms of intestinal obstruction at 17 months' follow-up. The patient is awaiting further cardiac surgery.

Discharge Summary:
Patient: 77-year-old Japanese male

Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]

Admitting Diagnosis: Liver Metastases from Gastric Cancer

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient's medical history revealed that he had undergone laparoscopic total gastrectomy with D1+ regional lymph node dissection 30 months prior for early gastric cancer. The patient underwent open splenectomy, after which histological examination confirmed the diagnosis of solid-type poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma originating from the previous gastric cancer.
The patient was treated with chemotherapy using S-1 plus oxaliplatin initially, but abdominal CT and magnetic resonance imaging revealed multiple liver metastases four months after splenectomy. Ramucirumab plus paclitaxel was administered as the second-line treatment. After two courses of systemic treatment, abdominal contrast-enhanced CT revealed progression of liver metastases. The patient's laboratory results, including serum carcinoembryonic antigen and cancer antigen 19-9, were within normal limits. The Glasgow prognostic score (GPS) and peripheral neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio (NLR) were normal, while slightly elevated C-reactive protein levels were observed.
As the third-line treatment, the patient was administered 3 mg/kg, I.V., nivolumab every two weeks. The response to the treatment was assessed using the Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST 1.1), which showed a marked shrinkage of liver metastases. After 12 cycles, abdominal CT revealed that all target lesions had disappeared, thus achieving complete clinical response.
The patient did not experience any adverse reactions during the course of the treatment. Currently, the patient continues to receive nivolumab treatment, and there is no evidence of disease recurrence for an 8-month period.

Discharge Diagnosis: Resolved Liver Metastases from Gastric Cancer

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Follow-Up Instructions:
The patient is advised to continue with regular follow-up appointments to monitor the status of the resolved liver metastases.

Discharge Condition: Stable.
