Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [MRN]
Age: 8
Sex: Female
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]

Admission Diagnosis: Absence of Mandibular First Permanent Molar
Final Diagnosis: PECR

Hospital Course:
The patient, an 8-year-old female, was admitted to the Lutheran University of Brazil for a dental consultation. The patient presented with chronology and sequence of eruption compatible with her age, but the left mandibular first permanent molar was absent. Clinical examination revealed no color, texture, or volume changes on the mucosa, and the patient did not experience any pain. A panoramic radiograph showed an alteration on the nonerupted first permanent molar, represented by a radiolucent dentin area at the occlusal surface. Based on both clinical and radiographic aspects, the lesion was diagnosed as PECR. 

The treatment was conducted in two parts. During the first phase of treatment, the crown was surgically exposed by removing the gingival mucosa that covered the unerupted tooth, allowing access to the occlusal surface of the tooth, which was sound. The second phase of treatment took place after 6 months, during which the first molar was partially erupted. Clinically, there were no structural or color changes on the crown. After local anesthesia, the site corresponding to the radiolucent area was reached, enamel and dentin that covered the lesion were removed using rotating instruments until the affected area was reached, where an “empty space” could be felt. Restoration was made with glass ionomer cement (Vitremer-3M/ ESPE). After a period of 6 months, the restoration was made with resin-based composite, and the glass ionomer cement was kept as a lining for the restoration.

The patient was discharged after 18 months of follow-up and showed no reports of pain symptomatology. The rhizogenesis also showed positive evolution.

Summary:
The 8-year-old female patient was admitted to the Lutheran University of Brazil for a dental consultation due to the absence of the mandibular first permanent molar. Clinical examination and radiographic imaging revealed PECR. The two-phase treatment involved surgically exposing the crown and restoring the tooth with glass ionomer cement and resin-based composite. After 18 months of follow-up, the patient showed no pain symptomatology, and the rhizogenesis showed positive evolution.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: (Redacted)
Age: 8 Years
Gender: Male
Date of Admission: (Redacted)
Date of Discharge: (Redacted)
Admitting Doctor: (Redacted)
Attending Doctor: (Redacted)

HOSPITAL COURSE:
An 8-year-old male patient was brought to the Department of Pediatric and Preventive Dentistry with the chief complaint of a boil on the upper right back region enlarging for 6 months. The patient's parents had disclosed that a similar lesion had occurred 6 months ago in the same region, which had been excised with a scalpel by a general dentist. The boil was a sessile lesion of 1.5 × 0.5 × 1 cm in dimension, which was a reddish hue, was fluctuant, and bled on slight examination. A complete medical and dental history of the parents and the child was taken. The intraoral periapical radiograph showed a radiolucency surrounding the developing premolar. The differential diagnosis for the lesion was pyogenic granuloma, PGCG, peripheral ossifying fibroma, inflammatory fibrous hyperplasia, and peripheral odontogenic fibroma. The patient underwent an excision with a soft tissue diode laser under local anesthesia. The excised lesion was analyzed under hematoxylin and eosin stain, which confirmed it as PGCG.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1. PGCG

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
N/A

DISCHARGE RECOMMENDATIONS:
The patient was followed up at 1, 3, 6, 12, 15, and 18 months. The premolar surrounded by the excised lesion is seen to erupt as per physiological process. The patient's parents were advised to follow dental hygiene protocols for oral health maintenance. 

FOLLOW-UP:
The patient was advised to follow up with his general dentist for any further dental problems.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]

DOB: [redacted]

Admission Date: [redacted]

Discharge Date: [redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Forwardly placed upper front teeth

Hospital Course:

An 11-year-old male child presented to the department of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics with a chief complaint of forwardly placed upper front teeth. The clinical examination revealed a convex facial profile due to mandibular retrusion and a mesoprosopic facial pattern. The intraoral examination revealed excessive overbite with incomplete, 8 mm interlabial gap and class II canine relation. The cephalometric analysis confirmed a marked class II dental relationship with mandibular retrusion, average growth pattern, normal axial inclination of upper incisors, proclined lower incisors, acute nasolabial angle, and mild rotation of the second premolars. The treatment objective was positive and suggested fixed appliance treatment to correct overjet with functional appliance and growth modulation deemed ineffective.

Treatment Summary:

The patient was treated with a fixed twin block appliance to correct the overjet and with the placement of fixed appliances to align the arches. The treatment plan involved two steps, with the correction of skeletal malocclusion as the primary objective and the correction of dental malocclusion as the secondary objective. 

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged in a stable condition without any complications. Follow-up appointments were scheduled to monitor the progress of the treatment and to assess the need for further intervention. 

Follow-up Recommendations:

The patient was advised to continue practicing good oral hygiene habits and to follow the orthodontist's instructions regarding diet and dental care. Regular follow-up appointments were recommended to ensure the continued success of the orthodontic treatment.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [confidential]
Medical Record Number: [confidential]
Date of Admission: [confidential]
Date of Discharge: [confidential]

HOSPITAL COURSE:
An 8-year-old male patient was admitted to the Pediatric Dental Clinic at the Federal University of Ceará with complaints of an unknown duration gingival enlargement in the anterior mandibular region associated with tooth pain. The patient was of normal height with no physical abnormalities observed. No history of trauma, infectious diseases, or nutritional disorders was noted. Intraoral examination revealed the presence of mandibular malformed and hypoplastic teeth, deciduous teeth (inferior central incisors) with localized gingival enlargement covered by a fibrous tissue, and teeth 83, 84, and 85 affected by caries.

IMAGING EXAMS:
Panoramic radiograph showed primary mandibular teeth, tooth 46 and dental germs with “ghost teeth” appearance due to a lack of clear definition of enamel and dentin in the presence of extensive pulp chamber demarcation. Agenesis of lower incisor teeth and images suggesting dental caries on teeth 84, 85, and 46 were also observed. Additionally, CBCT scan revealed a hypodense area suggestive of a periapical lesion associated with tooth 81, remarkable difference in the pulp chamber space when comparing deciduous teeth 84 and 74, and presence of ghost teeth associated with unerupted teeth 43 and 45. A semi-automated segmentation tool was used to provide pulp chamber volume, and it was observed that the volume of the RO-positive tooth pulp chamber was approximately 25% greater than the volume of the opposite unaffected tooth. Furthermore, the RO tooth was approximately 28% shorter than the corresponding contralateral tooth. Imaging exams also indicated an intense radiopacity pattern in the region of the trabecular bone surrounding adjacent RO teeth in comparison with the unaffected contralateral region. Fractal analysis of the mandibular trabecular pattern showed an altered bone microarchitecture in the mandibular region containing the RO teeth.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
Mandibular dental anomalies with associated severe gingival enlargement, dental caries, and presence of ghost teeth.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient discontinued treatment and was not present at the return visit for dental follow-up.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:
Stable at the time of discharge.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
None prescribed.

FOLLOW-UP:
Refer to the Pediatric Dental Clinic at the Federal University of Ceará for further treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Admitting Physician: [Redacted]
Attending Physician: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:

The 4-year-old female child was admitted to the clinic with a chief complaint of thumb sucking habit. The detailed history revealed that the child used to suck her thumb frequently while sleeping or feeling bored. The mother tried to stop the habit by applying a bitter neem oil substance, which did not yield any significant result.

The patient's extraoral examination showed good facial symmetry and convex profile. The intraoral examination revealed an anterior open bite, average-sized tongue, and proclination of maxillary anterior teeth with grade III mobility in the maxillary central incisors. Additionally, while swallowing, the tongue was placed between maxillary and mandibular anterior teeth (tongue thrusting habit). The intraoral periapical radiograph also revealed root resorption along the lateral and apical aspects of maxillary central incisors.

Based on the clinical and radiographic findings, the patient was diagnosed with ARR (Anterior Reversed Occlusion) accompanied by thumb sucking and a compensated tongue thrusting habit.

The treatment plan was formulated and explained to the patient's mother after obtaining her consent. Local anesthesia was administered before the extraction of maxillary central incisors. The extracted teeth were cleaned and preserved in saline, and the patient was scheduled for further treatment after a week.

During the second appointment, treatment of thumb sucking and tongue thrusting was initiated by counseling the parent and the child. The adverse effects of the habits on the developing dentition were discussed. A habit reminder therapy using a customized bluegrass appliance with natural tooth pontics was planned based on the parental esthetic concern. The appliance was designed both for parental esthetic concern and habit reminder therapy.

The patient showed good progress, and there were no significant complications during the hospital course.

Discharge Diagnosis:

1. Anterior Reversed Occlusion (ARR)
2. Thumb Sucking Habit
3. Compensated Tongue Thrusting Habit

Discharge Instruction:

1. It is crucial to continue following up the patient with frequent dental visits.
2. The positive reinforcement approach should be adopted to maintain a positive attitude towards the patient.
3. The patient should be encouraged to developing good oral hygiene habits, such as regularly brushing and flossing.
4. The parents should be reminded of the harm associated with thumb-sucking and tongue thrusting habits, and constant supervision should be provided to discourage these habits.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

IDENTIFYING INFORMATION:
Patient: Female, 6 years old (BA 3.5 years).
Admission date: [Date]
Discharge date: [Date]

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY:
The patient was admitted for rhGH treatment due to the growth failure. During the first 2 years of treatment, there was a significant increase in the growth velocity. The patient reached the 3rd centile in height at age 12.3 years, remaining prepubertal and with a 4.9 height-SDS increase after 6.5 years on treatment. 

TREATMENT:
The patient received rhGH for 6.5 years, which helped increase growth velocity and height.

LABORATORY DATA:
After 1 month of rhGH treatment, the patient's serum IGFBP-3 level normalized, and IGF-I level normalized after 6 months of therapy. Mild hypercholesterolemia was observed before the initiation of therapy, which did not change significantly during treatment.

ADHERENCE:
There was a period of non-adherence to treatment during the fourth year of therapy when GV, IGF-1, and IGFBP-3 levels decreased for 6 months.

FOLLOW-UP:
The patient needs ongoing monitoring for the growth progress and adherence to treatment. 

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient's parents were advised about adherence to medication regimen and the importance of regular follow-up visits.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Patient Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 28 years
Ethnicity: Swedish
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a pregnant 28-year-old Swedish female with no previous medical history, was diagnosed with a neck tumor during the summer of 2016. Further examination revealed a 30mm nodule in the neck, and after a second round of cytology, a diagnosis of papillary thyroid cancer was made. The patient underwent a total thyroidectomy with a lymph node dissection, which was uneventful without any postoperative complications.

Medical History:
The patient has no known medical conditions.

Diagnostic Findings:
Physical examination revealed a 30mm nodule on the neck. The second round of cytology confirmed the diagnosis of papillary thyroid cancer (Bethesda VI) based on the findings of follicular epithelium with nuclear atypia, nuclear inclusions and nuclear grooves. Immunohistochemical analyses showed that the tumor cells were positive for TTF1, CK19, and Bcl-2. The cells were negative for chromogranin A and calcitonin. A mutation was found in the BRAF gene at codon V600, but no mutations were found in the TP53 or TERT genes.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient underwent a total thyroidectomy with a lymph node dissection, which was uneventful without any postoperative complications. Postoperative radioiodine ablation was performed six weeks after childbirth, seven months post-operatively. Today, 16 months after surgery, the woman is well with no biochemical signs of disease.

Follow-up Recommendations:
The patient was referred for magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the neck and chest, which was negative for pulmonary involvement. Using ultrasonographic mapping, a fine needle biopsy was performed on a left-sided cervical lymph node in regio 2. The subsequent cytological examination, however, could not detect any malignant cells. No further follow-up is recommended at this time.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Irish woman
Gender: Female
Date of Admission: December 2015
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 65-year-old woman with a history of schizoaffective disorder and chronic renal failure, was admitted to the hospital with urinary tract infection, acute renal failure, and deranged international normalized ratio (INR).
During her stay, she was diagnosed with schizoaffective disorder with catatonia that was likely caused by her medical deterioration. The patient was treated by the psychiatry service with a trial of lorazepam, which was titrated to 3mg per day, and her mental state improved significantly over the following two weeks.
The patient remains admitted at the MMUH.

Hospital Course Overview:
-Admitted with urinary tract infection, acute renal failure, and deranged INR
-Diagnosed with schizoaffective disorder with catatonia that was likely caused by her medical deterioration
-Treated with lorazepam by the psychiatry service, with significant improvement in mental state over 2 weeks
-Remains admitted at the MMUH

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 75-year-old Irish woman with a history of bipolar affective disorder, stable on olanzapine and valproate, was admitted to a rural Irish hospital for a raised INR. During the admission, she developed sudden onset left-sided weakness and altered levels of consciousness, as well as rigidity and one isolated temperature spike. She was transferred to ICU for suspected neuroleptic malignant syndrome or encephalopathy, however, CT brain imaging was normal at the time. An electroencephalogram during admission showed changes suspicious of encephalopathy and MRI imaging showed no acute abnormality. A working diagnosis of metabolic encephalopathy was established but extensive investigations yielded no cause for the encephalopathy. The Liaison Psychiatry service was consulted in January 2016 due to prolonged altered mental state, cognitive dysfunction, and rigidity, felt to be most likely related to a catatonic exacerbation of her bipolar affective disorder, in the absence of an organic explanation.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted for management of a raised INR. During the admission, she developed sudden onset left-sided weakness and altered levels of consciousness, as well as rigidity and one isolated temperature spike. She was transferred to ICU for suspected neuroleptic malignant syndrome or encephalopathy, however, CT brain imaging was normal at the time. Extensive investigations did not yield any definitive cause for the prolonged altered mental state and cognitive dysfunction, but a working diagnosis of metabolic encephalopathy was established. The Liaison Psychiatry service was consulted in January 2016 due to catatonic exacerbation of her bipolar affective disorder, in the absence of an organic explanation.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Age: 68 years

Sex: Female

Chief Complaint: Acute laryngitis

Brief Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital on [Redacted] with complaints of acute laryngitis. Her medical history included bipolar affective disorder under monotherapy with lithium for the past 30 years that had been managed recently for a lithium toxicity secondary to deterioration of renal function. The patient was transferred to an acute medical ward from the ICU after her respiratory distress had stabilized. However, an acute onset confusional state with bizarre behavior was noted over a period of two days. After careful review and examination, she was diagnosed with bipolar I disorder with catatonia as per DSM-5.

During her admission, the patient was treated jointly by the ear, nose, and throat (ENT) team and the medical team. Once stabilized, she was seen by Liaison Psychiatry services who recommended treating her with paliperidone. Her mental state improved slightly as a result. However, she remained severely thought disordered and confused for two weeks. After this time, lithium was cautiously reintroduced under close monitoring of her renal function, which was well tolerated, and improved significantly over a two-week period.

The patient is no longer thought disordered, well orientated, and back to her fully independent baseline. She continues to live independently to date.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with bipolar I disorder with catatonia as per DSM-5.

Treatment:

The patient was treated with paliperidone. After not showing significant improvement, she was cautiously reintroduced to lithium under close monitoring of her renal function. The reintroduction of lithium was well tolerated, and she showed improvement.

Outcomes:

The patient has shown significant improvement in her mental state and is no longer thought disordered. She is well orientated and has returned to her independent baseline, continuing to live independently to date.

Follow-up:

The patient is advised to follow-up with her treating physician regularly to monitor her ongoing medical condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: Male, prematurely born at 29 weeks’ gestation with fetal hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and hydrops fetalis.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted after birth for neonatal appropriate care and treatment. An evaluation was done to assess hypertension, which was refractory to triple therapy administered. Extensive blood and urinary tests were conducted to evaluate atypical hypertension, which did not yield any significant results. However, calcifications in the renal arteries, abdominal aorta, and its major branches were detected using renal arterial Doppler ultrasound and low-dose whole-body computed tomography. Further investigation revealed that the patient has Generalized arterial calcification of infancy (GACI1) with a p.Ser262Gly mutation of the ENPP1 gene. The patient was given four courses of bisphosphonates by the intravenous route that showed significant improvement in the extent of arterial calcifications after two courses.
 

Follow-Up:
The patient showed transiently hypophosphatemia without any bone deformities, which was treated with oral phosphate supplementation. Regular follow-up visits performed on the patient showed hypertension treated with a triple combination of drugs. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy resolved with this treatment. The patient had normal growth and development without ocular or cutaneous manifestations of Pseudoxanthoma Elasticum (PXE).

Conclusion:
Based on the combination of cardiovascular findings and extensive calcifications on imaging, together with the ENPP1 mutation (c.784A>G; p.Ser262Gly), confirms the diagnosis of GACI1.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
DOB: [Redacted]
Age: 16-year-old
Sex: Female
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Pulmonary Embolism

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 16-year-old white girl, presented to our academic children's hospital with shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain on postoperative day six. She had undergone uncomplicated elective ACL reconstruction surgery with a bone-patellar tendon-bone autograft and lateral meniscus repair, and was discharged later that day. Upon admission, a CT-PE study confirmed the diagnosis of bilateral lower lobe emboli with moderate clot burden and an associated opacity in the left lung base. The patient was treated with Lovenox (enoxaparin) therapy and was discharged three days later. Follow-up echocardiogram and pulmonary function tests were performed at the 12-month mark, both of which were found to be within normal limits. The patient underwent a few investigational tests for the spontaneous or acquired thromboembolism; however, and further testing to identify causes of inherited thrombophilia was recommended to the patient to not change the treatment pathway irrespective of results. 

Recommendations:
The hematological team recommended that the patient should not use an estrogen-containing oral contraceptive pill, favoring a progesterone-only oral contraction or a progesterone-containing intrauterine device. The patient is ambulating independently and cleared for return to sports without any restrictions.

Follow-up:
Patient was recommended regular follow-up and periodic review by her treating physicians.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]

Age: 66-year-old

Gender: Female

Race: African-American

Initial Diagnosis: Cocaine-induced bilateral posterior inferior cerebellar artery and hippocampal infarction with multifocal punctate infarcts in bilateral posterior cerebral artery and basal ganglia secondary to severe vasoconstriction. Mild encephalopathy also observed.

Medical History: Polysubstance abuse (heroin, prescription opioids), bacterial endocarditis 30 years ago with remote epidural abscess, cervical cord compression from C3-C6 and myelopathy with residual bilateral upper extremity contractures and lower extremity weakness, hepatitis C, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Clinic Course: The patient was brought to ER due to confusion and short-term memory loss with significant receptive aphasia. She had no pain, fever, chest pain, palpitations, loss of consciousness, or seizure-like activity. She was a middle-aged lady who was alert oriented to name and place but not to time. Physical examination showed decreased bulk in bilateral upper extremities with moderate spasticity, tight contractures of the arms and forearms in flexed posture with some antigravity strength. Both posterior inferior cerebellar arteries were widely patent, and there was no evidence of obstructive hydrocephalus. CT of the brain showed heterogeneous low attenuation involving the entirety of bilateral cerebellar hemispheres with areas of petechial hemorrhage along with encephalomalacia in the right insular and anterior operculum. An MRI of the brain along with MR venogram showed infarcts in the bilateral occipital lobes, both hippocampi, and bilateral basal ganglia suspicious for an embolic phenomenon. Cerebral angiography was deferred given normal CT angiography. Blood cultures drawn on the day of admission showed no growth, and telemetric monitoring was unremarkable during the course of hospitalization. The patient was discharged to a skilled nursing facility after seven days with persisting memory problems and unable to recognize faces. 

Medications upon discharge: Unknown

Follow-up Care: Lost to follow-up.

Other Information: The patient had a past medical history of polysubstance abuse, including heroin and prescription opioids, which may have been responsible for the current condition. The clinical course showed significant receptive aphasia and decreased extremity strength, which were evaluated using the National Institutes of Health Stroke scale assessment. Despite suspicion for posterior circulation large vessel occlusion, CT angiogram of the head and neck ruled out any dissection, significant stenosis, or occlusion of intracranial or extracranial cerebral vasculature. The differential diagnosis included multifocal infarction secondary to cocaine-related vasospasm and posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES) and infective endocarditis with septic emboli. However, negative blood cultures, normal echocardiogram, and lack of fever and other constitutional symptoms ruled out the last possibility. The patient was diagnosed with cocaine-induced bilateral posterior inferior cerebellar artery and hippocampal infarction with multifocal punctate infarcts in the bilateral posterior cerebral artery and basal ganglia secondary to severe vasoconstriction. PRES was a consideration given the significant involvement of posterior circulation and mild encephalopathy, but vasogenic edema was not observed.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient is a 35-year-old Caucasian male with a three-month history of progressive lower back pain radiating to the left leg. Dorsal spine MRI revealed a mass involving the left ilium, sacrum, and left sacroiliac joint. Biopsy of the mass showed a small round blue cell malignant neoplasm. He was diagnosed with primary localized ES. The patient received neoadjuvant chemotherapy and adjuvant radiation therapy according to the VIVA regimen. He completed radiotherapy to the primary site and all planned treatment in January 2013. The patient was under close follow-up, and in May of 2014, he presented with multiple lung and two pleural lesions. Biopsy confirmed the lesions to be a relapse of ES with metastasis to lungs. The patient received five cycles of topotecan and cyclophosphamide. A follow-up CT of the chest in July 2014, before cycle 3, showed interval decrease in the metastatic lesions, consistent with chemosensitive disease. A PET/CT scan during August 2014, after five cycles of topotecan/cyclophosphamide, showed stable metastatic disease in the form of pulmonary nodules and pleural involvement. Autologous stem cells were collected during a single leukapheresis session before the first high-dose chemotherapy (HDCT). The patient received two rounds of planned consolidative high-dose chemotherapy. HDCT achieved 12 months of progression-free survival (PFS); however, on a subsequent PET scan performed during October 2015, the patient showed disease progression. The patient subsequently received six cycles of pembrolizumab and cyclophosphamide, vincristine, dactinomycin (alternating with ifosfamide), and etoposide, but the disease continued to progress. The patient chose hospice care in June 2016.

Hospital Course:
An 81-year-old male with stage IV metastatic prostate adenocarcinoma and worsening back pain presented for consideration of vertebral augmentation. CT scans revealed 40% compression deformity of T12 and MRI showed pathologic involvement of T12 and L1 and metastatic involvement of the epidural component, resulting in 40% spinal canal stenosis.

Treatment:
Vertebral augmentation was performed under monitored anesthesia care (MAC) and fluoroscopic guided imaging. Bilateral 10-gauge introducer needles were advanced into the T11, T12, and L1 vertebral levels using a bilateral transpedicular approach. Bilateral 17-gauge bipolar radiofrequency probes were then advanced into the vertebral cavities, and simultaneous application of radiofrequency energy was performed as part of the protocol for volumetric ablation of the vertebral bodies. This was done in serial at T11, T12, and L1 vertebral bodies for approximately 15 minutes for each level. Methylmethacrylate was injected into the vertebral bodies of T11, T12, and L1 for vertebral stability.

Outcome:
The patient did not experience any complications during the procedure and was discharged the same day. At the three-week follow-up, he reported no pain and was able to ambulate without assistance. At the eight-week follow-up, repeat MRI showed stable vertebral changes and complete resolution of epidural disease at the T12 and L1 level. The patient continued to be pain-free at the nine-month post-op follow-up and returned back to his normal activities.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]	
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course: 
The patient, a 32-year-old pre-menopausal woman, presented with a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) discovered on a routine pap smear. Subsequent cold knife cone biopsy revealed an infiltrating poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with lymphovascular invasion. Pelvic imaging studies demonstrated a non-enhancing cervical mass with left parametrial extension. The patient was diagnosed with FIGO IIB squamous cell carcinoma and was recommended to undergo concurrent chemoradiation, but was unable to receive chemotherapy due to an atypical mycobacteria pulmonary infection. External beam radiation therapy (EBRT) with IMRT was administered on a Tri-Cobalt-60 MRI-guided radiotherapy system (ViewRay MRIdian, Cleveland, Ohio, United States) involving the GTV, cervix, parametrium, uterus, upper vagina, and pelvic lymph nodes. After completion of EBRT, she underwent high-dose-rate (HDR) brachytherapy with four intracavitary implants. The patient experienced moderate fatigue toward the end of global chemoradiation treatment but did not develop adverse gastrointestinal, genitourinary, or integumentary toxicities. The patient also underwent daily setup MRIs for registration to assess organ motion. GTV motion was assessed via GTV displacements. GTV and organ volumes along with GTV and uterus displacements were determined in order to evaluate the relationship between GTV motion and bladder and rectal volumes. The patient tolerated brachytherapy well without acute side effects and was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Diagnosis:
FIGO IIB squamous cell carcinoma

Procedures:
- Cold knife cone biopsy 
- External beam radiation therapy (EBRT) with IMRT 
- High-dose-rate (HDR) brachytherapy with four intracavitary implants 

Hospital Course:
The patient was diagnosed with FIGO IIB squamous cell carcinoma after a routine pap smear revealed a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL). After a subsequent cold knife cone biopsy, the patient received external beam radiation therapy (EBRT) with IMRT followed by high-dose-rate (HDR) brachytherapy with four intracavitary implants. The patient underwent daily setup MRIs for registration to assess organ motion as well.

Additional Information:
- The patient tolerated the treatment well with moderate fatigue towards the end of the radiation therapy course. 
- Acute side effects were not observed during brachytherapy. 
- The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Patient: 35-year-old male of Fulani ethnicity admitted to the surgical ward with severe left submandibular abscess, on the background of untreated teeth infection.

Admission Date: [Date]

Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:

Admission: The patient had presented with severe left submandibular non-fluctuant swelling and was urgently transferred to the operating room (OR) for surgical drainage of the abscess. The patient was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) and started on broad-spectrum parenteral antibiotic therapy after confirmation of extensive leukocytosis.
 
Surgical Procedures: The patient underwent a left closed thoracostomy tube drainage (CTTD) for the significant abscess in both pleural spaces (empyema thoracis) four days after admission. He went to the OR two additional times for surgical debridement, drainage, and washout of neck wounds over the course of his stay in the hospital. 

Diagnostic Tests: Chest radiographs, ultrasound scans of the soft tissue neck and chest, and superficial ultrasonography were performed during the patient’s stay in the hospital for diagnosis. 

Medications: The patient was started on intravenously administered ceftriaxone and intravenously administered metronidazole on admission. Additional antibiotics such as ciprofloxacin were added later due to bacterial susceptibility of isolated growth of polymicrobial flora. 

Discharge Diagnosis: Extensive bilateral submandibular abscess collection and multiple cervical lymphadenopathy caused by untreated teeth infection.  

Follow-up plan:  The patient was discharged after three weeks of IV antibiotic therapy and underwent regular follow-up appointments with the dental surgery team for further treatment of his dental infection. 
 
Discharge Disposition: The patient's condition improved and he was discharged home. 

Summary: The patient was admitted with severe left submandibular non-fluctuant swelling due to neglected dental infection. He underwent surgical drainage of the abscess, was treated with broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics, and required multiple surgical interventions to manage the extensive abscesses localized in the submandibular and cervical regions, anterior superior mediastina space and both pleural spaces. He was discharged after three weeks with a follow-up plan for further treatment of the dental infection.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 32-year-old woman with right submandibular abscess and thoracic empyema.

Chief Complaint: Painful right submandibular swelling, right side of neck and upper anterior chest wall involvement, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, preceded by 1-week history of right second and third mandibular teeth infection.

History of Present Illness: The patient presented to our surgical ward with symptoms of painful right submandibular swelling with involvement of the right side of her neck and upper anterior chest wall. She reported a 1-week history of untreated right second and third mandibular teeth infection. She was also newly diagnosed with retroviral infection but had not started treatment. Ultrasound scan revealed right submandibular turbid collection with inflamed muscles, and chest radiograph revealed blunting of the right costophrenic angle. Thoracocentesis showed marked leukocytosis of 57,000 cells/ul, predominantly Gram-positive cocci.

Hospital Course: The patient underwent surgical drainage of the right submandibular abscess and right closed thoracostomy tube drainage connected to pleurovac and suction. She was admitted to the ICU while sedated, ventilated on oxygen by facemask, and hemodynamically stable. Broad-spectrum parenteral antibiotic therapy was initiated with intravenously administered ceftriaxone and metronidazole. The patient underwent extensive washout of abscess spaces of the submandibular region and neck. The culture of the submandibular abscess isolated viridans streptococci after 72 hours, and the bacteria of the isolated growth were susceptible to Augmentin and doxycycline. The patient showed significant relief of symptoms.

Outcome: On the fifth day of admission, the patient developed sudden onset of cardiac arrest from which she could not be resuscitated and was certified dead approximately 1 hour later. 

Summary: The patient initially presented with symptoms of right submandibular abscess and thoracic empyema, requiring urgent surgical intervention and antibiotic therapy. Despite showing significant relief of symptoms, the patient developed sudden cardiac arrest and was unable to be resuscitated.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 34
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course and Treatment:
The patient [REDACTED] was admitted to Felege Hiwot Referral Hospital with severe and persistent headache of a day’s duration which was occipital in location associated with blurred vision and generalized body swelling of 1 week’s duration. She was diagnosed with late second trimester pregnancy and preeclampsia with severity feature plus semilobar HPE. Her hypertension was managed with intravenously administered hydralazine 5 mg two doses at the emergency department. Seizure prophylaxis for preeclampsia was given and methyldopa 500 mg orally every 8 hours was added. The high incidence of associated anomalies, severe morbidities of survivors, and poor prognosis were discussed. Termination of pregnancy was decided and done with misoprostol 100 microgram every 3 hours at the third dose with outcome of 1.1 kg male, alive neonate. Following basic neonatal care, the neonate was transferred to our neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) but he died 20 minutes after admission to NICU. The patient's blood pressure was controlled and monitored. Postpartum visits were arranged and preconception care and prenatal screening in subsequent pregnancies were recommended.

Diagnosis:
Late second trimester pregnancy and preeclampsia with severity feature plus semilobar HPE.

Treatment:
Seizure prophylaxis for preeclampsia and methyldopa 500 mg orally every 8 hours were prescribed.

Follow-up:
Postpartum visits and preconception care and prenatal screening in subsequent pregnancies were recommended.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]           
Admission Date: [redacted]          
Discharge Date: [redacted]         

Reason for Hospitalization:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to a headache and pre-existing visual disturbance.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient was alert and afebrile. The neurological examination revealed only the worsening of pre-existing visual disturbance. The blood analysis revealed a slight elevation in CRP levels, and the interferon-γ release assay (T-SPOT) was positive. The chest X-ray revealed no abnormal lesions. In addition, the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) testing revealed elevated protein levels, no pleocytosis, and normal glucose levels, with a standard opening pressure. The patient's history comprised tuberculous meningitis treated with anti-TB drugs with adjunctive corticosteroid 10 years ago. 

During the course of treatment, a head CT revealed new emerging tuberculomas in the left sylvian fissure. While a contrast-enhanced axial T1-weighted brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan revealed tuberculomas with a diffuse hypointense area around the left sylvian fissure, brain fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) imaging indicated a hyperintense area around the tuberculomas in the left sylvian fissure, suggesting edematous changes. Repeated mycobacterial culture and real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) in the CSF did not indicate the existence of the reactivation of CNS tuberculosis.

After the administration of corticosteroids (prednisolone, 30 mg/day), it helped in the disappearance of the tuberculomas, including those previously present in the bilateral ambient cistern. The patient's symptoms remained stable during 1 year of follow-up without additional anti-TB drugs.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with late-onset post-treatment tuberculomas with edematous changes.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged with the condition stable.

Follow-Up Plans:
The patient is advised to visit a neurosurgical clinic regularly to check the patency of the VP shunt.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 62 years
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for the treatment of bullous hemorrhagic dermatosis. He had a history of morbid obesity, coronary artery disease, lipodermatosclerosis of the lower extremities, chronic peripheral venous insufficiency, and prostate cancer (Gleason 4+5) on long-term androgen deprivation therapy. The patient had a small renal tumor for which he was followed with imaging. He had a distant history of varicose vein ligation. The patient was started on enoxaparin 120 mg by subcutaneous injection twice daily after an incidental pulmonary embolism was discovered during surveillance imaging for his prostate cancer. Within several days of starting the anticoagulation therapy, the patient developed small black blisters on his hands that resolved spontaneously. The patient, however, did not report or observe these blisters during clinic visits. Four months after starting enoxaparin therapy, the patient presented with several large hemorrhagic bullae on his calves. His coagulation values and platelet count were within normal range. The diagnosis of bullous hemorrhagic dermatosis (BHD) was made by visual inspection. Enoxaparin was discontinued and apixaban was started as an alternative anticoagulation therapy. The lesions healed in 3 weeks with intensive outpatient wound care and have not recurred to date while on apixaban.

Conditions at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition with a plan for follow-up appointments with his primary care physician and outpatient care team.

Instructions:
The patient was advised to continue the alternative anticoagulation therapy (apixaban) as prescribed and to not restart enoxaparin or any other anticoagulation therapy without consulting his healthcare provider. He was also advised to keep the wound areas clean and dry and to avoid direct sun exposure. The patient was instructed to seek medical attention immediately if any new lesions appear or if he experiences any adverse reactions to his prescribed medications. The patient was advised to follow a healthy diet and exercise plan and to manage his comorbidities as per his healthcare provider's instructions.

Follow-up:
The patient will follow up with his primary care physician within 2 weeks of discharge and will have a telehealth follow-up visit with his outpatient care team in 4 weeks. Further follow-up appointments will be as per his healthcare provider's recommendations.

Signed,
[Attending Physician's Name] MD

Medical History:
The patient is a 7-year-old boy who presented with elevated blood lead levels (BLL) confirmed by Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (AAS). Two months prior to admission, the patient experienced dizziness, headaches, poor appetite, mouth bitterness, repeated vomiting, and intermittent abdominal pain. Joint pain and fatigue occurred subsequently, causing him to be unable to walk by himself. He was previously hospitalized twice for elevated serum liver enzymes and anemia; however, no etiology was identified. The patient was found to have “lead line” pigmentation on gums, and radiographic findings showed increased linear radio-density at the distal femoral and proximal tibial and fibular metaphyses.

Treatment:
The patient had been using a red-colored folk medicine obtained from a Traditional Chinese Medicine practitioner, which was found to have a high lead concentration. The patient received chelation therapy consisting of orally administered dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA), intravenous calcium disodium edetate (CaNa2EDTA), and glutathione. Chelation therapy was completed successfully and resulted in the resolution of all the patient’s symptoms.

Outcome:
The patient’s BLL declined to 21 μg/dL after chelation therapy was completed. The patient was discharged after a full recovery of symptoms.

Follow-up:
The patient will receive follow-up care to monitor his BLL levels and ensure the absence of lead-related health complications.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 8
Sex: Female
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Reason for admission: Severe abdominal colic, vomiting, constipation, and fatigue

Hospital Course
The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain, vomiting, and constipation. Laboratory tests indicated a venous blood lead level (BLL) of 91 μg/dL. Radiography of the abdomen revealed shadow of stool and gas with points of increased density. The patient's symptoms were attributed to the use of a nasal spray liquid containing 223,000 mg/kg (22.3%) lead prescribed by a traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) practitioner for rhinitis. The patient received a cathartic to eliminate lead from the intestine prior to initiating chelation therapy with CaNa2EDTA. Despite the initial response, vaccination against DMSA was withheld due to a decrease in white blood cells.

Course of Treatment
The patient was treated with CaNa2EDTA chelation to achieve a BLL of 36 μg/dL at the end of 5 days. Folium sennae was administered as a cathartic to eliminate lead from the intestine prior to initiating chelation. DMSA, which may have caused the reduction in white blood cells, was withheld subsequently. The patient was monitored for a total of 10 days, following which she was discharged.

Follow-up Care
The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care provider for further evaluation and monitoring of her BLL. Additionally, she was advised to avoid TCM practices that may contain high levels of heavy metals.

Summary
The 8-year-old female patient with a history of rhinitis developed severe digestive symptoms due to the use of a nasal spray containing high levels of lead prescribed by a TCM practitioner. She was treated with CaNa2EDTA chelation therapy to decrease the BLL. The discharge diagnosis was poisoning due to lead exposure, and the patient was advised to follow up with her primary care provider for further evaluation and monitoring.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
The 5-year-old male patient was admitted to our hospital due to severe abdominal pain and vomiting. He had consulted a Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) practitioner and was prescribed medication to be taken twice a day for seven days.

Hospital Course:
The patient's initial laboratory results showed elevated liver enzyme levels, and his liver was palpable 4 cm below the right costal margin. An abdominal x-ray did not show any abnormalities. Upon admission, his blood lead level (BLL) was 105 μg/dL. The nasal spray that the patient had been using was found to contain 33.4% lead.

Chelation therapy was initially withheld due to concerns of potential hepatotoxicity with the two drugs prescribed. Instead, the patient was given treatment to improve liver function and continued this treatment throughout the hospital course. His liver function tests and BLL improved over time, reaching 34 μg/dL after chelation with DMSA and CaNa2EDTA infusion.

Outcome and Follow-Up:
No adverse events occurred during the course of the patient's treatment, and the patient was discharged in stable condition. Follow-up appointments were scheduled for monitoring of lead levels and liver function. 

Impression:
This patient presented with symptoms of lead poisoning after using a nasal spray containing lead. Chelation therapy was initiated once liver function improved, resulting in a significant decrease in BLL. The patient responded well to treatment and was discharged in good condition.

Patient Summary: A 53-year-old woman with locally advanced rectal cancer underwent Laparoscopic intersphincteric resection (ISR) combined with intraoperative radiation therapy (IORT) and prophylactic ileostomy on December 5, 2015. She presented with symptoms of bloody stool, repeated constipation, defecation habits change, and weight loss for about a year. The pathology report confirmed adenocarcinoma with lymph node metastasis.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent thorough diagnostic testing, which included pelvic MRI, chest X-ray, abdominal CT scan, and hepatobiliary ultrasound. Anorectal manometry was used to determine preoperative anal function. The carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) level was 1 ng/ml, while CA19-9 level was 10.5 U/ml. The patient had no family history and no other systemic diseases. 

Discharge Summary:
After undergoing surgery, the patient remained in the hospital to recover and receive follow-up treatment. During her stay, she received proper postoperative care, including pain management, nutrition, and mobility assistance. She was monitored for any complications and underwent various diagnostic tests to evaluate her condition. After completing the recommended hospital stay, the patient was discharged home with instructions for further care and follow-up appointments.

Recommendations:
The patient was advised to maintain lifelong colon cancer surveillance, following screening guidelines for colonoscopy. She was also advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and avoid any habits that increase the risk of cancer recurrence, such as smoking. The patient was advised on the importance of following up with her prescribed medication and to attend all scheduled follow-up appointments. The patient was provided with all necessary documentation and instructions for continuing her care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 54 years
Sex: Female
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

[REDACTED] was admitted to our department with a ten-year history of progressive pain, cold sensitivity, and severe tenderness to palpation of the pulp of her left little finger. She was evaluated for this pain by her primary care doctor, but no definitive diagnosis was made. A clinical examination showed a painful subcutaneous nodule on the pulp of the distal phalanx of her left little finger, with no gross abnormalities of her fingers and no paresthesia or hypoesthesia in the area of the tumor. 

An X-ray study demonstrated no bony lesions, and MRI was not pursued as the diagnosis of glomus tumor was suspected. Surgical intervention was performed, and pathology confirmed the diagnosis of a glomus tumor. The mass was well circumscribed and removed completely with blunt dissection. The patient healed without complication, with complete healing of the pain within one year.

At discharge, the patient reported no signs of recurrence.

Diagnosis:

Glomus tumor

Condition at Discharge:

Improved

Instructions:

The patient is advised to follow up with their primary care doctor for any further concerns.

Discharge Summary:

Identification:

Patient: 54-year-old postmenopausal woman from Casablanca (Morocco)
Admission date: May 2011
Discharge date: Not Applicable

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our outpatient institution to undergo laboratory testing as part of a routine checkup. The primary complaint was episodic abdominal discomfort. Upon initial testing, the patient's cell count was normal, with a hemoglobin of 14 gm/dl, a total leukocyte count of 8,200/mm and a platelet count of 3,44,000/mm. However, serum lipase, and amylase levels were found to be elevated. Further tests were conducted to diagnose the cause of the increased levels of these enzymes.

Serological tests for hepatitis A, B, and C viruses, and Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) were conducted, but they all came out negative. The tumor markers were also normal. Tests for autoimmune diseases were conducted, but there was no significant deviation from normal ranges. Abdominal ultrasonography and magnetic resonance imaging scans showed normal pancreas, liver, and biliary tree.

Over the next five years, the patient was continuously monitored, during which there were no symptoms of the disease, though serum lipase and amylase values fluctuated widely. Although lipase concentration never exceeded 2,000 U/L, the lipase median values were 831.5 U/L while the amylase median value was 205.5 U/L. 

Diagnosis:

Gullo's Syndrome

Condition on Discharge:

Asymptomatic 

Follow-up:

The patient is required to remain under follow-up observations with blood and imaging tests to assess the progress of the disease.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Insert Date]
Discharge Date: [Insert Date]

Patient Name: [Insert Name]
Medical Record Number: [Insert Number]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with a distal radius fracture accompanied by a dorsal displacement of the distal bone fragment. She was initially diagnosed with a fracture at a local hospital and underwent splinting before being referred to our hospital. A blister was observed on the right forearm along the splint application area and considered to be due to the heat and stuffiness of the splint. Plain X-ray examination confirmed the fracture and surgery was planned.

Treatment:
A minimally invasive locking plate osteosynthesis was performed using the Henry approach through a small incision. The surgery reduced the distal bone fragment and stabilized it using a volar locking plate. The wrist was immobilized postoperatively in a bulky dressing without an arm splint until the tissue swelling had decreased. The patient was encouraged to perform active finger motion and wrist mobilization as soon as it was pain-free.

Outcome:
After six months, favorable union of the radius was obtained, and the range of motion in the wrist was recorded as follows: flexion, 70°; extension, 65°; pronation, 85°; and supination, 85°. The patient's pain score on the visual analogue scale (VAS) was 1/10, and the quick disabilities of the arm, shoulder, and hand (Q-DASH) score was 20.45/100. The Mayo wrist score was 85/100, indicating an excellent recovery. The state of the forearm skin and surgical wound favorably improved, and the patient returned to her preinjury job.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to continue performing gentle exercises to maintain the range of motion achieved. Excessive force or movement was discouraged during the healing process. She was discharged with instructions to follow up with her primary care physician and orthopedist as needed.
